PREFACE 
This Code constitutes a recodification of the general and permanent ordinances of the Village of Skokie, Illinois. 
Source materials used in the preparation of the Code were the 1979 Code, as supplemented through 1999, and ordinances subsequently adopted by the Mayor and Board of Trustees. The source of each section is included in the history note appearing in parentheses at the end thereof. By use of the comparative tables appearing in the back of this Code, the reader can locate any section of the 1979 Code, as supplemented, and any subsequent ordinance included herein. 
The chapters of the Code have been conveniently arranged in alphabetical order, and the various sections within each chapter have been catchlined to facilitate usage. Notes which tie related sections of the Code together and which refer to relevant State law have been included. A table listing the State law citations and setting forth their location within the Code is included at the back of this Code. 
Chapter and Section Numbering System 
The chapter and section numbering system used in this Code is the same system used in many state and local government codes. Each section number consists of two parts separated by a dash. The figure before the dash refers to the chapter number, and the figure after the dash refers to the position of the section within the chapter. Thus, the second section of Chapter 1 is numbered 1-2, and the first section of Chapter 6 is 6-1. Under this system, each section is identified with its chapter, and at the same time new sections can be inserted in their proper place by using the decimal system for amendments. For example, if new material consisting of one section that would logically come between Sections 6-1 and 6-2 is desired to be added, such new section would be numbered 6-1.5. New articles and new divisions may be included in the same way or, in the case of articles, may be placed at the end of the chapter embracing the subject, and, in the case of divisions, may be placed at the end of the article embracing the subject. The next successive number shall be assigned to the new article or division. New chapters may be included by using one of the reserved chapter numbers. Care should be taken that the alphabetical arrangement of chapters is maintained when including new chapters. 
Page Numbering System 
The page numbering system used in this Code is a prefix system. The letters to the left of the colon are an abbreviation which represents a certain portion of the volume. The number to the right of the colon represents the number of the page in that portion. In the case of a chapter of the Code, the number to the left of the colon indicates the number of the chapter. The following are typical parts of codes of ordinances, which may or may not appear in this Code at this time, and their corresponding prefixes: 
CODE 	CD1:1 
CODE COMPARATIVE TABLES 	CCT:1 
STATE LAW REFERENCE TABLE 	SLT:1 
CODE INDEX 	CDi:1 
 
Index 
The index has been prepared with the greatest of care. Each particular item has been placed under several headings, some of which are couched in lay phraseology, others in legal terminology, and still others in language generally used by local government officials and employees. There are numerous cross references within the index itself which stand as guideposts to direct the user to the particular item in which the user is interested. 
Looseleaf Supplements 
A special feature of this publication is the looseleaf system of binding and supplemental servicing of the publication. With this system, the publication will be kept up-to-date. Subsequent amendatory legislation will be properly edited, and the affected page or pages will be reprinted. These new pages will be distributed to holders of copies of the publication, with instructions for the manner of inserting the new pages and deleting the obsolete pages. 
Keeping this publication up-to-date at all times will depend largely upon the holder of the publication. As revised pages are received, it will then become the responsibility of the holder to have the amendments inserted according to the attached instructions. It is strongly recommended by the publisher that all such amendments be inserted immediately upon receipt to avoid misplacing them and, in addition, that all deleted pages be saved and filed for historical reference purposes. 
Acknowledgments 
This publication was under the direct supervision of Bill Carroll, Senior Code Attorney, and Connie Timmons, Editor, of the Municipal Code Corporation, Tallahassee, Florida. Credit is gratefully given to the other members of the publisher's staff for their sincere interest and able assistance throughout the project. 
The publisher is most grateful to Barbara Meyer, Corporation Counsel, Mark Vanderpool, Assistant Village Manager, Keith Glatz, Purchasing Agent, and Marlene Williams, Village Clerk, for their cooperation and assistance during the progress of the work on this publication. It is hoped that their efforts and those of the publisher have resulted in a Code of Ordinances which will make the active law of the Village readily accessible to all citizens and which will be a valuable tool in the day-to-day administration of the Village's affairs.

Editorial enhancements include, but are not limited to: organization; table of contents; section catchlines; prechapter section analyses; editor's notes; cross references; state law references; numbering system; code comparative table; state law reference table; and index. ADOPTING ORDINANCE 
ORDINANCE NO. 02-4-C-3077 
An Ordinance Revising, Amending, Enacting, Codifying and Consolidating the General Ordinances of the Village of Skokie, Illinois, Providing for the Repeal of Ordinances Not Included Therein, With Certain Exceptions, and for Other Purposes 
WHEREAS, the Village of Skokie is an Illinois home rule municipality pursuant to Article VII, Section 6, of the Illinois Constitution 1970; and 
WHEREAS, on June 11, 1979 the Mayor and Board of Trustees of the Village of Skokie adopted the recodification of the Code of Ordinances for the Village of Skokie (Skokie Village Code, 1979); and 
WHEREAS, the Corporation Counsel and Village Manger recommended to the Mayor and Board of Trustees, at a public meeting duly held, that the Village Code be updated and that the Mayor and Board of Trustees adopt the recodification of the Code of Ordinances; and 
WHEREAS, the Mayor and Board of Trustees concurred in the aforesaid recommendation; 
NOW, THEREFORE, BE IT ORDAINED by the Mayor and Board of Trustees of the Village of Skokie, Cook County, Illinois: 
Section 1: For the purposes of revising, amending, enacting, codifying and consolidating the general ordinances and laws of the Village of Skokie, Illinois, and pursuant to the home rule powers granted to the Village of Skokie under the Constitution and Laws of the State of Illinois, the following chapters, to wit, Chapters 1 through 118, inclusive, attached hereto and incorporated by reference as if set forth verbatim herein, are hereby adopted and passed as and for the general ordinances of the Village of Skokie, Illinois, and shall constitute and be known as the "Skokie Village Code, 2002" 
Section 2: The provisions of the Skokie Village Code, 2002, shall take effect and be in force upon the passage, approval, and publication in pamphlet form by the Village Clerk as required by law. 
Section 3: The provisions appearing in the Skokie Village Code, 2002, insofar as they are substantially the same as those of the Skokie Village Code, 1979, regardless of their location and numbering, and those of all other ordinances existing at the time of the adoption of said Skokie Village Code, 2002, shall be construed as a continuation thereof and not as new enactments. Provisions of the Skokie Village Code, 1979, as amended through and including April 15, 2002, not set forth in the same or substantially the same form in the Skokie Village Code, 2002, except as hereafter provided, shall be deemed repealed by this Ordinance. Any ordinance amending the Skokie Village Code, 2002, adopted on or after April 16, 2002, shall be deemed to amend the Skokie Village Code, 2002. Where an ordinance adopted on or after April 16, 2002, amended any portion of the Skokie Village Code, 1979, which was renumbered or relocated so as to be retained and included as a successor provision of the Skokie Village Code, 2002, said ordinance shall be deemed to have amended the successor provision of the Skokie Village Code, 2002, wherever located. 
Section 4: The repeal provided for in Section 3 of this Ordinance shall not be deemed to repeal any ordinance not amending or having been codified into the Skokie Village Code, 2002. 
Section 5: The repeal provided for in Section 3 of this Ordinance shall not be deemed to repeal the Zoning Regulations as contained in the Skokie Village Code, 1979, Chapter 21, as has been amended from time to time. 
Section 6: The repeal provided for in Section 3 of this Ordinance shall not be deemed to affect any offense or act committed or done or any penalty, forfeiture or punishment incurred or any claim, contract or right established or accruing before the effective date of this Ordinance; nor shall said repeal affect any ordinance or resolution promising or guaranteeing the payment of money for the Village or authorizing the issuance of any bonds of the Village or any evidence of the Village's indebtedness, or any contract or obligation assumed by the Village; nor shall said repeal affect the administrative ordinances and resolutions of the Village not in conflict or inconsistent with the Skokie Village Code, 2002; nor shall said repeal affect any annual appropriation ordinance of the Village, any ordinance or resolution concerning, levying or imposing any tax or imposing any fee other than that set forth specifically in the Skokie Village Code, 2002; nor shall said repeal affect any ordinance or resolution relating to wages, salaries and bonds of any Village officer or employee; nor shall said repeal affect any right or franchise conferred by ordinance or resolution of the Village on any person or entity; nor shall said repeal affect any ordinance or resolution concerning or relating to the annexation or to extending or reducing the boundaries of the Village; nor shall said repeal affect any ordinance or resolution establishing the grades of streets and avenues and the several railroad tracks in the Village; nor shall said repeal affect any ordinance or resolution establishing, naming or vacating any street, alley or other place or assuming jurisdiction over same; nor shall said repeal affect any ordinance or resolution relating to or granting powers to other governmental entities or relating in any way to the construction, operation and maintenance of the Village's water supply or sewer system, or any other municipal utility; nor shall said repeal affect any ordinance or resolution concerning the transfer of prisoners to places of accommodation, elections, zoning ordinances or variations or special uses granted pursuant thereto, the transfer, acceptance, lease, sale or purchase of any real or personal property, or any ordinance or resolution concerning special assessments or special taxing districts; nor shall said repeal affect any prosecution, suit or other proceeding pending or any judgment rendered prior to the effective date of this Ordinance. 
Section 7: That this Ordinance shall be in full force and effect from and after its passage, approval and publication in pamphlet form as provided by law. 
Adopted this 15th day of April, 2002. 
Ayes: 7 (Piper, Bromberg, Perille, Gelder, Roberts, McCabe, Van Dusen) 
Nays: 0 
Absent: 0

Chapter 1 - GENERAL PROVISIONS 
 
Sec. 1-1. - Title of Code; amendments. 
(a)  Title. This Code of Ordinances may be known and cited as the "Skokie Village Code." 
(b)  Amendments part of Code. Any additions or amendments to this Code are incorporated in this Code so that a reference to the Skokie Village Code includes such additions and amendments. 
(c)  Recording of amendments. It shall be the duty of the Village Clerk to keep at least 1 copy of the Village Code. 
(d)  Record of ordinances. The records mentioned in this section shall be kept in addition to the record of ordinances which the Clerk is required to keep by statute. 
(Code 1979, § 1.01) 
State Law reference— Revision and codification of ordinances, 65 ILCS 5/1-2-3 et seq.; ordinance book as prima facie evidence, 65 ILCS 5/1-2-6.  
Sec. 1-2. - Definitions. 
(a)  Terms used in this Code, unless specifically defined in this Code, have the meanings prescribed by the Illinois Compiled Statutes for the same terms. 
(b)  Terms used in this Code have the following meanings: 
County means Cook County. 
Illinois Compiled Statutes and statute mean the latest edition of the Illinois Compiled Statutes, and any amendments thereto. 
Illinois Municipal Code means Chapter 65 of the Illinois Compiled Statutes (65 ILCS 5/1-1-1 et seq.). 
Person means any natural individual, firm, partnership, trust, estate, club, association, corporation or other entity. As applied to partnership or associations the word includes the partners or members thereof; as applied to corporations it includes the officers, agents or employees thereof who are responsible for the act referred to. The singular includes the plural, and the plural includes the singular. The masculine gender includes the feminine and neuter genders. 
State means the State of Illinois. 
This Code means the Skokie Village Code. 
Village means the Village of Skokie, Illinois. 
Village Board and Board of Trustees mean the Mayor and the Board of Trustees of the Village of Skokie, Illinois. 
(Code 1979, § 1.02; Ord. No. 09-3-C-3667, § 1, 3-2-2009) 
State Law reference— Construction of statutes, 5 ILCS 70/0.01 et seq.  
Sec. 1-3. - Repeal of existing ordinances; ordinances not affected by Code; effect of Code on prior offenses and rights. 
(a)  All general ordinances or parts thereof heretofore adopted by the Mayor and Board of Trustees and not included in this Code are repealed, except the following, which are hereby continued in full force and effect: 
(1)  Ordinances authorizing contracts or the issuance of municipal notes or bonds. 
(2)  Ordinances levying taxes or making special assessments or establishing special taxing districts. 
(3)  Ordinances appropriating funds or establishing salaries. 
(4)  Ordinances granting franchises or rights to persons or corporations. 
(5)  Ordinances relating to the establishment, dedication, opening, grading, naming, improvements, altering, widening or vacating of any streets, alleys, sidewalks, parks or public grounds. 
(6)  Ordinances respecting the annexation of territory to the Village, or the conveyance, acquisition, or acceptance of real property or easements in real property. 
(7)  Ordinances authorizing or relating to particular public improvements. 
(8)  Ordinances relating to railroads or railroad crossings with streets and other public ways, or relating to the conduct, duties, service or rates of public utilities, except where this Code may contain provision for such matters, in which case this Code shall be considered as amending such ordinance or ordinances in respect of such provisions only. 
(9)  Zoning ordinances or ordinances pertaining to specific parcels of property. 
(10)  Any special ordinances not in conflict with the provisions of this Code. 
(11)  Any special ordinances providing for the indemnification of Village officials and employees. 
(b)  The provisions of this Code, so far as they are the same in substance as those of heretofore existing ordinances, are continuations of such ordinances and not new enactments. Any act done, offense committed, or right accruing or acquired or liability, penalty, forfeiture or punishment incurred prior hereto shall not be affected, but may be enjoyed, asserted, enforced, prosecuted or inflicted as fully and to the same extent as if the repeal had not been effected. 
(Code 1979, § 1.03)  
Sec. 1-4. - Ordinances repealed not reenacted. 
No ordinance or part of any ordinance heretofore repealed shall be considered reordained or reenacted by virtue of this Code, unless specifically reenacted. The repeal of any curative or validating ordinance does not impair or affect any cure or validation already effected thereby. 
(Code 1979, § 1.04)  
Sec. 1-5. - Jurisdiction of Code. 
Unless otherwise provided in this Code, this Code applies to acts performed within the corporate limits of the Village. Provisions of this Code also apply to acts performed outside the corporate limits and up to the limits prescribed by law where the law confers power on the Village to regulate such particular acts outside the corporate limits. 
(Code 1979, § 1.05)  
Sec. 1-6. - Penalties. 
(a)  Standard penalty. 
(1)  Whenever in this Code, in any ordinance or in any rule or regulation of the Village any act is prohibited or is declared to be unlawful or an offense, or whenever in this Code, any ordinance or any rule or regulation the doing of any act is required or the failure to do any act is declared to be unlawful, where no specific penalty is provided therefor, any person, upon the violation of any ordinance, shall be punished by a fine not exceeding $750.00 for each and every subsequent day until such time as it is abated, corrected or no longer exists. The Corporation Counsel may file a civil action to recover any penalty or fine, as imposed by an Administrative Law Officer, Judge, or any appropriate entity or tribunal so authorized, against any such person; provided, however, that the filing of such civil action shall preclude incarceration or imprisonment. 
(2)  In addition to any other fine or penalty provided for by this section or any other section of this Code, the court may also impose as a sentence any one of the following: 
a.  An amount of restitution to any person or entity suffering personal injury or property damage as the result of the conduct; 
b.  A period of community service; 
c.  Mandatory attendance at remedial counseling, treatment or educational sessions. 
(b)  Revocation or suspension. The revocation or suspension of a license, registration or permit shall not be considered a recovery or penalty so as to bar any penalty being enforced. 
(c)  Establishment of escrow accounts. The Village Manager's designee, with the approval of the Village Manager or Corporation Counsel, is authorized to establish escrow accounts to assist the Village in resolving disputes relating to: 
(1)  The issuance of a permit, license or certificate of occupancy; or 
(2)  Conditions relating to a Plan Commission or Zoning Board of Appeals case. The terms of the escrow account shall be determined by the Village Manager, the Village Manager's designee or the Corporation Counsel. 
(d)  Violations. 
(1)  Each act of violation, and each subsequent day the violation continues shall elicit a fine not to exceed $750.00 until such time as the violation no longer exists. 
(2)  There shall be a presumption of a continuing violation until adjudicated or until the Village Manager, or designee, determines that the violation has been abated, corrected or no longer exists. 
(3)  Daily fines for the violation shall accrue for the duration of time as outlined in Section 1-106(d)(2). 
(4)  The imposition of the accruing fine, or any part thereof, shall be at the discretion of the Administrative Law Officer or Judge. 
(e)  Notice. Upon service of a citation for any violation of this Code, it shall be sufficient to provide notice of continuing daily fines, if no compliance has been achieved, by mail to the last known address of the respondent cited or with service of the citation. 
(f)  Applicability and Exemption. 
(i)  Except for Chapter 2, Article XII, Traffic Law Enforcement, the penalty provided by this section applies to the amendment of any section of this Code or a code adopted in this Code by reference, whether or not such penalty is reenacted in the amendatory ordinance. 
(ii)  Each act of violation of Chapter 2, Article XII, and each day upon which a violation occurs constitutes a separate offense. Violations of this Article shall follow the penalties specifically set forth in the Article. 
(g)  References to sections include applicable penalty. Reference to a section of this Code shall be understood also to refer to and include the penalty section relating thereto, unless otherwise expressly provided. 
(h)  Failure of officers to perform duties. The failure of an officer or employee of the Village to perform an official duty imposed by this Code shall not subject such officer or employee to the penalty imposed for violation of this Code, unless a penalty is specifically provided in the section creating the duty. 
(i)  In the event any provision of this Section is in direct contravention with provisions in Chapter 2, Article XII, of this Code, then the provisions of Chapter 2, Article XII, shall control. 
(Code 1979, § 1.06; Ord. No. 08-3-C-3605, § 1, 3-17-2008; Ord. No. 13-3-C-3967, § 1, 3-4-2013) 
State Law reference— Limitation on penalties, 65 ILCS 5/1-2-1; "misdemeanor" defined, 65 ILCS 5/1-2-1.1, 730 ILCS 5/5-1-14; enforcement of ordinances, 65 ILCS 5/1-2-7; adoption of penalty clauses by reference, prohibition, 65 ILCS 5/1-3-4; "petty offense" defined, 730 ILCS 5/5-1-17; sentence of imprisonment for misdemeanor, 730 ILCS 5/5-8-3; authorized fines, 730 ILCS 5/5-9-1.  
Sec. 1-7. - Stipulated settlements. 
The Village Manager or designee is authorized to accept settlement amounts specified in this section in settlement for violations of this Code or any Village Ordinance and to establish settlement dates for each such violation. For violations where a showing of compliance is applicable, settlement as provided for in this section shall only be authorized upon a showing of compliance. The Village Manager as authorized by the Mayor and Board of Trustees may establish procedures for the issuance of notices of violations requiring appearance at an administrative hearing or court. If an appearance is not required the Village Manager or designee is authorized to issue a notice of violation specifying settlement amounts as provided for in this section. 
Violation Category 	Settlement amount if paid prior to the initial due date 	Settlement amount if paid after initial due date, but prior to Administrative Hearing or Summons & Complaint 	Settlement amount if paid after Summons and Complaint has been issued 
Parking and Motor Vehicle Equipment Violations except for parking at an expired parking meter or violations related to parking places reserved for persons with disabilities or violations related to parking in, by or near fire hudrants and designated fire lanes 	$ 35.00 	$ 45.00 	$100.00 
Expired parking meter violations 	15.00 	45.00 	100.00 
Violations related to designated disabled spaces 	250.00 	300.00 	350.00 
Violations relating to Fire Hydrants and Fire Lane 	100.00 	150.00 	200.00 
All other code and ordinance violations 	50.00 	60.00 	
 
This Section shall not be applicable to parking, standing, compliance, or automated traffic law violation notices, that are subject to, and processed through, the administrative adjudication system specified in Chapter 2, Article XII, of this Code. The provisions of Chapter 2, Article XII shall govern the fines and penalties applicable to all violations processed through that system. 
(Code 1979, §§ 12.1032, 13.24, 14.19, 23.09, 51.57; Ord. No. 00-10-C-2947, §§ 1—8, 10-16-2000; Ord. No. 07-6-C-3517, § 1, 6-18-2007; Ord. No. 08-3-C-3605, § 2, 3-17-2008)  
Sec. 1-8. - Aiding or abetting violation. 
(a)  Generally. Any person who prosecutes, counsels, aids or abets the commission of any act prohibited by this Code may be prosecuted and upon conviction is punishable as if such person had directly committed such act. 
(b)  Responsibility of parent, guardian or property owner. It shall be unlawful for any parent, guardian, or person in control of a minor to permit any minor to violate any of the provisions of this Code. There shall be a presumption that such parent, guardian, or person in control of a minor or the owner of property where a minor has committed an offense under this Code shall be considered to have permitted such an act. 
(Code 1979, § 1.07)  
Sec. 1-9. - Severability of provisions. 
Each section, paragraph, sentence, clause and provision of this Code is separable, and if any provision is held unconstitutional or invalid for any reason, such decision shall not affect the remainder of this Code or any part thereof, other than that part affected by such decision. 
(Code 1979, § 1.08) 
State Law reference— Severability of statutes, 5 ILCS 70/1.31.  
Chapter 2 - ADMINISTRATION[1] 
Footnotes:

Cross reference— Community development, ch. 30; fees for licenses, services and permits, ch. 46; administration and enforcement of day care home regulations, § 54-163; administration and enforcement of longterm care facilities regulations, § 54-225; human relations, ch. 58; law enforcement, ch. 62; library, ch. 66; taxation, ch. 98; administration and enforcement of hotel-motel tax regulations, § 98-143; administration and enforcement of infrastructure maintenance fee regulations, § 102-37; utilities, ch. 110; administration and enforcement of zoning regulations, § 118-31 et seq.

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 2-1. - Corporate seal. 
The corporate seal of the Village shall be a circular disc with the words "Village of Skokie, Cook County, Illinois" on the outer circle and the word "Seal" in the interior circle. 
(Code 1979, § 3.19) 
State Law reference— Authority of Village to have a corporate seal, 65 ILCS 5/2-3-8.  
Sec. 2-2. - Village flag. 
The Village flag shall consist of a rectangle with a green background and shall contain 2 gold vertical stripes on each end. One of these stripes shall symbolize the original name of "Niles Center" and the other stripe shall symbolize the present name of "Skokie." In the center of the flag there shall be a large gold Indian arrowhead containing the profile of an Indian with a chief's headdress. This symbolizes the original inhabitants of the area. Below the Indian head there shall be the number "1888" arranged vertically, which shall indicate the date of incorporation of the municipality. 
(Code 1979, § 3.26)  
Sec. 2-3. - Datum for levels and grades. 
(a)  The base line or datum for the Village levels and grades is hereby established as measured from the plane of the low-water line of Lake Michigan of the year A.D., 1847, as established by the Trustees of the Illinois and Michigan Canal, which was adopted by the Chicago Council as "Chicago City Datum." The datum was determined A.D., 1903, by the United States Coast and Geodetic Survey, precise levels to be 579,938 feet above mean ocean levels. 
(b)  The bronze tablet set in a projecting buttress front face stone water table, east of the south entrance of St. Peter's Roman Catholic Church, which church is located at the intersection of Lincoln Avenue and Niles Center Road, Skokie, Illinois, is hereby established as Benchmark No. 1 at an elevation of 43,459 feet above the Village datum as established in subsection (a) of this section. 
(Code 1979, § 3.20)  
Sec. 2-4. - Use of Village-owned meeting rooms. 
(a)  Village-owned meeting rooms are available for educational, cultural and public information events of Skokie organizations. 
(b)  All meetings held in Village-owned meeting rooms shall be open to the public and press. 
(c)  No admission fees may be charged by organizations using Village-owned meeting rooms. 
(d)  The Village Manager is hereby authorized and directed to promulgate such rules and regulations as are necessary to carry out the provisions of this section. 
(e)  Any organization which violates the rules and regulations adopted pursuant to this section shall be prohibited from conducting its meetings in Village-owned meeting rooms. 
(f)  This section shall not apply to units of local government, school districts, the Village or its boards and commissions and its employees and officers when acting under the provisions of the Meetings of Public Agencies Act, 5 ILCS 120/1 et seq. 
(Code 1979, § 3.18)  
Sec. 2-5. - Damaging or interfering with public property. 
It shall be unlawful to damage, deface or interfere with any property belonging to the Village without written authority from the Village Manager or the Board of Trustees. 
(Code 1979, § 3.21) 
State Law reference— Criminal damage to property, 720 ILCS 5/21-1.  
Sec. 2-6. - Surety bonds. 
Whenever a surety bond to indemnify the Village is required in exercising the duties of any office or position, or in the issuance of a license or permit or for the exercise of special privilege, the surety on such bond shall be a corporation licensed and authorized to do business in this State as a surety company, in the absence of specific provision to the contrary by ordinance. Whenever in its opinion additional sureties or an additional surety may be needed on any bond to indemnify the Village against any loss or liability because of the insolvency of the existing surety or sureties or for any other reason, the Mayor and Board of Trustees may order a new surety or sureties to be secured on such bond. If such new surety or sureties are not procured within 10 days from the time such order is transmitted to the principal on the bond, or the principal's assignee, the Board of Trustees shall declare the bond to be void, and thereupon such principal or assignee shall be deemed to have surrendered the privilege or position as a condition of which the bond was required. 
(Code 1979, § 3.23) 
State Law reference— Bonds, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-10-30.  
Secs. 2-7—2-30. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - BOARD OF TRUSTEES[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference— Board of trustees, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-45-5 et seq. 
 
Sec. 2-31. - Composition; election; functions. 
The Board of Trustees shall consist of the Mayor and 6 Trustees. The Trustees shall be elected by the electors of the Village to office for 4-year terms as is provided by statute. The Mayor and Board of Trustees shall be the legislative department of the Village government, and shall perform such duties and have such powers as may be authorized by statute. 
(Code 1979, § 2.01)  
Sec. 2-32. - Oath of members. 
The members of the Board of Trustees shall take the oath of office prescribed by statute. 
(Code 1979, § 2.02)  
Sec. 2-33. - Compensation of members. 
The members of the Board of Trustees shall receive such annual compensation as is fixed by the Mayor and Board of Trustees from time to time by the adoption of an ordinance in accordance with the Illinois Constitution and State statute. 
(Code 1979, § 2.02) 
State Law reference— Compensation of members of corporate authorities, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-50-15.  
Sec. 2-34. - Vacancies. 
(a)  A vacancy occurs in the office of Trustee by reason of resignation, failure of 1 or more Trustees to be elected or to qualify, death, permanent physical or mental disability, conviction of a disqualifying crime, abandonment of office, or removal from office, or by removal of residence from the Village. 
(b)  If a vacancy in the office of a Trustee occurs during the term for which the Trustee was elected, such vacancy shall be filled as provided by 65 ILCS 5/3.1-10-50. 
(Code 1979, § 2.03)  
Sec. 2-35. - Time and place of regular meetings. 
Commencing on Monday, January 3, 1983, the regular meetings of the Mayor and Board of Trustees shall be held at the Village Hall on the first and third Monday evenings of each month. The Village Clerk shall be required to post notice of the annual schedule of the regular meetings prior to January 1 of each year. Meetings shall be called to order at 8:00 p.m. If such meeting date should fall on a holiday, or if there is no quorum present, the meeting shall be held at the same hour on the next business day or as determined by the Mayor and Board of Trustees. The Board of Trustees may temporarily hold its meetings in any other convenient place upon giving at least 24 hours' public notice. 
(Code 1979, § 2.04) 
State Law reference— Meetings, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-40-25.  
Sec. 2-36. - Applicability of Open Meetings Act. 
All meetings of the Mayor and Board of Trustees shall be held in accordance with the Illinois Open Meetings Act, 5 ILCS 120/1 et seq. 
(a)  A verbatim record of all closed meetings in the form of an audio record shall be made by the Village Clerk or designee. A statement shall be made at the beginning of each recording identifying the participants and the purpose of the closed meeting. All verbatim records of closed meetings are hereby declared confidential and are not subject to release except as required by Section 2.06(e) of the Illinois Open meetings Act. The Village Clerk shall maintain the verbatim record for a minimum of eighteen months from the date of the closed meeting. Each verbatim record shall be labeled with the date, time and place of the meeting. 
(b)  The Village Clerk shall create written minutes of all closed meetings. The minutes shall include: (i) exemption applicable to the closed meeting; (ii) the date, time and place of the meeting; (iii) the elected officials that are present and those that are absent; (iv) the identity of other persons present; (v) a summary of discussion; and (vi) a record of any vote taken. The approved minutes are deemed to be the official record of the minutes and verbatim record shall not be part of the official record of any meeting. 
(c)  Unless otherwise required by law or ordered by a court, no person shall have access to any verbatim record. The prohibition on the review of a verbatim record does not apply to the Village Clerk, Village Manager or Corporation Counsel, who may review a verbatim record if they deem it necessary. In the event the Village Clerk, Village Manager or Corporation Counsel deem it necessary to review a verbatim record, that person shall notify the other two persons in writing. A review of a verbatim record shall only take place in the Office of the Village Clerk and in the presence of two or more of the aforesaid individuals. The Village Clerk shall maintain a log indicating date, time and persons present of any review made of verbatim records. Notwithstanding any other provision, none of the three aforementioned individuals shall have the authority to review a verbatim record wherein they are the subject of the meeting. 
(d)  On a regular basis, the Village Clerk shall send a written notice to the Mayor, Trustees, Village Manager and the Corporation Counsel listing all verbatim records scheduled for destruction. The notice shall include a synopsis of the subject of the closed session for which the verbatim record was created. The Village Manager and Corporation Counsel shall jointly determine whether it is necessary to preserve a verbatim record for the purposes contemplated by Section 2.06(e) of the Illinois Open Meetings Act and shall so instruct the Village Clerk if their determination is that the record needs to be preserved or that it may be erased or destroyed. 
(e)  The Mayor and Board of Trustees shall semi-annually, at the second meeting in January and the second meeting in June, consider the status of written minutes and verbatim records of executive sessions held by the Mayor and the Board of Trustees in accordance with the Illinois Open Meetings Act. 
(Code 1979, § 2.05; Ord. No. 04-2-C-3251, § 1, 2-17-2004)  
Sec. 2-37. - Notice of meetings. 
(a)  Whenever required, notice shall be either given by mail deposited in a U.S. mail receptacle or post office or deliveries by messenger, or may be given to Board of Trustees members at a prior regular or special meeting and noted in the recorded minutes. Notice may be waived in writing at any time, and the attendance of a Board of Trustees member at a special meeting or the member's voting on any issue shall constitute a waiver of notice as to such issue, without any written waiver. 
(b)  Where written notice is required, notice shall be mailed or delivered to the last known address of the Board of Trustees member by regular mail, and deposited in a U.S. mail receptacle or post office not less than 48 hours prior to the time set for the call to order of the meeting. 
(Code 1979, § 2.06) 
State Law reference— Special meetings, call, notices, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-40-25.  
Sec. 2-38. - Quorum and majority vote. 
(a)  A quorum of the Mayor and Board of Trustees shall consist of a majority of the entire Board of Trustees. Any 4 of the 7 members of the Board of Trustees shall constitute a quorum. A quorum shall be necessary to transact the business of the Board of Trustees. Members of the Board of Trustees shall only be considered in attendance at a meeting if such member is physically present. Attendance by electronic means at a meeting of the Board of Trustees is hereby prohibited. 
(b)  A majority vote of the Board of Trustees, unless otherwise stated, shall consist of not less than 4 members. A majority vote shall be required to adopt any ordinance or resolution or take affirmative action on any motion, the nature of which is other than procedural. 
(Code 1979, § 2.07) 
State Law reference— Quorum of corporate authorities, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-40-20; vote required, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-40-40.  
Sec. 2-39. - Presiding officer. 
The Mayor shall preside at all meetings of the Board of Trustees. The Mayor shall vote on any ordinance, resolution, or motion. An Acting Mayor or a Mayor Pro Tempore shall vote in such person's capacity as a Trustee, but shall not be entitled to another vote in such person's capacity as Acting Mayor or Mayor Pro Tempore. The Mayor or Mayor Pro Tempore shall announce the result of the Board of Trustees vote. 
(Code 1979, § 2.08) 
State Law reference— Presiding officer at meetings, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-40-30.  
Sec. 2-40. - Veto powers of Mayor. 
All resolutions and motions (i) which create any liability against the Village, or (ii) which provide for the expenditure of appropriation of its money, or (iii) to sell any Village property, and all ordinances passed by the Board of Trustees, shall be deposited with the Village Clerk. 
If the Mayor approves of them, the Mayor shall sign them. If the Mayor disapproves of any, the Mayor shall return them to the Board of Trustees with the Mayor's written objections at the next regular meeting of the Board of Trustees. The Mayor may disapprove of any 1 or more sums appropriated in any ordinance, resolution or motion making an appropriation, or the Mayor may disapprove entirely of an ordinance, resolution, or motion making an appropriation. If the Mayor fails to return any ordinance or any specified resolution or motion with the Mayor's written objections within the designated time, it shall become effective despite the absence of the Mayor's signature. 
(Code 1979, § 2.09) 
State Law reference— Veto power, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-40-45.  
Sec. 2-41. - Passage over veto. 
Every resolution and motion specified in Section 2-40 and every ordinance which is returned to the Board of Trustees by the Mayor shall be reconsidered by the Board of Trustees. If, after such reconsideration, 2/3 of all the Trustees elected to the Board of Trustees shall vote to pass an ordinance, resolution, or motion, notwithstanding the Mayor's refusal to approve it, then it shall be effective. The vote on a question of passage over the Mayor's veto shall be by yeas and nays, and shall be recorded in the minutes. 
(Code 1979, § 2.10) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-40-50.  
Sec. 2-42. - Meetings to be open to public. 
All meetings of the Mayor and Board of Trustees shall be open to the public except as provided by ordinance or statute. 
(Code 1979, § 2.11) 
State Law reference— Open Meetings Act, 5 ILCS 120/1 et seq.  
Sec. 2-43. - Disturbing meetings. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to disturb any meeting of the Board of Trustees or of any committee thereof. Any person violating the provisions of this section, upon being found guilty of disturbing a meeting, shall be subject to the penalties provided in Section 1-6 in addition to any other penalty specifically provided for. 
(Code 1979, § 2.12) 
State Law reference— Rules of expulsion, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-40-15.  
Sec. 2-44. - Rules of order. 
The current edition of Robert's Rules of Order shall govern the proceedings of the Board of Trustees, except where in conflict with the following rules: 
Rule 1. The agenda for a regular or special meeting shall be prepared by the Manager. The Manager or designee shall cause a copy of the agenda to be posted on the last business day prior to the meeting date. Trustees, the Corporation Counsel or department heads desiring matters to be placed on the agenda shall so notify the Manager within time sufficient for the Manager to prepare the agenda and distribute copies to Mayor and Board of Trustees. Each Trustee or department head shall also designate any matters which are to be placed on the consent agenda. The consent agenda contains all routine matters which do not require further discussion. All items on the consent agenda are to be marked with an asterisk on the regular agenda. Before the vote is taken, any item will be dropped from the consent agenda at the request of the Mayor, a Trustee, or any person in attendance at the meeting. That item will then be taken up at its regular place on the printed agenda. The Mayor shall take the chair at the hour at which the meeting shall have been called. The Board of Trustees shall take up business in the following order: 
a.  Pledge of Allegiance. 
b.  Call meeting to order and roll call. 
c.  Approve consent agenda. 
d.  Approve minutes of last meeting. 
e.  Approve voucher list. 
f.  Proclamations. 
g.  Recognitions, presentations, and awards. 
h.  Appointments, reappointments and resignations. 
i.  Report of the Village Manager. 
j.  Report of the Corporation Counsel. 
k.  Unfinished business. 
l.  New business. 
m.  Plan Commission cases. 
n.  Miscellaneous. 
o.  Citizens' comments. 
p.  Adjournment. 
Rule 2. The Mayor shall preserve order and decorum and may speak upon and decide all questions of order. 
Rule 3. The Mayor may call upon any member of the Board of Trustees to temporarily perform the duties of the chair, but such substitution shall not extend beyond an adjournment. 
Rule 4. Every question or motion when seconded shall be stated by the Mayor before it is open for debate. When a question is put the vote shall be conducted by a roll call vote. The Village Clerk shall enter the words "omnibus vote" in the journal in lieu of entering the names of the members of the Board of Trustees and each of their votes for all items which are on the consent agenda. 
Rule 5. All Board of Trustees committees shall consist of 3 members, of which the Mayor may be 1, and such committees shall be appointed by the Mayor and confirmed by the Trustees. 
Rule 6. Every member, previous to speaking, shall address the presiding officer as "Mr. Mayor," but shall not proceed with the member's remarks until named and recognized by the chair. 
Rule 7. If any member disregards the rule of the Board of Trustees, the Mayor or any member may call the member to order, and when called to order the member shall take the member's seat, unless permitted to explain. 
Rule 8. Every member, when a question is taken, shall vote unless excused by the Board of Trustees, or if the member is directly interested in the question, in which case the member shall abstain from voting. 
Rule 9. After a resolution or a motion is stated by the Mayor, it shall be deemed to be in the possession of the Board of Trustees, but it may be withdrawn by the maker thereof with the consent of the Trustee seconding prior to the call for the vote by the Mayor. 
Rule 10. When a motion is in the possession of the Board of Trustees, no other motion shall be received, except as specified in this rule, which shall have precedence in the order stated as follows: 
a.  To fix the time to adjourn. 
b.  To adjourn. 
c.  To take a recess. 
d.  To raise a question of privilege. 
e.  To call for the orders of the day. 
f.  To lay on the table. 
g.  To call for the previous question. 
h.  To limit or extend limits of debates. 
i.  To postpone to a certain time. 
j.  To commit or refer. 
k.  To amend. 
l.  To postpone indefinitely. 
m.  To call the main motion. 
Rule 11. The motion to adjourn or lay on the table shall be decided without debate, and the motion to fix the time to which to adjourn and the motion to adjourn shall always be in order, except: 
a.  When a member is in possession of the floor. 
b.  While the members are voting. 
c.  While the vote is being verified. 
d.  When it has been decided that the previous question shall be taken. 
e.  When adjournment was the last preceding motion. 
Rule 12. All votes shall be by roll call. 
Rule 13. An amendment to a motion does not require a separate vote on the amendment if the movants of the original motion concur with the amendment. 
Rule 14. When a Trustee calls for the question, it signifies a request of the chair to close debate and to vote on the pending motion. 
Rule 15. No vote shall be called for on an ordinance at the same meeting at which it shall be first introduced unless there first be a unanimous vote of the members present to suspend the rules; providing that no less than 5 members of the Board of Trustees are present and voting on the motion to suspend the rules. This rule shall not apply to any ordinance the subject matter of which was the subject matter of a recommendation of a commission, board, committee or staff member charged with the making of a recommendation to the Board of Trustees at a regular meeting. Every ordinance when first introduced shall have its title read, the contents explained and the date it will next be considered announced. 
Rule 16. A vote may be called for on all resolutions at the same meeting at which the resolution is first introduced. Resolutions of a routine nature may be placed on the consent agenda. 
Rule 17. All ordinances, before passage, shall be approved as to form by the Corporation Counsel of the Village. 
Rule 18. For purposes of identification, all ordinances shall be numbered consecutively and shall be further identified by using the last 2 digits of the year in which the ordinance is passed followed by a hyphen, followed by a numeral designating the month in which it is passed. Such ordinances may be further identified by a classification system based upon the subject matter. 
Rule 19. For purposes of identification, all resolutions shall be numbered consecutively and shall be further identified by using the last 2 digits of the year in which the resolution is passed followed by a hyphen followed by an "R." Such resolutions may be further identified by a classification system based upon the subject matter. 
Rule 20. The Village Clerk shall cause to be published in pamphlet form or by publication those ordinances which the statutes of the State require to be published, within the limit prescribed by statute. 
Rule 21. Special committees of Trustees or of citizens may be appointed at any time by the Mayor, with the advice and consent of the Trustees, to consider any special problems or issues of concern. 
Rule 22. All standing and special committees to which any matter may be referred shall report thereon, in writing, at a designated regular meeting, giving the facts and their opinion thereon, and the report shall be signed by a majority of the committee. 
Rule 23. When a question before the Board of Trustees contains several propositions, any member may call for a division of the question, so as to take a vote on each proposition separately. 
Rule 24. All petitions addressed to the Board of Trustees shall be in writing and filed with the Village Clerk, who shall present the petitions to the Board of Trustees, except as otherwise provided by statute. 
Rule 25. All resolutions, proclamations and ordinances adopted by the Board of Trustees shall be filed and preserved by the Village Clerk. 
Rule 26. In all cases when a resolution or motion shall be entered in the minutes of the Board of Trustees, the name of the member moving, the name of the member seconding and the exact vote shall also be entered in the minutes. 
Rule 27. Copies of all reports, proposed ordinances and resolutions shall, wherever possible, be made available to all members of the Board of Trustees. 
Rule 28. No contract to which the Village is a party shall be considered as having been entered into unless it is in writing and has been approved by the Board of Trustees at a public meeting. 
Rule 29. Any person or delegation may be recognized by the Mayor to speak on any matter under discussion. Each speaker should come forward, give the speaker's identity, and state the speaker's address. Unless otherwise specified by the Board of Trustees, a speaker's presentation shall be limited to 5 minutes. 
Rule 30. Plan Commission recommendations shall be considered within 120 days after the close of the Plan Commission hearing on a case. The Board of Trustees shall perform one of the following acts: 
a.  Concur with the recommendation; 
b.  Reject the recommendation; 
c.  Table further consideration to a date certain or until such time as further information may be received; or 
d.  Refer the matter back to the Plan Commission for further study or hearing. 
If the Board of Trustees fails to take any action within 6 months, it shall be considered a denial of the Plan Commission's recommendation. A majority vote shall be required to concur with any recommendation of the Plan Commission. A majority vote of the members present shall be sufficient to table or to refer back. If a required vote cannot be had because of the absence of any 1 or more members of the Board of Trustees, the matter shall be tabled to the next regular meeting at which the required attendance may be had. Where the recommendation of the Plan Commission is to deny a petition, and the recommendation has not been concurred with by the Board of Trustees as required by this rule, the next question immediately presented to the Board of Trustees shall be the affirmative motion to pass upon the petition as required. A favorable majority vote shall be required to adopt the motion. The Corporation Counsel shall prepare and present to the Board of Trustees an ordinance where required to effect the action of the Board of Trustees as soon after the consideration of the matter by the Board of Trustees as possible. No ordinance shall be adopted except by affirmative vote as stated in this section. 
Rule 31. Any member acting or appearing in a disgraceful manner, or who uses violent, obscene, or insulting language to or about the Mayor and/or any member of the Board of Trustees, or who does not obey the order of the chair, shall be, on motion, censured by a majority vote of the members present, or expelled from the meeting by a 2/3 vote of all the elected members. 
Rule 32. All new business introduced at any meeting shall be referred to the appropriate committee or the Village Manager or lie over until the next meeting. 
Rule 33. Any or all of the preceding rules may be temporarily suspended by the unanimous vote of all the Board of Trustees members present or may be amended by the majority vote of the Board of Trustees. 
Rule 34. The Village Manager shall determine bid reports which are of a routine nature and shall have them placed on the Manager's report as consent agenda items. 
Rule 35. A motion to reconsider can only be made at the regularly scheduled meeting following the meeting at which the vote to be considered was taken. The motion to reconsider must be made by a member who voted with the prevailing side. 
(Code 1979, § 2.13; Ord. No. 10-2-C-3735, § 1, 2-1-2010)  
Sec. 2-45. - Emergency interim successor for vacancies: Mayor, Clerk and Trustee. 
(a)  Purpose. The purpose of this Section is to ensure a functioning government during, or as a result of, a disaster, as defined herein, by ensuring that there is a procedure to fill vacancies in the offices of the Mayor, Clerk or Trustee. A vacancy that is permanent shall always be filled on a permanent basis if there is a quorum of the Mayor and the Board of Trustees. 
(b)  Definitions. For purposes of this Section, the following words or phrases are defined as follows: 
(1)  "Unavailable" means either that a vacancy in office exists, or that the lawful incumbent of the office is unable to exercise the powers and discharge the duties of the office. 
(2)  "Emergency interim successor" means a person designated pursuant to this Section, in the event the officer is unavailable to exercise the powers and discharge the duties of an office or until a successor is appointed or elected and qualified as may be provided by the constitution, statutes, charters and ordinances or until the lawful incumbent is able to resume the exercise of the powers and discharge of the duties. 
(3)  "Disaster" means a situation in which an occurrence or threat of catastrophic and widespread injury or loss of life or property resulting from any natural or manmade cause, including but not limited to fire, flood, earthquake, epidemic and explosion. A disaster occurs when the Governor declares that a disaster exists, or for a local disaster, when the Village Manager or Mayor and Board of Trustees declares that a disaster exists. 
(c)  Determination of vacancy. In the event that any of the offices of Mayor, Clerk or Trustee(s) becomes vacant, then those persons remaining in the offices of Mayor and Trustees shall declare the office vacant. The vacancy shall be filled in accordance with Section 3.1-5-5 of the Illinois Municipal Code and with Chapter 2 of the Skokie Village Code. 
(d)  Determination of vacancy in a disaster. In the event that the person duly serving as Mayor, Clerk or Trustee(s) becomes unavailable during, or as a result of a disaster, then those persons remaining as Mayor and Trustees shall declare the office vacant and shall determine whether such vacancy is permanent or temporary. 
(1)  If the vacancy is permanent and a quorum of the Mayor and Trustees may be achieved, then the vacancy shall be filled in accordance with Section 3.1-5-5 of the Illinois Municipal Code and the Chapter 2 of the Skokie Village Code. 
(2)  If the vacancy is determined to be permanent and a quorum of the Mayor and Trustees can not be achieved, then the vacancy shall be filled in accordance with paragraph (e) of this Section. 
(3)  If the vacancy is determined to be temporary, then the vacancy shall be filled in accordance with paragraph (f) of this Section. The determination of whether the vacancy is temporary shall be based upon the reasonable expectation of the unavailable officer resuming his or her powers and duties within ninety days. 
(e)  Permanent vacancy. In the event a permanent vacancy occurs in any of the offices of Mayor, Clerk or Trustee during, or as the result of, a disaster, and a quorum of the Mayor and Board of Trustees is not possible, then one or more emergency interim successor(s) shall automatically succeed to the office of Trustee until there are a sufficient number of the Mayor, if available, and Trustees, including emergency interim successors serving as Trustees, to achieve a quorum. Upon achieving a quorum, the Mayor and Board of Trustees shall fill any and all permanent vacancies, including any vacancy for which an emergency interim successor is serving, in accordance with Section 3.1-5-5 of the Illinois Municipal Code and Chapter 2 of the Skokie Village Code. 
(f)  Temporary vacancy. In the event a temporary vacancy occurs in the office Mayor or Clerk during, or as a result of, a disaster, then the Board of Trustees shall designate one of its remaining members as Emergency Interim Mayor, or Clerk, as the case may be. In the event a temporary vacancy occurs in the office of Trustee(s), then one or more emergency interim successor(s) shall automatically succeed to the office of Trustee on a temporary basis. An emergency interim successor shall serve as a temporary designee of the office until such time as the person, for which an emergency interim successor had been named, is available to continue in the performance of official duties, then the duly elected person shall resume his or her prior office and the emergency interim successor shall resume serving in the capacity held prior to her or his designation as an emergency interim successor. In the event the office of Mayor, Clerk or Trustee(s) is declared to be temporarily vacant during, or as a result of, a disaster, and the vacancy continues for ninety days or more, then the office shall be declared to be permanently vacant and the vacancy shall be filled consistent with the procedures established in subparagraph (e) above. 
(g)  Order of succession. In the event of a disaster, and it becomes necessary for an emergency interim successor to serve in the capacity of Mayor, Clerk or Trustee(s), then the person appointed to the following named positions shall serve as an emergency interim successor(s) in the order of succession listed below. 
(1)  Chairman of the Plan Commission; 
(2)  Chairman of the Police and Fire Commission; 
(3)  Chairman of the Zoning Board of Appeals; 
(4)  Chairman of the Appearance Commission; 
(5)  Vice Chairman of the Plan Commission; 
(6)  Vice Chairman of the Police and Fire Commission; 
(7)  Vice Chairman of the Zoning Board of Appeals; 
(8)  Vice Chairman of the Appearance Commission; and 
Should it be necessary to continue the order of succession, the next person designated would be the member with the most seniority on the Plan Commission, and if exhausted, then the next person designated is the member with the highest seniority on Police and Fire Commission, Zoning Board of Appeals and Appearance Commission, respectively. Emergency Interim Trustees shall be designated until the number of Trustees and emergency interim successors serving as Trustees is sufficient to constitute a quorum. 
(h)  Special election. In the event an emergency interim successor is performing the duties of Mayor, Clerk or Trustee(s) due to a permanent vacancy, and such person is performing the duties prior to the date specified in Section 3.2-10-50 of the Illinois Municipal Code, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-10-50 (2002), which would require a special election to fill the unexpired portion of the term, then the special election shall be conducted in accordance with the Illinois Election Code. 
(Ord. No. 05-8-C-3377, § 1, 8-1-2005)  
Secs. 2-46—2-60. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - OFFICERS AND EMPLOYEES[3] 
Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference— Ordinances appropriating funds or establishing salaries saved from repeal, § 1-3(3); special ordinances providing for indemnification of Village officials and employees saved from repeal, § 1-3(11); police powers of Village officers and employees, § 2-357; Animal Control Officer, § 18-5. 
State Law reference— Municipal officers generally, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-5-5 et seq.; functions and duties of certain municipal officers, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-35-5 et seq.; employees and employment, 65 ILCS 5/10-1-1 et seq. 
 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 2-61. - Form of government. 
(a)  The Village has adopted the managerial form of government as provided in 65 ILCS 5/5-1-1 et seq. The Village Board of Trustees shall be elected at large by the electors and shall consist of a Mayor and 6 Trustees as provided in 65 ILCS 5/5-2-12 and 65 ILCS 5/5-2-15. 
(b)  The election for the Mayor, Village Trustees and Village Clerk shall be conducted as a partisan election pursuant to 10 ILCS 5/7-1 et seq. and 10 ILCS 5/10-1 et seq. The results of a consolidated election conducted for the aforesaid offices shall be certified and proclaimed by resolution of the Mayor and Board of Trustees at the first regularly scheduled meeting of the Mayor and Board of Trustees following the official canvass and certification of the consolidated election results. Upon passage of the resolution, the outgoing Mayor and Board of Trustees shall adjourn their meeting and a new meeting shall be convened at the call of the outgoing Mayor. At the new meeting, the newly elected officials shall take their respective oaths and commence their terms of office. 
(Code 1979, § 3.01; Ord. No. 05-4-C-3351, § 1, 4-4-2005)  
Sec. 2-62. - Elections. 
Elections for municipal officers shall be held as is provided by statute, and at the time prescribed by statute. 
(Code 1979, § 3.22) 
State Law reference— Illinois Election Code, 10 ILCS 5/1-1 et seq.; elected officers generally, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-15-5 et seq.; elected Village officers, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-25-5 et seq.  
Sec. 2-63. - Indemnification. 
(a)  It is found and declared by the Mayor and Board of Trustees of the Village as follows: 
(1)  The Village has the power to indemnify its officials, both elected and appointed, and employees pursuant to law and the Constitution of the State. 
(2)  It is in the best interests of the Village to provide for the indemnification of its officials, both elected and appointed, and employees against claims, expenses and liabilities such persons may be subject to by reason of those persons acting in their capacity as officials, both elected and appointed, or employees of the Village. 
(b)  The Village shall indemnify any person who was or is a party or is threatened to be made a party to any threatened, pending or completed claim, action, suit or proceeding, whether civil, administrative or investigative, by reason of any act or omission, error, misstatement or misleading statement, or neglect or breach of duty which could reasonably be construed to have been committed, attempted or allegedly committed or attempted by such person (a "wrongful act") in the discharge of such person's duties in the person's capacity as an official, either elected or appointed, or employee of the Village, against expenses (including attorneys' fees), judgments and amounts paid in settlement actually and reasonably incurred by the person in connection with such action, suit or proceeding, if such person acted in good faith and in a manner which the person reasonably believed to be in, or not opposed to, the best interests of the Village. This indemnification shall not apply to any claim, suit, action or proceeding: 
(1)  Which is for the return by any such official, either elected or appointed, or employee of any remuneration paid in fact to such person without the previous approval of the Village if it shall be determined by a judgment or other final adjudication that such remuneration is in violation of law or if such remuneration is to be repaid to the Village under a settlement agreement; 
(2)  Which is for an accounting of profits made from the purchase or sale by such official, either elected or appointed, or employee of securities of the Village under any federal or State law; 
(3)  Which is brought about or contributed to by the fraudulent or dishonest acts of such official, either elected or appointed, or employee if a judgment or other final adjudication adverse to such official, either elected or appointed, or employee establishes that acts of active and deliberate dishonesty were committed or attempted by such official, either elected or appointed, or employee with actual dishonest purpose and intent and were material to the cause of action so adjudicated; 
(4)  Which is brought about or contributed to by any criminal activities of such official, either elected or appointed, or employee, except, in the case of such official, either elected or appointed, in respect of a wrongful act taken by a majority of the Board of Trustees, or in the case of such official, either elected or appointed, or employee, specifically directed by such a majority; 
(5)  Which is based upon or attributable to such official, either elected or appointed, or employee having gained any personal profit or advantage to which such person was not legally entitled, whether or not (i) a judgment or other final adjudication adverse to such person establishes that such a person in fact gained personal profit or other advantage to which the person was not entitled, or (ii) the official, either elected or appointed, or employee has entered into a settlement agreement to repay such personal profit or advantage to the Village; 
(6)  For which the Village is not authorized by law to provide indemnification to the official, either elected or appointed, or employee; 
(7)  Brought by the Village at the direction of its Board of Trustees against an official, either elected or appointed, or employee; or 
(8)  Brought against any Fire or Police Pension Board member for any acts arising from or in the course of the member's duties as a Pension Board member, due to the independent nature of such boards. 
(c)  The Village shall indemnify only those officials, both elected and appointed, or employees of the Village from whom or with respect to whom the Village has received written notice of a wrongful act. To the extent practicable, any notice from such official, either elected or appointed, or employee shall be mailed as soon as practicable and shall identify the official, either elected or appointed, or employee seeking indemnification and contain information with respect to the time, place and circumstances of the wrongful act, the names and addresses of any injured persons and the names of any available witnesses. In the case where legal proceedings have commenced, indemnification may be denied if the official, either elected or appointed, or employee has failed to mail to the Village, within 10 days after receiving service of process, a copy of such process relating to a wrongful act, unless (i) the Village has otherwise received a copy of, or written notice of, such process, or (ii) the failure to notify within such 10-day period does not adversely impact upon the Village's ability to defend such claim. 
(d)  The Village shall indemnify the official, either elected or appointed, or employee for any damages, expenses, court costs and legal fees incurred in connection with any settlement of a claim, action or proceeding where such settlement has been approved in advance by the Village. 
(e)  Any indemnification under subsection (b) of this section (unless ordered by a court) shall be made by the Village only upon a determination that indemnification of the person is required by this section. Such determination shall be made: 
(1)  By the Mayor and Board of Trustees by a majority vote of a quorum of the Board of Trustees who were not parties to such claim, suit, action or proceeding; 
(2)  If such quorum is not obtainable, or, even if obtainable and a quorum of disinterested Board of Trustees members, by independent legal counsel in a written opinion; or 
(3)  By a court of appropriate jurisdiction. 
(f)  Expenses incurred by any person who may have a right of indemnification pursuant to this section in defending a civil claim, suit, action or proceeding shall be paid by the Village in advance of the final disposition of such claim, suit, action or proceeding as authorized by the Board of Trustees upon receipt of an undertaking by or on behalf of such person to repay such amount to the Village, unless it shall ultimately be determined that such person is entitled to be indemnified by the Village pursuant to this section. 
(g)  Any official, either elected or appointed, or employee against whom any action, suit or proceeding is brought may employ the official's or employee's own attorney, provided that such attorney is reasonably acceptable to the Village, and provided further that the costs of such attorney shall not be paid by the Village unless the Corporation Counsel's office or unless independent counsel for the Village shall have advised the Village that such official's, elected or appointed, or employee's interests can or should not be represented by the same counsel that represents the Village in such action, suit or proceeding. 
(h)  The indemnification provided under this section shall be in addition to, and not exclusive of, any other indemnity or insurance to which the indemnitee may be entitled, and such indemnitee shall be entitled to look to the Village for such indemnification prior to making any claim under any such other indemnity or insurance. The indemnification provided under this section shall be payable whether or not the Village has obtained insurance therefor, and, in the case of the death of the indemnitee, shall inure to the benefit of the indemnitee's successors. 
(Code 1979, § 3.13) 
State Law reference— Indemnification for injuries caused by police officer, 65 ILCS 5/1-4-5, 5/1-4-6; general provisions relating to immunity, 745 ILCS 10/2-101 et seq.  
Sec. 2-64. - Inspection of records. 
All records kept by any employee or department of the Village shall be open to inspection by the Village Mayor, any member of the Board of Trustees, or the Village Manager at all reasonable times, whether or not such records are required to be kept by statute or ordinance. However, records pertaining to privacy issues shall be exempt from this section. 
(Code 1979, § 3.14) 
State Law reference— Freedom of Information Act, 5 ILCS 140/1 et seq.  
Sec. 2-65. - Arrests. 
The Village Mayor, members of the Board of Trustees, the Village Manager, and members of the Fire Department, as well as every member of the Police Department, are hereby declared to be conservators of the peace with such powers to make arrests as are given to conservators of the peace by statute. 
(Code 1979, § 3.15) 
State Law reference— Conservators of the peace, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-15-25.  
Secs. 2-66—2-80. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - MAYOR[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference— Functions and duties of mayor, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-35-5 et seq. 
 
Sec. 2-81. - Election; term. 
A Village Mayor shall be elected by the electors of the Village at a general municipal election for a term of 4 years in the year of 1977 and every 4th year thereafter. Such person shall be Mayor of the Board of Trustees, and such person shall hold such office until the person's successor is elected and is duly qualified. Such person shall be referred to as Mayor of the Village of Skokie. 
(Code 1979, § 3.021)  
Sec. 2-82. - Powers and duties. 
The Mayor shall be the official head of the Village for all legal purposes. The Mayor shall at all times have the power and authority to examine and inspect all books and records relating to Village business kept by any Village agent, employee or officer. The Mayor shall sign all proclamations, commissions, resolutions and ordinances issued or adopted by the Board of Trustees, except as otherwise provided by law or ordinance. 
(Code 1979, § 3.022)  
Sec. 2-83. - Vacancies; Acting Mayor. 
(a)  A vacancy occurs in the office of Mayor by reason of resignation, failure of a Mayor to be elected or to qualify, death, permanent physical or mental disability, conviction of a disqualifying crime, abandonment of office, or removal from office, or by removal of the Mayor's residence from the Village. 
(b)  If a vacancy occurs in the office of the Mayor during the Mayor's term, the vacancy shall be filled for the remainder of the term at the next election of Trustees, unless the vacancy is filled by a special election as provided by statute. 
(c)  During the period from the time that the vacancy occurs until a Mayor is elected and has qualified, the vacancy may be filled by the election of an Acting Mayor by the Board of Trustees. 
(d)  The Acting Mayor shall be paid the Mayor's salary for the period of time such person shall serve as Acting Mayor, and such person may be referred to as the Mayor. 
(Code 1979, § 3.023)  
Sec. 2-84. - Mayor Pro Tempore. 
If a temporary absence or disability of the Mayor incapacitates the Mayor from the performance of the Mayor's duties, but does not create a vacancy in the office, the Board of Trustees shall elect 1 of its members to act as Mayor Pro Tempore. The Mayor Pro Tempore, during this absence or disability, shall perform the duties and possess all the rights and powers of the Mayor. No additional salary or compensation shall be paid the Mayor Pro Tempore for acting as Mayor Pro Tempore. 
(Code 1979, § 3.024)  
Sec. 2-85. - Appointments by Mayor. 
The Mayor, with the advice and consent of the Board of Trustees, shall appoint such boards, commissions, committees or other agencies as may be authorized by ordinance or resolution of the Board of Trustees or as may be authorized by statute. 
(Code 1979, § 3.025)  
Sec. 2-86. - Oath. 
Before entering upon the duties of the Mayor's office, the Mayor shall take the oath of office prescribed by statute. 
(Code 1979, § 3.026)  
Sec. 2-87. - Compensation. 
The Mayor shall receive such annual compensation as is fixed by the Board of Trustees from time to time by the adoption of an ordinance in accordance with the Illinois Constitution and State statute. 
(Code 1979, § 3.027)  
Sec. 2-88. - Additional powers and duties. 
In addition to the powers otherwise described in this division, the Mayor shall perform all such other duties and acts and have all additional powers that are or may be prescribed by the law of the State or the ordinances of the Village. 
(Code 1979, § 3.028) 
State Law reference— Functions and duties of mayor, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-35-5 et seq.  
Secs. 2-89—2-110. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 3. - VILLAGE CLERK[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
State Law reference— Duties of clerk, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-35-90. 
 
Sec. 2-111. - Election; term. 
A Village Clerk shall be elected by the electors of the Village at a general municipal election for a term of 4 years. Such person shall hold office until the person's successor is elected and is duly qualified. 
(Code 1979, § 3.031)  
Sec. 2-112. - Oath. 
The Village Clerk shall take the oath of office prescribed by statute, and shall receive such compensation as may, from time to time, be provided by ordinance. 
(Code 1979, § 3.032)  
Sec. 2-113. - Compensation. 
The Village Clerk shall receive such annual compensation as is fixed by the Mayor and Board of Trustees from time to time by the adoption of an ordinance in accordance with the Illinois Constitution and State statute. 
(Code 1979, § 3.032)  
Sec. 2-114. - Bond. 
Before entering upon the duties of the Clerk's office, the Village Clerk shall execute a bond in such amount and with such sureties as provided by statute, conditioned upon the faithful performance of the Clerk's duties. The premium on such bond shall be paid by the Village. 
(Code 1979, § 3.033) 
State Law reference— Bond of municipal officers, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-10-30.  
Sec. 2-115. - Vacancies. 
In case the office of Village Clerk shall become vacant for any reason, the Mayor and Board of Trustees shall appoint a successor as is provided by statute. 
(Code 1979, § 3.034) 
State Law reference— Vacancies, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-10-50 et seq.  
Sec. 2-116. - Duties. 
(a)  Signatures. The Village Clerk shall seal and attest all contracts, licenses, permits, ordinances, and resolutions and such documents as shall require this formality. 
(b)  Disposition of money collected. The Clerk shall turn over all money received by the Clerk on behalf of the Village to the Village Treasurer promptly upon receipt of such money; and with such money the Clerk shall give a statement as to the source thereof. 
(c)  Accounts. The Clerk shall keep the accounts showing all money received by the Clerk and the source and disposition thereof, and such other accounts as may be required by statute or ordinance. 
(d)  Publication of annual Treasurer's report. The Village Clerk shall cause the annual Treasurer's report to be published in accordance with applicable laws. 
(e)  Records. In addition to the record of ordinances and other records which the Clerk is required by statute to keep, the Clerk shall keep a register of such licenses and permits as are issued by the Clerk, and the payments thereon, and such other records as may be required by the Board of Trustees. 
(f)  Seal. The Clerk shall be the custodian of the Village seal, and shall fix its impression on documents whenever this is required. 
(g)  Custody of documents. The Clerk shall be the custodian of all documents belonging to the Village which are not assigned to the custody of some other officer. The Clerk shall keep and maintain a proper index to all documents and records kept by the Clerk, so that ready access thereto may be had. 
(h)  Attendance at meetings of Mayor and Board of Trustees. The Clerk or Deputy Clerk shall attend all meetings of the Mayor and Board of Trustees and shall be responsible for recording the proceedings thereof; provided, however, in the absence of the Clerk or Deputy Clerk, the Mayor and the Board of Trustees may appoint a substitute. 
(i)  Office hours. The office of the Village Clerk shall be open during all regular business hours established for the Village Hall. 
(j)  Additional duties. In addition to the duties provided in this section, the Clerk shall perform such other duties and functions which may be required by statute or ordinance. 
(Code 1979, § 3.04; Ord. No. 01-10-C-3038, § 1, 10-15-2001)  
Sec. 2-117. - Deputy Clerk. 
A Deputy Clerk may be appointed by the Village Clerk with the consent of the Mayor and Board of Trustees to assist the Clerk in the performance of the duties of that office, at such compensation as shall be provided for in the annual budget. 
(Code 1979, § 3.05) 
State Law reference— Deputy clerks, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-35-95.  
Secs. 2-118—2-130. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 4. - VILLAGE MANAGER[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
State Law reference— Managerial form of municipal government, 65 ILCS 5/5-1-1 et seq. 
 
Sec. 2-131. - Creation of office. 
The office of Village Manager is hereby created. 
(Code 1979, § 3.061)  
Sec. 2-132. - Appointment; qualifications. 
The Village Manager shall be appointed by majority vote of the Mayor and Board of Trustees. The Manager shall be chosen solely on the basis of such person's executive and administrative qualifications without regard to such person's political beliefs. At the time of the Manager's appointment, the Manager need not be a resident of the Village or of the State, but during the Manager's tenure of office the Manager shall reside within the Village. 
(Code 1979, § 3.062)  
Sec. 2-133. - Powers and duties. 
The Village Manager shall be the chief administrative officer of the Village. The Manager shall be responsible to the Mayor and Board of Trustees for the proper administration of all the affairs of the Village. The Manager shall have the power and is required to: 
(1)  Enforce all laws and ordinances of the Village. 
(2)  Attend all meetings of the Mayor and Board of Trustees. The Manager shall have the right to take part in the discussion of all matters coming before the Board of Trustees but shall have no right to vote. The Manager shall be entitled to notice of all special and regular meetings of the Board of Trustees. 
(3)  Recommend to the Mayor and Board of Trustees such measures as, in the Manager's judgment, the Manager deems to be in the best interests of the Village.
