(4)  Appoint, suspend or remove all department heads, appointed staff and employees of the Village and prepare any and all documents commensurate with this authority. This shall not be taken to include the elected officers, consultants retained by the Mayor and Board of Trustees, the Corporation Counsel and the Assistant Corporation Counsels, employees in the uniformed fire and police service appointed by the Board of Fire and Police Commissioners, the Plan Commission, and all appointed board and commission members and other committees created by the Mayor and Board of Trustees. Such appointments, suspensions or removals shall be based upon the merit and fitness of such officer or employee, without regard to political belief or affiliation. The Manager may authorize the head of a department or office to appoint, suspend or remove subordinates in such department or office. 
(5)  Exercise control of all departments and divisions, except the Corporation Counsel and Assistant Corporation Counsels, now in existence or that may hereafter be created by the Mayor and Board of Trustees, except as limited or restricted by ordinance. 
(6)  Make recommendations to the Mayor and Board of Trustees concerning compensation for each appointive office and position in the Village service, except the Corporation Counsel and Assistant Corporation Counsels, including minimum, intermediate and maximum rates. 
(7)  Recommend to the Mayor and Board of Trustees the creating, consolidating and combining of officers, positions, departments or units of the administrative and executive departments of the Village. 
(8)  Investigate all complaints in relation to matters concerning the administration of the government of the Village and services maintained by the public utilities in the Village, and the Manager shall see that all franchises, permits and privileges granted by the Village are faithfully observed. 
(9)  Be the general purchasing agent of the Village; provided, however, that the Manager shall appoint a purchasing agent who shall serve under the direction of the Director of Finance but subject to the authority of the Village Manager. Except where specific provision to the contrary is made by law or by the Mayor and Board of Trustees, the Village Manager shall be responsible for purchasing all materials, supplies and equipment authorized by the Board of Trustees or for which funds are provided in the budget, but the Manager may not purchase any item which exceeds any appropriation until the Board of Trustees has increased the appropriation. Purchases of goods and services shall be made consistent with this Code and State statutes. The Village Manager may issue rules and regulations covering requisitions and the transaction of the business of purchasing. 
(10)  Sign on behalf of the Village any contract authorized by the Mayor and Board of Trustees, except where the Board of Trustees, this Code, ordinance, or statute directs that some other officer shall do so. It shall be the duty of the Village Manager to see that all terms of any contract to which the Village is a party are fully performed by all parties thereto. 
(11)  Prepare or cause to be prepared, on or before May 1 of each year, a budget of estimated funds necessary to defray the expenditure of the Village for the fiscal year; prepare, or cause to be prepared, the annual appropriation ordinance in time for consideration by the Mayor and Board of Trustees during the first month of the fiscal year; and prepare, or cause to be prepared, the tax levy ordinance and upon enactment thereof file a certified copy with the County Clerk. 
(12)  Cause the Village Treasurer to submit to the Mayor and Board of Trustees, promptly following the end of the fiscal year, a complete report on the finances and administrative activities of the Village for the fiscal year. 
(13)  Present or cause the Director of Finance to present to the Mayor and Board of Trustees each month a statement showing the exact financial condition of the Village as of the end of the preceding month and showing amounts appropriated, amounts expended and unexpended balances in the several items of appropriation. 
(14)  Keep a current inventory of all real and personal property of the Village and the location of such property. The Manager shall be responsible for the care and custody of all Village property which is not by law assigned to some other officer or body for care and control. 
(15)  Devote entire time to the discharge of the Manager's official duties. 
(16)  Perform such other lawful duties as may be required by resolution or ordinance of the Mayor and Board of Trustees. 
(Code 1979, § 3.063)  
Sec. 2-134. - Compensation. 
The Village Manager shall receive such compensation as the Mayor and Board of Trustees shall fix from time to time by ordinance. 
(Code 1979, § 3.064)  
Sec. 2-135. - Acting Village Manager. 
If the Village Manager shall be absent from the Village or incapacitated for a period of 30 consecutive days from performing the duties of the Manager's position, a qualified person may be appointed by the Mayor and Board of Trustees to act as Manager during such absence or incapacity, with all the powers and duties of that office, and the compensation to be paid such Acting Village Manager shall be fixed by the Mayor and Board of Trustees. 
(Code 1979, § 3.065)  
Sec. 2-136. - Vacancies; Manager Pro Tempore. 
In case of a vacancy of the office of Village Manager, the Mayor and Board of Trustees shall appoint a Manager Pro Tempore, who shall possess the powers and duties of the Manager until such time as a new Manager is appointed. No Manager Pro Tempore shall hold the position as such for more than 4 months, and no appointment of a Manager Pro Tempore shall be renewed. The compensation to be paid to such Manager Pro Tempore shall be fixed by the Mayor and Board of Trustees. 
(Code 1979, § 3.066)  
Sec. 2-137. - Removal. 
The Board of Trustees may remove the Village Manager at any time with or without cause by a majority vote of the entire Board of Trustees. 
(Code 1979, § 3.067)  
Secs. 2-138—2-160. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 5. - OFFICE OF THE CORPORATION COUNSEL 
 
Sec. 2-161. - Creation; composition. 
There is hereby created an executive office of the Village which shall be known as the Office of the Corporation Counsel and which shall consist of a Corporation Counsel and Assistant Corporation Counsels, together with such additional employees as the Corporation Counsel may from time to time require in the performance and discharge of the duties of the Corporation Counsel. 
(Code 1979, § 3.091)  
Sec. 2-162. - Appointment of attorneys and other personnel. 
(a)  The Corporation Counsel and Assistant Corporation Counsels shall be appointed by the Mayor with the consent of the Board of Trustees, and they shall hold office until their respective successors shall be duly appointed and qualified. 
(b)  Additional employees other than attorneys, required from time to time by the Corporation Counsel, shall be hired by the Village Manager. 
(Code 1979, § 3.092)  
Sec. 2-163. - Qualifications of attorneys. 
The Corporation Counsel and Assistant Corporation Counsels shall be duly licensed by the Supreme Court of the State, shall be members of the bar in good standing, and shall otherwise be qualified by law to serve as the attorneys for the Village. 
(Code 1979, § 3.093)  
Sec. 2-164. - Duties of Corporation Counsel. 
(a)  The Corporation Counsel shall be the head of the Office of the Corporation Counsel and shall have full charge of all the law business of the Village and shall be and act as legal advisor of the Mayor and Board of Trustees and of the several officers, boards, commissions and departments of the Village. The Corporation Counsel shall represent the Village in any legal action or matter to which the Village is a party or in which the Village has an interest, before any court, tribunal or commission, unless excused by the Mayor and Board of Trustees. 
(b)  The Corporation Counsel shall regularly attend the meetings of the Board of Trustees; however, the Corporation Counsel may designate an assistant to attend any meeting and empower such assistant to act in the place and stead of the Corporation Counsel. 
(c)  The Corporation Counsel shall direct the other members of the Law Department and shall call upon other members of the legal staff for assistance in performing the duties required of the Corporation Counsel, and may, with the approval of the Board of Trustees, engage such additional specialized counsel as the Corporation Counsel may require. 
(d)  The Corporation Counsel shall devote all the time that may be required to superintend and conduct such law business of the Village as is committed to the Corporation Counsel's charge. The Corporation Counsel shall draw such ordinances as may be required of the Corporation Counsel by the Mayor and Board of Trustees, or any board, commission or department of the Village. The Corporation Counsel shall draw contracts, leases, deeds and other documents and papers connected with any department of the Village, when required by the head of such department, and approve all bonds as to form. The Corporation Counsel shall, with the assistance of the Corporation Counsel's legal staff, prosecute all violations of Village ordinances. 
(e)  The Corporation Counsel shall, when requested, furnish written opinions upon subjects submitted to the Corporation Counsel by the Mayor and Board of Trustees, or any Board of Trustees member, with the approval of and transmission via the Mayor; or any department head, with the approval of and transmission via the Village Manager; and shall perform such other legal services on behalf of the Village as the Board of Trustees may from time to time direct. 
(Code 1979, § 3.094)  
Sec. 2-165. - Required records; inspection of records. 
The Corporation Counsel shall keep in proper records to be provided for that purpose by the Village a register or docket of all actions in court prosecuted or defended by the Corporation Counsel's office, and all proceedings had therein, which books and records shall at all times be open for inspection by the Mayor and the Board of Trustees. 
(Code 1979, § 3.095)  
Sec. 2-166. - Reports. 
The Corporation Counsel shall each year report to the Board of Trustees the transactions of the Corporation Counsel's office during the previous year, with such recommendations as the Corporation Counsel deems necessary and proper, and in addition shall make such further reports as the Mayor and Board of Trustees may from time to time request. 
(Code 1979, § 3.096)  
Sec. 2-167. - Authority to compromise actions. 
(a)  The Corporation Counsel, with the consent and approval of the Mayor and Board of Trustees, may compromise any action or cause of action, by or against or involving the Village, upon such terms and conditions as to the Corporation Counsel seem equitable and just, either before or after the filing of an action at law or in equity, when in the judgment of the Corporation Counsel the public interest is thereby served. 
(b)  The Corporation Counsel, or any member of the Corporation Counsel's legal staff, under the direction of the Corporation Counsel, may compromise with the party complained of, either before or after an action has been brought for any violation of a Village ordinance, when, in their individual judgment, public interest does not require that such action be prosecuted, and the Corporation Counsel or they, individually, shall have the power to discontinue any such action, upon terms and conditions as may seem equitable and just. 
(Code 1979, § 3.097)  
Sec. 2-168. - Compensation of Corporation Counsel and Assistant Corporation Counsels. 
The Corporation Counsel and the Assistant Corporation Counsels shall receive such compensation as the Mayor and Board of Trustees shall fix from time to time by ordinance. 
(Code 1979, § 3.098)  
Sec. 2-169. - Duty of Corporation Counsel to turn over records upon leaving office. 
Upon the resignation or removal from office of the Corporation Counsel, the Corporation Counsel shall forthwith, upon demand, deliver to the Mayor and Board of Trustees all books, deeds, periodicals, leases, contracts, files, records and other documents and papers belonging to the Village or its officers, including all documents pertaining to actions prosecuted by the Corporation Counsel or Assistant Corporation Counsels then pending and undetermined, together with the register or docket referred to in Section 2-165. 
(Code 1979, § 3.099)  
Secs. 2-170—2-190. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IV. - DEPARTMENTS  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Secs. 2-191—2-210. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - DEPARTMENT OF FINANCE[7] 

Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
Cross reference— Financial matters, § 2-991 et seq. 
State Law reference— Finance, 65 ILCS 5/8-1-1. 
 
Sec. 2-211. - Creation; composition. 
There is hereby created and established an executive department of the Village government which shall be known as the Department of Finance, which shall include a Director of Finance and such subordinates and assistants as the Village Manager shall appoint. 
(Code 1979, § 3.071)  
Sec. 2-212. - Appointment of Director. 
The office of the Director of Finance is hereby created. The Director of Finance shall be the head of the Department of Finance and shall be appointed by the Village Manager for an indefinite term, and be subject to supervision, direction and control by the Manager and subject to discharge by the Manager, with or without cause. 
(Code 1979, § 3.072)  
Sec. 2-213. - Appointment and discharge of employees. 
All employees of the Department of Finance shall be appointed by the Village Manager and shall be appointed for an indefinite term, and all persons appointed shall be subject to discharge by the Manager with or without cause.  
Sec. 2-214. - Compensation of employees. 
All persons appointed under this division shall receive compensation as may be authorized by the Mayor and Board of Trustees.  
Sec. 2-215. - General duties of Director. 
(a)  In all cases where the duty is not expressly charged to any other department or office of the Village, it shall be the duty of the Director of Finance to act to promote, secure, and preserve the financial and property interests of the Village. 
(b)  The Director of Finance shall serve as the Village Treasurer, and ex officio as the Village Collector and Comptroller, and in each capacity shall perform such duties as may be prescribed by statute or ordinance. 
(Code 1979, § 3.072)  
Sec. 2-216. - Specific duties of Director. 
In addition to the duties required by State law, if any, the Director of Finance shall have the following duties, functions and responsibilities: 
(1)  Fiscal supervision. Exercise general supervision over all fiscal matters relating to the functions of every department of the Village government. 
(2)  Auditing of books and records. Examine and audit the books, records and accounts of each department and determine that they are in proper form and balance. 
(3)  Payments. Supervise the prompt payments of all monies received by every department into the Village treasury and provide for the completion and delivery to the Director of Finance of such financial reports as the Director of Finance shall from time to time prescribe and require from such departments. The Director of Finance shall promptly report to the Village Manager every failure by any department to promptly pay into the Village treasury the money received or the failure to complete and deliver to the Director of Finance such financial reports, or the failure of the books, records and accounts to balance. 
(4)  Report of misuse of funds. Report to the Village Manager the defalcation of or misuse by any department, officer or employee of the Village of monies or property belonging to the Village. 
(5)  Collection of special assessments. Supervise and direct the collection and accounting of special assessment funds, and the proceeds received from the sale of bonds, all of which the Director of Finance shall without delay deposit or cause to be deposited in the Village treasury. All monies received on any special assessment shall be deposited in a special account and shall be applied only to payment for the improvement, or bonds or vouchers issued therefor, together with interest thereon, for which the assessment was made, and such money shall not be used for any other purpose, unless to reimburse the Village for money expended for such improvement. Payments on bonds or vouchers shall be made in accordance with the statutes or ordinances and the books, records, and accounts shall be so kept as to readily disclose the proration between payments of principal and interest. 
(6)  Deposit of funds. Deposit the Village funds only in such banks as may be designated by ordinance or resolution. Deposits made by the Director of Finance on such banks shall discharge the Director of Finance from responsibility while the funds and money are on deposit. The Director of Finance shall be subject to the provisions of the statutes relating to municipal treasurers. 
(7)  Accounts of receipts and expenditures. Keep, in proper books, a full and accurate account of all the monies received and disbursed by the Director of Finance in behalf of the Village, specifying the time of receipt and disbursement, from whom received and to whom disbursed, the purpose for which the money was received or disbursed, and the nature of the payment. Special assessment collections shall be identified by the warrant number and the installment thereof. 
(8)  Collection of monies and fees due Village. Demand and receive all monies and fees due and owing to the Village. When an indebtedness due the Village shall not be paid upon demand of the Director of Finance, the Director of Finance shall advise the Corporation Counsel thereof. 
(9)  Monthly report to Village Manager. Make a detailed monthly report to the Village Manager as to the business and activities of the Finance Department during the preceding month, together with such other identification, items, and facts as the Manager shall require. 
(10)  Certification of contracts. Certify as to whether an appropriation was made for all contracts, agreements, or other obligations involving the expenditure of public funds entered into by an official of the Village government, and no such contract, agreement, or other obligation shall be valid until so certified by the Director of Finance. The act of certifying may be delegated to a subordinate. 
(11)  Budget duties. Prepare estimates of revenue, and give such other assistance in the preparation of the budget as may be required by the Village Manager. 
(12)  Appropriation balances. Keep all departments, boards, commissions, or institutions currently informed of their classified unencumbered appropriation balances. 
(13)  Accounts. Keep all general accounts of the Village government and of the respective departments, offices, boards, commissions and institutions thereof. 
(14)  Purchasing. Under the direction and as authorized by the Village Manager, supervise the purchasing of all supplies for the use of all departments, boards, officers, commissions, or institutions of the Village government. 
(Code 1979, § 3.073)  
Sec. 2-217. - Warrants; transfer of funds. 
All warrants drawn on the Village Treasurer must be signed by the Mayor, or in his absence by the Village Manager, and countersigned by the Director of Finance, stating the particular fund or appropriation to which the warrant is chargeable, and the person to whom payable; and no money shall be otherwise paid except as may be authorized by statute. Money shall not be transferred by the Director of Finance from one fund to another after receipt by the Director, or appropriated to any other purpose than that for which it has been collected or paid, except as may be ordered by the Mayor and Board of Trustees in the manner and form prescribed by statute. 
(Code 1979, § 3.074) 
State Law reference— Warrants, 65 ILCS 5/8-1-8 et seq.  
Sec. 2-218. - Annual audit of accounts. 
As soon as practicable at the close of each fiscal year, and not later than 3 months thereafter, there shall be an audit of all accounts of the Village conducted independently of the Village Manager, made by a competent person, authorized to act as an auditor under the laws of the State, to be selected by the Mayor and Board of Trustees. 
(Code 1979, § 3.075) 
State Law reference— Audit of accounts, 65 ILCS 5/8-8-1 et seq.  
Sec. 2-219. - Reports. 
The Director of Finance shall monthly furnish the Village Manager with a full and comprehensive report of all matters pertaining to the activities of the Finance Department during the preceding month.  
Secs. 2-220—2-240. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 3. - DEPARTMENT OF PUBLIC WORKS[8] 

Footnotes: 
--- (8) --- 
Cross reference— Solid waste, ch. 86; streets and sidewalks, ch. 90; utilities, ch. 110. 
 
Sec. 2-241. - Creation; composition. 
There is hereby created and established an executive department of the Village government which shall be known as the Department of Public Works, which shall include a Director of Public Works and such subordinates and assistants as the Village Manager shall appoint. 
(Code 1979, § 3.111)  
Sec. 2-242. - Appointment of Director. 
The office of the Director of Public Works is hereby created. The Director of Public Works shall be the head of the Department of Public Works and shall be appointed by the Village Manager for an indefinite term, and be subject to supervision, direction and control by the Manager and subject to discharge by the Manager, with or without cause. The Director of Public Works may but need not be the Municipal Engineer. 
(Code 1979, § 3.111)  
Sec. 2-243. - Appointment and discharge of employees. 
All employees of the Department of Public Works shall be appointed by the Village Manager and shall be appointed for an indefinite term, and all persons appointed shall be subject to discharge by the Manager with or without cause. 
(Code 1979, § 3.111)  
Sec. 2-244. - Compensation of employees. 
All persons appointed under this division shall receive compensation as may be authorized by the Mayor and Board of Trustees. 
(Code 1979, § 3.111)  
Sec. 2-245. - General duties of Director. 
The Director of Public Works shall be the head of the Department of Public Works and shall have the management and control of all matters and things pertaining to such department. 
(Code 1979, § 3.112)  
Sec. 2-246. - Specific powers and duties of Director. 
The Director of Public Works shall be charged with and shall have the supervision, direction and control of and have the duty to: 
(1)  Operate and maintain the Village water distribution system and all intakes, reservoirs, mains, hydrants and equipment, fixtures, and appurtenances thereto and thereunto attached. 
(2)  Maintain and service all streets, curbs, alleys, public ways and highways in the Village and all walks, crosswalks, bridges, tunnels, viaducts, public places and public grounds under the jurisdiction of the Village, and promptly cause the repair or the alteration thereof whenever the circumstances shall require. 
(3)  Regulate, control and have custody of all public buildings which belong to the Village and maintain all Village buildings in good repair. 
(4)  Have charge, control and custody of all mechanical equipment and motor vehicle equipment, and operate, repair and maintain facilities for all equipment. 
(5)  Be in charge of all sewers and drains, basins and flood control apparatus in the streets, alleys and public places in the Village, and keep such sewers, drains, basins and flood control apparatus in good working order and condition and free and clean of obstructions, and make necessary repairs to all sewers, drains and appurtenances as from time to time may become necessary. 
(6)  Prescribe the mode of tapping or opening any sewers or drains and the form, size and material of the connection therewith, as otherwise provided by ordinance, and issue permits to make lateral connections with such sewers and drains. 
(7)  Direct and supervise the manner of using streets, alleys, public ways, highways, and other public places of the Village where improvements are being installed or repairs made, including the erection of electric light, telephone, streetlight, traffic light and other poles or posts, signs, canopies and other overhead structures, and the laying down of gas, water, and other pipes, electric light and telephone conduits and sewers authorized by law or Village ordinance, and, in the absence of a direction by the Mayor and Board of Trustees, determine and approve the location of such improvements or installations. During the progress of construction, alteration, placement or installation as described in this section, the Director of Public Works shall require that the location thereof be adequately barricaded and protected so as to protect the public from damage or injury, and such barricades and protection shall not be removed without the approval of the Director of Public Works. 
(8)  Supervise the removal and disposal of garbage and other household wastes; provided, however, that the abatement or removal of all conditions or nuisances which might affect the public health shall be under the jurisdiction of the Department of Public Health. 
(9)  Direct and supervise the removal of snow from the streets and sidewalks of the Village and the removal from and maintenance of the streets, alleys and public places of the Village free and clean of objectionable weed or plant growth; and remove weeds, brush and rubbish from privately owned property when so directed by the Village Manager. 
(10)  Make or cause to be made and kept in the office of the Director of Public Works a detailed map or plat of all sewers and water distribution mains and appurtenances in the Village distinctly showing all junctions, house connections, equipment and fixtures appurtenant thereto. 
(11)  Perform such other lawful duties which may be directed by Village Manager. 
(Code 1979, § 3.113)  
Sec. 2-247. - Supervision of engineering services. 
The Director of Public Works shall direct and supervise engineering services required by the Village. 
(Code 1979, § 3.114)  
Sec. 2-248. - Issuance of permits. 
In all cases where provision is made by this Code that the consent of the Director of Public Works shall be obtained to authorize any act to be done, the Director of Public Works may grant a permit therefor, subject to the restrictions of the Code provision in relation thereto. 
(Code 1979, § 3.115)  
Sec. 2-249. - Reports. 
The Director of Public Works shall monthly furnish the Village Manager with a full and comprehensive report of all matters pertaining to the activities of the Department of Public Works during the preceding month.  
Secs. 2-250—2-270. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 4. - DEPARTMENT OF COMMUNITY DEVELOPMENT[9] 

Footnotes: 
--- (9) --- 
Cross reference— Community development, ch. 30. 
 
Sec. 2-271. - Creation; composition. 
There is hereby created and established an executive department of the Village government which shall be known as the Department of Community Development, which shall include a Director of Community Development and such subordinates and assistants as the Village Manager shall appoint. 
(Code 1979, § 23.01)  
Sec. 2-272. - Appointment of Director. 
The office of the Director of Community Development is hereby created. The Director of Community Development shall be the head of the Department of Community Development and shall be appointed by the Village Manager for an indefinite term, and be subject to supervision, direction and control by the Manager and subject to discharge by the Manager, with or without cause. 
(Code 1979, § 23.01)  
Sec. 2-273. - Appointment and discharge of employees. 
All employees of the Department of Community Development shall be appointed by the Village Manager and shall be appointed for an indefinite term, and all persons appointed shall be subject to discharge by the Manager with or without cause. 
(Code 1979, § 23.01)  
Sec. 2-274. - Compensation of employees. 
All persons appointed under this division shall receive compensation as may be authorized by the Mayor and Board of Trustees. 
(Code 1979, § 23.01)  
Sec. 2-275. - Divisions. 
The Director of Community Development shall have management, direction and control over the following divisions, whose duties are as follows: 
(1)  Building Division. 
a.  Have general charge and supervision of the construction, alteration, repair, erection, remodeling, removal, wrecking, equipment, use, occupancy and maintenance of all buildings, walls, structures or portions or sections thereof and accessories thereto located within the Village, and enforce all Village ordinances relating thereto. 
b.  Have general charge and supervision of all electrical construction, boiler and elevator installation, and plumbing, heating, ventilating, refrigerating and air conditioning systems, and smoke and air pollution therefrom, and the inspection thereof, and enforce all ordinances relating thereto. 
c.  Examine applications for building permits and all plans and specifications in connection therewith, and have charge and supervision of building inspections on all buildings, structures or portions thereof in connection with work that has been authorized by a permit from the Department, including but not exclusive of boiler, elevator, lighting, electrical, plumbing, heating, ventilating, refrigerating and air conditioning equipment. 
d.  Require installation of safeguards which will prevent injury to person or property during construction, require adequate exit facilities in existing buildings and structures, and ensure compliance with all of the building code requirements for the safety, health and general welfare of the public. 
e.  Order all work stopped on construction, alteration, remodeling, repair or removal of buildings and structures when such work is being done in violation of any provision or provisions of any ordinance of the Village, including the zoning ordinances. A verbal stop order shall be promptly reduced to writing and served upon any person found on the job within 1 hour after the utterance of the verbal order and thereafter the work shall not be resumed unless written permission is obtained from the Director of Community Development or designee. Any authorized agent, employee or police officer of the Village may serve the written stop order. 
(2)  Property Maintenance Division. 
a.  Inspect the conditions and maintenance of all property, buildings and structures, and ensure that structures are safe, sanitary and fit for occupation and use. 
b.  Issue all necessary notices or orders to correct or remove illegal or unsafe buildings or structures or conditions. 
(3)  Planning Division. 
a.  Maintain permanent and current records of the Zoning Ordinance, including but not limited to all map amendments and special uses, variations, exceptions, appeals and applications; designate on the zoning district map each authorized amendment and special use; and keep such records which the Village requires to be kept in regards to zoning. 
b.  Forward to the appropriate reviewing body all documents and information pertaining to applications for special uses, zoning ordinances, amendments, variances, and other matters which are to be referred to the reviewing bodies. 
c.  Initiate, direct and review, from time to time, a study of the provisions of the Zoning Ordinance, and make recommendations to the Plan Commission at least once a year. 
(4)  Economic Development Division. 
a.  Initiate, direct and review the Village's Community Development Block Grant program. 
b.  Administer the federal government's Community Development Block Grant (CDBG) program. 
c.  Assist and coordinate Village efforts in development of industrial, commercial and residential projects, in regards to TIF and redevelopment districts. 
(Code 1979, § 23.02)  
Sec. 2-276. - Reports. 
The Director of Community Development shall monthly furnish the Village Manager with a full and comprehensive report of all matters pertaining to the activities of the Department of Community Development during the preceding month. Among such other matters as shall be relative thereto, there shall be included in the report the number of permits issued, stages of construction, alteration, remodeling or demolition, revocations, stop orders and notice and orders issued, and the total fees charged. 
(Code 1979, § 23.03)  
Secs. 2-277—2-290. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 5. - DEPARTMENT OF PUBLIC HEALTH[10] 

Footnotes: 
--- (10) --- 
Cross reference— Health and sanitation, ch. 54. 
State Law reference— Authority to maintain a board of health, 65 ILCS 5/11-16-1. 
 
Sec. 2-291. - Creation; composition. 
There is hereby created and established an executive department of the Village government which shall be known as the Department of Public Health, which shall include a Director of Public Health and such subordinates and assistants as the Village Manager shall appoint. 
(Code 1979, § 11.01)  
Sec. 2-292. - Appointment of Director. 
The office of the Director of Public Health is hereby created. The Director of Public Health shall be the head of the Department of Public Health and shall be appointed by the Village Manager for an indefinite term, and be subject to supervision, direction and control by the Manager and subject to discharge by the Manager, with or without cause. 
(Code 1979, § 11.02)  
Sec. 2-293. - Appointment and discharge of employees. 
All employees of the Department of Public Health shall be appointed by the Village Manager and shall be appointed for an indefinite term, and all persons appointed shall be subject to discharge by the Manager with or without cause.  
Sec. 2-294. - Compensation of employees. 
All persons appointed under this division shall receive compensation as may be authorized by the Mayor and Board of Trustees.  
Sec. 2-295. - Powers and duties of Director. 
It shall be the duty of the Director of Public Health to enforce all the laws of the State, the rules, regulations, and orders of the State Department of Public Health and the State Environmental Protection Agency and the ordinances of the Village in relation to matters pertaining to the preservation of public health within the Village, and the Director shall: 
(1)  Execute and enforce all rules, regulations and orders of the Department of Public Health and all ordinances of the Village relating to public health and sanitation. 
(2)  Execute and enforce all ordinances of the Village relating to the health standards maintained in every place of business in the Village where services of a personal nature are furnished to the public or where foods, food products, milk, milk products and beverages are either handled, sold, given away, stored, manufactured or processed. 
(3)  Investigate the existence of any reportable communicable disease within the Village and report such disease to the State Department of Public Health, and act without delay in carrying out such measures for controlling the transmission of such disease. 
(4)  Make all necessary sanitary and health investigations and inspections and cause all nuisances, whether public or private, affecting the health of persons in private employment and the public generally to be abated with reasonable promptness in accordance with the applicable provisions of this Code. 
Cross reference— Public nuisances, § 42-31 et seq. 
(5)  Initiate plans for dealing with public health problems not already included in the Department of Public Health program with the approval of the Village Manager and where required by the Mayor and Board of Trustees. 
(6)  Perform such other duties relating to health and sanitation as the Mayor and Board of Trustees or the Village Manager shall direct. 
(7)  Request the Police Department and such other State or municipal authorities for such assistance as may be deemed necessary in the performance of the duties of the office, and cause the prosecution of offenders violating any of the rules, regulations or orders of the Department of Public Health, or violating any of the Village ordinances relating to public or private nuisances, public health and sanitation. 
(Code 1979, § 11.03)  
Sec. 2-296. - Powers of enforcement officers. 
For the purpose of performing the Director's duties, the Director of Public Health and the Director's deputies and assistants shall have the authority to enforce the health ordinances in accordance with established procedures and practices and shall be permitted, at any reasonable hour, to enter into or upon any house, store or other building or unimproved land, if deemed necessary, in order to make a thorough inspection and examination of the health and sanitary conditions of the premises. All orders and directions emanating from the Department of Public Health shall be issued in the name of the Director or Village Manager. 
(Code 1979, § 11.04)  
Sec. 2-297. - Reports. 
The Director of Public Health shall monthly furnish the Village Manager with a full and comprehensive report of all matters pertaining to the activities of the Department of Public Health during the preceding month. 
(Code 1979, § 11.07)  
Secs. 2-298—2-320. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 6. - FIRE DEPARTMENT[11] 

Footnotes: 
--- (11) --- 
Cross reference— Board of Fire and Police Commissioners, § 2-461 et seq.; Board of Trustees of the Firefighters' Pension Fund, § 2-491 et seq.; fire prevention and protection, ch. 50. 
State Law reference— Authority to create a fire department, 65 ILCS 5/11-6-1. 
 
Sec. 2-321. - Creation. 
There is hereby established a Village Fire Department for the prevention and extinguishment of fire endangering life and property within the limits of the Village, and beyond the Village limits where contractual or mutual aid fire protection agreements have been or may be made. The Department is also responsible for provision of emergency medical assistance. The term "Department," when used in this division, shall mean the Fire Department for the Village. 
(Code 1979, § 5.01)  
Sec. 2-322. - Personnel. 
The personnel of the Village Fire Department is established as follows: 
(1)  The Mayor and Board of Trustees shall, from time to time, determine the number of firefighters necessary for the effective operation of the Fire Department. 
(2)  The Department shall have the following offices and they are hereby created: Fire Chief, Deputy Fire Chiefs, and such Captains, Assistant Shift Commanders and Lieutenants as authorized by the Mayor and Board of Trustees through the annual budget process. 
(Code 1979, § 5.02)  
Sec. 2-323. - Appointments. 
(a)  Generally. All sworn personnel in the Department shall be appointed in accordance with the provisions of 65 ILCS 5/10-2.1-1 et seq., and rules and procedures of the Board of Fire and Police Commissioners and applicable collective bargaining agreements, except as may be otherwise provided in this division. 
(b)  Fire Chief. The Fire Chief shall be the ranking officer of the Department. The Fire Chief shall be appointed by the Village Manager. 
(Code 1979, § 5.03)  
Sec. 2-324. - Qualifications of Fire Chief. 
No person shall be eligible to hold the office of Fire Chief unless such person shall possess technical training and knowledge and experience in the matters of firefighting and fire prevention so as to reasonably qualify in such matters. This shall encompass thorough knowledge of policies, regulations and requirements of a fire department and of fire prevention laws and ordinances; considerable knowledge of the principles of public administration with reference to departmental personnel and budget administration; ability to analyze the effectiveness of the Department and to correlate its development with changing conditions in the Village; ability to plan, assign and direct the work of a number of subordinate operating units under emergency conditions; ability to meet tactfully and effectively with public officials and the general public and to present ideas clearly in oral or written form; and ability to provide effective leadership and to maintain harmonious relationships in the Department. Also, considerable experience in a supervisory firefighting position with the responsibility for a major phase of departmental administration, and graduation from an accredited university or college with at least a bachelor's degree supplemented by formal fire training and certification, may be required as may be determined by the Village. 
(Code 1979, § 5.04)  
Sec. 2-325. - Duties of Fire Chief. 
The Fire Chief shall perform the following duties: 
(1)  The Fire Chief shall have the custody, subject to the direction of the Village Manager, of all Village property and equipment pertaining to the Fire Department. 
(2)  The Fire Chief shall have control and direction of all personnel of the Village Fire Department. 
(3)  The Fire Chief shall cause to be investigated the cause, origin, and circumstances of any fire or explosion involving a loss of life, injuries to persons or destruction of or damage to property. When, in the opinion of the Fire Chief, reasonable cause exists that the fire or explosion may have been of incendiary origin, the Fire Chief shall have the authority to take custody of all physical evidence relating to the cause of the fire or explosion and to continue the investigation to conclusion. Proprietary information as identified by the occupant which may relate to trade secrets or processes shall not be part of the public record except as may be directed by a court of law or applicable State statute. 
(4)  The Fire Chief shall from time to time during the year examine the condition of fire apparatus and fire stations, and report such information to the Village Manager. 
(5)  The Fire Chief shall, at least once in 6 months or as deemed necessary, inspect or cause to be inspected all buildings, except for single-family residential property, for the purpose of determining the safety of such buildings, including the sufficiency and adequacy of detection, suppression and alarm systems of doors, passageways, aisles, stairways, and, generally, facilities for egress in case of fire or other accident, the overloading of floors, and storage of combustibles. 
Cross reference— Inspections for fire hazards, § 50-36. 
(6)  The Fire Chief, or a designated subordinate, shall have the right to enter upon the premises wherein any fire has occurred, if necessary, in order to investigate the origin of the fire. 
(7)  The Fire Chief shall attend all major fires occurring in the Village. In the case of the Fire Chief's absence from any fire, it shall be the duty of a Deputy Fire Chief, or the highest ranking officer in command of the fire companies at such fire, to take charge of the Department. Such officer shall have and exercise all powers of the Fire Chief. 
(8)  The Fire Chief shall cause to be examined all buildings and walls reported dangerous or damaged by fire or accident, and shall, when requested by the Village Manager or designee, also examine all buildings under application to raze, enlarge, alter or rebuild, and make a report of the condition thereof as requested. 
(9)  The Fire Chief shall make rules and regulations not inconsistent with the Board of Fire and Police Commissioners' rules and regulations concerning the Fire Department; provided that, before taking effect, such rules and regulations shall have been submitted to and approved by the Village Manager. 
(10)  The Fire Chief shall evaluate and determine needs for training and plan and direct necessary orientation and in-service measures. 
(11)  The Fire Chief shall make a full and complete annual report to the Village Manager of all Fire Department matters for the preceding year. Such report shall show the number of fires, causes thereof, all accidents by fire, the number of and description of buildings destroyed or damaged, property destroyed by fire and insurance thereon, and such statistics and suggestions as deemed suitable. 
(Code 1979, § 5.05)  
Sec. 2-326. - Authority of Fire Chief and other officers at scene of fire. 
(a)  The Fire Chief, or, in the absence of the Fire Chief, the officer in command at any fire, shall have the power to cause the removal of any property whenever it shall become necessary for the preservation of such property from fire, or to prevent the spreading of fire, or to protect adjoining property. 
(b)  The Fire Chief, or, in the absence of the Fire Chief, the officer in command at any fire, may direct the members of the Fire Department to cut down and remove any building, structure or fence when deemed necessary. 
(c)  The Fire Chief, or any other officer in command at any fire, may prescribe limits in the vicinity of any fire within which no persons, except firefighters, police officers, and those admitted by any officer of the Fire Department, shall go, and the Police Department shall, upon the request of the Fire Chief, or other officer in command of the Fire Department at any fire, enforce the provisions of this subsection. 
(d)  The Fire Chief and other officers of the Fire Department in command at any fire shall have the right to give orders to any person present at a fire concerning the extinguishment of the fire and the removal and protection of property and persons. 
(Code 1979, § 5.06)  
Sec. 2-327. - Badges. 
The Village shall furnish every member of the Fire Department with a badge designating the member's rank in the Department, which shall be returned to the Village upon termination of employment. 
(Code 1979, § 5.071)  
Sec. 2-328. - Interfering with firefighters or other officers. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to interfere with a firefighter in performance of the firefighter's duty, or to refuse or neglect to furnish any member of the Fire Department help or information pertaining to the cause or origin of any fire, or to hinder any fire investigation in any manner. 
(Code 1979, § 5.072)  
Sec. 2-329. - Impersonating firefighter or other officer. 
It shall be unlawful for any person not a member of the Fire Department to impersonate a firefighter or officer of the Fire Department at any time, by wearing a uniform, cap, insignia, or badge or in any other way attempting to create the impression that such person is a member or official of the Fire Department. 
(Code 1979, § 5.073)  
Sec. 2-330. - Duty of members to enforce regulations; police powers. 
It shall be the duty of all members of the Fire Department to see that the provisions of this Code relating to the authority, functions and duties of the Fire Department are enforced, and to that end all such members are hereby vested with the power and authority of police officers; provided, however, they shall not be subject to the statutory requirements or privileges of the regular members of the Police Department, or be entitled to any additional compensation. 
(Code 1979, § 5.074)  
Sec. 2-331. - Mandatory retirement age for firefighters. 
The age of 65 shall be the maximum age for the employment of any sworn member of the Fire Department, with the exception of the positions of Chief, Deputy Chief, and Captain and for those affected employees at the time of adoption of Village Ordinance Number 07-7-C-3521, who at the time of their appointment to the department were over 35 years. 
(Ord. No. 07-7-C-3521, § 2, 7-2-2007)  
Secs. 2-332—2-350. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 7. - POLICE DEPARTMENT[12] 

Footnotes: 
--- (12) --- 
Cross reference— Board of Fire and Police Commissioners, § 2-461 et seq.; Board of Trustees of the Police Pension Fund, § 2-511 et seq.; law enforcement, ch. 62. 
 
Sec. 2-351. - Creation. 
There is hereby established a Village Police Department for the protection of lives and property within the limits of the Village, the enforcement of Village ordinances and related police functions. 
(Code 1979, § 6.01)  
Sec. 2-352. - Personnel. 
Personnel of the Village Police Department is established as follows: 
(1)  The Mayor and Board of Trustees shall, from time to time, determine the number of police officials necessary for the effective operation of the Police Department. 
(2)  The Police Department shall have the following offices and they are hereby created: Chief of Police, Captains, Lieutenants, Sergeants, and such other and further designations and ranks as authorized by the Board of Trustees through the annual budget process. 
(Code 1979, § 6.02)  
Sec. 2-353. - Appointment of employees. 
All sworn personnel in the Police Department shall be appointed in accordance with the provisions of 65 ILCS 5/10-2.1-4 and rules and regulations of the Board of Fire and Police Commissioners and applicable collective bargaining agreements, except as may be otherwise provided in this division. 
(Code 1979, § 6.03)  
Sec. 2-354. - Appointment of Chief of Police. 
The Chief of Police shall be the ranking officer of the Department. The Chief of Police shall be appointed by the Village Manager. 
(Code 1979, § 6.03)  
Sec. 2-355. - Qualifications of Chief of Police. 
No person shall be eligible to hold the office of Chief of Police unless such person shall possess technical training in and knowledge of principles and accepted good practices and procedures as applied to patrol, traffic control, criminal investigation, crime prevention, juvenile delinquency control work, and general police administration. Such person shall have considerable knowledge of the standards by which the quality of police service is evaluated and the use of police records and their application to police administration. Such person shall have considerable knowledge of the types and uses of firearms, communications, and automotive equipment in modern police work. Such person shall have a knowledge of the function of federal, State, and local jurisdictions and authorities as they relate to police work. Such person shall have the ability to plan, lay out and supervise the work of subordinates performing police activities, and to develop proper training and instructional procedures for those employees, and to maintain a high level of discipline and morale. Such person shall have had experience in modern police work which has afforded progressively responsible experience in a variety of police functions, including responsible supervisory police duties, and graduation from an accredited university, or college with at least a bachelor's degree, supplemented by formal training in modern police administration and practices. 
(Code 1979, § 6.04)  
Sec. 2-356. - Duties of Chief of Police. 
It shall be the duty of the Chief of Police to: 
(1)  Provide for the custody, care, and control of the public property of the Police Department, including all firearms and other equipment, and the books and records of the Police Department. 
(2)  Devote full time to the duties and responsibilities of the office. 
(3)  Preserve the peace, order, safety and cleanliness of the Village. 
(4)  Execute and enforce all ordinances and police regulations and orders of the Mayor and Board of Trustees and of the Village Manager. 
(5)  Protect the rights of persons and property within the Village. 
(6)  Take notice of all nuisances, and at all times render all assistance necessary to departments of the Village in abatement thereof. 
(7)  Take notice of all impediments, obstructions and defects in the walks, streets, avenues and public places of the Village, and remove such impediments, obstructions or defects or cause immediate notice thereof to be given to the proper person, including those whose duty it may be to attend to the removal of such impediments, obstructions or defects, according to the ordinances of the Village. 
(8)  Cause to be executed all orders transmitted to the Chief of Police by the Village Manager. 
(9)  Aid the Fire Department by giving alarms in case of fire, and in clearing the streets or grounds in the immediate vicinity of all fires so that the members of the Fire Department shall not be hindered or obstructed in the performance of their duties. 
(10)  Study police problems in matters of public welfare and administration as related to crime and law enforcement and make recommendations thereon to the Village Manager. The Chief of Police shall investigate, study, and recommend to the Village Manager from time to time traffic regulations, routings, and changes therein with a view to improving traffic conditions and lessening congestion in the streets and other places in the Village. 
(11)  Make such rules and regulations consistent with Board of Fire and Police Commissioners' rules and regulations and applicable collective bargaining agreements concerning the Police Department. Such rules and regulations shall be submitted to and approved by the Village Manager before becoming effective. 
(12)  Make a full and complete annual report to the Village Manager of all Police Department operations for the preceding year. Such reports shall show a detailed statement of the transactions of the Police Department for the preceding year, and such statistics and suggestions in regard to the requirements of the Department as the Chief of Police may deem advisable. 
(13)  For the purpose of carrying the provisions of this section into effect, cause to be detailed a sufficient number of the police force to make from time to time, and as often as may be necessary, a thorough and systematic examination of the Village, to ascertain and report to the proper authority for prosecution of all violations of the ordinances. 
(Code 1979, § 6.05)  
Sec. 2-357. - Police powers of Village officers and employees. 
All elected and appointed Village officials and specified employees, including Plumbing and Structural Inspectors, Electrical Inspectors, Sanitarians, Housing Inspectors, and their assistants, Fire Prevention Inspectors, License Officers, and Water Inspectors, are hereby constituted conservators of the peace as law enforcing officers and are hereby authorized and shall have power to: 
(1)  Charge or cause to be arrested by a police officer, with or without process, all persons who break the peace or are found violating any Village ordinance or any criminal law pursuant to the statutes of the State. 
(2)  Exercise all other powers as the Mayor and Board of Trustees may prescribe. 
(Code 1979, § 6.06) 
Cross reference— Officers and employees, § 2-61 et seq.  
Sec. 2-358. - Special police. 
(a)  Appointment of citizens. The Chief of Police, with the approval of the Village Manager, may, in time of peril, danger, riot, or pestilence, or apprehension thereof, and at all conflagrations, and during any public election or celebration, or unusual congregation of people in the Village, appoint as special police officers as many private persons, of good moral character, not otherwise employed by the Village, for a specified time, as the Chief of Police may deem necessary, and during the term of service such special police officers shall possess only the powers specified by the Chief of Police, and be subject to all rules and regulations covering the Police Department, all applicable Village Ordinances and all applicable statutes and regulations of the State pertaining to police officers of the Village. The Chief of Police shall not authorize any individual special police officer to use a weapon in the course of performing the duties of the special police appointment unless the individual appointee has previously and satisfactorily completed a course of training in the use of weapons in the performance of police duties, which course of training must be authorized and approved for the individual prior to the appointment as a special police officer. 
(b)  Appointment of Village employees. The Chief of Police, with the approval of the Village Manager, may in like manner, and under any of the circumstances mentioned in subsection (a) of this section, appoint persons of good moral character, who may be in the employment of the Village in other branches of the Village government, as special police officers. Village employees appointed as special police officers in accordance with this section shall receive no additional pay for their services as such special police officers. Such special police officers shall possess only the powers and privileges specified by the Chief of Police, and shall be subject to all the rules and regulations governing the Police Department, all applicable Village Ordinances and all applicable statutes and regulations of the State pertaining to police officers of the Village. The Chief of Police shall not authorize any individual special police officer to use a weapon in the course of performing the duties of the special police appointment unless the individual appointee has previously and satisfactorily completed a course of training in the use of weapons in the performance of police duties, which course of training must be authorized and approved for the individual prior to the appointment as a special police officer. 
(c)  Appointment of guards for special duty. The Village Manager may, on application of any person showing the necessity thereof, appoint and swear in any additional number of special police officers to do special duty at any fixed place within the Village, at the charge and expense of the person by whom the application was made. Persons so appointed shall conform and shall be subject to all rules and regulations governing the Police Department, and to such special rules, regulations and restricted powers and privileges as the Chief of Police may make concerning such special police officers. The Chief of Police may, at any time, with the consent of the Village Manager, remove or discharge from service any such special police officers, without assigning any cause therefor. 
(d)  Reports of appointments. It shall be the duty of the Village Manager or designee to report to the Board of Fire and Police Commissioners and to the Mayor and Board of Trustees, at the first regular meeting of the Mayor and Board of Trustees held after any appointment, all appointments of special police officers made by the Village Manager or the Police Chief, the duration of and the reasons for the appointments of special police officers. 
(Code 1979, § 6.07)  
Sec. 2-359. - Lost, stolen or seized property. 
(a)  Custodian. One of the employees of the Police Department shall be designated by the Chief of Police to be the custodian of lost and stolen property. Such person shall at all times be under the supervision and direction of the Chief of Police. As the custodian, such person shall take possession of all property seized or taken by the police. 
(b)  Disposition. The custodian shall keep a record of all property which may be seized or otherwise taken possession of by the Police Department. If such property shall not be claimed by the rightful owner and possession surrendered to such owner within 30 days from the date of such seizure or taking by the police, the custodian shall proceed to dispose of such property as follows: 
(1)  In all cases where any lost or unclaimed property is delivered into the custody of the Police Department by any person not the owner thereof, the property shall, at the end of the 30-day period, be delivered to the finder for purposes of disposition by the finder as provided in 765 ILCS 1020/27—1020/36. At the option of the finder, the Village may for its own account proceed to dispose of the property in accordance with the provisions of Illinois Compiled Statutes. 
(2)  Where the Police Department is the original finder or taker of lost or stolen property or where the Police Department obtains possession of any unclaimed property arising out of a court proceeding in connection with which such property was seized, then, upon such property remaining unclaimed for the 30-day period, the custodian shall publish or cause to be published, in the official newspaper of the Village, a description of such property, together with the date of seizure or the taking of possession thereof, and shall give notice that, if such property be not claimed by the rightful owner or owners thereof within 10 days from the date of such publication, such property will be sold at public auction at such places as the Chief of Police may direct and in such manner as to expose to the inspection of bidders all property so offered for sale, provided that if such unclaimed property is deemed by the Chief of Police to be of use to the Police Department, the property may be taken for the use of the Department. 
(3)  In addition to the publication of notice provided for in this subsection, the custodian of lost and stolen property shall post or cause to be posted, in at least 3 public places in the Village, a copy of the notice published in the official newspaper, and shall make a record of the date when such publication and the posting of notices are made. If, within 10 days from the date of such publication and posting, no claim for such property described in such notices shall have been made by the rightful owner thereof, the custodian shall proceed to sell such property at public auction. 
(c)  Weapons. None of provisions of this section shall apply to pistols, revolvers, knives, slingshots, metallic knuckles or other deadly weapons of like character, but all such weapons shall be either destroyed or retained for use by the Police Department. 
(d)  Disposition of proceeds of sale. The proceeds of any sale or sales so made after ownership shall have vested in the Police Department as provided for by the statute, and after deducting the cost of storage, advertising, selling, and other expenses incident to the handling or selling of such property, shall be paid to the Village Treasurer for the general fund. 
(Code 1979, § 6.08)  
Sec. 2-360. - Mandatory retirement age for police officers. 
The age of 65 shall be the maximum age for the employment of any sworn member of the Police Department, with the exception of the positions of Chief, Deputy Chief, and Commander, and for those affected employees at the time of adoption of Village Ordinance Number 07-7-C-3521, who at the time of their appointment to the department were over 35 years of age. 
(Ord. No. 07-7-C-3521, § 3, 7-2-2007)  
Secs. 2-361—2-380. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE V. - CODE OF ETHICS[13] 

Footnotes: 
--- (13) --- 
State Law reference— State Gift Ban Act, 5 ILCS 425/1 et seq.; pecuniary interest in contracts, 65 ILCS 5/4-8-6. 
 
Sec. 2-381. - Declaration of policy. 
The proper operation of democratic government requires that public office not be used for personal gain. In recognition of this goal there is hereby established the code of ethics set out in this article, for all officials and employees, whether elected or appointed, paid or unpaid. The provisions and purpose of this article and such rules and regulations as may be established pursuant to this article are hereby declared to be in the best interest of the Village. 
(Code 1979, § 3.161)  
Sec. 2-382. - Conflict of interest generally. 
(a)  No elected official or other official or employee, whether paid or unpaid, shall engage in any business or transaction or shall have a financial or other personal interest, direct or indirect, which is incompatible with the proper discharge of such person's official duties in the public interest or would tend to impair such person's independence of judgment or action in the performance of such person's official duties. Personal as distinguished from financial interest includes an interest arising from blood or marriage relationships or close business association. 
(b)  The following are hereby designated as constituting conflicts of interest: 
(1)  Engaging in or accepting private employment or rendering services for private interests when such employment or service is incompatible with the proper discharge of official duties or would tend to impair independence of judgment or action in performance of official duties. 
(2)  Appearing on behalf of private interests before any agency of the Village except without compensation and only in the course of duties as a representative of the electorate or in the performance of public or civic obligations. 
(3)  Failing to disclose the full nature and extent of a substantial or controlling financial interest in or any substantial dealings as a debtor, creditor or otherwise in connection with any business entity contracting with the Village for the sale of real estate, materials, supplies or services. Such official, with or without such disclosure, shall refrain from voting upon or otherwise participating in any such transaction, contract or sale. 
(Code 1979, § 3.162)  
Sec. 2-383. - Disclosure of income. 
An official or employee, whether paid or unpaid, who has a direct or indirect financial or other interest in any transaction, the disposition of which may be influenced by such person's official position or action, shall disclose all sources of income and the nature and extent of any personal interest in such transaction as an officer, agent, member, or owner of any business entity or other association which is subject to regulation by the Village. Such disclosure shall remove any presumption of conflict of interest for any transaction where the information disclosed is pertinent. 
(Code 1979, § 3.163)  
Sec. 2-384. - Appearing before agency in which formerly employed. 
It shall be improper for any administrative member of the staff or any appointive employee serving on the Plan Commission or the Zoning Board of Appeals to appear within a period of 2 years after the termination of such person's employment from the Village, or the termination of the appointive official's term of office, before the agency in which such official or employee was formerly employed in connection with any case or other matter with which such official or employee was directly connected while an official or employee, or as a member of the Plan Commission or Zoning Board of Appeals. 
(Code 1979, § 3.164)  
Sec. 2-385. - Enforcement. 
Nothing contained in this article shall create or detract from the civil or criminal liability of any public official or employee, or any other laws or ordinances or procedures, rules and contracts. Violations of any provisions of this article shall constitute a cause for suspension, removal from office or employment, or other disciplinary action by the appropriate authority. In the case of elected officials, a violation shall result in the issuance of a public proclamation calling upon the affected official to resign the official's office in the best interests of the Village. 
(Code 1979, § 3.165)  
Sec. 2-386. - Applicability of State Officials and Employees Ethic Act. 
(a)  Adoption of Act. 
(1)  The regulations of Sections 5-15 (5 ILCS 430/5-15) and Article 10 (5 ILCS 430/10-10 through 10-40) of the State Officials and Employees Ethics Act, 5 ILCS 430/1-1 et seq. (hereinafter referred to as the "Act"), are hereby adopted by reference and made applicable to the officers and employees of the Village to the extent required by Section 70-5 of the Act. 
(2)  The solicitation or acceptance of gifts prohibited to be solicited or accepted under Article 10 of the Act, by any officer or any employee of the Village, is hereby prohibited. The offering or making of gifts prohibited to be offered or made to an officer or employee of the Village under Article 10 of the Act, is hereby prohibited. 
(3)  The participation in political activities prohibited by Section 5-15 of the Act by any officer or employee of the Village is hereby prohibited. 
(b)  Definitions. 
(1)  For purposes of this Section 2-386, the term: (i) "employee" shall be defined as set forth in Section 70-5(c) of the Act; and (ii) "officer" shall mean each person holding the office of Mayor, Clerk, Deputy Clerk, Trustee, Corporation Counsel, Assistant Corporation Counsel, Village Manager and each person serving on a Board or Commission pursuant to Chapter 2, Article VII, of the Village Code. 
(2)  Terms and words used in this Section 2-386, other than "employee" and "officer" shall be defined as set forth in Section 1-5 of the Act, unless a different definition is clearly indicated in this section. For construction and interpretation purposes; (i) where ever the word "State" or term "State agency" is utilized in Sections 1-5 and 5-15, the word "Village" shall be substituted, except for the definition of "Governmental entity" in Section 1-5; (ii) prohibitions applicable to an "executive branch constitutional officer" and a "legislative branch constitutional officer" as referenced in Sections 1-5 and 5-15, are applicable to officers of the Village.; and (iii) certain definitions in Section 1-5 by their nature are inapplicable, including but not limited to, "Ultimate jurisdictional authority", subpart (5) of "Prohibited source," "Legislative leader". 
(c)  Penalties. 
(1)  Violations of this Section 2-386 may, in accordance with law, subject the employee or officer to: (i) a fine in amount not exceeding $750.00 or any penalty authorized by the Skokie Village Code; (ii) penalties stated in Section 50-5 of the Act; (iii) the appropriate discipline or discharge; or (iv) any combination of the foregoing. 
(2)  In the case of a violation of this Section 2-386 by an officer, the Mayor and the Board of Trustees shall make the decision in relation to any imposition of a penalty or the appropriate discipline or discharge. The Mayor and Board of Trustees have the authority to suspend without pay, or discharge, an officer appointed by them found to have violated this Section 2-386. In the case of a violation of this Section 2-386 by an employee, the Village Manager shall make the decision in relation to any imposition of a penalty or the appropriate discipline or discharge. 
(3)  The Mayor and Board of Trustees or the Village Manager, depending on the nature of the violation, may authorize or direct the Corporation Counsel to file the appropriate civil or criminal action in the Circuit Court if it is determined that penalties requiring a judicial order are appropriate for the violation at issue. 
(d)  Existing Ordinances and Policies. This Section 2-386 does not repeal any provision of the Skokie Village Code that regulates the conduct of Village officers and employees. This Section 2-386 does not repeal any policy in the Village of Skokie Personnel Manual that regulates the conduct of Village employees. To the extent that any provision of the Skokie Village Code or the Personnel Manual is more restrictive than the provisions of Section 5-15 or Article 10 of the Act, then the Code or Manual shall be applicable. 
(e)  Amendments to the Act. Any amendment to Section 5-15 or Article 10 of the Act that becomes effective after the effective date of this Section 2-386, shall be incorporated into this section by reference and shall be applicable to the employees and officers of the Village. However, any amendment that makes its provisions optional for adoption by municipalities shall not be incorporated into this Section 2-386 by reference without formal action by the Mayor and the Board of Trustees. 
(f)  Constitutionality. In the event the Illinois Supreme Court declares the Act unconstitutional in its entirety, then this Section 2-386 shall be repealed as of the date that the Illinois Supreme Court's decision becomes final without further action by the Mayor and Board of Trustees. If the Illinois Supreme Court declares part of Section 5-15 or Article 10 of the Act unconstitutional, but does not declare the remainder of Section 5-15 or Article 10 as unconstitutional, then the remainder of Section 5-15 or Article 10 adopted by this Section 2-386 shall remain in full force and effect. That part of this Section 2-386 relating to the parts of Section 5-15 or Article 10 of the Act found unconstitutional shall be deemed repealed without further action by the Mayor and Board of Trustees. 
(g)  Ethics Advisor. 
(1)  The Mayor, with the advice and consent of the Board of Trustees, shall designate an individual to serve as Ethics Advisor to provide ethical advice and guidance to all officers. 
(2)  The Village Manager shall appoint an individual to serve as an Ethics Advisor to provide ethical advice and guidance to all employees. The Village Manager may designate the duties of the Ethics Advisor, including but not limited to, investigating ethics complaints against employees and advising the Manager on appropriate action to be taken in relation to ethics complaints against employees. 
(3)  An Ethics Advisor may be an officer or an employee of the Village. A Temporary Ethics Advisor may be appointed in the event an ethical question or complaint arises in relation to an Ethics Advisor, and such Temporary Ethical Advisor shall perform the duties as performed by the Ethics Advisor. 
(h)  Ethics Governance. 
(1)  There is hereby created a commission to be known as the Officers Ethics Commission of the Village of Skokie. The Commission is charged with the responsibility of hearing ethical complaints made against officers of the Village and making recommendations to the Mayor and Board of Trustees. 
a.  The Commission shall be comprised of three members appointed by the Mayor, with the advice and consent of the Board of Trustees. No person shall be appointed as a member of the Commission who is related, either by blood or by marriage up to the degree of first cousin, to any elected officer of the Village. The Mayor shall designate one of the appointees to act as Chairperson. 
b.  All commissioners shall be appointed to 3-year terms and shall serve until their successors are duly appointed. Commissioners may be re-appointed to serve subsequent terms. 
c.  Meetings shall be held at the call of the chairperson or any 2 commissioners. A quorum shall consist of two commissioners and official action by the commission shall require the affirmative vote of two members. 
d.  The Mayor, with the advice and consent of the Board of Trustees, may remove a commissioner in case of incompetence, neglect of duty or malfeasance in office. 
e.  The Commission shall have the following powers and duties: 
1.  To promulgate procedures and rules governing the performance of its duties and the exercise of its powers; 
2.  To investigate, conduct hearings, deliberations and issue recommendations for the imposition of penalties or disciplinary actions. The Commission shall act only upon the receipt of a written complaint, signed and notarized, alleging a violation of this Ordinance and not upon its own prerogative; 
3.  To receive information from the public pertaining to its investigations and to require additional information and documents from officers who may have violated the provisions of this Section 2-386; and 
4.  To compel the attendance of witnesses and to compel the production of books and papers pertinent to an investigation. It is the obligation of all officers and employees of the Village to cooperate with the Commission during the course of its investigations. Failure or refusal of an officer to cooperate with requests by the Commission shall constitute grounds for a recommendation of penalty or discipline. The Commission shall notify the Village Manager of any request by it for a Village employee to appear before it, to be interviewed by an agent of the Commission or to provide any documents. 
f.  The powers and duties of the Commission are limited to matters clearly within the purview of this Section 2-386. The Mayor and Board of Trustees shall take action on any recommendation made by the Commission. The Mayor and Board of Trustees are not bound by the recommendation of the Commission and may impose any penalty or discipline, including but not limited to discharge, as they deem appropriate in accordance with law. Any action taken by the Mayor and Board of Trustees in relation to a recommendation by the Commission is a final decision for purposes of judicial review. 
g.  The Commission shall comply with the following procedures: 
1.  Within 7 business days after the receipt of a complaint, the Commission shall send by certified mail, return receipt requested, a notice to the Respondent that a complaint has been filed against him or her and a copy of the complaint. The Commission shall send by certified mail, return receipt requested, a confirmation of the receipt of the complaint to the complainant within 7 business days after receipt by the Commission. The notices to the Respondent and the complainant shall also advise them of the date, time, and place of the meeting to determine the sufficiency of the complaint and to establish whether probable cause exists to proceed; 
2.  The Commission shall meet to review the sufficiency of the complaint and, if the complaint is deemed sufficient to allege a violation of this Section 2-386, to determine whether there is probable cause to proceed, based on the evidence presented by the complainant. The meeting may be closed to the public to the extent authorized by the Open Meetings Act. The Commission shall issue notice to the complainant and the Respondent within 7 business days of the Commission's ruling on the sufficiency of the complaint and, if necessary, on probable cause to proceed; 
If there is a determination of probable cause, then the Commission's notice to the parties shall include a hearing date scheduled within 3 weeks. If the complaint is deemed not sufficient to allege a violation or if there is no determination of probable cause, then the Commission shall send by certified mail, return receipt requested, a notice to the parties of the decision to dismiss the complaint, and that notice shall be made public; 
3.  On the scheduled date, the Commission shall conduct a hearing on the complaint and shall allow both parties the opportunity to present testimony and evidence. The hearing may be closed to the public only if authorized by the Open Meetings Act; 
4.  Within 30 days after the date the hearing or any recessed hearing is concluded, the Commission shall either (i) dismiss the complaint or (ii) issue a recommendation to the Mayor and Board of Trustees for the imposition of a penalty or discipline, or both. The particular findings in the case, any recommendation for a penalty or discipline shall be a matter of public information; 
5.  If a complaint is filed during the 60 days preceding the date of any election at which the Respondent is a candidate, the Commission shall render its decision as required under subsection (h)(1)g.2. within 7 calendar days after the complaint is filed, and during the 7 days preceding that election, the Commission shall render such decision before the date of that election, if possible; and 
6.  A complaint alleging the violation of this Act must be filed within one year after the alleged violation. 
(2)  The Village Manager is charged with the responsibility of receiving and investigating ethical complaints made against employees of the Village and for imposing penalties or discipline, including but not limited to discharge. The Village Manager may utilize existing policies and procedures for conducting any investigation and imposing the appropriate penalty or discipline.
