(a)  Notwithstanding any other provision of the ordinances of the Village or this Code, all provisions of this Code or ordinances, except for those specified in subsection (c) of this section, may be enforced by instituting an administrative adjudication hearing with the Code Hearing Department as provided in this article. 
(b)  Notwithstanding any other provision of the ordinances of the Village or this Code, any enforcement action, including but not limited to license or permit suspension or revocation, which may be exercised by another department of the Village may also be exercised by the Code Hearing Department as provided in this article. 
(c)  Nothing in this article shall affect the jurisdiction of the Liquor Commissioner, the Human Relations Commission, the Firefighters' Pension Fund, the Police Pension Fund, the Zoning Board of Appeals, or the Board of Fire and Police Commissioners. 
(Code 1979, § 37.12)  
Sec. 2-1083. - Appeals. 
Any party to an administrative adjudication hearing may appeal from an adverse ruling to the Circuit Court of Cook County in accordance with the Illinois Code of Civil Procedure and applicable Cook County Circuit Court rules. 
(Code 1979, § 37.13; Ord. No. 09-3-C-3667, § 1, 3-2-2009)  
ARTICLE XI. - PUBLIC ARTS PROGRAM 
 
Sec. 2-1084. - Creation of a Public Arts Program. 
(a)  Public Arts Program established. A Public Arts Program is hereby established. The purpose of the Program is the acquisition and ownership of art by the Village for public display, and shall be under the supervision and direction of the Village Manager. 
(1)  Funding of the program. The Public Arts Program (hereinafter "Program") shall be funded through the collection of an Appearance and Arts Fee as stated in Section 46-44. The proceeds from the Appearance and Arts Fees shall be used to purchase, erect, construct, maintain and repair sculptures, art, landscapes, art features, murals, and other physical artistic features or structures for public display (hereinafter referred to as "public art"). 
(2)  Promulgation of rules and regulations. The Village Manager or designee shall develop rules and regulations for the maintenance, structural stability, insurance, and other logistical matters in relation to the public art selected for the program. 
(b)  Public Arts Advisory Committee. There is hereby established a Public Arts Advisory Committee (hereinafter "Committee"). 
(1)  Selection of art. The Committee shall develop policies and goals for the selection and placement of public art and shall approve the public art by a majority vote. 
(2)  Appointment of the Committee. The Committee shall be appointed by the Mayor with the advice and consent of the Village Board, and shall be comprised of five individuals, all of whom shall be residents of, or own or operate businesses in, or be employed in, the Village of Skokie. The Mayor may appoint no more than one employee of the Village. The Mayor shall appoint one of the individuals as the chairperson and he or she shall establish a schedule of meetings that will be open to the public. 
(3)  Compensation. Members of the Public Arts Advisory Committee shall serve without compensation, but will be entitled to reasonable reimbursement for expenses incurred in the accomplishment of its mission. 
(4)  Conflict of interest. No committee member or family member of a committee member, shall be eligible to sell or lease their art to the Village, as this is deemed a conflict of interest. 
(c)  Rights and duties of the Village Manager. 
(1)  The Village Manager or designee shall determine, with the consultation of the Public Arts Advisory Committee Chairperson, the amount to be proposed in the Village's annual budget for the program, to be approved the mayor and board of trustees. 
(2)  The Village Manager or designee may review the selection decision of the Committee in the event of a three vote majority. 
In the event of approval for the selection of public art by four or more votes, the Village Manager may review the decision solely for purpose of determining whether its cost can be achieved, the feasibility of location and its conformity with the Village Code and all other applicable statutes. 
(Ord. No. 07-4-C-3502, § 1, 4-16-2007)  
Secs. 2-1085—2-1089. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE XII. - TRAFFIC LAW ENFORCEMENT 
 
Sec. 2-1090. - Purpose. 
The purpose of this Article is to provide for the administrative adjudication of violations of those sections, also referred to as regulations, of the Skokie Village Code and the Illinois Compiled Statutes, referenced in Section 2-1093. The violations of (i) standing and parking regulations, and (ii) vehicle compliance regulations, including the (a) condition or use of equipment on a vehicle or (b) display of a municipal wheel tax license, shall be subjected to the administrative adjudication system. The intent is to provide a fair, equitable and efficient system for the enforcement of certain traffic violations. The administrative adjudication system set forth in this Article is established pursuant to Section 11-208.3 of the Illinois Vehicle Code, 625 ILCS 5/11-208.3 (2006) and Section 1-2.1-1 et seq. of the Illinois Municipal Code, 65 ILCS 5/1-2.1-1 et seq. (2006). 
The administrative adjudication system shall be applicable to automated traffic law violations upon the written notification by the Village Manager to the Chief of Police and the Traffic Compliance Administrator, informing them that that administrative adjudication of such violations shall begin on a date so specified. 
(Ord. No. 08-3-C-3605, § 3, 3-17-2008)  
Sec. 2-1091. - Definitions. 
Words or phrases used in this article shall have the following definitions: 
Automated Traffic Law Enforcement System means a system that utilizes a device as defined in Section 11-208.6 of the Illinois Vehicle Code. Specifically, it means the utilization of a device with one or more motor vehicle sensors working in conjunction with a red light signal to produce recorded images of motor vehicles entering an intersection against a red signal indication in violation of Section 11-306 of the Illinois Vehicle Code or similar provision of the Skokie Village Code. 
Automated Traffic Law Violation means a violation of the Section 11-306 of Illinois Vehicle Code, or similar provision of the Skokie Village Code, which is recorded and documented by an Automated Traffic Law Enforcement System. 
Business day means any day in which the office of the Village Clerk of the Village of Skokie is open to the public for a minimum of seven hours. 
IVC means the Illinois Vehicle Code, 625 ILCS 5/1-1 et seq. 
Motor vehicle or vehicle means every vehicle which is self-propelled, including, but not limited to, automobiles, trucks, vans, motorcycles and motor scooters, and shall include every vehicle defined by section 1-146 of the Illinois Vehicle Code. 
Owner means: (1) a person who holds legal title of a vehicle; or (2) in the event (i) a vehicle is the subject of an agreement for the conditional sale or lease thereof with the right of purchase upon performance of the conditions stated in the agreement and with an immediate right of possession vested in the conditional vendee or lessee, or (ii) a mortgagor of such vehicle is entitled to possession, then such conditional vendee or lessee or mortgagor shall be deemed the owner. For the purposes of determining the identity of an owner, the records of the Illinois Secretary of State, or such similar office of another state, shall be presumed to be true and correct. Any person may, with the owner's written permission, perform any act that the owner is authorized to perform. 
Wheel tax license means the Village of Skokie vehicle license required by section 106-152 of the Skokie Village Code. The wheel tax license may be referred to at times as a Village vehicle sticker or Village vehicle license and such references shall not have any legal affect on a violation. 
(Ord. No. 08-3-C-3605, § 3, 3-17-2008)  
Sec. 2-1092. - Traffic Compliance Administrator. 
The Village Manager shall appoint a Traffic Compliance Administrator (hereinafter the "Administrator"). The Administrator shall have the authority to: 
(a)  Adopt, distribute and process standing, parking, and compliance violation notices, Automated Traffic Law Violation notices and other notices required by law or Village ordinances; 
(b)  Collect money paid as fines and penalties for violation of standing, parking, and compliance regulations and Automated Traffic Law Violations; 
(c)  Establish rules, regulations and procedures for the operation of an administrative adjudication system, with the concurrence of the Village Manager; 
(d)  Operate an administrative adjudication system, including the scheduling of administrative hearings; 
(e)  Compile and revise a vehicle immobilization eligibility list pursuant to Chapter 106, Division 5, and authorize immobilization of a vehicle for the failure to pay five or more final determinations; and 
(f)  Implement procedures for the suspension of driver's licenses, provide notices of impending driver's license suspension and make reports to the Illinois Secretary of State, pursuant to Section 6-306.5 of the IVC, for the failure to pay ten or more final determinations of violation liability. 
The Administrator may delegate duties and assign functions that he or she may otherwise be required or authorized to perform. The Administrator may rely on the address of any Respondent or owner provided by the Illinois Secretary of State, or similar office in another state, on the date of the violation notice and shall not have a duty to inquire further for an updated or new address for a Respondent or owner. 
(Ord. No. 08-3-C-3605, § 3, 3-17-2008)  
Sec. 2-1093. - Violations and fines. 
Violation of the below listed parking, standing and vehicle compliance regulations shall be punishable by applicable fines and penalties in the dollar amounts provided below. Determination of liability for such violations shall be made pursuant to the Village's administrative adjudication system. 
Violation 	FINE 	FINE PLUS LATE PENALTY 	MAXIMUM PENALTY 
106-39 Violation of provisions of Illinois Vehicle Code, Child Passenger Protection Act or Skokie Park District Ordinances 	$50.00 	$65.00 	$250.00 
106-102 Obstructing traffic 	$50.00 	$65.00 	$250.00 
106-103 Stopping, standing, parking in prohibited locations 	$50.00 	$65.00 	$250.00 
106-103(a)(7) Parking within 15 feet of a fire hydrant 	$100.00 	$150.00 	$250.00 
106-103(a)(20) Parking in a Fire Lane 	$100.00 	$150.00 	$250.00 
106-105 Prohibited commercial vehicle parking 	$50.00 	$65.00 	$250.00 
106-106 Prohibited parking of boats, boat trailers and recreational vehicles 	$50.00 	$65.00 	$250.00 
106-107 Parking restrictions after snowfall 	$60.00 	$75.00 	$250.00 
106-108 Parking restrictions for loading or unloading a vehicle 	$50.00 	$75.00 	$250.00 
106-109 Metered parking violation 	$50.00 	$75.00 	$250.00 
106-110 Permit parking in residential areas 	$50.00 	$75.00 	$250.00 
106-111 Reserved parking for persons with disabilities 	$250.00 	$300.00 	$350.00 
106-111(c) Permit parking for persons with disabilities in residential areas 	$35.00 	$50.00 	$250.00 
106-112 Parking for prohibited purposes 	$50.00 	$75.00 	$250.00 
106-114 Municipal Parking lot restrictions 	$50.00 	$75.00 	$250.00 
106-152 Village Wheel tax license required 	$50.00 	$75.00 	$250.00 
106-157 Village Wheel tax license display 	$50.00 	$75.00 	$250.00 
 
The administrative hearing officer may impose a fine including penalties for late payment up to $250.00; provided, however, the maximum fine and late penalties that may imposed for improper use of a parking space reserved for a disabled person is $350.00. 
A violation notice may be written subjecting any owner of a vehicle to the administrative adjudication process contemplated by this Article for violations of any parking, standing and vehicle compliance regulations in the Code or IVC, regardless of whether it is listed in the above chart. In such case, the owner would be subject to a $35.00 fine, a $50.00 fine plus late payment penalty and a maximum penalty of $250.00. 
(Ord. No. 08-3-C-3605, § 3, 3-17-2008; Ord. No. 09-5-C-3677, § 1, 5-18-2009; Ord. No. 09-11-C-3718, § 1, 11-16-2009; Ord. No. 19-2-C-4444, § 1, 2-19-2019)  
Sec. 2-1094. - Violation notice. 
A violation notice shall be issued for a violation of a regulation referred to in Section 2-1093. A violation notice may be commonly referred to as a ticket or citation and such reference shall not affect the enforcement of the violation notice. 
(a)  A violation notice shall, at a minimum, state the following information: 
(1)  The date, time and place of the violation; 
(2)  The specific regulation violated; 
(3)  The fine that is assessed; 
(4)  The vehicle make; 
(5)  The state registration number of the vehicle, or if no registration number is available, then the vehicle identification number; 
(6)  The maximum amount that can be imposed including late penalties; and 
(7)  The Village identification number of the person issuing the notice. 
(b)  Whenever any vehicle is in violation of the standing, parking or compliance regulations listed in Section 2-1093, except for seat belt or child passenger protection statutes, each and every owner of the vehicle shall be prima facie liable and responsible for the violation and subject to the applicable fine and penalties for late payments. An owner shall be known as a "Respondent." Any police officer, parking enforcement officer or other person so designated by the Village Manager, who observes a violation may issue a violation notice. The violation notice shall be served on the owner of the vehicle by affixing it to the vehicle, or by handing the violation notice to the operator of the vehicle, if an operator is present. 
(c)  Whenever any operator or passenger is in violation of section 2-1093 for violation of seat belt requirements stated in Section 12-603.1 of the IVC or the Child Passenger Protection Act, the violation notice shall be served on the person in violation of the regulations by handing the notice to that person. The person identified in the violation notice for violating said statutes shall be known as the "Respondent." 
(d)  Whenever any vehicle is determined to have committed an Automated Traffic Law Violation, each and every owner of the vehicle shall be prima facie liable and responsible for the violation and subject to the applicable fine and penalties for late payments. An owner shall be known as a "Respondent." The Village, or its approved contractor, operating the Automated Traffic Law Enforcement System shall serve a violation notice on each owner of the vehicle by first class mail to the address of the owner as recorded by the Secretary of State or such similar office in another state. 
(e)  Whenever any vehicle or trailer is observed in violation of the regulation requiring the purchase or proper display of a Village wheel tax license, issuance and service of the violation notice shall be accomplished in the same manner and method specified in paragraph (b) of this Section. 
(f)  The Village's Director of Finance, or designee, is authorized to make a comparison of the list of vehicles or trailers registered to owners having an address in the Village, as provided by the records of the Secretary of State, to the list of vehicles or trailers that have purchased a Village wheel tax license. In the event the Director, or designee, determines that there is a vehicle or trailer registered to an owner having an address in the Village, but a valid or current Village wheel tax license for the vehicle or trailer has not been purchased in compliance with this Code, then the Director or designee shall issue a violation notice on each and every owner of the vehicle or trailer. This notice shall be served by first class mail or in person. 
(g)  The failure to name a specific owner on a violation notice does not relieve an unnamed owner from being liable or responsible for the violation, nor does it affect enforceability of the violation notice against any owner. The Village may seek to collect all fines and late penalties from any owner whether or not that owner was named on the violation notice, provided, however, that should an owner pay a fine and late penalties, the Village may not collect the same fine or late penalties from another owner. 
(h)  The person issuing and serving a violation notice shall certify as to the correctness of the facts entered on the violation notice by signing his or her name to the notice at the time of service, or in the case of a notice produced by a computerized device, by signing a single certificate to be kept by the Administrator attesting to the correctness of all violation notices produced by the device while it was under the person's control. In the case of an Automated Traffic Law Violation, a determination must be made by a technician, based on an inspection of recorded images, that the vehicle was being operated in violation of Section 11-208.6 of the IVC. The technician shall execute the appropriate form certifying that a determination of violation was made. 
(i)  The original or a copy of the violation notice, or a printed record of the notice generated by a computer device, showing the facts entered on the notice, shall be retained by the Administrator. A violation notice issued, signed and served in accordance with this Section, a copy of the notice, or the computer generated record, shall be prima facie correct and shall be prima facie evidence of the correctness of the facts shown on the notice. The notice, copy, or computer generated record shall be admissible in any subsequent administrative or legal proceeding without the need to provide foundation. The person issuing or certifying the violation notice is not required to appear at an administrative or legal proceeding in order to have the violation notice admitted. 
(Ord. No. 08-3-C-3605, § 3, 3-17-2008)  
Sec. 2-1095. - Administrative adjudication. 
Each person to whom a violation notice is issued against (a "Respondent"), shall have an opportunity for a hearing before an Administrative Hearing Officer (the "Hearing Officer"). The hearing will be conducted at the request of the Respondent on a scheduled date, at which the Respondent may contest the merits of the alleged violation. 
A Respondent may be represented by counsel at their own expense but need not secure such representation. The formal or technical rules of evidence shall not apply at the administrative hearing, however, all evidence offered must be relevant to the issues raised. 
The Hearing Officer shall be appointed by the Mayor with the consent of the Board of Trustees. The Hearing Officer shall not be an employee of the Village. The Hearing Officer's compensation will be set by ordinance. The Hearing Officer shall serve until such person is removed by the Mayor or replaced by a subsequent appointment of a new Hearing Officer by the Mayor with the consent of the Board. The Hearing Officer shall be an attorney, in good standing, that has been licensed to practice law in Illinois for more than five years prior to the appointment and must demonstrate sufficient training and experience to serve in the capacity as a Hearing Officer. In the event the Hearing Officer is unable to attend a scheduled hearing, the Corporation Counsel may appoint an attorney to serve as a temporary Hearing Officer. 
The Hearing Officer shall have the authority and powers that are necessary to conduct fair and impartial hearings, including, but not limited to, the powers granted to an Administrative Law Officer in Section 2-1072 (b) of the Skokie Village Code. 
(Ord. No. 08-3-C-3605, § 3, 3-17-2008; Ord. No. 09-5-C-3677, § 1, 5-18-2009)  
Sec. 2-1096. - Rights and duties of respondents. 
Each Respondent shall have the rights and duties stated herein. 
(a)  A Respondent shall, upon issuance and service of the violation notice pursuant to this Division, have 21 days from the date of issuance of the notice to do one of the following: 
(1)  Pay the amount of the fine indicated on the notice; 
(2)  Request an administrative hearing either in person at Village Hall or by mail; or 
(3)  Contest the merits of the alleged violation in writing. The proper information, as specified on the instructions attached to the violation notice, and all supporting documentation on behalf of the Respondent's position, must be submitted to the Administrator. The submittal may be mailed or delivered to Village Hall. 
In order to comply with the 21 day deadline referenced above, the Respondent must either appear at Village Hall to make the appropriate payment, request or written contest no later than the 21st day after the issuance of the violation notice, or if mailed, the submittals must be postmarked with a date that is no later than the 21st day after the issuance of the violation notice. 
(b)  In the event the Respondent pays the full amount of the fine within 21 days of the date of issuance of the violation notice, then such payment shall be a final disposition of the violation. 
(c)  In the event a Respondent makes a request for an administrative hearing within 21 days of the date of issuance of the violation notice, whether made in person or by mail, then the Administrator shall schedule the violation to be heard at the next available hearing date. The Administrator shall provide written notice of the hearing date and time to the Respondent by first class mail or in person. 
(d)  In the event a Respondent submits a written contest of the violation notice within 21 days of the issuance of the violation notice, the Administrator shall submit the written contest, together with all documentation provided by Respondent, and other relevant information, to the Hearing Officer. In the event a Respondent does not submit a written contest within 21 days of the date the violation notice is issued, the Respondent is deemed to have waived the right to submit a contest by mail. 
(e)  In the event a Respondent does not take any of the actions specified in paragraph (a) above, then the Administrator shall cause an additional notice (hereinafter the "Late Notice") to be sent by first class mail to the Respondent. For violations other than seat belt or child passenger protection regulations, the Late Notice shall be sent to at least one owner, but may be sent to each and every owner of the vehicle, if there are multiple owners, naming them as additional Respondents. The Late Notice shall inform the Respondent(s): 
(1)  that payment is late and a penalty for late payment is imposed; 
(2)  Respondent must pay the fine and penalty for late payment, schedule a hearing date to contest the violation, or contest the violation in writing pursuant to the procedures stated in paragraph (a)(3), above, within 14 days of the date of the Late Notice, otherwise a determination of liability will be issued by the Hearing Officer and a fine and penalty imposed up to $350; 
(3)  the ability to contest by mail has been waived; 
(4)  of all of the same information regarding the violation as required on the initial violation notice (or attach a copy of the violation notice); and 
(5)  that the failure to pay amounts owed or appear at a requested hearing shall result in a determination of violation liability and after the appropriate period for judicial review, the amount of the fine and penalty for late payment shall become a debt due and owing the Village. 
(f)  All hearing dates scheduled by the Respondent are firm. A Respondent is entitled to reschedule a hearing date one time. The request to reschedule must be made by a Respondent, or someone authorized in writing to act on the Respondent's behalf, in person or in writing to the Administrator prior to the hearing date. All other requests to continue a hearing must be made before the Hearing Officer. 
(g)  Unless an owner provides written notice of a new or different address, the Administrator may rely upon the address of each owner as indicated on the records kept by the Secretary of State, or similar office in another state, as of the date of the issuance of the violation notice. Subsequent to the issuance of a violation notice, it is the duty of each Respondent and owner to keep his or her address of record current with the Administrator. 
(Ord. No. 08-3-C-3605, § 3, 3-17-2008; Ord. No. 09-5-C-3677, § 1, 5-18-2009)  
Sec. 2-1097. - Defenses. 
(a)  The only defenses available to a Respondent to contest a violation notice regarding standing or parking of a vehicle, or the condition or use of vehicle equipment compliance (other than for seat belt or child passenger protection regulations), or an Automated Traffic Law Violation, are as follows: 
(1)  The cited vehicle or license plate was stolen at the time the violation notice was issued; 
(2)  The facts alleged in the violation notice contain inaccurate information to the extent that the facts fail to establish that the violation occurred; 
(3)  The Respondent was not the registered owner of the referenced vehicle on the date of the violation notice, provided, however, a determination in favor of one Respondent shall not have any affect on the liability of any other owner of the vehicle; or 
(4)  Other verifiable information exists which proves that the violation did not occur. 
(b)  The only defenses available to a Respondent upon the issuance of a violation notice for failure to purchase or display a wheel tax license are as follows: 
(1)  The Respondent did not own or lease the vehicle or trailer at the time the violation notice was issued, or had not exceeded the period of time allowed for the purchase or display of the license pursuant to this Code; or 
(2)  All owners of the vehicle or trailer are not required by State law to display or purchase a wheel tax license. 
(Ord. No. 08-3-C-3605, § 3, 3-17-2008)  
Sec. 2-1098. - Determinations by the hearing officer. 
The Hearing Officer shall preside over all proceedings at the administrative hearing. The Hearing Officer shall make a determination of violation liability or no liability based upon the facts presented at the hearing. Such determination shall be included in an order entitled, "Hearing Officer's Determination." The standard of proof is a preponderance of the evidence. 
(a)  In the event a Respondent makes a timely request for administrative hearing, however, Respondent does not appear at the hearing or does not pay the fine prior to the hearing date, the Hearing Officer shall make a determination of violation liability and enter the appropriate findings or orders imposing the fine. 
(b)  In the event the Administrator has issued a Late Notice, however, Respondent does not request a hearing, contest the violation in writing, or does not pay the fine and late penalty within 14 days of the Late Notice, the Hearing Officer shall make a determination of violation liability and enter the appropriate findings or orders imposing the fine and penalties up to the maximums allowed by law. 
(c)  In the event a Respondent has timely filed a written contest to the violation notice, then the Hearing Officer shall review all information submitted by Respondent and other relevant information presented by the Administrator. The Hearing Officer shall make a determination of liability or no liability, solely based upon the documents and information presented, and enter the appropriate findings or orders. 
(d)  In the event a Respondent appears at an administrative hearing to contest, or present a defense to, the merits of the violation notice, the Hearing Officer shall allow the Respondent to present relevant testimony and documents, or other evidence, in support of Respondent's position. The person issuing and serving the violation notice is not required to appear at the administrative hearing due to the properly prepared violation notice being deemed to be prima facie evidence of the facts stated therein. The Hearing Officer shall make a determination of violation liability or no liability and enter the appropriate findings or orders. 
In the event the Hearing Officer makes a determination of violation liability, the appropriate order shall be mailed by the Village via first class mail to Respondent, and to other owners if the other owners were given notice of the pending violation. The order shall bear the date of mailing on its face and specify the amount owed for a fine and penalty for late payment incurred, if any. In the event the Hearing Officer determines that a Respondent is not liable for the violation, then the appropriate order shall be entered and made a part of the file. If the finding of no liability was the result of a contest by mail, then a copy of the order shall be mailed via first class mail to the Respondent. 
(Ord. No. 08-3-C-3605, § 3, 3-17-2008; Ord. No. 09-5-C-3677, § 1, 5-18-2009)  
Sec. 2-1099. - Petition to set aside a determination. 
Whenever an administrative hearing is held for the purpose of determining the question of violation liability, and the Respondent does not appear, the Respondent may file a written petition with the Administrator to set aside a Hearing Officer's Determination of violation liability. 
(a)  In order to have such petition considered by the Administrator, the Respondent must file the petition with the Administrator in person or by mail no later than 14 days after the date that the Hearing Officer's Determination of violation liability is mailed to Respondent. The date on the Hearing Officer's Determination informing the Respondent of violation liability shall be presumed to be the date that the order was mailed unless another mailing date is indicated. 
(b)  The only grounds for setting aside the Hearing Officer's Determination are limited to: (i) the Respondent was not the owner of the vehicle referenced on the date of the alleged violation, provided, however, such defense is not available for a seat belt or child passenger protection regulations; (ii) the fine and penalty, if any is applicable, was paid prior to the hearing; or (iii) an excusable reason for the failure to appear at the hearing or request a new date for a hearing, supported by documents or other credible information, upon which a new hearing date will be assigned by the Administrator and notice of such date will be mailed to Respondent. 
(c)  Upon the Administrator's denial of a petition to set aside the Hearing Officer's Determination of liability, or upon the expiration of the 14 day period for filing such petition without a filing being made, the Hearing Officer's determination is a "final decision" for purposes of judicial review. The Administrator shall notify the Respondent of the decision on the petition via first class mail. Should the Administrator assign a new hearing date pursuant to paragraph (b)(iii), above, then the determination is not considered a final decision. Should the Respondent fail to appear at the newly assigned hearing date, then the Respondent shall not have the right to petition the Administrator to set aside a subsequent determination of violation liability and the Hearing Officer's Determination of violation liability shall be a "final decision" for purposes of judicial review. 
(d)  A Respondent that appears at the administrative hearing does not have the right to petition the Administrator to set aside the Hearing Officer's Determination. In such case, the Hearing Officer's Determination is a "final decision" for purposes of judicial review. 
(e)  A Respondent does not have the right to file a petition to set aside a Hearing Officer's Determination which is based upon the Respondent's failure to request a hearing, or pay the fine and late penalty, within 14 days of the Late Notice. 
(Ord. No. 08-3-C-3605, § 3, 3-17-2008; Ord. No. 09-5-C-3677, § 1, 5-18-2009)  
Sec. 2-1100. - Judicial review; notice of final determination of violation liability. 
All Respondents have the right to seek judicial review of any Hearing Officer's Determination that is or becomes a "final decision". Any petition seeking judicial review must be filed in the Circuit Court of Cook County in accordance with the Administrative Review Act. 
Upon the conclusion of any judicial review procedures wherein the Hearing Officer's Determination is upheld by the Circuit Court, or after the expiration of the time for which a petition for judicial review is allowed to be filed without the petition being filed, then the Administrator will send a "Notice of Final Determination of Violation Liability" to the Respondent, and to other owners if the other owners had received prior notice of the violation. Upon the issuance of a Notice of Final Determination of Violation liability the amount owed the Village shall be collectable by the Village pursuant to all procedures allowed by law or this Code, including, but not limited to, seeking a judgment in the Circuit Court or referral to a debt collection agency. 
The Notice of Final Determination of Violation Liability shall: 
(a)  advise the Respondent that the Hearing Officer's Determination of violation liability is final and has resulted in a debt due and owing the Village for the amounts of any unpaid fine and penalties, if any; 
(b)  contain a warning that the failure to pay any fine and penalties due and owing the Village, may result in the Village taking actions to collect the amounts owed, including, but not limited to, the filing of a petition with the Circuit Court to have the unpaid amounts rendered a judgment or referring said debt to a debt collection person; 
(c)  state that the failure to pay any fine and penalties may result in suspension of the person's driver's license for (i) 10 or more Final Determinations of Violation Liability, pursuant to Section 6-306.5 of the IVC, or (ii) 5 or more Automated Traffic Law Violations, pursuant to Section 11-208.6 of the IVC; or 
(d)  state that the failure to pay any fine and penalties may result in the vehicle being eligible for the vehicle immobilization program for 5 or more Final Determinations of Violation Liability. 
(Ord. No. 08-3-C-3605, § 3, 3-17-2008)  
Secs. 2-1101—2-1199. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE XIII. - ENVIRONMENTAL POLICY 
 
Sec. 2-1200. - [Purpose.] 
It is the policy of the Village of Skokie to work towards becoming a "Sustainable Community." 
(Ord. No. 08-12-C-3652, § 1, 12-1-2008)  
Sec. 2-1201. - [Strategy development.] 
A strategy, that includes an action plan, shall be developed to ensure steady progress towards becoming a Sustainable Community. A successful strategy and action plan must be comprehensive across the Village governmental activities, and eventually embrace the conduct and behaviors of residents, property owners and businesses. 
(Ord. No. 08-12-C-3652, § 1, 12-1-2008)  
Sec. 2-1202. - [Environmental Officer designated.] 
The Village Manager shall designate an employee to perform the functions of an "Environmental Officer," whose duties shall include coordinating compliance with the Environmental Best Practices Policy, as stated in Section 2-1204 of this Article, and assist with environmental analysis or provision of information in the decision-making process. The Environmental Officer may utilize the service of assistants and shall have such other duties as assigned by the Village Manager. 
(Ord. No. 08-12-C-3652, § 1, 12-1-2008)  
Sec. 2-1203. - [Examination by Decision Makers.] 
All decisions made by the corporate authorities and executive staff (the "Decision Makers") shall examine the outcome in relation to the sustainable and environmental policies, goals and objectives (the "Environmental Best Practices Policy"). This examination shall consider the economical feasibility of such outcome utilizing alternative approaches before committing resources. The Environmental Best Practices Policy shall apply to decisions relating to: (i) Village government operations and expenditures; and (ii) efforts or actions to encourage residents, property owners and businesses, including developers and contractors, to adhere to the goals and objectives stated. 
(Ord. No. 08-12-C-3652, § 1, 12-1-2008)  
Sec. 2-1204. - [Environment Best Practices Policy.] 
The Environmental Best Practices Policy shall develop over time. Initially, the Policy requires that Decision Makers take into consideration the following goals and objectives: 
a.  Limit the amount of water, fuels, energy, minerals, wood fiber, paper products, plastics, pesticides, and chemicals used by the Village to the minimum amount necessary to adequately deliver products and services to residents, property owners and businesses. This may be achieved by various techniques including, but not limited to, maximizing efficiencies or use of alternative resources. 
b.  Reduce the production and release of pollution through a combination of technology and product or process substitution. 
c.  Avoid adverse environmental consequences by protecting air and water quality, water table, natural conditions, wildlife habitat and physical environment. 
d.  Evaluate the true cost of goods or products by factoring the useful life, operation and maintenance costs, and ultimate disposal costs for comparison purposes. When cost considerations are nearly equal, preference to contractors or vendors that use energy efficient or reused or recycled products should be a priority. 
e.  Recycle and reuse as much of the Village's waste stream as is economically and technically feasible. 
f.  Explore and encourage water treatment methods that treat storm water as an asset for reuse and to recharge the ground water supply. 
g.  Associate with coalitions of governments and other organizations and entities to achieve the goals and objective. 
(Ord. No. 08-12-C-3652, § 1, 12-1-2008)  
Sec. 2-1205. - [Environmental Education and Outreach Program.] 
The Village shall undertake an on-going Environmental Education and Outreach Program designed to inform residents, property owners and businesses that everyday individual actions do matter. The Program shall, amongst other things: 
(a)  Provide useful and actionable information; 
(b)  Explore sustainable opportunities and assist residents in living a more sustainable lifestyle; 
(c)  Improve the public's understanding of recycling opportunities; 
(d)  Encourage residents, and others, to present their ideas and suggestions to the Sustainable Environmental Advisory Commission or the Village; and 
(e)  Establish a series of awards to be presented to residents, property owners or businesses for actions consistent with the goals and objectives stated in Section 2-1204 of this Article. 
(Ord. No. 08-12-C-3652, § 1, 12-1-2008)  
Secs. 2-1206—2-1230. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE XIV. - SIDEWALK INSTALLATION AND REPAIR 
 
Sec. 2-1231. - Creation of a Sidewalk Installation and Repair Program. 
A Sidewalk Installation and Repair Program is hereby established. The purpose of the program is to install public sidewalks where they do not exist, repair existing public sidewalks, and repair parkways, and shall be under the supervision and direction of the Village Manager or his designee. 
(Ord. No. 12-5-C-3905, § 1, 5-21-2012)  
Sec. 2-1232. - Funding of the program. 
The Sidewalk Installation and Repair Program shall be funded through the collection of a Sidewalk Installation and Repair Fee as stated in Section 46-45. The proceeds from the Sidewalk Installation and Repair Fees shall be used to install public sidewalks where they do not exist, repair existing public sidewalks, and repair parkways. 
(Ord. No. 12-5-C-3905, § 1, 5-21-2012)  
Sec. 2-1233. - Promulgation of rules and regulations. 
The Village Manager or designee shall develop administrative rules and regulations for the Sidewalk Installation and Repair Program. 
(Ord. No. 12-5-C-3905, § 1, 5-21-2012)  
ARTICLE XV. - UTILITY RELOCATION AND UNDERGROUNDING 
 
Sec. 2-1234. - Creation of a Utility Relocation and Undergrounding Program. 
A Utility Relocation and Undergrounding Program is hereby established. The purpose of the program is to relocate or place utilities underground that are located in a public right-of-way for safety, to allow the redevelopment of sites, or for area redevelopment programs, and shall be under the supervision and direction of the Village Manager or his designee. 
(Ord. No. 19-2-C-4444, § 2, 2-19-2019)  
Sec. 2-1235. - Funding of the program. 
The Utility Relocation and Undergrounding Program shall be funded through the collection of a Utility Relocation and Undergrounding Fee as stated in Section 46-45. The proceeds from the Utility Relocation and Undergrounding Fees shall be used to relocate or place utilities underground that are located in a public right-of-way underground for safety, to allow the redevelopment of sites, or for area reinvestment programs. 
(Ord. No. 19-2-C-4444, § 2, 2-19-2019)  
Sec. 2-1236. - Promulgation of rules and regulations. 
The Village Manager or designee shall develop administrative rules and regulations for the Utility Relocation and Undergrounding Program. 
(Ord. No. 19-2-C-4444, § 2, 2-19-2019)  
Chapter 6 - ADVERTISING[1]
