Secs. 22-301—22-399. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE XII. - FLOODPLAINS AND FLOOD INSURANCE RATE MAPS 
 
Sec. 22-400. - Northern Illinois Model Floodplain Ordinance 2008. 
Pursuant to authority granted by the Illinois Municipal Code, 65 ILCS 5/1-2-1, 5/11-12-12, 5/11-30-2, 5/11-30-8 and 5/11-31-2 (2006), the Village hereby adopts by reference the Northern Illinois Model Floodplain Ordinance 2008, as modified, pursuant to Village Ordinance Number 08-8-C-3631. 
(Ord. No. 08-8-C-3631, § 1, 8-4-2008)  
Secs. 22-401—22-409. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE XIII. - VACANT BUILDINGS 
 
Sec. 22-410. - Declaration of policy. 
The purpose of this Article is to protect the public health, safety, and welfare of the residents and property owners of the Village by enactment of this Article which: 
(1)  Establishes a program for identification and regulation of nonresidential buildings which are or become vacant on and after the effective date of this chapter. 
(2)  Determines the responsibilities relating to property maintenance and standards of owners of vacant buildings. 
(3)  Provides for administration and enforcement of the regulations contained herein. 
(Ord. No. 09-3-C-3667, § 1, 3-2-2009)  
Sec. 22-411. - Definitions. 
Unless otherwise expressly stated or clearly indicated by the context, the following terms shall, for the purpose of this Article, have the meanings indicated in this section: 
Boarded building: A building which has had, in a manner intended to be temporary or permanent, any or all openings, which openings are windows or doors which were present for the purpose of light, ventilation or egress, some material whether opaque, solid or transparent, affixed to such openings, from the interior or exterior of the building, for the purpose of securing or preventing access or damage to the building or its components. 
Building: Any structure occupied or intended for supporting or sheltering any occupancy. 
Director: The Director of Community Development or his or her designee. 
Owner: Any person, agent, operator, firm, trust, or entity: (i) having a legal or beneficial interest in the property; (ii) acting as agent by managing, controlling, or collecting rent; (iii) listed or recorded in the official records of the state, county, or municipality as holding title to the property; or (iv) having control of the property, including, but not limited to, a mortgagee or the guardian, executor or administrator of the estate of any person described in the preceding clauses (i), (ii) and (ii). 
Person: Any individual or an entity of any type. 
Property: A lot, plot or parcel of land including any structure thereon. 
Vacant building: A nonresidential building or portion of a nonresidential building which is: 
(1)  Unoccupied for over thirty 30 days. 
(2)  Unoccupied buildings which are undergoing construction, renovation, or rehabilitation and are in compliance with all applicable ordinances, codes, legislation, and regulations, and for which construction, renovation or rehabilitation has stopped for a period of sixty (60) days. 
But not including: 
Unoccupied buildings which are undergoing construction, renovation, or rehabilitation and are in compliance with all applicable ordinances, codes, legislation, and regulations, and for which construction, renovation or rehabilitation is proceeding diligently to completion. 
(Ord. No. 09-3-C-3667, § 1, 3-2-2009)  
Sec. 22-412. - Code violation liability. 
(a)  In the event property is in violation of the Code or other ordinance, then the owner of the property is liable for such violation, whether the violation is existing or occurring, or may have existed or occurred at or during any time in regard to said property, or any buildings thereon. The owner is subject to injunctions, judgments, abatement orders or other remedial orders. 
(b)  The liabilities and obligations imposed on an owner of property shall be applicable to any mortgagee, that holds a mortgage on the property, or any other person that knowingly takes any action in any judicial or administrative proceeding that is intended to delay the correction of a violation, or compliance with the Code or other ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 09-3-C-3667, § 1, 3-2-2009)  
Sec. 22-413. - Owner responsibilities. 
The owner of any nonresidential building that is vacant, and any person maintaining, operating or collecting rent for any nonresidential building that has become vacant shall, within 30 days, shall do the following: 
(1)  Enclose and secure the building in a manner approved by the Village. Buildings shall only be boarded after application and receipt of a permit except for emergencies such as fire or wind damage for which an application shall be filed within 48 hours of the board up. A vacant building may not remain boarded longer than 90 days unless an extension of that time is part of a plan approved by the Director; 
(2)  Properties with 100 percent building vacancy shall have a sign affixed to the building indicating the name, address and telephone number of the owner and the owner's authorized agent. The sign shall be no smaller than two (2) feet by two (2) feet, but no larger than four (4) by four (4) feet and be placed in such a location so as to be legible from the nearest public street or sidewalk, whichever is nearer. In addition, for buildings which are the subject of a foreclosure action or have been foreclosed on, the name, address, and telephone number of the maintenance company shall be on the sign; 
(3)  Maintain the property including any building on the property, in a secure and closed condition; 
(4)  An alarm system shall be installed by the owner of any building that is 100 percent vacant no later than eleven (11) months after notification that the building is vacant. The property owner shall pay for the alarm service one year in advance prior to the annual Certificate of Compliance renewal of the property or vacant tenant space. The alarm service company and level of detection shall be subject to approval by the Village Manager or designee; 
(5)  Install a Knox "Rapid Entry" key box at all vacant buildings/units within 30 days of vacancy. Commercial and industrial buildings that already have a Knox box do not need to install a box for individual units; 
(6)  The owner of a vacant property with ground floor windows facing a street shall: 
a.  Window covering. Cover the windows with a window display or decorative screening approved by the Village. Each window shall have at least 80 percent coverage so as to obscure a direct public view of the building interior. Allowable window coverage materials must be of one color and shall be in the form of one of the following: 
1.  Plastic film; 
2.  Horizontal, pleated and vertical shades; 
3.  Pleated paper; 
4.  A display of products, with a backdrop, which are sold by other businesses in a building, art work or an alternative window covering may be permitted if submitted to and approved by the Village Manager or designee. 
b.  Window signage. The only type of window sign that shall be allowed is a real estate sign for the sale or rental of that property that does not exceed 25 percent of the total of a window pane area. Only one sign shall be allowed per street frontage for a building. A window sign shall not be allowed if a ground sign is used to advertise the sale or rental of the property. Additional window signs shall be allowed if the property is participating in the Village's Window Covering Program. 
(7)  Maintain the building and property in compliance with the requirements of the most recently adopted International Property Maintenance Code, Zoning Chapter, and all other codes and ordinances of the Village. These regulations include but are not limited to the following: 
a.  Maintenance of parking areas. 
1.  All parking areas shall be maintained at all times in broom clean condition, without potholes, broken wheel stops and/or curbing or other surface irregularities. 
2.  All landscaping shall be maintained in a flourishing condition, free of weeds and debris, and all dead landscaping shall be replaced. 
3.  Pavement markings shall be visible at all times, and parking lot signage shall be readable at all times, with the signpost maintained in an upright manner. 
4  All parking lot curbing shall be maintained and vehicle stop blocks securely mounted in their proper locations. 
5.  Compliance is required with all conditions of the Village's private property fire lane sign maintenance program and the Village's designation of private property handicapped parking spaces program. 
6.  All area lighting shall be maintained in functioning condition. Drainage systems shall be maintained in a free-flowing working condition. 
7.  It shall be unlawful to alter any aspects of an approved parking lot plan unless approval has been received through the Director of Engineering. 
8.  Parking areas shall be used exclusively for parking purposes and not for storage of vehicles, boats, trailers, campers or other personal property. 
9.  All parking lot drainage structures and facilities shall be maintained and in working order. 
b.  Maintenance of landscaping. 
1.  All landscaping on public or private property that is part of an approved development plan shall be properly maintained in a vigorous growing condition by the owner of the property. Any landscaping which has deteriorated shall be replaced. 
2.  All shrubbery shall be maintained to a height not to exceed 30 inches for a distance of 15 feet from any vehicular access point into or out of the site. All trees planted near the drives on the property are required to have a ground clearance of 6 feet minimum to the bottom of the foliage. 
3.  All property shall be maintained free from weeds or plant growth in excess of 6 inches in height. All noxious weeds shall be prohibited. Weeds shall be defined as all grasses, annual plants and vegetation, other than trees or shrubs provided; however, this term shall not include cultivated flowers or gardens. 
c.  Maintenance of exterior property areas. 
1.  All property shall be maintained in a clean, litter free, safe and sanitary condition. 
2.  All property shall be graded and maintained to prevent the erosion of soil and to prevent the accumulation of stagnant water thereon, or within any structure located thereon. 
3.  All sidewalks, walkways, stairs, driveways, parking spaces and similar areas shall be kept in a proper state of repair, and maintained free from hazardous conditions including ice and snow. 
4.  No vehicles that are inoperable shall be permitted to be stored in the open. 
5.  Open off-street parking shall be located upon an approved surface. 
6.  There shall not be accumulations of litter, decayed animal or vegetable matter, trash, rubbish, rotting lumber, appliances, tires, landscape waste, bedding, packing material, abandoned vehicles or machinery, scrap metal or any material in which flies, mosquitoes, disease-carrying insects, rats or other vermin may breed or which create a fire hazard. 
7.  There shall be no active rodent infestation. 
8.  Stagnant water in which mosquitoes, flies or other insects can multiply shall not be allowed. 
9  Substances or things on the property emitting or causing any foul, offensive, noisome, nauseous, noxious, or disagreeable odors, effluvia or stenches extremely repulsive to the physical senses of ordinary persons which annoy, discomfort, injure or inconvenience the health of any appreciable number of persons within the Village shall not be allowed. 
10.  Garbage, paper products, rubbish, litter or any offensive substance shall not be allowed. 
11.  Marking, carving or graffiti shall not be allowed on buildings, fixtures, or other structures on the property. 
12.  The property shall not be used for nuisance activities. 
d.  Maintenance of building exterior. 
1.  The exterior of a structure shall be maintained in good repair, structurally sound and sanitary so as not to pose a threat to the public health, safety, or welfare. 
2.  All exterior surfaces, including but not limited to, doors, door and window frames, cornices, porches, trim, balconies, decks and fences shall be maintained in good condition. Exterior wood surfaces, other than decay-resistant woods, shall be protected from the elements and decay by painting or other protective covering or treatment. Peeling, flaking and chipped paint shall be eliminated and surfaces repainted. All siding and masonry joints as well as those between the building envelope and the perimeter of windows, doors, and skylights shall be maintained weather resistant and water tight. All metal surfaces subject to rust or corrosion shall be coated to inhibit such rust and corrosion and all surfaces with rust or corrosion shall be stabilized and coated to inhibit future rust and corrosion. Oxidation stains shall be removed from exterior surfaces. Surfaces designed for stabilization by oxidation are exempt from this requirement. 
3.  All exterior walls shall be free from dents, holes, breaks, and loose or rotting materials; and maintained weatherproof and properly surface coated where required to prevent deterioration. 
4.  All cornices, belt courses, corbels, terra cotta trim, wall facings and similar decorative features shall be maintained in good repair with proper anchorage and in a safe condition. 
5.  After the removal of wall signs or other fixtures the wall shall be repaired and/or painted to have the same surface color and finish as the rest of the building wall to which it was attached. 
6.  Every window, skylight, door and frame shall be kept in sound condition, good repair and weather tight. 
7.  All glazing materials shall be clean and maintained free from cracks, holes or other defects. 
8.  Marking, carving or graffiti shall not be allowed on buildings, fixtures, or other structures on the property. 
9.  Painted or color treated surfaces shall have a consistent surface color that is not faded, chipped, or discolored. 
10.  Buildings that have been approved by the Appearance Commission shall be maintained in accordance with the approved plan. 
e.  Maintenance of building interiors. 
1.  The building shall remain vacant unless a Certificate of Occupancy is obtained for a new use. 
2.  All interior fixtures, fire alarms, sprinkler system, utilities, and structural elements of the building shall be maintained and protected from the elements. 
3.  There shall be no harborage of rodents and active infestation in the building. 
4.  The interior of the building shall be free from any accumulation of rubbish or garbage. 
5.  The building shall not be used for nuisance activities. 
f.  Maintenance and removal of signs. 
1.  Every sign box or structure shall be maintained in a safe, presentable, and sound structural condition. 
2.  To prevent rust, peeling, flaking, fading or rotting, all sign boxes and supports shall be painted unless they have been anodized or similarly treated. 
3.  Broken panels, missing letters, defective illumination, torn fabric, flaking or peeling paint and other damage to a sign shall be replaced or repaired. 
4.  The owner shall be responsible for the removal of unused signs. A sign box may display a blank sign face until such unit is occupied. 
5.  All ground signs shall be removed if a building is 100 percent vacant or the building is removed. 
6.  Any sign which presents an immediate danger to the public may be removed at the direction of the Village Manager or designee in accordance with the procedures set forth in this section. 
7.  Signs that have been approved by the Appearance Commission shall be maintained in accordance with the approved plan. 
(8)  Submit the property for a Certificate of Compliance inspection for the vacancy at the request of the Director. Submit the property for an annual inspection each fiscal year thereafter that the vacancy exists. Pay the initial inspection fee and an annual inspection fee as required in subsection 46-117(c) as a condition of obtaining a Certificate of Compliance. 
(9)  Acquire or otherwise maintain commercial general liability insurance for as long as the building is 100 percent vacant, and file evidence of such insurance with the director, as follows: two million dollars ($2,000,000.00) for a vacant manufacturing, industrial, storage, or commercial building. Any insurance policy acquired after the building is vacant shall require written notice to the Community Development Department of any lapse, cancellation or change in coverage. The owner and the owner's authorized agent for service of process shall provide evidence of the insurance, with certificates evidencing renewal or replacement of said policy of insurance at least fifteen (15) days prior to the expiration or cancellation of any such policy. The owner and the owner's authorized agent for service of process shall provide evidence of the insurance, upon request, to the Community Development Department. 
(Ord. No. 09-3-C-3667, § 1, 3-2-2009; Ord. No. 12-2-C-3887, § 1, 2-21-2012; Ord. No. 16-7-C-4236, § 1, 7-18-2016)  
Sec. 22-414. - Authority of the Village. 
The Village shall have the following authority: 
(1)  Inspect the exterior and interior of all vacant buildings, and the property on which the building is located, for compliance with all applicable codes. Such inspection will determine the extent of compliance with the Code or other ordinances. If the property is in compliance, a Certificate of Compliance will be issued, which will be valid for one year; 
(2)  To charge an initial inspection fee for all vacant buildings and an annual inspection fee each fiscal year thereafter that the vacancy exists. The Owner will be invoiced for the inspection fees as provided in section 46-117(c), within thirty (30) days of the inspection; 
(3)  Access to property, and any building thereon, to turn off electrical, gas, and water utilities in case of system failures or emergencies that may threaten the safety of the building or surrounding property. The Owner shall pay all costs related to the Village's disconnection of utilities and securing the building; 
(4)  Secure a building that is opened by unauthorized entry by persons other than the owner or to turn off utilities for safety purposes. The owner shall pay all costs related to the Village's efforts to secure the building; 
(5)  Nothing herein contained prohibits the Village taking immediate action to the extent permitted under this Code to condemn or otherwise remediate a building which is determined to be a public nuisance or pose a danger to the occupants of the building, or the public, health, safety or welfare. 
(Ord. No. 09-3-C-3667, § 1, 3-2-2009)  
Sec. 22-415. - Notice. 
The Village will give written notice to the property owner a minimum of 10 days in advance of entering a building for inspection or other non emergency purposes. 
(Ord. No. 09-3-C-3667, § 1, 3-2-2009)  
Sec. 22-416 - Rules and regulations to be promulgated. 
The Village Manager or designee, may issue rules and regulations for the administration of this Article. These rules may designate materials for covering windows and securing materials and methods which must be used when securing a building so that the material is reasonably incapable of being removed by trespassers or others acting without the building owner's consent. Any person who violates any provision of this section or of the rules and regulations issued hereunder shall be fined as set forth in section 2-1095. Every day that a violation continues shall constitute a separate and distinct offense. 
(Ord. No. 09-3-C-3667, § 1, 3-2-2009)  
Sec. 22-417. - Certification. 
A Certificate of Occupancy is required before occupancy by a new tenant or owner of a vacant building or unit in a building. The Director will require payment in full of all fees and liens imposed by the Village and the correction of all violations of the Code and other ordinances prior to any occupancy of a vacant building or unit in a building. 
(Ord. No. 09-3-C-3667, § 1, 3-2-2009)  
Secs. 22-418—22-499. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE XIV. - RENTAL UNIT REGISTRATION[9] 

Footnotes: 
--- (9) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 14-1-C-4030, § 2, adopted Jan. 6, 2014, supplied provisions to be added to this Code as Art. IX, §§ 22-500—22-518. In order to maintain the existing numbering style, at the discretion of the editor, this article has been included as Art. XIV, §§ 22-500—22-518. 
 
Sec. 22-500. - Definitions. 
For the purposes of this Article, the following definitions shall apply: 
1.  Common Exterior: The open space and exterior of a building on the premises and on adjoining property under the control of the property Owner. The premises or property shall include the principal building, accessory structures, driveways, parking areas and all improvements to the property. Such common areas may serve, in whole or in part, one or more Multi-Unit Building. 
2.  Common Interior: Any portion or part thereof of a Multi-Unit Building having communal areas (laundry, furnace, storage rooms, hallways, stairways, meeting rooms, etc.) and all other areas, but not including a Dwelling. Interior common areas shall also include structural, mechanical and other elements or areas of a Multi-Unit Building for which the Owner is directly responsible for the proper maintenance thereof. 
3.  Dwelling: Any rooms or group of rooms located within a building and forming a single habitable unit with facilities which are used or intended to be used for living, sleeping, cooking, bathing and eating. 
4.  Multi-Unit Building: A structure that is designed and built with two (2) or more Dwellings. 
5.  Operator: Any person who has charge, care, control or management of a rental unit or building, in which rental units are let, including but not limited to building managers, managing agents, brokers or superintendents. 
6.  Owner: Any person who alone, jointly or severally with others has legal title to any Multi-Unit Building, or Dwelling unit, with or without accompanying actual possession thereof; or is an executor, administrator, trustee or guardian of the estate of the Owner; is a mortgagee in possession, or is a senior officer or a trustee of the association of unit Owners of a homeowners' association. Owner shall also mean any homeowners' association or other legal entity having the charge, care or control of any common area which serves in whole or in part one or more Multi-Unit Buildings. 
7.  Person: Any individual, firm, association, partnership, corporation, trust or any other legal entity. 
8.  Residential Rental Unit: A Dwelling, whether in a Multi-Unit Building, single-family home, townhouse, co-op or any other structure that is occupied by individuals other than the Owner, pursuant to Section 22-505 of the Skokie Village Code, or is vacant, that is being advertised to rent or is rented, through the exchange of money, goods, or services. 
9.  Tenant: Any occupant of a Residential Rental Unit. 
10.  Neighborhood Standards Officer: A Village Officer trained in the Crime Free Housing Program, including the Crime Prevention Through Environmental Design Program, as well as other types of property management and standards training, and working under the supervision of the Police Department and in cooperation with the Property Standards Division. In addition, the Neighborhood Standards Officer shall complete training regarding fair housing statutes and domestic violence education. 
(Ord. No. 14-1-C-4030, § 2, 1-6-2014)  
Sec. 22-501. - Residential rental unit registration. 
All Owners of a Residential Rental Unit must register each and all of their Residential Rental Units owned and operated in the Village. A Residential Rental Unit must be registered with the Village of Skokie in order to have Tenants. 
A.  Residential Rental Unit Registration shall not be required for residential units in a Multi-Unit Building with more than four (4) Dwellings organized and owned pursuant to the Illinois Condominium Act 765 ILCS 605, et seq. 
(Ord. No. 14-1-C-4030, § 2, 1-6-2014)  
Sec. 22-502. - Registration prior to rental. 
Each and every Residential Rental Unit must be registered prior to it being offered for rent in any manner, including but not limited to listing with a leasing agent, print advertisement or signs posted on property. 
(Ord. No. 14-1-C-4030, § 2, 1-6-2014)  
Sec. 22-503. - Method of registration and fee. 
To obtain a Residential Rental Unit Registration the Owner must file the prescribed application with the Property Standards Division of the Community Development Department of the Village containing all of the required information to include but not be limited to property Owner, management name and contact information for both. Applications to register a Residential Rental Unit shall be obtained from the Property Standards Division of the Community Development Department. Any fee required for the Residential Rental Unit Registration shall be submitted with the application, as set forth in Section 46-135 of the Skokie Village Code and the date of a completed application submission with fee and confirmation of compliance with Section 22-508 of the Skokie Village Code, shall be the date of Residential Rental Unit Registration. Should the Owner decide not to rent or lease the Residential Rental Unit within ninety (90) days of Residential Rental Unit Registration, the Owner may apply for a refund of the registration fee. 
(Ord. No. 14-1-C-4030, § 2, 1-6-2014)  
Sec. 22-504. - Change of information or ownership. 
A.  Every Owner shall report to the Property Standards Division of the Community Development Department any change in information previously provided on the required Residential Rental Unit Registration application within twenty-one (21) days of such change. This information shall include, but not be limited to, the removal or change of any Owner or Operator pursuant to Section 22-500(7) of the Skokie Village Code, or a change in ownership interest of more than 50% of the building. 
B.  If the ownership of a Residential Rental Unit or Multi-Unit Building changes during the registration year, the new Owner shall be required to register the Residential Rental Units anew under the new Owner's name and pay a pro rata registration fee. No refund of any registration fee shall be paid to the former Owner. 
(Ord. No. 14-1-C-4030, § 2, 1-6-2014)  
Sec. 22-505. - Owner occupied exemption. 
A.  Any Residential Rental Unit which is Owner occupied as the Owner's primary residence is exempted from the requirements of registration. 
B.  All Owners must comply with and nothing in this Act shall be construed to negate or alter the provisions of the Skokie Fair Housing Act (Chapter 58, Article II, of the Skokie Village Code). However, no portion of this section shall curb the rights of an Owner as described in Section 58-37 of the Skokie Village Code. 
(Ord. No. 14-1-C-4030, § 2, 1-6-2014)  
Sec. 22-506. - Fee waiver. 
A.  Any Multi-Unit Building or Residential Rental Unit found to be substantially in compliance with all applicable ordinances, codes and regulations of the Village upon inspection, as described in Section 22-509 of the Skokie Village Code, for three (3) consecutive years shall have the Residential Rental Unit Registration Fee waived the following year and every year thereafter, unless and until noncompliance is found. 
B.  Any Multi-Unit Building or Residential Rental Unit which was substantially in compliance with all applicable ordinances, codes and regulations of the Village for the most recent inspection, prior to the enactment of this Ordinance, by the Property Standards Division of the Community Development Department shall have the Residential Rental Unit Registration Fee waived the following year and every year thereafter, unless and until noncompliance is found. 
(Ord. No. 14-1-C-4030, § 2, 1-6-2014)  
Sec. 22-507. - Owner seminar. 
The Owner or Operator applying for registration shall have successfully completed the Village Residential Rental Property Landlord Seminar (hereinafter "Village Seminar") within three (3) months from the date of registration. 
A.  An Owner or Operator of any Residential Rental Unit, who has successfully completed prior professional training commensurate with the Village Seminar, may apply to the Village Manager or designee for a waiver from the Seminar requirement. The Village Manager or designee, in his or her sole discretion, shall determine whether the applicant's prior professional training constitutes the substantial equivalent of the Village's Seminar. 
B.  An Owner or Operator who successfully completes the Village Seminar shall not be required to attend another Village Seminar during subsequent renewal of registration. However, if an Operator who completed the Village Seminar is replaced, the Owner or the new Operator shall attend the Seminar. 
C.  The Village Manager may require an Owner or Operator to re-attend and complete a Village Seminar if there are multiple code violations within an eighteen (18) month period. 
(Ord. No. 14-1-C-4030, § 2, 1-6-2014)  
Sec. 22-508. - Compliance and certification. 
A.  Every Residential Rental Unit shall be owned, operated and maintained in full compliance with all applicable ordinances, codes and regulations. 
B.  An Owner that continues to meet the following standards shall be designated by the Village as a Certified Owner, may advertise as a Certified Landlord, and will receive annual proof of Certification from the Village: 
a.  All Residential Rental property has been inspected by the Property Standards Division and is in substantial compliance as of the most recent inspection. 
b.  Owner agrees to allow Property Standards Division, in addition to its regular inspections, to confirm that each Residential Rental Unit is equipped with working smoke and CO detectors, and GFI outlets where required. 
c.  Owner or Operator has successfully completed the Village Seminar. 
d.  Owner agrees to submit all Residential Rental property to a security audit performed by the Neighborhood Standards Officer and is in substantial compliance as of the most recent audit. 
e.  Owner or Operator has contact information posted in compliance with Sec. 22-512. 
Any use of the "Certified" designation for any purpose shall make clear that it is the Owner/Landlord that is Certified, rather than any individual building or Dwelling. 
C.  Improper use of this designation shall be subject to fine. 
(Ord. No. 14-1-C-4030, § 2, 1-6-2014)  
Sec. 22-509. - Regular property inspection. 
A.  The Village shall conduct regular property inspections of every building containing a Residential Rental Unit. 
B.  Inspections shall be conducted by the Property Standards Division of the Community Development Department, in consultation with or with the participation of the Neighborhood Standards Officer working under the supervision of the Skokie Police Department. 
C.  The Owner or Operator shall make available at the time of inspection all leases with the Crime Free Addendum for each Residential Rental Unit. 
D.  The scope of any inspections conducted pursuant to this section shall be limited to the exterior areas, Common Interior and Common Exterior of the property and upon a request by an Owner, Operator or Tenant, may include the interior of a Dwelling. 
E.  Where any common area is shared by more than one Residential Rental Unit, no Residential Rental Unit served in whole or in part by such common area shall be deemed to be in compliance for the purposes of registration until the common area is in full compliance with all applicable ordinances, codes and regulations. 
(Ord. No. 14-1-C-4030, § 2, 1-6-2014)  
Sec. 22-510. - Registration terminates upon sale. 
Notwithstanding any provision contained in this Article, Residential Rental Unit Registration shall terminate upon the sale of the Multi-Unit Building or Residential Rental Unit. 
(Ord. No. 14-1-C-4030, § 2, 1-6-2014)  
Sec. 22-511. - Inspection upon sale. 
A.  Transfer Stamps shall not be issued for a Multi-Unit Building or Residential Rental Unit until an inspection has been performed by the Property Standards Division of the Community Development Department, and any and all code violations that have been identified have been corrected as verified by a subsequent re-inspection. 
B.  In the event the Owner disputes the determination of code violations, the Owner may request an administrative hearing. An Administrative Hearing Officer appointed by the Village shall conduct the review within five (5) business days from the date of request. Upon completion of the hearing, the Administrative Hearing Officer will issue a final determination. 
C.  After being notified of code violations, an Owner shall complete the necessary repairs and notify the Property Standards Division of the Community Development Department which shall conduct a reinspection within three (3) business days and issue a determination. 
D.  The initial Inspection Upon Sale report must be dated no more than one hundred eighty (180) days prior to the date of closing and dated no later than the day of the closing on the sale of the Multi-Unit Building or Residential Rental Unit. Inspection areas shall include exterior areas, Common Interior, Common Exterior and all Dwellings. 
E.  Transfer Stamps may be issued for a Multi-Unit Building or Residential Rental Unit which has code violations, identified by the Inspection Upon Sale report, when such violations are not corrected, if a cash bond is posted with the Village for 110% of the cost of the required work or proof is submitted showing that a loan is in place exclusively for such required work If a Multi-Unit Building or Residential Rental Unit which has code violations, identified by the Inspection Upon Sale report, is intended for demolition, Transfer Stamps may be issued once a cash bond is posted and the cash bond shall be returned once the demolition is completed. 
F.  The request for an Inspection Upon Sale must be made in writing, not less than twenty-eight (28) days prior to the closing for the sale and may be made prior to offering the Multi-Unit Building or Residential Rental Unit for sale. 
G.  The fee required for the Inspection Upon Sale shall be as set forth in Section 46-136 of the Skokie Village Code. 
(Ord. No. 14-1-C-4030, § 2, 1-6-2014)  
Sec. 22-512. - Owner identification posting. 
A.  Owner or Operator shall post a weather proof sign with his or her name and active phone number in the Multi-Unit Building's Common Exterior or Common Interior next to the front door and accessible to the public, no smaller than eight (8) inches by ten (10) inches. 
B.  Multi-Unit Buildings that are Owner occupied and contain four (4) Residential Rental Units or less are exempt from this posting. 
(Ord. No. 14-1-C-4030, § 2, 1-6-2014)  
Sec. 22-513. - Tenant application and tenant information. 
A.  No Residential Rental Unit shall be rented without the Owner or Operator obtaining a written application. 
B.  It is recommended that the written application request, but need not require, applicants' and all potential tenants' names (first, middle and last), addresses, birth dates, social security numbers (if any), driver's license numbers (if any), work and home telephone numbers with a list of the applicant's current and past residences during the previous three (3) years, including addresses and name of landlords. 
C.  A certification as to the correctness of the information being provided signed by all of the adult prospective Tenants should be part of the written application. 
D.  Reserved. 
(Ord. No. 14-1-C-4030, § 2, 1-6-2014)  
Sec. 22-514. - Occupancy. 
No Owner or Operator shall permit the maximum occupancy of any Residential Rental Unit to be exceeded. The maximum occupancy of any Residential Rental Unit shall be: 
Number of Bedrooms 	Maximum Number of Persons in Household 
Studio 	2 
1 	2 
2 	4 
3 	6 
4 	8 
5 	10 
6 	12 
 
Owner or Operator shall also comply with Section 22-183 of the Skokie Village Code and may request additional occupancy for bedrooms which exceed one hundred (100) square feet for one (1) additional occupant for every additional fifty (50) square feet of floor area. If there is any conflict between the two sections, the more restrictive section shall apply. The decision of the Property Standards Division of the Community Development Department shall be the sole determiner as to what constitutes a bedroom for purposes of occupancy and shall be binding. 
(Ord. No. 14-1-C-4030, § 2, 1-6-2014)  
Sec. 22-515. - Tenant rights and responsibilities. 
A.  No Tenant shall commit vandalism in or upon the building in which the Tenant's Residential Rental Unit is located, and no Tenant shall permit vandalism to occur or shall violate any of the provisions of this Article or any applicable ordinance, code or regulation of the Village in the Residential Rental Unit occupied by the Tenant. 
B.  Every Owner or Operator shall maintain the premises in compliance with all local, state, and federal codes and shall promptly make any and all repairs necessary to fulfill the obligation. 
C.  Every Tenant shall keep that part of the premises that he or she uses in a safe, clean and healthy manner. 
D.  Every Owner or Operator shall disclose to the Tenant in writing at or before the commencement of the tenancy, the name, address and telephone number of a Person authorized to manage the premises. 
E.  Every Owner or Operator shall notify all prospective Tenants in writing that "The Village of Skokie prohibits discrimination of real estate transactions based on race, color, religion, sex, creed, ancestry, national origin, disability, age, marital status, presence or age of children, sexual orientation or source of income (Chapter 58, Section 58-36 of the Skokie Village Code)." Such language may be included with other printed materials. 
F.  Every Owner or Operator shall attach to any lease or written rental agreement or similar document a copy of Chapter 22, Article XIV, Rental Unit Registration and Chapter 58, Article II, Discrimination and Fair Housing, of the Skokie Village Code. 
(Ord. No. 14-1-C-4030, § 2, 1-6-2014)  
Sec. 22-516. - Registration renewal. 
A Residential Rental Unit Registration shall be renewed annually. Any Residential Rental Unit and Owner that is not substantially in compliance with this Article and any and all applicable codes, including health, safety and building codes shall be required to pay double the registration fee. 
(Ord. No. 14-1-C-4030, § 2, 1-6-2014)  
Sec. 22-517. - Administration of this article. 
The Village Manager or designee shall administer this Article and may promulgate rules and regulations to carry out its enforcement. 
(Ord. No. 14-1-C-4030, § 2, 1-6-2014)  
Sec. 22-518. - Implementation. 
A.  Inspections of Residential Rental Units by the Property Standards Division of the Community Development Department and the Neighborhood Standards Officer shall be prioritized based on Nuisance Intervention and Prevention Committee findings, code violations, location, timing of last inspection, complaints and other conditions that warrant an increased level of review and intervention. 
B.  Each registration shall be an annual registration, the term of which shall commence on May 1 of a given year and shall terminate on the following April 30. 
(Ord. No. 14-1-C-4030, § 2, 1-6-2014)  
Secs. 22-519—22-620. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE XV. - INTERNATIONAL FUEL GAS CODE 
 
Sec. 22-621. - International Fuel Gas Code adopted. 
Pursuant to authority granted by 65 ILCS 5/1-3-2, the Village hereby adopts by reference the International Fuel Gas Code, 2012, as published by the International Code Council, Inc., as the fuel gas code. 
(Ord. No. 14-9-C-4090, § 1, 9-15-2014)  
Sec. 22-622. - Conflicting regulations. 
If any provision of the International Fuel Code is in conflict with any provision of any code, ordinance or rules and regulations of the Village, the code, ordinance or rules and regulations shall prevail and the conflicting provision of the International Fuel Gas Code shall have no force or effect. 
(Ord. No. 14-9-C-4090, § 1, 9-15-2014)  
Sec. 22-623. - Amendments to the International Fuel Gas Code. 
The International Fuel Gas Code adopted by reference in this article shall be modified as follows: 
(1)  101.1 Title. Insert "Village of Skokie" 
(2)  109. Means of Appeal. Delete entirely. 
(3)  301.2 Energy utilization. Delete International Energy Conservation Code and replace with State of Illinois Energy Code in the last sentence of the paragraph. 
(4)  301.1.1 Other fuels. Add after last sentence - Natural draft combustion appliances are prohibited within the building envelope of use group R occupancies. Exception: In Existing group use R buildings natural draft appliances may be installed with approval of the Village Manager or designee. 
(Ord. No. 14-9-C-4090, § 1, 9-15-2014)  
Secs. 22-624—22-650. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE XVI. - ILLINOIS ENERGY CONSERVATION CODE 
 
Sec. 22-651. - Illinois Energy Conservation Code adopted. 
Pursuant to authority granted by The Illinois Municipal Code, 65 ILCS 5/1-3-2, et seq., and the Illinois Energy Conservation Code, 20 ILCS 3125, the Village hereby adopts by reference Illinois Administrative Code, and all regulations thereto, as the energy code, excepting those provisions which are modified or deleted as provided in this article. 
(Ord. No. 14-9-C-4091, § 1, 9-15-2014)  
Sec. 22-652. - Conflicting regulations. 
If any provision of the Illinois Energy Conservation Code is in conflict with any provision of any code, ordinance or rules and regulations of the Village, the code, ordinance or rules and regulations shall prevail and the conflicting provision of the Illinois Energy Conservation Code shall have no force or effect. 
(Ord. No. 14-9-C-4091, § 1, 9-15-2014)  
Secs. 22-653—22-723. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE XVII. - MOUNTED TELECOM AND/OR CELL PHONE ANTENNAE ANNUAL INSPECTION[10] 

Footnotes: 
--- (10) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 19-4-C-4448, § 1, adopted April 1, 2019, set out provisions intended for use as Art. XVII, §§ 22-624—22-628. At the editor's discretion, to preserve the style of this Code, these provisions have been included as Art. XVII, §§ 22-724—22-728. 
Cross reference— Mounted telecom or telephone cell antennae inspection fee, § 46-139. 
 
Sec. 22-724. - Annual inspection required. 
All mounted telecom and/or cell phone antennae installation which have been reviewed, approved and have received all necessary permits and approvals for initial installation, on the rooftop or side of a structure or building, higher than 35 feet, not including the installed telecom and/or cell phone equipment, shall be inspected annually. The inspection will determine and ensure the structural safety of the mounted antennae. 
(Ord. No. 19-4-C-4448, § 1, 4-1-2019)  
Sec. 22-725. - Inspections. 
(a)  Access to location. It shall be the duty of the owner of the property or the person in charge of the premises to be inspected, to admit or authorize entry thereto, for the purpose of making the inspection, to any employee of the Village who is authorized or directed to make such inspection at any reasonable time that access to the antenna is requested or required. 
(b)  Refusal to permit inspection. Should a Village employee or authorized agent of the Village be refused access or be hindered in making an inspection, the Village Manager or designee may in addition to any other penalty provided, direct the removal of a telecom and/or cell phone antennae installation. 
(Ord. No. 19-4-C-4448, § 1, 4-1-2019)  
Sec. 22-726. - Separate inspections required for each antennae. 
While a single building or structure may house multiple telecom and/or cell phone antennae installations, each installation shall be deemed as separate and an inspection shall be required for each. 
(Ord. No. 19-4-C-4448, § 1, 4-1-2019)  
Sec. 22-727. - Authority of the Village. 
The Village shall have the following authority: 
(1)  To inspect the installation and mounting of each telecom and/or cell phone antennae installation annually. The Village may inspect by access to roof or location of mounted telecom and/or cell phone antennae installation or by an electronic inspection which may include use of a drone, of all equipment including but not limited to mounts and antenna; 
(2)  If upon inspection the Village deems it necessary, the Village, at its discretion, may require inspection and certification from a structural engineer as to the safety of the equipment installation or mounting. Such an inspection will be at the property owner's expense. 
(Ord. No. 19-4-C-4448, § 1, 4-1-2019)  
Sec. 22-728. - Inspection fee. 
The fee for the annual inspection in located in Chapter 46, Section 46-139 of the Skokie Village Code. 
(Ord. No. 19-4-C-4448, § 1, 4-1-2019)  
Chapter 26 - BUSINESSES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Advertising, ch. 6; alcoholic liquor, ch. 10; amusements and entertainments, ch. 14; community development, ch. 30; consumer protection, ch. 34; emergency services, ch. 38; fees, ch. 46; business license fees, § 46-71 et seq.; fire extinguisher servicers, § 50-39; foreign fire insurance companies, § 50-40; automobile service stations, § 50-41; day care centers, § 54-131 et seq.; day care homes, § 54-161 et seq.; longterm care facilities, § 54-221 et seq.; food service establishments, § 54-291 et seq.; peddlers and solicitors, ch. 78; private solid waste collectors, § 86-41 et seq.; taxation, ch. 98; telecommunications, ch. 102; utilities, ch. 110; vehicles for hire, ch. 114; home occupations in residential districts, § 118-79; district regulations for motor vehicle service stations, § 118-82; business districts, § 118-141 et seq.; industrial districts, § 118-171 et seq. 
State Law reference— Municipal power over certain businesses, 65 ILCS 5/11-42-1 et seq. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 26-1. - Applicability of general licensing provisions. 
The provisions of Article II of this chapter, relating to licenses, shall govern the businesses, occupations and uses licensed under this chapter where no provision to the contrary is provided. 
(Code 1979, § 42.01)  
Sec. 26-2. - License and permit fees. 
Unless otherwise stated in this chapter, the applicable license and permit fees for the businesses, occupations and uses licensed under this chapter shall be as set forth in Chapter 46. 
(Code 1979, § 42.02)  
Secs. 26-3—26-30. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - LICENSES AND PERMITS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference— Issuance and revocation of municipal licenses, 65 ILCS 5/11-60-1. 
 
Sec. 26-31. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Licensee means any individual, firm, association, partnership, corporation, trust, or other legal entity licensed or subject to license. 
Owner means any individual, firm, association, partnership, corporation, trust or other legal entity having sufficient proprietary interest in the endeavor subject to license to maintain and manage its operation. 
(Code 1979, § 41.01) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 26-32. - Application. 
Applications for licenses and permits under this chapter shall be made to the Village Manager or designee on forms prescribed and furnished by the Village Manager or designee. The Village Manager or designee may request additional information from the applicant. 
(Code 1979, § 41.02)  
Sec. 26-33. - Persons subject to license requirement. 
Wherever in this Code a license is required for the maintenance, operation, or conduct of any business or establishment, or for doing business or engaging in any activity or occupation, every person shall be subject to the requirements if, by such person's own acts or through an agent or employee, such person is held forth as being engaged in the business or occupation, or solicits patronage therefor, actively or passively, or performs or attempts to perform any such business or occupation in the Village. 
(Code 1979, § 41.03)  
Sec. 26-34. - Investigation of applicant; issuance. 
(a)  Upon receipt of an application for a license or permit where an inspection or investigation is required before the issuance of such permit or license, the Village Manager or designee shall cause an investigation to be made as to the applicant's business and moral character, and secure such other information as the Village Manager or designee deems necessary for the protection of the public good, in keeping with the license or permit required. The officer charged with the duty of making the investigation or inspection shall make a report thereon to the Village Manager or designee, favorable or otherwise, within 10 days after receiving the application or a copy thereof. 
(b)  If, as a result of such investigation, the applicant's character, business responsibility, or other matters concerning the application are found to be unsatisfactory, the Village Manager or designee shall endorse on such application disapproval and the reasons therefor and no permit shall be issued. The Village Manager or designee shall promptly notify the applicant that the application is disapproved, and that no license or permit will be issued. 
(c)  If, as a result of such investigation, the applicant's character, business responsibility, and other matters concerning the application are found to be satisfactory, the Village Manager or designee shall endorse on the application approval and the license or permit shall be issued on payment of the fee. 
(Code 1979, § 41.05)  
Sec. 26-35. - Fee. 
Every license or permit authorized or required by any provision of this Code shall be issued by the Village Manager or designee upon payment of the prescribed fee or tax in accordance with the schedule set out in Chapter 46, or as otherwise provided. 
(Code 1979, § 41.06)  
Sec. 26-36. - Bond. 
The Village Manager or designee is authorized to approve the security in all cases where any code, ordinance, and rule and regulation require a bond to be given to the Village before such license or permit shall be issued. The approved bond shall be filed with the Village. 
(Code 1979, § 41.07)  
Sec. 26-37. - Term. 
(a)  Licenses. All licenses shall terminate on April 30 of each year where no provision to the contrary is made. The Village Manager or designee shall mail to all licensees of the Village a statement of the time of expiration of the license held by the licensee, if an annual license, at least 3 weeks prior to the date of such expiration. A failure to send out notice or the failure of the licensee to receive it shall not excuse the licensee for a failure to obtain a new license or a renewal thereof, nor shall it be a defense in an action for operation without a license. 
(b)  Permits. Permits shall be valid for the period stated thereon. 
(Code 1979, § 41.08)  
Sec. 26-38. - Building and premises to comply with applicable regulations. 
No license shall be issued for the conduct of any business and no permit shall be issued for any thing or act if the premises, buildings, or location to be used for the purpose do not fully comply with the requirements of the applicable codes, ordinances, and rules and regulations. 
(Code 1979, § 41.09)  
Sec. 26-39. - Change of location of business. 
The location of any licensed business or occupation or of any permitted act may be changed provided 10 days' notice is given to the Village Manager or designee, provided that all codes, ordinances, and rules are regulations are complied with. 
(Code 1979, § 41.10)  
Sec. 26-40. - Transfer. 
(a)  When an existing business, for which a current and valid license is in effect, is sold or leased, the unexpired term of such license may be transferred to the purchaser or lessee of the business, provided the purchaser or lessee would qualify as an original applicant for such license. 
(b)  The provisions of this section do not apply to a license for the retail sale of alcoholic liquor. 
(c)  A fee shall be payable for the transfer of a license as provided in Section 46-72. 
(Code 1979, § 41.11)  
Sec. 26-41. - Citizenship not required. 
(a)  Except as otherwise provided by federal and State statutes, no person of good moral character who has a legal right to be gainfully employed in the United States shall be denied any license, permit or other privilege solely because such person is not a citizen of the United States. 
(b)  All of the provisions of the this Code contrary to subsection (a) of this section are hereby revoked to the extent necessary to effectuate this section. 
(Code 1979, § 41.12)  
Sec. 26-42. - Separate license required for each location. 
No license for the operation of a licensed establishment in the Village shall be construed by any person to permit the operation of a licensed establishment in more than 1 location in the Village. A separate license shall be required for each location of a licensed establishment. For this purpose, the determination of 1 location shall be construed that all buildings containing the principal or accessory uses shall be connected or on the same lot or parcel, be operated and managed by the same person or owner, and be an establishment with the same classification. Two or more buildings separated by 1 or more dedicated public rights-of-way or by 1 or more buildings or vacant lots or parcels shall not be considered as 1 location. 
(Code 1979, § 41.13)  
Sec. 26-43. - Nuisances. 
No business, licensed or not, shall be so conducted or operated as to amount to a nuisance in fact. 
(Code 1979, § 41.14)  
Sec. 26-44. - Inspections. 
(a)  Access to premises. Whenever inspections of the premises used for or in connection with the operation of a licensed business or occupation are provided for or required by ordinance, code, rule or regulation or are reasonably necessary to secure compliance with any ordinance, code, rule or regulation or to detect violations thereof, it shall be the duty of the licensee or the person in charge of the premises to be inspected to admit thereto for the purpose of making the inspection any officer or employee of the Village who is authorized or directed to make such inspection at any reasonable time that admission is requested or required. 
(b)  Samples of materials. Whenever an analysis of any commodity or material is reasonably necessary to secure performance with any ordinance, code, rule or regulation or to detect violations thereof, it shall be the duty of the licensee or the person in charge of the premises to be inspected to give to any authorized officer or employee of the Village requesting such samples sufficient samples of such material or commodity for such analysis upon request. 
(c)  Refusal to permit inspection. In addition to any other penalty which may be provided, the Manager may revoke the license of any licensed owner of any licensed business in the Village who refuses to permit any such officer or employee who is authorized to make such inspection or take such sample to make the inspection or to take an adequate sample of the commodity or who interferes with such officer or employee while in the performance of the officer's or employee's duties in making such inspection. No license shall be subject to revocation for such cause unless written demand is made upon the licensee or person in charge of the premises in the name of the Village stating that such inspection or sample is desired at the time it is sought to make the inspection or obtain the sample. 
(Code 1979, § 41.15)  
Sec. 26-45. - Display. 
It shall be the duty of every person conducting a licensed business in the Village to keep the license posted in a prominent place on the premises used for such business at all times. 
(Code 1979, § 41.16)  
Sec. 26-46. - Vehicle tags. 
Wherever the number of vehicles used is the basis of a license fee, the Village Manager or designee shall furnish the licensee with a tag or sticker for each vehicle covered by the license, and such tag or sticker shall be posted in a conspicuous place on each vehicle while it is in use. 
(Code 1979, § 41.17)  
Sec. 26-47. - Suspension of license, permit or certificate of occupancy. 
(a)  When the conduct of any licensee, agent or employee is so inimical to the public health, safety, and general welfare as to constitute a nuisance or give rise to an emergency, the Village Manager shall have the authority to summarily order the cessation of business, the close of premises, and suspension of the certificate of occupancy, license, and/or permit for a period not to exceed 10 days. 
(b)  Within 5 days after the Village Manager has acted summarily, the Village Manager shall conduct a hearing for the purpose of determining whether or not the certificate of occupancy, license and/or permit should be revoked in accordance with Section 26-48(b) and (c). 
(Code 1979, § 41.18; Ord. No. 01-12-C-3050, § 2, 12-17-2001)  
Sec. 26-48. - Revocation of license, permit or certificate of occupancy. 
(a)  Grounds. Certificates of occupancy, licenses, and permits issued by the Village, unless otherwise provided, may be revoked by the Village Manager after notice and hearing as provided in this section for any of the following causes: 
(1)  Any fraud, misrepresentation, or false statement contained in the application for the certificate of occupancy, license, and/or permit. 
(2)  Any violation by the licensee or permittee of the ordinance, code, rule or regulation provisions relating to the certificate of occupancy, license, and/or permit, the subject matter of a certificate of occupancy, license, and/or permit, to the premises occupied, or for the violation of any condition of a special use permit or zoning variation. 
(3)  Conviction of the certificate of occupancy holder, licensee, and/or permittee of any felony or of a misdemeanor involving moral turpitude. 
(4)  Failure of the certificate of occupancy holder, licensee, and/or permittee to pay any fee, fine, or penalty owning to the Village. 
(5)  Refusal to permit inspection or take samples, or interference with an authorized Village officer or employee while in the performance of his duties in making such inspections as provided in Section 26-44(c). 
(6)  Failure of the certificate of occupancy holder to operate in compliance with the plans and information submitted for the approval of the certificate of occupancy. 
(7)  Violation of any code, ordinance, statute, or rules and regulations. 
The revocation, if ordered, shall not be in lieu of any other provision imposing a penalty for the violation of any ordinance, code, rule or regulation of the Village. 
(b)  Notice of hearing. Notice of the hearing for revocation of a license or permit shall be given in writing, setting forth specifically the grounds of the complaint and the time and place of the hearing. Such notice shall be sent by certified mail, return receipt requested, or personally delivered, to the certificate of occupancy holder, licensee, and/or permittee to such persons' last known addresses at least 5 days prior to the date set for the hearing. 
(c)  Conduct of hearing. The office of the Corporation Counsel shall present the complaint and shall represent the Village. The certificate of occupancy holder, licensee, and/or permittee shall be permitted counsel and shall have the right to submit evidence and cross examine witnesses. The Village Manager shall preside and shall render the decision. 
(Code 1979, § 41.19; Ord. No. 01-12-C-3050, § 3, 12-17-2001)  
Sec. 26-49. - Appeals. 
Any person aggrieved by the decision of the Village Manager in regard to the denial of the application for a certificate of occupancy, license, and/or permit, or in connection with the revocation of a certificate of occupancy, license, and/or permit, shall have the right to appeal to the Mayor and Board of Trustees. Such appeal shall be taken by filing with the Mayor and Board of Trustees, within 10 days after notice of a denial of an application or a revocation, a written statement under oath setting forth specifically the grounds for appeal. The Mayor and Board of Trustees shall thereupon set the time and place for a hearing on such appeal, and notice of such hearing shall be given to the applicant or certificate of occupancy holder, licensee, and/or permittee in the same manner as provided in Section 26-48(b). The decision of the Mayor and Board of Trustees on such appeal shall be final. 
(Code 1979, § 41.20; Ord. No. 01-12-C-3050, § 4, 12-17-2001)  
Secs. 26-50—26-70. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - AUCTIONEERS[3] 
Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference— Authority to regulate auctioneers, 65 ILCS 5/11-42-1; sale by auction, 810 ILCS 5/2-328. 
 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 26-71. - Violations declared nuisance. 
The operation or maintenance of the business of auctioneer in violation of this article is declared a public nuisance as that term is defined in Section 42-35. The Village Manager may, in addition to other remedies provided for in Chapter 42, Article II, recommend that the Corporation Counsel seek injunctive relief.  
Sec. 26-72. - Conduct of patrons. 
All auctions shall be conducted in an orderly manner. It shall be unlawful to create, cause, permit or cause to permit any disturbance or disorderly conduct at any auction. 
(Code 1979, § 42.032)  
Sec. 26-73. - Fraudulent statements. 
It shall be unlawful for any person selling goods at auction to make any fraudulent or untrue statements concerning the goods or articles to be sold. 
(Code 1979, § 42.033)  
Sec. 26-74. - Right of patrons to inspect goods. 
Every article offered for sale in a public auction shall be open to the inspection of any person wishing to purchase it prior to or during the bidding. 
(Code 1979, § 42.034)  
Sec. 26-75. - Location. 
No goods, wares, merchandise or any other thing shall be sold or exposed for sale in any street, alley, or public place in the Village at auction. All auctions shall be held or conducted in a store, warehouse or other proper place, which shall be so arranged that none of the bidders or bystanders will be compelled or required to stand or remain on the street or sidewalk in front of such warehouse, store, or other place in such a manner as to obstruct free travel. 
(Code 1979, § 42.035)  
Sec. 26-76. - Attracting attention. 
No bellman or crier, or any instrument of music, or mechanical reproducing device such as a loudspeaker connected to a record player or a record player, or any show, signal or means of attracting the attention of passersby, other than a sign or flag, shall be utilized or employed at or near any place of sale, auction room, or auction. 
(Code 1979, § 42.036)  
Secs. 26-77—26-90. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE 
 
Sec. 26-91. - Required. 
It shall be unlawful for any person or corporation to engage in the business of auctioneer without first obtaining a license in accordance with the provisions of this division. 
(Code 1979, § 42.031)  
Sec. 26-92. - Application information. 
Applications for licenses under this division shall be made to the Village Manager or designee on forms prescribed and furnished by the Village Manager or designee. The Village Manager or designee may request additional information from the applicant.  
Sec. 26-93. - Action on application. 
All licenses required by this division shall be acted upon within 30 days of the Village Manager's or designee's receipt of such application.  
Sec. 26-94. - Review of application. 
Upon receipt of an application for a license under this division, the Village Manager or designee shall review and investigate the information contained therein. Such review may include an investigation of the applicant.  
Sec. 26-95. - Display. 
Any license issued in accordance with the provisions of this division shall be prominently displayed at the location for which the license has been issued.  
Sec. 26-96. - Suspension or revocation. 
(a)  The Village Manager shall have the authority to revoke or suspend all licenses issued under this division. In addition to the provisions contained in this division, the Village Manager shall have the authority to establish rules and regulations for the conduct of a hearing relating to the revocation or suspension of a license. 
(b)  The Village Manager is hereby given the authority to revoke or suspend the license if the Village Manager finds: 
(1)  The licensee has not complied with applicable codes, ordinances, statutes, laws, policies or rules and regulations. 
(2)  The licensee has made fraudulent, false or misrepresentative statements in the application for the license. 
(3)  The licensee owes the Village required fees or outstanding fines or penalties.  
Sec. 26-97. - Contents and service of notices. 
(a)  Contents. All notices required to be given in accordance with this division shall be in writing, setting forth the reasons for the denial or revocation of the license. The notice shall inform the applicant or licensee that the applicant or licensee has the right to request a hearing before the Village Manager. 
(b)  Service. All notices shall be sent by certified mail, return receipt requested, to the applicant or licensee specified on the application or license. Notice shall be considered given on the date such notice is mailed.  
Sec. 26-98. - Hearings. 
The Village Manager or designee shall send notice of intent to revoke a license issued under this division. A license shall not be revoked unless the licensee has had an opportunity to present evidence in the licensee's behalf. The Village Manager or designee shall, within 5 business days of the hearing, issue a written order of the findings. Such written order shall be sent to the licensee in accordance with the notice provisions of Section 26-97. If, within 10 days of the notice, the licensee does not request a hearing in writing, the license shall be revoked.  
Sec. 26-99. - Fees. 
Fees for licenses under this division shall be as set forth in Section 46-73. 
(Code 1979, § 42.031)  
Sec. 26-100. - Transfer. 
No license issued or granted under this division shall be assigned or transferred to any other person or corporation other than to the person to whom such license was issued. No individual or corporation other than the licensee shall act or do business under such license.  
Secs. 26-101—26-130. - Reserved.

ARTICLE VI. - CIGARETTE AND TOBACCO SALES[6] 
Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
State Law reference— Cigarette tax, 35 ILCS 130/1 et seq.; cigarette use tax, 35 ILCS 135/1 et seq.; Tobacco Products Tax Act, 35 ILCS 143/10-1 et seq.; Tobacco Accessories and Smoking Herbs Control Act, 720 ILCS 685/1 et seq. 
 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 26-271. - Penalties. 
(a)  Any person who violates any provision of this article shall be subject to the penalties provided in Section 1-6 in addition to any other penalty specifically provided for. 
(b)  In addition to all other fines and penalties, the Village Manager may suspend or revoke the retail cigarette or tobacco products dealer's license for any violation of this article. 
(Code 1979, § 42.0811)  
Sec. 26-272. - Violations declared nuisance. 
The sale of cigarettes or tobacco products in violation of this article is declared a public nuisance as that term is defined in Section 42-35. The Village Manager may, in addition to other remedies provided for in Chapter 42, Article II, recommend that the Corporation Counsel seek injunctive relief.  
Sec. 26-273. - Responsibility of licensee for violations by agents and employees. 
Every act or omission constituting a violation of any of the provisions of this article by any officer, director, manager or other agent or employee of any licensee under this article shall be deemed and held to be the act of such licensee and shall subject the licensee to the same penalty as if such act or omission had been done or omitted by the licensee personally. 
(Code 1979, § 42.0810)  
Sec. 26-274. - Authority to establish additional regulations. 
The Village Manager is authorized to establish rules, regulations and procedures for the implementation of this article. 
(Code 1979, § 42.0812)  
Sec. 26-275. - Vending machines and self-service sales. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to operate or maintain a vending machine or self-service display for the sale or dispensing of tobacco or cigarette products. Self-service displays means open displays of tobacco or cigarette products and point of sale tobacco or cigarette promotional products that the public has access to without the intervention or assistance of a store employee. 
(Code 1979, § 42.083)  
Sec. 26-276. - Prohibitions regarding underage persons. 
(a)  Sales to underage persons. No licensee under this article, or any officer, associate, member, representative, agent or employee of such licensee, shall sell, give or deliver tobacco, e-liquid, cigarette or electronic cigarette products to any person under the age of 21 years. No person, after purchasing or otherwise obtaining tobacco, e-liquid, cigarette or electronic cigarette products, shall sell, give or deliver such tobacco, e-liquid, cigarette or electronic cigarette products to another person under the age of 21 years. 
(b)  Responsibility of parent or guardian. It shall be unlawful for any parent or guardian to permit any person under the age of 21 years of which such person may be the parent or guardian to violate any of the provisions of this article. 
(c)  Sale by underage persons. No licensee, or any officer, associate, member, representative, agent or employee of such licensee, shall engage, employ or permit any person under the age of 21 years to sell cigarette, e-liquid, electronic cigarette or tobacco products. 
(d)  Possession. No person under the age of 21 years shall have cigarette, e-liquid, electronic cigarette or tobacco products in such person's possession. 
(e)  Entry to retail tobacco store. No licensee under this article, or any officer, associate, member, representative, agent or employee of such licensee, shall permit any person under the age of 21 years to be or remain on or in any portion of a retail tobacco store unless the Underage Person is accompanied by his or her parent or guardian. 
(f)  Identification required. 
(1)  If a licensee or the licensee's agent or employee believes or has reason to believe that a sale or delivery of cigarette, e-liquid, electronic cigarette or tobacco products is prohibited because of the non-age of the prospective recipient, the licensee or agent or employee shall, before making such sale or delivery, demand presentation of some form of positive identification, containing proof of age, issued by a public officer in the performance of official duties. 
(2)  No person shall transfer, alter or deface such an identification card, use the identification card of another, carry or use a false or forged identification card, or obtain an identification card by means of false information. No person shall purchase, accept the delivery, or have the possession of cigarette, e-liquid, electronic cigarette or tobacco products in violation of this article. 
(Code 1979, § 42.086; Ord. No. 15-4-C-4136, § 1, 4-20-2015; Ord. No. 18-5-C-4376, § 1, 5-7-2018; Ord. No. 19-11-C-4498, § 1, 11-4-2019) 
Cross reference— Smoking in public places, § 58-61 et seq. 
State Law reference— Sale of Tobacco to Minors Act, 720 ILCS 675/0.01 et seq.  
Sec. 26-277. - Display of warning sign regarding violations by underage persons. 
In every establishment in the Village where cigarette, e-liquid, electronic cigarette or tobacco products are sold there shall be displayed at all times, in a prominent place, a printed card which shall be supplied by the Village and which shall read substantially as follows: 
WARNING TO ALL PERSONS UNDER THE AGE OF 21 YEARS. YOU ARE SUBJECT TO A FINE UP TO $750.00 UNDER THE ORDINANCES OF THE VILLAGE OF SKOKIE IF YOU PURCHASE CIGARETTE, E-LIQUID, ELECTRONIC CIGARETTE OR TOBACCO PRODUCTS OR IF YOU HAVE IN YOUR POSSESSION A FALSE, FORGED, ALTERED OR DEFACED IDENTIFICATION CARD WHICH MISREPRESENTS YOUR AGE. WARNING TO ALL PERSONS UNDER THE AGE OF 18 YEARS. YOU ARE SUBJECT TO A FINE UP TO $750.00 UNDER THE ORDINANCES OF THE VILLAGE OF SKOKIE IF YOU ACCEPT A GIFT OF CIGARETTE, E-LIQUID, ELECTRONIC CIGARETTES OR TOBACCO PRODUCTS OR HAVE CIGARETTE, E-LIQUID, ELECTRONIC CIGARETTE OR TOBACCO PRODUCTS IN YOUR POSSESSION. 
(Code 1979, § 42.087; Ord. No. 15-4-C-4136, § 1, 4-20-2015; Ord. No. 18-5-C-4376, § 1, 5-7-2018)  
Sec. 26-278. - Distribution of single products. 
No cigarette or tobacco products licensee or any officer, associate, member, representative, agent or employee of such licensee shall sell, give or deliver cigarette or tobacco products in any form other than an original factory-wrapped package. 
(Code 1979, § 42.088)  
Sec. 26-279. - Distribution of free products or coupons. 
No person shall give away, barter, exchange, distribute or in any way dispense free of charge or at nominal cost any cigarette or tobacco products, samples, and/or coupon redeemable for any tobacco products on any public street, alley, or sidewalk or in any public park, ground or playground. This section does not prohibit the distribution of coupons included in newspapers, magazines or other publications. 
(Code 1979, § 42.089)  
Secs. 26-280—26-300. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE 
 
Sec. 26-301. - Required. 
It shall be unlawful for any person or corporation to sell cigarettes, tobacco and tobacco products in the Village without first obtaining a license in accordance with the provisions of this division. 
(Code 1979, § 42.081)  
Sec. 26-302. - Application information. 
(a)  Applications for licenses under this division shall be made to the Village Manager or designee on forms prescribed and furnished by the Village Manager or designee. The Village Manager or designee may request additional information from the applicant. 
(b)  Application for a license under this division shall be accompanied by such evidence as shall be required indicating that the applicant is one of good character and reputation. If the Village Manager or designee shall be satisfied that the applicant is of good character and reputation so as to be suitable to be entrusted with the sale of cigarettes, the Village Manager or designee shall issue a license. 
(Code 1979, § 42.082)  
Sec. 26-303. - Action on application. 
All licenses required by this division shall be acted upon within 30 days of the Village Manager's or designee's receipt of such application.  
Sec. 26-304. - Review of application. 
Upon receipt of an application for a license under this division, the Village Manager or designee shall review and investigate the information contained therein. Such review may include an investigation of the applicant.  
Sec. 26-305. - Contents; display. 
Upon the approval of a license under this division, the Village Manager or designee shall issue a license designating the year and location for which the license is issued. The licensee shall display the license in a prominent location where the tobacco or cigarette products are sold. 
(Code 1979, § 42.085)  
Sec. 26-306. - Suspension or revocation. 
(a)  The Village Manager shall have the authority to revoke or suspend all licenses issued under this division. In addition to the provisions contained in this article, the Village Manager shall have the authority to establish rules and regulations for the conduct of a hearing relating to the revocation or suspension of a license. 
(b)  The Village Manager is hereby given the authority to revoke or suspend the license if the Village Manager finds: 
(1)  The licensee has not complied with applicable codes, ordinances, statutes, laws, policies or rules and regulations. 
(2)  The licensee has made fraudulent, false or misrepresentative statements in the application for the license. 
(3)  The licensee owes the Village required fees or outstanding fines or penalties.  
Sec. 26-307. - Contents and service of notices. 
(a)  Contents. All notices required to be given in accordance with this division shall be in writing, setting forth the reasons for the denial or revocation of the license. The notice shall inform the applicant or licensee that the applicant or licensee has the right to request a hearing before the Village Manager. 
(b)  Service. All notices shall be sent by certified mail, return receipt requested, to the applicant or licensee specified on the application or license. Notice shall be considered given on the date such notice is mailed.  
Sec. 26-308. - Hearings. 
The Village Manager or designee shall send notice of intent to revoke a license issued under this division. A license shall not be revoked unless the licensee has had an opportunity to present evidence in the licensee's behalf. The Village Manager or designee shall, within 5 business days of the hearing, issue a written order of the findings. Such written order shall be sent to the licensee in accordance with the notice provisions of Section 26-307. If, within 10 days of the notice, the licensee does not request a hearing in writing, the license shall be revoked.  
Sec. 26-309. - Fees. 
Fees for licenses under this division shall be as set forth in Section 46-73. 
(Code 1979, § 42.084)  
Sec. 26-310. - Transfer. 
No license issued or granted under this division shall be assigned or transferred to any other person or corporation other than to the person to whom such license was issued. No individual or corporation other than the licensee shall act or do business under such license.  
Secs. 26-311—26-330. - Reserved.
