ARTICLE XIII. - FARMERS' MARKET[7] 

Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
Cross reference— Farmers' market fees, § 46-38. 
 
Sec. 26-631. - General policy. 
It is in the public interest for the Village to allow producers of food to sell directly to the public as provided in 505 ILCS 70/1. Therefore, food products may be sold in a farmers' market in the Village as provided in this article without licensing, subject to the conditions set forth in this article. 
(Code 1979, § 42.151; Ord. No. 00-9-C-2926, § 1, 9-5-2000)  
Sec. 26-632. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Farmers' market means a designated area where, on designated days and times, growers and producers may sell directly to the public, in accordance with Village regulations. The Village shall have the right to relocate or discontinue the market, to specify the days and times of its use and to stipulate what goods may be sold. 
Grower and producer mean any person offering for sale articles for human consumption, such as fruits, vegetables, edible grains, nuts and berries, apiary products, maple sugars, syrups, eggs, cheese products, sausage, or nonedible articles such as cut or potted flowers, which articles have been raised or prepared by the grower or producer, by members of their family or by persons in their employ. All articles offered for sale by the grower or producer must be grown or processed in the state of Illinois, Indiana, Michigan or Wisconsin. Sale of any type of meat, fish or poultry and refrigerated dairy products or any article proscribed by the Director of Public Health, with the exception of those products specifically permitted to be sold under this article, shall be prohibited. The sale of eggs, cheese products and sausage shall be permitted only if proper refrigeration is provided. 
(Code 1979, § 42.152; Ord. No. 01-12-C-3050, § 1, 12-17-2001) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 26-633. - Market Manager. 
The Village Manager or designee shall act as a Market Manager, shall review the application of any grower or producer offering articles for sale under this article, issue permits and collect fees therefor, assign spaces to growers and producers, establish a system of bookkeeping for the market, and be responsible for maintaining the market's cleanliness and enforcing the market regulations. 
(Code 1979, § 42.153)  
Sec. 26-634. - Days of operation; location. 
The farmers' market shall conduct retail business only on Sundays. The location of the market shall be on Village property as designated by the Mayor and Board of Trustees and may be moved from time to time at the discretion of the Mayor and Board of Trustees. 
(Code 1979, § 42.154; Ord. No. 01-12-C-3050, § 1, 12-17-2001)  
Sec. 26-635. - Persons eligible to rent space. 
Permits for a space at the farmers' market shall only be issued to a grower or producer as defined in this article. 
(Ord. No. 01-12-C-3050, § 1, 12-17-2001)  
Sec. 26-636. - Application for space. 
An applicant for a space to sell goods within the farmers' market shall submit to the Village Manager or designee, together with the required fee, an application on a form prescribed and furnished by the Village Manager or designee. The Village Manager or designee may request additional information from the applicant. 
(Code 1979, § 42.155; Ord. No. 01-12-C-3050, § 1, 12-17-2001)  
Sec. 26-637. - Assignment of spaces. 
Spaces in the farmers' market shall be assigned in accordance with the order in which applications are filed with the Village Manager or designee. 
(Code 1979, § 42.156; Ord. No. 01-12-C-3050, § 1, 12-17-2001)  
Sec. 26-638. - Rental fees. 
Fees for farmers' market spaces shall be as set forth in Section 46-38. 
(Code 1979, § 42.156)  
Sec. 26-639. - Use regulations. 
(a)  Duties of sellers. No permittee under this article shall: 
(1)  Sell any product other than produce of their or the permittee's farm, orchard, vineyard or garden. Permittees shall submit in advance of occupancy an affidavit certifying that articles offered for sale comply with the requirements of this subsection. 
(2)  Sell or offer any article according to weight except in accordance with the established standards for weight of the State. All products must comply with applicable federal, State and local laws. 
(3)  Sell apiary products, maple sugars and syrups or any processed food unless properly labeled in accordance with State and local standards for labeling. 
(4)  Sell or offer any unwholesome or spoiled articles. 
(5)  Attract attention to the goods by loud sounds. 
(6)  Sell or offer any article without first obtaining an Illinois sales tax license of the current year or fail to display prominently the number of such license; provided, however, that when a temporary (daily) space is assigned, suitable evidence of application for such license may be presented to the Market Manager. 
(7)  Transport or display food without adequate protection against contamination. Delivery trucks and other equipment used for transportation and display shall be kept clean at all times. 
(8)  Allow any waste, garbage or any other refuse to remain on or near the space after the closing hour of any market day. 
(b)  Animals. No animals or pets shall be allowed in the market. 
(c)  Motorized vehicles. No motorized vehicles other than those of the sellers and the Market Manager shall be allowed in the market. 
(Code 1979, § 42.157; Ord. No. 01-12-C-3050, § 1, 12-17-2001)  
Sec. 26-640. - Cleanup deposit. 
All growers and producers shall pay the cleanup deposit provided for in Section 46-38 upon arrival at the market. Growers and producers shall remove all waste and refuse from their spaces before leaving the market. Any refusal or failure by the grower or producer, or their employees or agents, to clean their respective space shall result in forfeiture of the deposit. 
(Code 1979, § 42.158; Ord. No. 01-12-C-3050, § 1, 12-17-2001)  
Secs. 26-641—26-660. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE XIV. - RESERVED 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 08-1-C-3573, § 2, adopted Jan. 7, 2008, deleted Art. XIV, §§ 26-661—26-710, in its entirety. Former Art. XIV, §§ 26-661—26-710, pertained to florists and nurseries, and derived from Code 1979, §§ 42.161—42-163.  
ARTICLE XV. - GARAGE SALES[8] 
Footnotes: 
--- (8) --- 
Cross reference— Permit fee for garage sales, § 46-40. 
 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 26-711. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Garage sale means a garage sale, patio sale, basement sale, backyard sale, or any similar type sale of 3 or more household items, which is held on residential premises to which the general public is invited. 
(Code 1979, § 42.181) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 26-712. - Penalties. 
Any person who violates any provision of this article shall be subject to the penalties provided in Section 1-6 in addition to any other penalty specifically provided for. 
(Code 1979, § 42.187)  
Sec. 26-713. - Number and duration; permitted goods. 
No more than one garage sale permit may be issued to a dwelling unit in any one calendar year. Such a sale shall extend over not more than 3 consecutive days, and shall be limited to household goods and furnishings which have been in use in the dwelling unit located on the premises on which such a sale is conducted or which have been in use in more than one dwelling unit on the same block. 
(Code 1979, § 42.182; Ord. No. 04-9-C-3294, § 1, 9-7-2004)  
Sec. 26-714. - Signs, flags and banners. 
(a)  No signs or advertisement indicating the address, location or direction of a garage sale shall be allowed upon any tree, shrub or pole located in any street, parkway or other public place; nor shall any sign be allowed on any property other than the property wherein the garage sale is to take place. 
(b)  No flags, banners or buntings shall be displayed in connection with the conduct of any garage sale. 
(c)  Signs advertising the sale may be displayed between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 7:00 p.m. from April 1st through October 31st and from 8:00 a.m. until 5:00 p.m. November 1st through March 31st, each day the sale is held. It shall be the responsibility of the permittee to remove the signs in a timely manner. 
(d)  Each sign must state "Garage Sale" along with an attached adhesive label or other means of identifying the name and address of the person responsible for the placement and removal of the sign. The address and name must be consistent with where the garage sale has been permitted. 
(e)  Signs must be free standing and shall not exceed four square feet. 
(Code 1979, § 42.184; Ord. No. 04-9-C-3294, § 2, 9-7-2004)  
Sec. 26-715. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 04-9-C-3294, § 3, adopted Sept. 7, 2004, deleted § 26-715 in its entirety. Former § 26-715 pertained to display of goods in front yard and derived from Code 1979, § 42.185.  
Sec. 26-716. - Display of goods on public property or right-of-way. 
No household goods or furnishings shall be displayed or offered for sale on any public property or public right-of-way. 
(Code 1979, § 42.186)  
Secs. 26-717—26-730. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - PERMIT 
 
Sec. 26-731. - Required; procedures for issuance. 
No garage sale shall be allowed until a permit for such sale shall be granted. The Village Manager is authorized to establish necessary administrative procedures for obtaining a permit. 
(Code 1979, § 42.183)  
Sec. 26-732. - Application. 
Applications for permits under this division shall be made to the Village Manager or designee on forms prescribed and furnished by the Village Manager or designee. The Village Manager or designee may request additional information from the applicant.  
Sec. 26-733. - Contents. 
A garage sale permit shall include: 
(1)  The name and address of the permittee. 
(2)  Date(s) of the garage sale. 
(3)  A statement that, if a permit is granted, the permittee will abide by all applicable codes and ordinances of the Village. 
(4)  A statement that all goods and furnishings to be sold are in the possession and title of the permittee and meet the conditions set forth in Section 26-713. 
(Code 1979, § 42.183; Ord. No. 04-9-C-3294, § 4, 9-7-2004)  
Sec. 26-734. - Fees. 
Fees for garage sale permits shall be as set forth in Section 46-40. 
(Code 1979, § 42.183)  
Sec. 26-735. - Display. 
The permit issued under this division shall be prominently displayed in such a way that it is visible from the street, at the location of the sale. 
(Code 1979, § 42.183; Ord. No. 04-9-C-3294, § 5, 9-7-2004)  
Secs. 26-736—26-750. - Reserved.

ARTICLE XVII. - RESERVED 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 08-1-C-3573, § 2, adopted Jan. 7, 2008, deleted Art. XVII, §§ 26-801—26-850, in its entirety. Former Art. XVII, §§ 26-801—26-850, pertained to identification cards, and derived from Code 1979, §§ 42.311—42.314.  
ARTICLE XVIII. - MASSAGE SERVICES  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 26-851. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Approved massage school means a facility which meets the minimum standards for training and curriculum for the practice of massage and massage therapy and is accredited by one of the following: 
1.  Accrediting Bureau of Health Education Schools (ABHES); 
2.  Accrediting Council for Continuing Education and Training (ACCET); 
3.  Accrediting Commission for Career Schools and Colleges of Technology (ACCSCT); 
4.  Accrediting Council of Independent Colleges and Schools (ACICS); 
5.  Council of Occupational Education (COE); 
6.  Commission of Massage Training Accreditation (COMTA); 
7.  Distance Education and Training Council (DETC); 
8.  International Massage Somatic Therapies Accreditation Council (IMSTAC); 
9.  North Central Association of Colleges and Schools (NCACAS). 
Massage or massage therapy means a system of structured palpation or movement of the soft tissue of the body. The system may include, but is not limited to, techniques such as effleurage or stroking and gliding, petrissage or kneading, tapotement or percussion, friction, vibration, compression, and stretching activities as they pertain to massage therapy. These techniques may be applied by a licensed massage therapist with or without the aid of lubricants, salt or herbal preparations, hydromassage, thermal massage, or a massage device that mimics or enhances the actions possible by human hands. The purpose of the practice of massage, as permitted and licensed under this article, is to enhance the general health and well being of the mind and body of the recipient. "Massage" does not include the diagnosis of a specific pathology. "Massage" does not include those acts of physical therapy or therapeutic or corrective measures that are outside the scope of massage therapy practice as defined in this article. 
Massage services establishment means any business establishment or location in the Village having a source of income or compensation derived from the practice of massage or massage therapy as defined in this section, or which has a place of business where any person, firm, association, corporation or other entity engages in or carries on any of the activities described in the definition of massage or massage therapy. 
Massage services means the transaction or operation of any business or enterprise in the Village, that is organized and operated, in whole or in part, for the purpose of practicing, performing, providing or delivering a massage or massage therapy in return for compensation or consideration of any type. 
Massage therapist means any person who, for any consideration whatsoever, engages in the practice of massage or massage therapy as defined in this section. 
(Code 1979, § 42.331; Ord. No. 04-4-C-3265, § 1, 4-19-2004) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 26-852. - Violations declared nuisance. 
Violations of this article are declared a public nuisance as that term is defined in Section 42-35. The Village Manager may, in addition to other remedies provided for in Chapter 42, Article II, recommend that the Corporation Counsel seek injunctive relief or pursue other civil actions necessary to eradicate the nuisance. 
(Ord. No. 04-4-C-3265, § 1, 4-19-2004)  
Sec. 26-853. - Sanitation and health regulations, for massage services establishment licensees. 
Massage services establishment licensees must follow certain regulations in the operation of their massage services business to ensure a clean and sanitary environment. Such regulations include, but are not limited to, the following: 
(a)  All massage tables, equipment and areas shall have surfaces that are readily disinfected. 
(b)  The establishment shall have adequate equipment for disinfecting and sterilizing of nondisposable instruments and materials used. Such nondisposable instruments, equipment and materials shall be disinfected after each use. 
(c)  Clean linen, towels and other materials shall be stored in a manner so as to be protected from contamination. All soiled linens, towels and other materials shall be kept in a covered container and stored separately. 
(d)  An adequate supply of clean linens and towels shall be made available. Linens and towels must be for individual customer use and laundered after each use. 
(e)  All areas in a massage therapy establishment shall be in good repair and maintained in a clean and sanitary manner. 
(f)  All creams, oils, lotions, etc., shall be kept in clean, closed containers and shall be dispensed in doses so that the bulk containers are not contaminated between customers. 
(g)  No massage treatment shall be administered to a patron exhibiting any skin fungus, skin infection, skin inflammation or skin eruption unless a licensed physician certifies in writing that such patron may be safely massaged. 
(h)  The establishment must be equipped with a hand sink with dispensed soap and towels. The therapist shall wash hands in hot running water with soap before treating each patron. 
(Ord. No. 01-9-C-3025, 9-4-2001; Ord. No. 04-4-C-3265, § 1, 4-19-2004)  
Sec. 26-854. - Sanitation and health regulations for massage services licensees. 
Massage services licensees must follow certain regulations in the operation of their massage services business to ensure a clean and sanitary environment while conducting the business of massage or massage therapy in the Village. Such regulations include, but are not limited to, the following: 
(1)  All massage tables and equipment shall have surfaces that are readily disinfected. 
(2)  Nondisposable instruments, equipment and materials shall be disinfected after each use. 
(3)  An adequate supply of clean linens and towels shall be made available. Linens and towels must be for individual customer use and laundered after each use. 
(4)  All creams, oils, lotions, etc., shall be kept in clean, closed containers. 
(5)  No massage treatment shall be administered to a client exhibiting any skin fungus, skin infection, skin inflammation or skin eruption unless a licensed physician certifies in writing that such patron may be safely massaged. 
(6)  The therapist shall wash his or her hands in hot running water with soap before treating each client. 
All massage therapists must comply with the regulations stated in this section in the performance of their conduct. 
(Ord. No. 04-4-C-3265, § 1, 4-19-2004)  
Secs. 26-855—26-870. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - MASSAGE SERVICE LICENSE AND MASSAGE THERAPIST PERMIT 
 
Sec. 26-871. - Massage services establishment license or massage services license required. 
(a)  No person or entity shall operate a massage services establishment in the Village without first obtaining a massage services establishment license in accordance with the provisions of this division. A separate massage services establishment license shall be required for each massage services location, regardless of whether such multiple establishments are operated by the same person or entity. Hospitals and nursing homes are not required to obtain a massage services establishment license. 
(b)  A massage therapist residing in the Village and performing massages or massage therapy in the Village, who is not affiliated with a massage services establishment, must also obtain a massage services establishment license indicating his or her residence as the establishment location. 
(c)  In relation to persons or entities, not residing or located in the Village, that are organized, in whole or part, and operated for the purpose of providing, performing or delivering massages or massage therapy in the Village for money, gratuity or compensation of any type, then the persons or entities must obtain a massage services license. Any massage therapist not residing in the Village, but performing massages or massage therapy in the Village, must be affiliated with a massage services establishment licensed by the Village or a massage services business licensed by the Village, otherwise such therapist must obtain a massage services license in addition to a therapist permit. 
(Code 1979, § 42.332; Ord. No. 04-4-C-3265, § 1, 4-19-2004)  
Sec. 26-872. - Massage therapist permit required. 
No person shall practice, provide, perform or deliver a massage or massage therapy on another person in the Village, under circumstances in which it is reasonably expected that that the person receiving the massage or massage therapy, or some other third party, will pay money, or give a gratuity or compensation of any type, for the services rendered, without a valid massage therapist permit issued by the Village pursuant to the terms of this division. Massage therapist permits shall be issued only to natural persons and shall not be issued to any corporation, partnership or other entity. No massage therapist permit shall be issued to an individual who is not affiliated with a massage services establishment, or massage services business, licensed by the Village. If there is no such affiliation, then the prospective permittee must obtain either a massage services establishment license or a massage services license as set forth in section 26-871. 
(Code 1979, § 42.332; Ord. No. 04-4-C-3265, § 1, 4-19-2004)  
Sec. 26-873. - Exemptions. 
No license or permit shall be required under this article for any occupation, activity or conduct that is exempt pursuant to Section 25 of the Illinois Massage Licensing Act, 225 ILCS 57/1 et seq. 
(Code 1979, § 42.333; Ord. No. 04-4-C-3265, § 1, 4-19-2004)  
Sec. 26-874. - Application information; education requirements. 
Applications for licenses and permits under this division shall be made to the Village Manager or designee on forms prescribed and furnished by the Village Manager or designee. The Village Manager or designee may request additional information from an applicant. Evidence shall be submitted with an application that such applicant for a massage therapist permit has received training in massage or massage therapy from, and is certified by an institution that is an approved massage school, as defined herein. In the case of a legal entity applying for a massage services establishment license or a massage services license, the applicant shall list all officers and owners of the entity. At least one owner or manager of the entity shall be considered the applicant and shall meet the personal training and certification requirements stated in this section. 
Each applicant for a massage services establishment license or a massage services license shall disclose the names and addresses of all massage therapists affiliated with the proposed licensee. If approved for a license, the licensee shall inform the Village in writing, within 10 days, of any additions, deletions and changes in the list of affiliated massage therapists. All licensees have a duty to manage and supervise the activities and conduct of an affiliated therapist in the performance of his or her services. All massages or massage therapy services provided, performed or delivered are deemed to have been accomplished with the direct knowledge of the licensee. 
Each applicant shall be required to submit written proof establishing that the applicant has graduated from an approved massage school with a 500 hour curriculum or program. 
(Code 1979, § 42.334; Ord. No. 04-4-C-3265, § 1, 4-19-2004)  
Sec. 26-875. - Review of application. 
All licenses and permits required by this division shall be reviewed within 30 days of the Village Manager's or designee's receipt of such application. Such review shall include, but not be limited to, a criminal background investigation of the applicant or in the case of an entity, the listed owners, officers, managers, members, partners and shareholders. 
(Ord. No. 04-4-C-3265, § 1, 4-19-2004)  
Sec. 26-876. - Grounds for denial or discipline. 
The Village Manager or designee may (i) deny an application for a license or permit, (ii) refuse to renew a license or permit, or (iii) suspend or revoke a license or permit, if it is determined that the applicant, licensee or permittee, or an owner, officer or manager of a licensee: 
(1)  Was convicted of any crime under the laws of the United States or any state or territory therein that is either: (a) a felony, (b) a misdemeanor, pertaining to battery, prostitution, dishonesty or directly related to the practice of massage, or (c) an offense listed in Article 11 of the Illinois Criminal Code, 720 ILCS 5/11-6 et seq., and Article 16 of the Illinois Criminal Code, 720 ILCS 5/16-1, et seq. Conviction, as used in this paragraph, shall include a finding or verdict of guilty, an admission of guilt, or a plea of nolo contendere; 
(2)  Engaged in immoral conduct in the commission of any act, such as sexual abuse, sexual misconduct or sexual exploitation; 
(3)  Made fraudulent, false or misrepresentative statements, or material omissions, in the application for the license or permit; 
(4)  Is indebted to the Village for required fees, costs incurred by the Village in relation to the individual or entity, or outstanding fines or penalties; or 
(5)  Has not complied with applicable codes, ordinances, statutes, laws or rules and regulations of the Village or State of Illinois. 
(Ord. No. 04-4-C-3265, § 1, 4-19-2004)  
Sec. 26-877. - Display and renewal of licenses and permits. 
Any massage services establishment license issued in accordance with the provisions of this division shall be prominently displayed at the location for which the license or permit has been issued. The massage services license shall be in the possession of any affiliated massage therapist performing massage or massage therapy in the Village. Every massage therapist performing a massage or massage therapy shall have on their person his or her massage therapist permit. 
All licenses and permits expire at the end of each Village fiscal year. Licenses and permits may be renewed, based upon a request and payment of the fee by the respective licensee or permittee, however, the Village Manager or designee is authorized to review a renewal request in the same manner as an initial application. 
(Ord. No. 04-4-C-3265, § 1, 4-19-2004)  
Sec. 26-878. - Temporary suspension. 
In the event the Village Manager finds that there is sufficient evidence that indicates the occurrence of criminal behavior or a practice that would constitute a danger to the public, he or she may temporarily suspend a license or permit without a hearing simultaneously with the notification of the right to a hearing provided for in section 26-880. In the event that the Village Manager suspends a license or permit issued under this section, a hearing by the Village Manager must be held within 30 calendar days after the suspension has occurred. 
(Code 1979, § 42.335; Ord. No. 04-4-C-3265, § 1, 4-19-2004)  
Sec. 26-879. - Contents and service of notices. 
(a)  Contents. All notices required to be given in accordance with this division shall be in writing, setting forth the reasons for the denial or revocation of the license or permit. The notice shall inform the applicant, licensee or permittee that the applicant, licensee or permittee has the right to request a hearing before the Village Manager. 
(b)  Service. All notices shall be sent by certified mail, return receipt requested, to the applicant, licensee or permittee specified on the application, license or permit. Notice shall be considered given on the date such notice is mailed. 
(Ord. No. 04-4-C-3265, § 1, 4-19-2004)  
Sec. 26-880. - Hearings. 
In addition to the provisions contained in this article, the Village Manager shall have the authority to establish rules and regulations for the conduct of a hearing relating to the revocation or suspension of a license or permit. The Village Manager or designee shall send notice of intent to revoke a license or permit issued under this division. A license or permit shall not be revoked unless the licensee or permittee has had an opportunity to present evidence in the licensee's or permittee's behalf. The Village Manager or designee shall, within 5 business days of the hearing, issue a written order of the findings. Such written order shall be sent to the licensee or permittee in accordance with the notice provisions of Section 26-879. If, within 10 days of the notice, the licensee or permittee does not request a hearing in writing, the license or permit shall be revoked. 
(Ord. No. 04-4-C-3265, § 1, 4-19-2004)  
Sec. 26-881. - Fees. 
Fees for licenses and permits under this division shall be as set forth in section 46-73. 
(Code 1979, § 42.332; Ord. No. 04-4-C-3265, § 1, 4-19-2004)  
Sec. 26-882. - Transfer. 
No license or permit issued or granted under this division shall be assigned or transferred to any other person or corporation other than to the person to whom such license or permit was issued. No individual or entity other than the licensee or permittee shall act or do business under such license or permit. 
(Ord. No. 04-4-C-3265, § 1, 4-19-2004)  
Sec. 26-883. - Cease and desist. 
The Village Manager or designee is authorized to issue a cease and desist order to any person performing massage or massage therapy, as defined by this article, in the Village that is not properly permitted and affiliated with a licensed massage services establishment or licensed massage services business. The Village Manager or designee is authorized to issue a cease and desist order to any person or entity operating a massage services establishment or massage services business without being properly licensed. 
(Ord. No. 04-4-C-3265, § 1, 4-19-2004)  
Secs. 26-884—26-900. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE XIX. - MORTUARIES[9] 
Footnotes: 
--- (9) --- 
State Law reference— Funeral Directors and Embalmers Licensing Code, 225 ILCS 41/1 et seq. 
 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 26-901. - Violations declared nuisance. 
Maintaining an undertaking establishment or operating as an undertaker or mortician in violation of this article is declared a public nuisance as that term is defined in Section 42-35. The Village Manager may, in addition to other remedies provided for in Chapter 42, Article II, recommend that the Corporation Counsel seek injunctive relief.  
Sec. 26-902. - Notification of delivery of bodies. 
It shall be the duty of every undertaker to notify the Village Department of Public Health whenever a body is brought to the undertaker or turned over to the undertaker for the undertaker's services. 
(Code 1979, § 42.232)  
Secs. 26-903—26-920. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE 
 
Sec. 26-921. - Required. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to maintain an undertaking establishment or to operate as an undertaker or mortician without first obtaining a license in accordance with the provisions of this division. 
(Code 1979, § 42.231)  
Sec. 26-922. - Application information. 
Applications for licenses under this division shall be made to the Village Manager or designee on forms prescribed and furnished by the Village Manager or designee. The Village Manager or designee may request additional information from the applicant.  
Sec. 26-923. - Action on application. 
All licenses required by this division shall be acted upon within 30 days of the Village Manager's or designee's receipt of such application.  
Sec. 26-924. - Review of application. 
Upon receipt of an application for a license under this division, the Village Manager or designee shall review and investigate the information contained therein. Such review may include an investigation of the applicant.  
Sec. 26-925. - Display. 
Any license issued in accordance with the provisions of this division shall be prominently displayed at the location for which the license has been issued.  
Sec. 26-926. - Suspension or revocation. 
(a)  The Village Manager shall have the authority to revoke or suspend all licenses issued under this division. In addition to the provisions contained in this division, the Village Manager shall have the authority to establish rules and regulations for the conduct of a hearing relating to the revocation or suspension of a license. 
(b)  The Village Manager is hereby given the authority to revoke or suspend the license if the Village Manager finds: 
(1)  The licensee has not complied with applicable codes, ordinances, statutes, laws, policies or rules and regulations. 
(2)  The licensee has made fraudulent, false or misrepresentative statements in the application for the license. 
(3)  The licensee owes the Village required fees or outstanding fines or penalties.  
Sec. 26-927. - Contents and service of notices. 
(a)  Contents. All notices required to be given in accordance with this division shall be in writing, setting forth the reasons for the denial or revocation of the license. The notice shall inform the applicant or licensee that the applicant or licensee has the right to request a hearing before the Village Manager. 
(b)  Service. All notices shall be sent by certified mail, return receipt requested, to the applicant or licensee specified on the application or license. Notice shall be considered given on the date such notice is mailed.  
Sec. 26-928. - Hearings. 
The Village Manager or designee shall send notice of intent to revoke a license issued under this division. A license shall not be revoked unless the licensee has had an opportunity to present evidence in the licensee's behalf. The Village Manager or designee shall, within 5 business days of the hearing, issue a written order of the findings. Such written order shall be sent to the licensee in accordance with the notice provisions of Section 26-927. If, within 10 days of the notice, the licensee does not request a hearing in writing, the license shall be revoked.  
Sec. 26-929. - Fees. 
Fees for licenses under this division shall be as set forth in Section 46-73. 
(Code 1979, § 42.231)  
Sec. 26-930. - Transfer. 
No license issued or granted under this division shall be assigned or transferred to any other person or corporation other than to the person to whom such license was issued. No individual or corporation other than the licensee shall act or do business under such license.  
Secs. 26-931—26-949. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE XX. - BODY ART SERVICES[10] 
Footnotes: 
--- (10) --- 
Editor's note— Prior to reenactment by Ord. No. 19-3-C-4446, adopted March 4, 2019, Ord. No. 08-1-C-3573, § 2, adopted Jan. 7, 2008, repealed Art. XX, §§ 26-951—26-1000, which pertained to motor vehicle related uses, and derived from Code 1979, §§ 42.951—42.1000. 
 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 26-950. - Purpose. 
Tattoo and body piercing practices affect the health, safety, and welfare of the public. It has been established that non-sterile needles can lead to the spread of certain blood-borne illnesses such as Hepatitis and HIV. Therefore, the Mayor and Board of Trustees find that the regulation of tattoo and body piercing establishments is necessary to ensure public health, safety, and welfare. 
(Ord. No. 19-3-C-4446, § 1, 3-4-2019)  
Sec. 26-951. - Adoption of the Illinois Tattoo and Body Piercing Establishment Registration Act. 
The Village hereby adopts by reference the Tattoo and Body Piercing Establishment Registration Act, (410 ILCS 54) (hereinafter "Act"), and any subsequent revisions or amendments to the Act are hereby adopted and made part of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 19-3-C-4446, § 1, 3-4-2019)  
Sec. 26-952. - Fees. 
Fees for licenses and permits under this division shall be as set forth in Section 46-73. 
(Ord. No. 19-3-C-4446, § 1, 3-4-2019)  
Sec. 26-953. - Transfer. 
No license or permit issued or granted under this Article shall be assigned or transferred to any other person or entity. No individual or entity other than the licensee or permittee shall act or do business under such license or permit. 
(Ord. No. 19-3-C-4446, § 1, 3-4-2019)  
DIVISION 2. - BODY ART SERVICES 
 
Sec. 26-954. - Body Art Establishment License Required. 
(a)  All establishments providing body art services such as tattooing, microblading, micropigmentation, piercing, branding or scarification are required to be registered with the Illinois Department of Public Health (IDPH) and be in full compliance with the Act. 
(b)  No person or entity shall operate a body art establishment in the Village without first obtaining a body art establishment license in accordance with the provisions of this Article. A separate Body Art Establishment License shall be required for each body art establishment location, regardless of whether such multiple establishments are operated by the same person or entity. 
(c)  The number of licensed Body Art Establishments in the Village shall not exceed eight (8) at any given time. 
(d)  Body Art Establishments shall not be allowed in a residence and do not qualify as a Home Occupation pursuant to Section 118-79 of the Skokie Village Code. 
(Ord. No. 19-3-C-4446, § 1, 3-4-2019)  
Sec. 26-955. - Body Artist Permit Required. 
(a)  No person shall practice, provide, perform, engage in or deliver body art services on another person in the Village, under circumstances in which it is reasonably expected that the person receiving the services or some other third party, will pay money or give a gratuity or compensation of any type, for the services rendered, without a valid body artist permit issued by the Village pursuant to the terms of this Article. 
(b)  Body Artist Permits shall be issued only to natural persons and shall not be issued to any corporation, partnership or other entity. No Body Artist Permit shall be issued to an individual who is not affiliated with a body art establishment licensed by the Village. If there is no such affiliation, then the prospective permittee must obtain a body art establishment license as set forth in Section 26-954. 
(c)  A body artist not residing in the Village, and performing body art services in the Village must be affiliated with a body art establishment licensed by the Village and must also obtain a body artist permit. 
(Ord. No. 19-3-C-4446, § 1, 3-4-2019)  
Sec. 26-956. - Exemptions. 
The following practices, occupations and persons are exempted from this Part: 
(a)  The practice of electrology as defined in the Electrologist Licensing Act, 225 ILCS 412; 
(b)  The practice of acupuncture as defined in the Acupuncture Practice Act, 225 ILCS 2; 
(c)  The use, by a physician licensed to practice medicine in all its branches, of colors, dyes, or pigments for the purpose of obscuring scar tissue or imparting color to the skin for cosmetic, medical, or figurative purposes; and 
(d)  Individuals who pierce only the non-cartilaginous portion or lobe of the ear with a pre-sterilized single-use stud-and-clasp ear-piercing system. 
(Ord. No. 19-3-C-4446, § 1, 3-4-2019)  
DIVISION 3. - LICENSE/PERMIT: REQUIREMENTS 
 
Sec. 26-957. - Permit Application; Training and Vaccination Requirement. 
Applications for Body Art Establishment Licenses and Body Artist Permits under this Article shall be made to the Village Manager or designee on prescribed forms. Additional information may be requested from an applicant as part of the review process. 
(a)  Body Art Establishment License 
1.  The applicant for a Body Art Establishment Services License shall list all officers and owners of the entity. At least one owner or manager of the entity shall be considered the applicant and shall meet the personal training and education requirements stated in this section. 
2.  Each applicant for a Body Art Establishment License shall disclose the names and addresses of all body artists affiliated with the proposed licensee. If approved for a license, the licensee shall inform the Village in writing, within 10 days, of any additions, deletions and changes in the list of affiliated body artists. All licensees have a duty to manage and supervise the activities and conduct of an affiliated body artist in the performance of his or her services. All body art services provided, performed or delivered are deemed to have been accomplished with the direct knowledge of the licensee. 
(b)  Body Artist Permit. 
1.  Evidence shall be submitted by or on behalf of the applicant for a Body Artist Permit that the applicant has received training in each body art procedure that they will perform. This can be evidenced by an apprenticeship, either at a school or under the supervision of a permitted or licensed body artist skilled in these techniques. 
2.  Body artists shall provide documentation of completion of "Bloodborne Pathogen Training", as required by OSHA (29 CFR 1910.1030). This training must be completed prior to providing any services and annually, thereafter. Documentation shall be maintained at the body art establishment and shall be submitted to the Village upon request. 
3.  Body artists shall provide documentation of the hepatitis B vaccination. 
(Ord. No. 19-3-C-4446, § 1, 3-4-2019)  
Sec. 26-958. - Application Review. 
All applications for licenses and permits required by this Article shall be reviewed within 30 days of the Village Manager's or designee's receipt. Such review shall include, but not be limited to, a criminal background investigation of the applicant or in the case of an entity, the listed owners, officers, managers, members, partners and shareholders. 
(Ord. No. 19-3-C-4446, § 1, 3-4-2019)  
Sec. 26-959. - Grounds for denial or discipline. 
The Village Manager or designee may: (i) deny an application for a license or permit, (ii) refuse to renew a license or permit, or (iii) suspend or revoke a license or permit, if it is determined that the applicant, licensee or permittee, or an owner, officer or manager of a licensee: 
(1)  Was convicted of any crime under the laws of the United States or any state or territory therein that is either: (a) a felony, (b) a misdemeanor, pertaining to battery, prostitution, dishonesty or directly related to the practice of tattooing, or (c) an offense listed in Article 11 of the Illinois Criminal Code, 720 ILCS 5/11-6 et seq., and Article 16 of the Illinois Criminal Code, 720 ILCS 5/16-1 et seq. Conviction, as used in this paragraph, shall include a finding or verdict of guilty, an admission of guilt, or a plea of nolo contendere; 
(2)  Engaged in immoral conduct in the commission of any act, such as sexual abuse, sexual misconduct or sexual exploitation; 
(3)  Made fraudulent, false or misrepresentative statements, or material omissions, in the application for the license or permit; 
(4)  Is indebted to the Village for required fees, costs incurred by the Village in relation to the individual or entity, or outstanding fines or penalties; 
(5)  Is unable to substantiate the requisite training, was trained at a facility which the Village Manager or designee, determines to be inadequate or was trained at a facility at which the licensure was revoked by the issuing governmental entity. 
(6)  Has not complied with applicable codes, ordinances, statutes, laws or rules and regulations of the Village or State of Illinois. 
(Ord. No. 19-3-C-4446, § 1, 3-4-2019)  
Sec. 26-960. - Display and renewal of licenses and permits. 
(a)  Any Body Art Establishment License issued in accordance with the provisions of this Article shall be prominently displayed at the location for which the license has been issued. The Body Artist Permit of all affiliated body artists performing body art services at the location shall also be prominently displayed. 
(b)  All licenses and permits referenced in this Article expire at the end of each Village fiscal year. Licenses and permits may be renewed, based upon renewal application and payment of the fee by the respective licensee or permittee. The Village Manager or designee is authorized to review a renewal request in the same manner as an initial application. 
(Ord. No. 19-3-C-4446, § 1, 3-4-2019)  
DIVISION 4. - LICENSE/PERMIT: SUSPENSION AND REVOCATION 
 
Sec. 26-961. - Temporary suspension. 
In the event the Village Manager finds that there is sufficient evidence that indicates the occurrence of criminal behavior or a practice that would constitute a danger to the public, he or she may temporarily suspend a license or permit without a hearing simultaneously with the notification of the right to a hearing provided for in section 26-960. In the event that the Village Manager suspends a license or permit issued under this section, a hearing by the Village Manager must be held within 30 calendar days after the suspension has occurred. 
(Ord. No. 19-3-C-4446, § 1, 3-4-2019)  
Sec. 26-962. - Contents and service of notices. 
(a)  Contents. All notices required to be given in accordance with this Article shall be in writing, setting forth the reasons for the denial, suspension or revocation of the license or permit. The notice shall inform the applicant, licensee or permittee that the applicant, licensee or permittee has the right to request a hearing before the Village Manager. 
(b)  Service. All notices shall be sent by regular first class mail and certified mail, return receipt requested, to the applicant, licensee or permittee specified on the application, license or permit. Notice shall be considered given on the date such notice is mailed. 
(Ord. No. 19-3-C-4446, § 1, 3-4-2019)  
Sec. 26-963. - Hearings. 
In addition to the provisions contained in this Article, the Village Manager shall have the authority to establish rules and regulations for the conduct of a hearing relating to the revocation or suspension of a license or permit. The Village Manager or designee shall send notice of intent to revoke a license or permit issued under this Article. A license or permit shall not be revoked unless the licensee or permittee has had an opportunity to present evidence in the licensee's or permittee's behalf. The Village Manager or designee shall, within 5 business days of the hearing, issue a written order of the findings. Such written order shall be sent to the licensee or permittee in accordance with the notice provisions of Section 26-959. If, within 10 days of the notice, the licensee or permittee does not request a hearing in writing, the license or permit shall be revoked. 
(Ord. No. 19-3-C-4446, § 1, 3-4-2019)  
Sec. 26-964. - Cease and desist. 
The Village Manager or designee is authorized to issue a Cease and Desist Order to: 
a.  Any person or entity operating a body art establishment without required Village and State licenses; 
b.  Any person engaging in body art services in the Village, as referenced by this Article, if he or she is not properly permitted and affiliated with a licensed body art establishment. 
(Ord. No. 19-3-C-4446, § 1, 3-4-2019)  
Secs. 26-965—26-1000. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE XXI. - NEWSRACKS[11] 
Footnotes: 
--- (11) --- 
Cross reference— Exemption of newspapers from handbill regulations, § 6-34. 
 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 26-1001. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Distributor means the person responsible for placing and maintaining a newsrack. 
Newsrack means any self-service or coin-operated box, container, storage unit or other dispenser which fully encloses and secures the periodicals contained therein and is installed, used or maintained for the dissemination of newspapers or other news periodicals, regardless of whether a charge is imposed. 
Official Village newsrack enclosure means a fixture provided by the Village for the placement of multiple newsracks. 
Person means any person, persons, or entity, including but not limited to a corporation, partnership, unincorporated association or joint venture. 
Public property means any public property within the Village, which shall include but not be limited to streets, roadways, rights-of-way, and parkways. 
Roadway means that portion of a street improved, designed, or ordinarily used for vehicular travel. 
(Code 1979, § 42.321) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 26-1002. - Violations declared nuisance. 
The violation of any provision of this article is declared a public nuisance as that term is defined in Section 42-35. The Village Manager may, in addition to other remedies provided for in Chapter 42, Article II, recommend that the Corporation Counsel seek injunctive relief. 
(Code 1979, § 42.322)  
Sec. 26-1003. - Authority to establish additional regulations. 
The Village Manager is authorized to establish rules, regulations and procedures for the implementation of this article. 
(Code 1979, § 42.3215)  
Sec. 26-1004. - Existing newsracks. 
All newsracks existing within the Village as of September 30, 1995, shall be permitted to exist, provided there is subsequent compliance with the terms of this article within 30 days of being notified by the Village Manager or designee. 
(Code 1979, § 42.3216)  
Sec. 26-1005. - Location and manner of installation; size; advertisements; maintenance; distributor identification. 
Any newsrack which in whole or in part rests upon, in or over any public property shall comply with the following standards: 
(1)  Location and manner of installation. 
a.  No box shall be less than 1.5 feet from the back of the curb edge of the roadway. 
b.  No newsrack shall be permitted to rest upon, in or over any public property when such installation, use or maintenance endangers the safety of persons or property, or when such site or location is used for public utility purposes, public transportation purposes or other governmental use, or when such newsrack unreasonably interferes with or impedes the flow of pedestrian or vehicular traffic, including any legally marked or stopped vehicle, or the ingress into or egress from any residence or place of business, or interferes with the use of poles, posts, traffic signs or signals, hydrants, mailboxes, parking meters, traffic control devices, or other objects permitted at or near the location. 
c.  No newsrack shall be chained, bolted, or otherwise attached to any tree, utility pole, light pole, parking meter, traffic control post, street sign post, or other fixture located on public property, except to other newsracks or an official Village newsrack enclosure. 
d.  Newsracks may be placed next to each other, provided that no group of newsracks shall extend for a distance of more than 8 feet along a curb, and a space of not less than 3 feet shall separate each group of newsracks. 
e.  No newsracks shall be placed, installed, used or maintained: 
1.  Within 3 feet of any marked crosswalk. 
2.  Within 12 feet of the curb return of any unmarked crosswalk. 
3.  Within 5 feet of any fire hydrant, fire call box, police call box, or other emergency facility. 
4.  Within 15 feet of any intersection, driveway, alley or street from the point where the curbline meets an imaginary line which constitutes an extension of the boundary of the driveway, alley or street at its narrowest point. 
5.  Within 3 feet ahead or 15 feet to the rear of any sign marking a designated bus stop. 
6.  Within 3 feet of the outer end of any bus bench. 
7.  At any location whereby the clear space for the passageway of pedestrians is reduced to less than 3 feet. 
8.  Within 3 feet of or on any public area improved with lawn, flowers, shrubs, trees or other landscaping. 
9.  On or interfering with any handicapped access ramp. 
10.  On or within any median within any public right-of-way. 
11.  Within 250 feet of any other newsrack on the same side of the street in the same block containing the same issue or edition of the same publication or periodical. 
(2)  Size. No newsrack shall exceed the following: 
a.  Four feet in height. 
b.  Twenty-four inches in width. 
c.  Twenty inches in thickness. 
(3)  Advertisements; maintenance. 
a.  No newsrack shall be used for advertising signs or publicity purposes other than that dealing with the display, sale or purchase of the newspaper or news periodical sold therein. 
b.  Each newsrack shall be equipped with a coin-return mechanism to permit a person using the machine to secure an immediate refund if the person is unable to receive the paid-for periodical. The coin-return mechanisms shall be maintained in good working order. 
c.  Each newsrack shall be maintained in a neat and clean condition and in good repair at all times. Specifically, but without limiting the generality of the foregoing, each newsrack shall be services and maintained so that: 
1.  It is reasonably free of dirt and grease. 
2.  It is reasonably free of chipped, faded, peeling and cracked paint in the visible painted areas thereof. 
3.  It is reasonably free of rust and corrosion in the visible unpainted metal areas thereon. 
4.  The clear plastic or glass parts thereof, if any, through which the periodicals therein are viewed are unbroken and reasonably free of cracks, dents, blemishes and discoloration. 
5.  The paper or cardboard parts or inserts thereof are reasonably free of tears, peeling or fading. 
6.  The structural parts thereof are not broken or unduly misshapen. 
d.  Each newsrack shall fully enclose and secure the periodicals contained therein so as to prevent the periodicals from potentially littering public property. 
(4)  Distributor identification. Each newsrack shall have affixed to it, in a readily visible place so as to be seen by anyone using the newsrack, a notice setting forth the name and address of the distributor and the telephone number of a working telephone service to call to report a malfunction, or to secure a refund in the event of a malfunction of the coin-return mechanism. 
(Code 1979, § 42.327)  
Sec. 26-1006. - Official Village newsrack enclosures. 
(a)  Designation of locations. The Village Manager or designee shall determine various locations in the Village where official Village newsrack enclosures shall be placed for the purpose of avoiding the placement of multiple newsracks, in furtherance of the Village's general health, safety and welfare. 
(b)  Exemptions from location restrictions. The installation of newsracks located within an official Village newsrack enclosure shall be exempt from the location provisions set forth in Section 26-1005(1)a, b, and e.1 through 10. 
(c)  Additional newsracks in same block. If an official Village newsrack enclosure exists on a block within the Village, no other newsrack shall be permitted on the same side of a street on such a block unless the official Village newsrack enclosure is filled. If a place becomes vacant in the official Village newsrack enclosure, at the option of the Village Manager or designee, a permittee may be required to remove the additional newsrack on the block and relocate the newspaper or periodical to within the official Village enclosure. 
(Code 1979, § 42.328)  
Sec. 26-1007. - Abandonment. 
If a newsrack remains empty for a period of 30 continuous days, it shall be considered abandoned. 
(Code 1979, § 42.329)  
Sec. 26-1008. - Removal by Village. 
(a)  Authorized. After proper notice is given, the Village Manager or designee may cause the removal of a newsrack: 
(1)  After revocation of a permit in accordance with Section 26-1037. 
(2)  After expiration of a permit. 
(3)  That is installed without a permit. 
(4)  That is deemed abandoned or unclaimed. 
(b)  Immediate removal. If a determination is made that the existence of a newsrack presents an immediate danger to the public's health, safety or welfare, the Village Manager or designee may cause the removal of such a newsrack without giving prior notice. However, notice shall be given as soon as practicable after such removal. 
(c)  Impound fee. The permittee, or, if there is no permittee, the person responsible for installing a newsrack, shall be assessed an impound fee. The impound fee shall be determined by the Village Manager and be based on the actual cost to the Village for removal and storage, including a 10 percent administrative fee and the cost of restoring the public property to its condition prior to the installation and removal of the newsrack. Upon the payment of the assessed fees, the permittee or the person responsible for installing the newsrack shall be entitled to possession of the newsrack removed in accordance with this section. 
(d)  Unclaimed newsracks. Should a permittee or the person responsible for the installation of a newsrack fail to claim a removed newsrack or pay the fees assessed in accordance with subsection (c) of this section, such newsrack shall be deemed to be unclaimed property and may be disposed of pursuant to law. 
(Code 1979, § 42.3211)  
Secs. 26-1009—26-1030. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - PERMIT 
 
Sec. 26-1031. - Required. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to erect, place, install, maintain or operate a newsrack on any public property within the Village without first obtaining an administrative/inspection permit in accordance with the provisions of this division. 
(Code 1979, § 42.323)  
Sec. 26-1032. - Application information. 
Applications for an administrative/inspection permit under this division shall be made to the Village Manager or designee on forms prescribed and furnished by the Village Manager or designee. The Village Manager or designee may request additional information from the applicant. 
(Code 1979, § 42.324)  
Sec. 26-1033. - Review of application; action on application; issuance or denial. 
Upon receipt of an application for a newsrack administrative/inspection permit, the Village Manager or designee shall review the application and determine compliance with all applicable Village, State and federal codes, ordinances, statutes, policies and rules and regulations. When the review reveals that all applicable requirements are complied with, an administrative/inspection permit shall be issued within 10 business days of receipt of the application. If a determination is made that the applicant has not complied with all applicable codes, ordinances, statutes, policies and rules and regulations, the application shall be denied, and the reasons for such denial shall be stated in writing and mailed to the applicant within 5 business days of receipt of the application. Any applicant that receives a notification of denial for a newsrack administrative/inspection permit in accordance with this section shall have a right to a hearing as provided for in Section 26-1039. 
(Code 1979, § 42.325)  
Sec. 26-1034. - Placement of newsracks prior to obtaining permit. 
Any person may place a newsrack or newsracks on public property prior to submitting the application required in Section 26-1032 provided that the placement and maintenance of the newsrack or newsracks are otherwise in compliance with the requirements of this article and other applicable codes, ordinances, statutes and rules and regulations. Any person placing a newsrack or newsracks on public property under this section shall submit the required application no later than the next Village business day after placement of the newsrack or newsracks. 
(Code 1979, § 42.3251)  
Sec. 26-1035. - Agreement by applicant. 
In every application for a newsrack, the applicant shall agree to the following: 
(1)  That any and all costs related to the installation and maintenance or removal of the newsrack shall be incurred by the applicant. 
(2)  That the privileges granted to the applicant are nontransferable and shall only apply to the periodical and location specified in the respective application. 
(3)  That the applicant shall name the Village as an additional insured from any loss or claim for personal injury or property damage alleged against the Village or the applicant, arising out of the installation, removal, existence, use or maintenance of the newsrack. If the Village or its officers, directors, employees and agents are named as defendants in any personal injury or property damage claim or suit concerning a newsrack, the Village may tender and the applicant must accept defense of all claims and suits which do not allege specific misconduct, misfeasance or malfeasance on the part of the Village or its officers, directors, employees and agents as the proximate or contributing cause of the loss. 
(4)  That, upon the removal of a newsrack, the permittee shall restore the property where the newsrack was located to the condition of the property prior to the installation of the newsrack, normal wear and tear excepted. 
(Code 1979, § 42.3252)  
Sec. 26-1036. - Display. 
An administrative/inspection permit issued under this division shall be posted permanently in a conspicuous location upon the newsrack for which it was issued. 
(Code 1979, § 42.323)  
Sec. 26-1037. - Revocation. 
The Village Manager is hereby given the authority to revoke a newsrack administrative/inspection permit if a court of competent jurisdiction finds that: 
(1)  The permittee has not complied with applicable codes, ordinances, statutes, laws, policies or rules and regulations; 
(2)  A newsrack is a danger to the public, health, safety or welfare; or 
(3)  The permittee has made fraudulent, false or misrepresentative statements in the application for a permit. 
(Code 1979, § 42.3210)  
Sec. 26-1038. - Contents and service of notices. 
(a)  Contents. All notices required to be given in accordance with this article shall be in writing, setting forth the reasons for the denial or revocation of an administrative/inspection permit or the removal of a newsrack and the date the newsrack will be removed. The notice shall inform the permittee that the permittee has the right to request a hearing before the Village Manager and that the decision of the Village Manager, after the hearing, is appealable to the Mayor and Board of Trustees. 
(b)  Service. All notices shall be sent by certified mail, return receipt requested, to the permittee specified on the application. A copy of the notice shall be sent by first class mail to the distributor, if known. If notice is being sent regarding a newsrack for which no permit has been issued, reasonable efforts should be made to determine the identity of the person placing the newsrack and notice shall be sent in accordance with this section. Notice shall be considered given on the date such notice is mailed. 
(Code 1979, § 42.3212)  
Sec. 26-1039. - Hearings. 
The Village Manager or designee shall send notice of intent to revoke a newsrack administrative/inspection permit or remove a newsrack. A newsrack administrative/inspection permit shall not be revoked unless the permittee has had an opportunity to present evidence in the permittee's behalf. The Village Manager or designee shall, within 5 business days of the hearing, issue a written order of the findings. Such written order shall be sent to the permittee in accordance with the notice provisions of Section 26-1038. If, within 10 days of the notice, the permittee does not request a hearing in writing, the Village Manager shall have the subject newsrack removed. 
(Code 1979, § 42.3213)  
Sec. 26-1040. - Appeals. 
(a)  Generally. A permittee, or, if no permit has been issued, the person responsible for the installation of the newsrack, may appeal decisions of the Village Manager or designee only after a hearing is requested and a decision is rendered by the Village Manager or designee. If a hearing has not been requested, the decisions and determinations of the Village Manager are not appealable to the Mayor and Board of Trustees. 
(b)  Filing of appeal. A written notice of intent to appeal a decision of the Village Manager or designee must be filed with the Village Clerk within 20 days of the issuance of a notice of revocation, a notice of removal or the order of findings by the Village Manager or designee as provided in this article. 
(c)  Hearing date. All appeals shall be heard by the Mayor and Board of Trustees at a regularly scheduled Board of Trustees meeting within 30 days of the notice of appeal. The Village Clerk shall be responsible for notifying the individual filing the notice of appeal of the date, by certified mail, return receipt requested. 
(d)  Conduct of hearing; decision. The Mayor and Board of Trustees may reverse, affirm or modify the decision of the Village Manager. The Mayor and Board of Trustees' decision shall be based on a review of the facts as presented to the Village Manager and the standards as set forth in this article. The person appealing the decision of the Village Manager may present such person's case to the Board of Trustees, but may not introduce facts or factors not presented to the Village Manager. 
(Code 1979, § 42.3214)  
Sec. 26-1041. - Transfer. 
Administrative/inspection permits issued under this division are only valid for the person, periodical and location specified in the inspection permit application and are not assignable or transferable. 
(Code 1979, § 42.323)  
Secs. 26-1042—26-1060. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE XXII. - RESERVED 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 08-1-C-3573, § 2, adopted Jan. 7, 2008, deleted Art. XXII, §§ 26-1061—26-1120, in its entirety. Former Art. XXII, §§ 26-1061—26-1120, pertained to public parking lots, and derived from Code 1979, §§ 42.241—42.249.  
ARTICLE XXIII. - PAWNBROKERS AND PRECIOUS METALS DEALERS[12] 
Footnotes: 
--- (12) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 08-1-C-3573, § 2, adopted Jan. 7, 2008, deleted Art. XXII, §§ 26-1121—26-1170, in its entirety. Former Art. XXIVII, §§ 26-1121—26-1170, pertained to public garages, and derived from Code 1979, §§ 42.251, 42.252.  Subsequently, Ord. No. 14-8-C-4079, § 1, adopted Aug. 4, 2014, enacted new provisions as herein set out. 
 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 26-1121. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Pawnbroker means any person or entity who lends money on deposit or pledge of personal property, or who deals in the purchase of personal property on condition of selling the same back at a stipulated price, or who makes a public display at a place of business of any sign generally used by pawnbrokers to denote the business, or who publicly exhibits a sign to the effect that it provides money on loan for personal property or deposit or pledge. 
Precious Metals Dealer means any person or entity, aside from a Transient Merchant as defined in Section 26-1371, whose primary business is the purchase and sale of precious metals. 
(Ord. No. 14-8-C-4079, § 1, 8-4-2014)  
Sec. 26-1122. - Violations declared nuisance. 
Violations of this Article are declared a public nuisance as that term is defined in Section 42-35. The Village Manager or designee may, in addition to other remedies provided for in Chapter 42, Article II, recommend that the Corporation Counsel seek injunctive relief or pursue other civil actions necessary to eradicate the nuisance. 
(Ord. No. 14-8-C-4079, § 1, 8-4-2014)  
Sec. 26-1123. - Transactions with minors. 
It shall be unlawful for any licensee under this article to purchase or receive from minors, any article of property. 
(Ord. No. 14-8-C-4079, § 1, 8-4-2014)  
Sec. 26-1124. - Required records; inspection of goods and records. 
Every licensee under this Article shall keep a record of all property purchased, pledged, or sold, and shall maintain such record pursuant to the following: 
a.  All records, together with the articles themselves, shall be open to inspection by any member of the Police Department at all reasonable hours. 
b.  All licensees shall subscribe to, utilize, and participate in the recordkeeping system and vendor of the Police Department's approval. 
c.  All items purchased, pawned, or pledged shall be entered into such recordkeeping system within twelve (12) hours of receipt of the item. 
(Ord. No. 14-8-C-4079, § 1, 8-4-2014)  
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE 
 
Sec. 26-1125. - Required. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to set up or keep a Pawnbroker's or Precious Metals Dealer's establishment without first obtaining a license in accordance with the provisions of this Article. 
(b)  Any licensee under this section must have a permanent location in the Village at which to conduct business. A separate license shall be required for each location, regardless of whether multiple establishments are operated by the same person or entity. 
(Ord. No. 14-8-C-4079, § 1, 8-4-2014)  
Sec. 26-1126. - Number of licenses. 
(a)  There shall be no more than three (3) active and valid Pawnbroker licenses in existence at any given time. 
(b)  There shall be no more than one (1) active and valid Precious Metals Dealer license in existence at any given time. 
(Ord. No. 14-8-C-4079, § 1, 8-4-2014)  
Sec. 26-1127. - Location. 
No new license shall be granted for any establishment located on a street with an Average Daily Traffic count of 15,000 vehicles or higher, as determined by the Village Engineering Department, or within 300 feet of any intersection with such a street. No new license shall be granted for any establishment located within 300 feet of a school or religious institution. 
(Ord. No. 14-8-C-4079, § 1, 8-4-2014)  
Sec. 26-1128. - Application information. 
Applications for licenses under this Article shall be made to the Village Manager or designee on forms prescribed and furnished by the Village Manager or designee. The Village Manager or designee may request additional information from the applicant. In the case of a legal entity applying for a license, the applicant shall list all officers and owners of the entity, and provide an annual corporate report verifying this information. 
(Ord. No. 14-8-C-4079, § 1, 8-4-2014)  
Sec. 26-1129. - Action on application. 
All license applications as required by this Article shall be acted upon within thirty (30) days of the Village Manager's or designee's receipt of such application. 
(Ord. No. 14-8-C-4079, § 1, 8-4-2014)  
Sec. 26-1130. - Review of application; investigation of applicant; fingerprinting. 
(a)  In addition to the application required by this Article, each individual applicant, managing partner in a co-partnership, or officers and board of directors of a corporation must undergo fingerprinting, under the direction of the Chief of Police or designee and may also be required to submit to further investigation. The fee for such fingerprinting is set forth in Section 46-73. 
(b)  Upon receipt of the application, the fingerprints, and the fee, the Village Manager or designee shall review the application and shall cause to be made such investigation of the applicant's moral character and business responsibility as the Village Manager shall deem necessary to safeguard and protect the public good, safety and welfare. 
(Ord. No. 14-8-C-4079, § 1, 8-4-2014)  
Sec. 26-1131. - Grounds for denial, discipline, suspension and revocation. 
The Village Manager or designee may (i) deny an application for a license, (ii) refuse to renew a license, or (iii) suspend or revoke a license or permit, if it is determined that the applicant or licensee, or an owner, officer or employee of the applicant or licensee: 
(a)  Was convicted of any crime under the laws of the United States or any state or territory therein that is either: (i) a felony, or (ii) a misdemeanor pertaining to battery, fraud, theft or confidence games. Conviction, as used in this paragraph, shall include a finding or verdict of guilty, an admission of guilt, or a plea of nolo contendere; 
(b)  Made fraudulent, false or misrepresentative statements, or material omissions, in the application for the license; 
(c)  Is indebted to the Village for required fees, costs incurred by the Village in relation to the individual or entity, or outstanding fines or penalties; 
(d)  Has not complied with applicable codes, ordinances, statutes, laws or rules and regulations of the Village or State of Illinois; or 
(e)  Is of unsatisfactory moral character and business responsibility. 
(Ord. No. 14-8-C-4079, § 1, 8-4-2014)  
Sec. 26-1132. - Display. 
Any license issued in accordance with the provisions of this Article shall be prominently displayed at the location for which the license has been issued. 
(Ord. No. 14-8-C-4079, § 1, 8-4-2014)  
Sec. 26-1133. - Renewal. 
All licenses expire at the end of each Village fiscal year. Licenses may be renewed, based upon a request and payment of the fee by the respective licensee, however, the Village Manager or designee is authorized to review a renewal request in the same manner as an initial application. 
(Ord. No. 14-8-C-4079, § 1, 8-4-2014)  
Sec. 26-1134. - Temporary suspension. 
In the event the Village Manager finds that there is sufficient evidence that indicates the occurrence of criminal behavior or a practice that would constitute a danger to the public, he or she may temporarily suspend a license without a hearing simultaneously with the notification of the right to a hearing provided for in Section 26-1136. In the event that the Village Manager suspends a license issued under this Article, a hearing by the Village Manager may be held within 30 calendar days after the suspension has occurred at the request of the licensee. 
(Ord. No. 14-8-C-4079, § 1, 8-4-2014)  
Sec. 26-1135. - Contents and service of notices. 
(a)  Contents. All notices required to be given in accordance with this division shall be in writing, setting forth the reasons for the denial or revocation of the license. The notice shall inform the applicant or licensee that the applicant or licensee has the right to request a hearing before the Village Manager. 
(b)  Service. All notices shall be sent by certified mail, return receipt requested, to the applicant or licensee specified on the application or license. Notice shall be considered given on the date such notice is mailed. 
(Ord. No. 14-8-C-4079, § 1, 8-4-2014)  
Sec. 26-1136. - Hearings. 
(a)  In addition to the provisions contained in this article, the Village Manager shall have the authority to establish rules and regulations for the conduct of a hearing relating to the revocation or suspension of a license. The Village Manager or designee shall send notice of intent to revoke a license issued under this division. A license shall not be revoked unless the licensee has had an opportunity to present evidence in the licensee's behalf. 
(b)  The Village Manager or designee shall, within five (5) business days of the hearing, issue a written order of the findings. Such written order shall be sent to the licensee in accordance with the notice provisions of Section 26-1135. 
(c)  If, within ten (10) days of the Notice of Denial of License or Notice of Intent to Revoke, the licensee does not request a hearing in writing, the Village Manager may: 
(1)  Maintain the denial of the license; 
(2)  Lift or extend the suspension of the license; or 
(3)  Reinstate or revoke the license. 
(Ord. No. 14-8-C-4079, § 1, 8-4-2014)  
Sec. 26-1137. - Fees. 
Fee for licenses under this Article shall be set forth in Section 46-73. Fees for commercial inspections under this Article shall be set forth in Section 46-133. 
(Ord. No. 14-8-C-4079, § 1, 8-4-2014)  
Sec. 26-1138. - Transfer. 
No license issued or granted under this Article shall be assigned or transferred to any other person or entity other than to the person or entity to which such license was issued. No individual or entity other than the licensee shall act or do business under such license. 
(Ord. No. 14-8-C-4079, § 1, 8-4-2014)  
ARTICLE XXIV. - RAFFLES[13] 
Footnotes: 
--- (13) --- 
State Law reference— Raffles Act, 230 ILCS 15/0.01 et seq. 
 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 26-1171. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Charitable organization means an organization or institution organized and operated to benefit an indefinite number of the public. 
Educational organization means an organization or institution organized and operated to provide systematic instruction in useful branches of learning by methods common to schools and institutions of learning which compare favorably in their scope and intensity with the course of study presented in tax-supported schools. 
Fraternal organization means an organization of persons, including but not limited to ethnic organizations, having a common interest, organized and operated exclusively to promote the welfare of its members and to benefit the general public on a continuing and consistent basis. 
Labor organization means an organization composed of workers organized with the objective of betterment of the conditions of those engaged in such pursuit and the development of a higher degree of efficiency in their respective occupations. 
Net proceeds means the gross receipts from the conduct of raffles, less reasonable sums expended for prizes, local license fees and other reasonable operating expenses incurred as a result of operating a raffle. 
Nonprofit organization means an organization or institution organized and conducted on a not-for-profit basis, with no personal profit inuring to anyone as a result of the operation. 
Raffle means a form of lottery as defined in 720 ILCS 5/28-2, conducted by an organization licensed under this article, in which: 
(1)  The player pays or agrees to pay something of value for a chance, represented and differentiated by a number or by a combination of numbers or by some other medium, 1 or more of which chances is to be designated the winning chance. 
(2)  The winning chance is to be determined through a drawing or by some other method based on an element of chance by an act or set of acts on the part of persons conducting or connected with the lottery, except that the winning chance shall not be determined by the outcome of a publicly exhibited sporting contest. 
Religious organization means any church, congregation, society, or organization founded for the purpose of religious worship. 
Veterans' organization means an organization or association composed of members of which substantially all are individuals who are veterans or spouses, widows, or widowers of veterans, the primary purpose of which is to promote the welfare of its members and to provide assistance to the general public in such a way as to confer a public benefit. 
(Code 1979, § 42.302) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 26-1172. - Conduct of raffles; use of proceeds. 
Licenses issued under this article are subject to the following restrictions: 
(1)  The entire net proceeds of any raffle must be exclusively devoted to the lawful purposes of the organization permitted to conduct that game. 
(2)  No person except a bona fide member of the sponsoring organization may participate in the management or operation of the raffle. 
(3)  No person may receive any remuneration or profit for participating in the management or operation of the raffle. 
(4)  A licensee may rent premises on which to determine the winning chance or chances in a raffle only from an organization which is also licensed under this article. 
(5)  Raffle chances may be sold or issued only within the area specified on the license and winning chances may be determined only at those locations specified on the licenses. 
(6)  No person under the age of 18 years may participate in the conducting of raffles or chances. A person under the age of 18 years may be within the area where winning chances are being determined only when accompanied by such person's parent or guardian. 
(7)  The aggregate retail value of all prizes and merchandise awarded by a licensee in a single raffle should not exceed $200,000.00. 
(8)  The maximum retail value of each prize awarded in a single raffle should not exceed $200,000.00. 
(9)  The maximum price which may be charged for each raffle chance issued or sold shall not exceed $200.00. 
(10)  The maximum number of days during which chances may be issued or sold shall not exceed 180 days. 
(Code 1979, § 42.305)
