Sec. 26-1173. - Raffles manager. 
All operation of and the conduct of raffles shall be under the supervision of a single raffles manager designated by the organization. The manager shall give a fidelity bond, in a sum to be determined by the Village Manager or designee for each application, in favor of the organization, conditioned upon the manager's honesty in the performing of the manager's duties. Terms of the bond shall provide that notice shall be given in writing to the licensing authority not less than 30 days prior to its cancellation. The Village may waive this bond requirement by including a waiver provision in the license issued to an organization under this article; provided that a license containing such waiver provision shall be granted only by unanimous vote of the members of the licensed organization. 
(Code 1979, § 42.306)  
Sec. 26-1174. - Records. 
(a)  Each organization licensed to conduct raffles and chances shall keep the records of its gross receipts, expenses and net proceeds for each single gathering or occasion at which winning chances are determined. All deductions from gross receipts for each single gathering or occasion shall be documented with receipts or other records indicating the amount, and the description of net proceeds shall be itemized as to payee, purpose, amount and date of payment. 
(b)  Gross receipts from the operation of raffles programs shall be segregated from other revenues of the organization, including bingo gross receipts if bingo games are also conducted by the same nonprofit organization pursuant to license therefor issued by the State Department of Revenue, and placed in a separate account. Each organization shall have a separate record of its raffles. The person who accounts for gross receipts, expenses and net proceeds from the operation of raffles shall not be the same person who accounts for other revenues of the organization. 
(c)  Each organization licensed to conduct raffles shall report monthly to its membership, and to the licensing local unit of government, its gross receipts, expenses and net proceeds from raffles, and the distribution of net proceeds itemized as required in this section. 
(d)  Records required in this section shall be preserved for 3 years, and organizations shall make available their records relating to operation of raffles for public inspection at reasonable times and places. 
(Code 1979, § 42.307)  
Secs. 26-1175—26-1190. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE 
 
Sec. 26-1191. - Required. 
It shall be unlawful for any person or organization to operate or conduct a raffle in the Village without first obtaining a license. 
(Code 1979, § 42.301)  
Sec. 26-1192. - Limitation on scope of license. 
Nothing in this article shall be construed to authorize the conducting or operating of any gambling scheme, enterprise, activity or device other than raffles as provided in this article. 
(Code 1979, § 42.301)  
Sec. 26-1193. - Action on application. 
All raffle licenses shall be acted upon within 30 days from the date of application. 
(Code 1979, § 42.301)  
Sec. 26-1194. - Conditions. 
Raffles shall be conducted only by organizations licensed pursuant to this division, and such licenses are subject to the following conditions: 
(1)  Licenses shall be issued only to bona fide religious, charitable, labor, fraternal, educational or veterans' organizations that operate without profit to their members and which have been in existence continuously for a period of 5 years immediately before making application for a license and which have had during that entire 5-year period a bona fide membership engaged in carrying out their objectives. 
(2)  The license and application for license must specify the area or areas within the licensing authority in which raffle chances will be sold or issued, the time period during which raffle chances will be sold or issued, the time of determination of winning chances and the location or locations at which winning chances will be determined. 
(3)  The application must contain a sworn statement attesting to the not-for-profit character of the prospective licensee organization, signed by the presiding officer and the secretary of that organization. 
(Code 1979, § 42.303)  
Sec. 26-1195. - Ineligibility for license. 
The following are ineligible for a license under this division: 
(1)  Any person who has been convicted of a felony. 
(2)  Any person who is or has been a professional gambler or gambling promoter. 
(3)  Any person who is not of good moral character. 
(4)  Any firm or corporation in which a person defined in subsection (1), (2) or (3) of this section has a proprietary, equitable or credit interest, or in which such a person is active or employed. 
(5)  Any organization in which a person defined in subsection (1), (2) or (3) of this section is an officer, director or employee, whether compensated or not. 
(6)  Any organization in which a person defined in subsection (1), (2) or (3) of this section is to participate in the management or operation of a raffle. 
(Code 1979, § 42.304)  
Sec. 26-1196. - Fee. 
The fee for a raffle license shall be as set forth in Section 46-73 and shall only be valid for 1 raffle. 
(Code 1979, § 42.301)  
Secs. 26-1197—26-1220. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE XXV. - RETAIL PRICE MARKING AND DISPLAY OF FOOD[14] 

Footnotes: 
--- (14) --- 
State Law reference— Illinois Food, Drug and Cosmetic Act, 410 ILCS 620/1 et seq. 
 
Sec. 26-1221. - Applicability of article. 
This article shall be applicable to all retail stores located in the Village. 
(Code 1979, § 42.171)  
Sec. 26-1222. - Marking of prices. 
(a)  Except as otherwise provided in this article, no person shall sell or offer to sell any item in a retail store unless the item contains a price marked thereon in Arabic numerals which can be easily read by the purchaser. 
(b)  The following items are excluded from the price marking requirement of this section: 
(1)  Identical items within a multi-pak package which is properly price-marked. 
(2)  Single cigars and single packages of cigarettes. 
(3)  Items sold in retail food stores that provide each consumer with a printed complete current list of all items for sale in the stores by product category (i.e., canned fruits, canned vegetables, cereal, paper products, etc.) indicating the retail price and the unit price of each item and which display a large sign indicating the price in easily readable Arabic numbers. 
(4)  Shelf marking giving unit prices in ounces or pounds for the purpose of comparison. Such shelf marking shall be in close proximity to each item. 
(Code 1979, § 42.172)  
Sec. 26-1223. - Universal Product Code (UPC) scanners. 
(a)  If UPC scanners are utilized, the following must be provided for the consumer: 
(1)  Cash register receipts shall be provided giving the date, item and price of each item purchased. 
(2)  The scanner price must conform to the marked or listed price. 
(b)  The retail store shall keep a log book of all errors in which the shelf marking price is different than the UPC scanner price and which shall also contain the corrective actions taken. This log book shall be open for inspection by the Village Manager or designee. 
(Code 1979, § 42.173) 
Cross reference— Electronic price scanners, § 26-1429.  
Sec. 26-1224. - Display of meat. 
(a)  All prepacked fresh meat sold or offered for sale shall be packaged in trays affording a minimum of 90 percent visibility of the area of the meat. 
(b)  The following meats are excluded from the packaging requirements of this section: 
(1)  Ground beef. 
(2)  Boneless cube and sandwich steaks. 
(3)  Fresh or smoked sausage. 
(4)  Smoked bacon. 
(5)  Bacon skins. 
(6)  Fresh side bacon. 
(7)  Fresh or frozen poultry parts. 
(8)  Smoked offal (entrails). 
(9)  Beef liver. 
(10)  Beef hooves. 
(11)  Beef franks. 
(12)  Beef hocks. 
(13)  Honeycomb tripe, kidneys, hearts and tongue. 
(14)  Pig tails. 
(15)  Pigs' feet. 
(16)  Pig snouts. 
(17)  Bones. 
(18)  Smoked sweet meats. 
(19)  Suet. 
(20)  Sweet breads. 
(21)  Neck bones. 
(22)  Salted meats. 
(23)  Casings. 
(24)  Hog maws. 
(25)  Cooked meat and poultry. 
(Code 1979, § 42.174)  
Secs. 26-1225—26-1250. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE XXVI. - SCRAP, DISCARDED OR USED MATERIALS DEALERS[15] 
Footnotes: 
--- (15) --- 
State Law reference— Authority to regulate secondhand and junk stores, 65 ILCS 5/11-42-3. 
 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 26-1251. - Violations declared nuisance. 
The operation or maintenance of any place where any scrap, discarded or used materials, secondhand furniture, old clothing, old jewelry, rags, old metal or miscellaneous articles of personal property are purchased or sold, or engaging in the business of collecting rags, old bottles, old metal or miscellaneous articles of personal property of any sort, with vehicles or carts, or the keeping of a junk shop or junkyard, in violation of this article is declared a public nuisance as that term is defined in Section 42-35. The Village Manager may, in addition to other remedies provided for in Chapter 42, Article II, recommend that the Corporation Counsel seek injunctive relief.  
Sec. 26-1252. - Transactions with minors. 
It shall be unlawful for any licensee under this article to purchase or receive from minors, without the written consent of their parents or guardians, any article of property. 
(Code 1979, § 42.263)  
Sec. 26-1253. - Required records; inspection of goods and records. 
Every licensee under this article shall keep a record of all articles purchased, which record, together with the articles themselves, shall be open to inspection by any member of the Police Department at all reasonable hours. 
(Code 1979, § 42.264)  
Secs. 26-1254—26-1270. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE 
 
Sec. 26-1271. - Required. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to set up or keep any place where any scrap, discarded or used materials, secondhand furniture, old clothing, old jewelry, rags, old metal or miscellaneous articles of personal property are purchased or sold, or follow the business of collecting rags, old bottles, old metal or miscellaneous articles of personal property of any sort, with vehicles or carts, or keep a junk shop or junkyard, without first obtaining a license in accordance with the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1979, § 42.261)  
Sec. 26-1272. - Application information. 
Applications for licenses under this division shall be made to the Village Manager or designee on forms prescribed and furnished by the Village Manager or designee. The Village Manager or designee may request additional information from the applicant.  
Sec. 26-1273. - Action on application. 
All licenses required by this division shall be acted upon within 30 days of the Village Manager's or designee's receipt of such application.  
Sec. 26-1274. - Review of application. 
Upon receipt of an application for a license under this division, the Village Manager or designee shall review and investigate the information contained therein. Such review may include an investigation of the applicant. 
(Code 1979, § 42.262)  
Sec. 26-1275. - Display. 
Any license issued in accordance with the provisions of this division shall be prominently displayed at the location for which the license has been issued.  
Sec. 26-1276. - Suspension or revocation. 
(a)  The Village Manager shall have the authority to revoke or suspend all licenses issued under this division. In addition to the provisions contained in this division, the Village Manager shall have the authority to establish rules and regulations for the conduct of a hearing relating to the revocation or suspension of a license. 
(b)  The Village Manager is hereby given the authority to revoke or suspend the license if the Village Manager finds: 
(1)  The licensee has not complied with applicable codes, ordinances, statutes, laws, policies or rules and regulations. 
(2)  The licensee has made fraudulent, false or misrepresentative statements in the application for the license. 
(3)  The licensee owes the Village required fees or outstanding fines or penalties.  
Sec. 26-1277. - Contents and service of notices. 
(a)  Contents. All notices required to be given in accordance with this division shall be in writing, setting forth the reasons for the denial or revocation of the license. The notice shall inform the applicant or licensee that the applicant or licensee has the right to request a hearing before the Village Manager. 
(b)  Service. All notices shall be sent by certified mail, return receipt requested, to the applicant or licensee specified on the application or license. Notice shall be considered given on the date such notice is mailed.  
Sec. 26-1278. - Hearings. 
The Village Manager or designee shall send notice of intent to revoke a license issued under this division. A license shall not be revoked unless the licensee has had an opportunity to present evidence in the licensee's behalf. The Village Manager or designee shall, within 5 business days of the hearing, issue a written order of the findings. Such written order shall be sent to the licensee in accordance with the notice provisions of Section 26-1277. If, within 10 days of the notice, the licensee does not request a hearing in writing, the license shall be revoked.  
Sec. 26-1279. - Fees. 
Fee for licenses under this division shall be as set forth in Section 46-73. 
(Code 1979, § 42.261)  
Sec. 26-1280. - Transfer. 
No license issued or granted under this division shall be assigned or transferred to any other person or corporation other than to the person to whom such license was issued. No individual or corporation other than the licensee shall act or do business under such license.  
Secs. 26-1281—26-1300. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE XXVII. - SIDEWALK SALES[16] 

Footnotes: 
--- (16) --- 
Cross reference— Streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 90. 
 
Sec. 26-1301. - Designation of sidewalk sale days. 
(a)  The Village Manager is authorized to designate up to four (4) "Sidewalk Sale Days" during a calendar year and each one shall have a duration of no more than four (4) consecutive days. 
(b)  The Village Manager may designate "Sidewalk Sale Days" upon his own initiative or upon application by any duly authorized Skokie business association or the Skokie Chamber of Commerce. 
(Code 1979, § 42.291; Ord. No. 08-1-C-3573, § 3, 1-7-2008; Ord. No. 14-5-C-4058, § 1, 5-5-2014) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 14-5-C-4058, § 1, adopted May 5, 2014, changed the title of § 26-1301 from "Designation of sidewalk sale days; permit" to "Designation of sidewalk sale days."  
Sec. 26-1302. - Establishment of application, rules and regulations for sidewalk sale days. 
(a)  The Village Manager shall promulgate a set of rules and regulations with respect to the coordination, conditions and public safety of Sidewalk Sale Days, including the availability of sidewalk space for private vendors and artists in front of businesses not participating in a Sidewalk Sale Day. 
(b)  An application for the designation for Sidewalk Sale Days shall be available in the Village Manager's Office. The application shall be in a form approved by the Village Manager. 
(Code 1979, § 42.292; Ord. No. 14-5-C-4058, § 1, 5-5-2014) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 14-5-C-4058, § 1, adopted May 5, 2014, changed the title of § 26-1301 from "Establishment of regulations for conduct of sales" to "Establishment of application, rules and regulations for sidewalk sale days."  
Sec. 26-1303. - Conflicting regulations. 
All existing codes, ordinances, and rules and regulations that are inconsistent with the provisions of this article shall be deemed waived during the days designated pursuant to this article. 
(Code 1979, § 42.293)  
Secs. 26-1304—26-1320. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE XXVIII. - SOUND AMPLIFIERS[17] 
Footnotes: 
--- (17) --- 
Cross reference— Noise, § 42-71 et seq. 
 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 26-1321. - Restrictions on use. 
(a)  No licensee under this article shall use, operate or employ any such device within the Village between the hours of 10:00 p.m. and 8:00 a.m. No licensee shall use or operate or employ any such device within a radius of 2 blocks from any hospital or church or synagogue while services are being held there. 
(b)  No licensee shall use any device licensed under this article to make any false representation about any matter, product or project for which the sale of is prohibited by any code, statute, or ordinance. No licensee shall cause or permit to be emanated or emitted from any device licensed under this article any lewd, obscene, profane, or indecent language or sounds. 
(Code 1979, § 42.274)  
Secs. 26-1322—26-1340. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE 
 
Sec. 26-1341. - Required. 
It shall be unlawful for commercial purposes, public assemblies, parades, street demonstrations or similar activities to maintain or operate any loudspeaker or amplifier connected with any radio, phonograph, microphone, or other device by which sounds are magnified and made heard over any public street or public place without first obtaining a license in accordance with the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1979, § 42.271)  
Sec. 26-1342. - Application information. 
Applications for licenses under this division shall be made to the Village Manager or designee on forms prescribed and furnished by the Village Manager or designee. The Village Manager or designee may request additional information from the applicant. 
(Code 1979, § 42.272)  
Sec. 26-1343. - Issuance; conditions. 
The license required by this division shall be issued upon payment of the required license fee. Any license issued in accordance with this division shall only allow the use of the device for which the permit is issued, subject to the terms and conditions of this article, only for the date specified in the license. 
(Code 1979, § 42.273)  
Sec. 26-1344. - Fees. 
Fee for licenses under this division shall be as set forth in Section 46-73. 
(Code 1979, § 42.271)  
Secs. 26-1345—26-1370. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE XXIX. - TRANSIENT MERCHANTS[18] 
Footnotes: 
--- (18) --- 
Cross reference— Peddlers and solicitors, ch. 78. 
State Law reference— Authority to regulate transient merchants, 65 ILCS 5/11-42-5; Transient Merchant Act, 225 ILCS 465/1 et seq. 
 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 26-1371. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Transient merchant means any person, whether as owner, agent, consignee or employee, whether a resident of the Village or not, who engages in a temporary business for any period of time less than 12 months, of buying or selling, at wholesale or retail, and delivering to any person, goods, wares, and merchandise within the Village, and who, for the purpose of conducting such business, occupies or uses any parcel of land, building, tent, room, apartment, shop, store, structure, or other place within the Village for the purpose of exhibition and sale or offering to purchase or sell such goods, wares, and merchandise, either privately, publicly or at public auction. This definition shall not apply to: 
(1)  The transportation of goods, wares, and merchandise and chattels of every description which are merely being transported or which were raised, produced or manufactured by the person transporting the goods, wares, merchandise or chattels. 
(2)  Persons selling vegetables, fruits or perishable farm products at booths on or adjacent to the property owned or occupied by them. 
(3)  Any persons who, while occupying a temporary location, do not sell from stock but exhibit samples only for the purpose of securing orders for future delivery only. 
(4)  Persons using motor vehicles for the transportation of goods, wares and merchandise for delivery to an established list of customers or clientele, or to or from an established place of business. 
(5)  Persons conducting judicial or other sales under legal proceedings. 
(6)  Persons selling at circuses, carnivals or other public events, provided they are otherwise licensed by the Village. 
(Code 1979, § 42.281) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 26-1372. - Violations declared nuisance. 
Engaging in business as a transient merchant in violation of this article is declared a public nuisance as that term is defined in Section 42-35. The Village Manager may, in addition to other remedies provided for in Chapter 42, Article II, recommend that the Corporation Counsel seek injunctive relief.  
Sec. 26-1373. - Enforcement. 
It shall be the duty of the police officers of the Village to inspect and inquire of all licensees subject to this article to determine whether the provisions of this article have been complied with and to enforce the provisions of this article against any licensee or person in the licensee's employ found to be in violation thereof. 
(Code 1979, § 42.289)  
Sec. 26-1374. - Applicability to persons temporarily associated with local business. 
No person who would otherwise be conducting or engaged in a transient business shall be exempt from the provisions of this article by reason of being temporarily associated with any local dealer, trader, merchant or auctioneer, or by reason of conducting such business in connection with or as a part of the business of any such local person. 
(Code 1979, § 42.282)  
Sec. 26-1375. - Use of loud noises or speaking devices. 
No licensee under this article, or anyone in the licensee's behalf, shall shout, make any outcry, blow a horn, ring a bell or use any other sound device upon any of the streets, sidewalks, alleys, parks or other public places of the Village or upon any private premises in the Village, whereby sound of sufficient volume is emitted or produced thereby or therefrom capable of being heard upon the streets, sidewalks, alleys or parks or other public places, for the purpose of attracting attention to any goods, wares or merchandise which such licensee offers to sell. 
(Code 1979, § 42.288) 
Cross reference— Noise, § 42-71 et seq.  
Secs. 26-1376—26-1390. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE 
 
Sec. 26-1391. - Required. 
It shall be unlawful for a transient merchant to engage in or conduct business as a principal or agent in the Village without first obtaining a license in accordance with the provisions of this division. 
(Code 1979, § 42.283)  
Sec. 26-1392. - Application information. 
Applications for licenses under this division shall be made to the Village Manager or designee on forms prescribed and furnished by the Village Manager or designee. The Village Manager or designee may request additional information from the applicant. 
(Code 1979, § 42.284)  
Sec. 26-1393. - Action on application. 
All licenses required by this division shall be acted upon within 30 days of the Village Manager's or designee's receipt of such application.  
Sec. 26-1394. - Review of application; investigation of applicant; fingerprinting. 
(a)  In addition to the application required by this division, each individual applicant, managing partner in a co-partnership, or officers and board of directors of a corporation must undergo fingerprinting, under the direction of the Chief of Police or designee. The fee for such fingerprinting is set forth in Section 46-73. 
(b)  Upon receipt of the application, the fingerprints, and the fee, the Village Manager or designee shall cause to be made such investigation of the applicant's moral character and business responsibility as the Manager shall deem necessary to safeguard and protect the public good, safety and welfare. 
(c)  If, as a result of such investigation, the applicant's moral character and business responsibility are found to be unsatisfactory, the application shall be denied. 
(Code 1979, § 42.285)  
Sec. 26-1395. - Issuance. 
If, as a result of the investigation provided for in Section 26-1394, the applicant's moral character and business reputation is found to be satisfactory, the Village Manager or designee shall so certify in writing, and thereupon the Village shall issue a license to the applicant, provided the fee therefor is paid and the bond or bonds required are deposited, as provided in this division. 
(Code 1979, § 42.286)  
Sec. 26-1396. - Record of licenses; contents of license. 
The Village Manager or designee shall keep a full and complete record in the office of the Manager or designee of all licenses issued, which shall include the application and the certification by the Village Manager. The license shall show the date upon which it was issued, the nature of the business authorized to be conducted, the location or place where the business may be conducted under the license, whether a vehicle, motor or otherwise, will be used in connection with the conduct of the business, the name of the person authorized to conduct the business, the expiration date of the license, the amount of the license fee paid, the nature and amount of the bond or bonds deposited, and the fact that the license is nontransferable both as between persons and the vehicle or location or place of conducting business. A number shall be assigned to the license, which number shall be preceded by the last 2 numbers of the year in which it is issued. 
(Code 1979, § 42.286)  
Sec. 26-1397. - Suspension or revocation. 
(a)  The Village Manager shall have the authority to revoke or suspend all licenses issued under this division. In addition to the provisions contained in this article, the Village Manager shall have the authority to establish rules and regulations for the conduct of a hearing relating to the revocation or suspension of a license. 
(b)  The Village Manager is hereby given the authority to revoke or suspend the license if the Village Manager finds: 
(1)  The licensee has not complied with applicable codes, ordinances, statutes, laws, policies or rules and regulations. 
(2)  The licensee has made fraudulent, false or misrepresentative statements in the application for the license. 
(3)  The licensee owes the Village required fees or outstanding fines or penalties.  
Sec. 26-1398. - Contents and service of notices. 
(a)  Contents. All notices required to be given in accordance with this division shall be in writing, setting forth the reasons for the denial or revocation of the license. The notice shall inform the applicant or licensee that the applicant or licensee has the right to request a hearing before the Village Manager. 
(b)  Service. All notices shall be sent by certified mail, return receipt requested, to the applicant or licensee specified on the application or license. Notice shall be considered given on the date such notice is mailed.  
Sec. 26-1399. - Hearings. 
The Village Manager or designee shall send notice of intent to revoke a license issued under this division. A license shall not be revoked unless the licensee has had an opportunity to present evidence in the licensee's behalf. The Village Manager or designee shall, within 5 business days of the hearing, issue a written order of the findings. Such written order shall be sent to the licensee in accordance with the notice provisions of Section 26-1398. If, within 10 days of the notice, the licensee does not request a hearing in writing, the license shall be revoked.  
Sec. 26-1400. - Fees. 
Fee for licenses under this division shall be as set forth in Section 46-73. 
(Code 1979, § 42.283)  
Sec. 26-1401. - Bond and insurance. 
(a)  Prior to the issuance of the license issued under this division, the applicant shall have an indemnity and performance bond issued to the Village in a sum determined by the Village Manager. The bond shall be for the faithful observance and performance by the applicant for the license of all of the provisions of this article for which the license is issued and compliance with all codes, ordinances, statutes and rules and regulations, and for the purpose of protecting the public against any fraudulent acts or misrepresentations as to weight, measure, grade, quality, quantity, character or class of the goods, wares and merchandise to be sold and delivered by the licensee, and the bond shall further guarantee the actual payment by the licensee of any and all bank checks, drafts, promissory notes or other evidences of indebtedness delivered by the licensee in payment for the purchase of goods, wares and merchandise to be sold and delivered by the licensee. The bond shall further provide for the indemnification of the Village and hold the Village harmless for all property damage or personal injury resulting from the licensee, and shall be conditioned to pay any judgment or judgments obtained against the licensee for civil liability arising out of the conduct of business, excluding, however, any cause of action or damages arising out of the operation of a vehicle, motor or otherwise, provision for which is provided in subsection (b) of this section. 
(b)  If the business of a licensee is to be conducted from or by the use of any vehicle, motor or otherwise, the licensee shall also provide a liability insurance policy, issued by an insurance company authorized to do business in the State, and approved as to form by the Village Manager or designee. The insurance policy shall insure or indemnify the licensee for liability arising out of the operation of each vehicle, motor or otherwise, used in connection with the conduct of the licensed business, in an amount to be determined by the Village Manager. 
(c)  All bonds or insurance required shall be maintained by the licensee in full force and effect for the full period of time in which the temporary business is to be conducted, plus 30 days following the discontinuance or termination of such temporary business. If any bond or insurance required by this article expires or is cancelled by either the licensee, the bond company or the insurer, and is not immediately replaced with bonds of the same kind, type and amount, such expiration or cancellation shall operate as a simultaneous revocation of the license, and thereafter it shall be unlawful to conduct or operate such temporary business. All bonds and insurance required by this article shall require that the Village receive written notice from the issuing company, 30 days prior to cancellation, termination or expiration. 
(Code 1979, § 42.286)  
Sec. 26-1402. - Transfer. 
No license issued or granted under this division shall be assigned or transferred to any other person or corporation other than to the person to whom such license was issued. No individual or corporation other than the licensee shall act or do business under such license.  
Secs. 26-1403—26-1420. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE XXX. - WEIGHTS AND MEASURES[19] 

Footnotes: 
--- (19) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 11-12-C-3866, § 1, adopted Dec. 5, 2011, amended and replaced the former Art. XXX, §§ 26-1421—26-1430, and enacted a new Art. XXX as set out herein. The former Art. XXX pertained to weights and measures and derived from the Code of 1979, §§ 49.01—49.05, §§ 49.07, 49.08, §§ 49.10—49.12. 
Cross reference— Consumer protection, ch. 34; weights and measures inspection and testing fees, § 46-43. 
State Law reference— Weights and Measures Act, 225 ILCS 470/1 et seq. 
 
Sec. 26-1421. - State and federal standards adopted. 
The Standards of Weights and Measures as received by the State from the United States, and all standards of weights and measures as are adopted by the State, are by reference adopted as part of this article, and such standards shall be and become the standards of weights and measures for the Village. 
(Ord. No. 11-12-C-3866, § 1, 12-5-2011)  
Sec. 26-1422. - Electronic scanners. 
(a)  When an electronic cash register is interfaced with any weighing or measuring device, the final receipt presented to a customer shall include the name of the commodity, the price per pound or price per single count, and the total price charged. 
(b)  When a Universal Product Code scanner is used to arrive at a final selling price for tangible commodities, the final price shall not differ from the marked price of an item, the shelf price of an item, the principal display panel used to advertise the sales price of an item or, when a price list is provided, the listed price for each item. 
(Ord. No. 11-12-C-3866, § 1, 12-5-2011) 
Cross reference— Universal Product Code scanners, § 26-1223.  
Sec. 26-1423. - Gasoline price signs. 
(a)  Any sign, which advertises the price of gasoline per gallon or liter, and which is viewable to or intended to be viewed by a passing motorist or the general public, shall display the total price of gasoline per gallon or liter. 
(b)  Any automotive fuel station may display not more than 1 sign per street frontage, which shall advertise only the total price of gasoline per gallon or liter. 
(c)  All automotive fuel station price signs shall state the total price of gasoline per gallon or liter in numbers not more than 18 inches in height and not less than 12 inches in height. All fractional numbers which appear on such pump signs or any other gasoline station price advertising sign shall be at least ½ as large as the whole numbers. 
(d)  All automotive fuel station price advertising signs shall be displayed in such a manner as to be clearly viewable and readable from all streets upon which a gasoline station may have street frontage. 
(e)  As used in this section, the term "total price of gasoline per gallon or liter" shall mean that price which appears on the gasoline pump and which is the price per gallon or liter of gasoline which includes all federal, State and local taxes and which is to be the final price per gallon or liter of gasoline paid by the consumer. 
(f)  Gasoline shall not be sold by the liter and by the gallon in the same retail automotive fuel station. However, any signs advertising the price of gasoline per liter shall display with equal prominence the price that would be paid by a purchaser if such gasoline were sold by the gallon. 
(g)  Each gasoline dispensing pump in a retail automotive fuel station which dispenses gasoline by the liter shall display both the total price per gallon and the total price per liter. The price per gallon shall appear directly above the price per liter in numerals not less than 4 inches in height and not less than 2 inches in length. The price per liter shall appear directly below the gasoline price in numerals not less than 2 inches in height and 1 inch in length. These numerals shall be protected from the elements at all times. 
(h)  The term "gallon" shall refer to the standard non-metric measure of liquid volume. 
(Ord. No. 11-12-C-3866, § 1, 12-5-2011) 
Cross reference— Consumer protection, ch. 34; automobile service stations, § 50-41; signs, ch. 82.  
Chapter 30 - COMMUNITY DEVELOPMENT[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Administration, ch. 2; Department of Community Development, § 2-271 et seq.; buildings and building regulations, ch. 22; businesses, ch. 26; environment, ch. 42; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 90; subdivisions, ch. 94; utilities, ch. 110; zoning, ch. 118. 
Federal law references— Community development, 42 U.S.C.A. § 5301 et seq.; enterprise zone development, 42 U.S.C.A. § 11501 et seq. 
State Law reference— Urban problems, 315 ILCS 5/1 et seq.; community planning and development, 65 ILCS 5/11-39.1-1. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Secs. 30-1—30-30. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference— Economic development tax, § 98-71 et seq. 
State Law reference— Powers of municipalities re economic development project areas, 65 ILCS 110/60. 
 
Sec. 30-31. - Title of article. 
This article may be referred to as the "Village of Skokie Economic Development Revenue Bond Enabling Ordinance." 
(Code 1979, § 3.2401)  
Sec. 30-32. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Bond ordinance means an ordinance authorizing a specific issue of bonds adopted by the Board of Trustees of the Village in accordance with the policies and procedures set forth in this article. 
Economic development project means any land, interest in land, building, structure, facility, system, fixture, improvement, addition, appurtenance, machinery, or equipment, or any combination or portion thereof, and all real and personal property deemed necessary in connection therewith, for use by any person, provided that the existence of such economic development project will create or retain employment opportunities in the Village or increase the tax base thereof. 
Person means any individual, partnership, copartnership, firm, company, corporation (including public utilities), association, joint stock company, trust, estate, political subdivision, State agency, or any other legal entity, or their legal representatives, agents or assigns. 
Project means any economic development project located within the Village. 
Project costs includes the sum total of all reasonable or necessary costs incidental to the acquisition, construction, or reconstruction, repair, alteration, improvement and extension of a project, including, without limitation, the cost of studies and surveys; plans, specifications, architectural and engineering services; legal, marketing or other special services; financing, acquisition, demolition, construction, equipment and site development of new and rehabilitated buildings, and rehabilitation, reconstruction, repair or remodeling of existing buildings; and all other necessary and incidental expenses including an initial bond and interest reserve together with interest on bonds issued to finance a project during construction and for a reasonable time thereafter. 
User means the person or persons who will occupy, operate, maintain, or employ the project after acquisition or construction thereof, whether as owner, purchaser, lessee or otherwise. 
(Code 1979, § 3.2402) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 30-33. - Purpose of article. 
It is hereby determined and declared that the purpose of this article is to provide a financing device which will aid in financing the cost of projects, and the this article is hereby declared and determined to be for a public purpose and function pertaining to the government and affairs of the Village. 
(Code 1979, § 3.2403)  
Sec. 30-34. - Powers of Village enumerated. 
In addition to powers which it may now have, the Village shall have the power under this article to: 
(1)  Construct, acquire by gift, purchase or lease, reconstruct, improve, better or extend and finance 1 or more projects, whether or not now or hereafter in existence, and, if desirable, acquire by gift, purchase or lease lands or rights in land in connection with any project. 
(2)  Issue its revenue bonds to defray in whole or in part the project costs of any project, which bonds shall be issued pursuant to a bond ordinance authorizing the bonds. 
(3)  Enter into leases or other agreements with any user in order to secure the Village's revenue bonds; provided, however, that any such lease or other agreement must provide that such user shall pay to, for or on behalf of the Village an amount sufficient to pay principal, interest, redemption, premiums and all other costs in connection with the Village's revenue bonds so that such bonds will never constitute an indebtedness of the Village or a loan of its credit within the meaning of any constitutional or statutory provision. 
(4)  Pledge to the punctual payment of such bonds the interest thereon, and the redemption premiums, if any, the revenue and receipts to be received pursuant to such leases or other agreements. 
(5)  Mortgage any project in favor of the holder or holders of bonds issued therefor. 
(6)  Sell and convey any project, including, without limitation, the sale and conveyance thereof subject to a mortgage, if any, as provided in this article, for such price and at such time as the Mayor and Board of Trustees may determine. However, no sale or conveyance of any project shall ever be made in such manner as to impair the rights or interests of the holder or holders of any bonds issued under this article. 
(7)  Issue its bonds to refund, in whole or in part, bonds theretofore issued by the Village under the authority of this article. 
(Code 1979, § 3.2404)  
Sec. 30-35. - Exercise of powers; bonds generally. 
(a)  The exercise of all powers granted by this article shall be authorized by majority vote of the Mayor and Board of Trustees, and such bonds shall be authorized by the bond ordinance, which may be adopted at the same meeting at which it is introduced and shall take effect immediately upon adoption. 
(b)  The bonds shall bear interest at such rate or rates, shall be payable at such times, may be in 1 or more series, may bear such date or dates, may mature at such time or times not exceeding 40 years from their respective dates, may be payable in such medium of payment at such place or places, may carry such registration privileges, may be subject to such terms of redemption at such premiums, may be executed in such manner, may contain such terms, covenants and conditions, and may be in such form, either coupon or registered, as the bond ordinance may provide or as may be subsequently determined by the Mayor and Board of Trustees before the bonds are issued. The bonds may be sold at public or private sale in such manner and upon such terms as may be deemed advisable by the Mayor and Board of Trustees. The bonds shall be deemed to be investment securities and negotiable instruments within the meaning and for all purposes of the Uniform Commercial Code, 810 ILCS 5/1-101 et seq. 
(Code 1979, § 3.2405)  
Sec. 30-36. - Title to project. 
It shall not be necessary for the Village to own or acquire any project or part thereof financed under this article. 
(Code 1979, § 3.2406)  
Sec. 30-37. - Covenants in bonds. 
(a)  Any bond ordinance may contain covenants as to: 
(1)  The use and disposition of the revenues and receipts from the lease and other agreements or the project for which the bonds are to be issued, including the creation and maintenance of reserves; 
(2)  The issuance of other or additional bonds relating to any project or any rehabilitation, improvements, renovations, enlargements or additions thereto; 
(3)  The maintenance and repair of any project; 
(4)  The insurance to be carried thereon and the use and disposition of insurance moneys; 
(5)  The appointment of any bank or trust company within or outside the State having the necessary trust powers as trustee for the benefit of the bondholders, paying agent and bond registrar; 
(6)  The investment of any funds held by such trustee; and 
(7)  The terms and conditions upon which the holders of the bonds or any portion thereof, or any trustees therefor, are entitled to the appointment of a receiver. 
(b)  The bond ordinance may provide that the principal of and interest on the bonds shall be secured by a mortgage or indenture of trust covering the project for which the bonds are issued and may include any improvements or extensions thereafter made. Such mortgage or indenture of trust may contain such covenants and agreements to properly safeguard the bonds as may be provided for in the bond ordinance and shall be executed in the manner provided for in the bond ordinance. The provisions of this article and the bond ordinance and any such mortgage or indenture of trust shall constitute a contract with the holder or holders of the bonds and continue in effect until the principal of, the interest on, and the redemption premiums, if any, on the bonds so issued have been fully paid, or until provision for payment shall have been made as provided in the bond ordinance, and the duties of the Village and its corporate authorities and officers under this article and any bond ordinance and any such mortgage or indenture of trust shall be enforceable by mandamus, foreclosure of any such mortgage or indenture of trust or other appropriate suit, action or proceedings in any court of competent jurisdiction, in the manner and subject to the terms of such bond ordinance, mortgage or indenture of trust. 
(Code 1979, § 3.2407)  
Sec. 30-38. - Signatures of officers on bonds; validity of bonds. 
Bonds issued under this article shall bear the signatures of such officers of the Village as may be designated in the bond ordinance and such signatures shall be the valid and binding signatures of such officers, notwithstanding that before the delivery thereof and payment therefor any or all of the persons whose signatures appear thereon have ceased to be officers of the Village. The validity of the bonds is not dependent on or affected by the validity or regularity of any proceedings relating to the acquisition, purchase, construction, reconstruction, improvement, equipping, betterment, or extension of the project for which the bonds are issued. The bond ordinance may provide that the bonds shall contain a recital that they are issued pursuant to this article, which recital shall be conclusive evidence of their validity and of the regularity of their issuance. 
(Code 1979, § 3.2408)  
Sec. 30-39. - Lien of bonds. 
All bonds issued under this article shall have a lien upon the revenues and receipts derived from the lease or other agreement between the Village and the user, and the Mayor and Board of Trustees may provide in the bond ordinance for the issuance of additional bonds to be equally and ratably secured by a lien upon such revenues and receipts or may provide that the lien upon such revenues and receipts is subordinate. 
(Code 1979, § 3.2409)  
Sec. 30-40. - Liability for bond payments. 
All bonds issued under and pursuant to this article shall be limited obligations of the Village payable solely out of the revenues and receipts derived from such lease or other agreement. No holder of any bond issued under this article has the right to compel any exercise of the taxing power of the Village to pay the bonds, the interest or premium, if any, thereon, and the bonds shall not constitute an indebtedness of the Village or a loan of credit thereof within the meaning of any constitutional or statutory provisions. 
(Code 1979, § 3.2410)  
Sec. 30-41. - Exemption from construction and bidding requirements. 
The acquisition and construction of a project shall not be subject to any requirements relating to public buildings, structures, grounds, works or improvements imposed by the Illinois Revised Statutes or any other similar requirements which may be lawfully waived by this article, and any requirements of competitive bidding or restriction imposed on the procedure for award of contracts for such purpose or the lease, sale or other disposition of property of the Village is not applicable to any action taken under authority of this article. 
(Code 1979, § 3.2411)  
Sec. 30-42. - Supplemental nature of powers. 
The powers conferred by this article are in addition and supplemental to, and the limitations imposed by this section shall not affect, the powers conferred by any law or any other ordinance. Projects may be acquired, purchased, constructed, reconstructed, improved, bettered, equipped, extended and financed, and bonds may be issued under this article for such purposes, notwithstanding that any law or any other ordinance may provide for the acquisition, purchase, construction, reconstruction, improvement, equipping, betterment, extension and financing of a like project, or the issuance of bonds for like purposes, and without regard to the requirements, restrictions, limitations or provisions contained in any law or any other ordinance. 
(Code 1979, § 3.2412)  
Sec. 30-43. - Financing fee established. 
The Village shall charge a financing fee each time that bonds are issued by it as provided in this article. The fee shall be computed at the rate set forth in Section 46-33. Financing fees shall be calculated on the principal amount of bonds issued at the time of the issuance of bonds by the Village. Financing fees shall be deemed reimbursement to the Village for its administrative costs in reviewing, evaluating and administering any bond issue and shall be a project cost in addition to those costs described in Section 30-32. 
(Code 1979, § 3.2413)  
Sec. 30-44. - Application fee and deposit for persons requesting financing; payment of financing fee. 
Any person requesting the Village to finance any project by issuance of its revenue bonds shall pay a nonrefundable application charge to the Village Treasurer in the amount set forth in Section 46-33 to reimburse the Village for its preliminary expenses in investigating the desirability and feasibility of such financing. This nonrefundable charge is in addition to the financing fee referred to in Section 30-43. Upon the adoption of the resolution indicating the Village's preliminary agreement (the "resolution of intent") to issue a specific amount of bonds, a deposit in the amount set forth in Section 46-33, to be applied to the financing fee, shall be paid to the Village. The deposit will be disbursed by the Village in payment of such expenses notwithstanding that financing is not completed; however, the deposit may be repaid as a project cost from the proceeds of any bonds issued to finance the project. The balance of the Village's financing fee shall be payable on or before the closing on the bond issue. 
(Code 1979, § 3.2414)  
Chapter 34 - CONSUMER PROTECTION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Consumer Affairs Commission, § 2-801 et seq.; advertising, ch. 6; businesses, ch. 26; weights and measures, § 26-1421 et seq.; gasoline price signs, § 26-1430; taxpayers' rights, § 98-31 et seq. 
State Law reference— Consumer fraud and deceptive business practices act, 815 ILCS 505/1 et seq. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 34-1. - Definitions. 
For the purposes of this article the following words shall have the definitions indicated. 
Lighter means a thing that lights or ignites and includes but is not limited to a mechanical device used in lighting cigarettes, cigars, or pipes for smoking, or for lighting grills or other fires. This will also include those items of dual purpose, i.e. lighter/mini-flashlight, so long as one of the purposes is to ignite or create fire. 
Match means a slender piece of wood, cardboard, or other flammable material tipped with a chemical substance that produces fire when rubbed on a rough or chemically produced surface. Matches means the plural of "match" and the prohibitions included in this Section are applicable to a single match or any combination of matches however grouped together. 
(Ord. No. 07-10-C-3552, § 1, 10-15-2007)  
Sec. 34-2. - Prohibitions regarding sale or distribution of lighters and matches. 
(a)  Sales to underage persons. It is prohibited for any person to sell, give, transfer, deliver or distribute a lighter or matches to a person under the age of 18 years. A person under the age of 18 years is prohibited from purchasing or possessing a lighter or matches. If a person believes, or has reason to believe, that another person is under the age of 18 years, then prior to the sale, gift, transfer, delivery or distribution of a lighter or matches, the presentation of some form of positive identification must be demanded and confirmed before the recipient of the item is allowed to take receipt of the lighter or matches. 
(b)  Employer's Responsibility. 
i.  An employer, business owner and/or manager of a business shall inform all employees and agents of their business that it is a violation of Skokie Village Code to sell, give, transfer, deliver, or distribute a lighter or matches to anyone under the age of 18 years. The employer, business owner and/or manager have a duty to properly supervise his or her employees and agents to ensure that no such sale or delivery takes place in violation of this Section. 
ii.  An employer, company or other business entity shall be deemed to be in violation of the prohibition stated in paragraph (a) of this Section, if its employee or agent sells, gives, transfers, delivers or distributes a lighter or matches to a person under the age of 18 years. The Village may issue citations, or seek other action, against the individual who sells, gives, transfers, delivers or distributes a lighter or matches in violation of paragraph (a) and the employer, company or business entity which employs the individual. 
(c)  Possession. A person under the age of 18 years shall not have in her or his possession a lighter or matches, nor shall such person use a lighter or matches, except as may be allowed in Section 34-3. 
(Ord. No. 07-10-C-3552, § 2, 10-15-2007)  
Sec. 34-3. - Exceptions. 
It is not a violation of this Section for a person under the age of 18 years to possess or use a lighter or matches in conjunction with a religious, social or educational event or activity under the supervision of the person's parent or legal guardian or another adult acting in loco parentis. 
(Ord. No. 07-10-C-3552, § 3, 10-15-2007)  
Secs. 34-4—34-30. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - CONDOMINIUMS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference— Condominium inspection fee, § 46-124. 
Federal law reference— Condominium and cooperative conversion protection and abuse relief, 15 U.S.C.A. § 3601 et seq. 
State Law reference— Condominium Property Act, 765 ILCS 605/1 et seq. 
 
Sec. 34-31. - Purpose of article. 
The purpose of this article is to regulate the sale and operation of condominiums for the protection and welfare of the citizens of the Village. 
(Code 1979, § 30.01)  
Sec. 34-32. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Act means the Illinois Condominium Property Act as set forth in 765 ILCS 605/1 et seq. 
Agent means any person, firm, partnership, association, joint venture, corporation or other entity or combination of entities who represents or acts for on or behalf of a developer in selling or offering to sell any condominium unit, excepting an escrow officer acting for a title company. 
Blanket encumbrance means a trust deed, mortgage, judgment, or other lien or encumbrance including an option or contract to sell or a trust agreement affecting a condominium including any lien or other encumbrance arising as a result of the imposition of any tax assessment by a public authority. 
Board of managers means the board of managers provided and referred to in 765 ILCS 605/1 et seq. 
Closing of the sale means the transferring of ownership of a condominium unit to the new owner from the developer through a deed of conveyance, articles of agreement for a warranty deed, transferring of beneficial interest in a land trust, or any other method of transfer from the developer to the new owner. 
Common elements means all portions of the property except the units, including limited common elements, unless otherwise specified. 
Common expenses means the proposed or actual expenses affecting the property, including reserves, if any, lawfully assessed by the board of managers of the unit owners' association. 
Condominium means a form of property established pursuant to 765 ILCS 605/1 et seq. 
Condominium project means a plan by a developer to sell condominium units in a building, whether through conversion to condominium status or construction of new buildings with condominium ownership. 
Conversion means the offering for sale by a developer or developer's agent of a conversion condominium unit that was rented by any person before commencement of a condominium project which includes such unit. 
Conversion condominium means a property which contains structures, excepting those newly constructed and intended for condominium ownership, which are or have previously been wholly or partially occupied before recording of condominium instruments by persons other than those who have contracted for the purchase of condominiums. 
Declaration means the declaration referred to in 765 ILCS 605/1 et seq. 
Developer means any person who submits property legally or equitably owned by such person to the provisions of this article, or any person who offers units legally or equitably owned by such person for sale in the ordinary course of such person's business, including any successor or successors to such developer's entire interest in the property other than the purchaser of an individual unit. The term "developer" may include a land trustee or beneficiary of a land trust. 
Limited common elements means a portion of the common elements so designated in the declaration as being reserved for the use of a certain unit or units to the exclusion of other units, including but not limited to balconies, terraces, patios and parking spaces or facilities. 
Notice of intent means the notice of intent to submit the real estate to the Illinois Condominium Property Act which is contained in 765 ILCS 605/30. 
Offering means any statement by the developer or the developer's representative that a condominium unit in a specified condominium project is or may be available for sale. 
Person means a natural individual, corporation, partnership, trustee or other legal entity capable of holding title to real property. 
Plat means a plat or plats of survey of the parcel and of all units in the property submitted to the provisions of this article, which may consist of a 3-dimensional horizontal and vertical delineation of all such units. 
Property report means the property report required by this article. 
Prospective purchaser means a person who visits the condominium project site for the purpose of inspection for possible purchase or who requests the property report. 
Unit means a part of the property designed and intended for any type of independent use. 
Unit owners' association and association mean the association of all the unit owners acting pursuant to bylaws through its duly elected board of managers. 
(Code 1979, § 30.02) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 34-33. - Enforcement; penalties. 
(a)  The Corporation Counsel is hereby authorized and directed to receive complaints and conduct such investigations as the Corporation Counsel deems necessary pursuant to the authority vested in that office. 
(b)  Whenever it is determined by the Corporation Counsel that there has been a violation of this article or any duly adopted rule or regulation of the Village, that office is authorized to seek all or a portion of the following relief, or any other relief that may be granted by law: 
(1)  Attempt to conciliate the matter by conference or otherwise and secure a written conciliation agreement; 
(2)  Seek a written assurance of discontinuance, which shall be signed by the developer and the Corporation Counsel; 
(3)  Institute injunctive or other appropriate action or proceeding in any court of competent jurisdiction to obtain a restraining order, permanent or temporary injunction or any other appropriate form of relief; or 
(4)  Institute legal proceedings. 
(c)  The Corporation Counsel may apply to any court of competent jurisdiction to enjoin a violation which has been found to exist by the Village as a result of an inspection. The penalty for such violation shall be as provided in Section 1-6, for each unit with respect to which the violation has occurred. Each day during which any unit has been advertised or offered and such advertisement or offer has not been withdrawn shall constitute a separate offense. 
(d)  Any unit owner may file a suit in any court of competent jurisdiction for injuries sustained by such owner as a result of a violation by developer of any provisions of this article. The court may also award the unit owner's attorney reasonable fees for the attorney's services if such a violation has occurred. If the court finds that no violation has occurred, the court may assess reasonable attorneys' fees against the unit owners. 
(Code 1979, § 30.18)  
Sec. 34-34. - Property report required; contents. 
(a)  At least 4 weeks before offering for sale any condominium unit in a condominium project, the developer shall file with the Village a property report and shall certify by affidavit that all disclosures are true. The Village Manager may, by regulation, prescribe the form of this report; provided, however, that each separate sheet of the property report, including the exhibits, shall be separately numbered in numerical sequence and the report shall contain a table of contents. 
(b)  The report shall contain, but not be limited to, the following information about the condominium project: 
(1)  Ownership and responsibility. Each property report shall include a statement of ownership and responsibility, which shall include the following: 
a.  The name and address of the developer and owner. If the developer and owner are artificial entities such as a corporation, trust or partnership, then the statement shall include all officers and directors of the corporation, and all partners of a general partnership. The names and addresses of all persons with an ownership interest in the offering equal to 10 percent or more of the total ownership interest therein shall be included. 
b.  All architects, contractors, attorneys, engineers, accountants, and principal sales and management agents. 
(2)  Description of project. Each property report shall include a description of the condominium project, in addition to the legal documents described in subsection (5) of this section, as follows: 
a.  A map or plat showing the size and dimensions of the condominium project together with all improvements, including: 
1.  A description of the condominium units offered and the nature and extent of individual ownership in such condominium units. 
2.  A description and the nature and extent of ownership of all common elements, general and limited. 
3.  A description and the nature and ownership of all property and facilities on the site which are not part of the condominium. 
4.  A description of all existing and proposed facilities, including but not limited to recreational facilities, within the condominium. 
5.  The location, nature and ownership of all existing and proposed streets, parking facilities and roads on and contiguous to the site, as well as all existing and proposed easements on or contiguous to the site. 
6.  Drawings, architectural plans and other suitable documents setting forth the necessary information for location, maintenance and repair of all condominium facilities. Such items shall be incorporated in the property report by reference, and shall be located at the sales office site and shall be turned over to the council co-owners upon transfer of control by the developer. 
b.  Projected initiation and completion dates for any proposed construction, renovation or conversion. 
c.  Uses permitted for individual condominium units by the declaration, the bylaws of the condominium association or organization and applicable zoning provisions, including whether or under what conditions a condominium unit may be rented. 
d.  A statement as to whether a purchaser may purchase more than 1 unit and under what circumstances or conditions. 
e.  A statement of legal ownership, listing all restrictions of record and the condition of title. 
(3)  Financial aspects. Each property report shall include a statement of the financial aspects of the condominium project, including but not limited to the following: 
a.  The name of providers of construction and interim funds. 
b.  The name of the institution offering longterm mortgage financing for the condominium units, if available, and terms and conditions of such mortgages. 
c.  A statement of financial ability to complete, within a specified period of time, construction, renovation or conversion of proposed condominium units and recreational and other facilities, including projected costs and methods of payment, and the additional costs to be imposed upon unit owners if such date is not met. 
d.  A statement of any pending litigation which would affect the condominium and/or the developer's ability to convey clear title. 
(4)  Sales materials. Each property report shall include copies of the sales documents and literature, including but not limited to the following: 
a.  Copies of the purchase contract. 
b.  Copies of a sample deed of trust, mortgage and promissory note. 
c.  A statement of sale prices, terms and conditions of sale of each unsold unit. 
d.  A copy of the sales brochure and floor plans. 
e.  The identity of the agent of the developer in charge of sales. 
f.  A statement of the terms and conditions of sale, including estimated itemized closing and settlement costs, taxes and expected assessments levied either by the condominium or a governmental entity. 
g.  A statement of anticipated monthly payments based upon a commonly used purchaser's financing arrangement, e.g., 20 percent down payment, 20-year payoff, and taxes, condominium fee and utilities for a period of 1 year from the expected date of settlement, as well as a statement of what costs are included in the assessments made by the board of managers or the developer. 
h.  If financed by the developer, the proposed financing of each unit, including percent of sales price required for down payment, duration of the loan, interest rate, service charge, appraisal charge, closing charges, and total monthly payment. 
i.  A description of all appliances and personal property included with each unit. 
(5)  Legal documents. Each property report shall include copies of legal documents binding or to be binding upon the unit owners and the unit owners' association for 1 year or more from the date of the first sale, including: 
a.  The declaration or master deed and plat. Prior to the recording of the declaration, a preliminary declaration and plat may be supplied, provided it is accompanied by a statement in capital letters inserted in a conspicuous caption as follows: 
The description of units and percentage of ownership interest in common elements herein is preliminary and may be changed in material respects upon the recording of the declaration and plat which must occur no less than 30 days prior to the time of the first closing. 
If a declaration or master deed or plat is not available at the time the property report is prepared, a floor plan shall be provided at least 30 days prior to closing. 
b.  The articles of incorporation or charter of the condominium association. 
c.  The bylaws and regulations of the condominium association. 
d.  Any leases of real or personal property binding for 1 year or more from the date of first sale. 
e.  Schedules of ownership interest in the general and limited common areas. 
f.  Coverage and amounts of condominium insurance policies. 
g.  Any management contract, employment contract, or other contract affecting the use, maintenance or access to all or any part of the condominium, binding for 1 year or more. 
(6)  Management and operation information. Each property report shall include a statement of management and expected operation of the condominium project, including but not limited to: 
a.  The name of the management agent, if any, and the services the agent will perform. 
b.  A statement disclosing that under the provisions of this article the developer may not enter into any exclusive contract for management or services of a condominium project or permit a clause in the sales contract between a developer and prospective purchaser of a condominium unit that would stipulate an exclusive management contract to exceed a period of 1 year after the condominium project is given over to the individual unit owners in accordance with 765 ILCS 605/18.2. 
c.  The length of term of any management contract and charges and circumstances, if any, under which the charges may be increased. 
d.  The conditions, if any, under which the contract may be cancelled or terminated. 
e.  A statement disclosing any relationship between the developer and the management firm and their respective corporate officers and controlling interests. 
f.  An estimated operating budget for the condominium, projected for a period of 1 year from the expected date that control of the condominium project passes to the board of managers. The operating budget shall include at least the following: 
1.  Operation costs: 
i.  Utilities. 
ii.  Heating fuels. 
iii.  Janitorial services. 
iv.  Trash and garbage disposal. 
v.  Ground and building maintenance. 
vi.  Security. 
vii.  Maintenance and operation of recreational and other facilities. 
viii.  Building insurance. 
ix.  Elevator maintenance. 
x.  Sidewalks and street maintenance. 
xi.  Other operating costs. 
2.  Management costs: 
i.  Accounting and bookkeeping services. 
ii.  Legal services. 
iii.  Management fees. 
3.  Reserve costs: 
i.  Reserve for improvements. 
ii.  Reserve for unexpected repair work. 
iii.  Reserve for replacement and upkeep of common areas and facilities, including the basis upon which reserves are calculated. 
iv.  Reserve for taxes and special assessments. 
If no reserve is provided for any 1 or more of the costs listed in this subsection, the following statement must be inserted in the property report in a type, size and style equal to at least 10-point bold type: 
The developer has not provided a reserve for certain possible future costs of the condominium in his budget. Accordingly, it may be necessary to provide for a special assessment to all condominium unit owners to pay for such costs should they occur. 
g.  An estimate of the taxes which will be assessed against the unit owner during the first 2 years of such person's ownership. 
(7)  Report on condition of building. In the case of a conversion from rental or other legal status to a condominium, the property report shall include a report from a qualified licensed engineer or registered architect stating the condition and the rated life and expected useful life of the roof, foundation, external and supporting walls, mechanical, electrical, plumbing and structural elements and all other common facilities, together with an estimate of repair and replacement costs, at current market prices, which shall indicate what the cost per category of co-owner would be if the co-owners were assessed for the estimated replacement cost. This report shall include the approximate dates of installation of the facilities listed in this subsection and the dates of major repairs to such facilities. 
(8)  Warning statement. Each property report shall contain on the first page the following warning in capital letters: 
The Village of Skokie has not passed on the merits of this project or given approval of the statements in this property report. Oral representations cannot be relied upon as correctly stating the representations of the developer and are not binding on the developer. Refer to your purchase contract for binding representations. 
(9)  Facilities included or excluded. Each property report shall include a statement of whether, and under what circumstances, the unit owners are required to be a member of, support, or participate financially in recreational facilities, such as but not limited to health clubs, exercise clubs, exercise rooms, swimming pools, party rooms and golf putting greens. If any such facility is not part of the common elements, the following warning shall be included in capital letters, in a conspicuous caption: 
The (here name facilities) are not included in the common elements. These facilities are available to unit owners for (here describe monthly charge and initiation fee). Unit owners are/are not (as applicable) required to participate financially. 
(10)  Parking facilities. 
a.  Each property report shall include a description of the location, ownership, and availability to unit owners and the general public of accessory off-street parking associated with the condominium. If all of such parking facilities are not (a) part of the common elements or (b) divided as individual parking spaces among and designated as being part of the units, the following statement shall be included in a conspicuous caption: 
Parking facilities associated with this building are not owned by the unit owners and may be subject to being denied to or taken from unit owners. 
b.  The description of the availability of such off-street parking shall include a statement as to the parking requirements contained in the Zoning Ordinance at the time the building was originally constructed or as required under any ordinance enacted under the site plan review procedures of the Zoning Ordinance for a specific development. 
(11)  Restrictions on resale. Each property report shall include a statement as to whether there are any restrictions upon the free sale, transfer, conveyance, encumbrance or leasing of a unit. If such restrictions exist, the following shall be included in capital letters in a conspicuous caption: 
The sale, lease or transfer of your unit is restricted or controlled. 
Immediately following this statement, there shall appear a reference to the documents, articles, paragraphs, and pages in the property report where the restriction, limitation or control on the sale, lease or transfer of units is set forth or described in detail. 
(Code 1979, § 30.03)  
Sec. 34-35. - Submission of property report to prospective purchasers and Village. 
(a)  A copy of the property report and any amendments and supplements thereto shall be filed with the Village Manager or designee by the developer promptly upon preparation. Such copy shall be used for informational purposes only and shall be attached to the building permit files. 
(b)  Subject to the provisions contained in this article, a developer or agent shall not enter into a binding contract or agreement for the sale of a condominium unit until: 
(1)  A copy of the property report and any amendments and supplements thereto, if any, have been given to the prospective purchaser and to all existing tenants in condominium conversions. 
(2)  The prospective purchaser has been given an opportunity to read the property report. 
(3)  A receipt signed by the prospective purchaser has been received by the developer or agent acknowledging that the prospective purchaser has received and has had an opportunity to review the property report. 
(c)  Such receipts shall be kept on file in the possession of the developer for a period of 3 years from the date of signature by the prospective purchaser. Receipts shall be subject to inspection by the Village at any reasonable time. 
(d)  The property report and any amendments and supplements thereto shall be made available by the developer for inspection by the public in a reasonably accessible place and at reasonable hours. 
(e)  If any information required to be contained in the property report is unavailable prior to the time a prospective purchaser desires to enter into a contract of sale, the contract may, at the purchaser's option, be executed without the availability of such information, provided that such information shall be furnished to the purchaser and its receipt acknowledged in writing by the purchaser prior to the closing of the sale. 
(f)  Before making any material changes in the terms of a property report which has been submitted to the Village Manager or designee, the developer shall first notify the Village Manager or designee in writing of such intended change, and shall also notify all purchasers and prospective purchasers and all existing tenants in the condominium conversions of such change. 
(g)  After the signing of the contract of sale for a condominium unit and prior to the closing of the sale, the developer must deliver to the buyer a copy of any amendments, supplements or modifications to the property report. 
(Code 1979, § 30.04)  
Sec. 34-36. - Certificate of inspection required; issuance. 
(a)  Any developer desiring to sell a unit as regulated by this article shall first apply to the Village Manager or designee for a certificate of inspection with respect to such unit and with respect to the common elements of the property containing the unit. The applicant shall submit with the application the declaration and plat pertaining to the property and as-built architectural drawings of the building and site development certified by a registered architect. The Village Manager or designee shall thereupon cause an inspection to be made of the unit and of the common elements to ascertain compliance with current codes and with those codes in force when the unit was built and shall make a determination thereon. 
(b)  Except as otherwise provided by this article, no certificate of inspection shall be issued and no sale shall be made of any unit if such unit or the common elements pertaining thereto are not in compliance with current codes. 
(c)  After the inspection, as provided for in this section, has been completed and compliance with current codes has been ascertained or waived, the Village Manager or designee shall issue a certificate of inspection with respect to each unit inspected. All of the certificates issued shall include therein a specification of each separate condition of noncompliance which has been waived. The Village Manager or designee shall also issue to such applicant clear and legible copies of the certificates suitable for posting. 
(d)  It shall become the obligation of the applicant to post and keep posted 1 copy of the certificate of inspection on the front doorway of each unit to which it pertains until the sale of that unit is consummated and to post and keep posted a copy of the certificate pertaining to the common elements on the doorway of the main entrance and any such other places as may be directed by the Village Manager or designee until the sale of the last unit has been consummated. The developer shall maintain documentation pertaining to each unit to establish that the purchaser of such unit has received from the developer or the developer's agent a copy of the certificate of inspection pertaining thereto. These records shall be maintained and available for examination by appropriate authorities of the Village. 
(e)  It shall be considered an ordinance violation by the developer if a closing of a sale of any unit located within the Village is completed without the issuance of a certificate of inspection for the unit and the common elements, or a certificate of occupancy. 
(Code 1979, § 30.05)  
Sec. 34-37. - Fee for certificate of inspection. 
The applicant for a certificate of inspection under this article shall pay the fee set forth in Section 46-124. 
(Code 1979, § 30.17)  
Sec. 34-38. - Construction requirements for new buildings. 
Construction requirements for new buildings regulated by this article are as follows: 
(1)  All major items of any significant weight installed on the roof shall be mounted on platforms raised above the roof plane by a minimum of 18 inches so that the roof can be reasonably maintained.
