(2)  If a meeting room is provided, a separate ventilation exhaust system must be provided for that room sufficient to provide 6 air changes per hour. 
(3)  In accordance with State and federal accessibility standards for handicapped persons, all new curbs and sidewalks, and all existing curbs or sidewalks which are a part of or are directly adjacent to any condominium conversion site at the intersections of sidewalks and streets, driveways, sidewalks and alleys, and at other points of major pedestrian flow, shall be constructed or reconstructed so that the sidewalk and street, or the sidewalk and driveway, or the sidewalk and alley, meet at a common level. This requirement shall apply to any sidewalk within the public right-of-way or abutting private property. 
(Code 1979, § 30.06) 
State Law reference— Environmental Barriers Act, 410 ILCS 25/1 et seq.  
Sec. 34-39. - Waiver of building and development requirements. 
For condominium conversions, the requirements of compliance with current codes may be waived under the following circumstances: 
(1)  With respect to the number of off-street parking spaces, if the number was in compliance with the codes in force when the unit was built and if compliance with current codes would lessen the number of off-street parking spaces available to the unit owners. 
(2)  With respect to other provisions of the codes, if the unit containing the building and the common elements pertaining thereto were in compliance with the codes in force when the unit was built and if current compliance would require structural changes. The exceptions to this waiver are as follows: 
a.  Residential buildings with 6 units or less shall have the following fire protection equipment installed: 
1.  Individual in- series smoke detectors in each unit per State requirements. 
2.  A fire alarm system for all common areas, including hallways, stairways, furnace rooms, storage rooms and basements, with notification devices in each unit. 
3.  Exit signs/Emergency lighting with battery back up in common areas, including hallways, stairways, storage rooms, and basements. 
b.  Residential buildings with more than six units shall have the following fire protection equipment installed: 
1.  A fire suppression system in common areas with one sprinkler head over the interior side of each unit entryway. 
2.  Individual in- series smoke detectors in each unit per State requirements. 
3.  A fire alarm system with manual pull stations at exits in buildings over three stories. 
4.  Notification devices in each unit that sound upon activation of the sprinkler system. 
5.  Exit signs/emergency lighting with battery back up in all common areas, including hallways, stairways, storage rooms, and basements. 
6.  Buildings greater than 3 stories shall have manual pull stations at each exit and a stand pipe in the stairwell. 
c.  Conversion of commercial/industrial buildings less than 5,000 square feet shall have the following fire protection equipment installed: 
1.  A fire alarm system in compliance with Life Safety Code. 
2.  Exit signs/emergency lighting with battery back up in all common areas, including hallways, stairways, storage rooms, and basements. 
d.  Conversion of commercial/ industrial buildings greater than 5,000 sq. feet 
1.  A fire alarm system in compliance with current Life Safety Codes. 
2.  A fire suppression system, including notification devices that sound upon activation of the suppression system. 
3.  Manual pull stations in the means of egress, in compliance with Life Safety Code. 
4.  Exit signs/emergency lighting with battery back up in all common areas, including hallways, stairways, storage rooms, and basements. 
(3)  With respect to the total number of and location of units contained within the building, if the number and location were in compliance with the codes in force when the building was built. 
(Code 1979, § 30.07; Ord. No. 04-12-C-3320, § 1, 12-6-2004)  
Sec. 34-40. - Warranty. 
Any sale agreement for the sale of a condominium unit under the provisions of this article shall contain a warranty that the unit and common elements are in good condition, free from any latent or patent defects, and that the developer shall repair or replace any defect in the unit or the common elements at the developer's sole cost promptly upon being notified of such defect, in writing, by the purchaser, provided, however, that such notice of defect must be delivered to the developer within 1 year from closing of the sale of the condominium unit. 
(Code 1979, § 30.08)  
Sec. 34-41. - Escrow funds. 
To ensure compliance with the obligations of the developer under this article, the developer shall either: 
(1)  Place in escrow a sum equal to 2 percent of the gross sales price of each unit upon closing, which sum shall be allocated to the owner of the unit sold, or 
(2)  Submit an irrevocable letter of credit to the Village in a form that is acceptable to the Village Manager and the Corporation Counsel in an amount equal to the amount of 2 percent of the gross sales price of each unit. 
The monies shall remain in escrow for 1 year from the date of closing or 1 year from the date the control of the condominium has been transferred to the unit owners' association, as provided in the Illinois Condominium Property Act, 765 ILCS 605/1 et seq., whichever occurs last. In the event the developer has opted to submit an irrevocable letter of credit to the Village, it shall be effective prior to the closing of the first unit and remain in effect 1 year from the date of the closing of the last unit covered by the letter of credit or 1 year from the date the control of the condominiums covered by the letter of credit has been transferred to the unit owners' association, as provided in the Illinois Condominium Property Act, 765 ILCS 605/1 et seq., whichever occurs last. The Village Manager is authorized to establish rules, regulations and procedures for the implementation of this section. The developer of newly constructed condominiums in tax increment finance districts established by the Mayor and Board of Trustees in accordance with the statutes of the State shall be exempt from placing funds in escrow as required in this section. However, nothing in this section shall relieve such developers from complying with the obligations of this article. 
(Code 1979, § 30.09; Ord. No. 04-11-C-3314, § 1, 11-1-2004)  
Sec. 34-42. - Exclusive management contracts. 
The developer may not enter into any exclusive contract for management or services of a condominium project or permit a clause in the sales contract between a developer and prospective purchaser of a condominium unit that would stipulate an exclusive management or service contract to exceed a period of 1 year after the condominium project is given over to the individual unit owners in accordance with 765 ILCS 605/18.2. 
(Code 1979, § 30.10)  
Sec. 34-43. - Costs to be paid by developer. 
(a)  The developer shall be required to pay the developer's proportionate share of maintenance, service and/or management fees for unsold units. 
(b)  The developer shall pay for all development expenses attributable to the developer which are assessed after closing against the owner of a condominium unit. 
(c)  For conversions only, the developer shall pay all reasonable relocation costs for tenants then residing in the building to be converted having Section 8 housing subsidies on the date that the letter of intent to convert is delivered. 
(Code 1979, § 30.11)  
Sec. 34-44. - Existing tenants in conversions. 
The following additional provisions shall apply to existing tenants in conversions: 
(1)  Delay of eviction beyond existing lease. For tenant families containing at least 1 member of the household who is 65 years of age or older or who is physically or mentally disabled, or for tenant families containing 2 or more children as part of the household, eviction shall be delayed beyond the term of the existing lease for a period of not less than 12 months from the date of filing of the declaration, or the date the notice of intent was given, whichever occurs later. For all other households, eviction shall be delayed beyond the term of the existing lease for a period of not less than 6 months from the date of filing of the declaration, or the date the notice of intent was given, whichever occurs later. 
(2)  Right of tenant to terminate lease. Any tenant with more than 30 days remaining on a lease who receives a notice of an intent to convert shall at any time after receipt of such notice have the right to terminate such lease with 30 days' written notice to the landlord. Such termination shall be without penalty or other termination charge to the tenant. 
(3)  Tenant's right of first refusal. Each tenant in a conversion project shall receive a copy of the property report. For a period of 30 days following the date the tenant receives a copy of the property report, such tenant shall have the right of first refusal on the unit the tenant occupies. This provision shall not reduce the rights provided for under State statute. 
(4)  Required provisions of contract; cooling-off period. 
a.  The developer in a condominium conversion shall include in the contract of sale for each condominium unit a clause which shall read as follows: 
Seller hereby grants to any purchaser who is an existing tenant at time of notice of conversion a period of 15 days within which to review the condominium documents made available to the purchaser pursuant to Chapter 34, Article II, of the Skokie Village Code. 
Notwithstanding any other provision of this agreement, if the tenant-purchaser is not satisfied with the said condominium documents, the tenant-purchaser may, at his election, by written notice to the seller at any time prior to midnight local time of the 15th day following the date the contract is signed by the tenant purchaser, terminate this agreement, and the tenant-purchaser's deposit shall be refunded and the parties thereto shall have no further rights or liabilities under the agreement. 
b.  The clause in the sales contract which provides for the 15-day cooling-off period must be located: 
1.  Either immediately above the purchaser's signature; or 
2.  Under a conspicuous caption entitled "Tenant purchaser's right to cancel." 
c.  The rights of tenant-purchasers under this section may not be waived in the contract of sale and any attempted waiver is void. 
(5)  Information to be furnished to Village. The developer in any condominium conversion which is subject to this article shall, before offering any unit for sale, supply the Village with a list of the names and apartment numbers of each occupant of the building. One week after the declaration of condominium has been filed, the developer shall notify the Village of the date of filing. 
(Code 1979, § 30.12)  
Sec. 34-45. - Discrimination in sale or leasing of units. 
No person shall be denied the right to purchase or lease a condominium unit because of race, religion, color, ancestry, age, sex, physical or mental disabilities, or marital status. 
(Code 1979, § 30.13)  
Sec. 34-46. - Rental arrangement if condominium project does not succeed or is delayed. 
(a)  Every contract of sale for each condominium unit shall contain a provision requiring that satisfactory rental arrangements will be afforded the prospective purchaser for a definite period of time in the eventuality that the condominium project does not succeed in anticipated sales. 
(b)  Every contract of sale for a condominium unit shall provide that in the eventuality the condominium project is not consummated within a reasonable period of time, the prospective purchaser or purchasers will be afforded rental arrangements for a reasonable period of time and that a specific portion of the rental payments will be applied to the condominium unit purchase price at settlement. 
(Code 1979, § 30.14)  
Sec. 34-47. - Exclusion of small developments. 
The provisions of this article shall not apply to conversions of condominium projects containing 6 dwelling units or less; provided, however, that all conversions, regardless of the number of units contained therein, shall be subject to the Village inspections and reports outlined in Section 34-36. Moreover, nothing contained in this section shall exclude or exempt any condominium project from the requirements of State law. 
(Code 1979, § 30.15)  
Sec. 34-48. - Resale of previously inspected units. 
(a)  This article shall not apply to the resale of any unit for which a certificate of inspection has been previously issued pursuant to the terms of this article, or to the sale or resale of any unit which was originally designed and sold under the Condominium Property Act, 765 ILCS 605/1 et seq., if a certificate of occupancy has been issued with respect thereto. 
(b)  There shall be no clause in the sales contract between the developer and the prospective purchaser of a condominium unit that would create an exclusive sales agreement with a real estate agent as to the subsequent sale of the condominium unit. Any condominium owner shall have the right to decide what agent, if any, shall be used in the subsequent sale of a condominium unit. 
(Code 1979, § 30.16)  
Chapter 38 - EMERGENCY SERVICES[1]

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL

ARTICLE II. - ALARM SYSTEMS[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference— Fee for automatic dialing devices connected to Police Department, § 46-35; permit fees for alarm systems and users, false alarm fees, § 46-74. 
State Law reference— Private Detective, Private Alarm, Private Security, and Locksmith Act, 225 ILCS 446/1 et seq. 
 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 38-31. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Alarm Contractor means a person or company, licensed by the State of Illinois, to engage in the activity of altering, installing, leasing, maintaining, moving, repairing, replacing, selling, servicing, or responding to an emergency alarm system. 
Alarm Occurrence means the activation of an alarm system for or as a result of any reason whatsoever which notifies either the Police and/or the Fire Departments to respond to the premises on which the alarm system exists. 
Alarm Detection System means any assemblage of mechanical or electrical equipment or devices (or a single device such as a solid state unit which plugs directly into a 110-volt AC line) arranged to signal the presence of a hazard, a fire, an occurrence of an unauthorized intrusion or other activity requiring urgent and immediate attention. The term "alarm detection system" shall include the terms "automatic holdup alarm system," "burglar alarm system," "fire alarm system," and "holdup alarm system". The following alarm systems are specifically excluded from the provisions of this article: medical emergency alarms, motor vehicle alarm systems, alarm systems used solely to alert or signal persons within the premises, and alarm systems which monitor temperature, humidity or other conditions not directly related to a fire incident or the detection of an unauthorized intrusion into the premises or an attempted robbery or burglary at the premises. 
Alarm Monitoring System means a system in which the operation of electrical protection circuits and devices are signaled automatically to, recorded in, and maintained. 
Alarm user means a person, firm, entity, partnership, association, corporation, company, organization or state, or political subdivision thereof, in possession or control of any building, structure, facility or property in the Village wherein an alarm system is installed and maintained. 
Alarm user permit means a permit issued by the Village for the privilege and ability to operate an alarm system within the Village. 
Combined Communication Center, also known as CCC, means the location at which Alarm Monitoring System signals are received. 
False alarm means any alarm occurrence except when the following circumstances exist: 
(1)  Evidence of an actual intrusion or an obvious intrusion attempt. 
(2)  Evidence of an actual fire or other smoke, noxious gas or high temperatures on premises. 
(3)  Evidence of electrical utility outage conditions affecting a general neighborhood area. 
(4)  Evidence of violent and extreme conditions of nature or acts of God, including thunder, snow, ice and electrical storms. 
(5)  Alarm occurrences during the 30-day period following installation of an alarm system, at an address that did not previously have an alarm system. 
Holdup alarm system means an alarm system signaling a robbery or attempted robbery. 
Fire Alarm System means a system or portion of a combination system that consists of components and circuits arranged to monitor and annunciate the status of fire alarm or supervisory signal-initiating devices and to initiate the appropriate response to those signals. 
Village Alarm Administrator shall also be known as the Communications Coordinator whose responsibilities include coordination, administration and documentation of alarm and detection systems users in the Village. 
(Code 1979, § 36.01; Ord. No. 04-10-C-3306, § 1, 10-4-2004; Ord. No. 11-4-C-3829, § 1, 4-20-2011) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 38-32. - Building Occupancy. 
It shall be unlawful to occupy any building, structure or place which does not comply with the regulations set forth in Section 50-31(b) of this Code. 
(Code 1979, § 36.10; Ord. No. 04-10-C-3306, § 1, 10-4-2004; Ord. No. 11-4-C-3829, § 1, 4-20-2011)  
Sec. 38-33. - Approval of plans for Fire Alarm Systems. 
Two sets of plans showing the location and installation of the Fire Alarm Systems shall be submitted to the Community Development Department. One set shall be forwarded to the Fire Prevention Bureau for review. If approved, these plans shall be retained for the Fire Prevention Bureau. The second set of plans shall be returned to the submitter with comments regarding deficiencies or an indication of approval. 
(Ord. No. 00-10-C-2947, § 7(36.13), 10-16-2000; Ord. No. 04-10-C-3306, § 1, 10-4-2004; Ord. No. 11-4-C-3829, § 1, 4-20-2011; Ord. No. 15-8-C-4167, § 3, 8-3-2015; Ord. No. 15-8-C-4167, § 3, 8-3-2015) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 15-8-C-4167, § 3, adopted Aug. 3, 2015, deleted the former § 38-33 which pertained to maintenance and installation of fire alarm systems and derived from Ord. No. 00-10-C-2947, § 7(36.12), adopted Oct. 16, 2000; Ord. No. 04-10-C-3306, § 1, adopted Oct. 4, 2004; and Ord. No. 11-4-C-3829, § 1, adopted Apr. 20, 2011. Section 3 of said ordinance also renumbered §§ 38-34—38-41 as §§ 38-33—38-40 to read as set out herein.  
Sec. 38-34. - Delay mechanism required for burglar alarm systems. 
No alarm user permit shall be issued for any burglar alarm system that is not equipped with an alarm delay mechanism that allows for at least a 15-second delay before activation of the alarm. 
(Code 1979, § 36.03; Ord. No. 04-10-C-3306, § 1, 10-4-2004; Ord. No. 15-8-C-4167, § 3, 8-3-2015) 
Editor's note— See editor's note following § 38-33.  
Sec. 38-35. - Outside alarm ringers. 
(a)  All hold up alarm systems with outside alarm ringers shall be equipped with a time-out switch that shall not allow the outside alarm to sound for more than 15 minutes. 
(b)  All hold up alarms which sound for more than 15 minutes shall be subject to the penalties provided for in this article, in addition to being declared a public nuisance in accordance with Chapter 42, Article II. 
(c)  No person shall allow or cause to exist an outside ringer, which emits an audible sound in any manner similar to emergency vehicles of the Village of Skokie. In addition, said sound shall also be distinguishable from any and all Village alert systems disseminated in an audible manner. 
(d)  It shall be the sole responsibility of the persons owning or operating an outside ringer to maintain the system at the sole expense of the owner or operator. 
(e)  In addition to any other remedies provided by ordinance, the Village Alarm Administrator, whenever he shall have knowledge of the misuse or improper maintenance of an outside ringer, may order the immediate suspension of the alarm permit and removal or deactivation of the system. Removal and deactivation will not apply to alarms mandated by Code. 
(Code 1979, § 36.04; Ord. No. 04-10-C-3306, § 1, 10-4-2004; Ord. No. 11-4-C-3829, § 1, 4-20-2011; Ord. No. 15-8-C-4167, § 3, 8-3-2015) 
Editor's note— See editor's note following § 38-33.  
Sec. 38-36. - Automatic telephone alarms. 
Any automatic telephone alarm or device installed and operated that dials the Village emergency telephone lines to the Communications Center of the Police and Fire Departments is prohibited. No person shall install, or cause to be installed, or maintain or cause to be maintained, any automatic telephone alarm that dials the Village emergency telephone lines to the Communications Center, the only exception being elevator communication devices. 
(Code 1979, § 36.05; Ord. No. 04-10-C-3306, § 1, 10-4-2004; Ord. No. 11-4-C-3829, § 1, 4-20-2011; Ord. No. 15-8-C-4167, § 3, 8-3-2015) 
Editor's note— See editor's note following § 38-33.  
Sec. 38-37. - False alarms. 
(a)  Authority to impose fees; notice to alarm user; fees. The Village Manager shall have the authority to impose fees, for an emergency response to a false alarm, pursuant to Section 46-74(2). The Village Manager or designee shall notify any alarm user after 2 false alarms occur for any alarm system in any calendar year, in writing, by first class mail, or by personal service, that additional false alarms may result in the imposition of the fees set forth in Section 46-74(2). The fees shall be due 30 days from the date of invoice. 
(b)  Request for waiver of fee. Any alarm user may request, in writing, to the Village Manager, that the fee for a false alarm be waived. The request shall be made within 10 days of the false alarm occurrence and shall specify the circumstances of the false alarm occurrence. The Village Manager or designee shall respond to such request within 10 days of receipt thereof. 
(Code 1979, § 36.06; Ord. No. 04-10-C-3306, § 1, 10-4-2004; Ord. No. 11-4-C-3829, § 1, 4-20-2011; Ord. No. 15-8-C-4167, § 3, 8-3-2015) 
Editor's note— See editor's note following § 38-33.  
Sec. 38-38. - Disclaimer of liability. 
The Village assumes no liability for any defects in the operation of any alarm system, for any failure or neglect of any person associated with the installation, operation or maintenance of any alarm system, for any failure or neglect of any alarm subscriber, for the transmission or receipt of alarm signals or any failure or neglect to respond upon receipt of an alarm from any source. If the Village finds it necessary to revoke an alarm subscriber permit or to otherwise provide for the disconnection of any alarm system, the Village shall have no liability for such action. No special duty other than that owed to the general public shall be created by virtue of the permit or the direct connection of the alarm system with the Center. The provisions of this section constitute a waiver of any and all potential future claims by the alarm users for all matters stated in this article, and the text of this section shall be included in the application for an alarm user permit. The alarm user's submission of the application and use of the alarm user permit shall constitute acceptance of this provision and a waiver of all potential claims against the Village or its personnel in connection with or arising out of the operation of or any response to an alarm system. 
(Code 1979, § 36.09; Ord. No. 04-10-C-3306, § 1, 10-4-2004; Ord. No. 11-4-C-3829, § 1, 4-20-2011; Ord. No. 15-8-C-4167, § 3, 8-3-2015) 
Editor's note— See editor's note following § 38-33.  
Sec. 38-39. - Notice of violation. 
Whenever any person violates any provision of this article, such person shall be served with a notice of violation providing for an opportunity to appear before either the Administrative Law Officer in an Administrative Hearing or the Circuit Court of Cook County. 
(Ord. No. 11-4-C-3829, § 1, 4-20-2011; Ord. No. 15-8-C-4167, § 3, 8-3-2015) 
Editor's note— See editor's note following § 38-33.  
Sec. 38-40. - Penalties. 
Any person who violates any provision of this division shall be subject to the penalties provided in Section 1-6 or any other penalty provided by law. 
(Ord. No. 11-4-C-3829, § 1, 4-20-2011; Ord. No. 15-8-C-4167, § 3, 8-3-2015) 
Editor's note— See editor's note following § 38-33.  
Secs. 38-41—38-60. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - ALARM USER PERMIT 
 
Sec. 38-61. - Required. 
It shall be unlawful for any person, entity or alarm user to maintain or operate an alarm system without a valid and effective alarm user permit. 
(Code 1979, § 36.02; Ord. No. 04-10-C-3306, § 1, 10-4-2004)  
Sec. 38-62. - Application. 
Applications for alarm user permits shall be made to the Village Manager or designee on forms prescribed and furnished by the Village Manager or designee. The Village Manager or designee may request additional information from the applicant. 
(Code 1979, § 36.01; Ord. No. 04-10-C-3306, § 1, 10-4-2004)  
Sec. 38-63. - Revocation of permit. 
(a)  The Village Manager shall have the authority to revoke all permits issued under this division. In addition to the provisions contained in this article, the Village Manager shall have the authority to establish rules and regulations for the conduct of a hearing relating to the revocation of a permit. 
(b)  The Village Manager is hereby given the authority to revoke the permit if the Village Manager finds: 
(1)  The permittee has not complied with applicable codes, ordinances, statutes, laws, policies or rules and regulations. 
(2)  The permittee has made fraudulent, false or misrepresentative statements in the application for the permit. 
(3)  The permittee owes the Village required fees or outstanding fines or penalties. 
(4)  More than 10 false alarms for 1 alarm system have occurred in any calendar year. 
(c)  Notice and hearing. The Village Manager or designee may revoke, suspend, or take other action with respect to a permit in accordance with the following procedures: 
(1)  The Village Manager or designee shall send written notice of the intent to revoke or suspend a permit by certified mail or personal delivery, setting forth the reasons for revocation or suspension. 
(2)  The notice shall state that the effective date of the revocation or suspension shall be 30 days from the date of the notice, shall state the effective date, and shall inform the permit holder of the right to submit in writing within 15 days of the date of the notice either: 
a.  Documentation to explain the past occurrences stated in the notice and to propose corrective action to eliminate the violations; or 
b.  A request for hearing. 
(3)  If the Village Manager or designee accepts the corrective action proposed by the permit holder, the Manager or designee shall respond in writing, stating the conditions for continuing to hold the permit, and retracting or deferring the notice of intent to revoke or suspend the permit. 
(4)  If the permit holder requests a hearing, the Village Manager or designee shall hold a hearing within 30 days of the date of the original notice, at which hearing the permit holder and a Police Department representative, or Fire Department representative, other than the designee of the Village Manager conducting the hearing, shall have the right to present any evidence and cross examine witnesses. 
(5)  The Village Manager or designee conducting the hearing shall render a written decision within 7 days of the hearing, sent to the permit holder by certified mail or personal delivery, either: 
a.  Revoking or suspending the permit, stating the effective date of the action; or 
b.  Stating any conditions for continuing to hold the permit. 
(Code 1979, § 36.07; Ord. No. 04-10-C-3306, § 1, 10-4-2004)  
Sec. 38-64. - Reinstatement of revoked or suspended permit. 
Any alarm user whose permit has been revoked or suspended pursuant to this article may request reinstatement of the permit. The request shall be made to the Village Manager in writing and shall include payment of the reinstatement fee established in Section 46-74 and full payment of all past due amounts. No permit shall be reinstated within the 6-month period following the effective date of the revocation. However, a permit may be reinstated within the 6-month period if sufficient evidence of future compliance with the provisions of this article is presented. 
(Code 1979, § 36.08; Ord. No. 04-10-C-3306, § 1, 10-4-2004)  
Sec. 38-65. - Fees. 
Every alarm user shall pay an initial permit fee and annual fee as set forth in Section 46-74. The initial fee and the annual fee shall each be based upon the amount of money determined by the Mayor and Board of Trustees to be reasonable compensation for the services and liabilities assumed by the Village in responding to alarm occurrences. 
(Code 1979, § 36.02; Ord. No. 04-10-C-3306, § 1, 10-4-2004)  
Sec. 38-66. - Term; renewal. 
Alarm user permits shall be valid for 1 year effective January 1st each year and expiring December 31st, and may be renewed for another year effective the next January 1st, upon the payment of the renewal fee referred to in this article and all other unpaid fees assessed pursuant to this article. 
(Code 1979, § 36.01; Ord. No. 04-10-C-3306, § 1, 10-4-2004)  
Chapter 42 - ENVIRONMENT[1]
