ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 50-1. - Damaging or interfering with Village equipment; taking saved property in possession of Fire Department. 
(a)  Damaging fire apparatus. It shall be unlawful for any person in any manner to willfully destroy, injure or deface any engine or other fire apparatus or equipment belonging to the Village. 
(b)  Taking saved property. It shall be unlawful for any person to take away any property in the possession of the Fire Department saved from any fire until proof of ownership shall be made to the satisfaction of the Village Manager or designee at the fire. 
(c)  Interference with alarm system. It shall be unlawful for any person to activate any emergency alarm pull box or call 911 for a purpose other than reporting an emergency matter to the Fire Department or Police Department, or break, cut, injure, deface, damage, or in any manner meddle or interfere with any emergency alarm box or any municipal electric wires, poles, conduits or apparatus whatever. 
(d)  Taking water from hydrants. It shall be unlawful for any person, other than the members of the Fire Department for the uses and purposes of such Department, and those specially authorized by the Village Manager or designee, to open any public fire hydrant or attempt to draw water from the any public fire hydrant. 
(e)  Damaging or interfering with hydrants. It shall be unlawful for any person to willfully or carelessly break, injure or interfere with any of the public fire hydrants in the Village. 
(Code 1979, § 5.08) 
State Law reference— Criminal damage of firefighting apparatus, hydrants or equipment, 720 ILCS 5/21-1.1.  
Sec. 50-2. - Entering fire station or other Fire Department facilities. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to enter a Fire Department station or stations, or any place where the equipment and apparatus of the Fire Department are stored, at any time, except on business pertaining to the Fire Department or other Village business, unless authorized by the Village Manager or designee. 
(Code 1979, § 5.09)  
Sec. 50-3. - False alarms. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to give any false alarm of fire or other emergency to any police or fire station or officer, or to the Village. 
(Code 1979, § 5.11) 
State Law reference— False alarm of fire, 720 ILCS 5/26-1 et seq.  
Secs. 50-4—50-30. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - FIRE PREVENTION CODE 
 
Sec. 50-31. - International Fire Code (IFC) and National Fire Protection Association Life Safety Code adopted. 
(a)  A fire prevention code is hereby established to provide the Village with rules and regulations to improve public safety by promoting the control of fire hazards, to regulate the installation, use, and maintenance of equipment, to regulate the use of structures, premises, and open areas, to provide for the abatement of fire hazards, to establish the responsibilities and procedures for code enforcement, and to set the standards for compliance and achievement of these objectives. 
(b)  Pursuant to authority granted by 65 ILCS 5/1-3-2, the Village hereby adopts by reference the International Fire Code, 2012 edition, hereinafter referred to as the "IFC" published and modified by the International Code Council (ICC), as the fire prevention code, excepting those provisions that are modified or deleted as provided in this Article. 
(c)  Pursuant to authority granted by 65 ILCS 5/1-3-2, the Village hereby adopts by reference the Life Safety Code, 2012 edition, hereinafter referred to as the "LSC" published and modified by the National Fire Protection Association (NFPA). 
(Code 1979, § 34.01; Ord. No. 04-10-C-3305, § 1, 10-4-2004; Ord. No. 08-4-C-3613, § 2, 4-7-2008; Ord. No. 15-8-C-4167, § 4, 8-3-2015) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 15-8-C-4167, § 4, adopted Aug. 3, 2015, changed the title of § 50-31 from "NFPA Fire Prevention Code adopted" to read as set out herein. 
State Law reference— Municipal Adoption of Codes and Records Act, 50 ILCS 220/0.01 et seq.; incorporation by reference of certain construction regulations, 65 ILCS 5/1-3-1 et seq.  
Sec. 50-32. - Enforcement. 
(a)  The fire prevention code shall be enforced by the Fire Chief and the Chief's subordinate officers. 
(b)  The Fire Chief shall detail such members of the Fire Department as fire inspectors as may be necessary. The Fire Chief may recommend to the Village Manager the employment of technical inspectors. 
(c)  Whenever the word "municipality" is used in the fire prevention code adopted by this article, it shall mean the Village of Skokie. 
(Code 1979, § 34.02)  
Sec. 50-33. - District limits for bulk storage of flammable liquids or liquified petroleum gas. 
The fire prevention code adopted by reference in this article shall be modified as follows: 
(1)  The limits referred to in Standard 30, Chapter 4, of the Fire Prevention Code, in which new bulk plants where flammable liquids are stored are prohibited, are subject to the provisions of the Zoning Ordinance (Chapter 118). 
(2)  The limits referred to in Standard 58, Chapter 3, of the Fire Prevention Code, in which bulk storage of liquified petroleum gas is restricted, are subject to the provisions of the Zoning Ordinance (Chapter 118). 
(Code 1979, § 34.03; Ord. No. 04-10-C-3305, § 2, 10-4-2004)  
Sec. 50-34. - Appeals. 
(a)  If a person in good faith believes that any notice given by the Fire Chief as provided in this Code is without merit or if the Fire Chief shall disapprove an application for a license or permit, or when it is claimed that the provisions of the Fire Prevention Code do not apply or that the true intent and meaning of the code has been misconstrued or wrongfully interpreted, the person aggrieved thereby may appeal from the decision of the Fire Chief to the Mayor and Board of Trustees within 3 days from the date of such notice. 
(b)  The appeal shall be in the form of a written petition, an original and 3 copies of which shall be filed with the Village Manager, who shall notify the Mayor and the Board of Trustees thereof, and the Manager shall set the hearing of the appeal for the meeting date of the Mayor and Board of Trustees next following the receipt of the appeal. 
(c)  The appeal shall set forth in detail the nature of the petitioner's grievance and in what respect the notice, disapproval, or decision of the Fire Chief is without merit or erroneous, and it shall be verified upon the oath or affirmation of the petitioner. 
(d)  The appeal shall operate to stay all court proceedings pending the decision of the Mayor and Board of Trustees, which shall be rendered not later than the date of the next meeting of the Mayor and Board of Trustees, following the hearing of the appeal. 
(e)  The failure to appeal shall render the action of the Fire Chief as final. 
(Code 1979, § 34.04)  
Sec. 50-35. - Determination of new materials, processes or occupancies which may require permits. 
The Fire Chief shall determine and specify, after giving affected persons an opportunity to be heard, any new materials, processes or occupancies which shall require permits, in addition to those now enumerated in the Fire Prevention Code. The Fire Chief shall post such list in a conspicuous place in the Fire Chief's office and distribute copies thereof to interested persons. 
(Code 1979, § 34.05)  
Sec. 50-36. - Inspections for fire hazards. 
It shall be the responsibility of the Fire Chief or a designated subordinate, upon the own initiative of the Fire Chief or designee, or when requested by any citizen, when it appears that there may exist in any building or place of employment a fire hazard or a condition which will impede escape from a fire or the prompt extinguishment of a fire, or any condition in violation of the fire prevention code, to make a personal examination of such building or place, and, if such condition or representation is found to be true, to give notice in writing personally or by registered U.S. mail to the owner or person in possession and control of such building or place to promptly make such changes, alterations or repairs as the public safety and ordinances of the Village may require. If no person is found upon the premises, the notice may be affixed in a conspicuous place upon or near the main entrance door to the premises. 
(Code 1979, § 34.15) 
Cross reference— Duty of Fire Chief to inspect for fire hazards, § 2-325(5).  
Sec. 50-37. - Penalty for failure to correct fire hazard. 
Any owner, or agent, employee or officer thereof, or person in possession or control of building or place mentioned in Section 50-36, who shall refuse or neglect to make such changes, alterations or repairs within a period of 5 days after the date of such notice, shall be subject to the penalties provided in Section 1-6 in addition to any other penalty specifically provided for. 
(Code 1979, § 34.15)  
Sec. 50-38. - Standards for fire extinguishers. 
(a)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Service, where used in reference to fire extinguishers, means the inspection, repair, recharging or testing of fire extinguishers. 
Serviceperson means a person licensed by the Village to inspect, repair, recharge or test fire extinguishers. 
Standard fire extinguisher means a portable fire extinguisher which bears the label of approval of a national testing laboratory acceptable to the Fire Chief. 
(b)  Tags. Every standard fire extinguisher shall have attached thereto a tag or other label approved by the Fire Chief which clearly indicates the dates of inspection and recharging. The tag or label shall have clearly imprinted thereon in numerals no less than ½ inch in height the year for which it is issued. 
(c)  Servicing. Fire extinguishers more than 1 year past the service date are in violation of this section. Pressurized extinguishers must be hydrostratically tested as prescribed in current NFPA standards. 
(Code 1979, § 34.06)  
Sec. 50-39. - Fire extinguisher servicers. 
(a)  License required. No person shall engage in the business of servicing fire extinguishers unless having first obtained a license as provided in this section. 
(b)  Application for license. 
(1)  Applications for licenses under this section shall be made to the Village Manager or designee on forms prescribed and furnished by the Village Manager or designee. The Village Manager or designee may request additional information from the applicant. 
(2)  Every application shall be accompanied by 2 1-inch by 1-inch prints of a photograph of the applicant. 
(c)  Approval of applicant for license. The Village Manager or designee shall pass on the qualifications of applicants desiring to be licensed as fire extinguisher service persons. 
(d)  Issuance of license; insurance. A license shall be granted to all qualified applicants who shall have passed such examination and who shall have delivered evidence of the existence of a public liability insurance policy issued by an insurance company of national standing, insuring the public in an amount determined by the Village Manager or designee against property damage caused by the negligence of such applicant in servicing fire extinguishers. The insurance coverage shall include both manufacturers and contractors liability and products liability types. 
(e)  License fee; term. Upon payment of the license fee set forth in Section 46-73, a license shall be issued. Such license shall expire on December 31 of the year in which it is issued. 
(f)  Renewal of license. Licenses shall expire on December 31 of the year issued. Any such license may be renewed upon payment of the annual fee. Any change of address of the licensee shall be reported to the Village Manager or designee. 
(g)  Inspection of fire extinguishers; authority to establish additional regulations. The Fire Chief, in the discretion of the Fire Chief, may make or cause to be made an inspection of the contents and working condition of any fire extinguisher, and may promulgate such reasonable rules and regulations as deemed necessary to carry out the purposes of the provisions of this section. 
(Code 1979, § 34.07) 
Cross reference— Businesses, ch. 26.  
Sec. 50-40. - Foreign fire insurance companies. 
(a)  Compliance required. It shall be unlawful for any corporation, company or association not incorporated under the laws of the State to engage in providing fire insurance or to transact any business of fire insurance in the Village without having fully complied with the provisions of this section; provided, however, that the failure to comply shall not relieve any insurer from the payment of any loss upon any risk that may be taken while in default or violation of this section. 
(b)  Fee imposed. Every such corporation, company, or association shall pay to the Village a fee as provided in Section 46-78. 
(c)  Report of premiums; payment of fee. Every person acting as a representative for or on behalf of any such corporation, company or association shall, on or before July 15 of each year, render to the Village Manager or designee a full, true and just account, verified by oath, of all premiums which have been received by such person for and on behalf of the corporation, company, or association during each year ending the preceding July 1 on such fire insurance policies. Failure to furnish such account or pay the sum due by July 15 shall constitute a default of the provisions of this section, in consequence of which it shall be unlawful for any corporation, company, or association, so in default, to transact any business in the Village, directly or indirectly, until the account is furnished or the sum due is fully paid. The filing of reports and the payment of fees in accordance with this section may, at the direction or concurrence of the Village, be done by another agency, subject to all conditions and provisions of this section. 
(d)  Recovery of unpaid fees. The sum of money due shall be recoverable from the corporation, company, or association which owes it, or from its agent, by an action in the same name for the use of the Village, together with its costs in that behalf expended, as for money had and received. 
(e)  Penalty. In addition to any other remedy provided in this Code, if any corporation, company, or association required by this section fails to file a report as set forth in subsection (c) of this section by the specified date, or if the amount shown to be due by such report is unpaid after the day limited for the payment thereof as set forth in subsection (c) of this section, every such defaulting or delinquent corporation, company, or association shall be subject to the penalties provided in Section 1-6 in addition to any other penalty specifically provided for. A separate and distinct offense shall be deemed committed each day on which a violation occurs or continues. 
(Code 1979, § 34.08) 
Cross reference— Businesses, ch. 26; foreign fire insurance company fees, § 46-78. 
State Law reference— Foreign fire insurance company fees, 65 ILCS 5/11-10-1.  
Sec. 50-41. - Automobile service stations. 
(a)  License. It shall be unlawful to conduct or operate an automobile service station in the Village without a license therefor. The license fee shall be as set forth in Section 46-3. No such license shall be issued unless the location and equipment to be used fully comply with the ordinances of the Village. 
(b)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Automobile service station means a building or premises used for the storage and sale at retail of motor vehicle fuels, lubricating oil and grease, tires, batteries and similar automobile accessories and parts. Automobile service, including minor repairs and adjustments, shall be permitted within closed premises. 
(c)  Non-business filling stations. Any person maintaining or operating any storage tank for gasoline for the use of the automobiles of the owner, lessee, employees or agents of such person shall comply with all of the provisions of this section, other than the requirement for the payment of a fee. 
(d)  Bulk sale prohibited. No motor fuels shall be dispensed at any service station except into the fuel tanks of motor vehicles, when such tanks are connected with the carburetion systems of such vehicles. However, individual sales up to 5 gallons may be made in metal receptacles when painted red and labeled in full conformity with the Illinois Red Can Gasoline Law, 430 ILCS 20/1, such individual sales to be limited to 5 gallons to any 1 person. 
(e)  Operation and safety requirements. 
(1)  No fuel tank of any motor vehicle shall be serviced until the motor and ignition have been shut off. 
(2)  It shall be unlawful for any person to smoke or carry a lit cigarette, cigar or pipe on the premises at any time except as follows: The Fire Chief or the Fire Chief's authorized subordinate shall designate specific safe locations, if necessary, in any building, structure or place, in which smoking may be permitted. The Fire Chief or the Fire Chief's authorized subordinate is empowered to order the owner or occupant to post no smoking signs in each building, structure, room or place in which smoking is prohibited. It shall be unlawful for the owner or occupant to refuse to install any legally required no smoking signs or for any person to remove such signs. 
(3)  No open lights or flame shall be permitted except within a stove within the station building. 
(4)  Premises shall be kept clean and neat, free from litter or trash. Covered receptacles for litter and trash shall be provided and maintained on pump islands and in accessible points on the premises. 
(5)  Cleaning with gasoline, naphtha or other highly flammable liquids of Class I and Class II shall not be permitted in or around a service station. 
(6)  Waste oil or other flammable liquids shall be stored in tanks approved by the Fire Chief pending removal from the premises. No such waste shall be permitted to drain into any sewer or drainage system. Rags and soiled waste shall be kept in approved metal containers with self-closing covers. 
(7)  No wrecked, junked or stripped vehicles, or vehicles without current license plates, or vehicles for sale, shall be maintained or stored on the premises. 
(8)  Motor rebuilding, body repairs and painting are not permitted on service station premises. All major repairs shall be effected within an enclosure approved by the Fire Chief or designee provided within the service station building. Vehicles, preparatory to being serviced as set forth in this subsection, shall not be permitted to be left standing upon any public highway or sidewalk or other area not within the legal confines of the service station. 
(9)  Restrooms shall be maintained in a clean, sanitary condition subject to recurring inspection and approval by a Village inspector. 
(10)  Each service station shall be equipped with at least 1 fire extinguisher suitable for oil and gasoline fires. 
(f)  Regulations adopted. The rules and regulations relating to service stations (revised March 6, 1963) adopted by the Department of Public Safety are incorporated in this section by reference, and such provisions shall be controlling where the subject matter is not otherwise dealt with in this Code. 
(g)  Approval of plans. Drawings or blueprints, made to scale, shall be submitted in triplicate to the Village Manager or designee before any new construction, addition or remodeling is undertaken. Drawings shall carry the name of the person proposing the installation, and the location, and shall, in addition, show and conform to the following: 
(1)  The plot to be utilized, and its immediate surroundings on all sides, shall be shown. All property lines shall be designated and adjacent streets and highways shall be named. 
(2)  The complete installation as proposed, including tanks and their capacity, pumps, buildings, drivers and all equipment, shall be shown. 
(3)  Clearance from tanks to property lines shall be shown. 
(4)  The type of construction of the service station building or buildings shall be shown, with a clear drawing or blueprint showing that there will be no basement, cellar, or excavation under any portion. 
(5)  The location of basements, cellars or pits of other buildings on the property, or on adjacent property, and the location of tanks with reference thereto, as provided in this section, shall be shown. If a building has no basement, cellar, or pit, a note shall be made to that effect. 
(6)  The location of sewers, manholes, catchbasins, cesspools, septic tanks, wells or cisterns (whether on the property, or adjacent property, or in adjoining streets, highways or alleys), and the location of tanks with reference thereto, shall be shown. If there is no sewer, manhole or catchbasin in a street or alley, or no sewer, manhole, or cesspool, septic tank, well or cistern on the property, a notation shall be made to that effect in the proper place. 
(7)  The location of vent pipe outlets and the location of fill pipes shall be shown. 
(8)  The ventilation of greasing pits, if the greasing pit is located within a building or enclosure, shall be shown. 
(9)  Drawings shall be accompanied by an application made available by the Village. 
(10)  Drawings shall be approved by the State Fire Marshal before being considered by the Village. 
(11)  The location and type of light fixture and height of any light fixture to be used for illuminating any outside area shall be shown. 
(Code 1979, § 34.09; Ord. No. 16-7-C-4236, § 1, 7-18-2016) 
Cross reference— Businesses, ch. 26; gasoline price signs, § 26-1430.  
Sec. 50-42. - Underground tanks. 
(a)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Proper disposal of underground tanks. If a tank is to be disposed of as junk, it shall be retested for flammable vapors, and, if necessary, rendered gas-free (so that vapors from the combustible or flammable liquid from the tank are not present in a concentration sufficient to support combustion). After junking and before releasing to a junk dealer, a sufficient number of holes or openings (at least 2 percent of the total surface area of the tank) should be made in it to render it unfit for further use. NFPA 327, Standard Procedures for Cleaning or Safeguarding Small Tanks and Containers, provides information on safe procedures for such operation. 
Proper removal of an underground tank means that: 
(1)  All flammable or combustible liquids from the tank and from connecting lines are removed. 
(2)  Piping is disconnected at all tank openings. 
(3)  Sections of connecting lines which are not to be used further are removed, and all tank openings are capped or plugged. 
(4)  Tanks are removed from the ground. 
(5)  After removal, the tank shall be gas-free (so that vapors from the combustible or flammable liquid from the tank are not present in a concentration sufficient to support combustion) on the premises as required by NFPA 327, or the tank may be transported to an area not accessible to the public and the gas-freeing completed at that location. 
(6)  Adherence to the regulations of the Office of the State Fire Marshal, Title 41, Chapter 430, Act 15/2, Regulation of Tanks, as well as any other applicable State and federal regulations, is required. 
Properly safeguarding an underground tank means that: 
(1)  All products are removed. 
(2)  The tank is filled with a solution of water and inerting chemicals to reduce the oxygen content in the enclosed space to a concentration at which combustion cannot take place. 
(3)  All fill, gauge, suction or other lines, except vents, are capped. 
(4)  Adherence to the regulations of the Office of the State Fire Marshal, Title 41, Chapter 430, Act 15/2, Regulation of Tanks, as well as any other applicable State and federal regulations, is required. 
Underground tanks means underground storage tanks which are used for the storage of motor fuel or other combustible or flammable liquids. 
(b)  Declaration of nuisance. 
(1)  Any underground tanks which are out of service for 180 days and have not been properly safeguarded are considered dangerous and unsafe and are hereby declared a public nuisance, and it shall be unlawful for any property owner to permit such tanks thereon. 
(2)  Any out-of-service underground storage tanks which were previously filled with an inert solid material shall be removed as part of any new construction or substantial remodeling. 
(c)  Notice of violation; abatement by Village. If a property owner violates any part of this section, the Fire Chief or the Fire Chief's agent shall send by certified mail a notice of such violation to such person, informing the person of the violation and that such violation must be abated within 10 days from the time of mailing the notice. If the violation is not abated within the 10-day period, the Village, through its agent, shall enter upon the property where the underground tanks are located and shall proceed to properly safeguard the underground tanks with an inert solid material. Any expense incurred by the Village in safeguarding the tanks shall be a charge against the property owner, and such charge may be recovered in an appropriate action in law instituted by the Corporation Counsel. In addition thereto, the Village may create a lien against the property involved. 
(d)  Lien for costs of abatement by Village. Any costs incurred by the Village or its duly appointed officers or agents in safeguarding underground tanks shall be a lien upon the real estate so affected, and the lien shall be superior to all other liens and encumbrances, except tax liens, provided that, within 60 days after such cost and expense is incurred, the Village, or the person performing the service by authority of the Village, in its or such person's own name, files notice of lien in the office of the County Recorder of Deeds. The notice shall consist of a sworn statement setting out (i) a description of the real estate sufficient for identification thereof, (ii) the amount of money representing the costs and expenses incurred or payable for the service, and (iii) the date or dates when such costs and expenses were incurred by the Village or one acting under its direction and authority. Upon payment of the costs and expenses by the owner of or persons interested in such property after notice of lien has been filed, the lien shall be released by the Village or person in whose name the lien has been filed, and the release shall be filed of record as in the case of filing notice of lien. 
(Code 1979, § 34.10) 
State Law reference— Gasoline Storage Act, 430 ILCS 15/1 et seq.  
Sec. 50-43. - Bonfires; Prairie burns. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful to build or light any bonfire anywhere in the Village except, a bonfire that is: 
(1)  Performed in connection with an event sponsored by a governmental entity, or a unit thereof; and 
(2)  Approved by the Village Manager or his designee; and 
(3)  Complies with all rules and regulations of the Illinois Air Pollution Control Board; and 
(4)  Is conducted under the supervision of the Fire Chief or designee. 
(b)  Controlled prairie burns, for environmental restoration or remediation is permitted in the Village, only if; 
(1)  Authorization is granted by the Illinois Environmental Protection Agency, in accordance with its rules and regulations; and 
(2)  Approval is granted by the Village Manager or designee and is conducted under the supervision of the Fire Chief or designee. 
(Code 1979, § 34.11; Ord. No. 03-12-C-3238, § 1, 12-15-2003)  
Sec. 50-44. - Open burning prohibited; Exceptions. 
It shall be unlawful to burn or cause the burning at any location within the Village, of any paper, cardboard, leaves, twigs, branches, wood, grass, grass clippings, landscape waste, or other combustible materials of any nature whatsoever, except the following: 
(a)  Burning any combustible materials wholly within a building, in a designated fireplace or facility designed and constructed for such purpose, provided that any refuse burning incinerator installed in any residence building shall comply with the rules and regulations of the Illinois Air Pollution Control Board, as amended from time to time. 
(b)  Burning is permitted in an outdoor fireplace or cooking unit, only if: 
1.  The fuel used is charcoal, propane gas, dry, seasoned firewood or commercial fire logs; and 
2.  The fireplace or cooking unit is raised above ground level; and 
3.  The fireplace or cooking unit, is constructed of noncombustible brick, stone, or metal materials, and is commercially designed for outdoor fire or cooking and is maintained is good working order; and 
4.  The fireplace or cooking unit, if moveable, is placed on a noncombustible surface during use and is maintained at a safe and reasonable distance from any combustible material; and 
5.  The fireplace or cooking unit is directly attended by and under the supervision of an adult, at all times during use; and 
6.  The fire shall be entirely extinguished prior to leaving the fireplace or cooking unit unattended. 
(Code 1979, § 34.12; Ord. No. 03-12-C-3238, § 2, 2003) 
Cross reference— Solid waste, ch. 86.  
Sec. 50-45. - Storage of combustible refuse. 
It is unlawful to permit or store any combustible refuse in such a way as to create a fire hazard. 
(Code 1979, § 34.13)  
Sec. 50-46. - Negligently setting fire in hotel or other place of abode. 
It shall be unlawful for any person in any hotel, roominghouse, motel, nursing home, hospital, child care facility, or similar place of abode, through carelessness or negligence, to set fire to, or cause the burning of, any bedding, furniture, rug, curtain, drape, or other house or household furnishings or fittings or any other part of such hotel, roominghouse, motel, nursing home, hospital, child care facility, or similar place of abode, in such manner as to endanger the safety of any person or property. It shall be the duty of the owner or operator of any such place to place a printed copy of this section in a prominent place in each room of such place. 
(Code 1979, § 34.14)  
Sec. 50-47. - Lock box system. 
(a)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Hazardous substance means a substance for which an occupational safety and health standard has been adopted under the Occupational Safety and Health Act of 1970, 84 Stat. 1590, 29 U.S.C.A. § 651, as amended, and the rules adopted pursuant thereto; or a mixture of substances that contains any substance listed in such Act in a quantity that constitutes more than 1 percent of the composition or volume of the mixture. 
Lock box means heavy steel box fitted with a Level 3 locking device that requires a key that cannot be duplicated by a locksmith. 
(b)  Lock box system required for certain buildings. All premises required by the Village Code to provide fire detection or fire extinguishing systems, with the exception of residential property, or premises in which hazardous substances are used or stored, shall be required to have a lock box installed on the premises. 
(c)  Lock box authorized for residential units. Lock boxes are authorized, but not required for any legal residential unit in the Village. Property management companies and property owners of multifamily properties shall not prohibit or deter the use of Lock boxes. Condominium Associations shall allow the use and installation of Lock boxes if so desired by the individual unit owner or tenant. 
(1)  Residential Lock boxes are to be installed on the front door of an individual residential unit to provide access during an emergency response by the Skokie Fire Department. 
(2)  The Lock box shall contain a key to the door upon which it is mounted. 
(d)  Authorization of installation; waiver and indemnification agreement. 
(1)  Prior to the installation of any lock box, approval for the location and utilization must be obtained from the Village Manager or designee. The owner or occupant of the premises must provide the Village Manager or designee with a completed application including authorization form for the Village's utilization of the lock box. 
(2)  An executed waiver and indemnification agreement, on a form provided by the Village shall be submitted with the authorization form by the owner or occupant. 
(e)  Contents of lock boxes referred to in Section 50-47(b) shall include the following as appropriate: 
(1)  Keys to locked points of ingress, whether on the interior or exterior of such buildings. 
(2)  Keys to locked mechanical equipment rooms. 
(3)  Keys to locked electrical rooms. 
(4)  Keys to elevator controls. 
(5)  Keys to other areas as directed by the Fire Official. 
(6)  A list of all hazardous substances and information sheets on these substances. 
(7)  Any other valuable information such as floor plans, protection systems, HVAC drawings, utilities access, etc., which could be requested by the Fire Department for its overall approach to a fire emergency. 
(f)  Access to lock box. It shall be the responsibility of the owner or occupant of the premises to keep the contents of the lock box required in subsection (e) of this section up to date. If it is necessary for the owner or occupant of the premises to access the lock box for the purpose of updating its contents, the owner or occupant shall contact the Village Manager or designee. The Village Manager or designee shall have the only key to access the lock box and shall be present when the lock box is accessed. 
(g)  Authority to establish additional regulations. The Village Manager is authorized to establish rules, regulations and procedures for the implementation of this section. 
(Code 1979, § 34.16; Ord. No. 04-10-C-3305, § 3, 10-4-2004; Ord. No. 10-12-C-3806, § 1, 12-6-2010) 
Federal law reference— Hazardous Substances Act, 15 U.S.C.A. § 1261 et seq. 
State Law reference— Uniform Hazardous Substances Act, 430 ILCS 35/1 et seq.  
Sec. 50-48. - Cleanup of deposits of hazardous materials. 
(a)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Hazardous materials means any substance or material in a quantity or form which, in the determination of the Fire Chief or the Fire Chief's authorized representative, poses an unreasonable and imminent risk to the life, health or safety of persons or property or to the ecological balance of the environment, and shall include but not be limited to such substances as explosives, radioactive materials, petroleum or petroleum products or gases, poisons, etiologic (biologic) agents, flammables or corrosives. 
(b)  Cleanup and abatement authorized. The Village Manager or designee is authorized to order the cleanup, or abatement of the effects, of any hazardous materials. 
(c)  Liability for costs of cleanup or abatement. Any person or persons who intentionally or negligently cause such deposits shall be liable for the payment of all costs incurred as a result of such cleanup or abatement, including but not limited to actual labor costs of Village personnel (including workers' compensation benefits, fringe benefits, and administrative overhead), costs of equipment operation and materials obtained directly by the Village, and other costs, including attorneys' fees, incurred as a result of a contract by the Village for labor, material and removal. However, the authority to recover costs under this section shall not include costs of actual fire suppression services which are normally or usually provided by the Fire Department. 
(d)  Lien for costs incurred by Village. 
(1)  Any costs incurred by the Village, or its duly appointed officers or agents, in cleaning up or abating the effects of such deposits pursuant to this section shall be a lien upon the real estate so affected, and the lien shall be superior to all other liens and encumbrances, except tax liens, provided that, within 60 days after such cost and expense is incurred, the Village, or person performing the service by authority of the Village, in its or such person's own name, files notice of lien in the office of the County Recorder of Deeds. The notice shall consist of a sworn statement setting out (i) a description of the real estate sufficient for identification thereof, (ii) the amount of money representing the costs and expenses incurred or payable for the service, and (iii) the date or dates when such costs and expenses were incurred by the Village or one acting under its direction and authority. However, the lien shall not be valid as to any purchaser whose rights in and to such real estate have arisen subsequent to such cleanup or abatement and prior to the filing of such notice, and the lien shall not be valid as to any mortgagee, judgment creditor or other lienor whose rights in and to the affected real estate arise prior to the filing of such notice. Upon payment of the costs and expenses by the owner of or persons interested in such property after notice of lien has been filed, the lien shall be released by the Village or person in whose name the lien has been filed and the release shall be filed of record as in the case of filing notice of lien. 
(2)  The cost of the cleanup and abatement shall not be a lien on the real estate affected unless a notice is personally served on, or sent by certified mail to, the person to whom was sent the tax bill for the general taxes on the property for the preceding year. The notice shall be delivered or sent after the cleanup or abatement of such deposits on the property. The notice shall contain a copy of this section and 65 ILCS 5/11-20-7, and shall identify the affected real estate, by common description and the location of the hazardous materials. 
(e)  Remedies additional to other remedies and penalties. The remedy provided by this section shall be in addition to any other remedies or penalties provided by law. 
(Code 1979, § 34.17) 
Cross reference— Environment, ch. 42. 
Federal law reference— Hazardous Substances Act, 15 U.S.C.A. § 1261 et seq. 
State Law reference— Uniform Hazardous Substances Act, 430 ILCS 35/1 et seq.  
Sec. 50-49. - Privately owned fire hydrants. 
(a)  Generally. It shall be unlawful to have a privately owned fire hydrant which is in violation of this section. 
(b)  Application for approval. All owners of private fire hydrants shall apply to the Village Manager or designee for installation approval and inspections of the fire hydrant. Applications shall be made to the Village Manager or designee on forms prescribed and furnished by the Village Manager or designee. The Village Manager or designee may request additional information from the applicant. In every application for a privately owned fire hydrant, the applicant shall agree to the following: 
(1)  That any and all costs related to the installation and maintenance or removal of the privately owned fire hydrant shall be incurred by the applicant. 
(2)  That the privileges granted to the applicant are nontransferable and shall only apply to the fire hydrant specified in the respective application. 
(3)  That the applicant shall name the Village as an additional insured from any loss or claim for personal injury or property damage alleged against the Village or the applicant, arising out of the installation, removal, existence, use or maintenance of the fire hydrant. 
(4)  That the applicant agrees and covenants to forever hold harmless and indemnify the Village and its officers, employees and agents, and to save them from and indemnify for all costs, claims, suits, demands, and actions arising out of the installation, removal, existence, use or maintenance of the fire hydrant. 
The applicant shall provide the Village Fire Department, Fire Prevention Bureau, with current contact names, addresses, and phone numbers of parties responsible for hydrant maintenance. 
(c)  Standards. All privately owned fire hydrants shall be acceptable to the Village Manager or designee and contain 2 4½-inch National Standard Thread (NST) ports. Manufacturers acceptable to the Fire Chief include Mueller and Waterous. 
(d)  Installation. The Village Manager or designee shall approve the location of all privately owned hydrants, including orientation of the ports, proximity to buildings and roadways, and any other pertinent criteria. Installation shall be in compliance with NFPA standards and the Illinois Plumbing Code, as may be amended from time to time. The Village Manager or designee shall inspect privately owned fire hydrants for proper materials and workmanship. 
(e)  Labeling and numbering. The Village Manager or designee shall issue specifications for labeling private hydrants. Every privately owned fire hydrant shall have a label clearly imprinted thereon in compliance with Village standards. The Village Manager or designee shall issue a hydrant inventory number for all approved privately owned fire hydrants. 
(f)  Maintenance. Private water mains and fire hydrants are the responsibility of the property owners. NFPA standards require them to be inspected and maintained in proper working order. Repairs and maintenance include operation, appearance, protection from traffic, clearance from obstructions, and any other items impacting the hydrant operation. Hydrants must be painted every 5 years with paint approved by, and to the color scheme 
specified by, the Village Manager or designee. A licensed plumbing contractor, bonded for work in the Village, shall obtain necessary permits to make repairs to hydrants and associated plumbing. 
(g)  Village inspections. The Village Manager or designee shall inspect and flow privately owned hydrants. 
(h)  Notification of repairs. The Village shall forward any repair or maintenance discrepancies to the designated contact person for correction. Notification of completion of any repair shall be made to the Village Manager or designee for the purpose of inspection and acceptance. Repairs are to be completed in a timely manner. 
(i)  Time limit for completing repairs. Property owners have 10 days from notification to effect repairs or to request a time extension from the Village Manager or designee. Failure to make necessary repairs or to request an extension shall result in water to the property being shut off after 20 days of noncompliance. Notification of initiation and completion of any repair, regardless of whether it is in response to a Village-initiated notification, shall be made to the Village Manager or designee for the purpose of notification, inspection and acceptance. 
(Code 1979, § 34.18) 
State Law reference— Authority to regulate hydrants, 65 ILCS 5/11-20-10.  
Sec. 50-50. - Obstructing hydrants. 
It shall be unlawful for any person in manner to obstruct the use of any public fire hydrant, or place any material or vehicle in front thereof, or within 15 feet thereof at any curb, such distance to be measured from that point on the curb perpendicular to the exact location of the public fire hydrant. Any material or any vehicle found to be such an obstruction or within such 15 feet may be immediately removed by the Village, at the risk, cost, and expense of the owner or claimant thereof. 
(Code 1979, § 34.20) 
Cross reference— Parking near fire hydrant, § 106-103(a)(7). 
State Law reference— Obstacles hiding or impeding use, 425 ILCS 20/1 et seq.; parking vehicle near fire hydrant, 625 ILCS 5/11-1303.  
Sec. 50-51. - Conflicting regulations. 
If any provision of either the International Fire Code of the International Code Council, as adopted in this Article, or the Life Safety Code, 2012 edition, published and modified by the National Fire Protection Association (NFPA) is in conflict with any provision of any code, ordinance, rule or regulation of the Village, then the code, ordinance, rule or regulation of the Village shall prevail and the conflicting provision of the International Fire Code of the International Code Council or the Life Safety Code of the National Fire Protection Association shall have no force or effect. If any provision of either the International Fire Code of the International Code Council, as adopted in this Article, or the Life Safety Code 2012 edition, published and modified by the National Fire Protection Association (NFPA) is in conflict, the Fire Chief or designee shall be considered the Authority Having Jurisdiction (AHJ) and shall have the authority to make the final code compliance determination. 
(Ord. No. 04-10-C-3305, § 4, 10-4-2004; Ord. No. 15-8-C-4167, § 4, 8-3-2015)  
Sec. 50-52. - Amendments to International Fire Code. 
The International Fire Code adopted by reference in this article shall be modified as follows: 
(1)  109.4 Violation Penalties. Replace existing text with the following: 
Penalty for failure to correct fire hazard. Any owner, or agent, employee or officer thereof, or person in possession or control of building or place mentioned in Section 50-36, who shall refuse or neglect to make such changes, alterations or repairs within a period of five (5) days after the date of such notice, shall be subject to the penalties provided in Section 1-6 in addition to any other penalty specifically provided for; Skokie Village Ordinance Sec. 50-37 (Code 1979, § 34.15). 
(2)  Sec. 404.5 Availability. Add the following subsection: 
404.5.1.2 Pre-Plan Drawings. To assist the fire department to develop pre-plans for fire emergencies, all new and altered buildings (except single-family detached dwellings) are required to present as-build drawings prior to certificate of occupancy. Drawings shall indicate a full site plan and a complete interior floor plan (building foot print). Where practical the drawings shall be in an electronic media format, but in all cases in a format approved by the AHJ. 
(3)  Sec. 510 Radio Amplification system. Delete text and replace with: 
510.1 General. This Section covers radio amplification systems, which are bi-directional amplifier systems, or similar systems needed to meet the threshold radio communication standards for the Village of Skokie's public safety communications network. For the purpose of this section all such systems shall be referred to as a radio amplification system. 
510.2 When required. A radio amplification system shall be installed at no cost to the Village, in any building or structure, other than single-family residential, following a determination by a qualified third party, that such a system is needed to provide adequate radio coverage in areas requiring amplification when: 
1.  New buildings or structures greater than 50,000 square feet in area are constructed. 
2.  New buildings or structures greater than 10,000 square feet in area with sub-grade mechanical areas or parking are constructed. 
3.  Existing building or structures greater than 50,000 square feet in area are modified, altered or repaired in such a way that increases existing building or structure value by fifty percent (50%) or the floor area by 50%, within any twelve (12) month period. 
510.3 Adequate minimum coverage. For purposes of this Section, adequate radio coverage shall be accomplished (satisfied) when each floor of a structure attains ninety-five percent (95%) radio communications reliability 95% of the time with a minimum signal capacity of Delivered Audio Quality 3 (DAQ3 - Speech understandable with slight effort. Requires occasional repetition due to noise or distortion). The following rooms/areas shall have complete radio coverage with signal capacity DAQ3: 
1.  Fire command rooms 
2.  Fire pump rooms 
3.  Mechanical rooms 
4.  Rooms/areas that contain hazardous materials 
5.  Computer rooms 
510.4 System requirements. The radio amplifications system shall be developed in accordance with the guidelines set forth in this Section. 
510.4.1 Type. Buildings and structures may be equipped with any of the following in order to achieve adequate radio coverage: 
1.  An internal radio amplification system as needed to encompass the frequency range specified by the Fire Department. 
2.  A system that has been approved by the Fire Department as being capable of providing amplification to meet the requirements of this Section. 
510.4.2 Power back-up. The radio amplification system shall be capable of operating on an independent battery and/or generator system for a period of at least twelve (12) hours without external power input. The battery system shall automatically charge in the presence of external power input. There shall be no connection between the radio amplification system and the fire alarm system. 
510.5 Evaluation. The evaluation process for determining the need for in-building amplification is conducted in a minimum of three phases: pre-construction, construction, and acceptance/implementation. 
510.5.1 Pre-construction base submittals. Before the beginning of construction, basic information must be submitted to the Fire Department to begin the process of determining the need, type and actual implementation or augmentation to the radio system. These submittal requirements include: 
1.  The number of stories and square footage of the building. 
2.  Orientation of building above/below ground shown in cross section drawings. 
3.  Construction materials type of the outer and inner walls. 
4.  The location of proposed equipment areas such as equipment rooms, cableways, and conduits and rooms requiring complete radio coverage in Section 510.3. 
5.  Location of the building on a site plan. 
6.  Building blueprints or drawings. 
510.5.2 Construction phase. During construction phase, a needs determination must be completed. 
510.5.3 Acceptance testing. Acceptance testing for an in building or in structure radio amplification system is required upon completion of the installation of the of the radio amplification system. 
510.5.3.1 Acceptance testing responsibility. It is the building owner's responsibility to have the radio amplification system tested to ensure that two-way coverage on each floor of the building attains ninety-five percent (95%) radio communications reliability 95% of the time with a minimum signal capacity of Delivered Audio Quality 3 (DAQ3). 
510.5.3.2 Testing procedure. The testing company/person shall submit a description of the testing procedures for review and approval to the Fire Chief or designee. 
510.5.3.3 Results maintenance. The gain values of all amplifiers shall be measured and the results kept on file with the building/structure owner so that measurements can be verified each year during the annual test. In the event that this information is lost the building/structure owner will be required to rerun the acceptance test to reestablish the gain values. 
510.6 Annual test. When an in-building/structure radio amplification system is installed, the building/structure owner shall test all active components of the radio amplification system including, but not limited to the amplifier, the power supplies and the back-up batteries, a minimum of once every twelve (12) months. Amplifiers shall be tested to ensure that the gain is the same as it was upon initial installation and acceptance of the radio amplification system. Back-up batteries and power supplies shall be tested under load for a period of two (2) hours to verify that they will operate during an actual power outage. All other active components shall be checked to determine that they are operating within the manufacturer's specification for the intended purpose. 
510.7 Five-Year test. In addition to the annual test in Subsection 510.6, the building/structure owner shall perform a radio coverage test at least once every five (5) years to ensure that the radio amplification system continues to meet the requirement of this Section. The acceptance test procedures, set forth above in Subsection 510.5.3, shall apply to such tests. 
510.8 Inadequate radio coverage. When a building or structure with a radio amplification system fails to support adequate radio coverage tests required in Subsection 510.6 and 510.7, the owner shall have the system repaired as required in Section 510.11. However, if major components of the system are in need of replacement or the entire system is obsolete the building/structure owner must present a compliance plan to the Fire Chief or designee, within fourteen (14) days after the discovery of said failure, to address the inadequate radio coverage. The owner of the building/structure shall, within forty-five (45) days of the approval of the compliance plan, have the approved plan enacted. Thirty (30) day extensions for the completion of the compliance plan may be granted by the Fire Chief or designee. 
510.9 Qualifications of testing personnel. All tests required by this Section shall be conducted, documented and signed by a person in possession of a current FCC general radio telephone operator license. All test records shall be retained at the inspected premises by the building/structure owner, with a copy thereof being submitted to the Village's Fire Chief within thirty (30) days of when the test has been conducted. In the even the test indicates a failure to comply with the requirement of this Section, appropriate repairs shall be made and additional tests conducted until the testing requirements of this Section are met. 
510.10 Inspections. Village personnel, or their agents after providing reasonable notice to the owner or owner's representative, shall have the right to enter any building/structure which is subject to the requirements of Section 510, to conduct field-testing to be certain that the required level of radio coverage is present. 
510.11 Property owner maintenance responsibilities. Once a radio amplification system has been found to be in compliance with the requirement of this Section, the building/structure owner shall be responsible for maintaining said radio amplification system thereafter in full compliance with the provisions of said Section. A maintenance contract shall be provided to the Fire Chief or designee, with the name of the contractor who will supply a twenty-four (24) hours a day, seven (7) days a week emergency response, within two (2) hours after notification by either the Village or the building/structure owner. The maintenance contract shall contain contact information relative to the contractor including but not limited to phone numbers. The building/structure owner shall also submit contact information. Building/structure owner shall be responsible for making any repairs, replacements or upgrades to the radio amplification system, as directed by the Village should the radio amplification system fail to work properly. 
510.12 Permit required. A building permit shall be required for the installation of any radio amplification system. The fee for the permit shall be the minimum permit fee as established by the building permit fee schedule set forth in Chapter 46 of the Skokie Village Code 
(4)  511 Village Public Safety Communications Network. Add as follows: 
If the erection or construction of a structure interferes with the existing telecommunications system for public safety purposes, the developer and/or owner shall provide for appropriate easement, facilities and equipment to ensure the continued satisfactory operation of the public safety telecommunications system at no cost to the Village. Facilities and equipment needed to alleviate the concern shall become part of the Village of Skokie's communications network and shall be operated and maintained by the Village. In the event that the facilities and equipment cannot be located on the proposed structure, or their location on the structure will not provide satisfactory operation of the public safely telecommunications system, the development shall pay the cost of equipment, installation and easement to locate the equipment at an alternative location determined by the Village to provide proper communications.

All new fire alarm control panels shall be connected via radio to Skokie Communication Center. Building is a single story having basement compartments with one (1) hour fire protective rating no larger than 2,500 square feet, with basement use limited to storage of dry goods, merchandise and food products, not needing specialized fire protection, ventilation or handling, with access to basements limited to employees or employee agents only and not for public use with no production work or continuous operations;

Sec. 903.4.2.1 Alarm Notification for One and Two Family Dwellings. A weather proof audio visual device shall be installed on the exterior of the structure as part of the fire suppression system so that the operation of the fire sprinkler suppression system will cause audio visual device to be seen from the fronting street. A minimum six (6) inch bell shall be installed in the interior of the structure, and shall be mounted, if possible on the HVAC return air system, to reverberate the sound of bell throughout the entire structure to signal that there is an activation of water flow to the sprinkler system. The bell, A/V, and water flow switch shall be wired into a shared basement electrical circuit (such as sump pump, basement lights, etc.) this to prevent accidental disruption of the alarm notification system.

A weather proof horn/strobe shall be mounted on the exterior front of that tenant space and as indicated in Section 903.4.2. The horn/strobe device shall activate upon water flow and/or fire alarm activation within that individual unit.

(14)  Sec. 907.6.5 Monitoring. Delete text and replace with: 
All fire alarm subscribers, all required new or significantly modified Fire Alarm Systems, excluding systems in one-and two-family residential buildings and those existing systems that do not require modification but have experienced an increase in risk or life safety, shall have a direct connection to the Combined Communications Center (CCC). This connection shall be made and operational before occupancy of the building will be approved by the Fire Prevention Bureau. The Fire Chief, or designee, shall make the determination of whether a system has been significantly modified or potential for a higher loss of life or hazard classification has increased. Any waiver or modification of this connection requirement may only be authorized by the Village Manager or designee. Any significantly modified fire alarm system that is under contract to transmit its emergency signal to a remote monitoring station rather than to the CCC prior to submittal of alarm system improvement plans shall be allowed to remain under such contract until the end of the current term of the contract or until the contract is terminated, whichever occurs first. Upon expiration or termination of said contract, the alarm shall be converted to an alarm that transmits its emergency signal via a Village-owned radio transmitter directly to the CCC.

(16)  Section 907.8.5 Add as follows: 
Section 907.8.5.1 Alarm Out of Service 
If at any time coverage or protection provided by a fire alarm system, excluding systems in one-and two-family residential buildings, decreases or ceases, the following shall occur: 
1.  The alarm user shall notify the CCC anytime a system is removed from service due to maintenance, mechanical problems, or any other condition in which the system will not transmit an activated alarm to the CCC. 
2.  The alarm user shall provide notice to all tenants/occupants in the building that the fire alarm system is out of service, and that it will be necessary to notify the fire department by calling 9-1-1 of any fires or similar hazardous conditions. 
3.  If, at the discretion of the fire chief or designee, a system is anticipated to remain out of service for more than four (4) hours, a fire watch at the property owner's expense, may be required. 
4.  Upon restoration of the fire alarm system to normal operating conditions, the property owner shall notify the CCC and any affected tenant or occupant. 
5.  Any and all corrective actions necessary to restore the system to a normal operating condition shall be taken by the alarm user or their agent to place the alarm back in full service within seventy-two (72) hours after the initial out of service report to the CCC. 
(17)  Section 912.1. Add as follows: 
Section 912.1.1 Exterior fire department connection visual indicator. When a fire sprinkler system is required to have a fire department connection in accordance with Section 912.1, a visual indicator shall be installed directly above the fire department connection in a location approved by the AHJ. In those cases where architectural design visually obscures the visual indicator from being seen from the primary roadway in front of the building and/or structure that is protected by the fire sprinkler system, the AHJ shall determine and alternate location of placement of the visual indicator on the front of the building/or structure. The visual indicator shall be weather proof and activate on water flow alarms only. 
(18)  Add Sec. 1106 Fire Protection Requirements: Additions, Alterations, and Hazard Classification Changes to Existing Structures. 
Additions - Any existing structure that is adding an addition will have fire protection as indicated based on the following: 
1.  Fire Protection Sprinkler System will be provided as the fire protection. 
If the resultant size of the structure is equal to or greater than 5,000 square feet and the Hazard Classification is increased based on evaluation by the AHJ. 
2.  Fire Detection System will be provided as the fire protection. 
a.  If the resultant size of the structure is equal to or greater than 2,500 square feet. 
b.  If the resultant size of the structure is less than 2,500 square feet and the Hazard Classification is increased based on evaluation by the AHJ. 
Existing Structure being reoccupied will have fire protection as indicated based on the following: 
1.  Fire Protection Sprinkler System will be provided as the fire protection. If the resultant size of the structure is equal to or greater than 5,000 square feet and the Hazard Classification is increased based on evaluation by the AHJ. 
2.  Fire Detection System will be provided as the fire protection. 
a.  If the resultant size of the structure is equal to or greater than 2,500 square feet. 
b.  If the resultant size of the structure is less than 2,500 square feet and the Hazard Classification is increased based on evaluation by the AHJ. 
Alterations - Existing structures undergoing alterations that include a work area for the alteration of fifty percent (50%) of the aggregate area of the building will have fire protection as indicated based on the following: 
1.  Fire Protection Sprinkler System will be provided as the fire protection. 
If the resultant size of the structure is equal to or greater than 5,000 square feet and the Hazard Classification is increased based on evaluation by the AHJ. 
2.  Fire Detection System will be provided as the fire protection. 
a.  If the resultant size of the structure is equal to or greater than 2,500 square feet. 
b.  If the resultant size of the structure is less than 2,500 square feet and the Hazard Classification is increased based on evaluation by the AHJ. 
(Ord. No. 04-10-C-3305, § 5, 10-4-2004; Ord. No. 08-4-C-3613, § 2, 4-7-2008; Ord. No. 15-8-C-4167, § 4, 8-3-2015)

ARTICLE III. - FOREIGN FIRE INSURANCE BOARD 
 
Sec. 50-60. - Creation and purpose. 
(a)  There is hereby established a Foreign Fire Insurance Board of the Village of Skokie, hereafter known as "the FFI Board," to receive and expend Foreign Fire Insurance Tax funds, hereafter known as "Tax Funds," for the maintenance, use and benefit of the Village of Skokie Fire Department, in accordance with the Illinois Compiled Statutes. All Tax Funds received by the Village are public funds and shall be deposited in the General Fund, but shall be earmarked for the purposes stated herein and be assigned a separate account number. The Tax Funds shall be subject to appropriation by the Mayor and the Board of Trustees during the usual budget cycle and subject to the same procedures, except as specified herein, as all other Village revenues and receipts. 
(Ord. No. 09-2-C-3663, § 1, 2-2-2009)  
Sec. 50-61. - Definition. 
(a)  "Members of the Department" for purpose of this Article shall include all members of the Fire Department, including sworn and non-sworn members. 
(Ord. No. 09-2-C-3663, § 1, 2-2-2009; Ord. No. 10-3-C-3744, § 1, 3-1-2010)  
Sec. 50-62. - Organization. 
(a)  The FFI Board shall consist of members as described in Section 11-10-2 of the Illinois Municipal Code, 65 ILCS 5/11-10-2. 
(b)  The Village Finance Director, or designee, shall serve as an ex-officio member of the FFI Board. The Village Finance Director is entitled to all notices of all meetings and has the right to participate in the meetings; however, he or she shall not be entitled to vote. 
(c)  At the first meeting of the FFI Board and annually thereafter, the FFI Board members shall select officers as required by Section 11-10-2 of the Illinois Municipal Code, 65 ILCS 5/11-10-2. 
(Ord. No. 09-2-C-3663, § 1, 2-2-2009; Ord. No. 10-3-C-3744, § 1, 3-1-2010)  
Sec. 50-63. - Term of office. 
(a)  Elected FFI Board members shall serve a two (2) year term. The terms will be staggered with three Board members being elected in even numbered years and the other three elected in odd numbered years. 
(b)  In the event no successor FFI Board member assumes office prior to the expiration of the two (2) year term, then the FFI Board member shall serve until a successor FFI Board member assumes office. The initial terms of office of the FFI Board members shall begin thirty (30) days after completion of the election. Each FFI Board member shall hold office during his/her term unless the member resigns from the department, retires from the department, or is discharged from the department. If any of these three (3) events occur, the FFI Board member shall automatically be removed from the FFI Board and the position shall be deemed vacant. 
(c)  Vacancies in the FFI Board shall be filled as described in Section 50-64(d) herein below. Any person elected to fill a FFI Board position vacancy shall assume office immediately upon completion of the election. 
(Ord. No. 09-2-C-3663, § 1, 2-2-2009; Ord. No. 10-3-C-3744, § 1, 3-1-2010)  
Sec. 50-64. - Election procedures. 
(a)  The election of members to the FFI Board shall be conducted by the FFI Board. 
(b)  Nomination of members shall commence on the third Monday of February and the period of time for making nominations shall remain open until 5:00 p.m. on the third Monday of March. The period of time for casting of ballots shall commence no later than 5:00 p.m. on the day following the third Monday in March and shall remain open until 4:00 p.m. on the third Monday of April. 
(c)  Elections shall be by secret ballot collected in a secured ballot box located in the Secretary of the Fire Chief's office. No voting by proxy or write in candidates shall be accepted. 
(d)  When a FFI Board member position becomes unexpectedly vacant, and the balance of the unexpired term is greater than six months, a special election may be held to fill that position for the unexpired term. When a FFI Board member position becomes unexpectedly vacant, and the balance of the term is less than six months, the FFI Board may appoint a member to fill the balance of the unexpired term. 
(Ord. No. 09-2-C-3663, § 1, 2-2-2009; Ord. No. 10-3-C-3744, § 1, 3-1-2010)  
Sec. 50-65. - Duties of officers. 
(a)  The Chairperson shall preside over meetings of the FFI Board. He/she shall be the executive head of the FFI Board and an ex-officio member of all committees. He/she shall appoint such committees as may be provided for in this Article and any special committees as may be from time to time established by the FFI Board to carry out specific tasks. The Chairperson shall have general supervision of the activities of committees created in accordance with this Article. 
(b)  The Vice Chairperson, if the position is created, shall assist the Chairperson in any such manner as the Chairperson may determine. In the absence of the Chairperson, he/she shall preside at the meetings of the FFI Board. If the office of the Chairperson becomes vacated, the Vice-Chairperson shall be acting Chairperson until the office of Chairperson is filled. 
(c)  The Secretary, if the position is created, shall be custodian of all documents, records, books and papers belonging to the FFI Board. He/she shall keep an accurate record of the meetings of the FFI Board and of the various committees of which he/she shall be the Secretary. He/she shall conduct correspondence of the FFI Board promptly. If the position of Secretary is not created, then all duties shall be performed by the Treasurer in addition to the duties of the Treasurer specified in paragraph (d) of this Section. 
(d)  The Treasurer shall be charged with the responsibility of monitoring the expenditures of all monies. He/she shall work closely with the Village's Finance Director with regard to the account balances and financial transactions affecting the account. He/she shall maintain a current ledger showing the starting account balance and subsequent debits for items purchased. He/she shall present a financial statement at all regular business meetings. 
(e)  The officers of the FFI Board shall serve without compensation. Officer vacancies will be filled as needed by FFI Board selection. 
(Ord. No. 09-2-C-3663, § 1, 2-2-2009; Ord. No. 10-3-C-3744, § 1, 3-1-2010)  
Sec. 50-66. - Powers and duties. 
(a)  The FFI Board shall make all necessary rules and regulations with respect to the Foreign Fire Insurance Board and/or the decision making process for selection of expenditures. No expenditures or transfers shall be made without a majority approval of the FFI Board. The FFI Board shall coordinate its activities and decisions relating to expenditures or transfers with the Chief of the Fire Department during the Village budget cycle to ensure maximum effectiveness and reduce redundancy. 
(b)  The FFI Board shall develop and maintain a listing of those items that it determines are appropriate expenditures for the maintenance, use and benefit of the Fire Department. 
(c)  The expenditures and transfers made by the FFI Board shall be annually reviewed as part of the Village audit. The audit shall verify that expenditures and transfers made by the FFI Board are for the maintenance, use and benefit of the Fire Department, as described in Section 50-67 herein below. 
(d)  The Village Finance Director shall receive the Tax Funds paid to the FFI Board and shall pay out such monies and/or otherwise make expenditures upon the order of the FFI Board. Any expenditure made by the Village Finance Director or designee, pursuant to the order of the FFI Board, shall be solely for the maintenance, use and benefit of the Fire Department, as described in Section 50-67 herein below. 
(e)  The Director of Finance of the Village shall: 
1.  Have charge and custody of and be responsible for all Tax Funds collected by the Village from the FFI Board; 
2.  Deposit all such monies for the FFI Board in such banks, savings and loan associations, or other depositories as shall be authorized by the Village Board; 
3.  Invest such Tax Funds as are not immediately required in such securities consistent with policies and practice in place, while collecting all interest earned and depositing such interest to the benefit of the account; 
4.  Maintain the financial books and records of the account; 
5.  Provide the FFI Board a quarterly accounting of receipts and expenditures of the account; 
6.  Pay the service charge levied by the Illinois Municipal League for the collection of the Foreign Fire Insurance Tax from the proceeds of the Foreign Fire Insurance Tax provided that the service charge has not already been retained by the Illinois Municipal League prior to disbursement of the Tax Funds. 
(f)  The FFI Board members, being employees of the Village, shall be subject to the Code of Ethics applicable to employees as set forth in Article V, Chapter 2, of the Skokie Village Code and Section 1.2 of the Village of Skokie Personnel Policy Manual. 
(Ord. No. 09-2-C-3663, § 1, 2-2-2009; Ord. No. 10-3-C-3744, § 1, 3-1-2010)  
Sec. 50-67. - Use of funds. 
(a)  Tax Funds received by the FFI Board shall be used solely for the maintenance, use and benefit of the Fire Department. Upon the purchase of any approved items, title shall be placed in the name of the Village. 
(b)  The FFI Board reserves the right, after full review of a written proposal for expenditure from a member of the department, to approve or reject by majority vote any request for proposed expenditure. A majority vote shall be defined as one (1) vote more than fifty (50) percent of those present and voting. A tie vote shall be considered a rejected request. 
(c)  By October 1 st of each year the FFI Board shall provide the Fire Chief a proposed budget for the expenditure of the Tax Funds. 
(d)  In furtherance of his duties, as specified in Section 2-235 (1) and (2) of Chapter 2 of the Skokie Village Code, the Fire Chief shall review the proposed budget and has the absolute right to prohibit any item and/or service to be located or conducted in any fire station. If the Fire Chief decides to allow any such item(s) and/or service(s) into any fire station, the Fire Chief shall also have the absolute right to prohibit the FFI Board's proposed physical location of any such item(s) or rendering of service in any fire station. The Fire Chief must respond in writing to the FFI Board regarding the proposed budget within 30 days from his receipt of the proposed budget. The Fire Chief must explain the basis for his decision(s). 
(e)  The FFI Board may appeal, in writing, any decision of the Fire Chief rendered pursuant to paragraph (d) of this Section, within 21 days of the decision. The appeal shall be to the Village Manager who shall issue his decision in writing within 21 days of his receipt of the FFI Board's written appeal. The decision of the Village Manager shall be final. 
(f)  The approved budget shall be submitted to the Village Board with the Fire Department budget. The approved budget may be amended at any time by a majority vote of the officers of the FFI Board and the approval of the Fire Chief; any amendment shall be subject to approval of the Village Board. Expenditures shall be made only for items specifically described in the approved budget as originally adopted or subsequently amended by the FFI Board and approved by the Village Board. 
(g)  The FFI Board shall have the power to approve the expenditure of money for items specifically described in the approved budget. 
(h)  Any expenditure made from the Tax Funds account shall be made in accordance with Village rules, regulations, practices and ordinances, as may be amended from time to time, which govern the procurement of goods and services. All expenditures must be coordinated with the purchasing agent to ensure compliance with purchasing requirements. 
(i)  Money received from the Foreign Fire Insurance account may be used solely for the purchase of goods and services for the maintenance, use, and benefit of the fire department. Any items or services purchased with money from the account shall thereupon become the property of the Village. Money from the account shall not be used for: (i) the personal benefit of any person; (ii) any person, use, or function not directly related to the Fire Department; (iii) food or beverages; (iv) any recreational or entertainment equipment or activity; (v) any litigation; (vi) the benefit of any private for-profit or not-for-profit entity; or (vii) legislative activity. The FFI Board, being an agency of the Village, shall not enter into any contract or agreement without the approval of the Village Manager, or if legally required, the Mayor and Board of Trustees. The FFI Board shall not make, or obligate, expenditures from the account in excess of the amount of money currently on deposit in and currently available for use from the account. 
(Ord. No. 09-2-C-3663, § 1, 2-2-2009; Ord. No. 10-3-C-3744, § 1, 3-1-2010)  
Sec. 50-68. - Meetings—Quorum, special meetings. 
The FFI Board shall, in accordance with the Open Meetings Act, establish a regular time and place for its meetings and publish notices of those meetings. The FFI Board shall be subject to the provisions of the Illinois Open Meeting Act. Four (4) FFI Board members shall constitute a quorum for the transaction of business. The Chairperson may call a special meeting at any time. A special meeting may also be called upon the written notice of four (4) FFI Board members. Such notice shall be in writing, duly signed by the FFI Board members, describing, in brief, the nature or object of the special meeting. All special meetings require a minimum of 48 hours written notice in advance of the meeting. Any person shall be entitled to attend any FFI Board meeting. Minutes of all FFI Board meetings shall be filed with the Village Clerk. 
(Ord. No. 09-2-C-3663, § 1, 2-2-2009)  
Sec. 50-69. - Rules and regulations. 
The FFI Board may promulgate written rules and regulations governing FFI Board matters so long as such rules and regulations are not inconsistent with law. All rules and regulations promulgated by the FFI Board must be approved by the Village Manager. All rules and regulations shall be available in each fire station, the Village Hall, and the Village Clerk. Before any rule or regulation shall become effective, such rule or regulation shall be filed with the Village Clerk and shall be made available for public inspection. The FFI Board secretary shall maintain a record of all FFI Board rules and regulations, which shall be available for public inspection. 
(Ord. No. 09-2-C-3663, § 1, 2-2-2009)  
Sec. 50-70. - Limited function of board. 
The FFI Board shall be limited in function to the purposes stated in Sections 11-10-1 and 11-10-2 of the Illinois Municipal Code (65 ILCS 5/11-10-1 et seq.) and the Skokie Village Code. Nothing in this article shall give the FFI Board any function or authority for any other purpose. At no time shall the actions of the FFI Board interfere with the duties, responsibilities and rights of the Fire Chief, the Village Manager, the Village Board, the Board of Fire and Police Commissioners, nor shall its actions in any way impede the ordinary, usual and customary operation of the Fire Department. 
(Ord. No. 09-2-C-3663, § 1, 2-2-2009)  
Chapter 54 - HEALTH AND SANITATION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Department of Public Health, § 2-291 et seq.; animals, ch. 18; dangerous animals, rabies control, § 18-61 et seq.; buildings and building regulations, ch. 22; environment, ch. 42; solid waste, ch. 86; utilities, ch. 110.
