Federal law references— Hazardous substances, 15 U.S.C.A. § 1261 et seq.; federal food, drug and cosmetic act, 21 U.S.C.A. § 301 et seq.; public health service, 42 U.S.C.A. § 201 et seq. 
State Law reference— Territorial jurisdiction for enforcement of health and quarantine ordinances and regulations, 65 ILCS 5/7-4-1; municipal health regulations, 65 ILCS 5/11-16-1 et seq.; public health, 410 ILCS 5/1 et seq. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 54-1. - Failure to correct violation; penalties. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to fail or refuse to correct or remedy any condition which is found by the Village Manager or designee to be unsafe, unhealthy or unwholesome or to endanger, impair or jeopardize the public health or safety. Every person in violation of this chapter shall be subject to the penalties provided in Section 1-6 in addition to any other penalty specifically provided for. In addition to all other fines and penalties, the Village Manager may suspend or revoke one's business license for any violation of this chapter. 
(Code 1979, § 11.16)  
Sec. 54-2. - Prosecution of violations. 
Violations of this chapter or other health regulations of the Village not corrected or remedied within the period of time required by the Village Manager or designee shall be referred to the office of the Corporation Counsel for prosecution. 
(Code 1979, § 11.15)  
Sec. 54-3. - Obstructing or polluting watercourse or source of water supply. 
It shall be unlawful and a nuisance for any person to obstruct or pollute any watercourse or source of water supply in the Village. 
(Code 1979, § 11.10) 
Cross reference— Public nuisances, § 42-31 et seq. 
State Law reference— Water pollution, 415 ILCS 5/11 et seq.  
Sec. 54-4. - Cemeteries and burials. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to establish a cemetery or to bury any person within the Village limits except in an established cemetery. 
(Code 1979, § 11.11) 
State Law reference— Burial of Dead Bodies Act, 410 ILCS 5/1 et seq.; Cemetery Association Act, 805 ILCS 320/1 et seq.  
Sec. 54-5. - Public drinking cups. 
It shall be unlawful to maintain any common drinking cup or cups, dipper or other similar utensil for the use of more than 1 person in any public hall, theater, store or other place frequented by the public. 
(Code 1979, § 11.12)  
Sec. 54-6. - Spitting in public place. 
It shall be unlawful to spit or expectorate on any public sidewalk or other public place, or on the floor or walls of any store, theater, hall, public vehicle or other place frequented by the public or to which the public is invited. 
(Code 1979, § 11.13) 
Cross reference— Streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 90.  
Secs. 54-7—54-30. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - VITAL STATISTICS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference— Vital Records Act, 410 ILCS 535/1 et seq. 
 
Sec. 54-31. - Registrar of Vital Statistics. 
The Director of Public Health shall be and is hereby made Registrar of Vital Statistics of the Village. 
(Code 1979, § 11.081)  
Sec. 54-32. - Reports of births and deaths. 
A report of all births, still births and deaths shall be made to the local Registrar of Vital Statistics, which report shall contain all information required by law. 
(Code 1979, § 11.082)  
Sec. 54-33. - Records of births and deaths. 
(a)  The Registrar of Vital Statistics shall keep a record showing all births, still births and deaths occurring within the Village, which record shall include the information required to be kept by statute. 
(b)  Copies of such birth and death certificates shall be available for the fee provided in Section 46-31. 
(Code 1979, § 11.083)  
Sec. 54-34. - Conformance with State law. 
The provisions of the statutes relative to vital statistics shall be fully complied with by the Director of Public Health in connection with vital statistics report. 
(Code 1979, § 11.084)  
Sec. 54-35. - Disposition of fees paid by State. 
Fees due the local Registrar of Vital Statistics of the Village from the State, pursuant to Illinois Vital Records Act, 410 ILCS 535/1 et seq., are to be paid to the Village and deposited in the appropriate Village account in accordance with established Village procedures and practices. 
(Code 1979, § 11.085)  
Secs. 54-36—54-60. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - SMOKING IN PUBLIC PLACES[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 08-2-C-3595, § 1, adopted Jan. 4, 2008, repealed and deleted the former Art. III, §§ 54-61—54-75, and enacted a new Art. III as set out herein. The former Art. III pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Code 1979, §§ 55.271—55.274, 55.276; Ord. No. 00-10-C-2947, § 8(55.38), adopted Oct. 16, 2000; Ord. No. 03-7-C-3188, § 2, adopted July 7, 2003; Ord. No. 04-7-C-3289, § 1, adopted July 19, 2004. 
Cross reference— Smoking in places of amusement, § 14-38; sale of tobacco products to underage persons, § 26-276; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 90. 
State Law reference— Clean Indoor Air Act, 410 ILCS 80/1 et seq.; Smoke Free Illinois Act, 30 ILCS 805/8.31. 
 
Sec. 54-61. - Definitions. 
Bar means an establishment that is devoted to the serving of alcoholic beverages for consumption by guests on the premises and that derives no more than 10% of its gross revenue from the sale of food consumed on the premises. "Bar" includes, but is not limited to, taverns, nightclubs, cocktail lounges, adult entertainment facilities, and cabarets. 
Electronic cigarette shall mean an electronic or battery-operated device that delivers vapors for inhalation. This term shall include every variation and type of such devices whether they are manufactured, distributed, marketed or sold as an electronic cigarette, an electronic cigar, an electronic cigarillo, an electronic pipe, an electronic hookah or any other product name or descriptor. 
E-liquid shall mean any liquid product composed either in whole or part of nicotine, propylene glycol, polyethylene glycol, glycerin and/or other similar substances and manufactured for use with an electronic cigarette to be converted into gas for inhaling. 
Employee means a person who is employed by an employer in consideration for direct or indirect monetary wages or profits or a person who volunteers his or her services for a nonprofit entity. 
Employer means a person, business, partnership, association, or corporation, including a municipal corporation, trust, or nonprofit entity, that employs the services of one or more individual persons. 
Enclosed area means all space between a floor and a ceiling that is enclosed or partially enclosed with (i) solid walls or windows, exclusive of doorways, or (ii) solid walls with partitions and no windows, exclusive of doorways, that extend from the floor to the ceiling, including, without limitation, lobbies and corridors. 
Enclosed or partially enclosed sports arena means any sports pavilion, stadium, gymnasium, health spa, boxing arena, swimming pool, roller rink, ice rink, bowling alley, or other similar place where members of the general public assemble to engage in physical exercise or participate in athletic competitions or recreational activities or to witness sports, cultural, recreational, or other events. 
Healthcare facility means an office or institution providing care or treatment of diseases, whether physical, mental, or emotional, or other medical, physiological, or psychological conditions, including, but not limited to, hospitals, rehabilitation hospitals, weight control clinics, nursing homes, homes for the aging or chronically ill, laboratories, and offices of surgeons, chiropractors, physical therapists, physicians, dentists, and all specialists within these professions. "Healthcare facility" includes all waiting rooms, hallways, private rooms, semiprivate rooms, and wards within healthcare facilities. 
Place of employment means: any area under the control of a public or private employer that employees are required to enter, leave, or pass through during the course of employment, including, but not limited to entrances and exits to places of employment, including a minimum distance of 15 feet from entrances, exits, windows that open, and ventilation intakes that serve an enclosed area where smoking is prohibited; offices and work areas; restrooms; conference and classrooms; break rooms and cafeterias; and other common areas. A private residence or home-based business, unless used to provide licensed child care, foster care, adult care, or other similar social service care on the premises, is not a "place of employment". 
Private club means a not-for-profit association that (1) has been in active and continuous existence for at least 3 years prior to the effective date Public Act 95-0017, whether incorporated or not, (2) is the owner, lessee, or occupant of a building or portion thereof used exclusively for club purposes at all times, (3) is operated solely for a recreational, fraternal, social, patriotic, political, benevolent, or athletic purpose, but not for pecuniary gain, and (4) only sells alcoholic beverages incidental to its operation. For purposes of this definition, "private club" means an organization that is managed by a board of directors, executive committee, or similar body chosen by the members at an annual meeting, has established bylaws, a constitution, or both, to govern its activities, and has been granted an exemption from the payment of federal income tax as a club under 26 U.S.C. 501. 
Private residence means the part of a structure used as a dwelling, including, without limitation, a private home, townhouse, condominium, apartment, mobile home, vacation home, cabin, or cottage. For the purposes of this definition, a hotel, motel, inn, resort, lodge, bed and breakfast or other similar public accommodation, hospital, nursing home, or assisted living facility shall not be considered a private residence. 
Public place means that portion of any building or vehicle used by and open to the public, regardless of whether the building or vehicle is owned in whole or in part by private persons or entities, the State of Illinois, or any other public entity and regardless of whether a fee is charged for admission, including a minimum distance of 15 feet from entrances, exits, windows that open, and ventilation intakes that serve an enclosed area where smoking is prohibited. A "public place" does not include a private residence unless the private residence is used to provide licensed child care, foster care, or other similar social service care on the premises. A "public place" includes, but is not limited to, hospitals, restaurants, retail stores, offices, commercial establishments, elevators, indoor theaters, libraries, museums, concert halls, public conveyances, educational facilities, nursing homes, auditoriums, enclosed or partially enclosed sports arenas, meeting rooms, schools, exhibition halls, convention facilities, polling places, private clubs, gaming facilities, all government owned vehicles and facilities, including buildings and vehicles owned, leased, or operated by the State or State subcontract, healthcare facilities or clinics, enclosed shopping centers, retail service establishments, financial institutions, educational facilities, ticket areas, public hearing facilities, public restrooms, waiting areas, lobbies, bars, taverns, bowling alleys, skating rinks, reception areas, and no less than 75% of the sleeping quarters within a hotel, motel, resort, inn, lodge, bed and breakfast, or other similar public accommodation that are rented to guests, but excludes private residences. 
Restaurant means (i) an eating establishment, including, but not limited to, coffee shops, cafeterias, sandwich stands, and private and public school cafeterias, that gives or offers for sale food to the public, guests, or employees, and (ii) a kitchen or catering facility in which food is prepared on the premises for serving elsewhere. "Restaurant" includes a bar area within the restaurant. 
Retail tobacco store means a retail establishment that derives more than 80% of its gross revenue from the sale of loose tobacco, plants, or herbs and cigars, cigarettes, electronic cigarettes, e-liquid, pipes, and other smoking devices for burning tobacco and related smoking accessories and in which the sale of other products is merely incidental. "Retail tobacco store" does not include a tobacco department or section of a larger commercial establishment or any establishment with any type of liquor, food, or restaurant license. 
Smoke or smoking means the carrying, smoking, burning, inhaling, or exhaling of any kind of lighted pipe, cigar, cigarette, electronic cigarette, e-liquid, hookah, weed, herbs, or any other lighted smoking equipment. 
(Ord. No. 08-2-C-3595, § 1, 1-4-2008; Ord. No. 15-4-C-4136, § 2, 4-20-2015) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 54-62. - Smoking in public places, places of employment, and governmental vehicles prohibited. 
No person shall smoke in a public place or in any place of employment or within 15 feet of any entrance to a public place or place of employment. No person may smoke in any vehicle owned, leased, or operated by the State or a political subdivision of the State. Smoking is prohibited in indoor public places and workplaces unless specifically exempted by Section 54-66 of this Article. 
(Ord. No. 08-2-C-3595, § 1, 1-4-2008)  
Sec. 54-63. - Posting of signs; removal of ashtrays. 
(a)  "No Smoking" signs or the international "No Smoking" symbol, consisting of a pictorial representation of a burning cigarette enclosed in a red circle with a red bar across it, shall be clearly and conspicuously posted in each public place and place of employment where smoking is prohibited by this Act by the owner, operator, manager, or other person in control of that place. 
(b)  Each public place and place of employment where smoking is prohibited by this Act shall have posted at every entrance a conspicuous sign clearly stating that smoking is prohibited. 
(c)  All ashtrays shall be removed from any area where smoking is prohibited by this Act by the owner, operator, manager, or other person having control of the area. 
(Ord. No. 08-2-C-3595, § 1, 1-4-2008)  
Sec. 54-64. - Smoking prohibited in student dormitories. 
Notwithstanding any other provision of this Act, smoking is prohibited in any portion of the living quarters, including, but not limited to, sleeping rooms, dining areas, restrooms, laundry areas, lobbies, and hallways, of a building used in whole or in part as a student dormitory that is owned and operated or otherwise utilized by a public or private institution of higher education. 
(Ord. No. 08-2-C-3595, § 1, 1-4-2008)  
Sec. 54-65. - Designation of other nonsmoking areas. 
Any employer, owner, occupant, lessee, operator, manager, or other person in control of any public place or place of employment may designate a non-enclosed area of a public place or place of employment, including outdoor areas, as an area where smoking is also prohibited provided that such employer, owner, lessee or occupant shall conspicuously post signs prohibiting smoking in the manner described in subsections (a) and (b) of Section 54-63 of this Article. 
(Ord. No. 08-2-C-3595, § 1, 1-4-2008)  
Sec. 54-66. - Exemptions. 
Smoking is not prohibited in the following areas: 
(1)  Private residence, except when used as a home-based business open to the public. 
(2)  A retail tobacco store that legally allowed smoking prior to March 1, 2011. Any retail tobacco store that begins operations subsequent to February 28, 2011, shall not permit smoking on its premises. Any retail tobacco store that commenced operations prior to March 1, 2011, and did not allow smoking on its premises, shall not allow smoking on its premises. A retail tobacco store that allows smoking is required to annually file with the Illinois Department of Public Health by January 31st an affidavit stating the percentage of its gross income during the prior calendar year that was derived from the sale of loose tobacco, plants, or herbs and cigars, cigarettes, pipes, or other smoking devices for smoking tobacco and related smoking accessories. A copy of such affidavit shall be filed on the same date with the Village of Skokie Department of Public Health. 
(3)  Private and semi-private rooms in nursing homes and long-term care facilities that are occupied by one or more persons, all of whom are smokers and have requested in writing to be placed or to remain in a room where smoking is permitted and the smoke shall not infiltrate other areas of the nursing home. 
(4)  Hotel and motel sleeping rooms that are rented to guests and are designated as smoking rooms, provided that all smoking rooms on the same floor must be contiguous and smoke from these rooms must not infiltrate into nonsmoking rooms or other areas where smoking is prohibited. Not more than 25% of the rooms rented to guests in a hotel or motel may be designated as rooms where smoking is allowed. The status of rooms as smoking or nonsmoking may not be changed, except to permanently add additional nonsmoking rooms. 
(Ord. No. 08-2-C-3595, § 1, 1-4-2008; Ord. No. 11-3-C-3825, § 1, 3-7-2011)  
Sec. 54-67. - Violations. 
(a)  A person, corporation, partnership, association or other entity who violates Section 54-62 of this Article shall be fined. Each day that a violation occurs is a separate violation. 
(b)  A person who smokes in an area where smoking is prohibited under Section 54-62 of this Article shall be fined in an amount that is not less than $100 and not more than $250. A person who owns, operates, or otherwise controls a public place or place of employment that violates Section 62 of this Article shall be fined (i) not less than $250 for the first violation, (ii) not less than $500 for the second violation within one year after the first violation, and (iii) not less than $2,500 for each additional violation within one year after the first violation. 
(c)  A fine imposed under this Section shall be allocated as follows: 
(1)  One-half of the fine shall be distributed to the Illinois Department of Public Health; and 
(2)  One-half of the fine shall be distributed to the Village of Skokie. 
(Ord. No. 08-2-C-3595, § 1, 1-4-2008)  
Sec. 54-68. - Injunctions. 
The Village may institute, in a circuit court, an action to enjoin violations of this Article. 
(Ord. No. 08-2-C-3595, § 1, 1-4-2008)  
Sec. 54-69. - Discrimination prohibited. 
No individual may be discriminated against in any manner because of the exercise of any rights afforded by this Article. 
(Ord. No. 08-2-C-3595, § 1, 1-4-2008)  
Sec. 54-70. - Severability. 
If any provision, clause or paragraph of this Article shall be held invalid by a court of competent jurisdiction, such validity shall not affect the other provisions of this Article. 
(Ord. No. 08-2-C-3595, § 1, 1-4-2008)  
Sec. 54-71. - Entrances, exits, windows, and ventilation intakes. 
Smoking is prohibited within a minimum distance of 15 feet from entrances, exits, windows that open, and ventilation intakes that serve an enclosed area where smoking is prohibited under this Article. 
(Ord. No. 08-2-C-3595, § 1, 1-4-2008)  
Secs. 54-72—54-90. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IV. - COMMUNICABLE DISEASES[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference— Communicable Disease Prevention Act, 410 ILCS 315/0.01 et seq.; Communicable Disease Report Act, 745 ILCS 45/0.01 et seq. 
 
Sec. 54-91. - Report required. 
Every person, including physicians, having knowledge of a known or suspected case or carrier of communicable disease or communicable disease death shall report such occurrences to the Department of Public Health as required by statute. 
(Code 1979, § 11.101)  
Sec. 54-92. - Quarantine (Reserved). 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 09-10-C-3711, § 1, adopted Oct. 19, 2009, deleted § 54-92. Former § 54-92 pertained to quarantine and derived from Code 1979, § 11.92.  
Sec. 54-93. - Investigate to Protect Public Health. 
The Department shall investigate the causes of dangerously contagious or infectious diseases, especially when existing in epidemic form, and take means to restrict and suppress the same. Whenever such disease becomes, or threatens to become epidemic, the Department may enforce such measures as it deems necessary to protect the public health. 
(Ord. No. 09-10-C-3711, § 1, 10-19-2009)  
Sec. 54-94. - Powers and Authority to Quarantine or Isolate. 
(a)  To prevent the probable spread of a dangerously contagious or infectious disease, including, but not limited to, non-compliant tuberculosis patients, the Department may order a person or group of persons to be quarantined or isolated, or a place to be closed and made off limits to the public, until such time as the condition can be corrected or the danger to the public health eliminated or reduced in such a manner that no substantial danger to the public's health any longer exists. Orders for isolation of a person or quarantine of a place to prevent the probable spread of a sexually transmissible disease shall be governed by the provisions of Section 7 of the Illinois Sexually Transmissible Disease Control Act. 
(b)  Except when immediate action is required pursuant to Section 54-96, below, no person or a group of persons may be ordered to be quarantined or isolated and no place may be ordered closed and made off limits to the public unless the person or owner of the place consents to the order. In the event emergency action is not being taken pursuant to Section 54-96 and the person or owner of the place does not consent to the aforementioned order, then the Department must obtain a court order prior to the taking the appropriate action to quarantine or isolate the person or closing a place and making it off limits to the public. 
(Ord. No. 09-10-C-3711, § 1, 10-19-2009)  
Sec. 54-95. - Other Powers. 
(a)  The Department shall have the following powers and authority. In order to prevent the probable spread of a dangerously contagious or infectious disease, the Department may order: 
(1)  physical examinations and tests and collect laboratory specimens as necessary for the diagnosis or treatment of individuals. Physical examinations, tests, or collection of laboratory specimens must not be such as are reasonably likely to lead to serious harm to the affected individual; 
(2)  the administration of vaccines, medications, or other treatments to persons as necessary. A vaccine, medication, or other treatment to be administered must not be such as is reasonably likely to lead to serious harm to the affected individual; and 
(3)  observation and monitoring of persons. 
(b)  Except when immediate action is required pursuant to Section 54-96, below, no person shall be ordered to be (i) subjected to physical examinations, tests and the collection of laboratory specimens, (ii) administered vaccines, medications, or other treatments, or (iii) placed under observation and monitoring unless that person consents to the order. In the event emergency action is not being taken pursuant to Section 54-96 and the person does not consent to the aforementioned order, then the Department must obtain a court order prior to the taking the appropriate action to quarantine or isolate the person or closing a place and making it off limits to the public. 
(Ord. No. 09-10-C-3711, § 1, 10-19-2009)  
Sec. 54-96. - Emergency Actions. 
(a)  The Department may order a person or a group of persons to be quarantined or isolated or may order a place to be closed and made off limits to the public on an immediate basis without prior consent or court order if, in the reasonable judgment of the Director of the Department, immediate action is required to protect the public from a dangerously contagious or infectious disease. In the event of an immediate order issued without prior consent or court order, the Department shall, as soon as practical, within 48 hours after issuing the order, obtain the consent of the person, or owner, or file a petition requesting a court order authorizing the isolation or quarantine or closure. When exigent circumstances exist that cause the court system to be unavailable or that make it impossible to obtain consent or file a petition within 48 hours after issuance of an immediate order, the Department must obtain consent or file a petition requesting a court order as soon as reasonably possible. 
(b)  To obtain a court order, the Department must prove that: 
(1)  the public's health and welfare are significantly endangered by: (A) a person or group of persons that (i) has, (ii) is suspected of having, (iii) has been exposed to, or (iv) is reasonably believed to have been exposed to, a dangerously contagious or infectious disease including, but not limited to, non-compliant tuberculosis patients; or (B) a place where there is a significant amount of activity likely to spread a dangerously contagious or infectious disease. 
(2)  All other reasonable means of correcting the problem have been exhausted and no less restrictive alternative exists. For purposes of determining whether no less restrictive alternative exists, the court shall consider evidence showing that quarantine or isolation is the measure provided for in a rule of the Department or in guidelines issued by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention or the World Health Organization. 
(c)  Persons who are or are about to be ordered to be isolated or quarantined and owners of places that are or are about to be closed and made off limits to the public shall have the right to counsel. 
(d)  Persons who are ordered to be isolated or quarantined or who are owners of places that are ordered to be closed and made off limits to the public, shall be given a written notice of such order. The written notice shall additionally include the following: (1) notice of the right to counsel; (2) notice of the reason for the order for isolation, quarantine, or closure; (3) notice of whether the order is an immediate order, and if so, the time frame for the Department to seek consent or to file a petition requesting a court order as set out in this subsection; and (4) notice of the anticipated duration of the isolation, quarantine, or closure. 
(Ord. No. 09-10-C-3711, § 1, 10-19-2009)  
Sec. 54-97. - Isolation and Quarantine for Refusing Appropriate Order. 
To prevent the spread of a dangerously contagious or infectious disease, the Department may order the isolation or quarantine of any person whose refusal to submit to any of the orders authorized in Section 54-95(a)(1), (2) and (3) (hereinafter "Appropriate Order"), if the refusal and the circumstances result in uncertainty regarding whether the person has been exposed to or is infected with a dangerously contagious or infectious disease or otherwise poses a danger to the public's health. A person that refuses to consent to any Appropriate Order shall be given a written notice that shall include the following: (i) that the person may refuse to consent to the actions required by the Appropriate Order, however, the refusal to consent may result in uncertainty regarding whether the person has been exposed to or is infected with a dangerously contagious or infectious disease or otherwise poses a danger to public health and that the person may be subjected to isolation or quarantine pursuant to the requirements of Section 54-96; or (ii) that if the person consents to the actions required by the Appropriate Order, the results of the actions required by the Appropriate Order may subject the person to isolation or quarantine pursuant to the provisions of Section 54-96. 
(Ord. No. 09-10-C-3711, § 1, 10-19-2009)  
Sec. 54.98. - Compliance with State Regulations. Adoption of Village Regulations. 
The Department shall comply with TITLE 77, PUBLIC HEALTH CHAPTER I, DEPARTMENT OF PUBLIC HEALTH SUBCHAPTER k: COMMUNICABLE DISEASE CONTROL AND IMMUNIZATIONS, PART 690: CONTROL OF COMMUNICABLE DISEASES CODE, SUBPART H: ISOLATION, QUARANTINE, AND CLOSURE. 
The Director is authorized to develop rules and regulations for the implementation of the powers and authority granted in this Article. 
(Ord. No. 09-10-C-3711, § 1, 10-19-2009)  
Sec. 54-99. - Destruction of Animals and Property. 
To prevent the spread of a dangerously contagious or infectious disease among humans, the Department may examine, test, disinfect, seize, or destroy animals or other related property believed to be sources of infection. An owner of such animal or other related property shall be given written notice regarding such examination, testing, disinfection, seizure, or destruction. The owner or the Department shall immediately destroy the animals by "humane euthanasia" as that term is defined in Section 2.09 of the Humane Care for Animals Act. Dogs and cats, however, shall be euthanized pursuant to the provisions of the Humane Euthanasia in Animal Shelters Act. The owner or the Department shall additionally, dispose of the carcasses, and disinfect, change, or destroy the premises occupied by the animals, in accordance with rules prescribed by the Department governing such destruction and disinfection. Upon his or her failure so to do or to cooperate with the Department, the Department shall cause the animals or related property to be destroyed and disposed of in the same manner. 
(Ord. No. 09-10-C-3711, § 1, 10-19-2009)  
Sec. 54-100. - Emergency Access to Medical and health Records. 
(a)  Pursuant to State law, to prevent the spread of a dangerously contagious or infectious disease, the Department shall have the right emergency access to medical or health information or records or data of any person, upon the condition that the Department shall protect the privacy and confidentiality of any medical or health information or records or data obtained pursuant to this Section in accordance with federal and State law. 
(b)  Any medical or health information or records or data obtained pursuant to paragraph (a) of this Section shall be exempt from inspection and copying under the Freedom of Information Act. 
(c)  Other than a hearing for the purpose of Sections 54-94 or 54-95, any information, records, reports, statements, notes, memoranda, or other data obtained pursuant to paragraph (a) of this Section in the possession of the Department shall not be admissible as evidence, nor discoverable in any action of any kind in any court or before any tribunal, board, agency, or person. 
(d)  The access to or disclosure of any information or data obtained pursuant to paragraph (a) of this Section by the Department, a local board of health, or a local public authority shall not waive or have any effect upon its non-discoverability or non-admissibility. 
(e)  Pursuant to State law: (i) any person, facility, institution, or agency that provides emergency access to health information and data pursuant to this Section shall have immunity from any civil or criminal liability, or any other type of liability that might otherwise result by reason of these actions except in the event of willful and wanton misconduct; and (ii) the privileged quality of communication between any professional person or any facility shall not constitute grounds for failure to provide emergency access. 
(f)  Nothing in this section shall prohibit the sharing of information or data obtained with the Illinois Department of Public Health and other local public health authorities. 
(Ord. No. 09-10-C-3711, § 1, 10-19-2009)  
Secs. 54-101—54-110. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE V. - SCHOOLS[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
State Law reference— School building code, 105 ILCS 5/2-3.12. 
 
Sec. 54-111. - Jurisdiction of Department of Public Health; report of conditions dangerous to health. 
(a)  The Department of Public Health of the Village shall have jurisdiction in all matters pertaining to the preservation of the health of those in attendance at the public and private schools in the Village. 
(b)  With the approval of the Village Manager or designee, written notification of any findings that the health or well-being of those in attendance at any school may be impaired or endangered, shall be made to the superintendent of the respective Board of Education and to the principal of the school. The written notification shall include instructions to correct or remedy the condition or conditions found that would endanger or impair the health or physical well-being of those in attendance. 
(Code 1979, § 11.05)  
Secs. 54-112—54-130. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VI. - DAY CARE CENTERS[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
Cross reference— Businesses, ch. 26; zoning, ch. 118. 
State Law reference— Child Care Act, 225 ILCS 10/1 et seq. 
 
Sec. 54-131. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Day care center means any child care facility receiving 5 or more children for care during part or all of a day, between the hours of 6:00 a.m. and 9:00 p.m. The term "day care center" includes facilities commonly called child care centers, play schools, day nurseries, nursery schools, kindergartens, play groups, and centers for mentally retarded, with or without stated educational purposes, but does not include: 
(1)  Bona fide kindergartens or nursery schools operating under the auspices of established public or private boards of education. 
(2)  Bona fide kindergartens or nursery schools approved by the Superintendent of Public Instruction of the State or the school districts in which such kindergartens or nursery schools are located. 
(3)  Those facilities operated in connection with a shopping center or shopping service where transient children are received while parents are shopping on the premises. 
(Code 1979, § 11.06-2) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 54-132. - Jurisdiction of Health Department. 
The Health Department for the Village shall have jurisdiction in matters pertaining to the health of children who are placed or kept in a day care center, to assure proper compliance with all applicable state and local statutes, codes, ordinances and rules and regulations, including but not limited to those rules and licensing schemes promulgated by the State Department of Children and Family Services. 
(Code 1979, § 11.06-1)  
Secs. 54-133—54-160. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VII. - DAY CARE HOMES[7] 
Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
Cross reference— Businesses, ch. 26; business license fees, § 46-71 et seq.; zoning, ch. 118. 
State Law reference— Child Care Act, 225 ILCS 10/1 et seq. 
 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 54-161. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Caregiver means the person directly responsible for child care. 
Child means any person under 18 years of age. 
Day care home means a family home which receives more than 3 up to a maximum of 8 children for less than 24 hours per day. The maximum of 8 children includes the family's birth or adopted children and all other persons under the age of 12. 
Department means the Public Health Department of the Village. 
Inspection means the review of a day care home to determine compliance with the Child Care Act of 1969, 225 ILCS 10/1 et seq., and the standards prescribed by the Village. The review shall consist of on-site visits, interviews and the collection and review of supporting documents. 
State license means a document issued by the Department of Children and Family Services which authorizes child care facilities to operate in accordance with applicable standards and the provisions of the Child Care Act of 1969, 225 ILCS 10/1 et seq. 
Supervising agency means the Village Public Health Department. 
Village license means a document issued by the Village which authorizes child care facilities to operate in accordance with applicable standards and the provisions of the Child Care Act of 1969, 225 ILCS 10/1 et seq., the State Department of Child and Family Services' Licensing Standards for Day Care Homes, the Life Safety Code, and any amendments prescribed to these standards and provisions. 
(Code 1979, § 18.03) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 54-162. - Violations declared nuisance. 
The operation or maintenance of a day care home in violation of this article is declared a public nuisance as that term is defined in Section 42-32. The Village Manager may, in addition to other remedies provided for in Chapter 42, Article II, recommend that the Corporation Counsel seek injunctive relief. 
(Code 1979, § 18.07)  
Sec. 54-163. - Administration and enforcement. 
The Village Manager or designee shall administer this article and may promulgate rules and regulations to carry out its enforcement. 
(Code 1979, § 18.02) 
Cross reference— Administration, ch. 2.  
Sec. 54-164. - Inspections. 
In addition to the inspection set forth in Section 54-188, all day care homes shall be subject to inspections every 6 months conducted by a Health Department nurse and/or sanitarian and the Village Fire Department. It is not required that prior notice of these inspections be given to the licensee. 
(Code 1979, § 18.06)  
Sec. 54-165. - Adoption of State regulations. 
The Village hereby adopts by reference the Minimum Standards, Rules and Regulations for the Licensing of Day Care Homes prescribed and published by the State Department of Children and Family Services, pursuant to the Child Care Act of 1969, 225 ILCS 10/1 et seq., and all rules, regulations and amendments thereto. A violation of any of such standards, rules and regulations as adopted by this article shall be considered a violation of the provisions of this article, provided that: 
(1)  Any reference in the rules and regulations to "Department" shall read as meaning the Department of Public Health of the Village. 
(2)  Any reference in the rules and regulations to the "Director" shall mean the Director of the Department of Public Health of the Village. 
(3)  One copy of the minimum standards, rules and regulations adopted by reference shall be filed in the office of the Village Clerk and kept available for public use, inspection and examination. 
(4)  At least 1 copy of the minimum standards, rules and regulations of the National Fire Protection Association's Life Safety Code shall be kept on file in the office of the Village Clerk. 
(Code 1979, § 18.01)  
Sec. 54-166. - Standards for operation and premises. 
All provisions contained in the publications entitled "Licensing Standards for Day Care Homes," as published in the State Department of Children and Family Services, and the "Life Safety Code," as published by the National Fire Protection Association, including all requirements therein for the proper licensing and regulation of short term child care in residential districts within the Village, are hereby adopted as the licensing standards for day care homes in the Village, except for the following, which shall supersede provisions in "Licensing Standards for Day Care Homes" as published by the State Department of Children and Family Service: 
(1)  Residence of caregiver. The address of the day care home provided on the Village licensing application shall be the caregiver's primary residence. It shall be illegal for a caregiver to rent or purchase residential space strictly for the purpose of providing a day care home. 
(2)  Swimming pools. All in-ground or aboveground swimming pools will be subject to regulations set forth in Chapter 22, Article VIII. 
(3)  Portable wading pools. The use of portable wading pools shall be prohibited. 
(4)  Hot and cold water. Hot and cold water shall be provided through mixed valves at an appropriate pressure. 
(5)  Certification of health of household pets. Before a day care home is allowed to operate in the Village, a licensed veterinarian shall certify that all household pets are free of diseases that could endanger the children's health, and that dogs and cats have been inoculated for rabies. This certification shall occur annually. 
(6)  Notification of injuries from pets. The Village Health Department shall be notified immediately of any injuries to children from household pets. 
(7)  Care of sick children. Whenever a child becomes ill or is suspected of having a contagious disease, that child shall be removed immediately from the general vicinity of other children. Provisions shall be made for isolating the child in a separate room. The child's parent(s) shall be notified immediately of the apparent illness. The child shall remain in isolation until the parent(s) can remove the child from the day care home. 
(8)  Floors. When used for child care, basement floors, play areas, dining areas and restrooms shall have protective and easily cleanable surfaces, such as but not limited to tile, linoleum and low-ply carpeting. Painted concrete is not considered to be a safe and protective surface covering. 
(9)  Outdoor equipment. Whenever equipment and materials for outdoor use exist, the following standards shall be adhered to: 
a.  Equipment and materials for outdoor use shall be appropriate to the age and development needs of the children served. Such equipment and materials for infants, toddlers and preschool children shall be provided in appropriate quantity and variety. 
b.  Outdoor equipment shall be placed so as to avoid collisions and accidents while still permitting freedom of action by the children. 
c.  Supports for climbing apparatus and large equipment shall be securely fastened to the ground. 
d.  There shall be a soft, resilient surface or pad under all permanently affixed outdoor recreational equipment from which children may jump or fall. 
e.  Sandboxes shall be covered when not in use and shall be cleaned daily. 
f.  Outdoor storage shall be available for equipment not permanently secured to the ground, unless indoor storage space is available. 
g.  Provisions shall be made so that access to outdoor play areas shall be physically restricted via a temporary enclosure or permanent fence to safely protect children from traffic and other hazards. 
(10)  Non-child-care activities. Operation of another business or any other activities on the premises must not interfere with the care or safety of children. 
(11)  Submission of court records; annual criminal records check. All court records referred to in the State Department of Children and Family Services' Licensing Standards for Day Care Homes shall be submitted to the Department for consideration prior to licensing approval. The Department, in conjunction with the Village Police Department, shall conduct an annual criminal record check of all day care home operators, family members, staff members, new employees and volunteers and report their findings to the Village Manager. If the Village Manager or designee finds that an individual should not be allowed in the day care home as an operator/owner, family member, employee or volunteer, the Village Manager or designee shall notify the applicant of this fact. 
(12)  Hours of operation; maximum time of care. Children served in a day care home shall not remain on the premises for more than 12 hours in a 24-hour period. The hours of operation for a day care home within the Village will be between 6:00 a.m. and 8:00 p.m. 
(13)  Screening of children for illness. The caregiver shall conduct a daily, pre-admissions screening to determine if the child has obvious symptoms of illness. If symptoms of illness are present, the caregiver shall determine whether to provide care for the child, depending upon the apparent degree of illness, other children present, and facilities available to provide care for the ill child. Whenever children are admitted into the day care home with a communicable illness or whenever a child develops a communicable illness while under the care of a day care home operator, the caregiver shall immediately notify the Department of all communicable illnesses present, as required in the State Rules and Regulations for the Control of Communicable Diseases. 
(14)  Storage of medication. All medication shall be stored in a locked cabinet or container. The storage area shall be well-lighted and inaccessible to children. 
(15)  Record of incidents or accidents. A complete written record will be maintained of any and all serious incidents or accidents involving a child or a group of children. This record shall include the date and time of the incident or accident and the action taken concerning the incident/accident. These incidents or accidents include all situations requiring the emergency and non-emergency medical services of a physician, a hospital, the Police Department and/or the Fire Department. The Village Health Department will be notified by telephone of all such incidents or accidents within 24 hours of their occurrence. In addition, a written copy of the record shall be sent to the Health Department within 7 days. 
(16)  Handwashing supplies; drinking cups. Each child shall be provided with an individually labeled towel, washcloth and drinking cup. Single-use disposable articles are acceptable. Provisions shall also be made for providing liquid dispensed soap, powdered soap or properly drained bar soap for appropriate handwashing by all children, caregivers, assistants and family members. 
(17)  Appropriate and safe design required. The materials and equipment and their arrangement and use must be appropriate to the development needs and of safe design for the children in care. 
(18)  Cleaning of materials and toys. Materials and toys shall be cleaned and sanitized as needed with a germicidal solution. Materials and toys shall also be kept orderly, attractive and accessible to children. 
(19)  Smoking disclosure. It shall be the duty and responsibility of the licensee to disclose to the parent or guardian of the child being cared for whether any caregiver or other individual in the home smokes during the hours of operation. 
(20)  Construction requirements. Each building used as a family day care home must meet the requirements of the BOCA/National Existing Structures Code, as adopted by the Village. 
Cross reference— Existing structures code, § 22-181 et seq. 
(21)  Maximum occupancy. The occupant load shall be a minimum of 100 square feet per occupant. 
(22)  Exits. 
a.  Every room used for sleeping, living, or dining purposes shall have at least 2 means of egress, at least 1 of which shall be a door or stairway providing a means of unobstructed travel to the outside of the building at street or ground level. The second means of egress may be a window approved by the Village Manager or designee which can be opened from the inside by the caregiver or a member of the staff. No room or space shall be occupied for living or sleeping purposes which is accessible only by a ladder, by folding stairs, or through a trap door. 
b.  Where clients are located on a floor (basement) below the level of exit discharge, at least 1 means of egress shall be an exit discharging directly to the outside, and the vertical travel to ground level shall not exceed 8 feet. The second means of egress may be a window approved by the Village Manager or designee which can be opened from the inside by the caregiver or a member of the staff. No facility shall be located more than 1 story below the ground. 
c.  Travel distance to exits shall be no greater than 150 feet. 
d.  All exitways shall be lighted by normal sources. 
(23)  Stairs. Every stairway shall comply with the minimum requirements for stairs, which are 8-inch risers, 9-inch treads and 32-inch stair width. All stairs shall be maintained free of items of storage. 
(24)  Width of doors. Each exit door shall be a minimum of 32 inches wide. 
(25)  Closet latches. Every closet door latch shall be such that children can open the door from inside the closet. 
(26)  Bathroom doors. Every bathroom door lock shall be designed to permit the opening of the locked door from the outside in an emergency. The opening device shall be readily accessible to the caregiver or a member of the staff. 
(27)  Interior finishes. The interior finish of all occupied spaces in the home shall be a minimum of Class C (76/200 flame spread rated). The Village Manager or designee shall have the authority to approve interior finishes. 
(28)  Electrical wiring. Electrical wiring shall meet the electrical code of the Village as contained in Chapter 22, Article IV. The Village Manager or designee shall have the authority to classify existing electrical services as complying with all applicable electrical codes. 
(29)  Heating equipment. Unvented fuel-fired room heaters shall not be permitted. Vented fuel-fired heaters or oil- or gas-fired room heaters shall be installed in accordance with the BOCA Mechanical Code, current edition, as adopted by the Village. A guard shall be provided to protect the children from hot surfaces and open flames. 
(Code 1979, § 18.05) 
Cross reference— Mechanical code, § 22-121 et seq.  
Secs. 54-167—54-180. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE 
 
Sec. 54-181. - Required. 
No person may establish, operate, maintain, offer or advertise a day care home within the Village without first obtaining a license in accordance with the provisions of this division. 
(Code 1979, § 18.04)  
Sec. 54-182. - Exemptions. 
A family home in which care is given to children from a single household or to relatives shall be exempt from the licensing requirements of this article. A family home which is licensed as a "foster family home" as defined in the Child Care Act of 1969, 225 ILCS 10/1 et seq. 
(Code 1979, § 18.047)  
Sec. 54-183. - Application information. 
Applications for licenses under this division shall be made to the Village Manager or designee on forms prescribed and furnished by the Village Manager or designee. The Village Manager or designee may request additional information from the applicant. 
(Code 1979, § 18.04)  
Sec. 54-184. - Compliance with zoning regulations. 
An applicant for a license under this division must comply with all applicable provisions of the Zoning Ordinance (Chapter 118). 
(Code 1979, § 18.04)  
Sec. 54-185. - State certification required. 
Each applicant for a day care home license shall provide evidence of compliance with the State Department of Public Health certification requirements.  
Sec. 54-186. - Action on application. 
All licenses required by this division shall be acted upon within 30 days of the Village Manager's or designee's receipt of such application. 
(Code 1979, § 18.045)  
Sec. 54-187. - Review of application. 
Upon receipt of an application for a license under this division, the Village Manager or designee shall review and investigate the information contained therein. Such review may include an investigation of the applicant.  
Sec. 54-188. - Inspection of facilities. 
After receipt and upon review of an application for a license under this division, the Village Manager or designee shall cause inspections to be made of the applicant's facilities. The Village Manager or designee shall, upon consideration of the application and reports of the inspecting departments, approve or reject the application. 
(Code 1979, § 18.043)  
Sec. 54-189. - Display. 
Any license issued in accordance with the provisions of this division shall be prominently displayed at the location for which the license has been issued.  
Sec. 54-190. - Contents; term. 
Any license issued under this division shall state the date the license was issued and the expiration date. Such licenses shall be issued for a period of 1 year. 
(Code 1979, § 18.044)  
Sec. 54-191. - Renewal. 
At least 90 days but not more than 120 days prior to the expiration of a license issued under this division, the licensee shall submit an application for renewal. 
(Code 1979, § 18.042)  
Sec. 54-192. - Suspension or revocation. 
(a)  The Village Manager shall have the authority to revoke or suspend all licenses issued under this division. In addition to the provisions contained in this article, the Village Manager shall have the authority to establish rules and regulations for the conduct of a hearing relating to the revocation or suspension of a license. 
(b)  The Village Manager is hereby given the authority to revoke or suspend the license if the Village Manager finds: 
(1)  The licensee has not complied with applicable codes, ordinances, statutes, laws, policies or rules and regulations. 
(2)  The licensee has made fraudulent, false or misrepresentative statements in the application for the license. 
(3)  The licensee owes the Village required fees or outstanding fines or penalties. 
(Code 1979, § 18.046)  
Sec. 54-193. - Contents and service of notices. 
(a)  Contents. All notices required to be given in accordance with this division shall be in writing, setting forth the reasons for the denial or revocation of the license. The notice shall inform the applicant or licensee that the applicant or licensee has the right to request a hearing before the Village Manager. 
(b)  Service. All notices shall be sent by certified mail, return receipt requested, to the applicant or licensee specified on the application or license. Notice shall be considered given on the date such notice is mailed.  
Sec. 54-194. - Hearings. 
The Village Manager or designee shall send notice of intent to revoke a license issued under this division. A license shall not be revoked unless the licensee has had an opportunity to present evidence in the licensee's behalf. The Village Manager or designee shall, within 5 business days of the hearing, issue a written order of the findings. Such written order shall be sent to the licensee in accordance with the notice provisions of Section 54-193. If, within 10 days of the notice, the licensee does not request a hearing in writing, the license shall be revoked.  
Sec. 54-195. - Fee. 
Fees for licenses under this division shall be as set forth in Section 46-73. 
(Code 1979, § 18.041)  
Sec. 54-196. - Transfer. 
No license issued or granted under this division shall be assigned or transferred to any other person or corporation other than to the person to whom such license was issued. No individual or corporation other than the licensee shall act or do business under such license. 
(Code 1979, § 18.044)  
Secs. 54-197—54-220. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VIII. - LONGTERM CARE FACILITIES[8] 
Footnotes: 
--- (8) --- 
Cross reference— Businesses, ch. 26; business license fees, § 46-71 et seq.; zoning, ch. 118. 
State Law reference— Nursing Home Care Act, 210 ILCS 45/1-101 et seq.; Long-Term Care Peer Review and Quality Assessment and Assurance Protection Act, 745 ILCS 55/1 et seq. 
 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 54-221. - Purpose of article. 
It is the purpose of this article and the policy of the Village to establish standards for the licensing and regulation of all intermediate care and skilled nursing care facilities within the Village and to require compliance with at least the minimum requirements of the Nursing Home Care Act of 1979, 210 ILCS 45/1-101 et seq., including the rules and regulations promulgated thereunder. 
(Code 1979, § 16.01)  
Sec. 54-222. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Administrator means a person who is charged with the general administration and supervision of a facility and licensed under the Nursing Home Administrators Licensing and Disciplinary Act, 225 ILCS 70/1 et seq. 
Applicant means any person making application for a license under this article. 
Department means the Public Health Department of the Village. 
Director means the Director of the Village Public Health Department. 
Facility means longterm care facility. 
Fire Chief means the Fire Chief of the Village Fire Department. 
Longterm care facility. 
(1)  The term "longterm care facility" means a private home, institution, building, residence, or any other place, whether operated for profit or not, which provides personal care and/or skilled nursing care on a 24-hour basis for 3 or more persons who, because of physical or mental incapacity, may be unable to provide for their own needs and safety without the assistance of another person. The term "longterm care facility," wherever used in this article, shall include only skilled nursing facilities and intermediate care facilities, those terms being defined as follows: 
a.  Intermediate care facility means a longterm care facility which provides basic nursing care and other restorative services under periodic medical direction. Such facilities are primarily for residents who have longterm illnesses or disabilities which may have reached a relatively stable plateau. 
b.  Skilled nursing facility means a longterm care facility which provides skilled nursing care, continuous skilled nursing observations, restorative nursing, and other services under professional direction with frequent medical supervision. Such facilities are primarily provided for patients who need the type of care and treatment required during the post-acute phase of illness or during reoccurrences of symptoms in longterm illness. 
(2)  This article does not apply to the following types of facilities: 
a.  Intermediate care facilities for the developmentally disabled, as defined in the Minimum Standards for the Licensing of Long-Term Care Facilities, 1980, 210 ILCS 45/1-101 et seq. 
b.  Community living facilities, as defined in the Minimum Standards for Community Living Facilities, 1982, 210 ILCS 35/1 et seq. 
Manager means the Village Manager. 
Neglect means a failure of a facility to provide adequate medical or personal care or maintenance, which failure may result in physical or mental injury to a resident or in the deterioration of a resident's physical or mental condition. 
Nurse means a registered nurse or licensed practical nurse, as defined in the Nursing Home Care Act, 210 ILCS 45/1-101 et seq. 
Owner means the individual, partnership, corporation, association, or other person who owns a facility. If a facility is operated by a person who leases the physical plant, which is owned by another person, the term "owner" means the person who operates the facility, except that, if the person who owns the physical plant is an affiliate of the person who operates the facility and has significant control over the day-to-day operations of the facility, the person who owns the physical plant shall incur jointly and severally with the owner all liabilities imposed on an owner under this article. 
Personal care means assistance with meals, dressing, movement, bathing, or other personal needs or maintenance, or general supervision and oversight of the physical and mental well-being of an individual who is incapable of maintaining a private, independent residence or who is incapable of managing their person, whether or not a guardian has been appointed for such individual. 
(Code 1979, § 16.04) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 54-223. - Violations declared nuisance. 
The operation or maintenance of a longterm care facility in violation of this article is declared a public nuisance as that term is defined in Section 42-32. The Manager may request, in addition to other remedies provided in Chapter 42, Article II, that the Corporation Counsel bring action for an injunction to enjoin the future operation or maintenance of any such longterm care facility. 
(Code 1979, § 16.09)  
Sec. 54-224. - Adoption of State regulations. 
(a)  The Village hereby adopts by reference the Minimum Standards, Rules and Regulations for the Licensing of Long-Term Care Facilities prescribed and published by the State Department of Public Health pursuant to the Nursing Home Care Act of 1979, 210 ILCS 45/1-101 et seq., and all rules, regulations and amendments thereto. A violation of any of such standards, rules and regulations as adopted by this article shall be considered a violation of the provisions of this article. 
(b)  Any reference in the minimum standards, rules and regulations adopted by reference in this section to the "Department" shall read as meaning the Department of Public Health of the Village. 
(c)  Any reference in the minimum standards, rules and regulations adopted by reference in this section to the "Director" shall mean the Director of the Department of Public Health of the Village. 
(d)  One copy of the minimum standards, rules and regulations adopted by reference in this section shall be filed in the office of the Village Clerk and kept available for public use, inspection and examination. 
(e)  At least 1 copy of the minimum standards, rules, and regulations adopted by reference in this section shall be kept on file in the Department of Public Health of the Village for public inspection. 
(Code 1979, § 16.02)  
Sec. 54-225. - Administration and enforcement. 
The Village Manager or designee shall administer this article and may promulgate rules and regulations to carry out its enforcement. 
(Code 1979, § 16.03) 
Cross reference— Administration, ch. 2.  
Sec. 54-226. - Inspections. 
Inspections of all longterm care facilities shall be made at least once every 60 days by a Department nurse and by a Sanitarian, either separately or concurrently. These inspections shall be conducted without prior notice to the longterm care facility. 
(Code 1979, § 16.07)  
Sec. 54-227. - Standards for operation and premises. 
(a)  Resident assessment and security. 
(1)  Within 5 days prior to or 72 hours after admittance to a longterm care facility, each resident shall be examined by a licensed physician. If, after examination of the resident and review of the resident's case history, the physician determines that 1 or more of the following conditions are present, the resident shall be referred to a certified psychiatrist or senior resident under the direction of a certified psychiatrist or a registered clinical psychologist for further evaluation: 
a.  Suffering from a mental deficiency diagnosed as moderate or mild or whose disability is attributable to mental retardation, autism, or other pathological conditions which generally originate before such individuals attain age 18, and which continue or can be expected to continue indefinitely and which constitute a substantial functioning handicap. 
b.  Suffering from mental illness diagnosed as psychosis or psychoneurosis which requires medical, surgical, or psychiatric management, excluding individuals suffering from senile dementia. 
c.  A history of aggressive, hostile, or homicidal behavior or a history of suicide attempts. 
d.  A history of or suffering from mental and/or physical illness or disorder related to or caused by chronic alcoholism or addiction to drugs. 
(2)  Upon completion of the examination, the physician shall fill out the resident assessment form provided by the Village, which shall become a part of the resident's permanent record. The form shall contain a diagnosis as well as any restrictions to be placed on the resident's movement and/or activities. 
(3)  All residents must use 1 entry/exit point in each facility except for emergencies. The entry/exit point must be monitored 24 hours each day by a staff member. The staff member must sign each resident in and out of the facility and must document the following information: 
a.  Resident's name. 
b.  Time of exiting the facility. 
c.  Destination. 
d.  Estimated time of return. 
e.  Actual time of return and who the resident was accompanied by. 
(4)  It is the responsibility of the staff to determine that any resident leaving the facility is in compliance with physicians' orders. If an alarm is present and activated at the entry/exit point a staff person is not required at the entry/exit point between the hours of 11:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. 
(b)  Review of resident care. Each longterm care facility shall establish a procedure for review of resident care based on the evaluation of a resident's immediate and longterm needs. Such review shall occur once every 6 months, or more frequently as needed. This procedure shall be the responsibility of a care review committee consisting of at least 1 supervisory nurse, 1 nurse's aide, 1 social worker and 1 activity worker. The resident's physician and/or psychiatrist shall also be included. In the absence of the resident's physician, a signed statement stating approval of the resident's care plan shall be included in the care review proceedings. Other persons shall be included where appropriate. The resident, when able, shall be encouraged to participate in the care review committee or, if not able, may be represented by a person of the resident's own choosing. 
(c)  Nursing care. The following personnel requirements shall apply in addition to the State personnel requirements under the Nursing Home Care Act of 1979, 210 ILCS 45/1-101 et seq.: 
(1)  In longterm care facilities, there shall be a full-time director of nurses licensed as a registered nurse in the State. The director of nurses shall be on duty a minimum of 40 hours per week. 
(2)  In facilities of 100 beds or more, there shall be an assistant director of nurses who shall be licensed as a registered nurse in the State. Either the assistant director or a supervising nurse, who shall also be a registered nurse and licensed in the State, shall be on duty on those days on which the director of nurses is not on duty. The assistant director of supervising nurses shall not be included in the staff/resident ratio calculations. 
(3)  In addition to the director of nurses and the assistant director of nurses, there shall be at least 1 registered nurse or licensed practical nurse in charge of each 8-hour shift who understands and speaks adequate English, regardless of the size of the longterm care facility. 
(4)  Within 6 months of August 15, 1983, and annually thereafter, each facility shall provide the nursing staff with a minimum of 18 continuing education units (CEU's) of formal restorative nursing training approved by the Department. Nurses receiving the training shall provide in-service training to all other nursing personnel. 
(5)  Medication shall not be given to any patient without the written order of the attending physician. All such medication shall be administered to the patient only by a physician, registered nurse, or licensed practical nurse who has successfully completed training in pharmacology and passed an examination approved by the Illinois Department of Public Health. 
(d)  Required services. 
(1)  All longterm care facilities shall provide the following services: 
a.  Food service. Every longterm care facility shall comply with Article IX of this chapter. 
b.  Social services. Every longterm care facility shall provide: 
1.  Referral to appropriate agencies where there are indicators that financial, psychiatric, rehabilitative, legal, or social service help will be needed that the longterm care facility cannot provide. 
2.  Assistance with the resident's adjustment to the longterm care facility and availability of continuing social services to residents of the facility, including the availability of contact with family members to keep them involved. 
3.  Assistance to staff and residents in discharge planning and its implementation. 
4.  Assistance in providing in-service training to longterm care facility staff directed toward understanding emotional problems and social problems of residents and assistance in solving these problems. 
5.  Assistance to staff and residents in using community resources. 
c.  Mental health services. All longterm care facilities with residents who have been discharged from psychiatric care within the last 3 years or with residents evidencing mental retardation or mental problems as determined by the resident's attending physician and/or psychiatrist shall meet the following staff requirements: 
1.  A psychiatrist licensed to practice in the State shall be under formal contract by the facility to provide psychiatric treatment as deemed necessary by the attending physician and/or the care review committee. 
2.  Social work shall be provided to individual residents defined in this subsection at the minimum rate of 30 minutes per week by a social worker who has either a master's in social work or a bachelor's degree from an undergraduate program accredited by the Council on Social Work Education. 
d.  Activity program. All longterm care facilities shall have an activity program directed by a full-time staff member who shall be qualified by training or experience to direct an activity program. Records of programming and patient participation shall be maintained and shall include program goals, attendance records and progress notes. The plan for activity programming shall incorporate community resources and shall include group activities to promote learning about interpersonal behavior. 
e.  Physical therapy. Each longterm care facility shall make available to its residents the services of a registered physical therapist currently licensed by the State and under formal contract to the longterm care facility, who shall, under physicians' orders, spend such time within the facility as such orders may require. 
f.  Occupational therapy/recreational therapy. All longterm care facilities shall make available the services of an occupational therapist who is registered by the American Occupational Therapy Association or a therapeutic recreation specialist who shall be under formal contract to or employed full-time by the longterm care facility. 
(2)  The determination as to which resident shall be taking part in any or all of the therapy programs provided for in subsection (d)(1) of this section shall be made by the care review committee, in consultation with the resident's physician and/or psychiatrist and therapists, each of whom shall: 
a.  Complete an evaluation of each resident within 30 days of admission to the facility. The evaluation shall include an assessment of communication skills, mobility and physical strength and coordination and shall include recommendations for care and treatment needed to maintain or restore maximum functioning in such areas. The evaluation shall be utilized by the care review committee in the review of resident care required in subsection (b) of this section. 
b.  Conduct bimonthly in-service programs designed to assist staff in carrying out restorative procedures. 
c.  Consult with the activity director as needed to plan activities which are supportive of restorative care needs. 
(e)  Records. All longterm care facilities shall maintain the following records: 
(1)  Admission records. A medical history and interim psychosocial history of each resident shall be compiled within 72 hours of admission to a longterm care facility and filed with each resident's chart. 
(2)  Active records. A complete medical file including both past medical history and current medical status shall be maintained for each resident. 
(f)  Additional standards. The following standards shall apply in addition to State standards for all longterm care facilities hereafter constructed or for existing structures which are hereafter converted to use as intermediate care or skilled nursing care facilities, and for all additions to existing facilities. The rate for air changes per hour shall be certified by a licensed HVAC contractor or a mechanical engineer at the longterm care facility's expense. 
(1)  All corridors shall be provided with 6 tempered fresh air changes per hour at a rate of 2 cubic feet per minute per square foot. 
(2)  Residents' living space shall meet the following standards: 
a.  There shall be 225 square feet of floor area per bed provided. This 225 square feet of living space shall include no less than 120 square feet of bed space per single bedroom, 100 square feet of bed space per multiple bedroom and 75 square feet of recreational and dining space per resident. 
b.  All longterm care facilities shall provide each resident with a functional closet or wardrobe with a floor area of no less than 4 square feet. This area is in addition to the requirements of subsection (f)(3)a of this section. 
(3)  There shall be 1 lavatory and 1 toilet for each bedroom. Except, when there are no more than 4 residents in 2 rooms which have such facilities directly accessible from each of the 2 rooms, 1 lavatory and toilet facility may be provided. 
(4)  There shall be 1 bathtub or shower for each 10 resident beds on each floor with direct access from the resident's room or common hallway. Where this results in more than 3 tubs or showers, they are to be placed in 2 separate rooms. Each such room shall contain a lavatory. Each resident's privacy shall be preserved. 
(5)  Pest control shall be provided by a certified pest control operator. 
(6)  All door alarms shall be the tamper/pilfer-proof type. Door alarms shall either require a control key to deactivate the alarm or a remote switch which cannot be easily reached from outside the building or functional area to deactivate the alarm. 
(Code 1979, § 16.06)  
Sec. 54-228. - Emergency medical care and transportation. 
It shall be the responsibility of each longterm care facility to provide or to have available emergency medical care, including transportation, for its residents. If the longterm care facility fails to provide such care and/or transportation and, as a result, the Village is requested to respond, there shall be a charge to the facility in accordance with Section 46-36, which shall be borne exclusively by said facility, for any of the following: 
(1)  Transportation to a hospital for any treatment which can be handled by basic life support ambulance. 
(2)  Transportation to a hospital of naturally deceased residents for the purpose of verifying death. 
(3)  In-house treatment of residents not requiring advanced life support. 
The Village Manager or designee shall have the authority to waive such charges upon ascertainment that the request for aid from the Village was due to unforeseen circumstances beyond the control of the longterm care facility. 
(Code 1979, § 16.08)  
Secs. 54-229—54-250. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE 
 
Sec. 54-251. - Required. 
No person may establish, operate, maintain, offer, or advertise a longterm care facility within the Village without first obtaining a license in accordance with the provisions of this division. The requirement of a valid municipal license does not preclude the requirement of a valid State license, as required by the Nursing Home Care Act of 1979, 210 ILCS 45/1-101 et seq. 
(Code 1979, § 16.051)  
Sec. 54-252. - Application information. 
(a)  Applications for licenses under this division shall be made to the Village Manager or designee on forms prescribed and furnished by the Village Manager or designee. The Village Manager or designee may request additional information from the applicant. 
(b)  The application shall contain the following: 
(1)  A copy of the annual financial statement given to the State Department of Public Aid/Public Health (either the long or short form). 
(2)  A permit as required by the Illinois Health Facilities Planning Act, 20 ILCS 3960/1 et seq. 
(3)  In the case of new construction or the conversion of existing structures, preliminary plans and specifications for the proposed facility. 
(Code 1979, § 16.052(a))  
Sec. 54-253. - Statement of ownership. 
Before a license can be issued or renewed, the applicant shall provide the Village Manager or designee with a statement of ownership, which shall be public information, on forms prescribed and furnished by the Village Manager or designee. The Village Manager or designee may request additional information from the applicant. 
(Code 1979, § 16.052(d))  
Sec. 54-254. - State certification required. 
Each applicant for a license for a longterm care facility shall provide evidence of compliance with the State Department of Public Health certification requirements.  
Sec. 54-255. - Action on application. 
All licenses required by this division shall be acted upon within 30 days of the Village Manager's or designee's receipt of such application.  
Sec. 54-256. - Review of application. 
Upon receipt of an application for a license under this division, the Village Manager or designee shall review and investigate the information contained therein. Such review may include an investigation of the applicant.  
Sec. 54-257. - Inspection of facilities. 
After receipt and review of an application for a license under this division, the Village Manager or designee shall cause an inspection to be made of the applicant's facility. 
(Code 1979, § 16.052(e))  
Sec. 54-258. - Display. 
Any license issued in accordance with the provisions of this division shall be prominently displayed at the location for which the license has been issued.  
Sec. 54-259. - Contents; term. 
Any license granted by the Manager shall state the maximum bed capacity for which it is granted, the date the license was issued and the expiration date. Such licenses shall be issued for a period of 1 year. However, the Manager may issue licenses or renewals for periods of less than 1 year in order to distribute the expiration dates of such licenses throughout the calendar year, and fees for such licenses shall be prorated on the basis of the portion of a year for which they are issued. 
(Code 1979, § 16.053)  
Sec. 54-260. - Renewal. 
At least 90 days but not more than 120 days prior to the expiration of a license issued under this division, the licensee shall submit an application for renewal of the license on forms provided by the Department. 
(Code 1979, § 16.052(c))  
Sec. 54-261. - Notification of change of ownership or administrator. 
Change of majority ownership must be reported to the Village Manager or designee. Any change in administrator must be reported to the Village Manager or designee within 5 days. 
(Code 1979, § 16.054)  
Sec. 54-262. - Suspension or revocation. 
(a)  The Village Manager shall have the authority to revoke or suspend all licenses issued under this division. In addition to the provisions contained in this article, the Village Manager shall have the authority to establish rules and regulations for the conduct of a hearing relating to the revocation or suspension of a license. 
(b)  The Village Manager is hereby given the authority to revoke or suspend the license if the Village Manager finds: 
(1)  The licensee has not complied with applicable codes, ordinances, statutes, laws, policies or rules and regulations. 
(2)  The licensee has made fraudulent, false or misrepresentative statements in the application for the license. 
(3)  The licensee owes the Village required fees or outstanding fines or penalties.  
Sec. 54-263. - Contents and service of notices. 
(a)  Contents. All notices required to be given in accordance with this division shall be in writing, setting forth the reasons for the denial or revocation of the license. The notice shall inform the applicant or licensee that the applicant or licensee has the right to request a hearing before the Village Manager.
