(1)  Seeking to obtain orders for the purchase of goods, wares, merchandise, foodstuffs, or services, of any kind, character or description whatever, for any kind of consideration whatever; 
(2)  Seeking to obtain prospective customers for application for or purchase of insurance of any type, kind or character; or 
(3)  Seeking to obtain subscriptions to books, magazines, periodicals, newspapers and every other type or kind of publication. 
(Code 1979, § 45.01) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 78-32. - Exclusion of charitable solicitations. 
Nothing contained in this article shall apply to charitable solicitations as defined and provided for in Article III of this chapter. 
(Code 1979, § 45.02)  
Sec. 78-33. - Hours and days restricted. 
It is unlawful and shall constitute a nuisance for any person, whether registered under this article or not, to go upon any premises and ring the doorbell upon or near any door of a residence located thereon, or rap or knock upon any door, or create any sound in any other manner calculated to attract the attention of the occupant of such residence, for the purpose of securing an audience with the occupant thereof and engaging in soliciting, prior to 9:00 a.m. or after 7:30 p.m. of any weekday, prior to noon or after 5:00 p.m. on a Saturday or Sunday, or on a State or national holiday. 
(Code 1979, § 45.10; Ord. No. 17-6-C-4292, § 1, 6-5-2017) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 17-6-C-4292, § 1, adopted June 5, 2017, repealed §§ 78-33—78-36, which derived from Code 1979, §§ 45.06—45.09. Additionally, said ordinance renumbered §§ 78-37 and 78-38 as §§ 78-33 and 78-34.  
Sec. 78-34. - Minors to be accompanied by parent or guardian. 
No person under 16 years of age shall be permitted to engage in door to door solicitation, as defined in section 78-31, unless accompanied by a parent or guardian. 
(Ord. No. 03-12-C-3231, § 5, 12-1-2003; Ord. No. 17-6-C-4292, § 1, 6-5-2017)  
Secs. 78-35—78-60. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - CERTIFICATE OF REGISTRATION 
 
Sec. 78-61. - Required. 
Every person engaging in soliciting from persons in residences within the Village is required to have a certificate of registration as provided in this division. Any person issued a certificate of registration in accordance with this division, while engaged in solicitation activities shall have their certificate of registration in their possession. 
(Code 1979, § 45.03)  
Sec. 78-62. - Application; background check. 
(a)  Application for a certificate of registration under this division shall be made to the Village Manager or designee on forms prescribed and furnished by the Village Manager or designee. The Village Manager or designee may request additional information from the applicant. 
(b)  The Village Manager or designee shall cause a criminal background check to be performed for each named solicitor. 
(Code 1979, § 45.04; Ord. No. 03-12-C-3231, § 6, 12-1-2003)  
Sec. 78-63. - Eligibility. 
No certificate of registration shall be issued under this division to any person who has been convicted of the commission of a felony under the laws of the State of Illinois or any other state or federal law of the United States, within 5 years of the date of the application, or to any person who has been convicted of a violation of any of the provisions of this article, or to any person whose certificate of registration issued under this article has previously been revoked as provided in this article. 
(Code 1979, § 45.04)  
Sec. 78-64. - Issuance or denial. 
The Village Manager or designee, after review of the application for a certificate under this division and all information obtained relative thereto, shall deny the application if the applicant does not possess the qualifications for such certificate as required in this division, and if the issuance of a certificate to the applicant would not be in accord with the intent and purpose of this article. When the applicant is found to be fully qualified, the certificate shall be issued forthwith. 
(Code 1979, § 45.05)  
Sec. 78-65. - Revocation. 
(a)  The Village Manager shall have the authority to revoke all certificates of registration issued under this division. In addition to the provisions contained in this article, the Village Manager shall have the authority to establish rules and regulations for the conduct of a hearing relating to the revocation of a certificate. 
(b)  The Village Manager is hereby given the authority to revoke the certificate if the Village Manager finds: 
(1)  The certificate holder has not complied with applicable codes, ordinances, statutes, laws, policies or rules and regulations. 
(2)  The certificate holder has made fraudulent, false or misrepresentative statements in the application for the certificate. 
(3)  The certificate holder owes the Village required fees or outstanding fines or penalties. 
(4)  The certificate holder otherwise becomes disqualified for the issuance of a certificate of registration under the terms of this article. 
(c)  Immediately upon such revocation, written notice thereof shall be given by the Chief of Police to the holder of the certificate as provided in subsection (c) of this section. Upon the giving of such notice the certificate of registration shall be null and void. 
(d)  All notices required to be given in accordance with this section shall be in writing, setting forth the reasons for the revocation of the certificate. All notices shall be sent by certified mail, return receipt requested, to the certificate holder. Notice shall be considered given on the date such notice is mailed. 
(Code 1979, § 45.05)  
Sec. 78-66. - Expiration. 
The certificate of registration issued under this division shall state the expiration date thereof. 
(Code 1979, § 45.05)  
Sec. 78-67. - Badge or identification card. 
A badge or identification card issued by the Village, which shall bear a number, the organization's name, the individual's name and the date(s) of validity, shall be worn by each person soliciting door to door. 
(Ord. No. 03-12-C-3231, § 7, 12-1-2003)  
Secs. 78-68—78-90. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - CHARITABLE SOLICITATIONS[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference— Handbills and billposters, § 6-31 et seq.; permit fee for charitable soliciting, § 46-77. 
State Law reference— Solicitation for Charity Act, 225 ILCS 460/0.01 et seq. 
 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 78-91. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Charitable includes but is not exclusive of the word "philanthropic," "benevolent," "social services" or "welfare," either actual or purported. 
Contributions includes the words "alms," "food," "clothing," "money," "property," "subscription" or "pledge," and also donations under the guise of loans of money or property. 
Fund raiser means any person who promotes, manages, supervises, organizes, or attempts to promote, manage, supervise, or organize a campaign of solicitation. 
Solicit and solicitation mean the request, directly or indirectly, of money, credit, property, financial assistance, or other thing of value on the plea or representation that such money, credit, property, financial assistance, or other thing of value will be used for a charitable purpose as those purposes are defined in this section. These words shall also mean and include the following methods of securing such money, credit, property, financial assistance or other things or value: 
(1)  Any oral or written request. 
(2)  The making of any announcement to the local press or by telephone concerning a local appeal or campaign to which the public is requested to make a contribution for any charitable purpose connected therewith. 
(3)  The distribution, circulation, posting or publishing of any handbill, written advertisement, or other local publication. 
Solicitation shall be deemed to have taken place when the request is made, whether or not the person making the request receives any contribution referred to in this section. 
Vehicle solicitor for charity means any person undertaking to or engaging in the solicitation of money from passengers or drivers in motor vehicles for charitable purposes. 
(Code 1979, § 46.01, 46.20) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 78-92. - Financial records of permittees. 
No person shall solicit any contributions for any charitable purpose without maintaining a system of accounting whereby all donations to it and all disbursements are entered upon the official books or records of such person's treasurer or other financial officer. 
(Code 1979, § 46.11; Ord. No. 17-6-C-4292, § 1, 6-5-2017) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 17-6-C-4292, § 1, adopted June 5, 2017, repealed §§ 78-92 and 78-94, which derived from Code 1979, §§ 46.01, 46.12; Ord. No. 03-5-C-3162, § 1, 5-5-2003. Additionally, said ordinance renumbered § 78-93 as § 78-92 and §§ 78-95—78-97 as §§ 78-93—78-95.  
Sec. 78-93. - Misrepresentation, deception or fraud. 
No person shall directly or indirectly solicit contributions for any purpose by misrepresentation of such person's name, occupation, financial condition, social condition, residence or principal place of business. No person shall make or cause to be made any misstatement, deception, or fraud in connection with any solicitation of any contribution for any purpose in the Village, or in any application or report filed under this article. 
(Code 1979, § 46.13; Ord. No. 17-6-C-4292, § 1, 6-5-2017)  
Sec. 78-94. - Hours restricted. 
It is unlawful and shall constitute a nuisance for any person or organization, whether a permittee under this article or not, to go upon any premises and ring the doorbell upon or near any door of a residence located thereon, or rap or knock upon any door, or create any sound in any other manner calculated to attract the attention of the occupant the residence for the purpose of securing an audience with the occupant and engaging in soliciting, prior to 8:00 a.m. or after 9:00 p.m., Monday through Friday, and prior to 10:00 a.m. or after 9:00 p.m., Saturday and Sunday. 
(Code 1979, § 46.14; Ord. No. 04-9-C-3303, § 1, 9-20-2004; Ord. No. 17-6-C-4292, § 1, 6-5-2017)  
Sec. 78-95. - Solicitations from persons in motor vehicles. 
(a)  Applicability of article. All of the conditions enumerated in this article pertaining to charitable solicitations shall pertain to charitable solicitations from passengers and drivers in automobiles. 
(b)  Age requirements. Vehicle solicitors for charity shall be at least 16 years of age. Any such solicitor between the ages of 16 and 18 may engage in vehicle soliciting only in the presence of a supervising adult who must be present at all times. 
(c)  High-visibility clothing required; Identification badge. All vehicle solicitors for charity are required to wear highly visible paraphernalia or clothing and, where applicable an easily recognizable badge or other symbol from which the organization for which they solicit can be easily recognized by a driver or passenger in a motor vehicle. 
(d)  Hours and location. Charitable solicitations from motor vehicles shall be only between 6:00 a.m. and 7:00 p.m., and shall only occur at intersections protected by traffic lights, stop signs, or median islands at all corners. 
(e)  Indemnification of Village; Insurance. Any organization seeking to secure a permit for charitable solicitation shall present evidence satisfactory to the Corporation Counsel's office that the Village will incur no liabilities for injuries resulting directly or indirectly from the granting of the permit, and will, in addition thereto, present an insurance policy satisfactory to the Corporation Counsel's Office insuring each vehicle solicitor against bodily injuries to the extent of $300,000.00 during the solicitation period. 
(Code 1979, § 46.20; Ord. No. 03-12-C-3231, § 8, 12-1-2003; Ord. No. 17-6-C-4292, § 1, 6-5-2017) 
Cross reference— Traffic and vehicles, ch. 106.  
Secs. 78-96—78-120. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - PERMIT 
 
Sec. 78-121. - Required. 
It shall be unlawful for an individual or group to solicit door to door or on public property, contributions for any charitable purpose within the Village, except for an individual soliciting for himself or herself, without a permit from the Village Manager or designee, verifying the authenticity of the represented solicitation. The provisions of this section shall not apply to any established person, organization, or not-for-profit corporation, organized and operated wholly or partially for charitable purposes and not operated for the pecuniary profit of any person, if the solicitations by such established person or not-for-profit corporation are conducted only among the members thereof by other members or officers thereof, voluntarily and without remuneration for making such solicitations, or if the solicitations are in the form of collections or contributions at the regular assemblies or meetings of any such established person, organization, or not-for-profit corporation. Also exempt from this provision are those individuals belonging to an organization or group which has obtained the required permit. 
(Code 1979, § 46.02; Ord. No. 17-6-C-4292, § 1, 6-5-2017)  
Sec. 78-122. - Application. 
(a)  Information and filing. 
(1)  Applications for a permit to solicit shall be made to the Village Manager or designee on forms prescribed and furnished by the Village Manager or designee. The Village Manager or designee may request additional information from the applicant. Such application shall be sworn to or affirmed and filed with the Manager at least 15 days prior to the time at which the permit applied for shall become effective; provided, however, that the Manager may for good cause shown allow the filing of an application less than 15 days prior to the effective date of the permit applied for. 
(2)  The application shall include a financial statement for the last preceding fiscal year of any funds collected for charitable purposes by the applicant, such statement giving the amount of money so raised, together with the cost of raising it, and the final distribution thereof. 
(3)  The application shall include a full statement of the character and extent of the charitable work being done or to be done by the applicant, showing how much thereof is being done or to be done within the Village. 
(4)  The application shall include a statement that the actual cost of the solicitation will not exceed 25 percent of the total amount to be raised, or, if the cost of solicitation is expected to exceed 25 percent, a statement of what the maximum cost is expected to be, together with a statement of any special facts tending to show that there are peculiar reasons which make a cost higher than 25 percent reasonable in the particular case. 
(5)  The application shall include a statement to the effect that, if a permit is granted, it will not be used or represented in any way as an endorsement by the Village, or by any department or officer thereof. 
(6)  The application shall include a statement to the effect that, if a permit is granted, no person under the age of 16 will be permitted to solicit money. 
(b)  Notification of change in information. If, while any application is pending, or during the term of any permit granted thereon, there is any change in fact, policy, or method that would alter the information given in the application, the applicant shall notify the Manager in writing thereof within 24 hours after such change. 
(Code 1979, § 46.03)  
Sec. 78-123. - Investigation of applicant. 
Upon receipt of an application for a permit under this division, the Village Manager or designee shall review the information contained therein. Such review may include an investigation of the information and/or the applicant. 
(Code 1979, § 46.05; Ord. No. 03-12-C-3231, § 9, 12-1-2003)  
Sec. 78-124. - Examination of records. 
Upon request by the Manager, the applicant for a permit under this division shall make available for inspection by the Manager, or any person designated in writing by the Manager as the Manager's representative for such purpose, all of the applicant's books, records and papers at any reasonable time before the application is granted, during the time a permit is in effect, or after a permit has expired.  
Sec. 78-125. - Granting or denial. 
(a)  The Manager shall issue the permit provided for in this division whenever the Manager shall find the following facts to exist: 
(1)  All of the statements made in the application are true. 
(2)  The applicant, or, if the applicant is not an individual person, that its managing officers and managing agents, are of good character and reputation for honesty and integrity. 
(3)  The control and supervision of the solicitation will be under responsible and reliable persons. 
(4)  The applicant has not engaged in any fraudulent transaction or enterprise. 
(5)  The solicitation will not be a fraud of the public. 
(6)  The solicitation is prompted solely by a desire to finance the charitable cause described in the application, and will not be conducted primarily for private profit. 
(7)  The cost of raising the funds will be reasonable. Any such cost in excess of 25 percent of the amount collected shall be considered to be unreasonable unless special facts are presented showing to the satisfaction of the Manager that peculiar reasons make a cost higher than 25 percent reasonable in the particular case. 
(8)  The kind, character and method of the proposed solicitation, the time when it will take place, and its duration are such that the solicitation will be in the interest of and not inimical to the safety, convenience or welfare of the inhabitants of the Village. 
(b)  The Village Manager shall file for public inspection a written statement of the Manager's findings of fact and decisions upon each application, for which a denial has been issued. In such case, the Manager shall notify the applicant by registered mail, at the address given in the application, of the Manager's decision along with a copy of the findings of fact. 
(Code 1979, § 46.06)  
Sec. 78-126. - Contents. 
Permits issued under this division shall bear the name and address of the person or organization to whom the permit is issued, the number of the permit, the date issued, the dates within which the permit holder may solicit, and a statement that the permit does not constitute an endorsement by the Village, or by any of its departments, officers or employees, of the purpose or of the person conducting the solicitation. All permits must be signed by the Village Manager. 
(Code 1979, § 46.07; Ord. No. 17-6-C-4292, § 1, 6-5-2017)  
Sec. 78-127. - Badge or identification card. 
A badge or identification card shall be issued to be worn by each person soliciting contributions, which badge or identification card shall bear a number and the words "Solicitor for charitable purposes, Village of Skokie." 
(Code 1979, § 46.04)  
Sec. 78-128. - Term; renewal. 
The Village Manager may by permit grant the right to solicit for one calendar year from the date of the permit. Upon the expiration of a permit granted under this article, if requested in writing so to do, the Manager may renew the permit, if the Manager is satisfied that the requirements of this article are still being met, and that no violation of this article has been committed. The Manager may, in the Manager's discretion, require a new application, and the Manager's action upon such new application shall be governed by the same standards as to granting or withholding the permit as in the case of an original application. 
(Code 1979, § 46.07; Ord. No. 17-6-C-4292, § 1, 6-5-2017)  
Sec. 78-129. - Procedure for suspension or revocation. 
Whenever it shall be shown or whenever the Manager has reason to believe that any person to whom a permit has been issued under this division has violated any of the provisions of this article, or that any promoter, agent or solicitor of a permit holder has misrepresented the purpose of the solicitation, the Manager shall immediately suspend the permit. The Village Manager shall send the permit holder written notice by personal delivery, or by certified mail. This notice must contain a statement of the facts upon which the Manager has acted in suspending the permit. The permit holder may request a hearing within five business days of the issuance of the suspension notice by the Village Manager. At the hearing, the permit holder, and any other interested person, shall have the right to present evidence as to the facts upon which the Manager based the suspension of the permit, and any other facts which may aid the Manager in determining whether this article has been violated and whether the purpose of the solicitation has been misrepresented. If, after such hearing, the Manager finds that this article has been violated, or the purpose of the solicitation has been misrepresented, the Manager shall, within 2 days after the hearing, file in the Manager's office for public inspection and send to the permit holder by registered mail, or serve upon the permit holder in any manner provided by general law for the service of notices, a written statement of the facts upon which the Manager bases such a finding, and shall immediately revoke the permit. If, after such hearing, the Manager finds that this article has not been violated and the purpose of the solicitation has not been misrepresented, the Manager shall, within 2 days after the hearing, give to the permit holder a written statement reinstating the permit and stating that no violation or misrepresentation was found to have been committed. If no request for hearing is made by the permit holder within the aforesaid time period such suspension shall become a revocation of the permit. 
(Code 1979, § 46.09)  
Sec. 78-130. - Notification to Chief of Police of suspension or revocation. 
The Chief of Police shall be notified forthwith by the Village Manager or designee of the suspension or revocation of any permit issued under this division. 
(Code 1979, § 46.10)  
Sec. 78-131. - Transfer. 
No permit issued or granted under this division shall be assigned or transferred to any other person or corporation other than to the person to whom such permit was issued. No individual or corporation other than the permittee shall act or do business under such permit. 
(Code 1979, § 46.08; Ord. No. 17-6-C-4292, § 1, 6-5-2017) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 17-6-C-4292, § 1, adopted June 5, 2017, repealed § 78-131, which pertained to fees and derived from Code 1979, § 46.04. Additionally, said ordinance renumbered § 78-132 as § 78-131.  
Chapter 82 - SIGNS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Appearance Commission, § 2-771 et seq.; advertising, ch. 6; buildings and building regulations, ch. 22; gasoline price signs, § 26-1430; fees for sign permits and inspections, § 46-123; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 90; posting of political signs on election day, § 90-41(f); zoning, ch. 118. 
 
Sec. 82-1. - Title of chapter. 
This chapter shall be known and cited as the "Sign Code." 
(Code 1979, § 31.01)  
Sec. 82-2. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Alter means change or modification of any sign except for normal maintenance and repair. 
Approved combustible materials means any material more than 1/20 inch in thickness which burns at a rate of not more than 2½ inches per minute when subjected to the ASTM (American Society for Testing Materials) standard test for flammability in sheets of 0.06-inch thickness. 
Curbline. The curbline shall be measured from the back of the curb. 
Electrical code means the latest edition of the National Electrical Code which has been adopted by the Mayor and Board of Trustees for the Village (see Section 22-91). 
Erect means to build, construct, attach, hang, place, suspend or affix, and shall also include the painting of signs on building surfaces. 
Facing and surface mean the surface of the sign upon, against, or through which the message is displayed or illustrated on the sign. 
Gross surface area of sign means the entire area defined by the limits or perimeter of a sign. However, such perimeter shall not include any structural elements lying outside or inside of the limits of such sign and not forming an integral part of the display. 
(1)  For computing the area of any wall sign which consists of letters, trademarks or symbols mounted on a wall, the gross surface area shall be the area within a single continuous perimeter formed by the parallel lines at the top, bottom and sides of such letters, trademarks or symbols. 
(2)  For computing the area of any multi-sided sign, the gross surface area shall refer to all sides of such sign. 
Incombustible material means any material which will not ignite at or below a temperature of 1,200 degrees Fahrenheit and will not continue to burn or glow at that temperature. 
IBC means the latest edition of the International Building Code, published by the International Code Council, Inc., code which has been adopted by the Mayor and Board of Trustees for the Village (see Section 22-31). 
Inflatable or air-supported signs means structures which are used for advertising promotional purposes which are supported by air. This shall include but shall not be limited to balloons or dirigibles. 
Maintenance means the replacing or repairing of a part of a sign made unusable or unsightly by ordinary wear and tear or damage beyond the control of the owners, or the reprinting of existing copy without changing the wording, composition or color of the sign as it was approved. 
Major occupant means any owner or tenant who occupies more than 50,000 square feet of building floorspace. 
Nonconforming sign is as defined in Section 82-8. 
Notice. The following is the required notice procedure in each situation stated; 
(1)  Upon determination that a sign or portion thereof is unsafe or in violation of any of the provisions of this chapter, the Village Manager or designee shall serve or cause to be served on the owner, a written notice containing the description of the sign, building or structure or portion thereof that is unsafe or in violation. The notice shall include order requiring the sign, building or structure or portion thereof to be made safe and secure, removed, or brought into compliance as may be deemed necessary by the Village Manager or designee. If the person to whom such notice and order is addressed cannot be found after a diligent search then such notice and order shall be sent by certified or registered mail to the last known address of such person, and a copy of such notice shall be posted in a conspicuous place on the premises to which it relates. Such mailing and posting shall be deemed adequate notice and service. 
(2)  Whenever the Village Manager or designee has determined that a sign, or any work in connection therewith, the installation, construction or addition or alteration, execution of which is regulated, permitted or forbidden by this chapter or other applicable statutes, ordinances, codes or regulations and regulations, is being erected, constructed, added to or altered in violation of the provisions or requirements of this chapter or other applicable statutes, ordinances or regulations or in violation of a submitted and approved detailed statement or plan or of a permit or issued certificate, the Manager or designee shall serve a written notice or order upon the owner or person responsible for or performing such work, directing that all work be ceased until the violation is remedied. 
Owner means any person or persons having legal title to any sign, property, building, structure or premises, with or without accompanying actual possession thereof, and shall include such person's duly authorized agent or attorney, a purchaser, devise, lessee, executor, trust officer, administrators or fiduciary and any person having a vested or contingent interest or control of or in the sign, property, building, structure or premises in question. The term "person" shall include any legal entity. 
Public right-of-way means all of the land included within an area which is dedicated, reserved by deed or granted by easement for a street, alley, walkway, parkway or easement, in which the public, public agencies, utilities and service have access at all times. 
Rigid materials means a material or composition of materials which cannot be folded and can support its own weight when rested upon parallel edges of such materials. 
Sign means any device designed to inform or attract the attention of persons, and any structure or part thereof, or device attached thereto, painted or represented thereon, which displays or includes any letter, word, model, insignia, device which is in the nature of an announcement, direction or advertisement. The term "sign" shall include but shall not be limited to the following: 
(1)  Ground sign. Any sign supported by uprights, solid base, columns, poles, posts or braces placed in the ground and not attached to any building. 
(2)  Wall sign. Any sign attached, applied to, or placed flat against the exterior front, rear or side wall or fascia of any building or other structure. 
(3)  Temporary sign. Any sign, banner, bunting, pennant, valance, or advertising displayed for a limited time period allowed by this Code or Village ordinances or regulations. 
(4)  Marquee. Any fixed hood, designed primarily for advertising purposes, which is constructed of metal or other noncombustible material, supported solely by and extending from the building to which it is attached. 
(5)  Canopy and awning. Any hood, designed to provide pedestrian shelter, made of cloth or an approved membrane, with metal frames attached to a building and carried by a frame supported by the ground, sidewalk or wall. 
(6)  Window sign. Those signs, regardless of material, which are on the inside or outside surface of the window. Signs, packaged products, packaging materials and other opaque materials which are not placed upon the surface of a window shall be considered to cover the window if they are placed within 36 inches of the window surface. A permanent window sign is a sign that is displayed on a constant basis for more than 4 weeks. A temporary window sign is a sign that is displayed on a constant basis for 4 weeks or less. 
(7)  Painted sign. Signs painted directly on an exterior wall, fascia or parapet of a building or fence, or on a chimney. 
(8)  Roof sign. A sign, any portion of which is erected, constructed and maintained above any portion of the roof of a building. 
(9)  Projecting sign. A sign attached to a structure which projects greater than 12 inches from the exterior wall of the structure. 
(10)  Flashing sign. Any illuminated sign on which the artificial light(s) are not maintained in a stationary condition or constant in intensity and color at all times when such sign is illuminated. For purposes of this definition only, stationary condition or constant in intensity and color, shall mean such imagery shall not change more than once in any 24 hour period. 
(11)  Restaurant information sign. A case or frame containing a menu limited to 20 inches in height and four hundred (400) square inches attached to a building where a restaurant is located. 
(12)  Blade sign. A projecting sign allowed only in the CX Core Mixed-Use district attached to the exterior front, rear or side wall or fascia of any building or other structure to identify a business use where a wall sign is allowed. 
(13)  A-frame sign. A freestanding sign constructed of two ridged sheets of material that are hinged on top that is used to display the name of the business, information concerning the services or products provided by the business and the cost of the same. 
(14)  Illuminated sign. Any sign which has characters, letters, figures, designs or outlines lit by electric lights, luminous tubes or any other light source. 
Signable area means a designated area of the facade of a building, the boundaries of which shall form a square, rectangle or other Appearance Commission approved shape, which is free of windows, doors and all major architectural details. Only 1 signable area may be established for a facade of a building. In no event shall the signable area of a building exceed, in square footage, 1/3 of the square footage of any facade of the building. 
Site means all lots as defined by the Zoning Ordinance, Buildings, and/or uses in a development. 
Standards means a test, measure, model or example of quantity, extent or quality. 
Structural trim means any molding, battens, capping, nailing strips, latticing, and platforms which are attached to the sign structure. 
(Code 1979, § 31.02; Ord. No. 04-12-C-3320, § 5, 12-6-2004; Ord. No. 05-10-C-3390, § 1, 10-10-2005; Ord. No. 12-2-C-3887, § 1, 2-21-2012) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 82-3. - Penalties. 
Any person who violates any provision of this chapter shall be subject to the penalties provided in Section 1-6 in addition to any other penalty specifically provided for. 
(Ord. No. 00-10-C-2947, § 6(31.16), 10-16-2000)  
Sec. 82-4. - Notice of violation. 
Whenever any person violates any provision of this chapter, such person shall be served with a violation notice providing for an opportunity to appear in court to answer the charge of such violation. 
(Ord. No. 00-10-C-2947, § 6(31.17), 10-16-2000)  
Sec. 82-5. - Stipulated settlements. 
The Village Manager or designee is authorized to accept the amounts specified in Section 1-7 in settlement for violations of the specified Code sections and to establish settlement dates for each such violation. For violations where a showing of compliance is applicable, settlement as provided for in this section shall only be authorized upon a showing of compliance. 
(Ord. No. 00-10-C-2947, § 6(31.18), 10-16-2000)  
Sec. 82-6. - Permit; inspections. 
(a)  Permit required; fee. It shall be unlawful for any person to erect, alter, relocate or change the message or graphic display of any sign without first obtaining a permit from the Village Manager or designee. The permit fees shall be as set forth in Section 46-123. No permit shall be required for the maintenance of existing signs or for those signs exempt under the provisions of Section 82-7. 
(b)  Certificate of appropriateness. Prior to the issuance of a permit as required in this chapter, a certificate of appropriateness must be obtained from the Appearance Commission, except for sign face changes to existing signs, which require review and approval by the Village Manager or designee. 
(c)  Application for permit. 
(1)  Applications for sign permits shall be made to the Village Manager or designee on forms prescribed and furnished by the Village Manager or designee. The Village Manager or designee may request additional information from the applicant. 
(2)  All permit applications shall contain a written consent of the owner of the building, structure, or land to which or on which the sign is to be installed. In lieu of written consent, a copy of the lease clearly authorizing such installation shall be acceptable. 
(3)  Applications for temporary sign permits shall be accompanied by such information as may be requested by the Village Manager or designee to ensure compliance with all applicable regulations. 
(d)  Compliance with electrical code. Prior to the issuance of a permit for the installation of a sign in which electrical wiring and connections are to be used, a determination of compliance with the electrical code must be established. The plans and specifications respecting all wiring and connections shall be submitted to and examined by the Village Manager or designee to determine if there is compliance with the electrical code. 
(e)  Pre-installation and post-installation inspections. 
(1)  Pre-installation inspection. Prior to the installation of a sign requiring a permit, the Village Manager or designee shall conduct an inspection of the proposed sign location. The inspection shall include but shall not be limited to an inspection of the footing, mountings and placements. 
(2)  Post-installation inspection. Upon completion of the installation of a sign requiring a permit, the Village Manager or designee shall conduct an inspection of the sign to confirm that the work has been completed in accordance with the plans as approved by the Appearance Commission and Village codes, ordinances and regulations. If there has been a determination of noncompliance with the plans or certificate of appropriateness, the Village Manager or designee may order the removal of such sign. 
(f)  Issuance of permit; expiration. 
(1)  If the Village Manager or designee determines that the application, plans and specifications comply with all relevant codes, ordinances and regulations, after the inspection provided for in subsection (e) of this section and payment of required fees, the requested permit shall be issued. A permit shall only be issued for those permitted signs enumerated in Section 82-12. 
(2)  If, within 6 months after the date of issuance of the permit for the installation, the work has not been completed, the permit shall become null and void and the applicant shall be required to restore the premises/structure to its original condition. 
(g)  Periodic inspections. For the purpose of determining whether a sign is secure or in need of repair or removal, the Village Manager or designee shall cause biennial inspections or inspections at such other times as deemed necessary. The inspection fee shall be as set forth in Section 46-123. 
(Code 1979, § 31.04; Ord. No. 04-12-C-3320, § 5, 12-6-2004)  
Sec. 82-7. - Exempt signs. 
The provisions and regulation of this chapter shall not apply to the following signs; provided, however, such signs shall be subject to the provisions of Section 82-29(c). The following signs shall be exempt from the provisions of this chapter, except for the conditions contained in this section: 
(1)  Address/name signs. A sign, not exceeding 1 square foot in area, identifying the name or house number of the occupant or the presence of a permitted home occupation. 
(2)  Auxiliary signs. Auxiliary signs placed in store windows regarding hours of operation, accepted charge cards, warnings or similar information. 
(3)  Business nameplates. Non-illuminated nameplates not exceeding 1 square foot which denote the business name of an occupation legally conducted on the premises. Only 1 nameplate per proprietor shall be permitted. 
(4)  Construction signs. One sign per street frontage not exceeding 32 square feet in area. Such sign may indicate the architect, engineer or contractor and can be installed upon application of a building permit and removed upon the issuance of a certificate of completion. 
(5)  Flags and pennants. Flags and pennants at educational, governmental, or eleemosynary institutions which are not displayed for commercial purposes and are not greater than 50 square feet. A maximum of 4 flags or pennants per site may be displayed. The pole height shall be limited to the zoning district height limitation. The maximum number of 4 flags to be displayed as provided for in this subsection shall not be applicable at the Northshore Sculpture Park. 
(6)  Garage sale signs. Signs advertising garage sales, yard sales or house sales, in accordance with Chapter 26, Article XVI, on the day(s) that the sale is actually taking place, which do not exceed 4 square feet. No more than 2 signs per sale shall be permitted, with 1 sign per street frontage on the premises containing the sale. 
(7)  Government signs. Traffic signs, regulatory signs, municipal signs, legal notices, railroad crossing signs, danger signs and such temporary emergency or noncommercial signs as may be approved by the Village Manager or designee. 
(8)  Interior signs. Signs which are located on the interior of premises and which are primarily oriented to persons within the premises. 
(9)  Monument signs. Plaques, tablets, cornerstones, or lettering inlaid into the architectural materials of a building or structure not exceeding 4 square feet, denoting the name of that structure and date of erection. 
(10)  Promotions/special displays. The display of 4 American flags shall be allowed on a permanent or temporary basis without a permit, provided that each flag does not exceed 24 square feet. The pole height shall be limited to the zoning district height limitation. A banner shall be permitted for 3 periods in each calendar year for a maximum of 14 days per period, or one 30 day period. A separate permit for such display or promotion shall be required for each instance of its use subject to the following conditions: 
a.  Temporary banners are permitted for any non-residential use in any non-residential district. 
b.  Temporary banners are limited to 32 square feet for uses less than 20,000 square feet in gross floor area. Uses with a gross floor area of 20,000 square feet or more shall be allowed a temporary banner with a maximum area of 48 square feet. 
c.  Only one banner is permitted per street frontage of the property. 
d.  Only one banner is allowed at one time for tenants in a multiple tenant property. 
e.  No temporary banner may be located higher than the roof line of the building to which it is attached or, if attached to a permanent sign, higher than the permanent sign. 
f.  All materials must be nonflammable. 
g.  The banner must be maintained in a safe and aesthetically pleasing condition. A banner that becomes illegible, damaged, or is otherwise in poor condition, must be removed. 
(11)  Real estate signs. Signs pertaining to the sale, rental, management or lease of real property, referred to in this section as "real estate signs," subject to the following conditions: 
a.  Real estate signs shall be non-illuminated, and no more than 1 sign per street frontage shall be posted on any property. 
b.  No real estate sign pertaining to residential property may contain more than 4 square feet, excluding the post. When computing the 4-square-foot area, any marking or symbol which identifies a real estate licensee or group of real estate licensees shall be included. 
c.  A placard stating "Open House" may be temporarily erected on or above a residential sign on the subject property and 1 off-premises directional sign may be permitted on private property or the public parkway on Sundays from noon to 5:00 p.m. and Tuesdays from 9:00 a.m. to 1:00 p.m. The term "public parkway" shall not include the median strip. Any such directional sign shall not exceed 30 inches for a minimum distance of 15 feet from a street intersection or alley/street intersection. Signs set back more than 15 feet shall have a maximum height of 3 feet. Directional signs must indicate the real estate agency or individual responsible for the placement of the sign. 
d.  A real estate sign advertising "vacant business or industrial property" shall not exceed 24 square feet for property with a street frontage up to 100 feet and shall have a sign setback of 6 feet from the property line. For property with more than 100 feet of frontage, the sign shall not exceed 48 square feet and shall have a sign setback of 8 feet from the property line. In the CX Core Mixed-Use district, a real estate sign advertising "vacant business property" shall not exceed 24 square feet for property with a street frontage up to 100 feet. For property with more than 100 feet of frontage, the sign shall not exceed 48 square feet. Window signage shall not exceed 25 percent of the total of a window pane area. Only one sign shall be allowed per street frontage of the building. A window sign shall not be allowed if a ground or wall sign is used to advertise the sale or rental of the property. Additional window signs shall be allowed if the property is participating in the Village's Window Covering Program. 
e.  Nothing contained in this section shall be construed to permit the maintenance or installation of any sign which promotes an unlawful housing practice pursuant to federal, State, or local laws or regulations. 
Cross reference— Fair housing, § 58-31 et seq. 
f.  Real estate signs may be erected only on the vacant lot or outside of a building to which the sign applies. 
g.  Signs for the sale of residential property shall be removed by the owner of the property or the real estate agency or individual responsible for such sign within 14 days after a contract for the sale of the property has been signed by the buyer and the seller, or their representatives. The existence of any contingencies to which the contract is subject to shall not defer the 14-day period. 
(12)  Direction signs. Signs to direct traffic flow or parking, which shall be limited to directional/traffic information. Directional/traffic information signs covered by the Illinois Manual on Traffic Control Devices shall comply with all regulations therein. Signs shall not exceed 4 square feet, with a maximum dimension of 38 inches in one direction, unless required by the Illinois Manual on Traffic Control Devices. No more than 1 sign per driveway opening shall be permitted, unless additional signs are required by the Village Manager or designee. The size and number of direction signs may also be increased as part of a planned development or site plan approval granted in accordance with the Zoning Ordinance (Chapter 118). 
(13)  Temporary window signs. No more than 25 percent of an individual window pane surface inside the frame shall be covered by any type of sign. Signs, packaged products, packaging material and other opaque materials shall be considered when calculating the window coverage area. 
(14)  Restaurant informational sign. As defined in Section 82-2. 
(Code 1979, § 31.05; Ord. No. 12-2-C-3887, § 1, 2-21-2012)  
Sec. 82-8. - Nonconforming signs. 
(a)  Legal nonconforming signs. Any sign which, on July 15, 1991, the date of adoption of the ordinance from which this chapter is derived, does not conform with the provisions of this chapter shall be considered a legal nonconforming sign and shall be permitted, provided that when originally installed it was in compliance with all applicable codes, ordinances and regulations which were in effect. 
(b)  Unlawful nonconformance. Any sign which does not conform with the provisions of this chapter, all applicable codes, ordinances, and rules and regulations and is not considered a legal nonconforming sign is unlawful. The Village Manager or designee shall serve notice that the sign must be brought into compliance within 30 days. 
(c)  Loss of legal nonconforming status. A sign shall no longer be considered a legal nonconforming sign, and shall be considered an unlawful sign, if one or more of the following occurs: 
(1)  Alteration. The sign is altered in any way, except for normal maintenance or repair, which makes the sign less in compliance with this chapter or other applicable codes, ordinance or regulations. 
(2)  Message change. The message or graphic display is changed in any way, except for normal maintenance or repair which does not increase the nonconformity. 
(3)  Relocation. The sign is relocated either on the premises or to another location. 
(4)  Unsafe signs. The sign fails to conform with applicable maintenance, operation and safety standards. 
(5)  Damaged signs. The sign is damaged to the extent that required repairs exceed 50 percent of replacement value. 
(6)  Excessive maintenance costs. Maintenance costs exceed 50 percent of the replacement value. 
(7)  Change in use. A change in use or occupancy of the premises which requires a new occupancy permit. 
If any one of the conditions or events described in this subsection occurs, the sign shall be brought into compliance with this chapter and all applicable codes, ordinances and regulations within 30 days. 
(Code 1979, §§ 31.151, 31.152)  
Sec. 82-9. - Relief. 
(a)  Criteria. Relief may be granted from the provisions of this chapter upon a request to the Plan Commission or Zoning Board of Appeals as allowed in Section 118-6 and Section 118-7 of the Village Code if: 
(1)  The relief is consistent with the general purpose and intent of this chapter. 
(2)  There are practical difficulties or particular hardship in complying with the provisions of this chapter and all applicable codes, ordinances and regulations. 
(3)  The relief is not for any sign specifically prohibited by Section 82-11. 
(4)  The signs have been reviewed and endorsed by the Appearance Commission. 
(b)  Effect of decisions. All variances shall be construed as administrative actions for the purpose of assuring that inequities in specific situations may be avoided by granting a variance and shall not be construed as amendments to the provisions of this chapter unless otherwise provided by the corporate authorities. 
(Code 1979, § 31.153; Ord. No. 13-12-C-4024, § 2, 12-16-2013)  
Sec. 82-10. - Signs on public right-of-way. 
Nothing contained in this chapter shall permit the installation of signs on the public right-of-way except as otherwise provided in this chapter. 
(Code 1979, § 31.03) 
Cross reference— Private use of public ways, § 90-55.  
Sec. 82-11. - Prohibited signs. 
Prohibited signs shall include the following: 
(1)  All signs specifically or generally prohibited by other sections of this chapter. 
(2)  Signs painted directly on a building surface. 
(3)  Roof signs, except as provided for in this chapter. 
(4)  Projecting signs. 
(5)  Inflated or air-supported signs. 
(6)  Signs painted or attached directly to a vehicle for advertising purposes when the vehicle is used primarily for advertising purposes and not for transportation. 
(7)  Flashing signs. 
(Code 1979, § 31.06; Ord. No. 12-2-C-3887, § 1, 2-21-2012)  
Sec. 82-12. - Permitted types of signs. 
The following types of signs are permitted signs, subject to the restrictions and limitations contained in this chapter: 
(1)  Ground signs. 
(2)  Wall signs. 
(3)  Temporary signs. 
(4)  Marquee signs. 
(5)  Canopies and awning signs. 
(6)  Permanent window signs. No more than 25 percent of an individual window glass surface inside the frame shall be covered by any type of sign. Signs, packaged products, packaging material and other opaque materials shall be considered when calculating the window coverage area. 
(Code 1979, § 31.07)  
Sec. 82-13. - General requirements. 
(a)  Materials standards. All permanent signs permitted by this chapter shall be constructed in accordance with the provisions of this chapter and all applicable federal, State, and local laws and regulations. 
(b)  Information to be affixed on electrical signs. Every sign shall have indicated in a conspicuous place the date of installation, the name of the applicant, and the voltage of any electrical apparatus. 
(c)  Wind pressure and dead load. All signs shall be designed and constructed to withstand a wind pressure of not less than 30 pounds per square foot of net surface area and to receive dead loads as required in IBC. 
(d)  Obstructions. No sign shall be installed or maintained so as to: 
(1)  Obstruct any fire escape or means of ingress or egress. 
(2)  Interfere with any opening required for ventilation. 
(3)  Interfere with any existing warning or instructional sign. 
(4)  Interfere with pedestrian or vehicular traffic. 
(5)  Interfere with or be attached to a standpipe used for fire suppression purposes. 
(e)  Sign face and smoothness. Any sign which is installed or maintained within 5 feet of a public right-of-way shall have no nails, tacks, wires or other projections, except illuminating devices, which may extend in front of the sign. 
(f)  Illumination. 
(1)  Exterior and interior illumination shall be permitted on all signs except temporary signs and blade signs. All illuminating devices shall be completely shielded from view beyond the lot line in order to prevent glare upon the street or adjacent property. 
(2)  Letter or symbols having channeled neon lighting, with the light source flush or in line with the face of the letters or symbols, are permitted. 
(3)  In no instance shall the lighting intensity of any sign exceed 75 footcandles when measured with a standard light meter perpendicular to the face of the sign from a distance equal to the narrowest dimension of the sign. 
(Code 1979, § 31.08; Ord. No. 05-10-C-3390, § 2, 10-10-2005; Ord. No. 12-2-C-3887, § 1, 2-21-2012)  
Sec. 82-14. - Construction and installation. 
(a)  Ground signs. 
(1)  Construction. 
a.  Any movable part of a ground sign shall be securely fastened by chains or hinges. Movable parts shall include but shall not be limited to the cover of the service opening. 
b.  Lettering or advertising designs illuminated from the interior shall be composed of noncombustible or approved combustible materials. 
c.  All letters, figures, characters or representations in cut-out or irregular form maintained in conjunction with, attached to, or superimposed upon any sign shall be safely and securely built or attached to the sign structure. 
(2)  Installation. 
a.  Every ground sign shall be securely constructed, erected and installed upon posts and standards extending at least 3 feet below the natural surface of the ground. 
b.  All wood posts, anchors and bracings shall be treated to protect them from moisture by creosoting or other approved form of moisture protection. 
c.  Where pedestrians or vehicles may reasonably pass beneath or within 2 feet of the perimeter of the sign, there shall be no less than 10 feet of open space between the ground and the bottom of the sign structure. In areas where pedestrians may pass but vehicles are prohibited, a ground sign may be supported at a height less than 10 feet off the ground. In all circumstances, a pedestrian barrier shall be provided which is a maximum height of 30 inches and a minimum height of 24 inches. 
d.  No part of a ground sign supported above ground level shall extend horizontally more than ½ its height from the pole or column to which it is attached. 
e.  All ground signs and related structures shall be located entirely on private property. In the CX Core Mixed-Use district ground signs shall be located in a landscaped bed that extends beyond the plan dimensions of the sign. The landscape bed shall be elevated a minimum of 12 inches high, and shall be planted with shrubs, perennials, and/or groundcovers. 
f.  All wiring shall be contained in rigid conduit or enclosed in poles or raceways. Wiring shall not be visible to the public. 
(b)  Wall signs. 
(1)  Construction. Every wall sign shall have a surface or facing of noncombustible or approved combustible materials. Illuminated fire-resistant wooden signs shall be lighted from an exterior source of illumination. 
(2)  Installation. 
a.  Attachment to building. No wall sign shall be secured to a building with wire, wood strips or nails. Every wall sign shall be safely and securely attached to the building wall in one of the following manners: 
1.  Embedded a minimum of 5 inches into the wall with metal anchors, bolts, or expansion screws of not less than 3/8 inch in diameter. 
2.  Securely fixed to the wall by bolting the sign to metal brackets or saddles which shall be no more than 6 feet apart. 
b.  No wall sign shall cover wholly or partially any wall opening, or project beyond the ends or top of the wall to which it is attached. 
c.  Any wall sign which is located above and within 1 foot of a public right-of-way shall be attached to the building or wall at a height of not less than 10 feet above the public right-of-way. In areas where pedestrians may pass but vehicles are prohibited, a wall sign may be supported at a height less than 10 feet off the ground. In all circumstances, a pedestrian barrier shall be provided which is a maximum height of 30 inches and a minimum height of 24 inches. A sign shall not project more than 12 inches from the wall to which it is attached. 
(c)  Temporary signs. 
(1)  Construction. 
a.  No temporary sign of combustible material shall exceed 4 feet in any of its dimensions if it is attached to an exterior building wall or other stable structure. 
b.  Every temporary sign with an area in excess of 16 square feet, if it is attached to an exterior building wall or other stable structure, shall be made of rigid materials. 
(2)  Installation. 
a.  Every temporary sign shall be attached to an exterior building wall or other stable structure with an approved anchorage, with the exception of A-frame signs allowed in the CX Core Mixed-Use district. 
b.  No temporary sign shall extend more than 4 inches beyond the face of the wall or structure to which it is attached. 
c.  No temporary sign or its supports shall cover wholly or partially any wall opening, or project beyond the ends or top of the building or wall to which it is attached. 
(d)  Marquees. 
(1)  Construction. 
a.  The roof of every marquee shall be properly guttered and connected by downspouts to the ground in order to ensure that water will not drip or flow onto public property. 
b.  Signage shall be limited to the face of the hood. 
(2)  Installation. 
a.  Every marquee shall be supported solely by the building to which it is attached. No additional supports, columns or posts shall be permitted. 
b.  The roof of any marquee shall be designed and constructed to support a live load of not less than 100 pounds per square foot. 
c.  No marquee shall be installed on any building or other structure of wood frame construction. 
d.  No marquee shall overhang or extend into the public right-of-way. 
e.  No part of a marquee shall be less than 10 feet above the level of the sidewalk or other right-of-way over which it projects. 
f.  No marquee shall be wider than the entrance of the building from which it extends plus 5 feet on each side. 
(e)  Canopies and awnings. 
(1)  Construction. All canopies and awnings shall be constructed and installed in compliance with IBC and all other applicable federal, State, and local laws and regulations. 
(2)  Installation. 
a.  The lowest part of the projecting frame of canopies and awnings shall not be less than 7 feet 6 inches above the ground. the lowest portion of the descending skirt shall not be less than 6 feet 8 inches above the ground. 
b.  No canopy or awning shall be within 4 feet of the public curb line. 
(Code 1979, § 31.09; Ord. No. 05-10-C-3390, § 3, 10-10-2005; Ord. No. 12-2-C-3887, § 1, 2-21-2012)  
Sec. 82-15. - Obscene or immoral displays. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to display upon any sign any obscene, indecent or immoral matter. 
(Code 1979, § 31.101)  
Sec. 82-16. - Unlawful freestanding signs. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to install within the Village, except the CX Core Mixed-Use district, any freestanding sign which is not attached to the ground or to an existing structure in the manner provided in this chapter. 
(b)  Temporary freestanding A-frame signs are permitted in the CX Core Mixed-Use district with the following restrictions: 
1.  Limited to 6 square feet in area (each side) and 4 feet in height. 
2.  Use of sign is limited to business hours (sign must be stowed indoors during off hours) and must not be used outdoors in high winds. The sign must not be used when snow accumulation is 2 inches or more and shall not be placed in a snow bank. 
3.  One sign is permitted per business. 
4.  Sign must be placed within 10 feet of the center of the primary entrance of the business, but not directly in front of the business door or in front of an adjacent business. 
5.  Placement of signs must maintain a five (5) foot sidewalk clearance at all times. 
6.  Placement of signs must not violate standards of accessibility as required by the ADA or Illinois accessibility codes. 
7.  Sign must be on building side of sidewalk. 
(Code 1979, § 31.102; Ord. No. 12-2-C-3887, § 1, 2-21-2012)  
Sec. 82-17. - Maintenance. 
All signs and appurtenances thereto shall be maintained by the owner and occupant in a clean and inoffensive manner. 
(Code 1979, § 31.103)  
Sec. 82-18. - Electronic Message Centers (EMC) regulations. 
(a)  An Electronic Message Center (hereinafter referred to in this Article as "EMC") is any sign or portion of a sign that displays electronics or electronically generated images, graphics, videos or pictures, with or without text, generated by a matrix of elements using different combinations of light emitting diodes (LEDs), fiber optics, light bulbs, pixelated screens or other illumination devices within the display panels(s). 
(b)  An EMC shall comply with the following regulations: 
(1)  It shall be designed and located so that the entire message is legible to the traveling public; 
(2)  It shall be constructed from non-reflective materials and illuminated in a manner that does not create a glare; 
(3)  It shall be located and mounted in compliance with requirements for the type of sign (ground, wall, window, etc.) in this chapter; and 
(c)  The message format shall conform to the following requirements: 
(1)  The message shall not consist of flashing, chasing or animated lights, or include animated pictorial graphics; 
(2)  Text shall be uniform in color, appearance, and font; 
(3)  The message, including single and multiple lines of text, shall not change more frequently than once every twenty (20) seconds; 
(4)  Relief to allow a sign facing residential property shall only be allowed after the following factors are reviewed and determined not to be detrimental to the residential property: time the sign is illuminated, duration of display, and brightness of the display. 
(d)  EMC signs must not exceed a maximum illumination of five thousand (5,000) nits (candelas per square meter) during daylight hours and a maximum illumination of five hundred (500) nits (candelas per square meter) between dusk to dawn and/or on cloudy days as measured from the sign's face at maximum brightness. All signs shall have an ambient light monitor that will automatically adjust the brightness levels based on ambient light conditions. Prior to the issuance of a permit, the applicant shall submit photos of the proposed EMC, as it would appear during daytime and evening hours. 
(e)  All EMC signs must be equipped with a default mechanism that will stop the messaging, freeze the image in one position, or turn off the sign when a malfunction in electronic programming occurs. 
(Code 1979, § 31.104; Ord. No. 05-10-C-3390, § 4, 10-10-2005; Ord. No. 19-4-C-4449, § 1, 4-15-2019)  
Sec. 82-19. - Traffic hazards. 
No sign shall be installed or maintained which purports to be an imitation of or resembles an official traffic control device, railroad sign or signal, which attempts to direct the movement of traffic, or which obstructs the view of any official traffic control device or any railroad sign or signal, without prior approval from the appropriate governmental agency. 
(Code 1979, § 31.105) 
Cross reference— Traffic and vehicles, ch. 106.  
Sec. 82-20. - Off-premises signs. 
Every sign shall relate directly to the property, business or enterprise conducted on the premises. No vacant lot shall have permanent signage. 
(Code 1979, § 31.106)  
Sec. 82-21. - Product and service identification. 
Product and service identification shall not occupy more than 25 percent of the surface area of a single sign. This requirement shall not apply to exclusive dealerships, manufacturers of name-brand products or the exclusive manufacturer's representatives, or single word product or service identification or window signs. Phone numbers and website locations shall only be allowed as part of a window sign. 
(Code 1979, § 31.107; Ord. No. 12-2-C-3887, § 1, 2-21-2012)  
Sec. 82-22. - Awning, canopy or marquee signs. 
(a)  Number and placement. Each use shall be allowed only 1 awning, canopy or marquee sign facing any street, mall, parking lot, or public access area where there is a business entrance or display window. No awning, canopy or marquee sign shall be permitted facing any residential use, except where it is the principal frontage. For uses in the CX Core Mixed-Use district, an individual awning, canopy or marquee may be allowed over each door or window facing any street, mall, parking lot, or public access area where there is a business entrance or display window, however, only one awning, canopy or marquee per street frontage sign shall be allowed to have lettering or a logo. The top of the awning, canopy or marquee shall be at least 12 inches below the top of the building parapet or 10 percent of the facade above the first floor window line whichever is less. 
(b)  Area and design. The surface area of any sign affixed to an awning, canopy or marquee shall not exceed 50 percent of the face to which it is attached or 100 square feet, whichever is less. Letters or signs affixed to any awning, canopy or marquee shall be subject to the following conditions: 
(1)  Letters, lettering, or logos shall not project above the physical dimensions of the awning, canopy or marquee. No letters shall exceed 18 inches in height, nor shall any logo exceed 20 inches in height. For uses located in the CX Core Mixed-Use district, if the business has a wall sign, the awning may only contain a logo and address number and street. The address shall not exceed 12 inches in height. The lettering or logo shall not exceed one-third the area of the face parallel to the building. Letters or lettering shall only identify the name or use of the business conducted therein, the address number, and street name. Lettering or logos are allowed only on the canopy face that is parallel to the building wall. 
(2)  The general character, color and style of all awnings and canopies shall relate to each other and be harmonious within the group of uses having common party walls. 
(3)  Letters or lettering shall only identify the name or use of the business conducted therein, and the address number. The common name or identity for a group of uses may be substituted. The establishment/building owner may elect to designate the marquee, canopy or awning as the signable area as defined in Section 82-27(c). 
(4)  No temporary sign shall be attached to or hung from a marquee, awning or canopy except a sign painted or illuminated directly upon the vertical hanging fascia of the structure, and such sign shall not be lower than 7 feet 6 inches above the sidewalk or public right-of-way. 
(5)  No advertising material shall be placed upon the roof of or hung from any awning, canopy or marquee. 
(c)  Approval. Any lettering, logo, or sign on an awning, canopy or marquee shall be approved by the Appearance Commission. 
(d)  Height. The height of any awning, canopy, or marquee shall be regulated by Section 82-14(d) and (e). 
(Code 1979, § 31.108; Ord. No. 12-2-C-3887, § 1, 2-21-2012)  
Sec. 82-23. - Window signs. 
No more than 25 percent of an individual window pane surface shall be covered by any type of sign. Signs, packaged products, packaging material and other opaque materials shall be calculated in the window coverage area. Only one (1) sign per window pane or glass door is allowed in the CX Core Mixed-Use district. 
(Code 1979, § 31.109; Ord. No. 12-2-C-3887, § 1, 2-21-2012)  
Sec. 82-24. - Changeable copy signs. 
Any ground or wall sign may contain changeable copy with the limitations contained in this chapter. Any changeable copy shall not exceed a gross surface area of 25 square feet, and such footage shall be included as part of the maximum square footage for the form of sign taken and shall be subject to all other regulations for such signs. When temporary signs are not displayed in a development, the gross surface area of the changeable copy area on the ground sign may be increased to a maximum of 50 square feet. 
(Code 1979, § 31.1010)  
Sec. 82-25. - Temporary or sale signs. 
No temporary or sale sign shall exceed 25 square feet in sign area or more than 25 percent of any window pane or other surface to which it is attached. Such a sign shall be calculated as part of the total square footage of any other applicable permitted signs. No temporary or sale signs made of paper or cardboard shall be affixed to any exterior window surface, wall or other exterior surface of the structure. Such signs in the CX Core Mixed-Use district shall not be hand drawn or hand written except for those on A-frame signs. 
(Code 1979, § 31.1011; Ord. No. 12-2-C-3887, § 1, 2-21-2012)  
Sec. 82-26. - Residential district uses. 
(a)  Applicability. This section applies to signs in all residential districts, and no other signs except those listed in this section shall be permitted. 
(b)  Permitted signs. The following signs are permitted in residential districts without prior approval of the Appearance Commission, but are subject to the conditions and limitations as contained in Section 82-7: 
(1)  Real estate signs. 
(2)  Address/name signs. 
(3)  Garage sale signs: those signs advertising a garage sale in accordance with Chapter 26, Article XVI. 
(4)  Government signs: Official signs of governmental or quasi-governmental entities. 
(5)  One non-illuminated window sign per residential unit not to exceed 4 square feet. Such sign may be displayed for a period not to exceed 30 days in any 6-month period. 
(6)  One non-illuminated ground sign per property not to exceed 4 square feet. Such sign may be displayed for a period not to exceed 30 days in any 6-month period. 
(c)  Signs requiring approval of Appearance Commission. The following signs are permitted in residential districts with the prior approval of the Appearance Commission; however, sign face changes to existing signs shall only require review and approval by the Village Manager or his designee: 
(1)  Residential development signs. 
a.  Type. Such signs shall be either a wall or ground sign. 
b.  Number. There shall only be 1 sign for each abutting street frontage. 
c.  Area. Such signs shall not exceed 6 square feet in gross surface area for each exposed face, not to exceed an aggregate gross surface area of 12 square feet. 
d.  Location. Such signs shall not be located closer than ½ the minimum setback required for the zoning district or within 15 feet of any point of vehicular access from a zoning lot to a public roadway. 
e.  Height. Wall signs shall not be higher than 10 feet from the sign base to building grade, or ground signs shall not be higher than 4 feet from the sign base to grade. 
(2)  Cemetery signs. 
(3)  Historic markers. 
(4)  Signs for eleemosynary uses. 
a.  Type. Wall and ground signs are permitted. 
b.  Number. There shall be only 1 sign of each type for each street frontage. 
c.  Area. Ground signs shall not exceed 35 square feet. When a changeable copy sign is included, the square footage allowed may be increased to 50 square feet. Wall signs shall not exceed 24 square feet. 
d.  Location. Ground signs shall not be located closer than the minimum setback required for the zoning district, or within 15 feet of any point of vehicular access from a zoning lot to a public roadway. 
e.  Height. Wall signs shall not be higher than 10 feet from the sign base to building grade. Ground signs shall not be higher than 4 feet from the sign base to grade. 
(Code 1979, § 31.11; Ord. No. 04-12-C-3320, § 5, 12-6-2004)  
Sec. 82-27. - Mixed-Use and small business district uses. 
(a)  Applicability. This section applies to all signs in the NX Neighborhood Mixed-Use, TX Transit Mixed-Use, and CX Core Mixed-Use, and B1 Service Commercial zoning districts and signs on sites under 1 acre in the B2 Commercial and B3 Business zoning districts. All signs listed in Section 82-12 shall be permitted subject to the conditions set forth in this chapter and as regulated by this section. 
(b)  CX Core Mixed-Use District. Buildings in the CX Core Mixed-Use district undergoing historically correct renovations to their original appearance shall be exempt from the sign criteria in this chapter. However, all building signage, signage support structures, and illumination shall be subject to review and approval by the Appearance Commission and Board of Trustees. 
(c)  Wall signs. 
(1)  Signable area. 
a.  The signable area shall be no greater than 1/3 of the commercial portion of the facade and shall be subject to the review and approval of the Appearance Commission. 
b.  The signable area may be established on the following facades: 
1.  A facade facing a street frontage, except where it faces residentially zoned property, unless it is the only street frontage. 
2.  A facade facing a mall, parking lot. or public access area where there is a business entrance or display window. 
(2)  Number. Each business shall be allowed only 1 wall sign per signable area. 
(3)  Area. No wall sign shall have a gross surface area in excess of 1/3 of the signable area. No letter or logo shall be larger than 36 inches in height. For uses in the CX Core Mixed-Use district, no letter or logo shall be taller than 24 inches for uses less than 10,000 square feet in area of the building footprint. Uses 10,000 square feet or greater in size shall be allowed letters or logos up to 36 inches. No wall sign shall be located closer than 10 percent of the distance to the top or to the bottom of any fascia or structural surface to which it is attached. No wall sign shall be wider than 80 percent of the width of an occupant's space with a minimum width of 2 feet from each side of the tenant's space. 
(4)  Location. Wall signs shall be displayed only within the signable area of a building, and only to the extent permitted by this chapter. 
(5)  Height. No wall sign shall extend over the top of the facade of any building to which it is attached. The sign shall not be located above the sills of any second-story window in the same elevation. 
(6)  Sign information. Signs shall only identify the name, use and/or logo of the business conducted therein, and the address number. 
(d)  Ground signs. 
(1)  Number. There shall only be 1 ground sign at any single- or multiple-use site, excluding ground signs used for directional purposes. Where there are adjoining uses sharing party walls, there shall only be 1 ground sign to be used jointly by all the adjoining uses. Each use shall have its proportionate share of the sign area based on its proportion of the linear footage of building frontage. 
(2)  Area. No ground sign shall have a gross surface area in excess of 35 square feet per face, with a maximum gross surface area of 70 square feet per sign for a single occupant/use or common identity use. When more than 1 occupant is listed or when a changeable copy sign is included, the square footage allowed may be increased to 50 square feet per face with a maximum gross surface area of 100 square feet per sign. 
(3)  Location. No ground sign (other than directional signs such as entrance/exit signs) shall be located closer than its height, measured horizontally, to any interior lot line, rear lot line, or adjacent ground sign, subject to the approval of the Director of Engineering. No ground sign shall overhang or encroach upon any public sidewalk or other public right-of-way. 
(4)  Height. No ground sign shall exceed a height of 18 feet or the top of the lowest level or any roof or facade line of the associated building, whichever is less. 
(e)  Blade signs. 
(1)  Signable area. 
a.  The signable area shall be no greater than 1/3 of the commercial portion of the facade and shall be subject to the review and approval of the Appearance Commission. 
b.  The signable area may be established on the following facades: 
1.  A facade facing a street frontage, except where it faces residentially zoned property, unless it is the only street frontage. 
2.  A facade facing a mall, parking lots or public access area where there is a business entrance or display window. 
(2)  Number. Each business shall be allowed only one (1) blade sign per signable area. A blade sign is not allowed if the business has an awning or a wall sign. 
(3)  Area. No blade sign shall have a gross surface area in excess of 10 square feet. No letter or logo shall be larger than 24 inches in height. Blade signs shall all be at least as tall as wide and shall not project more than 36 inches from the wall to which it is attached. The sign shall be constructed of rigid material or of taut fabric and attached without chains or diagonal bracing and have a maximum thickness of 3 inches. The sign shall not be illuminated. 
(4)  Location. Blade signs shall be displayed only within the signable area of a building, and only to the extent permitted by this chapter. No blade sign shall be located closer than 10 percent of the distance to the top or to the bottom of any fascia or structural surface to which it is attached. A blade sign shall be located at least 2 feet from each side of the tenant's lease line. 
(5)  Height. No blade sign shall extend over the top of the facade of any building to which it is attached. The sign shall not be located above the sills of any second-story window in the same elevation. Height from the top of the facade shall be 12 inches or 10 percent above the window line, whichever is less. The minimum clearance from the ground shall be 8 feet. 
(6)  Sign information. Signs shall only identify the name, use, and/or logo of the business conducted therein, and the address number. 
(f)  Maximum gross surface area. Maximum gross surface area of signs is 1/3 of all signable areas, as defined in Section 82-2 and allowed in subsection (c) of this section, excluding ground signs, as regulated in this section. 
(Code 1979, § 31.12; Ord. No. 09-2-C-3664, § 1, 2-17-2009; Ord. No. 12-2-C-3887, § 1, 2-21-2012)  
Sec. 82-28. - Large business district uses and industrial district uses. 
(a)  Applicability. This section applies to signs in the B2 Commercial and B3 Business zoning districts where the site exceeds 1 acre and all signs in the B4 Regional Shopping, B6 Downtown Science and Technology, H1 Hospital, M1 Office Assembly Industry, M2 Light Industry, M3 Industry, and OR Office Research zoning districts. All signs listed in Section 82-12 shall be permitted subject to the conditions set forth in this chapter and as regulated by this section. 
(b)  Wall signs. 
(1)  Number. 
a.  Only 1 wall sign facing a street frontage on which it is located shall be permitted per occupancy. In the B4 Regional Shopping district, no wall sign shall be permitted facing a street frontage where there is residentially zoned property located directly opposite such street frontage, unless it is the only street frontage of the business. 
b.  Only 1 wall sign shall be permitted per facade facing a mall, parking lot or public access area for an occupancy without street frontage. 
c.
