In the B4 Regional Shopping district, only 1 wall sign shall be allowed for each occupant in a development, except that, where an occupant abuts 2 or more streets, 1 additional sign shall be permitted for each building facade abutting a street, provided that no wall sign shall be permitted facing a street frontage where there is residentially zoned property located directly opposite such street frontage, unless it is the only street frontage of the business. In addition, 1 wall sign shall be allowed for each exterior building facade of an occupant facing an internal court of the development. 
Major occupants of shopping centers on sites over 80 acres in the B4 Regional Shopping district shall be permitted 1 sign for each building facade. Major occupants shall be allowed 1 additional sign per public entrance, if, in the judgment of the Appearance Commission, the primary sign is permanently obstructed from view at the pedestrian level by construction such as canopies, retail buildings, major landscape features, parking structures, etc. 
(2)  Area. No wall sign shall have a gross surface area in excess of 20 percent of the wall to which it is applied or 200 square feet, whichever is less. In the B-4 Regional Shopping district, no wall sign shall have a gross surface area in excess of 10 percent of the wall to which it is applied for major occupants of shopping centers on sites over 80 acres. If more than 1 wall sign is located on a face of a major occupant building, the gross surface area of all signs shall not exceed 10 percent of wall to which it is applied. 
(3)  Location. A wall sign shall be located on the outermost wall of any principal building. 
(4)  Height. 
a.  Except in the B6 Downtown Science and Technology, OR Office Research, B4 Regional Shopping, and H1 Hospital Zoning districts, a wall sign shall not extend over the top of the facade of any building to which it is attached. The sign shall not be located above the sign frieze. 
b.  In the B6 Downtown Science and Technology, OR Office Research, B4 Regional Shopping, and H1 Hospital zoning districts, wall signs may be located above the top of the facade, on a building penthouse, or above the first floor. 
(5)  Sign information. Signs shall only identify the name, use and or logo of the business conducted therein, and the address number. 
(c)  Ground signs. 
(1)  Number. There shall only be 1 ground sign at any single or multiple-use site excluding ground signs for directional purposes. Each use shall have its proportionate share of the sign based on its proportion of the linear footage of building frontage. However, at shopping centers with a minimum of 10 or more tenants and minimum of 50,000 square feet of gross leasable floor area, the Appearance Commission may approve, as an element of the site's sign criteria, a sign package limiting the ground sign to anchor tenants and major uses. In such instances, other means of signage must be available for tenants not represented on the ground sign and written proof provided to the Village that these uses are not entitled to signage on the ground sign. Additional ground sign locations may be permitted if the following criteria are met: 
a.  For industrial zoned sites: 
1.  The site must be at least 3 acres in size and the occupied building floor area must be at least 50,000 square feet. 
2.  The use must have a separate street address and entrance. 
3.  The use must have direct street frontage. 
4.  There shall be no common ground sign for the development, unless it is a single tenant building. 
5.  The sign and all other ground signs to be located at the site must be approved as a package. 
6.  All ground signs shall have the same size, shape, lettering, style, color and means of illumination and shall be set back the same distance from the street frontage. 
b.  For sites in business zoning districts: 
1.  The site must be at least 2 acres in size. 
2.  The site must have more than 1 street frontage with a maximum of 1 sign per street frontage. 
3.  The sign shall be a common ground sign for all uses at the site. 
4.  The sign and all other ground signs to be located at the site must be approved as a package. 
5.  All ground signs shall have the same size, shape, lettering, style, color and means of illumination and all shall be set back the same distance from the street frontage. 
c.  As part of a hotel development with a restaurant that is enclosed in, or part of, the building. A separate ground sign specifically for the restaurant is authorized, subject to the following conditions: 
1.  The restaurant sign cannot exceed 15 feet in height. 
2.  The gross surface area of the restaurant sign shall not exceed 75% of the total square feet per sign allowed pursuant to paragraph (c)(2) of this Section. 
3.  If the special use permit or site plan approval has already been granted and the only item that is requested is a separate restaurant sign, then the request shall be considered through the modified review procedure stated in Section 118-8. 
4.  Only one separate sign for a restaurant may be authorized, the number of: (A) streets that are adjacent to the hotel site; or (B) restaurants on the hotel site. 
5.  A restaurant that has a separate restaurant sign shall not be allowed to have another sign in combination with a hotel sign. 
(2)  Area. 
a.  No ground sign shall have a gross surface area in excess of 100 square feet per face, with a maximum gross surface area of 200 square feet per sign or 2 square feet per face for every linear foot of building frontage, whichever amount is less. The total permitted gross surface area of a ground sign may be increased by 2 square feet for each linear foot of sign setback from the street right-of-way for a maximum gross surface area of 150 square feet per face with a maximum gross surface area of 300 square feet per sign. Where the site exceeds 2 acres, a common ground sign shall not exceed 200 square feet per face, with a maximum gross surface area of 400 square feet per sign, or 2 feet per face for every linear foot of building frontage, whichever amount is less. 
b.  No ground sign shall have a gross surface area in excess of 100 square feet or 2 square feet per face for every linear foot of building frontage, whichever amount is less. The total permitted gross surface area of a ground sign may be increased by 2 square feet for each linear foot of sign setback from the street right-of-way for a maximum gross surface area of 150 square feet. Where the site exceeds 2 acres, a common ground sign shall not exceed 200 square feet or 2 feet per face for every linear foot of building frontage, whichever amount is less. 
(3)  Location. A ground sign may be located in any required yard subject to the conditions contained in the Zoning Ordinance (Chapter 118). All ground signs over 30 inches in height shall not be located within a 15-foot sight triangle in any direction along the property line from any vehicular access drive or public thoroughfare and shall not create any dangerous sight obstructions at other locations on the site, including visual obstructions of, or to, pedestrian traffic on designated public or private sidewalks. 
(4)  Height. No ground sign shall exceed a height of 18 feet or to the top of the lowest level of any roof or facade line of the associated building, whichever is less. Ground sign height may be increased as part of a planned development or site plan approval granted in accordance with the Zoning Ordinance (Chapter 118). 
(d)  Maximum gross surface area. 
(1)  The total permitted gross surface area of all signs for a single building shall not exceed 3 times in square feet the total building frontage expressed in linear feet, up to a maximum of 500 square feet for a building with 1 frontage, 800 square feet for a building with 2 frontages, and 1,000 square feet for a building with 3 or more frontages. 
(2)  If a single building is designed for occupancy by more than 1 establishment or use and is so used, the formula to be applied in ascertaining the permitted gross surface area for each individual establishment shall be determined on the basis of 3 times, in square feet, the total building frontage of each individual establishment. 
(3)  The total permitted gross surface area of all signs for a single building shall be increased by 2 square feet for each linear foot of building setback beyond the setback required under the Zoning Ordinance (Chapter 118). For a single development on a site larger than 3 acres, the total permitted gross surface area of all signs for all buildings shall be increased by 50 square feet for each acre of land in excess of 3 acres. 
(4)  The total permitted gross surface area of all signs advertising the sale, development, use or ownership of vacant or undeveloped real estate shall be limited to and in conformity with the provisions of Section 82-7. 
(Code 1979, § 31.13; Ord. No. 04-12-C-3320, § 5, 12-6-2004; Ord. No. 09-2-C-3664, § 1, 2-17-2009; Ord. No. 10-1-C-3731, § 1, 1-19-2010; Ord. No. 13-12-C-4024, § 2, 12-16-2013)  
Sec. 82-29. - Maintenance; removal on termination of business; unsafe signs. 
(a)  Maintenance. 
(1)  Required. Every sign, including but not limited to those signs for which permits are required, shall be maintained in a safe, presentable, and sound structural condition. 
(2)  Paint or surface treatment. To prevent rust, peeling, flaking, fading or rotting, all signs and supports shall be painted unless they have been anodized or similarly treated. 
(3)  Repairs. Broken panels, missing letters, defective illumination, torn fabric, flaking or peeling paint and other damage to a sign shall be replaced or repaired. 
(b)  Removal on termination of business. Within 30 days of the termination of a business, commercial, or industrial enterprise, all signs relating to such activity shall be removed. The owner shall be responsible for the removal of such signs or, display a blank sign face until such unit is occupied and also cover the interior of all ground floor windows that face public streets or sidewalks with an opaque, single-color material that prevents interior viewing of the space by the public. 
(c)  Unsafe signs. 
(1)  If a determination is made by the Village Manager or designee that any sign is unsafe, is not secure, is in violation of this chapter, or is in violation of any applicable law or a public danger, notice of such violation shall be given to the owner that the sign must be removed or repaired or the violation cured within 30 days. 
(2)  If such remedial action or removal does not occur, the Village Manager or designee may cause the removal of the sign. The owner shall be responsible for the cost of removal within 30 days after notification of such costs. Any costs that continue to go unpaid shall cause a lien to be recorded against the affected property. The lien shall be superior to all other liens and encumbrances, except tax liens, provided that, within 60 days after such cost and expense is incurred, the Village files notice of lien in the office of the Recorder of Deeds for Cook County. 
(3)  Any sign which presents an immediate danger to the public may be removed at the direction of the Village Manager or designee in accordance with the procedures set forth in this section. 
(Code 1979, § 31.14; Ord. No. 04-12-C-3320, § 5, 12-6-2004)  
Chapter 86 - SOLID WASTE[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Department of Public Works, § 2-241 et seq.; health and sanitation requirements at carnivals, circuses, fairs and other amusements, § 14-276; buildings and building regulations, ch. 22; health and sanitary regulations for dry cleaning establishments, § 26-434; environment, ch. 42; fee for landscape waste bag stickers, § 46-44; burning garbage or refuse, § 50-44; health and sanitation, ch. 54; refuse and litter on streets and sidewalks, § 90-52; utilities, ch. 110. 
Federal law reference— Solid waste disposal, 42 U.S.C.A. § 6901 et seq. 
State Law reference— Disposal of refuse, garbage and ashes in municipalities, 65 ILCS 5/11-19-1 et seq.; removal of garbage and debris, 65 ILCS 5/11-20-13; land pollution and refuse disposal, 415 ILCS 5/20 et seq.; Local Solid Waste Disposal Act, 415 ILCS 10/1 et seq.; Solid Waste Planning and Recycling Act, 415 ILCS 15/1 et seq.; Illinois Solid Waste Management Act, 415 ILCS 20/1 et seq.; Litter Control Act, 415 ILCS 105/1 et seq.; spilling loads on highways, 625 ILCS 5/15-109 et seq. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 86-1. - Purpose and scope of chapter. 
This chapter regulates the collection and pre-collection practices within the Village with respect to garbage, refuse, rubbish, landscape wastes, building materials, debris, all other waste materials and recyclables. Its provisions are binding upon all citizens, residents, homeowners, tenants, landowners, institutions, businesses, manufacturers, and private scavengers located within or operating within the Village. 
(Code 1979, § 14.01)  
Sec. 86-2. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Composting means the controlled method of decomposing organic matter (landscape waste) by the natural activity of microorganisms. 
Containers means Village-provided refuse carts. 
Hazardous waste shall be as defined by the Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation and Liability Act (1980) (CERCLA) (42 U.S.C.A. § 9605), the Superfund Amendments and Reauthorization Act of 1986 (SARA) (42 U.S.C.A. § 11001 et seq.), the Illinois Environmental Protection Act, Section 5/3.15 (415 ILCS 5/3.15), Section 3001 of the Resource Conservation and Recovery Act of 1976, PL 94-580 (42 U.S.C.A. § 6921), the Illinois Potentially Infectious Medical Waste Act (P.A. 87-752) (415 ILCS 5/56 et seq.), or pursuant to State Pollution Control Board regulations, all as may be amended from time to time. 
Landscape waste means grass, leaves, small brush and tree clippings and other similar waste. 
Medical waste sharps includes but is not limited to used or unused discarded hypodermic, intravenous, or other needles, or hypodermic or intravenous syringes. 
Private scavenger means any person, firm or organization engaged in the business of collecting, hauling or disposing of waste materials. 
Putrescent and putrescible mean waste material which is decayed or is likely to decay. 
Recyclable materials includes materials collected in accordance with the Village recycling program. 
Recycling containers means containers provided by the Village to residents in accordance with the Village's recycling program in which recyclable materials are placed for collection by the Village or its contractor. 
Recycling program means the Village-wide recycling program as approved by the Mayor and Board of Trustees on March 5, 1990, and as amended from time to time. 
Waste materials includes but is not limited to litter, garbage and other household waste products. 
(Code 1979, § 14.02) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 86-3. - Penalties. 
Any person who violates any provision of this chapter shall be subject to the penalties provided in Section 1-6 in addition to any other penalty specifically provided for. 
(Code 1979, § 14.17)  
Sec. 86-4. - Notice of violation. 
Whenever any person violates any provision of this chapter, such person shall be served with a violation notice providing for an opportunity to appear in court to answer the charge of such violation. 
(Code 1979, § 14.18)  
Sec. 86-5. - Stipulated settlements. 
The Village Manager or designee is authorized to accept the amounts specified in Section 1-7 in settlement for violations of the specified Code sections and to establish settlement dates for each such violation. For violations where a showing of compliance is applicable, settlement as provided for this section shall only be authorized upon a showing of compliance. 
(Code 1979, § 14.19)  
Sec. 86-6. - Responsibility for compliance. 
The responsibility for compliance with this chapter shall include but shall not be limited to each, all or any combination of persons or organizations as follows: 
(1)  The specific individual who commits an act or omission in direct violation of this chapter. 
(2)  The person or organization in charge of the day-to-day operation and management of the premises wherein the violation occurred. 
(3)  The owner or agent of the owner of the premises wherein the violation occurred, provided that no such owner or agent shall be held responsible for such violations unless the owner or agent has actual knowledge thereof or has been duly notified by the Department of Public Health that such violations have occurred. 
(Code 1979, § 14.16)  
Sec. 86-7. - Garbage containers; preparation of garbage for disposal. 
All putrescent or putrescible waste materials or substances, except landscape waste, recyclable materials and hazardous waste, placed out for collection must be stored in Village provided containers. Waste should be drained and wrapped or bagged in such a manner that moisture cannot spill when the material is removed from the container. Animal feces and dusty residuals such as charcoal ash, fireplace ash and sawdust must be bagged and not placed loose in the container. 
(Code 1979, § 14.03)  
Sec. 86-8. - Preparation of refuse for disposal. 
All nonputrescible waste materials, including recyclable materials, must be stored in a bag or wrapped, tied or bundled in such a manner that the material will not blow or scatter during the storage period. 
(Code 1979, § 14.04)  
Sec. 86-9. - Combining garbage and refuse. 
When any putrescible materials are combined with nonputrescible materials, the provisions pertaining to putrescible materials shall apply. 
(Code 1979, § 14.05)  
Sec. 86-10. - Unlawful deposit of waste. 
No waste materials shall be deposited, be thrown away, or be permitted to accumulate or remain in any street, alley, or other public place or in any place or in any condition where its presence would constitute a nuisance to others, or a potential or actual hazard to health, sanitation or safety. 
(Code 1979, § 14.06) 
Cross reference— Public nuisances, § 42-31 et seq.  
Sec. 86-11. - Hazardous wastes. 
(a)  Explosives and flammable liquids shall not be placed in garbage containers for storage or collection. 
(b)  Medical waste sharps shall be packaged in a puncture-proof container prior to disposal in the Village container. 
(c)  Hazardous waste shall be disposed of in accordance with state and federal laws. Paint shall be completely dried or mixed with an absorbent material, such as sand or cat litter, and allowed to solidify prior to disposal. 
(Code 1979, § 14.07) 
Cross reference— Environment, ch. 42.  
Sec. 86-12. - Designated collection area required. 
Every building, establishment, institution or premises wherein waste materials are created shall contain a designated collection site or sites which meet the standards of convenience, health and safety set by the Mayor and Board of Trustees or Village Manager. This requirement expressly includes all construction sites and remodeling projects. 
(Code 1979, § 14.08)  
Sec. 86-13. - Responsibilities of operators of multiple-occupancy buildings. 
Whenever premises are occupied or used by more than 1 family, business or legal entity, it shall be the responsibility of the owner or owners of the premises to designate or cause to be designated a single named individual who at all times shall be responsible for all pre-collection practices. The failure of the owner or owners to designate such a person shall be deemed a violation of this chapter. 
(Code 1979, § 14.09)  
Sec. 86-14. - Prohibited collections. 
It shall be unlawful for any person or entity to collect, procure, or obtain any waste materials from parkways or alleys unless the person or entity is the Village or its contractor. 
(Code 1979, § 14.10)  
Sec. 86-15. - Place of disposal; collection hours. 
(a)  No waste materials collected shall be disposed of within the Village. 
(b)  Waste material pickup shall only occur between the hours of 7:00 a.m. and 9:30 p.m. unless the Village Manager or designee authorizes the implementation of an emergency waste collection schedule. 
(Code 1979, § 14.11)  
Sec. 86-16. - Regulations for premises serviced by Village crews. 
The following provisions relate to buildings serviced by Village refuse crews pursuant to policies and procedures set forth by the Village's refuse policy: 
(1)  Containers generally. 
a.  All locations serviced by Village refuse crews shall utilize only containers provided by the Village for putrescible waste and recyclable materials. 
b.  All materials placed in containers shall be in compliance with instructions specified on the container or otherwise provided by the Village as prescribed by the Village's refuse policy. 
(2)  Use of containers; ownership of containers. Containers shall only be used in accordance with this chapter and other applicable regulations. Village-provided containers shall be considered Village property and shall at all times remain at the property originally provided for. 
(3)  Residential waste materials. 
a.  Containers provided for a residential property shall be used for waste materials and recyclables generated on that property only. Building, construction and remodeling materials generated by a professional contractor shall be removed by the contractor. Disposal of do-it-yourself projects shall conform to instructions specified by the Village as prescribed by the Village's refuse policy. 
b.  Waste materials generated on other properties shall not be placed in Village containers. 
(4)  Noncomplying garbage cans. Garbage cans not meeting the standards of the Village are subject to removal by the Village. 
(5)  Placement of waste for pickup. 
a.  No recycling or waste material, including landscape waste, intended for regularly scheduled pickup shall be placed at the curbside sooner than 6:00 p.m. of the day prior to the date scheduled for collection. Containers placed at the curbside shall be removed from the curbside the same day as the pickup. 
b.  The time restrictions in subsection (5)a of this section shall also apply when containers are placed for alley pickup where the collection site is not directly adjacent to the resident's property (e.g., townhomes). 
c.  All waste material must be so packaged, stored or bundled that 2 persons can carry it away or load the material in an efficient manner. The weight of the waste material, including the container, shall not exceed 200 pounds (90 kg). Bagged or boxed items placed outside the container shall not exceed 50 pounds each. 
d.  All waste materials must be placed in an open space on the owner's property or on the Village parkway adjacent to the property in a spot conveniently accessible to the Village or its contractor at ground level. 
(Code 1979, § 14.12)  
Sec. 86-17. - Landscape waste and landscape and food scrap composting. 
(a)  Landscape Waste Collection. 
(1)  Landscape waste collected by the Village or its contractor at residential sites, except as provided in this section, shall be placed in biodegradable paper bags. 
(2)  Large limbs must be cut into lengths not exceeding 5 feet and shall not exceed 3 inches in diameter and shall be bundled for collection with other landscape waste. No bag of landscape waste or bundle of brush, including branches and limbs, shall exceed the weight of 50 pounds each. 
(3)  Leaves may either be pushed into the curb lane of the street during the Village's fall leaf collection or bagged like landscape waste in a biodegradable paper bag. 
(b)  Landscape and Food Scrap Composting. 
(1)  Definitions. 
a.  "Backyard Composting" shall mean an operation which (i) has no more than 25 cubic feet of landscape waste and composting material on site at any one time and (ii) is for personal use and not for any commercial activity. 
b.  "Approved Composting Bin" shall mean any composting bin which meets the specifications, as outlined by the Director of the Skokie Health Department or designee, and as may be amended from time to time. 
c.  "Permitted Composting Materials" shall mean landscape waste materials including grass clippings, leaves and twigs and food scraps such as but not limited to, vegetable scraps, fruit peels, coffee grounds, egg shells and tea leaves. 
(2)  Open compost piles of any kind are not permitted. 
(3)  Backyard Composting is permitted, in Approved Composting Bins that have been constructed in compliance with specifications set forth by the Skokie Health Department or commercial models approved by the Skokie Health Department. 
(4)  Only Permitted Composting Materials are permitted to be put into Approved Compost Bins. 
(5)  Backyard Composting is permitted in R1 Single-Family residential zoning districts and in R2 Single-Family residential zoning districts, for the benefit of the owner/occupant of the residence. Approved Composting Bins shall be located in a rear yard, and be placed a minimum of 5 feet away from all side yard lot lines. 
(6)  Required Maintenance of Approved Composting Bins. 
a.  Approved Composting Bins must be maintained in such a way as to prevent pest infestation or noxious odors. 
b.  In the event an Approved Composting Bin has been damaged or penetrated by rodents or another animal pest, then the owner or occupant of the residence, shall immediately dismantle or destroy the bin and dispose of any and all material, or cause this to happen. Failure to do so shall be a violation of the Section. 
(7)  Authorized Entry. In furtherance of the goal of maintaining the public's health and safety, the Skokie Health Department is hereby authorized entry onto private property in the following circumstances: 
a.  In the course of investigating a rodent or other pest infestation, the Skokie Health Department is authorized to examine any Approved Composting Bin located in the blocks with a known infestation and determine if the Approved Composting Bin(s) are contributing to the infestation. 
b.  If it is determined that an inspected bin is a direct cause of an infestation in the area, then the Skokie Health Department shall direct the property owner/occupant to immediately dismantle or destroy the Approved Composting Bin and dispose of any and all material, or cause this to happen or direct the property owner/occupant to make specific changes to the Approved Composting Bin within a proscribed time. In the event that the property owner/occupant fails to act and make proscribed changes and dismantle or destroy and remove all composting material, the Skokie Health Department, at the direction of the Director of Health or designee, is hereby authorized to enter on the property and dismantle or destroy the damaged bin, dispose of all material and eradicate any infestation found at the site. Any and all expenses incurred, shall be paid by the property owner. 
(Code 1979, § 14.13; Ord. No. 06-1-C-3408, § 2, 1-17-2006; Ord. No. 17-8-C-4310, § 1, 8-7-2017)  
Sec. 86-18. - Demolition, construction, renovation and other non-garbage waste requiring the use of a dumpster. 
(a)  All residential, commercial, and industrial sites where demolition, construction, renovation, clean up or like activity is underway shall have a construction dumpster or roll-off type waste receptacle for depositing all construction waste and related non-garbage litter and trash. It shall be the responsibility of both the property owner and the contractor, if applicable, to ensure regular servicing of the roll-off type waste receptacle as required and to ensure removal of the receptacle within 14 days of the completion of the work or, if applicable, prior to the issuance of a Certificate of Completion, whichever is sooner. 
(b)  All construction dumpsters and roll-off waste receptacles shall exhibit a clear and legible demarcation of owner of the receptacle, contact information, address and a 24 hour contact phone number. 
(c)  Construction dumpsters and waste receptacles shall be located on the private property undergoing construction, demolition or renovation. The location of the construction dumpster shall not block exit doors or fire lanes and said dumpsters and waste receptacles shall remain free of graffiti as defined in Section 42-41(a) of the Skokie Village Code. 
(d)  Where the private lot has limited space, the construction dumpster or similar waste receptacle may be placed in the public right-of-way provided that that the receptacle: 
(1)  Does not block the public street or right-of-way; 
(2)  Is not placed within 15 feet of a fire hydrant; 
(3)  Is not placed within 15 feet of an intersection; 
(4)  Is not placed within 8 feet of a private driveway; 
(5)  Is located in a legal parking area if parked on a street; 
(6)  Is parked 12 inches or less from the curb; 
(7)  Has one of the following types of visible safety markings: 
(a)  sufficient reflective stripes and/or reflectors visible by motorists and pedestrians; or 
(b)  possess a barricade with flashing lights at each street-side corner; 
(8)  Is free of graffiti as defined in Section 42-41(a) of the Skokie Village Code; 
(e)  It shall be the responsibility of the entity that owns the dumpster or like receptacle, to ensure safe and legal placement and maintenance of the receptacles, in accordance with this Section. 
(f)  The Village Manager or designee will address special circumstances on a case-by-case basis. 
(g)  Any dumpster or roll-off type receptacle in violation of this Section on the public right of way, is hereby declared to be a nuisance, which may be abated by any police officer by ticketing and/or removing such receptacle to a Village vehicle pound or to any authorized garage or storage area. 
(Ord. No. 02-9-C-3117, § 1, 9-3-2002; Ord. No. 02-12-C-3137, § 1, 12-2-2002; Ord. No. 16-7-C-4236, § 1, 7-18-2016)  
Secs. 86-19—86-40. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - PRIVATE COLLECTORS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference— Businesses and business regulations, ch. 26; business license fees, § 46-71 et seq. 
 
Sec. 86-41. - General policy. 
As suits the current best interest of the Village, and to better enable the Village to regulate and control the services provided to the users of solid waste services, the Mayor and Board of Trustees may provide for an exclusive franchise for the collection and disposal of solid waste for commercial, industrial, institutional and multifamily users by competitive procurement of 1 (or more) contracts with qualified scavengers. 
(Code 1979, § 14.14)  
Sec. 86-42. - Franchise and license required. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person or entity to engage in the business of collection, transportation or disposing of solid waste, from any commercial, industrial, institutional and multifamily building within the Village without first having secured an exclusive franchise and license and made payment of the license fee as provided in Section 46-73, unless said building has received an exemption pursuant to Section 86-45. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person or entity to engage in the business of collection, transportation or disposal of solid waste, from any commercial, industrial, institutional or multifamily building within the Village that have been exempted pursuant to the circumstances outlined in Section 86-45, without first having secured a license and having made payment of the license fee as provided in Section 46-73. 
(Code 1979, § 14.1401; Ord. No. 04-6-C-3276, § 1, 6-7-2004)  
Sec. 86-43. - Service under contracts. 
All commercial, industrial, institutional and multifamily buildings shall be serviced by the exclusive solid waste franchise scavenger selected by the Village. No person or entity owning or occupying a commercial, industrial, institutional or multifamily building shall enter into a contract for solid waste collection with a person or entity other than the exclusive franchisee unless said building is exempted pursuant to Section 86-45. 
(Code 1979, § 14.1402; Ord. No. 04-6-C-3276, § 2, 6-7-2004)  
Sec. 86-44. - Standards for service. 
Private scavengers operating under a license or exclusive franchise shall provide collection services as often as may be required to prevent a nuisance or a threat to public health, welfare and safety, but in no event shall service be less than once each week. The site and containers for storage of waste materials shall meet the requirements of health, sanitation and safety set by the Village Manager or designee or the Mayor and Board of Trustees. 
(Code 1979, § 14.1403)  
Sec. 86-45. - Request for exemption from franchised service. 
Any person or entity occupying any commercial, industrial, institutional or multifamily building may request, in writing, to the Village Manager or designee, that they be exempted from the franchised service. The request shall specify the circumstances that necessitate such exemption status, which may include but are not limited to a corporate contract whose provisions are outside the person's or entity's control, or a specialized service that cannot be provided by the Village franchised service. In the event an exemption is granted to a building, then the solid waste hauler servicing the building must obtain a license from the Village. 
(Code 1979, § 14.1404; Ord. No. 04-6-C-3276, § 3, 6-7-2004)  
Sec. 86-46. - Use of licensed scavenger required for persons exempted from franchised service. 
Any commercial, industrial, institutional or multifamily user that has been granted an exemption from the exclusive franchise or has a valid contract for solid waste services shall utilize only a scavenger that is licensed by the Village. 
(Code 1979, § 14.1405)  
Sec. 86-47. - Duties of franchisees and licensees. 
Each licensee or franchisee under this article shall maintain its equipment used in the designated services in good repair and working order, shall perform its operations efficiently and faithfully, and shall punctually perform all obligations imposed on it pursuant to this article. All collection equipment used by the licensee or franchisee must have the name of the firm clearly displayed on both sides of vehicles and on the front of refuse containers. 
(Code 1979, § 14.1406)  
Sec. 86-48. - Examination of records. 
Each licensee or franchisee under this article shall make and keep proper books and accounts in which complete entries shall be made of all transactions relating to the licensed or franchised services (separate and apart from all other records and accounts of the licensee or franchisee), which books and accounts shall be made available to inspection by the Village. 
(Code 1979, § 14.1407)  
Sec. 86-49. - Additional standards and specifications. 
All licensees or franchisees under this article shall meet any other standards and specifications with respect to service, fees and collection thereof, and manner of performance, as may from time to time be required by agreement of the Village and such licensee or franchisee. 
(Code 1979, § 14.1408)  
Sec. 86-50. - Indemnification of Village; insurance. 
All licensees and franchisees under this article shall indemnify, save and keep harmless the Village from any and all loss, cost, damage, expense or liability of any kind whatsoever which the Village may suffer or which may be recovered against the Village from or on account of the issuance of the license or franchise agreement or on account of any activity advocated or permitted by the Village. Licensees and franchisees shall furnish the Village a certificate of insurance for the insurance amounts indicated in a solid waste agreement, as established by the Village Manager or designee, and shall obtain additional insured coverage protecting the Village for the required amounts of insurance, which additional insured status shall be reflected in the certificate of insurance. 
(Code 1979, § 14.1409)  
Sec. 86-51. - Revocation of franchise or license. 
(a)  Authority of Village Manager. The Village Manager has the authority to temporarily revoke the license or franchise of any scavenger whose practices present an immediate threat to the health, safety and well-being of the community or any persons therein. The Village Manager has the right of permanent revocation for violation of any of the provisions of this article upon notice and after a hearing. In addition to the provisions contained in this article, the Village Manager shall have the authority to establish rules and regulations for the conduct of a hearing relating to the revocation or suspension of a franchise or license. 
(b)  Grounds. The Village Manager is hereby given the authority to revoke or suspend a franchise or license if the Village Manager finds: 
(1)  The franchisee or licensee has not complied with applicable codes, ordinances, statutes, laws, policies or rules and regulations. 
(2)  The franchisee or licensee has made fraudulent, false or misrepresentative statements in the application for the franchise or license. 
(3)  The franchisee or licensee owes the Village required fees or outstanding fines or penalties. 
(c)  Contents and service of notices. 
(1)  Contents. All notices required to be given in accordance with this section shall be in writing, setting forth the reasons for the denial or revocation of the franchise or license. The notice shall inform the franchisee or licensee that the franchisee or licensee has the right to request a hearing before the Village Manager. 
(2)  Service. All notices shall be sent by certified mail, return receipt requested, to the franchisee or licensee specified in the franchise or license. Notice shall be considered given on the date such notice is mailed. 
(d)  Hearings. The Village Manager or designee shall send notice of intent to revoke a franchise or license. A franchise or license shall not be revoked unless the franchisee or licensee has had an opportunity to present evidence in the franchisee's or licensee's behalf. The Village Manager or designee shall, within 5 business days of the hearing, issue a written order of the findings. Such written order shall be sent to the franchisee or licensee in accordance with the notice provisions of subsection (c) of this section. If, within 10 days of the notice, the franchisee or licensee does not request a hearing in writing, the franchise or license shall be revoked. 
(Code 1979, § 14.1410)  
Sec. 86-52. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 04-6-C-3276, § 4, adopted June 7, 2004, deleted § 86-52 in its entirety. Former § 86-52 pertained to the effective date for use of franchised contractor and derived from Code 1979, § 14.1411.  
Chapter 89 - STREET NAMES AND ADDRESS NUMBERS 
 
Sec. 89-1. - General. 
The Village shall have an established address numbering and street naming system. 
(Ord. No. 09-6-C-3678, § 2, 6-1-2009)  
Sec. 89-2. - Authority. 
The Village shall have the sole authority to assign address numbers and street names to any and all properties within its jurisdiction. The Village may also reassign address numbers and street names if it determines that an existing address number or street name is in violation of the conditions set below or is impeding public safety response. 
(Ord. No. 09-6-C-3678, § 2, 6-1-2009)  
Sec. 89-3. - Record of address. 
The Village Manager or designee shall keep a listing showing the official address of every property in the Village, which shall be open to inspection by anyone interested. 
(Ord. No. 09-6-C-3678, § 2, 6-1-2009)  
Sec. 89-4. - Required address number. 
All buildings, parks, stand-alone parking lots, construction sites, and vacant lots in the Village shall have an assigned address number. 
(Ord. No. 09-6-C-3678, § 2, 6-1-2009)  
Sec. 89-5. - Address numbering procedures. 
(a)  All addresses shall follow the continuation of the Village's grid system and shall maintain a street frontage interval of 20 feet per address. A building/structure's address number shall be assigned at the location where the front entrance falls relative to its position along the street frontage interval. 
(b)  No single-tenant building/structure shall use more than one address number. 
(c)  Multiple address numbers for buildings on corner lots shall be prohibited unless occupants within those buildings have separate entrances on different streets. 
(d)  No half (e.g. 4000 ½ Main Street) or alphanumeric address numbers (e.g. 4000A Main Street) shall be used. 
(e)  Address numbers for parks, stand-alone parking lots, and vacant properties shall be assigned based upon the location of the midpoint of the property's shortest street frontage relative to the frontage unit interval along the block face. 
(f)  Where multiple residences or businesses share one common entrance, one address number shall be used and shall have a unit numbering system that adheres to the following conditions: 
(1)  Alphabetic (e.g. unit A), three-digit numeric (e.g. unit 101), or alphanumeric (e.g. unit 1A) unit numbers shall be assigned to each unit. 
(2)  Alphabetic, three-digit numeric, or alphanumeric unit numbers may be used in buildings with one floor. 
(3)  Only three-digit numeric or alphanumeric unit numbers shall be used in buildings with more than one floor. 
(4)  Unit numbers shall reflect the floor that the unit is located on (e.g. unit 401 is located on the fourth floor and unit 2B is located on the second floor). 
(5)  Buildings with units in the basement shall use three-digit numeric unit numbers beginning with zeroes (e.g. unit 001) or lower-level alphanumeric unit numbers (e.g. unit LL5) only. 
(6)  Combinations of alphabetic, three-digit numeric, and alphanumeric unit numbers within one building are prohibited. 
(g)  Directional prefixes shall not be used within an address (e.g. 4000 W. Main Street). 
(Ord. No. 09-6-C-3678, § 2, 6-1-2009)  
Sec. 89-6. - Posting of address numbers. 
(a)  It is the duty of the owners and occupants of every building in the Village to display address numbers in a position to be plainly legible and visible from the street. 
(b)  All address numbers shall be a minimum of 4 inches high with a minimum stroke width of 0.5 inch. 
(c)  All address numbers shall contrast with their background. 
(d)  Where alleys are present, the address numbers shall also be posted on a garage such that the address is visible from the alley. If no garage is present, the address numbers shall be posted on the rear door, rear wall, or rear porch of the principle building, or on the rear gate behind the principle building, such that the address number is visible from the alley. Businesses shall post their address numbers on their rear door, regardless of whether an alley is present or not. 
(e)  Where a residence or business exists on a corner lot, the address numbers shall be posted such that they face the street used in the address. 
(f)  Where multiple residences share one common entrance, the unit number shall be provided on each mailbox. The unit number shall also be posted on all interior and exterior points of entry to the unit. 
(g)  Where multiple businesses share one common entrance, the business name and unit number shall be listed on a directory in the lobby. 
(h)  In instances where a tenant occupies more than one storefront or the business spans multiple connected buildings, and the storefronts or connected buildings each have individual addresses, the tenant shall use the address of the storefront where the entrance is located and remove all addressing labels from the other storefronts or connected buildings. 
(i)  In instances where a tenant occupies multiple units in a building, the tenant shall post and use the address number of the unit that functions as the main entrance. The address numbers of adjoining combined units on a single floor shall be removed. 
(j)  All sites and buildings under construction shall post the address of the site or building under construction on the construction fence surrounding the property so that it is visible from the street. If no construction fence is present, the address shall be posted on the building so that it is visible from the street. If no new address has yet been assigned for the site or building under construction, the existing address of the site shall be used. 
(k)  Village staff shall have the authority to determine additional locations where address numbers need to be posted, if necessary. 
(l)  It shall be prohibited for any person to remove any address numbers placed on any property in accordance with this section, except for repair or replacement of such address numbers. 
(m)  It shall be prohibited to display any address number on any such building or property other than as designated in this section and approved by the Village. 
(Ord. No. 09-6-C-3678, § 2, 6-1-2009)  
Sec. 89-7. - Naming of Streets. 
(a)  All platted public or private streets shall be named consistent with the existing grid system, except as indicated below. 
(b)  Non-standard street designations shall be as follows: 
(1)  Any newly platted public or private street that is 660 feet in length or less and is parallel to the existing grid system or is in between the regular grid streets shall use the name of the street to its south or east and "Terrace" as its street designation (e.g. Kostner Terrace). 
(2)  Any newly platted public or private street that terminates in a permanent dead-end shall use "Court" as its street designation (e.g. Lee Court). 
(3)  Any newly platted curvilinear public or private street that does not follow the grid system shall use "Lane" as its street designation (e.g. Salem Lane). 
(c)  A public or private street shall not be designated by more than one name, except where the street is also a numbered County, State, or U.S. route (example: Skokie Boulevard is also known as U.S. Route 41). Temporary or permanent honorary street names shall not be permitted. 
(d)  Any change to the name of a public or private street shall require approval by the Mayor and Board of Trustees and be subject to the following conditions: 
(1)  The applicant shall file with the Community Development Department a written request demonstrating a need critical to public safety or emergency response or to rename the street to be consistent with the existing grid system. 
(2)  The applicant shall submit to the Community Development Department a signed and verifiable petition containing the signatures of a minimum of 60 percent of the occupants and property owners adjacent to the street affected by the proposed name change. 
(3)  Upon approval of the request, the applicant shall be responsible for the Village's cost of producing the new street signs. One sign for each intersection is required. 
(Ord. No. 09-6-C-3678, § 2, 6-1-2009)  
Sec. 89-8. - Violations. 
Any building, unit, lot, property, owner, occupant in violation of this Section shall be subject to penalties provided in Section 1-6 of the Village Code. 
(Ord. No. 09-6-C-3678, § 2, 6-1-2009)  
Chapter 90 - STREETS, SIDEWALKS AND OTHER PUBLIC PLACES[1] 
Footnotes:

Cross reference— Ordinances levying taxes or making special assessments or establishing special taxing districts saved from repeal, § 1-3(2); ordinances relating to the establishment, dedication, opening, grade, naming, improvements, altering, widening or vacating of streets, alleys, sidewalks, parks or public grounds saved from repeal, § 1-3(5); ordinances authorizing or relating to particular public improvements saved from repeal, § 1-3(7); ordinances relating to railroads or railroad crossings with streets and other public ways or relating to conduct, duties, service or rates of public utilities saved from repeal, § 1-3(8); Department of Public Works, § 2-241 et seq.; billposting and distribution of handbills, § 6-31 et seq.; distributing handbills in public places, § 6-37; animals in public areas, § 18-37; buildings and building regulations, ch. 22; numbering of buildings, § 22-301 et seq.; sidewalk sales, § 26-1301 et seq.; community development, ch. 30; environment, ch. 42; fees for street and sidewalk work, § 46-161; spitting in public place, § 54-6; smoking in public places, § 58-61 et seq.; obstructing pedestrian or vehicular traffic, unlawful assemblages, § 70-121 et seq.; scaffolds or ladders on streets, § 70-156; indecent or lewd writing in public places, § 70-244; parades and public assemblies, ch. 74; peddlers and solicitors, ch. 78; signs, ch. 82; subdivisions, ch. 94; water, sewer and street improvements in subdivisions, § 94-7; deposit for cost of street signs, § 94-8; telecommunications, ch. 102; traffic and vehicles, ch. 106; temporary street closings, § 106-44; one-way streets, § 106-50; authority to restrict use of streets, § 106-53; riding bicycles on sidewalk, § 106-227; utilities, ch. 110; vehicles for hire, ch. 114; zoning, ch. 118.

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 90-1. - Skokie owned or leased property; hours of operation. 
(a)  All property and facilities either owned or leased by Skokie shall close daily at 11:00 p.m. and reopen daily at 4:30 a.m. The Village Manager or designee is hereby authorized to post signage indicating different hours of operation, if warranted, in his or her judgement. 
(b)  The hours of operation outlined in Section 90-1(a), shall not apply to roadways, alleys, and other public rights-of-way or to the properties containing the Skokie Police Station and Skokie Fire Stations. 
(Ord. No. 18-5-C-4380, § 1, 5-22-2018)  
Sec. 90-2. - Keeping or storing of personal items on Skokie owned or leased property; removal of items. 
(a)  No person may keep, hold, harbor or store personal belongings or personal property on any Skokie owned or leased property, facility or location without written permission from the Village Manager or designee. 
(b)  Any personal belonging left or stored in violation of Section 90-2(a) shall be subject to removal by Skokie. There shall be no obligation on the part of Skokie to store, hold inventory or return such material. 
(Ord. No. 18-5-C-4380, § 1, 5-22-2018)  
Secs. 90-3—90-30. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - STREETS AND SIDEWALKS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference— Fees for construction of parking areas and driveways, § 46-125; fees for street and sidewalk work, § 46-161 et seq. 
 
Sec. 90-31. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Carriage walk means that portion of a street immediately adjacent to the curb parallel to the street that is intended for ingress and egress from the street or vehicles located upon the street which is separated from the sidewalk by the parkway and which was originally installed by the owner of and for the benefit of the adjacent property. 
Driveway means that portion of the street that is intended for vehicular travel to and from the street to the adjacent property which was installed and constructed by the owner of the adjacent property. 
Parkway means any portion of the right-of-way not improved by a street or sidewalk. 
Permittee means any person who has been issued a permit and has agreed to fulfill all the terms and requirements of this article and the specifications adopted in connection therewith. 
Service walk means that portion of the street which is intended for pedestrian travel to and from the sidewalk to the adjacent property or to and from the street to the sidewalk. 
Sidewalk means that portion of a street that is intended for pedestrian travel and is situated between the curblines or the lateral outside lines of the street and the adjacent property lines, except that portion thereof defined in this section as a parkway, carriage walk, service walk or driveway. 
Street means the entire width between property lines of every public way, easement, right-of-way, highway, alley, road, or curb of every nature whatsoever when any part or all thereof is open to the use of the public as a matter of right for the purpose of vehicular traffic. 
(Code 1979, § 8.01) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 90-32. - Penalties. 
Any person who violates any provision of this article shall be subject to the penalties provided in Section 1-6 in addition to any other penalty specifically provided for. 
(Ord. No. 00-10-C-2947, § 1(8.27), 10-16-2000)  
Sec. 90-33. - Notice of violation. 
Whenever any person violates any provision of this article, such person shall be served with a violation notice providing for an opportunity to appear in court to answer the charge of such violation. 
(Ord. No. 00-10-C-2947, § 1(8.28), 10-16-2000)  
Sec. 90-34. - Stipulated settlements. 
The Village Manager or designee is authorized to accept the amounts specified in Section 1-7 in settlement for violations of the specified Code sections and to establish settlement dates for each such violation. For violations where a showing of compliance is applicable, settlement as provided for in this section shall only be authorized upon a showing of compliance. 
(Ord. No. 00-10-C-2947, § 1(8.29), 10-16-2000)  
Sec. 90-35. - Work on public ways. 
(a)  Supervision and control. The maintenance, repair, new construction, curb cuts, excavation and pavement cuts or street openings of streets, sidewalks, alleys, curbs and other public ways shall be supervised, controlled, and under the direction of the Village Manager or designee and, the Village Manager or designee is hereby charged with the duty, and authorized, to enforce the provisions of this article in the Manager's or designee's official capacity on behalf of the Village. 
(b)  Permit required. It shall be unlawful for any person to construct, reconstruct, alter, grade, or lay any pavement or surfacing material, tunnel, open or excavate on any public street, sidewalk, alley, curb or other public way in the Village, or to repair any public street, sidewalk, alley, curb or other public way, or to make curb cuts, without a permit from the Village as provided by this article. 
(c)  Emergency work. Any person maintaining pipes, lines, cables, conduits, or any other underground facilities in or under the surface of any street, sidewalk, alley or other public way may proceed with an opening without a permit being first obtained when unforeseen circumstances or occurrences constituting a clear and immediate danger to persons or property create an emergency, in which event the necessary work may be done immediately; provided, however, that the person charged with the responsibility of making the tunnel, opening or excavation shall apply for a permit on the first regular business day and the permit shall be retroactive to the date when the work was begun. 
(d)  Application for permit. 
(1)  Applications for permits under this section shall be made to the Village Manager or designee on forms prescribed and furnished by the Village Manager or designee. The Village Manager or designee may request additional information from the applicant. The applicant shall provide proof of insurance for a comprehensive general liability insurance policy issued by an insurance company authorized to do business in the State in an amount of not less than $1,000,000.00. Cancellation of the insurance shall automatically suspend the permit. 
(2)  Contractors who are required to be licensed by the State shall provide proof of such license. 
(3)  A bond will be required to guarantee proper construction of the work as provided in Section 90-37. 
(4)  A certificate of arrangement to protect against interference with underground public utility facilities shall be required to be filed with the application for permit. 
(e)  Transfer of permit. No permit shall be assigned or transferred to any other person or corporation other than to the person to whom such permit was issued. No individual or corporation other than the permittee shall act under such permit. The work shall not be done in any place other than the location specifically designated in the permit. 
(f)  Permit fee. Fees for permits under this section shall be as set forth in Section 46-161. 
(g)  Violations; stop work order. If the Village Manager or designee as a result of inspection shall find that the work being done or the work that has been done is in violation of the provisions of this article or any other code, ordinance, statute, or rule or regulation, the Manager or designee shall promptly notify the permittee to cease and discontinue violation or noncompliance or the work resulting in the violation or noncompliance. Upon the failure of the permittee to discontinue the Village Manager or designee is authorized to stop further work. If the work has proceeded to completion in violation of this article, the bond posted in accordance with this article shall not be refunded. 
(h)  Notice of violation. The notice required under subsection (g) of this section shall be in writing and delivered directly to the permittee or any one of the permittee's agents or employees. Such notification shall specifically set forth the nature of the violation. 
(Code 1979, § 8.02; Ord. No. 04-12-C-3320, § 6, 12-6-2004)  
Sec. 90-36. - Construction and repair of sidewalks. 
(a)  Sidewalks required. A public sidewalk is required along all rights-of-way containing a street that abuts a lot, unless otherwise provided in this Article. 
(b)  Design. The design and materials of the sidewalk and other required sidewalk amenities and parkway elements are determined by the Village and must conform to the sidewalk plan for the area. These amenities and elements include, but are not limited to, handicapped accessibility improvements, landscaping, lighting, pavers, service walks, curbs and gutters, and driveway aprons. 
(c)  Handicapped accessibility improvements. All new curbs and sidewalks must meet federal, state, and Village handicapped accessibility standards and may only be constructed with a Village permit. Any substandard curbs and sidewalks must be made to conform to those standards in conjunction with any new construction or reconstruction within the right-of-way or on an abutting lot. 
(d)  Requirement for applicant for a building permit. As a condition of obtaining a building permit for any work with a construction value that equals or exceeds $10,000.00, the applicant must pay the Sidewalk Installation and Repair Fee. 
(e)  When a sidewalk is not present in an adjoining public way for any use other than a single-family residence, the applicant must also either construct a public sidewalk or pay into a dedicated fund an amount calculated on the Village's cost of sidewalk construction under the terms of the existing contract for new sidewalk construction at the time the work is performed or an estimate determined by the Village Manager or designee. In areas with a unique sidewalk design and plan, including but not limited to the areas of Dempster Street, Main Street and Downtown, the amount paid shall be based on the Village's cost estimate for implementing the improvements as determined by the Village Manager or his designee. This determination shall be based on a review of the site plan, the location of nearby existing sidewalks, and the sidewalk plan for the area. The applicant must also repair any preexisting adjoining damaged public sidewalks, curbs, and parkways, and any damage or alteration of any area outside the owner's property caused by the work permitted. 
(f)  Failure to complete work. A certificate of occupancy or certificate of completion for the building will not be issued until the work in the abutting right-or-way is constructed or repaired as shown on the approved plans or drawings or a payment made into the Sidewalk Installation or Repair Fund. 
(g)  Responsibility for maintenance. Property owners must maintain sidewalks, parkways, service walks, carriage walks, and driveway aprons in adjoining public ways in a reasonably safe condition for the use for which these facilities were intended. The Village shall have a right to recover from the adjoining property owner any sums for which the Village may be held liable as a result of a property owner's failure to maintain the areas specified in this subsection. 
(h)  Action taken for failure to maintain. If sidewalks and other improvements are not maintained as required in subsection (g) of this section, the Village will take the following actions: 
(1)  Notice. The Director of Public Works or designee shall send the adjoining property owner responsible for maintenance a notice by certified mail, return receipt requested, informing the owner which sections of sidewalk or improvements will be replaced or repaired by the Village and the costs or charges due. Within 10 days from the owner's receipt of the certified mailing of the notice as shown by the return receipt, the adjoining property owner shall have the right to file an objection with the Director of Public Works or designee objecting to the necessity for the work and the amount of the charge. All decisions by the Director of Public Works can be appealed to the Village Manager within 10 days of the Director's decision, and the Manager's decision is final and non-appealable. There is no fee to file such objections. 
(2)  Calculation of cost. The cost to the property owner shall be divided evenly between the Village and the property owner, and shall be based on the Village's cost of sidewalk construction under the terms of the existing contract for sidewalk replacement or repair at the time the work is performed. In areas with a unique sidewalk design and plan, including but not limited to the areas of Dempster Street, Main Street and Downtown, the amount paid shall be based on the Village's cost estimate for implementing the improvements. The property owner shall also pay an additional 10 percent of the full construction cost to cover program administration expenses. 
(3)  Recovery of charges. If the cost determined in subsection (g)(2) has not been remitted to the Village within 30 days from mailing of the bill to the owner, the Village will seek to recover the cost in an appropriate action instituted by the Corporation Counsel and cause a lien to be recorded against the property involved for any uncollected charges owed the Village to maintain sidewalks and other improvements. Upon receipt of payment of the costs and any additional expenses incurred by the Village to file the lien, the lien shall be released by the Village. Any recording of the release of lien shall be the responsibility of the owner and at the owner's expense. 
(Code 1979, § 8.03; Ord. No. 04-12-C-3320, § 6, 12-6-2004; Ord. No. 12-5-C-3905, § 3, 5-21-2012)  
Sec. 90-37. - Bonds. 
(a)  Prior to the issuance of a permit under Section 90-35(b) and (c), the applicant shall have an indemnity and performance bond issued to the Village in a sum determined by the Village Manager. The bond shall be for the faithful observance and performance by the applicant for the permit of all of the provisions of this article for which the permit is issued and compliance with all codes, ordinances, statutes and rules and regulations. The bond shall further provide for the indemnification of the Village and hold the Village harmless for all property damage or personal injury resulting from the permittee. 
(b)  In any case where a permittee under this article shall be in default or shall otherwise fail to complete the work or fail to comply with the requirements of this article or be in violation of the codes, ordinances, or rules and regulations of the Village, the Village Manager or designee shall invoke the penalty of the bond and order the completion of the work to be done on behalf of the Village. If the cost of the work to be done exceeds the proceeds recoverable by the Village under the bond, the Village shall recover the additional cost, in an action at law, from the permittee. 
(Code 1979, § 8.04)  
Sec. 90-38. - Street specifications. 
(a)  The repair, construction, and reconstruction of streets, sidewalks, alleys, curbs, and curb cuts of all other public ways shall, unless otherwise provided by special ordinances of the Mayor and Board of Trustees, conform to all Village specifications and all applicable codes, ordinances, statutes and rules and regulations. 
(b)  The Village Manager or designee shall have the duty to prepare, from time to time, and keep on file in the appropriate office of the Village, such specifications as to material and manner of construction and repair which will provide the Village good and durable streets, sidewalks, alleys and curbs. 
(Code 1979, § 8.05)  
Sec. 90-39. - Work done by Village or by Village contractors exempt from permit requirement. 
The provisions of this article relative to obtaining permits shall not apply to officers, employees, or contractors of the Village engaged in doing work for or on behalf of the Village. 
(Code 1979, § 8.06)  
Sec. 90-40. - Damage to streets or sidewalks. 
(a)  New streets or sidewalks. 
(1)  It shall be unlawful for any person to walk upon or drive any vehicle over and upon, or place an object or permit an animal to go upon, any newly laid street, sidewalk, curb or alley constructed of concrete or any other material while the street, sidewalk, curb or alley is guarded by a warning sign or barricade, or is under construction, or in any other manner damage any soft or newly laid street, sidewalk, curb or alley. 
(2)  It shall be unlawful to drive a vehicle over and upon, or walk upon, or place an object or permit an animal to go upon, any street or alley in the Village after oil or other liquid, asphalt, macadam, stone chips or other material has been freshly applied, during the time such street or alley is under construction. 
(b)  Vehicles. It shall be unlawful for any person to propel, drive or operate any type of vehicle, or any type of mechanical device, upon, along or across any street, sidewalk, curb, alley or parkway in such manner as to break, crack, damage or injure the street, sidewalk, curb, alley or parkway. 
(c)  Duty to repair damage. In addition to the penalties provided in Section 1-6, any person who violates any of the provisions of this section and damages any street, sidewalk, curb, alley or parkway shall, without cost to the Village, repair, replace or reconstruct such damage. 
(Code 1979, § 8.07) 
Cross reference— Vehicles or equipment damaging street or sidewalk, § 106-52.  
Sec. 90-41. - Parkways. 
(a)  Use. Parkways shall be used exclusively as an ornamental strip for the planting of grass, trees, flowers or other surface material approved by the Village. 
(b)  Permit for cutting trees. It shall be unlawful to remove, cut down, trim or damage any trees or shrubs in any parkway or other public place without a permit therefor from the Village Manager or designee, except as provided in subsection (c) of this section. 
(c)  Trees on private property overhanging street or sidewalk. Any trees or shrubs on private property which overhang any parkway, sidewalk, street or other public place, including alleys, in such a way as to impede or interfere with traffic or travel on such public places shall be trimmed or removed by the owners or those in control of the premises where such trees or shrubs grow so that the obstruction shall cease. If, after due notice, such overhanging trees or shrubs have not been trimmed or removed within 10 calendar days, then the Village Manager or designee shall have the authority to do so, and the costs for such removal may be assessed against such owner or person in control. No notice shall be required if the overhanging trees or shrubs constitute an imminent threat to public health or safety; provided, however, that in such an event the owner or person in control shall be assessed with costs. 
(d)  Assessment of costs incurred by Village. Any costs incurred by the Village, or its duly appointed officers or agents, in trimming or removing trees or shrubs in accordance with subsection (c) of this section shall be assessed against an owner or person in control of the property where the shrubs or trees are located. Such costs may result in a lien upon the real estate and the lien shall be superior to all other liens and encumbrances, except tax liens. The Village, or person performing the service by authority of the Village, in its or such person's own name, shall file a notice of lien in the office of the Recorder of Deeds for Cook County. The notice shall consist of a sworn statement setting out (i) a description of the real estate sufficient for identification thereof, (ii) the amount of money representing the costs and expenses incurred or payable for the service, and (iii) the date or dates when such costs and expenses were incurred by the Village or one acting under its direction and authority. Upon payment of the costs and expense by the owner of or persons interested in such property after notice of lien has been filed, the lien shall be released by the Village or person in whose name the lien has been filed and the release shall be filed of record, at the expense of the adjacent property owner, as in the case of filing notice of lien. 
(e)  Attaching signs to trees or other plants. It shall be unlawful to attach any sign, advertisement or notice to any tree, shrub or landscape material in any street, parkway or other public place in the Village, except the temporary posting of notices of danger or warning of unsafe conditions or Village notices. 
(f)  Posting of political signs on election day. On official election days within the Village, signs relating to candidates for public office, political parties, and referenda may be posted in public rights-of-way. No sign shall be posted closer than 100 feet to a polling place or farther than 300 feet from a polling place. All such signs shall be removed when the polls close. 
Cross reference— Signs, ch. 82. 
(g)  Trimming of trees near poles and wires. Any person given the right to maintain poles and wires in the streets, alleys or other public places, in the absence of provision in the franchise concerning the subject, shall keep such wires and poles free from and away from any trees or shrubs so far as may be possible, and shall keep such trees and shrubs properly trimmed and subject to the supervision of the Village Manager or designee, so that no injury or damage shall be done to the shrubs and trees by contact with such poles or wires. 
(h)  Excavations. Any person making an excavation in any street or other public or private place shall exercise due and proper care to avoid injury to the roots of any tree or shrub wherever possible, and excavations made on parkways shall be resodded after closing so as to restore the area to its prior condition. 
(i)  Vehicle parking. Vehicle parking in the parkway shall be allowed upon the approval of the Village Manager or designee as part of a Village-approved plan in designated redevelopment areas in the M-1 Office Assembly Industry, M-2 Light Industry and M-3 Industry Districts in accordance with the Zoning Ordinance (Chapter 118). 
(j)  Agreement by applicant for building permit to plant trees in the public right-of-way. In every application for permit to construct a new residence or an addition to a residence that is greater than 400 square feet in area or to erect, construct, alter, or remodel any commercial, industrial, institutional, or public building, structure, or facility the applicant shall agree to plant trees, or pay the Village for the planting of trees, in the public parkway to complete the Village's tree planting pattern. The location of trees, species, and size shall be shown in the submitted plans or drawings and shall conform to Village specifications, codes, ordinances, and rules and regulations. 
(Code 1979, § 8.08; Ord. No. 00-4-C-2887, § 1, 4-3-2000; Ord. No. 04-12-C-3320, § 6, 12-6-2004)  
Sec. 90-42. - Trees on public property. 
(a)  Purpose; applicability; authority of Village Manager. 
(1)  It is hereby declared to be the policy of the Village to regulate and control the planting, transplanting, removal, maintenance and protection of trees and shrubs in the Village in order to eliminate and guard against dangerous conditions which may result in injury to persons using the streets, alleys, sidewalks or property of the Village; to promote and enhance the beauty and general welfare of the public; to prevent damage to any street, sidewalk or other Village property; to protect trees and shrubs located in public areas owned by the Village from undesirable and unsafe planting, removal, treatment and maintenance practices; and to guard all trees and shrubs on Village property against the spread of pests and disease. It is the intent of the Village that the provisions of this section shall apply to all trees and plants growing or planted in or upon any public right-of-way or other premises owned or controlled by the Village. 
(2)  The Village Manager or designee is hereby empowered to superintend and regulate the planting, preservation, protection and maintenance of trees on all public ways of the Village. No person shall plant any tree or plant on any public way or place any planting thereon until the Village Manager or designee has issued a permit for such planting. 
(b)  Approved species. Tree species planted in the parkway must conform to the parkway tree planting list as approved by the Village Manager or designee. 
(c)  Removal of diseased or damaged trees. All crippled, deformed and physically damaged trees, regardless of species, if professional opinion indicates that recovery and normal development cannot be expected, shall be removed. All trees infected with a non-curable disease that will result in deformation, death and infection of other trees shall be removed. 
(d)  Spacing. All new plantings in parkways shall conform with a tree spacing of 30 feet, except where the Village Manager or designee has determined that the tree species planted is appropriate for the planting space available. 
(e)  Planting requirements. 
(1)  Trees, when planted, shall have a minimum trunk diameter of 2 inches measured at a distance of 6 inches above ground level and shall be free from deformity and indication of undesirable growth characteristics. 
(2)  Trees, when planted, shall be free of infectious disease or insect infestation. 
(3)  No trees may be planted on parkways less than 3 feet wide, unless, in the opinion of the Village Manager or designee, the planting and the species of tree approved will not endanger the sidewalk, curb or other property. 
(4)  Planting of trees is prohibited under the following conditions: 
a.  If such planting interferes with existing or planned structures or existing or planned underground or overhead utilities, such as sewers, pipes, or cables. 
b.  If such planting would create a hazardous traffic situation by impairing driver or pedestrian visibility at intersections or where traffic controls are located. 
(f)  Spraying, injections and pruning. Spraying and injections of trees in parkways for the prevention and elimination of diseases and insect infestation shall be performed to meet the specific requirements of the species of tree and the particular disease or insect infestation which exists or threatens. It shall be the responsibility of the Village Manager or designee to determine the need and extent of spraying, injections and pruning requirements. 
(g)  Tree protection. 
(1)  Protection during construction work. During any type of construction work, the owner or contractor shall place guards around all nearby trees on the parkway or any other public ways to prevent injury to such trees or plants. In case of injury to a tree or plant, an approved replacement must be furnished. 
(2)  Wires. No person shall permanently attach or connect any electric or other wire to any tree or permit any such wire to come in contact with any tree. 
(3)  Placing materials around trees. No person shall place or maintain upon the ground around a parkway tree any surfacing or material which will impede free passage of water and air to the roots without leaving an open space of not less than 2 feet in width around the tree. 
(h)  Planting and replacement of trees by Village. The Village retains the right to plant parkway trees wherever needed in conformance with this section. 
(i)  Permit required for trimming or removing trees. 
(1)  No person shall, without a permit from the Village Manager or designee, remove, destroy, break, cut, deface, trim or injure or interfere with any tree or plant growing in any street, parkway, or public place in the Village. 
(2)  When such trees or shrubs are damaged or broken by the force of nature in such a manner as to constitute a threat to life or property, then such owner or person in control shall promptly remove them or the parts thereof which constitute the danger and shall report such person's actions to the Village Manager or designee within a reasonable period thereafter. 
(Code 1979, § 8.09)  
Sec. 90-43. - Obstructions to view at intersections. 
(a)  Street intersections. The owner or occupant of every lot or parcel of land adjoining a street intersecting with another street upon which any trees, shrubs, bushes or plants are growing shall trim, prune or cut the trees, shrubs, bushes or plants or cause the trees, shrubs, bushes or plants to be trimmed, pruned or cut so as not to obstruct the passage of light from any streetlight or traffic signal light or interfere with or obstruct the vision of persons using the streets. The existence of any trees, shrubs, bushes or plants on the premises of any owner or occupant adjoining a street intersecting with another street which shall obstruct the passage of light from any streetlight or traffic signal light or which shall interfere with or obstruct the vision at street intersections or the intersection of a street with a public way is hereby declared to constitute a public nuisance. It shall be unlawful for any owner or occupant of such premises to fail, neglect or refuse to abate such nuisance by removing, trimming, cutting or pruning such tree, shrub, bush or plant within 5 days after being notified in writing to do so by the Village Manager or designee. 
(b)  Driveway and alley intersections. The owner or occupant of every lot or parcel of land adjacent to a driveway or upon which a driveway exists and where such driveway intersects with a street or where such lot or parcel of land is adjacent to an alley intersecting with a street upon which any trees, shrubs, bushes or plants are growing shall trim, prune or cut the trees, shrubs, bushes or plants or cause the trees, shrubs, bushes or plants to be trimmed, pruned or cut so as to maintain a visual angle of 10 feet from the intersecting street, alley or driveway and to have a maximum height of 30 inches within the visual angle distance. The existence of any trees, shrubs, bushes or plants on the premises of any owner or occupant of land adjacent to a driveway or upon which a driveway exists and where such driveway intersects with a street or where such lot or parcel of land is adjacent to an alley intersecting with a street within the visual angle distance mentioned in this subsection is hereby declared to constitute a public nuisance.
