(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to drive any vehicle in violation of markings, signs, barriers or other devices so placed to designate street, parts of streets or specific lanes thereon upon which vehicular traffic shall proceed in one direction during one period and the opposite direction during another period of the day. 
(Code 1979, § 51.13) 
Cross reference— Streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 90. 
State Law reference— Authority to designate one-way streets, 625 ILCS 5/11-208(a)(4); one-way roadways, 625 ILCS 5/11-708.  
Sec. 106-51. - Duties of pedestrians. 
(a)  Use of crosswalks. Whenever, upon the basis of an engineering or traffic investigation it is determined that pedestrian crossing between intersections shall be prohibited in the interest of public safety, pedestrians shall not cross between intersections except at a marked crosswalk. Such regulations against pedestrians crossing between intersections shall become effective when appropriate signs are erected. 
(b)  Crossing roadway in mixed-use or business zoning district. No pedestrian shall cross a roadway other than in a crosswalk in any mixed-use or business zoning district. 
(c)  Crossing limited access street. No pedestrian shall cross the roadway of a limited access street or highway other than by means of those facilities which have been constructed as pedestrian crossing or at those points where marked crosswalks have been provided. 
(d)  Use of pedestrian bridges. No pedestrian shall cross a roadway where a public bridge with a sidewalk has been provided other than by such sidewalk and as designated by the erection of appropriate signs or fencing. 
(e)  Passing through railroad gate. No pedestrian shall pass through, around, over, or under any crossing gate or barrier at a railroad grade crossing or bridge while such gate or barrier is closed or is being opened or closed. 
(f)  Direction of crossing. No pedestrian shall cross a roadway at any place other than by a route at right angles to the curb or by the shortest route to the opposite curb except in a marked crosswalk. 
(g)  Walking into path of vehicle. No pedestrian shall suddenly leave a curb or other place of safety and walk or turn into the path of a vehicle which is so close that it is impossible for the driver to yield. 
(Code 1979, § 51.14; Ord. No. 09-2-C-3664, § 1, 2-17-2009) 
State Law reference— Authority to prohibit pedestrian crossings at other than designated and marked crosswalks or at intersections, 625 ILCS 5/11-208(a)(12); pedestrians' rights and duties, 625 ILCS 5/11-1001 et seq.  
Sec. 106-52. - Vehicles or equipment damaging street or sidewalk. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to propel, drive, or operate, or cause to be propelled, driven, or operated any type of motor vehicle, or any type of mechanical device of any nature whatsoever, over, upon, along or across any street, sidewalk, curb, alley or parkway, in such manner as to break, crack, damage, or injure the street, sidewalk, curb, alley or parkway. 
(Code 1979, § 51.15) 
Cross reference— Damage to streets or sidewalks, § 90-40. 
State Law reference— Liability if highway or structure damaged, 625 ILCS 5/15-318.  
Sec. 106-53. - Authority to restrict use of streets. 
The Village Manager, with respect to streets under the jurisdiction of the Village, is authorized, subject to the approval of the Mayor and Board of Trustees, to determine and designate those streets or parts of streets upon which the operation of trucks or other commercial vehicles shall be prohibited or upon which the use of such vehicles shall be restricted by imposing limitations as to the weight of such vehicles. The Village Manager or designee shall erect and maintain appropriate signs. 
(Code 1979, § 51.16) 
Cross reference— Streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 90. 
State Law reference— Authority to restrict use of streets, 625 ILCS 5/11-208(a)(7).  
Sec. 106-54. - Permit for vehicles of excess size and weight. 
(a)  Authorized. When in the Village Manager's judgment an emergency exists, the Village Manager, with respect to streets and highways under the jurisdiction of the Village, may, in the Manager's discretion, upon application in writing and good cause being shown therefor, pursuant to the provisions of 625 ILCS 5/15-301, issue a special permit in writing authorizing the applicant to operate or move a vehicle or combination of vehicles of a size or weight of vehicle or load exceeding the maximum specified in the laws of the State or otherwise not in conformity with the provisions of this article upon any street or highway under the jurisdiction of the Village. 
(b)  Application. The application for any such permit shall specifically describe the vehicle or vehicles and load to be operated or moved and the particular streets or highways for which the permit to operate is requested, and whether such permit is requested for a single trip or for continuous operation. 
(c)  Issuance; conditions. The Village Manager is authorized to issue or withhold such permit at the Manager's discretion. Any permit is issued in accordance with this section may limit the number of trips, establish seasonal or other limitations within which the vehicles described may be operated on the streets or highways indicated, or otherwise to limit or prescribe conditions of operation of such vehicle or vehicles, when necessary to ensure against undue damage to the road foundations, surfaces, or structures. Any permit issued may require security as may be deemed necessary by the Village Manager or designee to compensate for any damage to any roadway or load structure. 
(d)  Permit for single trip. Whenever the application for such a permit is for the transportation of a single article which cannot be divided and which exceeds 24,000 pounds total on any axle or exceeds 60 feet in total length or 102 inches in maximum width, the Village Manager or designee may issue a permit for a single trip for the load to be transported. The person making such application shall have paid to the Village a fee as set forth in Section 46-222 for such permit and shall have furnished a bond to the Village in an amount determined by the Village Manager or designee. Any permit issued in accordance with this subsection shall be conditional so as to save the Village harmless from any claim, loss or damage that may result from the granting of such permit or that may arise from or on account of any work done thereunder, and further conditioned that the permittee shall restore, at the permittee's own cost, to a condition satisfactory to the Village Manager or designee, any pavement, subway, tunnel, sewer, pipe, conduit, or other public utility that may be injured by reason of the transportation of such article under such permit. 
(e)  Permit to be carried in vehicle; compliance with terms of permit. Every permit issued under the provisions of this section shall be carried in the vehicle or combination of vehicles to which it refers and shall be open to inspection by any police officer, and no person shall violate any of the terms or conditions of such special permit. 
(Code 1979, § 51.17)  
Sec. 106-55. - Projecting loads. 
(a)  Passenger vehicles. No passenger vehicle shall be operated on any roadway with any load thereon extending more than 6 inches beyond the line of the fenders on the right and left sides thereof. 
(b)  Commercial vehicles. No commercial vehicle shall be operated on any roadway with any load extending to the rear 4 feet or more beyond the bed or body of such vehicle unless there shall be displayed at the extreme end of the load, during the periods when lighted lamps are required, a red light or lantern plainly visible from a distance of at least 500 feet to the rear and sides. The red light or lantern required under this section shall be in addition to the red rear light required upon every vehicle. During all other times, there shall be displayed at the extreme end of the load a red flag or cloth not less than 16 inches square. This flag or cloth shall be visible to the driver of any vehicle approaching from the rear or sides. 
(Code 1979, § 51.18) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, 625 ILCS 5/15-105 et seq.  
Sec. 106-56. - Trailers and towed vehicles. 
(a)  Any trailer being operated on any roadway while attached to a self-propelled motor vehicle, leading trailer or semi-trailer shall, in addition to the regular coupling device, have attached to the corners of the trailer frame adequate safety chains or devices sufficient to pull the trailer and its maximum load. 
(b)  Any trailer having a gross weight of 3,000 pounds or less, including the weight of the trailer and its maximum load, may be coupled to the towing vehicle by means of clamp-on hitches. Such hitches must be of sufficient strength to hold and control the trailer when fully loaded. Such trailers shall be equipped with 2 safety chains or cables which are permanently affixed to the tongue of the trailer. 
(Code 1979, § 51.19) 
State Law reference— Towed vehicles, 625 ILCS 5/15-110.  
Sec. 106-57. - Public carrier stops and stands. 
The Village Manager, subject to the approval of the Mayor and Board of Trustees, shall erect appropriate signs establishing bus stops, bus stands, taxicab stands, and stands for other passenger common carrier motor vehicles on such public streets in such places and in such number as the Village Manager or designee shall determine to be of the greatest benefit and convenience to the public. 
(Code 1979, § 51.20) 
Cross reference— Public passenger vehicles, § 114-31 et seq.  
Sec. 106-58. - Stopping, standing and parking of buses and taxicabs. 
(a)  The driver of a bus shall not stand or park such vehicle upon any street at any place other than at a designated bus stand or bus terminal. 
(b)  The driver of a bus shall not stop such vehicle upon any street at any place for the purpose of loading or unloading passengers other than at a designated bus stop, bus stand, passenger loading zone, or bus terminal, except in case of an emergency. 
(c)  The driver of a bus shall enter a bus zone or passenger loading zone on a public street in such a manner that the bus, when stopped to load or unload passengers, shall be in position with the right front wheel of such bus not further than 18 inches from the curb and the bus approximately parallel to the curb so as not to unduly impede the movement of other vehicular traffic. 
(Code 1979, § 51.21; Ord. No. 07-8-C-3539, § 1, 8-20-2007)  
Sec. 106-59. - Cruising by public passenger vehicles. 
No operator of a public passenger vehicle shall solicit business in such manner as to interfere with the lawful movement of traffic. 
(Code 1979, § 51.22) 
Cross reference— Public passenger vehicles, § 114-31 et seq.  
Sec. 106-60. - Riding coasters, roller skates and similar devices on roadway. 
No person operating or riding roller skates, in line skates, skateboards, any coaster, toy vehicle, scooter, or similar device shall go upon any roadway except while crossing a street on a crosswalk, and when so crossing such person shall be granted all the rights and shall be subject to the duties applicable to pedestrians. This section shall not apply upon any street set aside as a play street as authorized by this chapter. 
(Code 1979, § 51.23)  
Sec. 106-61. - Clinging to moving vehicle. 
Persons riding upon any bicycle, motorcycle, motor-driven cycle, coaster, sled, roller skates, scooter, toy vehicle, or other similar device shall not attach the vehicle or themselves to any moving vehicle upon any roadway. 
(Code 1979, § 54.06)  
Sec. 106-62. - Parades and processions. 
No parade or procession, except a funeral procession, the armed forces of the United States, the military forces of the State and forces of the Police Department and Fire Department of the Village, shall occupy, march or proceed along any street except in accordance with a permit issued by the Village Manager or designee and such other regulations as are set forth in this Code which may apply. 
(Code 1979, § 51.24) 
Cross reference— Parades and public assemblies, ch. 74. 
State Law reference— Authority to regulate processions, 625 ILCS 5/11-208(a)(3); funeral processions, 625 ILCS 5/11-1420.  
Sec. 106-63. - Driving on wet paint markings. 
It shall be unlawful for the driver of any vehicle to drive on or across any freshly painted roadway marking when such marking is clearly evidenced to still be wet by virtue of painting equipment in operation upon or near such markings. The temporary placement or rubber marking cones or similar devices along upon any pavement marking shall similarly give evidence that such markings are wet. 
(Code 1979, § 51.25)  
Sec. 106-64. - Railroad trains blocking streets. 
It shall be unlawful for the directing officer or the operator of any railroad train to direct the operation of or to operate the train in such manner as to prevent the use of any street for purposes of travel for a period of time longer than 5 minutes, except that this provision shall not apply to trains or cars in motion other than those engaged in switching. 
(Code 1979, § 51.26)  
Sec. 106-65. - Picking up pedestrians soliciting ride. 
No person operating a private vehicle shall pick up any person standing in a roadway for the purpose of soliciting a ride. 
(Code 1979, § 51.27) 
State Law reference— Pedestrians soliciting rides or business, 625 ILCS 5/11-1006.  
Sec. 106-66. - Boarding or alighting from vehicle in motion. 
No person shall board or alight from any vehicle while such vehicle is in motion. 
(Code 1979, § 51.28)  
Sec. 106-67. - Riding on portion of vehicle not intended for passengers. 
No person shall ride on any vehicle upon any portion thereof not designed or intended for the use of passengers. This provision shall not apply to an employee engaged in the necessary discharge of a duty, or to persons riding within truck bodies in space intended for merchandise. 
(Code 1979, § 51.29)  
Sec. 106-68. - Permit for parking of vans and buses in residential areas. 
(a)  The Village Manager or designee shall have the authority to issue special permits for the parking of vans or buses in residential areas if the Manager or designee finds the following facts: 
(1)  The van or bus is designed for 15 persons or less, has no commercial markings except as required by the State, is not more than 18 feet 11 inches in length and 6 feet 9 inches in height, and is properly licensed by the State and the relevant municipality. 
(2)  The van or bus is provided by an employer for the purpose of conserving energy or carpooling. 
(3)  The van or bus will be used on a regular daily basis to transport 5 or more individuals, including the driver, who are employees of the employer who provides the bus, to and from their homes and the employer's premises or to participate in a prescribed program of a public transit agency. 
(b)  The permits so issued shall be of not more than 6 months' duration, and each renewal shall require new findings by the Village Manager or designee as set forth in subsection (a) of this section. 
(c)  The applicant shall receive a sticker which shall be placed upon the windshield and shall specify the termination date. 
(Code 1979, § 51.62)  
Sec. 106-69. - Notification of eligibility of driver's license suspension. 
(a)  The Village Manager or designee is hereby authorized to cause a notice of impending driver's license suspension to be sent, to any person who has failed to satisfy amounts owed for ten or more citations, issued and processed pursuant to procedures in place prior to the commencement of the administrative adjudication system established in Chapter 2, Article XII, incurred as a result of violations of the Village's parking regulations set forth in chapter 106 of the Skokie Village Code, after the exhaustion of judicial review procedures. 
(b)  The Traffic Compliance Administrator or designee, as defined in Chapter 2, Article XII, shall send a notice of impending driver's license suspension to any person who has failed to pay any fine and penalty due and owing as a result of ten or more unpaid Final Determinations of Violation Liability for violation notices issued for violations of vehicular standing, parking or compliance regulations established in this Code and processed pursuant to Chapter 2, Article XII. The Traffic Compliance Administrator or designee shall also send a notice of impending driver's license suspension to any person that has failed to pay any fine or penalty due and owning as a result of five or more offenses for Automated Traffic Law Violations as defined in Section 11-208.6 of the Illinois Vehicle Code. 
(c)  Notice of impending driver's license suspension; notice to Illinois Secretary of State. 
(1)  Pursuant to the authority or requirements stated in paragraph (a) or (b) of this Section, a notice of impending driver's license suspension shall be sent by first class United States mail, postage prepaid, to the person at the address recorded with the Secretary of State. Any such notice shall include a list of the citations, or violation notices, as the case may be, the dates of the violations, and amounts owed. The notice shall specify procedures whereby the person may request a copy of the violation notice, or citation, as the case may be. 
(2)  If within 45 days of the date of the notice referred to in subsection 106-69(c)(1), the amounts owed listed in the notice remain unpaid, the Village Manager or designee, or the Traffic Compliance Administrator or designee, as the case may be, shall notify the Secretary of State, by filing a certified report, that the person's driver's license is eligible for suspension pursuant to Chapter 625 Section 5/6-306.5 of the Illinois Compiled Statutes. 
(d)  The person named in the certified report filed with the Secretary of State, who failed to pay the fines or penalties, may file a written challenge contesting the accuracy of the certified report. The written challenge must be filed with the Chief of Police or designee within 14 days of the date that the Secretary of State notified the person that their driver's license will be suspended. The failure to file the written challenge shall be deemed to be a waiver of the right to challenge the accuracy of the certified report. The written challenge shall include a telephone number where the person may be reached and the hearing will be scheduled within seven days unless another date is agreed to by the person and the Chief of Police or designee. The only grounds to challenge the accuracy of the certified report are: 
(1)  the person was not the owner, as defined by Section 2-1091 of this Code, of the vehicle or vehicles receiving (A) ten or more standing, parking, or compliance violation notices, or citations, as the case may be, on the date or dates that such violation notices, or citations were issued, or (B) five or more Automated Traffic Law Violation notices on the date or dates that such notices were issued; or 
(2)  the person, or another person, previously paid the fines and penalties for the ten or more standing, parking, or compliance violations, or citations, as the case may be, or for five or more Automated Traffic Law Violations. 
In the event a person proves by a preponderance of the evidence that one or both of the above stated grounds make the certified report inaccurate to the extent that suspension would not be appropriate, then the Chief of Police or designee shall notify the Traffic Compliance Administrator and the appropriate report or correction shall be filed with the Secretary of State. 
(Ord. No. 02-6-C-3102, § 2, 6-17-2002; Ord. No. 08-3-C-3605, § 4, 3-17-2008)  
Sec. 106-70. - Definitions. 
Words or phrases used in this Division shall have the following definitions: 
(a)  "Automated Traffic Law Enforcement System" means a system that utilizes a device as defined in Section 11-208.6 of the Illinois Vehicle Code. Specifically, it means the utilization of a device with one or more motor vehicle sensors working in conjunction with a red light signal to produce recorded images of motor vehicles entering an intersection against a red signal indication in violation of Section 11-306 of the Illinois Vehicle Code or similar provision of the Skokie Village Code. 
(b)  "Automated Traffic Law Violation" means a violation of Section 11-306 of the Illinois Vehicle Code, or similar provision of the Skokie Village Code, which is recorded and documented by an Automated Traffic Law Enforcement System. 
(c)  "Fine" means the amount owed for a violation of Section 11-306 of the Illinois Vehicle Code or similar provision of the Skokie Village Code. Fine shall also have the same meaning as "civil penalty" as used in Section 11-208.6 of the Illinois Vehicle Code. 
(d)  "IVC" means the Illinois Vehicle Code, 625 ILCS 5/1-1 et seq. 
(e)  "Motor vehicle" or "vehicle" means every vehicle which is self-propelled, including, but not limited to, automobiles, trucks, vans, motorcycles and motor scooters, and shall include every vehicle defined by Section 1-146 of the Illinois Vehicle Code. 
(f)  "Owner" means: (1) a person who holds legal title of a vehicle; or (2) in the event (i) a vehicle is the subject of an agreement for the conditional sale or lease thereof with the right of purchase upon performance of the conditions stated in the agreement and with an immediate right of possession vested in the conditional vendee or lessee, or (ii) a mortgagor of such vehicle is entitled to possession, then such conditional vendee or lessee or mortgagor shall be deemed the owner. For the purposes of determining the identity of an owner, the records of the Illinois Secretary of State, or such similar office of another state, shall be presumed to be true and correct. Any person may, with the owner's written permission, perform any act that the owner is authorized to perform. 
(g)  "Recorded Images" means images recorded by an automated traffic law enforcement system on: (1) 2 or more photographs; (2) 2 or more microphotographs; (3) 2 or more electronic images; or (4) a video recording showing the motor vehicle. On at least one image or portion of the recording, the registration plate number of the motor vehicle must be clearly identified. 
(Ord. No. 08-12-C-3651, § 1, 12-1-2008)  
Sec. 106-71. - Authorization; location. 
The Village of Skokie is authorized to operate an Automated Traffic Law Enforcement System at intersections within the boundaries of the Village in a manner consistent with the requirements with Section 11-208.6 of the Illinois Vehicle Code. The Village Manager shall select the locations at which Automated Traffic Law Enforcement Systems shall be located. The Village Manager shall notify the Mayor, Clerk and the Trustees of the locations selected for the Automated Traffic Law Enforcement System. The Village Manager may take any and all action necessary to construct and operate the System. The Village may contract with a private company to construct and operate the Automated Traffic Law Enforcement System. Before any citations are issued, potential violations shall be subject to a final review and approval by a dedicated Skokie Police Officer, who shall review any and all evidence of a violation to determine whether or not the motor vehicle was being operated in violation of Section 11-208.6 of the Illinois Vehicle Code. 
(Ord. No. 08-12-C-3651, § 1, 12-1-2008; Ord. No. 13-11-C-4016, § 1, 11-18-2013)  
Sec. 106-72. - Violation notice. 
A Violation Notice shall be issued for a violation of Section 11-306 of the Illinois vehicle Code, or a similar provision of the Skokie Village Code, if the images recorded by the Automated Traffic Law Enforcement System demonstrate that a vehicle entered the intersection contrary to the red light. The owner of the vehicle appearing on the recorded image shall be liable for the fine and late penalties associated with an Automated Traffic Law Violation. A Violation Notice may be commonly referred to as a ticket or citation and such reference shall not affect the enforcement of the Violation Notice. The Violation Notice shall be mailed by first class mail to the owner of the vehicle within 30 days after the Secretary of State, or similar office in another state, notifies the Village of the identity of the owner, but in no event later than 90 days after the alleged violation. 
(a)  A Violation Notice shall, at a minimum, state the following information: 
(1)  The name and address of the registered owner; 
(2)  The date, time and place of the violation; 
(3)  The specific regulation violated; 
(4)  The fine that is assessed and the date by which it should be paid; 
(5)  The state registration number of the motor vehicle; 
(6)  A copy of the recorded images; 
(7)  A statement that recorded images are evidence of a violation of a red light signal; 
(8)  A warning that failure to pay the fine or to contest liability within a timely manner is an admission of liability and may result in suspension of the driving privileges of the owner of the motor vehicle or immobilization of any vehicle owned by the owner of the motor vehicle; and 
(9)  A statement that an owner may elect to proceed by: (A) paying the fine; (B) contesting the violation by requesting an administrative hearing or by filing a written contest. 
(Ord. No. 08-12-C-3651, § 1, 12-1-2008)  
Sec. 106-73. - Procedures. 
The procedures stated in Chapter 2, Article XII of this Code, and specifically Section 2-1096, including, but not limited to, the deadlines, rights, duties, and enforcement, collection and other procedures relating to administrative adjudication, shall be applicable to violations alleged under this Division. The words and phrases used in Article XII of Chapter 2 shall have the same meaning in this Division. If any provision of Article XII of Chapter 2 is in direct conflict with this Division, then the provisions of this Division shall be interpreted to govern the specific issue or procedure. 
(Ord. No. 08-12-C-3651, § 1, 12-1-2008)  
Sec. 106-74. - [Images.] 
Images produced by an Automated Traffic Law Enforcement System and the facts stated in the Violation Notice shall be: (i) prima facie evidence demonstrating the facts attendant to the alleged violation; (ii) admissible in any legal proceeding without any further foundation; and (iii) presumed true and correct of the facts shown on the recorded image and the facts stated in the Notice. 
(Ord. No. 08-12-C-3651, § 1, 12-1-2008)  
Sec. 106-75. - [Defenses.] 
In addition to the defenses available to the owner as stated in section 2-1097 of this Code, the Hearing Officer may find the owner not liable if it is demonstrated that the driver of the vehicle passed through the intersection when the light was red either: (i) in order to yield the right of way to an emergency vehicle; or (ii) as part of a funeral procession. 
(Ord. No. 08-12-C-3651, § 1, 12-1-2008)  
Sec. 106-76. - Fine. 
The owner of a motor vehicle that is found liable for a violation of Section 11-306 of the Illinois Vehicle Code, or similar provision of the Skokie Village Code, pursuant to an Automated Traffic Law Enforcement System shall be fined $100. In the event an owner is sent a Late Notice as provided for in Section 2-1096(e) of Article XII of Chapter 2, then an additional late penalty shall be added increasing the total fine owed to $150. If the owner is found liable at a subsequently scheduled administrative hearing, under no circumstances will the owner be fined less than $125.00. An owner that does not pay the total fine after 21 days of the Late Notice, and does not appear at the scheduled administrative hearing, shall be liable for a total fine and late penalty amount of $200. An owner that does not pay the total fine after 21 days of the Late Notice may be liable for fines and late penalties up to $200. An owner that does not appear at the scheduled administrative hearing may be liable for fines and late penalties up to $200. 
(Ord. No. 08-12-C-3651, § 1, 12-1-2008; Ord. No. 13-11-C-4016, § 1, 11-18-2013)  
Sec. 106-77. - Appeals. 
Any owner of a motor vehicle found liable may appeal from an adverse ruling to the Circuit Court of Cook County in accordance with the Illinois Code of Civil Procedure, all applicable Cook County Circuit Court rules and the Administrative Review Act, 735 ILCS 5/3-101 et seq. 
(Ord. No. 13-11-C-4016, § 1, 11-18-2013)  
Secs. 106-78—106-90. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - STOPPING, STANDING AND PARKING[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference— Parking on parade route, § 74-3(c); off-street parking and loading facilities, § 118-201 et seq. 
State Law reference— Authority to regulate standing or parking of vehicles, 625 ILCS 5/11-208(a)(1); stopping, standing and parking, 625 ILCS 5/11-1301 et seq. 
 
Sec. 106-91. - Registered owner of vehicle presumed responsible for violations. 
Whenever any vehicle shall have been parked in violation of any of the provisions of any ordinance prohibiting or restricting parking, the person in whose name such vehicle is registered shall be prima facie responsible for such violation and subject to the penalty therefor. 
(Code 1979, § 51.55)  
Sec. 106-92. - Placement of violation notice on vehicle. 
(a)  Whenever any vehicle is parked in violation of the provisions of any ordinance prohibiting or restricting parking and there is no person in attendance upon such parked vehicle to be served immediately with a traffic violation notice with an opportunity to appear in court to answer the charge of such violation, any police officer or authorized personnel observing such violation may attach to the vehicle used in such violation a traffic violation notice requiring that the person in whose name such vehicle is registered request a court date or pay the amount approved by the Mayor and Board of Trustees by the adoption of an ordinance. However, any violation notice issued pursuant to Chapter 2, Article XII, shall be subject to the issuance, service and other procedures in said Article XII. 
(b)  When any vehicle is parked in a private parking lot in violation of section 106-104 and there is no person in attendance upon such parked vehicle to be arrested or served immediately with a traffic violation notice to appear in court to answer the charge of such violation, any police officer or authorized personnel, upon a written complaint signed by the owner or proprietor of the lot, or by the owner's or proprietor's authorized agent, that the vehicle is not entitled to the privileges of the parking lot may attach to the vehicle a traffic violation notice as provided in this section. However, any violation notice issued pursuant to Chapter 2, Article XII, shall be subject to the issuance, service and other procedures in said Article XII. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person, other than the driver of the vehicle to which the notice is attached, to remove the notice from the vehicle. 
(Code 1979, § 51.56; Ord. No. 08-3-C-3605, § 5, 3-17-2008)  
Sec. 106-93. - Impoundment authorized; vehicles subject to impoundment. 
Members of the Police Department are hereby authorized to remove a vehicle from any public way to the Village vehicle pound or authorized garage as determined and designated by the Village Manager or designee under the following circumstances: 
(a)  When any vehicle is left unattended upon any bridge or viaduct, or upon any approach thereto, where such vehicle constitutes an obstruction to traffic. 
(b)  When a vehicle upon any public way is so disabled as to constitute an obstruction to traffic and the person or persons in charge of the vehicle are by reason of physical injury incapacitated to such an extent as to be unable to provide for its custody or removal. 
(c)  When any vehicle is left unattended upon any public way and is so parked illegally as to constitute a definite hazard or obstruction to the normal movement of traffic. 
(d)  When an abandoned vehicle is found on any public way. 
(e)  When any vehicle illegally occupies a parking meter space for an unreasonable period of time. 
(f)  When any vehicle is parked in violation of Section 106-105. 
(g)  When any vehicle is parked in violation of Section 106-107. 
(h)  When any vehicle is parked in violation of official signs indicating that parking, standing, or stopping is prohibited at all times or during designated hours or prohibited for a longer time than indicated on such sign. 
(i)  When a vehicle pursuant to Section 106-131 et seq. has been immobilized by the Skokie Police Department. 
(j)  When a driver of a vehicle is in violation of Section 106-142. 
(k)  When a vehicle pursuant to Section 106-151 et seq. has been immobilized by the Skokie Police Department. 
(Code 1979, § 51.49; Ord. No. 02-6-C-3104, § 1, 6-17-2002; Ord. No. 08-2-C-3593, § 1, 2-4-2008; Ord. No. 08-4-C-3608, § 2, 4-7-2008)  
Sec. 106-94. - Relocation of vehicles in emergencies. 
When any emergency arises necessitating the removal of any vehicle upon any public way, the Village Manager or designee is authorized to remove or have removed any such vehicle from 1 location to any other location. 
(Code 1979, § 51.50)  
Sec. 106-95. - Impoundment procedures. 
(a)  Records. It shall be the duty of the Chief of Police to safely keep any impounded vehicle until such vehicle shall have been repossessed by the owner or person legally entitled to possession thereof or otherwise disposed of as provided in this section. The Chief of Police shall cause to be kept an accurate record of the description of such vehicle, including the name of the officer from whom such vehicle was received, the officer employed to tow or deliver the vehicle to the pound or authorized garage, the date and time when received, the place where found, seized or taken possession of, the make and color of the car, style or body, kind of power, motor number, serial number, number of cylinders, year built, state license number, if any, wheel tax license number, if any, equipment and general description of condition, the name and address of the person redeeming the vehicle, the date of redemption, and the manner and date of disposal of the vehicle in case the vehicle shall not be redeemed, together with the towing and storage charge. Such record shall be in form prescribed by the Chief of Police to keep weekly reports of all such vehicles delivered to the Chief of Police, which reports shall be kept in the office of the Chief available for the inspection of any interested party at all reasonable hours of the day. 
(b)  Removal of vehicle. 
(1)  It shall be the duty of the Chief of Police to cause every vehicle removed from any public way as provided in Section 106-93 to be removed and conveyed by or under the direction of a member of the Police Department to a vehicle pound or authorized garage. 
(2)  The Village Manager or designee shall make such arrangements as are necessary for towing vehicles for the purpose of carrying out the provisions of this section. 
(c)  Notice to owner. Whenever the Police Department has impounded or relocated any vehicle, the Police Department shall ascertain from the registration records of the State or the Village the name and address of the owner and shall as soon as practicable give or cause to be given written notice of the removal, the impounding, the reason, and the place to which the vehicle has been removed. When the vehicle is impounded pursuant to Division 4 of this Chapter, the notice shall be provided as stated in that Division. 
(d)  Vehicle pound. The Village Manager or designee is hereby authorized to establish or designate a vehicle pound or pounds to which motor vehicles may be removed by police officers in the manner provided in this section. Such pound shall be located at such places as may be designated by the Village Manager or designee and operated by the custodian of lost and stolen property, under the direction of the Village Manager or designee. 
(e)  Notice to Secretary of State when owner is unknown. Whenever the Police Department has impounded any vehicle as provided in this section and does not know and is not able to ascertain the name of the owner, or for any reason is unable to give the notice to the owner as provided in this section, and if the vehicle is not returned to the owner within a period of 3 days, the Police Department shall immediately send or cause to be sent a written report of such removal and impounding by mail to the Illinois Secretary of State. Such notice shall include a complete description of the vehicle, the date, time, and place from which removed, the reasons for such removal and the address of the vehicle pound or authorized garage where the vehicle is stored. 
(Code 1979, § 51.51; Ord. No. 08-2-C-3593, § 1, 2-4-2008)  
Sec. 106-96. - Designation of restricted parking zones. 
(a)  No parking zones. The Village Manager is authorized, subject to the approval of the Mayor and Board of Trustees, to determine and designate by erecting the appropriate signs those streets upon which parking shall be prohibited or upon which parking shall be prohibited on 1 side only. 
(b)  Limited stopping, standing and parking zones. The Village Manager or designee is hereby authorized, subject to the approval of the Mayor and Board of Trustees, to determine and designate by erecting the appropriate signs those streets or parts of streets upon which stopping, standing, or parking shall be prohibited within certain hours or permitted for a limited time. 
(c)  Parking meter zones. 
(1)  The Village Manager or designee shall cause parking meters to be installed in such numbers and at such places in parking meter zones as established by the Mayor and Board of Trustees as in the judgment of the Manager or designee may be necessary for the regulation, control, and inspection of the parking of vehicles. The Manager or designee shall have supervision of the installation, operation, maintenance, regulation and use of such meters, and shall have charge of the collection of coins deposited in the meters. 
(2)  Parking meters shall be installed immediately adjacent to the individual parking places designated. Each parking meter shall be set in such manner as to display by a signal that the parking space adjacent to such meter is or is not legally in use. Each parking meter shall indicate the parking time established, and when operated shall indicate the duration of the period of legal parking, and on expiration of such period shall indicate illegal or overtime parking. 
(3)  The Village Manager or designee shall have markings painted or placed upon the pavement adjacent to each parking meter for the purpose of designating the parking space for which the meter is to be used, and each vehicle parking adjacent to any parking meter shall park within the lines of markings so established. It shall be unlawful to park any vehicle across any such lines or markings or to park the vehicle in such position that the vehicle shall not be entirely within the area so designated by such lines or markings. 
(Code 1979, § 51.30)  
Sec. 106-97. - General parking limitations on streets and Village property; signs. 
(a)  Compliance with signs. When signs have been erected upon any street or other Village property indicating that stopping, standing or parking is prohibited during designated hours, prohibited for a longer time than is designated or that parking is by permit only, no person shall park any vehicle on such street or other Village property in violation of such signs. 
(b)  Temporary signs. For the purpose of facilitating snow removal or the cleaning of streets and roadway construction, the Village Manager or designee is authorized to erect temporary signs designating the days of the week and hours of the day and the part of street in which the parking of vehicles is prohibited during the periods and at the locations designated on the signs, as provided in this section. 
(c)  Effective days and hours. The provisions of this article prohibiting the stopping, standing or parking of vehicles shall apply at all times, at those times therein specified or as indicated on official signs, except when it is necessary to stop a vehicle to avoid conflict with other traffic or in compliance with the directions of a police officer or official traffic control device. 
(d)  Regulations not exclusive. The provisions of any ordinance imposing a time limit on parking shall not relieve any person from the duty to observe other and more restrictive provisions prohibiting or limiting the stopping, standing, or parking of vehicles in specified places or at specified times. 
(Code 1979, § 51.36)  
Sec. 106-98. - Diagonal and parallel parking. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for the operator of any vehicle to park a vehicle diagonally to the edge of the roadway except where such diagonal parking is permitted by suitable signs and markings. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for the operator of any vehicle to park a vehicle on any diagonal parking zone except diagonally to the edge of the roadway and within the pavement markings. 
(c)  The Village Manager is hereby authorized to establish diagonal parking zones, and to designate such zones by placing and maintaining suitable signs and markings. Such diagonal parking zones shall be established only after appropriate engineering studies and surveys have indicated that diagonal parking will not be hazardous, and that such diagonal parking shall leave at all times not less than 20 feet of available roadway for the ingress and egress of vehicles between the rows of such parked vehicles. The parking of vehicles diagonal to the roadway may be permitted only on streets at their termini beyond the last cross-street intersection and on streets which serve only as service drives. 
(d)  Except as otherwise provided in subsections (a), (b) and (c) of this section, no person shall stand or park a vehicle in a roadway other than parallel with the edge of the roadway headed in the direction of lawful traffic movement and with the curbside wheels of the vehicle within 12 inches of the curb or edge of the roadway, except as otherwise provided in this article. Double parking is prohibited. 
(Code 1979, § 51.31)  
Sec. 106-99. - Authority to prohibit stopping, standing or parking at hazardous or congested places. 
The Village Manager or designee is hereby authorized to determine and designate, by appropriate signs, places not exceeding 150 feet in length in which the stopping, standing, or parking of vehicles would create an especially hazardous condition or would cause unusual delay to traffic. 
(Code 1979, § 51.32)  
Sec. 106-100. - Establishment of curb loading zones, no parking zones and fire lane zones. 
The Village Manager or designee, subject to the approval of the Mayor and Board of Trustees, is authorized to determine the location of passenger and freight curb loading zones, no parking zones and fire lanes and shall place and maintain appropriate signs indicating such zones and stating the hours, if applicable, during which the provisions of this section are applicable. 
(Code 1979, § 51.33)  
Sec. 106-101. - Establishment of prohibited parking space in front of specific buildings. 
No sign shall be erected upon the special request of the owner, agent, or lessee of any building for the specific purpose of designating a prohibited parking space in front of the entrance to such building or in front of the property on which such building is located, unless in the opinion of the Village Manager or designee such sign is necessary for the protection of the health, safety and general welfare of the persons and the property in and about the area. A sign may be permitted to be erected upon the special request of the owner, agent, or lessee of any building for the specific purpose of designating a curb loading zone and fire zone in front of the entrance to such building or in front of the property which such building is located if in the opinion of the Village Manager or designee such sign is necessary for the protection of the health, safety and general welfare of the persons and the property in and about the area. The Village Manager or designee shall not maintain any such sign after 1 year from the date of erection unless the owner, agent, or lessee shall pay the fee set forth in Section 46-223 annually for the maintenance of each such sign, and the Manager or designee shall remove such sign when the payment of yearly maintenance fees on such sign shall be 30 days in arrears. The Village Manager or designee may also remove such sign whenever public convenience or necessity warrants such removal after 15 days notice of such intended removal is given to the owner, agent, or lessee. The fees required in this section shall not apply to the erection of signs in front of any public building, or in front of any school or house of worship. No fee shall be required for any sign erected under the provisions of this section when in the opinion of the Village Manager such sign is required for the health, safety and welfare of the general public. 
(Code 1979, § 51.34)  
Sec. 106-102. - Obstructing traffic. 
(a)  No person shall park any vehicle upon a street in such a manner or under such conditions as to leave available less than 15 feet of the width of the roadway for free movement of vehicular traffic on a two-way street or less than 10 feet of the width of the roadway for free movement of vehicular traffic on a 1-way street. 
(b)  The operator of a vehicle shall not operate or allow the vehicle to remain upon any street in such a manner as to form an unreasonable obstruction to the traffic thereon. 
(Code 1979, § 51.35) 
Cross reference— Obstructing pedestrian or vehicular traffic, § 70-121.  
Sec. 106-103. - Stopping, standing or parking prohibited in specified places. 
(a)  General prohibitions. It shall be unlawful for the operator of any vehicle to stop, stand or park such vehicle in any of the following places, except when necessary to avoid conflict with other traffic or in compliance with directions of a police officer or official traffic sign or signal: 
(1)  Within an intersection or alley intersection. 
(2)  On a crosswalk. 
(3)  Upon any bridge, or viaduct thereto. 
(4)  Between a safety zone and the adjacent curb or within 30 feet of a point on the curb immediately opposite the end of a safety zone. 
(5)  Within 30 feet of an official traffic signal or stop sign on the approaching side. 
(6)  Within 20 feet of a crosswalk at an intersection. 
(7)  At any curb within 15 feet of a fire hydrant, such distance to be measured from that point on the curb perpendicular to the exact location of the fire hydrant. 
Cross reference— Obstructing hydrants, § 50-50. 
(8)  At any place within 20 feet of the entrance to any fire station, and on the side of any street opposite the entrance to any fire station within 75 feet of the entrance. 
(9)  Within 8 feet in a residential district and 15 feet in a commercial district from the point where the curbline running parallel to the road meets a line perpendicular to the road drawn from the edge of the driveway at its narrowest point. The prohibition of parking within eight feet of a driveway does not apply to an occupant of a detached, duplex or townhouse residence parking his or her vehicle within eight feet of a driveway used solely by the occupant of such residence in R1, R2, R3 and R4 Residential districts. 
(10)  Within any sidewalk area. 
(11)  Alongside or opposite any street excavation or obstruction when such stopping, standing or parking would obstruct traffic. 
(12)  On the roadway side of any vehicle stopped or parked at the edge or curb of a street. 
(13)  At any place where official traffic signs have been erected prohibiting stopping, standing, or parking. 
(14)  Within 50 feet of the nearest rail of a railroad crossing. 
(15)  Within any designated bus zone, where such zone is marked by signs or pavement markings. 
(16)  In any alley within 20 feet of the inner sidewalk line projected across such alley. 
(17)  Under the lowest portion of any fire escape. 
(18)  Upon a railroad track or between a railroad track and a line parallel with and 10 feet distant from the outer rail thereof. 
(19)  Upon any parkway except in case of emergency. 
(20)  Within any designated fire lane zone. 
(21)  On a road, within 15 feet of an alley, measured from the point where the curbline running parallel to the road meets a line perpendicular to the road drawn from the edge of the alley at its narrowest point. 
The Village Manager shall designate the locations of the areas mentioned in subsections (a)(3), (4), and (15) of this section by curb markings or by the erection of appropriate signs. 
(b)  Narrow roadways. Whenever, upon engineering investigation, the width of a roadway is found to be insufficient to meet requirements set forth in Section 106-102, the Village Manager or designee is authorized to erect signs giving notice of prohibition of parking. 
(c)  Alleys. 
(1)  No person shall stop, stand, or park any vehicle in any alley for a period of time longer than is necessary for the expeditious loading or unloading of such vehicle. 
(2)  No person shall stop, stand, or park a vehicle within any alley in such a manner or under such conditions as to leave available less than 10 feet of the width of the roadway for the free movement of vehicular traffic. 
(3)  No person shall stop, stand, or park a vehicle within an alley in such position as to prevent the full use of the driveway or entrance to any abutting property. 
(d)  Parking adjacent to schools and playgrounds. 
(1)  The Village Manager or designee is authorized to erect signs indicating no parking upon that side of any street adjacent to any school property or playground when such parking would, in the Manager or designee's opinion, interfere with traffic or create a hazardous situation. 
(2)  When official signs are erected indicating no parking upon that side of a street adjacent to any school property or playground, no person shall park a vehicle in any such designated place. 
(e)  Public property. It shall be unlawful for any person to park a vehicle upon any property owned by the Village and used for the transaction of public business where such parking is prohibited or limited by order of the custodian of the property. This section shall not apply to Village-owned vehicles or to other vehicles whose operation is useful or essential to the proper functioning of the department, board or commission occupying the property. The custodian of the property shall post signs indicating the prohibition or limitation. 
(f)  Private property. It shall be unlawful for any person to park or stand a vehicle, whether occupied or not, otherwise than temporarily for the purpose of and while actually engaged in loading or unloading, in a private drive or driveway or on private property without the express or implied consent of the owner or person in lawful possession of such driveway or property. 
(g)  Skokie Swift parking lots. 
(1)  It shall be unlawful for any person to park a vehicle in the Skokie Swift parking lots unless the vehicle shall be parked in a designated numbered parking space and the person shall pay the sum set forth in Section 46-228 for the parking space in which the vehicle is parked through one of the approved payment options. The Skokie Swift parking lots are comprised of a South Lot, located contiguous to the CTA Swift Station and south of Dempster Street, and the North Lot, located north of Dempster Street across from the CTA Swift Station. 
(2)  Failure to make the appropriate payment shall be a violation of this Code. 
(h)  Residential permit parking lots. It shall be unlawful for any person to park a vehicle in a lot designated by the Mayor and Board of Trustees as a residential permit parking lot unless the vehicle bears an official sticker issued by the Village and the sticker is clearly visible in the lower lefthand corner of the rear windshield. The fee for the sticker is set forth in Section 46-227. 
(i)  Parking of customer vehicles. All customer vehicles driven to a business shall be parked on the subject site or at a remote private parking area in designated parking spaces and shall not be parked on public streets. 
(Code 1979, § 51.37; Ord. No. 03-9-C-3204, § 1, 9-15-2003; Ord. No. 08-12-C-3656, § 1, 12-15-2008; Ord. No. 09-1-C-3658, § 1, 1-5-2009; Ord. No. 14-2-C-4034, § 1, 2-3-2014; Ord. No. 14-5-C-4055, § 1, 5-5-2014) 
State Law reference— Obstructing pedestrian or vehicular traffic, § 70-121.  
Sec. 106-104. - Parking in private lots. 
It shall be unlawful for any person not entitled to do so to park a vehicle in a private parking lot, which has been established voluntarily or pursuant to the Zoning Chapter (Chapter 118), to provide off-street parking facilities for tenants or employees of the owner of lot. Public passenger vehicles shall be allowed to park in the parking lots of private properties in all mixed-use, business, and industrial zoning districts with a Village permit. 
(Code 1979, § 51.47; Ord. No. 08-1-C-3577, § 1, 1-7-2008; Ord. No. 09-2-C-3664, § 1, 2-17-2009)  
Sec. 106-105. - Parking of trucks and commercial vehicles. 
(a)  Generally. Except as otherwise provided in Section 106-68, no person shall stand or park any commercial truck, tractor, semi-trailer, trailer, bus or commercial vehicle on any street in a residential, business, mixed use or industrial district for a longer period than is necessary for the expeditious loading or unloading of such vehicle, except that a driver of a bus may park such bus in a designated bus stand as provided in this article. Between the hours of 9:30 p.m. and 7:00 a.m., no motor vehicle shall, for the purpose of loading or unloading, be parked, stopped, left with its engine or refrigeration idling or stored on any alley, street or parking lot adjacent to or within 150 feet of any dwelling. 
(b)  Vehicles allowed in residential, mixed-use or business zoning district. Except as provided in [subsection] 106-105(d), only the following motor vehicles shall be allowed to stand or park on any street in a residential, mixed-use or business zoning district: 
(1)  Motorcycles. 
(2)  Passenger vans with RV license plates. 
(3)  Non-commercial vehicles under 8,000 pounds with passenger or Class B license plates. 
(c)  Commercial vehicles. For the purpose of this section, those factors that determine a commercial vehicle shall include, but not be limited to, all of the following: 
(1)  More than single rear wheels. 
(2)  Signs, advertisements, business identifications or business license plates. 
(3)  Attached auxiliary equipment on the outside of the vehicle including, but not limited to trailers, plows, equipment racks or roof racks containing ladders or other construction equipment or materials or open storage boxes or lockers. 
(4)  Any debris, construction materials or equipment intended for commercial or business use in the open or uncovered bed of the vehicle . 
(5)  Any trailer of any size, whether enclosed or unenclosed, even if empty. 
(d)  Time limit. No person shall stand or park any commercial truck, tractor, semi-trailer, trailer bus, public passenger vehicle, commercial vehicle or any vehicle as defined in Section 106-106 on any street in the Village except for such time as is necessary for the expeditious loading or unloading of such vehicle and as long as the vehicle is attended by its driver. Notwithstanding the forgoing sentence, commercial vehicle parking, including, but not limited to, tractor trailer and semi-trailers, is allowed in legally authorized off-street parking spaces or areas in M1, M2, and M3 industrial districts with the express permission of the property owner and as otherwise complies with all Village codes. 
(e)  Enforcement. Any truck, tractor, semi-trailer, trailer, bus, commercial vehicle or any vehicle as defined in Section 106-106 parked in violation of this section is hereby declared to be a nuisance, which may be abated by any police officer by ticketing and/or removing such vehicle to the Village vehicle pound or to any authorized garage or otherwise securing the vehicle for further investigation and upon presentation of reasonable cause, obtain a search warrant or upon risk of immediate harm to persons or property, open the vehicle to inspect the vehicle. 
(f)  Storage of vehicles on street. No person shall store any truck, tractor, semi-trailer, trailer, bus, commercial vehicle or any vehicle as defined in Section 106-106 on any street in an industrial zoning district. 
(Code 1979, § 51.38; Ord. No. 02-5-C-3089, § 1, 5-6-2002; Ord. No. 07-8-C-3539, § 2, 8-20-2007; Ord. No. 09-2-C-3664, § 1, 2-17-2009; Ord. No. 18-4-C-4372, § 1, 4-2-2018)  
Sec. 106-106. - Parking of boats, boat trailers and recreational vehicles. 
(a)  For purposes of this chapter, a recreational vehicle is a vehicular, portable structure built on a chassis, designed to be used as a temporary dwelling for travel, recreational and vacation uses. A recreational vehicle shall include the following: travel trailer, pickup coach, motorized home, camping trailer, and any other recreational vehicle or recreational trailer bearing a recreational license plate, i.e., "RV," "RT," or "TA." 
(b)  No boat, boat trailer, or recreational vehicle shall be permitted to park, stand or load on any street or alley in any residential, business or industrial district except with the prior written approval by the Chief of Police or designee. This approval shall be granted for loading or unloading purposes only and shall specify the date and time of its applicability. This prohibition shall not apply to stock vans bearing "RV" or passenger license plates which have not been modified in such a manner as to increase their length, width or height. 
(c)  Any vehicle parked in violation of this section is declared to be a nuisance, which may be abated by any police officer by removing such vehicle to the Village vehicle pound or to any authorized garage. 
(Code 1979, § 51.441; Ord. No. 18-4-C-4372, § 1, 4-2-2018)  
Sec. 106-107. - Parking restrictions after snowfall. 
(a)  Restrictions. Whenever there is an accumulation of 2 inches or more of snow as determined by the Village Manager or designee, the following alternate side street parking restrictions shall apply on all roadways within the Village: 
(1)  On even-numbered days of the month, between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 6:00 p.m., motor vehicles shall only be parked on the side of the street bearing even-numbered addresses. 
(2)  On odd-numbered days of the month, between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 6:00 p.m., motor vehicles shall only be parked on the side of the street bearing odd-numbered addresses. 
(b)  Exempt roadways. The following streets are exempted from the provisions of this section on Saturdays, Sundays and holidays: 
Birchwood Avenue, 4600 block. 
Bronx Avenue, 8800, 8900, 9000 and 9100 blocks. 
Carol Street, 4800, 4900 and 5000 blocks (to terminal). 
Central Park Avenue, 8000 and 8100 blocks. 
Cleveland Street, 3300, 3400, 4600 and 4700 blocks. 
Conrad Street, 4800 and 4900 blocks (to terminal). 
Crain Street, 4800, 4900 and 5000 blocks (to terminal). 
Davis Street, 4600, 4700, 4800, 4900, 5000 and 5100 blocks. 
Dobson Street, 4700 block. 
Elm Street, 4800 block. 
Enfield Avenue, 4800, 4900, 5000 and 5100 blocks (to terminal). 
Greenleaf Avenue, 4800 block. 
Greenwood Avenue, 4800, 4900, 5000 and 5100 blocks (to terminal). 
Grove Street, 4700, 4800, 4900, 5000 and 5100 blocks (to terminal). 
Hull Street, 4800 and 4900 blocks. 
Jarvis Street, 3800 and 3900 blocks. 
Karlov Avenue, 7900 block. 
Keating Avenue, 8000, 8100, 8200 to 8350 and 9000, 9100 and 9200 blocks. 
Kedvale Avenue, 7900 block. 
Keeney Avenue, 4600 and 4700 blocks. 
Kilpatrick Avenue, 8000, 8100, 8200, 8300, 9000, 9100 and 9200 blocks. 
Kimball Avenue, 8300 block. 
Kirk Street, 4800 and 4900 blocks. 
Knox Avenue, 7600, 8000, 8100, 8200 and 8300 blocks. 
LaCrosse Avenue, 7900, 8800, 8900, 9000 and 9100 blocks. 
Lamon Avenue, 7800, 7900, 8800, 8900, 9000 and 9100 blocks. 
Lavergne Avenue, 8800, 8900, 9000, 9100, 9200, 9300, 9400 and 9500 blocks. 
Lawler Avenue, 9100, 9200, 9300, 9400 and 9500 blocks. 
Lee Street, 4800 block. 
Long Avenue, 7800, 7900, 8000, 8100 and 8200 blocks. 
Louise Street, 4800 and 4900 blocks. 
Madison Street, 4600 and 4700 blocks. 
Monticello Avenue, 8000 and 8100 blocks. 
Mulford Street, 4800, 4900, 5400 and 5500 blocks. 
Niles Avenue, 7750, 7800 and 7900 blocks. 
Ridgeway Avenue, 8000 and 8100 blocks. 
St. Louis Avenue, 8300, 8600 and 8700 blocks. 
Suffield Terrace, 5000 block. 
Trumbull Avenue, 8600 and 8700 blocks. 
Washington Street, 4600 and 4700 blocks. 
Wright Terrace, 4800 block. 
(c)  State and County roadways, for which jurisdiction and snow removal responsibility remains with the respective governmental entity, are exempt from the provisions of Section 106-107 at all times. The Village Manager shall promulgate rules and regulations for parking of motor vehicles on exempt roadways. Those State and County roadways, for which jurisdiction and snow removal responsibility has been transferred to and accepted by the Village of Skokie remain subject to this Section 106-107. 
(d)  Applicability of parking regulations during snow removal operations. During snow removal operations when there is an accumulation of 2 inches or more of snow, all parking restrictions in the Village shall be suspended except for the following: 
(1)  Posted "No Parking Here To Corner." 
(2)  Parking within 15 feet of a fire hydrant (Section 106-103(a)(7)). 
(3)  Parking at any place where the standing of any vehicle will prevent the full use of any driveway (Section 106-103(a)(9)). 
(4)  Parking within a designated bus loading zone (Sections 106-107(d) and 106-103(a)(15)). 
(5)  Parking provisions for disabled persons (Section 106-110). 
(6)  Parking on all roadways under the jurisdiction of the State and the County. 
(7)  Posted "No Stopping, Standing, or Parking" (Sections 106-97 and 106-103(a)(13)). 
(8)  Parking not to obstruct traffic (Section 106-102). 
(e)  Towing of vehicles. The Village Manager or designee shall have authority to tow any motor vehicle parked in violation of this section and to collect towing fees from the owner of such a vehicle. 
(Code 1979, § 51.40; Ord. No. 05-12-C-3404, § 1, 12-19-2005)  
Sec. 106-108. - Parking for loading or unloading; use of loading zones and bus stands. 
(a)  Parking in passenger curb loading zone. No person shall stop, stand, or park a vehicle for any purpose or period of time other than for the expeditious loading or unloading of passengers in any place marked as a passenger curb loading zone or prohibited parking space during hours when the regulations applicable to such curb loading zone or prohibited parking space are effective, and then only for a period not to exceed 3 minutes. 
(b)  Backing vehicle to curb for purpose of loading or unloading. The Village Manager or designee is authorized to issue special permits to allow the backing of a vehicle to the curb for the purpose of loading or unloading merchandise or materials subject to the terms and conditions of such permit. Such permit may be issued to the owner of the vehicle and shall grant such person the privileges as therein stated and authorized therein, provided that such permit shall be either in the possession of the operator or on the vehicle at the time such vehicle is backed against the curb to take on or discharge a load. It shall be unlawful for any permittee or other person to violate any of the special terms or conditions of any such permit. 
(c)  Parking in truck loading zone. 
(1)  No person shall stop, stand, or park a vehicle for any purpose or length of time other than the expeditious unloading and delivery or pickup and loading of materials in any place marked as a truck loading zone during hours when the provisions applicable to such zones are in effect. In no case shall the stop for loading and unloading of materials exceed 30 minutes. 
(2)  The driver of a passenger vehicle may stop temporarily at a place marked as a truck loading zone for the purpose of and while actually engaged in loading or unloading passengers when such stopping does not interfere with any motor vehicle used for the transportation of materials which is waiting to enter or about to enter such zone. 
(d)  Parking in bus stand. No person shall stop, stand, or park a vehicle other than a bus in a bus zone, bus stand or bus terminal when any such stop or stand has been officially designated by appropriate signs, except that the driver of a passenger vehicle may temporarily stop therein for purposes of and while actually engaged in loading or unloading passengers when such stopping does not interfere with any bus or taxicab waiting to enter or about to enter such zone. 
(Code 1979, § 51.41)  
Sec. 106-109. - Parking meters. 
(a)  Parking meter zones. The operator of a vehicle shall not park such vehicle in a parking meter zone as established by order of the Board of Trustees except as provided in this section. The Board of Trustees shall by order designate the hours of the day and the days of the year when parking in a parking meter zone may be permitted without compliance with the provisions of this section. Each parking meter shall bear thereon a legend indicating the days and hours when the requirement to deposit coins therein shall apply. 
(b)  Establishment of time limits and parking fees. Time limitations for parking in parking meter zones shall be established from time to time by the Board of Trustees. Parking fees in parking meter zones shall be as established by the Board of Trustees. 
(c)  Overtime parking; posting of time limits. 
(1)  It shall be unlawful for the operator of any motor vehicle, having placed a parking meter in operation, to park such vehicle in such parking zone for a period of time longer than is designated on the meter for the value of the coin or coins deposited in such meter. 
(2)  Stickers shall be affixed to each meter indicating that parking in a metered space for longer than the time specified on the meter shall be a violation of this Code. 
(d)  Deposit of coin. When any vehicle shall be parked in any parking meter zone, the operator of such vehicle shall, upon entering the parking space, immediately deposit or cause to be deposited a coin of the United States in such parking meter, of the denomination indicated, and put such meter in operation. Failure to deposit such coin and put the meter in operation shall constitute a violation of this section. 
(e)  Tampering with meters. It shall be unlawful for any person to deface, damage, tamper with, open or willfully break, destroy, or impair the usefulness of any parking meter. 
(f)  Use of slugs. 
(1)  It shall be unlawful for any person to insert, or to attempt to insert, into the coin receptacle of any parking meter, any slug, button or other object, or to manipulate or operate, or to attempt to manipulate or operate, in any manner whatever, any parking meter or any mechanism or device connected or commonly used therewith, with the intent to park in a parking meter zone without paying therefor. 
(2)  It shall be unlawful for any person to insert, or to attempt to insert, into the coin receptacle of any parking meter, any slug, button, wire hook, or other implement or substance with the intent to obtain from such coin receptacle any object theretofore deposited. 
(Code 1979, § 51.42)  
Sec. 106-110. - Permit parking in residential areas. 
(a)  Establishment of restrictions; posting of signs. The Village Manager or designee is authorized, subject to the approval of the Mayor and Board of Trustees, to determine and designate zoned permit residential parking restrictions, and the Manager or designee shall erect and maintain appropriate signs giving notice thereof. 
(b)  Parking permit. Any resident on a street designated in a zoned permit residential parking area may obtain a street parking permit for a passenger motor vehicle which is owned by such resident and registered from the address of the resident's dwelling unit or for such a vehicle which is leased to the resident at this address or leased to the resident's employer and assigned to the resident. The fee for the permit is set forth in Section 46-226. The permit shall be valid only during the calendar year in which it is issued. 
(c)  Visitor passes. 
(1)  Any resident on a street included in the program may obtain visitor passes for passenger motor vehicles for visitor parking in a zoned residential permit area at the cost set forth in Section 46-226. The purchase of the visitor passes shall be limited to adults with vehicle registration or proof of residence on a street included in the program. Each visitor pass shall only be valid for the date specified on the pass. 
(2)  It shall be unlawful for any person to resell the visitor passes. Any person found in violation of this section shall be subject to the penalties provided in Section 1-6 in addition to any other penalty specifically provided for. 
(d)  Applicability of parking time restrictions. The posted time limitation on any street in the area shall not pertain to an automobile displaying a current permit for the applicable zone, if the sign has a supplemental plate indicating that vehicles bearing a Zone 1, Zone 2, Zone 4, Zone 5, or Zone 6, whichever is applicable, permit are exempt. All other parking regulations shall be complied with. 
(Code 1979, § 51.43; Ord. No. 01-5-C-2981, 5-7-2001; Ord. No. 12-4-C-3894, § 1, 4-16-2012; Ord. No. 18-6-C-4381, § 1, 6-4-2018)  
Sec. 106-111. - Reserved parking for persons with disabilities. 
(a)  Purpose; applicability. It is the intention of this section to restrict designated parking places on municipally owned or operated properties, on residential streets and on private parking lots for the exclusive use of persons with disabilities as defined in this section. 
(b)  Reserved parking on municipal properties. 
(1)  The Village Manager or designee shall designate parking places on municipally owned or operated properties for the exclusive use of persons with a disability. It shall be unlawful to park a motor vehicle in a space reserved for the use of persons with disabilities unless the motor vehicle displays an authorized disability parking decal and the authorized holder of the decal enters or exits the vehicle at the time the parking space reserved for persons with disabilities is being utilized. 
(2)  Any motor vehicle parked on any such space which does not contain a visible indication of its official designation by a unit of government for the usage of persons with a disability shall be presumed to be parked in violation of this section. 
(c)  Reserved parking on residential streets. 
(1)  The provisions for reserved residential parking on streets shall not be applicable to any household or any person therein if any member thereof owns, rents or has regular use of private driveways, carports or garages that give convenient access to the dwelling of the person with a disability. 
(2)  Any resident licensed driver of the Village who has obtained official designation of their vehicle based on permanent disability may apply for a determination by the Village Manager or designee that such person is a person with a disability, or any member of such person's household may similarly make an application if their vehicle constitutes the primary mode of transportation for the person with a disability. Upon determination by the Village Manager or designee that this permanent disability exists and upon payment of the fee set forth in Section 46-224 for installation, the Village Manager shall install 2 signs, a maximum of 25 feet apart, on a residential street at the point determined to be most accessible to the dwelling of the person with a disability, which will designate the space between the signs as reserved for the sole use of the person with a disability. The application shall contain such information as the Village Manager may require to make a determination. 
(3)  The number of reserved disability parking spaces on any 1 residential street shall not exceed 25 percent of the available parking spaces on each side of a block. 
(4)  Reserved residential parking will be renewed each year by reapplication and by payment of an annual renewal fee set forth in Section 46-224, due on the anniversary of installation. If a renewal is not requested, or the annual fee not paid 31 days after it becomes due, the signs will be removed. 
(5)  Any vehicle parked in a reserved residential parking space as described in Subsection c of the Section, shall be considered to be illegally parked unless it belongs to the person for whom the space is reserved. 
(d)  Reserved parking on private lots. 
(1)  It shall be unlawful to park a motor vehicle in a space serving the general public if the space has been reserved by signs for the use of persons with disabilities, unless the motor vehicle displays an authorized disability parking decal and the authorized holder of the decal enters or exits the vehicle at the time the parking space reserved for persons with disabilities is being utilized. 
(2)  Any motor vehicle parked on any such space which does not contain a visible indication of its official designation by a unit of government for the usage of persons with disability shall be presumed to be parked in violation of this section. 
(e)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Accessible parking means parking spaces located closest to the nearest entrance using a convenient route. 
Official designation means any motor vehicle which bears registration plates, placards, decals, or similar designation issued to a physically handicapped person pursuant to 625 ILCS 5/3-616 or 625 ILCS 5/11-1301.2, or to a disabled veteran pursuant to 625 ILCS 5/3-609. 
Person with disabilities means a natural person who, as determined by a licensed physician, by a physician assistant who has been delegated the authority to make this determination by his or her supervising physician, or by an advanced practice nurse who has written collaborative agreement with a collaborating physician that authorizes the advanced practice nurse to make this determination: 
(1)  Cannot walk without the use of, or assistance from, a brace, cane, crutch, another person, prosthetic device, wheelchair, or other assistive device; 
(2)  Is restricted by lung disease to such an extent that the person's forced (respiratory) expiratory volume for 1 second, when measured by spirometry, is less than 1 liter, or the arterial oxygen tension is less than 60 mm/hg on room air at rest; 
(3)  Uses portable oxygen; 
(4)  Has a cardiac condition to the extent that the person's functional limitations are classified in severity as Class III or Class IV, according to standards set by the American Heart Association; 
(5)  Is severely limited in the person's ability to walk due to an arthritic, neurological, oncological, or orthopedic condition; 
(6)  Cannot walk 200 feet without stopping to rest because of one of the above 5 conditions; or 
(7)  Is missing a hand or arm or has permanently lost the use of a hand or arm. 
Resident means an individual who lives at the Skokie address for a minimum of 185 days per year. 
(f)  Temporary disability parking identification card. Any resident of the Village may apply for a determination by the Village Manager or designee that such person possesses a disability, as defined in paragraph (e) of this Section, of at least 3 months' duration, or any member of such person's household may similarly make an application if the person's vehicle constitutes the primary mode of transportation for the person with a disability. Upon determination by the Village Manager or designee that this disability exists, the Village Manager shall issue a disability parking identification card valid for no more than 90 days. A resident may apply for another card, when necessary. 
(g)  Signs and markings for spaces on private lots. Parking spaces on private lots for the exclusive use of persons with disabilities shall be provided in accordance with the State of Illinois Accessibility Standards. The Village Manager shall cause to be installed the appropriate signage and place the pavement symbols for these designated disability parking spaces. The owner, agent, or lessee shall pay the fee set forth in Section 46-224 for each such sign installed, which shall include maintenance for such sign for a period of 1 year from the date of installation. The owner, agent or lessee shall also be responsible for the annual maintenance fee as set forth in Section 46-224. 
(Code 1979, § 51.44; Ord. No. 07-7-C-3520, § 2, 7-2-2007; Ord. No. 14-2-C-4033, § 1, 2-3-2014)  
Sec. 106-112. - Parking for certain purposes prohibited. 
(a)  Generally. No person shall park a vehicle upon any roadway: 
(1)  To display such vehicle for sale. 
(2)  To grease or repair such vehicle, except for repairs necessitated by an emergency. 
(3)  To sell merchandise from such vehicle. 
(b)  Auto repair businesses. The operator of any auto repair business shall not park or cause to be parked any vehicle serviced, to be serviced or used in conducting such business on a roadway. 
(Code 1979, § 51.45)  
Sec. 106-113. - Lights on parked vehicles. 
Whenever a vehicle is lawfully parked at nighttime upon any street within a business or residence district, no lights need to be displayed upon such vehicle. Any lighted headlamps upon a parked vehicle shall be depressed or dimmed. 
(Code 1979, § 51.46)  
Sec. 106-114. - Village parking lots. 
(a)  Manner of parking. Vehicles parking in any parking lot maintained by the Village shall be parked in accordance with the painted lines upon the surface of the parking lot and in accordance with the posted signs. 
(b)  Vehicles permitted. The parking of motor vehicles in any Village parking lot shall be in accordance with the requirements set forth within the zoning districts for the specific parking lot. 
(c)  Time limit. No vehicle shall be parked in a Village parking lot for a longer period of the posted time or more than 24 hours without specific consent of the Chief of Police. 
(d)  Supervision. The Village Manager or designee shall have supervision over all the Village parking lots. 
(Code 1979, § 51.48)  
Secs. 106-115—106-130. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 3. - VEHICLE IMMOBILIZATION FOR CITATIONS ISSUED PRIOR TO ADMINISTRATIVE ADJUDICATION 
 
Sec. 106-131. - Program of vehicle immobilization. 
On March 17, 2008, Village Ordinance Number 08-3-C-3605 was adopted creating an administrative adjudication system for the enforcement of violations of parking, standing, compliance and Automated Traffic Law regulations, as more fully detailed in Chapter 2, Article XII. Subsequent to the effective date of the commencement of the administrative adjudication system, vehicle immobilization for all violation notices issued pursuant to that system will be governed by Division 5 of Article III of this Chapter, and Article XII of Chapter 2.
