Vehicle immobilization for citations issued prior to the commencement of the administrative adjudication shall be governed by this Division 3 of Article III of this Chapter. 
The Village Manager or designee, is hereby authorized to direct and supervise a program of vehicle immobilization as provided in this division. This program of vehicle immobilization shall provide for immobilizing any eligible vehicle upon a public way, public property, or private property with consent of the property owners, by placement of a wheel restraint device, in such a manner as to prevent its operation, or if the eligible vehicle is parked or left in violation of any provision of the Chapter 106 of the Village Code concerning obstruction of traffic, access or egress from driveways, alleys, firelanes, hydrants or station, or in any place where it constitutes an obstruction or a hazard, the Village Manager or designee may cause the eligible vehicle to be towed by the Village or an authorized agent thereof, to a Village vehicle pound or an approved vehicle storage facility pursuant to Section 106-93 et seq., of the Village Code. 
(Ord. No. 02-6-C-3101, § 2, 6-17-2002; Ord. No. 03-C-9-3205, § 1, 9-15-2003; Ord. No. 08-4-C-3608, § 3, 4-7-2008)  
Sec. 106-132. - Definitions. 
Unless the context shall otherwise require, terms used in this Division shall have the meaning as set forth below. Any term in this division not defined in this section, shall then have the meaning as defined in the Skokie Village Code or the Zoning Ordinances of the Village of Skokie. 
(1)  State registration number shall mean license plate number issued to a vehicle by the Illinois Secretary of State, or comparable issuing body, if the vehicle is registered outside Illinois. 
(2)  Registered owner shall refer to the person(s) or entity in which the Illinois Secretary of State or comparable issuing body, if the vehicle is registered outside Illinois, has as the recorded owner of the subject vehicle. 
(Ord. No. 02-6-C-3101, § 2, 6-17-2002)  
Sec. 106-133. - Eligibility for immobilization. 
(a)  All vehicles eligible for immobilization shall be included on the immobilization eligibility list. Those vehicles eligible for the immobilization list shall include: 
1.  Any vehicle or vehicles registered to a registered owner, who has accumulated five or more parking citations on any vehicle or vehicles registered to that same owner, for which payment has not been made after the time allotted in the final notice and court dates have not been requested, shall be eligible for immobilization. 
2.  The State registration number of any vehicle(s) registered to an owner who accumulated five or more parking citations as set forth in Section 106-133(a)1, as described in 106-133(a)1 shall be included on the immobilization eligibility list. 
(b)  Notice of impending immobilization of an owner's vehicle or vehicles shall be sent to the registered owner by first class mail to the address of the registered owner as recorded with the Illinois Secretary of State, or in the case of a vehicle bearing a registration of a state other than Illinois, the address of the registered owner recorded in that state's registry of motor vehicles. Said notice shall be sent at least thirty (30) days prior to placing the State registration number of the vehicle or vehicles described in 106-133(a) on the immobilization eligibility list. Prior to sending Notice of impending immobilization, the Village shall verify with the Illinois Secretary of State or a comparable keeper of records in another state, the ownership of vehicles of the of the registered owner that was issued the citations. 
(Ord. No. 02-6-C-3101, § 2, 6-17-2002; Ord. No. 03-C-9-3205, § 2, 9-15-2003)  
Sec. 106-134. - Notice of impending immobilization, pre-immobilization hearings. 
(a)  Notice of impending immobilization. Notice as required by 106-133(b), to a registered owner, as described in 106-133(a), shall advise them that any vehicle registered to them is eligible for immobilization. Said notice shall also include the State registration numbers of the vehicle or vehicles to which the outstanding citations were issued, the nature of the ordinance(s) violated, the section number(s) and the issue dates of the outstanding citations. The notice shall also advise that the registered owner may challenge the validity of the notice of impending vehicle immobilization by requesting, in writing, a pre-immobilization hearing. 
(b)  Pre-immobilization hearings. The registered owner of a vehicle, who has received notice of impending immobilization or whose vehicle's registration number has been placed on the immobilization list, shall have the right to a pre-immobilization hearing to determine whether the vehicle was properly included on an immobilization list. The registered owner may file a written demand for hearing, on a form provided by the Village. The Village Manager or designee shall conduct a pre-immobilization hearing, within two business days of the receipt of the demand for a pre-immobilization hearing, unless otherwise mutually agreed by 
parties. A sole issued to be determined in a pre-immobilization hearing provided by this section is whether the registered owner was liable for the citations outlined in the notice of impending immobilization. 
The registered owner may appear in person and may submit evidence, which tends to conclusively disprove liability, such as the following: 
(1)  That the person was not the owner or lessee of the vehicle on the date or dates the notices of violation were issued; 
(2)  That the amount owed for the violations cited in the notice of impending immobilization were paid. 
(Ord. No. 02-6-C-3101, § 2, 6-17-2002; Ord. No. 03-C-9-3205, § 3, 9-15-2003)  
Sec. 106-135. - Post immobilization. 
(a)  Notice. Upon immobilization of an eligible vehicle, a notice shall be to be affixed on the vehicle. Such notice shall warn that the vehicle is immobilized and that any attempt to move the vehicle may result in its damage. This notice shall include information specifying the procedure to secure the release of the vehicle from the immobilizing restraint. Additionally, the notice will include on how the registered owner can pursue a post immobilization hearing pursuant to this Section 106-135(c) of this Code. 
(b)  Impoundment. Unless the vehicle is otherwise subject to towing, if the immobilization restraint has not been released pursuant to Section 106-135(c), within (72) hours of its placement, the restraint may be released and the vehicle towed and impounded pursuant to Section 106-93 et seq. 
(c)  Vehicle release. The registered owner of an immobilized vehicle shall be permitted to secure release of the vehicle by: 
(1)  Paying the immobilization fee, as specified in section 106-138 and any towing and storage fees, if applicable, and 
(2)  Taking one the of the following actions: 
a.  Paying the entire amount owed as specified in the notice of impending vehicle immobilization; or 
b.  Requesting a court date for all outstanding citations specified in the notice of impending vehicle immobilization and depositing bond in the amount of 100% of the total amount owed as specified in the notice of impending vehicle immobilization. The bond shall be in the form of U.S. currency, money order, cashier's check or certified check. No personal checks shall be accepted; or 
c.  File a written demand for a post immobilization hearing as provided for in Section 106-136 of this Code and depositing a bond in the amount of 100% of the total amount owed as specified in the notice of impending vehicle immobilization. The bond shall be in the form of U.S. currency, money order or certified check. No personal checks shall be accepted. 
(Ord. No. 02-6-C-3101, § 2, 6-17-2002)  
Sec. 106-136. - Post immobilization hearing. 
The owner of an immobilized vehicle shall have the right to a post immobilization hearing. The owner may file a written demand for hearing, on a form provided by the Village, within seven days of the immobilization. A post immobilization hearing shall be conducted by the Village Manager or designee, within two business days of the receipt of a written demand for hearing unless other wise mutually agreed by the parties. Failure to request a hearing within the specified period of time or attend a scheduled post immobilization hearing shall be deemed a waiver of the right to a hearing. In the event of a violator's failure to appear, any amount deposited pursuant to subsection 106-135(c)(2)c., of the Village Code, shall be forfeited to the Village and there shall be no right for refund. The sole issued to be determined in a post immobilization hearing provided by this section is whether the owner was liable for the citations outlined in the notice of impending immobilization. 
(Ord. No. 02-6-C-3101, § 2, 6-17-2002)  
Sec. 106-137. - Removal of immobilized vehicle. 
It shall be unlawful to relocate or tow any vehicle restrained by an immobilizing device without the approval of the Village Manager or designee. 
(Ord. No. 02-6-C-3101, § 2, 6-17-2002)  
Sec. 106-138. - Immobilization fee. 
The fee for immobilization shall be as set forth in Section 46-230. 
(Ord. No. 02-6-C-3101, § 2, 6-17-2002)  
Sec. 106-139. - Penalty. 
Any person who violates or aids and abets in a violation of this section shall be subject to the penalties provided in Section 1-6 in addition to any other penalty specifically provided. 
(Ord. No. 02-6-C-3101, § 2, 6-17-2002)  
Sec. 106-140. - Rules, regulations and agreements. 
(a)  The Village Manager or designee is authorized to establish rules, regulations, procedures and forms for the implementation of this Section 106-131 et seq. 
(b)  The Village Manager is hereby authorized to enter into agreements, subject to the approval of the Corporation Counsel, with property owners in the Village of Skokie, to enable the Skokie Police Department to enter on to the property owner's private property for purpose of immobilizing eligible vehicles under this division. 
(Ord. No. 02-6-C-3101, § 2, 6-17-2002; Ord. No. 03-C-9-3205, § 4, 9-15-2003)  
DIVISION 4. - VEHICLE SEIZURE AND IMPOUNDMENT 
 
Sec. 106-141. - Definitions. 
Words or phrases used in this Division shall have the meaning as set forth below. 
(a)  Business day means any day in which the office of the Village Clerk of the Village of Skokie is open to the public for a minimum of seven hours. 
(b)  Motor vehicle or vehicle means every vehicle which is self-propelled, including, but not limited to, automobiles, trucks, vans, motorcycles and motor scooters, and shall include every vehicle defined by Section 1-146 of the Illinois Vehicle Code. 
(c)  Owner means a person who holds legal title of a vehicle, or in the event a vehicle is the subject of an agreement for the conditional sale or lease thereof with the right of purchase upon performance of the conditions stated in the agreement and with an immediate right of possession vested in the conditional vendee or lessee, or in the event a mortgagor of such vehicle is entitled to possession, then such conditional vendee or lessee or mortgagor shall be deemed the owner. Any person may, with the owner's express permission, perform any act that the owner is authorized to perform. 
(Ord. No. 08-2-C-3593, § 1, 2-4-2008)  
Sec. 106-142. - Acts subjecting vehicle to seizure and impoundment; administrative and public safety fee. 
(a)  A motor vehicle that is driven, used, or operated, by a person in connection with any of the following violations shall be subject to seizure and impoundment by the Village: 
(1)  Driving a motor vehicle under the influence of alcohol, other drug or drugs, intoxicating compound(s), or a combination thereof, as prohibited in Section 5/11-501(a) of the Illinois Vehicle Code, 625 ILCS 5/11-501(a) or as prohibited by a similar law in another state; 
(2)  Driving a motor vehicle while driver's license, permit or privilege to operate a motor vehicle is suspended or revoked, regardless of whether the revocation or suspension was of an Illinois driver's license or the driver's license from another state; 
(3)  Driving a motor vehicle without ever having been issued a valid driver's license; or 
(4)  Driving a motor vehicle when the driver's license has been expired for more than one year, or the driver's permit, restricted driver's permit or other driving privilege has expired, regardless of whether such expired license, permit, restricted driver's permit or other driving privilege was previously issued by the State of Illinois or another state. 
(b)  No vehicle shall be seized and impounded pursuant to paragraphs (a)(3) and (4), above, if the driver was driving pursuant to certain exceptions to the licensing requirements, as allowed in Section 5/6-102 of the Illinois Vehicle Code. 
(c)  In the event a motor vehicle is seized and impounded pursuant to this Division, the owner of the motor vehicle shall be liable to the Village for an administrative and public safety fee of five hundred dollars ($500.00), in order to cover the costs incurred by the Village in ensuring that the motor vehicle is properly removed from the scene of the incident and the vehicle, and personal property enclosed therein, is secured and safeguarded. All owners of a motor vehicle shall be jointly and severally liable for the administrative and public safety fee. 
(d)  Upon demonstration that it has the right to possession of a seized motor vehicle, a lessor, whether a rental agency or otherwise, or lien holder of a motor vehicle shall have the right to pay the administrative and public safety fee and be issued a release from the Skokie Police Department authorizing it to gain possession of the vehicle. 
(e)  The administrative and public safety fee is separate and distinct from, and in addition to, any fees or costs owed by the owner to a private towing company for the towing and storage of the vehicle. 
(Ord. No. 08-2-C-3593, § 1, 2-4-2008)  
Sec. 106-143. - Seizure and impoundment procedures. 
(a)  Whenever a police officer has reason to believe that a motor vehicle is subject to seizure and impoundment pursuant to Section 106-142, above, the police officer shall order that the vehicle be seized and impounded. The Skokie Police Department shall utilize the services of a private towing company. If towed, the motor vehicle must be impounded and stored in a secure facility owned, leased, or operated by the private towing company. 
(b)  The police officer shall inform the person being arrested for the offenses identified in Section 106-142, or any owner of the vehicle at the scene of the arrest, of the circumstances, rights and obligations related to the: 
(1)  Seizure and impoundment of the vehicle; 
(2)  Owner's right to retrieve the vehicle by payment of the administrative and public safety fee to the Village and towing and storage fees and costs to the private towing company; and 
(3)  Availability of posting a bond in the full amount of the administrative and public safety fee and to request a hearing before an administrative hearing officer to determine whether or not the seizure and impoundment was proper. 
(c)  The police officer shall allow for another properly licensed and otherwise fit person to drive the vehicle, if insured, from the scene of the arrest if that person is the owner, or is authorized by the owner, and such person is present at the scene prior to the arrival of the tow truck. The police officer shall not be under any duty or requirement to: 
(1)  Inform the person being arrested that he or she may contact another person to remove the vehicle from the scene of the incident; 
(2)  Allow a driver being arrested to make or send a telephone call, electronic message or other attempt to contact a person to drive the vehicle from the scene of the arrest; and 
(3)  Initiate such call, message or contact another person on behalf of the arrestee. 
(d)  Upon the arrest of a driver for violations referenced in Section 106-142 above, the vehicle shall not be removed from the scene by any owner, or another person authorized by the owner, if the police officer determines that the vehicle should not be released due to the applicability of Section 106-149, below. 
(e)  The imposition of the administrative and public safety fee shall not apply if the vehicle driven by a person arrested in connection with the offenses identified in Section 106-142, was stolen at that time and the theft was reported to the appropriate police authorities within twenty-four (24) hours after the theft was discovered or reasonably should have been discovered. 
(Ord. No. 08-2-C-3593, § 1, 2-4-2008)  
Sec. 106-144. - Release of motor vehicle. 
(a)  The owner of a motor vehicle that is seized and impounded pursuant to this Division may regain possession of the vehicle by first: (i) paying to the Village the $500 administrative and public safety fee; or (ii) posting a bond in the full amount of the fee, pursuant to Section 106-145. The fee or bond shall be paid at the Skokie Police Department. The fee or bond shall only be paid with cash, credit card, cashier's or certified check, or other type of payment acceptable to the Village that has the legal effect of being equivalent to the aforementioned methods of payment. 
(b)  Upon payment of the fee or bond, the Department shall provide the owner with a document authorizing the release of the vehicle from the private towing company. No release shall be granted unless proof of insurance is provided. The owner may present the Department-issued document authorizing release to the private towing company, and upon payment of any fees and costs to company for towing and storage of the vehicle, shall regain possession of the vehicle. 
(Ord. No. 08-2-C-3593, § 1, 2-4-2008)  
Sec. 106-145. - Right to a hearing; posting of bond. 
(a)  Any owner, or lien holder or lessor of record, shall have the right to a hearing before an administrative hearing officer to contest whether the seizure and impoundment was proper. All requests for a hearing shall be made in person at the Skokie Police Department. If a request for a hearing is made, a bond in the amount of five hundred dollars ($500.00) must be posted with the Skokie Police Department and it shall be held by the Village until the administrative hearing officer makes a final decision. 
(b)  Administrative hearings shall be held at the time and date as the Village may schedule for the conduct of business by the administrative hearing officer. If a request for a hearing is not made at the time the administrative and public safety fee is paid or the bond is posted, the owner shall be deemed to have waived the right to an administrative hearing. No party shall have a right to a hearing unless requested within 10 days of the date of the notice referenced in Section 106-146. 
(c)  Administrative hearing procedures shall be as follows: 
(1)  All parties shall be given a reasonable opportunity to present testimony and evidence at the administrative hearing. Continuances of the administrative hearing date must be made in person before the administrative hearing officer and may be granted upon a showing of good cause. The formal rules of evidence will not apply at the hearing, and hearsay evidence shall be admissible, subject to the discretion of the administrative hearing officer. 
(2)  The Village shall not be required to produce any police officer or other witness at the administrative hearing. The Village may file any and all documents, records or other tangible items prepared or maintained in the normal course of business that it desires the administrative hearing officer to consider at the hearing. The filing of the documents, records or items shall be accompanied by a certification from a Skokie police officer of a rank of Commander or higher, certifying that the records, documents or items were prepared or maintained in the normal course of business. Any records, documents or items filed and certified, shall be admitted as evidence at the hearing, and the facts and contents contained therein shall be presumed true and correct without the need for any additional foundation. 
(3)  If an owner appears at the administrative hearing and the administrative hearing officer determines that the seizure and impoundment was proper, the case will be disposed of at that time. If the owner does not appear at the hearing, then the administrative hearing officer, upon a review of the file, shall make a determination on the question of whether the seizure and impoundment was proper. 
(4)  If the administrative hearing officer determines by a preponderance of evidence that the seizure and impoundment was proper, the administrative hearing officer shall enter a final order finding the owner of the vehicle liable to the Village for the administrative and public safety fee in the amount of $500.00. In the event a bond was posted, it will be retained by the Village as final payment of the administrative and public safety fee. If the administrative hearing officer finds that the seizure and impoundment was not proper, the bond will be returned to the owner and the Department shall issue a release for the vehicle, if still impounded. A finding that the seizure and impoundment was not proper shall not have any bearing on whether the owner is obligated to pay the towing and storage fees and costs, and the owner must pay all fees and costs owed to the private towing company. 
(5)  The decision by the administrative hearing officer on the issue of whether the seizure and impoundment was proper, shall constitute a final determination for purposes of judicial review and shall be subject to review pursuant to the Illinois Administrative Review Act, 735 ILCS 5/3-101 et seq. (2006), as now or hereafter amended. A party must exhaust its administrative remedies prior to seeking judicial review. 
(Ord. No. 08-2-C-3593, § 1, 2-4-2008; Ord. No. 09-3-C-3667, § 1, 3-2-2009)  
Sec. 106-146. - Notice of seizure and impoundment. 
(a)  The Village shall, within five (5) business days after a vehicle is seized and impounded pursuant to this Division, send a written notice by first class mail to all owners of the vehicle. Copies of the notice shall be sent to any lien holder or lessee or lessor, if determinable using reasonable efforts. 
(1)  The notice shall: (i) state that the motor vehicle was seized and impounded; (ii) contain all pertinent facts relating to the date, time and reason for the seizure and impoundment; (iii) specify the procedures by which possession of the vehicle may be regained; (iv) state that the failure to regain possession of the vehicle, pursuant to the provisions of this Division, shall result in the vehicle being disposed of pursuant to law; and (v) explain the right to request an administrative hearing. In the event an administrative hearing was requested, then the notice shall provide the date and time of the scheduled hearing and the identity of the person requesting the hearing. 
(2)  The notice shall not be mailed if: (i) the administrative and public safety fee has been paid, and possession of the vehicle has been regained by an owner, within five (5) business days after the vehicle is seized and impounded; or (ii) possession of the vehicle may not be regained due to the vehicle being retained by the Skokie Police Department pursuant to the provisions of Section 106-149, below. 
(Ord. No. 08-2-C-3593, § 1, 2-4-2008; Ord. No. 09-3-C-3667, § 1, 3-2-2009)  
Sec. 106-147. - Collection of unpaid administrative and public safety fee. 
If an administrative and public safety fee is imposed pursuant to this Division, such fee shall constitute a debt due and owing the Village of Skokie. The Village may collect on the debt using all means permitted by law, including, without limitation, obtaining a judgment on the debt and enforcing such judgment against the owner, or disposing of the vehicle as unclaimed vehicle. 
The Village may commence legal proceedings to collect an unpaid administrative and public safety fee, or take actions to dispose of the impounded vehicle: (i) 35 days after a determination was made at the requested administrative hearing that the seizure and impoundment was proper, and no petition was filed in the Circuit Court seeking judicial review of the administrative hearing officer's determination; (ii) 30 days after a final order is rendered by a judge of the Circuit Court whenever a petition seeking judicial review was filed by a party; or (iii) 15 days after the notice referenced in Section 106-146, above, was mailed and no administrative hearing was requested. 
(Ord. No. 08-2-C-3593, § 1, 2-4-2008; Ord. No. 09-3-C-3667, § 1, 3-2-2009)  
Sec. 106-148. - Lien holders. 
Except as may otherwise be provided by law, no owner, lien holder, lessor, or other person, shall be legally entitled to take possession of a vehicle impounded under this Division, until the administrative and public safety fee has been paid or a bond is posted. However, whenever a lien holder against the impounded vehicle has commenced foreclosure proceedings, then possession of the vehicle shall be given to lien holder without the requirement that the administrative and public safety fee be paid or bond posted, conditioned upon the lien holder agreeing in writing to pay to the Village the fee from the net proceeds of any foreclosure sale. 
(Ord. No. 08-2-C-3593, § 1, 2-4-2008)  
Sec. 106-149. - Release of motor vehicle not allowed. 
The provisions of this Division authorizing an owner, or other party, to regain possession of a motor vehicle are not applicable when vehicle or asset forfeiture proceedings have been instituted under state or federal drug asset forfeiture laws or Article 36 of the Illinois Criminal Code of 1961. In such case, the Village shall not release, or dispose of, the vehicle to any person, except as consistent with those proceedings. 
In the event the Skokie Police Department determines that the vehicle seized and impounded pursuant to this Division should not be released to its owner or other persons, or disposed of as an unclaimed vehicle, due to the need to retain the vehicle as part of a continuing criminal investigation, or as evidence in a crime, then the Village shall notify the owner that the vehicle will be retained and not released except as required by law. 
(Ord. No. 08-2-C-3593, § 1, 2-4-2008)  
Sec. 106-150. - Multiple owners. 
Whenever in this Division the word owner is used, it shall apply to all owners. This Division presumes that all owners have equal rights to a seized and impounded vehicle. In instances of multiple owners of a vehicle, the Village shall not have any duty or responsibility to inquire or determine whether all owners concur with, or object to, any action taken, or omissions, by any one owner in relation to the vehicle seized and impounded. 
(Ord. No. 08-2-C-3593, § 1, 2-4-2008)  
DIVISION 5. - VEHICLE IMMOBILIZATION PURSUANT TO ADMINISTRATIVE ADJUDICATION[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 08-4-C-3608, § 4, adopted Apr. 7, 2008, supplied provisions to be added to the Code as §§ 106-151—106-159. In order to maintain the existing numbering system and ease of use of the Code, at the discretion of the editor, these provisions have been redesignated as §§ 106-150.1—106-150.9 to read as set out herein. 
 
Sec. 106-150.1. - Program of vehicle immobilization. 
Chapter 2, Article XII, establishes procedures and processes for the administrative adjudication for violations of vehicular parking, standing, compliance and Automated Traffic Law regulations (hereinafter referred to as "Administrative Adjudication System"). This Division 5 creates a program of vehicle immobilization for the purpose of facilitating enforcement of those regulations. This Division authorizes the immobilization of eligible vehicles for unpaid final determinations of violation liability. 
The Traffic Compliance Administrator, as defined by Section 2-1092, or designee, in conjunction with the Skokie Chief of Police, or designee, are hereby authorized to direct and supervise a program of vehicle immobilization as provided in this Division. This program of vehicle immobilization shall provide for immobilizing any eligible vehicle upon a public way, public property, or private property with consent of the property owners, by placement of a wheel restraint device in such a manner as to prevent the vehicle's operation. 
In the event an eligible vehicle is parked or left in violation of any provision of Chapter 106 concerning obstruction of traffic, access or egress from driveways, alleys, fire lanes, hydrants or station, or in any place where it constitutes an obstruction or a hazard, the Chief of Police or designee may cause the eligible vehicle to be towed, without the need to first immobilize the vehicle or provide notice to the owner prior to such towing, by the Village or an authorized contractor thereof, to a Village vehicle pound or an approved vehicle storage facility pursuant to Section 106-93 et seq., of the Village Code. 
(Ord. No. 08-4-C-3608, § 4, 4-7-2008)  
Sec. 106-150.2. - Definitions. 
Unless the context shall otherwise require, words, terms and phrases used in this Division shall have their meaning as defined or stated in Chapter 2, Article XII. The definitions of the words, and the descriptions of the procedures, contained in Chapter 2, Article XII, are hereby incorporated into this Division as if stated in full. 
(Ord. No. 08-4-C-3608, § 4, 4-7-2008)  
Sec. 106-150.3. - Eligibility for immobilization. 
(a)  All vehicles eligible for immobilization shall be included on the immobilization eligibility list prepared by the Administrator. In the event an owner or vehicle accumulates five or more unpaid final determinations of liability, then all vehicles which are registered to that owner, or to the owner or owners of that vehicle, shall be eligible for immobilization. Specifically, those vehicles eligible for immobilization shall include: 
(1)  Any vehicle or vehicles registered to an owner, subsequent to the owner accumulating five or more unpaid final determinations of violation liability for parking, standing, compliance or Automated Traffic Law violations rendered pursuant to the Administrative Adjudication System on any vehicle or vehicles currently or previously registered to that same owner shall be eligible for immobilization. 
(2)  The State registration number or vehicle identification number of any vehicle registered to an owner who accumulated five or more unpaid final determinations of violation liability for parking, standing, compliance or Automated Traffic Law violations pursuant to the Administrative Adjudication System shall be eligible for immobilization. 
(3)  The name and address of any person that has accumulated five or more unpaid final determinations of violation liability for parking, standing, compliance or Automated Traffic Law violations pursuant to the Administrative Adjudication System shall be eligible for immobilization. 
(b)  In order to determine whether a subject vehicle is eligible for immobilization under this Division, the Administrator shall take into consideration and total all unpaid final determinations of violation liability: (i) in which the subject vehicle was the subject of the violation; (ii) whereby the owner of the subject vehicle has outstanding unpaid final determinations issued against the owner regardless of the identity or description of the vehicle for which the violation notice was issued against; and (iii) in relation to other vehicles which are, or were at the time of the violation notice, registered to the same owner of the subject vehicle. Each and every owner of a vehicle is deemed to be responsible for every violation notice issued in relation to that vehicle, regardless of whether a specific owner was named as a Respondent in the violation notice, the Late Notice, the Hearing Officer's Determination, or the Notice of Final Determination of Violation Liability. 
(c)  Notice of Impending Immobilization of an owner's vehicle or vehicles shall be sent by the Administrator or designee to the owner by first class mail to the address of the owner as recorded with the Illinois Secretary of State, or in the case of a vehicle bearing a registration of a state other than Illinois, the address of the owner recorded in that state's registry of motor vehicles. The Notice shall be sent at least thirty (30) days prior to placing the vehicle, the owner, other vehicles registered to the owner, or the State registration number or vehicle identification number of the vehicle or vehicles on the immobilization eligibility list. Prior to sending Notice of Impending Immobilization, the Administrator or designee may verify with the Illinois Secretary of State, or a comparable keeper of records in another state, the address of record of the owner, however, the Administrator or designee has no duty to so verify such address due to the requirement placed on the owner in Chapter 2, Article XII, to keep the Administrator informed of the owner's current address. 
(Ord. No. 08-4-C-3608, § 4, 4-7-2008)  
Sec. 106-150.4. - Notice of impending immobilization, pre-immobilization hearings. 
(a)  The Notice required by 106-150.3(c) shall advise the owner that any vehicle registered to that owner is eligible for immobilization. The Notice shall also include the State registration numbers of the vehicle or vehicles to which the unpaid final determinations of violation liability were issued, the identification and nature of the regulations violated, and the issue dates of the violation notices. The Notice shall inform the owner that a challenge to the validity of the owner's inclusion on the immobilization list may be made to the Skokie Chief of Police or a designee by requesting, in writing, a pre-immobilization hearing. 
(b)  An owner of a vehicle who has received Notice of Impending Immobilization or whose vehicle has been placed on the immobilization list may be removed from the list by appearing at the Skokie Police Department and pay the amount owed in the Notice. The owner shall have the right to a pre-immobilization hearing to determine whether the owner or a vehicle was properly included on an immobilization list. The owner may file a written request for a hearing with the Chief of Police or designee and include a telephone number at which the person may be contacted. The Chief of Police or designee shall contact the person by telephone. A pre-immobilization hearing shall be conducted within seven business days of the receipt of the request for a pre-immobilization hearing, unless another date is mutually agreed upon by the owner and the Chief of Police or designee. The sole issue to be determined in a pre-immobilization hearing is whether the owner or a vehicle was properly included on the immobilization list. 
(c)  The owner may appear in person and may submit evidence at the pre-immobilization hearing, which would conclusively prove that the owner was not liable for the unpaid final determinations of violation liability for the parking, standing, compliance, or Automated Traffic Law violations listed in the Notice of Impending Immobilization. A person or a vehicle shall not be placed on the immobilization list if the Chief of Police or designee concludes that the number of unpaid final determinations that should not be considered would reduce the total below five unpaid final determinations, based upon the following: 
(1)  That the person was not the owner of the vehicle on the date or dates a violation notice was issued; or 
(2)  That the amount owed for a violation referenced in the Notice of Impending Immobilization was paid. 
(d)  Any vehicle eligible to be immobilized may be immobilized if payment of the amounts owed as stated in the Notice of Impending Immobilization is not made within 30 days of the date of said Notice. Subsequent to the mailing of a Notice of Impending Immobilization, no owner has the right to pay for any of the unpaid final determinations of violation liability without payment being made for all unpaid final determinations of violation liability listed in the Notice and any unpaid final determinations of violation liability that have arisen after the date of the Notice. The acceptance by a Village employee of payment for less than the full amount owed as stated in the Notice of Impending Immobilization plus amounts owed on unpaid final determinations arising subsequent to the Notice, does not impact the enforceability of the Village's right to immobilize eligible vehicles and the Village may proceed with the immobilization process. 
(Ord. No. 08-4-C-3608, § 4, 4-7-2008; Ord. No. 09-5-C-3677, § 1, 5-18-2009)  
Sec. 106-150.5. - Post-immobilization. 
(a)  Upon immobilization of an eligible vehicle, a Notice of Immobilization shall be affixed to the vehicle. The Notice shall state that the vehicle is immobilized and that any attempt to move the vehicle may result in its damage or damage to the immobilizing restraint device. The Notice shall include the date and time that the immobilizing restraint device was affixed to the vehicle and provide information specifying the procedure: (i) to obtain the release of the vehicle from the immobilizing restraint device; and (ii) to pursue a post-immobilization hearing, should the owner desire such a hearing. 
(b)  The owner of an immobilized vehicle shall be permitted to secure release of the vehicle from the immobilizing restraint device by: 
(1)  Paying the immobilization fee, as specified in Section 46-230 of this Code, and any towing and storage fees, if applicable, and 
(2)  Taking one of the following actions: 
(A)  Paying the entire amount owed for the unpaid final determinations as specified in the Notice of Impending Immobilization plus an amount for any unpaid final determinations that arose subsequent to date of the Notice of Impending Immobilization to the Skokie Police Department; or 
(B)  Filing a written demand for a post-immobilization hearing and depositing a bond with the Skokie Police Department in the amount of 110% of the total amount owed in clauses (1) and (2)(A) above. 
All payments and bonds shall be in the form of U.S. currency, money order or certified check. No personal checks or credit cards shall be accepted. 
(c)  In the event the immobilizing restraint device has not been released pursuant to this Section within 72 hours of its placement, the restraint may be released and the vehicle towed and impounded pursuant to Section 106-93 et seq. In the event an owner has made a request for an post-immobilization hearing within 72 hours, then the vehicle shall not be towed and impounded until such time as the owner has had the opportunity to attend the post-immobilization hearing, but in no event shall this delay in towing and impounded exceed five days beyond the date that the request for a hearing is received by the Chief of Police or designee. 
(Ord. No. 08-4-C-3608, § 4, 4-7-2008)  
Sec. 106-150.6. - Post-immobilization hearing. 
(a)  The owner of an immobilized vehicle shall have the right to a post-immobilization hearing. The owner may file a written request for hearing with the Skokie Chief of Police or designee within seven days of the immobilization. The person filing the request shall include a telephone number and the Chief of Police or designees shall contact that person by telephone to schedule the hearing. 
(b)  A post-immobilization hearing shall be conducted by the Chief of Police or designee within 48 hours of the receipt of a written request unless otherwise mutually agreed upon by the owner and the Chief of Police or designee. Failure to request a hearing within seven days of the immobilization or attend a scheduled post-immobilization hearing shall be deemed a waiver of the right to a hearing. 
(c)  In the event an owner does not appear at a post-immobilization hearing, any bond posted pursuant to subsection 106-150.5(b)(2)(A) shall be forfeited to the Village. 
(d)  The sole issue to be determined in a post-immobilization hearing is whether the inclusion of the owner or vehicle onto the immobilization list was proper. If the Chief of Police or designee concludes that a sufficient number of unpaid final determinations referenced in the Notice of Impending Immobilization should not be considered, based upon the same reasons stated in Section 106-150.4(c)(1) and (2), and the resulting number of unpaid final determinations would be reduced below a total of five unpaid final determinations, then the person's vehicle shall be released without cost and the person or vehicle shall be removed from the immobilization list. 
(Ord. No. 08-4-C-3608, § 4, 4-7-2008; Ord. No. 09-5-C-3677, § 1, 5-18-2009)  
Sec. 106-150.7. - Improper tampering with an immobilized vehicle. 
It is a violation of this Code to relocate or tow any vehicle restrained by an immobilizing device. It is a violation of this Code to tamper with, remove, destroy or damage any immobilizing restraint device used in the immobilization of a vehicle. Any person that withholds an immobilizing restraint device from the Village or destroys or damages said device shall be liable for the cost to replace or repair the device. In addition to paying costs associated with the replacement or repair of the device, the person violating this Section shall be subject to a fine in the maximum amount allowed by this Code. Any person aiding or abetting in a violation of this Section shall be liable to the Village for damages and subject to the fine. Any citations, tickets or violation notices written for a violation of this Section shall be assigned to the administrative adjudication hearing process established pursuant to Chapter 2, Article X, of this Code. This Section shall not apply to a contractor performing its duties pursuant to an agreement with the Village. 
(Ord. No. 08-4-C-3608, § 4, 4-7-2008)  
Sec. 106-150.8. - Immobilization fee. 
The fee for immobilization shall be as set forth in Section 46-230. 
(Ord. No. 08-4-C-3608, § 4, 4-7-2008)  
Sec. 106-150.9. - Rules, regulations and agreements. 
(a)  The Chief of Police or designee, and the Administrator or designee, are authorized to establish rules, regulations, procedures and forms for the implementation of this Division. 
(b)  The Village Manager or designee is hereby authorized to enter into agreements, subject to the approval of the Corporation Counsel, with property owners in the Village of Skokie, to enable the Skokie Police Department to enter on to the property owner's private property for purpose of immobilizing eligible vehicles under this Division. 
(Ord. No. 08-4-C-3608, § 4, 4-7-2008)  
ARTICLE III. - VEHICLE LICENSES[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Cross reference— Motor vehicle license fees, § 46-221. 
State Law reference— Authority to license and tax motor vehicles of residents, 65 ILCS 5/8-11-4. 
 
Sec. 106-151. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Moped means a motor vehicle capable of being powered by either the muscular power of man or as a motor vehicle at the discretion of the operator. For the purpose of licensing, a moped shall be licensed as a motor bicycle or motor tricycle. 
Motor vehicle includes automobiles, trucks, tractors, trailers, and semi-trailers drawn by motor vehicles, traction engines, road rollers, motor bicycles, motorcycles, motorscooters, and all other vehicles drawn, towed or propelled otherwise than by muscular power, excluding, however, cars of electric and steam railways and other motor vehicles running only upon fixed rails or tracks. This article does not apply to or affect bicycles or tricycles or other such vehicles as are propelled exclusively by human muscular power. 
Newly acquired vehicle includes vehicles acquired from date of acquisition up to and including 60 days thereafter. 
(Code 1979, § 52.01) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 106-152. - License required. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation residing within the Village, or maintaining and conducting such person's or its principal place of business in the Village, to own, use or cause to be used any motor vehicle unless such vehicle is licensed as provided in this article. 
(b)  Whoever violates this section shall be subject to the penalties provided in Section 1-6 in addition to any other penalty specifically provided for. The Corporation Counsel may file a civil action to recover any penalty or fine against any such person; provided, however, that the filing of such civil action shall preclude incarceration or imprisonment. 
(Code 1979, § 52.02)  
Sec. 106-153. - Application. 
Any person, firm or corporation requiring a license for any vehicle shall make application to the Village Manager or designee upon a form provided by the Village setting forth the name and address of the applicant and a description of the vehicle for which the license is desired. Upon making application as provided in this section, and upon the payment by the applicant of the license fee specified to the Village Manager or designee, a license shall be issued authorizing the use of such vehicle within the Village until the expiration date of such license. The license fee shall be as set forth in Section 46-221. 
(Code 1979, § 52.03)  
Sec. 106-154. - State license required. 
No motor vehicle shall be licensed by the Village unless the vehicle shall have been licensed by the Illinois Secretary of State under 625 ILCS 5/3-100 et seq. 
(Code 1979, § 52.04)  
Sec. 106-155. - Numbering; reserved numbers. 
All vehicle licenses issued by the Village shall begin with the numerical number "1" and will be numbered consecutively thereafter. Those vehicles licenses bearing numbers "1" to "8" inclusive shall be reserved unto the following Village officials to the following manner: 
(1)  Vehicle license number 1 shall be reserved to the Village Mayor. 
(2)  Vehicle license number 2 shall be reserved to the Village Clerk. 
(3)  Vehicle license numbers 3 to 8 shall be reserved to the Board of Trustees and shall be reserved to such officials in alphabetical order as determined by the last name of each Trustee. 
(Code 1979, § 52.05)  
Sec. 106-156. - School buses. 
Upon notification that any school bus or vehicle, after being licensed pursuant to this article, has been used for any purpose other than for a school bus, the Village Manager or 
designee may revoke the license, in which event there shall be no further operation upon any street or highway prior to further licensing and the payment of the regular license fee established in accordance with this article. 
(Code 1979, § 52.06)  
Sec. 106-157. - Term; display. 
(a)  All licenses required in this Article shall be for a term of 1 year, except those licenses issued after July 31 shall be for a term of less than 1 year. All licenses required by this article expire on July 31 of the calendar year. 
(b)  All license stickers issued pursuant to this article shall be permanently affixed to the vehicle the sticker is issued for on the lower inner corner of the windshield on the driver's side. 
(Code 1979, § 52.07; Ord. No. 19-2-C-4444, § 10, 2-19-2019)  
Sec. 106-158. - Transfer of vehicle. 
Whenever the owner of any vehicle licensed under this article shall, before the expiration of such license, dispose of such vehicle, the owner may make application the Village Manager or designee for the transfer of such license to a newly acquired vehicle, if any, whereupon the owner shall pay a fee as set forth in Section 46-221 for the transfer of such license to such newly acquired vehicle plus any additional fee by reason of increase in the classification of the vehicle. It shall be unlawful to transfer any license from 1 vehicle to another except as provided in this section, and it shall be unlawful to transfer any license from 1 person to another under any circumstances as set forth in Section 46-221. 
(Code 1979, § 52.08)  
Sec. 106-159. - New residents. 
For purposes of this section, the term "new resident" shall be defined as any person, firm or corporation that has taken a residence or established a place of business or other activity within the corporate limits of the Village within the last 60 days. New residents of the Village shall purchase a current vehicle license at a fee as set forth in Section 46-221; provided, however, that the motor vehicle for which the license is to be purchased has been properly registered elsewhere in the State, and that proof of such registration is given to the Village Manager or designee. In all other instances, however, new residents shall purchase vehicle licenses at the current applicable rate. 
(Code 1979, § 52.09)  
Sec. 106-160. - Issuance of windshield sticker. 
Upon the execution of an application and payment of fees as provided in this article, the Village Manager or designee shall deliver to the applicant a metal plate, or windshield sticker or other form or tag, the form and size of which shall have been approved by the Board of Trustees. 
(Code 1979, § 52.10)  
Sec. 106-161. - Duplicate licenses. 
A duplicate vehicle license may be issued by the Village Manager or designee upon affidavit by the owner that the owner's vehicle tag has been lost or stolen and upon payment of the fee required in Section 46-221. 
(Code 1979, § 52.11)  
Secs. 106-162—106-190. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IV. - MOTOR-DRIVEN CYCLES[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
State Law reference— Riding on motorcycles and motorized pedalcycles, 625 ILCS 5/11-1403 et seq. 
 
Sec. 106-191. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Area means the geographical boundaries within which an operating motorcycle or operating motor-driven cycle can be heard. 
Motor vehicle and vehicle mean a motorcycle or motor-driven cycle. 
Motorcycle means every motor vehicle having a seat or saddle for the use of the rider and designated to travel on not more than 3 wheels in contact with the ground, but excluding a tractor. 
Motorized scooter shall mean every board or other device or object having wheels, utilizing a platform, with or without a seat and which is propelled by some type of motor and steered in some manner by an individual. 
Motor-driven cycle means every motorcycle including every device propelled by a motor, which produces not to exceed 5 horsepower which has a seat for the operator to sit, and every bicycle with motor attached. 
Nonresident means every person who is not a resident of the State. 
Nonresident's operating privilege means the privilege conferred upon a nonresident by the laws of the State pertaining to the operation by such person of a motor vehicle, or the use of a vehicle owned by such person in the State. 
Operator means every person who drives or is in actual physical control of a motor vehicle upon a street or who is exercising control of or steering a vehicle being towed by a motor vehicle. 
Personal assistive mobility device means a motorized self-balancing unit, designed to transport individuals, including but limited to those who have limited mobility. 
Racing of motor means sudden acceleration or deceleration of the motor of a motorcycle or motor-driven cycle. 
Street means the entire width between the boundary lines of every way, including alleys publicly maintained when any part thereof is open to the use of the public for purposes of vehicular traffic. 
Stunting means operating a vehicle in a manner causing it to weave or suddenly change course, or the loss of body contact with the seat by a driver or passenger, and not for the purpose of safe operation of such vehicle. 
Touring means any repetitious driving in the same area which causes a disturbance or is done with the intent of calling attention to an operator of a motorcycle or motor-driven cycle. 
(Code 1979, § 53.01; Ord. No. 03-2-C-3152, § 1, 2-3-2003) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 106-192. - Operation generally. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to operate or cause to be operated a motorcycle or motor-driven cycle upon any street within the Village except in compliance with the following: 
(1)  Driver's license. The operator of such vehicle shall have in the operator's possession a valid driver's license issued by the State (or, if such operator is a nonresident, such operator shall have in the operator's possession evidence of a nonresident's operating privilege) and which has not been suspended, limited or cancelled. 
(2)  Compliance with vehicle standards. Such vehicle shall at such time of operation be capable of performing in accordance with the standards then fixed by the motor vehicle laws of the State and by the ordinances of the Village. 
(3)  Compliance with traffic regulations. The operator shall operate the vehicle in accordance with the motor vehicle laws of the State and ordinances of the Village. 
(4)  Exhaust system and muffler. Such vehicle shall be equipped with an exhaust system in good working order, sufficient to prevent excessive or unusual noises. No such vehicle shall be equipped with any muffler cutout, or removable exhaust pipe cover, or any bypass in a muffler, or any muffler from which the baffle plates, screens, or other original internal parts have been removed or altered. No such vehicle shall be equipped with an exhaust system which has been modified in a manner which will amplify or increase the noise emitted by the motor of such vehicle above that emitted by the exhaust system originally installed on the vehicle. No such vehicle shall be equipped with an exhaust system which has been modified or altered in any way from that furnished by the vehicle manufacturer; provided, however, that equipment equivalent to that originally installed may be substituted when parts are replaced. 
(5)  Proficiency in operation. Before operating a motorcycle or motor-driven cycle upon a public street, the operator thereof shall have first become sufficiently proficient in the operation thereof to control the vehicle without unreasonable danger to others. If the vehicle is rented, leased or borrowed from another, the operator shall first have demonstrated to the lessor, renter or lender of such equipment that the operator is sufficiently proficient to operate such vehicle upon a public street without unreasonable danger to others. 
(6)  Carrying passengers. A person operating a motorcycle or motor-driven cycle shall ride only upon the permanent and regular seat attached thereto, and such operator shall not carry any other person nor shall any other person ride on a motorcycle or motor-driven cycle unless such vehicle is designed to carry more than 1 person, in which event a passenger may ride upon the permanent and regular seat if designed for 2 persons, or upon another seat firmly attached to the rear or side of the operator. Where a seat designed to carry a person in addition to the operator is at attached to the rear of the operator, 2 footrests must be firmly attached to each side of the vehicle for the use of such person. 
(7)  Riding in tandem. Not more than 2 motorcycles or motor-driven cycles shall be operated side by side in any 1 lane of traffic upon any street. 
(8)  Causing disturbance; touring, stunting or racing of motor. No motorcycle or motor-driven cycle shall be operated in any manner so as to cause a disturbance in any area of the city. Touring, stunting, or racing of motors is prohibited. 
(9)  Dangerous operation. No operator of a motorcycle or motor-driven cycle shall engage in maneuvers, stunting or other operations dangerous to the operator or the operator's passenger or to the persons or property of others, and an operator must at all times keep body contact with the saddle or seat of such vehicle. The operation of a motorcycle or motor-driven cycle on 1 wheel is prohibited. 
(10)  Maximum height of handlebars. No person shall operate a motorcycle or motor-driven cycle having handlebars exceeding 15 inches in height measured from the lowest point of the saddle to the highest point of the handlebars. 
(11)  Required equipment. The operator of a motorcycle or motor-driven cycle and every passenger thereon shall be protected by glasses, goggles or a transparent shield in accordance with 625 ILCS 5/11-1404. Every motorcycle or motor-driven cycle shall be equipped with a rearview mirror, electrical horn, fenders, headlights and rear lights, and front and rear brakes. 
(Code 1979, § 53.02)  
Sec. 106-193. - Operation by persons under 18 years of age. 
No person under 18 years of age shall purchase, rent, lease or borrow a motorcycle or motor-driven cycle unless such person has first obtained written consent from either of the person's parents, or the person's legal guardian. No such person under 18 years of age shall take possession of and operate any motorcycle or motor-driven cycle unless, on the occasion of such purchasing or on the occasion of such renting, leasing or borrowing of such motorcycle or motor-driven cycle, such person under 18 years of age obtains and files with such seller, renter, lessor or lender a consent in writing on a form furnished by the Village, signed by either parent of such minor, or such minor's legal guardian, in the presence of and witnessed by such lessor, renter or lender, or the duly authorized agent of the lessor, renter or lender, to the effect that permission is granted for such child to purchase a vehicle, or to rent, lease or borrow a motorcycle or motor-driven cycle from such renter, lessor of lender, and that such parent or guardian consents to such sale and/or consents to the renting, leasing or lending of a motorcycle or motor-driven cycle to such child, and assumes full legal responsibility for acts or actions of such child in the operation of any such motorcycle or motor-driven cycle then or thereafter sold, rented, leased or lent to such child, and such responsibility and commitment of such parent or guardian shall continue for a period of 60 days. The written consent must be renewed every 60 days thereafter. 
(Code 1979, § 53.03)  
Sec. 106-194. - Suspension or revocation of business license and certificate of occupancy for violation of article. 
In addition to any fines or penalties imposed by this Code, the Village Manager may suspend or revoke the license and certificate of occupancy of any person engaged in the business of selling motorcycles or motor-driven cycles violating the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1979, § 53.06; Ord. No. 11-12-C-3866, § 1, 12-5-2011)  
Sec. 106-195. - Operation of a motorized scooter. 
No person shall use, operate or be in control of a motorized scooter on a public or private street, parking lot, sidewalk, bike path or other area open to the public. Operation of a motorized scooter may be permitted on private property with the permission of the property owner. 
(Ord. No. 03-2-C-3152, § 2, 2-3-2003)  
Sec. 106-196. - Parental responsibility for violations by minors. 
It shall be unlawful for any parent or guardian of a person under the age of 17 years to permit such person under the age of 17 years to violate any provisions of this article. The commission of any such act by a minor who is living with the minor's parents or guardian shall raise the presumption that the parent or guardian has neglected to restrain such minor from committing such act. It shall be an affirmative defense for the parent or guardian to prove that such parent or guardian exercised the parent's or guardian's duty to restrain the minor from committing such act complained of in the pending action, but that such action on the part of the parent or guardian to attempt to restrain the minor, although exercised with due care, was unsuccessful. 
(Ord. No. 03-2-C-3152, § 2, 2-3-2003)  
Sec. 106-197. - Operation of personal assistive mobility devices. 
(a)  Personal assistive motorized devices shall be prohibited on any public right-of-way, including but not limited to, parking lots, sidewalks, bike paths or other areas open to the public, except when utilized, subject to the conditions outlined in Section 106-197(b) and by an individual or individuals described as follows: 
(1)  Those who have limited mobility, including but not limited to the elderly and disabled individuals; or 
(2)  The United States Postal Service for purpose of the delivery of the United States Mail; or 
(3)  Governmental entities for public safety purposes. 
(b)  Personal assistive motorized devices when utilized by individuals, pursuant to section 106-197(a)(1) through 106-197(a)(3) may be operated on public sidewalks when utilized in a generally safe manner and in such a way that their use does not impede pedestrian traffic. The speed of any such device may not exceed 10 m.p.h. 
(c)  Sections 106-197(a) and (b) do not apply to motorized wheelchairs, as defined in the Illinois Motor Vehicle Code, 625 ILCS 5/1 et seq. 
(Ord. No. 03-2-C-3152, § 2, 2-3-2003)  
Secs. 106-198—106-220. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE V. - BICYCLES[7] 

Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
State Law reference— Authority to regulate the operation of bicycles, 625 ILCS 5/11-208(a)(8); bicycles, 625 ILCS 5/11-1501 et seq. 
 
Sec. 106-221. - Applicability of traffic laws to persons riding bicycles. 
Every person riding a bicycle upon a roadway shall be granted all of the rights and shall be subject to all of the duties applicable to the driver of a vehicle by the laws of this State declaring rules of the road applicable to vehicles or by the traffic ordinances of the Village applicable to the driver of a vehicle, except as to those provisions of laws and ordinances which by their nature can have no application. 
(Code 1979, § 54.01)  
Sec. 106-222. - Parental responsibility for violations by children. 
The parent of any child and the guardian of any ward shall not authorize or knowingly permit any such child or ward to violate any of the provisions of this article applicable to bicycles. 
(Code 1979, § 54.13)  
Sec. 106-223. - Areas where article is applicable. 
The regulations in this article applicable to bicycles shall apply whenever a bicycle is operated upon any street or public sidewalk or upon any public path set aside for the exclusive use of bicycles, subject to those exceptions stated in this article. 
(Code 1979, § 54.13)  
Sec. 106-224. - Registration. 
(a)  Required. It shall be unlawful for any resident to operate or use, or permit to be operated or used, or rent for use, any 2-wheel bicycle upon any of the public highways, streets, sidewalks, or public places in the Village without first obtaining therefor a registration certificate from the Village. 
(b)  Issuance. The Village Manager or designee is hereby authorized and directed to issue, upon written application, bicycle registrations. Any such registration, when issued, shall entitle the person to operate any bicycle for which the registration has been issued upon all the public highways, streets, sidewalks, and public places in accordance with applicable laws. 
(c)  Tag and registration certificate. The Village shall provide registration tags together with registration certificates or cards. Tags and registration documents shall have numbers stamped thereon in numerical order. The tags shall be kept firmly attached to the bicycle frame below the seat facing forward during the valid term of such registration. All persons engaged in the business of renting bicycles for hire within the Village shall obtain a tag and registration certificate or card for each bicycle used for hire. 
(d)  Fee. There shall be no registration fee for any bicycle registration. 
(e)  Transfer of ownership. It shall be the duty of every person residing in the Village who sells or transfers ownership of any 2-wheel bicycle to remove and destroy the tag at the time of the sale or transfer. It shall be the duty of the purchaser or transferee, if the purchaser or transferee resides within the Village, to apply for registration thereof within 5 days of the date of sale or transfer. Issuance of such registration shall be subject to all other applicable provisions of this article. 
(f)  Term. Bicycles shall be registered every 5 years. 
(Code 1979, § 54.11)  
Sec. 106-225. - Speed. 
No person shall operate a bicycle at a speed greater than is reasonable and prudent under the conditions then existing. In no event shall the speed exceed the applicable speed limit for motor vehicles. 
(Code 1979, § 54.02)  
Sec. 106-226. - Emerging from alley, driveway or building. 
The operator of a bicycle emerging from an alley, driveway or building shall, upon approaching a sidewalk or the sidewalk area extending across any alleyway, yield the right-of-way to all pedestrians approaching on the sidewalk or sidewalk area, and upon entering the roadway shall yield the right-of-way to vehicles approaching on the roadway. 
(Code 1979, § 54.03) 
Cross reference— Buildings and building regulations, ch. 22; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 90.  
Sec. 106-227. - Riding on sidewalk. 
(a)  No person shall ride a bicycle upon a sidewalk within a CX Core Mixed-Use zoning district. 
(b)  Whenever any person is riding a bicycle upon a sidewalk, such person shall yield the right-of-way to any pedestrian and shall give audible signal before overtaking and passing such pedestrian. 
(Code 1979, § 54.04; Ord. No. 09-2-C-3664, § 1, 2-17-2009) 
Cross reference— Streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 90.  
Sec. 106-228. - Riding on roadway. 
(a)  Every person operating a bicycle upon a roadway shall ride as near to the righthand side of the roadway as practicable, exercising due care when passing a standing vehicle or 1 proceeding in the same direction, and at all times giving the right-of-way to other moving vehicles. 
(b)  Bicycles shall not be operated upon any street where the operation of bicycles has been prohibited and signs have been erected indicating such prohibition. 
(c)  Persons riding bicycles upon a roadway shall not ride other than single file except on paths or parts of roadways set aside for the exclusive use of bicycles. 
(d)  Whenever a usable path for bicycles has been provided adjacent to a roadway, bicycle riders shall use such path and not use the roadway. 
(Code 1979, § 54.05)  
Sec. 106-229. - Carrying articles. 
No person operating a bicycle shall carry any package, bundle, or article which prevents the rider from keeping at least 1 hand upon the handlebars. 
(Code 1979, § 54.07)  
Sec. 106-230. - Parking. 
No person shall park a bicycle upon a street other than upon the roadway against the curb or upon the sidewalk in a rack to support the bicycle or against a building or at the curb in such manner as to afford the least obstruction to pedestrian traffic. 
(Code 1979, § 54.08)  
Sec. 106-231. - Riding on seat required; carrying additional persons. 
(a)  A person propelling a bicycle shall not ride other than astride a permanent and regular seat attached thereto. 
(b)  No bicycle shall be used to carry more persons at 1 time than the number for which it is designed and equipped. 
(Code 1979, § 54.09)  
Sec. 106-232. - Obedience to traffic control devices. 
(a)  Any person operating a bicycle shall comply with official traffic control signals, signs, and other control devices applicable to vehicles, unless otherwise directed by a police officer. 
(b)  Whenever authorized signs are erected indicating that no right or left turn or a turn in the opposite direction is permitted, no person operating a bicycle shall disobey the direction of any such sign, except where such person dismounts from the bicycle to make any such turn, in which event such person shall then obey the regulations applicable to pedestrians. 
(Code 1979, § 54.10)  
Sec. 106-233. - Required equipment. 
(a)  Lights and reflectors. Every bicycle, when in use at nighttime, shall be equipped with a headlamp which shall emit a white light visible from a minimum distance of 500 feet from the front and with a rear red reflector which will emit a reflected light visible for a distance of approximately 200 feet to 250 feet from the rear. 
(b)  Signaling device. No person shall operate a bicycle unless it is equipped with a bell or other device capable of giving a signal audible for at least 100 feet, except that a bicycle shall not be equipped with nor shall any person use upon a bicycle any siren or whistle. 
(c)  Brakes. Every bicycle shall be equipped with a brake which will enable the operator to make the braked wheel skid on dry, level, clean pavement. 
(d)  Helmets. Every person under the age of sixteen (16) years shall wear a protective helmet that meets the standards promulgated by either; the American National Standards Institute, the American Society for Testing or the Snell Memorial Foundation, Inc., whenever that person is upon a public highway, sidewalk, bicycle path or other public right-of-way within the corporate limits of the Village and is riding or being carried on any bicycle or any carrier attached to or pulled by a bicycle. 
(Code 1979, § 54.12; Ord. No. 02-11-C-3125, § 2, 11-4-2002)  
Chapter 110 - UTILITIES[1] 
Footnotes:

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Secs. 110-1—110-30. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - WATER AND SEWER SERVICE[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference— Municipal water supply and sewage systems, 65 ILCS 5/11-124-1 et seq. 
 
Sec. 110-31. - Scope of article. 
The provisions of this article contain general regulations regarding the installation of plumbing, including provisions for health and safety; the connection to public systems when available; the exclusion of certain wastes detrimental to the sewage system; and the matters of corrosion, freezing, trenching, bedding, tunneling and backfilling. 
(Code 1979, § 9.01)  
Sec. 110-32. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Administrator means the administrator of the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency. 
Basic user charge means the assessment levied on all users of the public sewer system. 
Building drain means that part of the lowest piping of a drainage system which receives the discharge from soil, waste, and other drainage pipes inside the walls of the building and conveys it to the building sewer or other approved point of discharge, beginning 5 feet outside the inner face of the building wall. 
Building sewer means the extension from the building drain to the public sewer or other place of disposal beginning 5 feet outside the face of the building wall. 
Combined sewer means a sewer which is designed and intended to receive wastewater, stormwater, surface water and groundwater drainage. 
Commercial user includes transient lodging, retail and wholesale establishments or places engaged in selling merchandise or rendering services. 
Control manhole means a structure located on a site from which industrial wastes are discharged. Where feasible, the manhole shall have an interior drop. The purpose of a control manhole is to provide access for the MWRDGC representative to sample and/or measure discharges. 
Debt service charge means the amount to be paid each billing period for payment of interest, principal and coverage of loans outstanding owed to the Illinois Environmental Protection Agency and/or other agencies and financial institutions. 
Director means the Director of the Illinois Environmental Protection Agency. 
Easement means an acquired legal right for the specific use of land owned by others. 
Effluent criteria shall be as defined in any applicable NPDES permit. 
Enterprise fund means the fund utilized to account for the operations of the water and sewer system which is similar to a business enterprise in the private sector. 
Federal Act means the Federal Clean Water Act, 33 U.S.C.A. § 1251 et seq., as amended (Public Law 95-217). 
Fiscal year means the period from May 1 to April 30. 
Floatable oil means oil, fat, or grease in a physical state such that it will separate by gravity from wastewater by treatment in an approved pretreatment facility. A wastewater shall be considered free of floatable fat if it is properly pretreated and the wastewater does not interfere with the collection system. 
Fund means a fiscal and accounting entity with a self-balancing set of accounts recording cash and other financial resources, together with all related liabilities and residual equity balances, and charges therein, which are segregated for the purpose of carrying on specific activities. 
Garbage means solid wastes from the domestic and commercial preparation, cooking and dispensing of food, and from the handling, storage and sale of food. 
Industrial users includes establishments engaged in manufacturing activities involving the mechanical or chemical transformation of materials of substance into products. 
Industrial waste means any solid, liquid or gaseous substance or discharge permitted to flow or escaping from any industrial, manufacturing, commercial or business establishment or process or from the development, recovery or processing of any natural resource, as distinct from sanitary sewage. 
Institutional/governmental user includes schools, churches, penal institutions, and users associated with federal, State and local governments. 
Milligrams per liter is a unit of the concentration of water or wastewater constituents. It is 0.001 gram of the constituent in 1,000 milliliters of water. It has replaced the unit formerly used commonly, parts per million, to which it is approximately equivalent, in reporting the results of water and wastewater analysis. 
Municipal Engineer means the Municipal Engineer of the Village or designee. 
MWRDGC means the Metropolitan Water Reclamation District of Greater Chicago. 
Natural outlet means any outlet into a watercourse, pond, ditch, lake, or other body of surface water or groundwater. 
NPDES permit means any permit or equivalent document or requirements issued by the Village, after enactment of the Federal Clean Water Act, to regulate the discharge of pollutants pursuant to Section 402 of the federal act. 
Person means any individual, firm, company, municipal or private corporation, association, society, institution, enterprise, governmental agency or other entity. 
pH is the logarithm (base 10) of the reciprocal of the hydrogen ion concentration expressed by one of the procedures outlined in the IEPA Division of Laboratories Manual of Laboratory Methods. 
Population equivalent is a term used to evaluate the impact of industrial or other waste on a treatment works or stream. 
ppm means parts per million by weight. 
Pretreatment means the treatment of wastewaters from sources before introduction into the wastewater treatment works. 
Properly shredded garbage means the wastes from the preparation, cooking and dispensing of food that have been shredded to such a degree that all particles will be carried freely under the flow conditions normally prevailing in public sewers, with no particle greater than ½ inch (1.27 centimeters) in any dimension. 
Public sewer means a sewer provided by or subject to the jurisdiction of the Village. It shall also include sewers within or outside the Village boundaries that serve 1 or more persons and ultimately discharge into the Village sanitary, storm, or combined sewer system, even though those sewers may not have been constructed with Village funds. 
Replacement means expenditures for obtaining and installing equipment, accessories, or appurtenances which are necessary during the useful life of the wastewater collection facilities to maintain the capacity and performance for which such works were designed and constructed. The term "operation and maintenance" includes replacement. 
Residential user means all dwelling units such as houses, mobile homes, apartments, and permanent multifamily dwellings. 
Sanitary sewer means a sewer that conveys sewage or industrial wastes or a combination of both, and into which stormwater, surface water and groundwater or polluted industrial wastes are not intentionally admitted. 
Sewage is used interchangeably with the term "wastewater." 
Sewer means a pipe or conduit for conveying sewage or any other waste liquids, including stormwater, surface water and groundwater drainage. 
Sewer service charge means the charge levied on all users of the wastewater collection facilities computed as outlined in Section 110-53(a)(2). 
Sewer service line means sewer pipe on private property which serves a building or buildings that extends to the public sewer and includes the connection to the public sewer. 
Sewerage means the system of sewers and appurtenances for the collection, transportation and pumping of sewage. 
Sludge means any discharge of water, sewage or industrial waste which in concentration of any given constituent or in quantity of flow exceeds for any period of duration longer than 15 minutes more than 5 times the average 24-hour concentration or flows during normal operation. 
Storm sewer means a sewer that carries stormwater, surface water and groundwater drainage but excludes sewage and industrial wastes other than unpolluted cooling water. 
State Act means the Illinois Anti-Pollution Bond Act of 1970, 30 ILCS 405/1 et seq. 
State grant or loan means the State participation in the financing of the construction of treatment works as provided for by the Illinois Anti-Pollution Bond Act, 30 ILCS 405/1 et seq., and for making such grants or loans as filed with the Illinois Secretary of State. 
Stormwater runoff means that portion of the precipitation that is drained into the sewers. 
Suspended solids (SS) means solids that either float on the surface of or are in suspension in water, sewage, or industrial waste, and which are removable by a laboratory filtration device. Quantitative determination of suspended solids shall be made in accordance with procedures set forth in the IEPA Division of Laboratories Manual of Laboratory Methods. 
Unpolluted water means water quality equal to or better than the effluent criteria in effect, or water that would not cause violation of receiving water quality standards and would not be benefited by discharge to the sanitary sewers and wastewater treatment facilities provided. 
Useful life means the estimated period during which the collection system will be operated. 
User charge means a charge levied on users of the sewage collection system for the cost of operation, maintenance and replacement. 
User class means the type of user (residential, institutional, governmental, commercial, or industrial) as defined in this article. 
Wastewater means the spent water of a community. This may include a combination of the liquid and water-carried wastes from residences, commercial buildings, industrial plants, and institutions, together with any groundwater, surface water, and stormwater that may be present.
