Wastewater facilities means the structures, equipment, and processes required to collect, carry away, and treat domestic and industrial wastes and transport effluent to a watercourse. 
Wastewater treatment works means an arrangement of devices and structures for treating wastewater, industrial wastes, and slugs. The term is interchangeable with the term "waste treatment plant" or "wastewater treatment plant" or "pollution control plant." 
Water quality standards are as defined in the Water Pollution Regulations of Illinois. 
Water service pipe means the pipe from the water main or other source of potable water supply to the water distributing system of the building served. 
Water supply system means the water service pipe, water distribution pipes, and necessary connecting pipes, fittings, control valves, and all appurtenances in or adjacent to the building or premises. 
Watercourse means a channel in which a flow of water occurs, either continuously or intermittently. 
(Code 1979, § 9.04) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 110-33. - Penalties. 
Any person who violates any provision of this article shall be subject to the penalties provided in Section 1-6 in addition to any other penalty specifically provided for. 
(Code 1979, § 9.23)  
Sec. 110-34. - Right of entry of inspectors. 
(a)  Generally. The Village Manager or designee and representatives of the MWRDGC, Illinois Environmental Protection Agency, and U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, shall be permitted to enter all properties for the purposes of inspection, observation, measurement, sampling and testing in accordance with the provisions of this article and other applicable ordinances, codes, statutes, rules and regulations. 
(b)  Easements. The Village Manager or designee shall be permitted to enter all private properties through which the Village holds an easement for the purposes of, but not limited to, inspection, observation, measurement, sampling, repair, and maintenance of any portion of the sewage works lying within the easement. All entry and subsequent work, if any, on the easement, shall be done in full accordance with the terms of the easement. 
(Code 1979, § 9.20)  
Sec. 110-35. - Connection to sanitary drainage system required. 
Every plumbing fixture, drain, appliance, or appurtenance thereto which is to receive water or waste, or discharge any liquid wastes or sewage, shall discharge to the sanitary drainage system of the building in accordance with the requirements of this article. 
(Code 1979, § 9.02)  
Sec. 110-36. - Connection to public water and sewer system required, prohibition of use of ground water. 
a.  The water distribution and drainage system of any building in which plumbing fixtures are installed shall be connected to a public water main and sewer. 
b.  The use or attempted use of groundwater from within the corporate limits of the Village of Skokie, as a potable water supply, by the installation or drilling of wells after the effective date of this section is prohibited. This prohibition expressly includes the Village of Skokie. 
c.  Any person violating the provision of this Section shall be subject the penalty provisions set out in Section 2-106 of this Code. 
d.  As used in this Section, the terms below shall have the following meaning: 
Person is an individual, partnership, co-partnership, firm, company, Limited Liability Company, corporation, association, joint stock company, trust, estate, or any other legal entity or their representative, agents or assigns. 
Potable water is any water used for human or domestic consumption, including but not limited to water used for drinking, bathing, swimming or preparing foods. 
(Code 1979, § 9.03; Ord. No. 08-2-C-3597, § 1, 2-4-2008)  
Sec. 110-37. - Safety and construction standards; protection of pipes. 
(a)  Generally. Any part of a building or premises and adjacent public streets, sidewalks and parkways which are changed, altered, or required to be replaced as a result of the installation, alteration, renovation, or replacement of a plumbing system or any part thereof shall be left in a safe, nonhazardous condition. 
(b)  Correction of health and safety hazards. Where a health or safety hazard exists on premises by reason of an existing plumbing installation or lack thereof, the owner or the owner's agent shall install additional plumbing or make such corrections as necessary to abate such nuisance and bring the plumbing installation within the provisions of this Code. 
Cross reference— Public nuisances, § 42-31 et seq. 
(c)  Safety of structural members. Any structural member weakened or impaired by cutting, notching or otherwise shall be reinforced, repaired or replaced so as to be left in a safe structural condition in accordance with the requirements of the building code listed in Chapter 22, Article II. 
(d)  Protection of footings. Trenching installed parallel to footings shall not extend below the line of a 45-degree (0.79 radian) angle to the bearing plane of the footing. 
(e)  Protection of pipes from breakage. Pipes passing under or through walls shall be protected from breakage. Any plumbing pipe passing under a footing or through a foundation wall shall be provided with a relieving arch or sleeve 2 pipe sizes greater than the pipe passing through the wall. 
(f)  Protection of pipes from corrosion. Pipes subject to corrosion by passing through or under corrosive fill, such as but not limited to cinders, concrete, or other corrosive material, shall be protected against external corrosion by protective coating, wrapping or other means which will resist such corrosion. 
(g)  Freeze protection. Water service piping shall be installed below recorded frost penetration but not less than 5 feet below grade. Plumbing pipes in exterior building walls or areas subjected to freezing temperatures shall be protected against freezing by insulation or heat. 
(h)  Sewer depth. Building sewers shall be a minimum of 2 feet 6 inches below grade. 
(i)  Excavations. Excavations for installing service pipes or repairing service pipes shall be made in compliance with the provisions relating to excavations in streets provided for in Section 110-50(l). 
(j)  Trenching and bedding. Trenching and bedding shall adhere to regulations set forth by the Metropolitan Water Reclamation District of Greater Chicago Procedures Manual. 
(k)  Tunneling. Pipe shall be protected from damage during tunneling installation and from uneven loading. Where earth tunnels are used, supporting structures shall be provided to prevent future settling or caving. All tunneling performed shall be in compliance with all federal, State and local laws and regulations. 
(l)  Backfilling. Loose sand or gravel shall be placed in the trench in 6-inch layers and tamped in place. The backfill under and beside the pipe shall be compacted for pipe support. Backfill shall be brought up evenly on both sides of the pipe to retain alignment. 
(Code 1979, § 9.05)  
Sec. 110-38. - Permit and fee for connection to water main. 
It shall be unlawful for any person or corporation to connect with the water main without first obtaining a permit. Applications for permits shall be made to the Village Manager or designee on forms prescribed and furnished by the Village Manager or designee. The Village Manager or designee may request additional information from the applicant. Fees for permits shall be as set forth in Section 46-192. 
(Code 1979, § 9.09)  
Sec. 110-39. - Installation and repair of water service pipes and shutoff valves. 
(a)  Permit required for installation; payment of costs. No installation of service pipes from the water main to the premises or installation of shutoff valves shall be made without a permit. Such installation shall be at the owner's expense. 
(b)  Repairs. 
(1)  All repairs on service pipes from the service valve, including the valve box and plumbing system of buildings, shall be made by and at the expense of the owners of the premises served, by a licensed plumber. Failure to repair such pipes, valve, box or plumbing systems after notice is given to the property owner and may result in the shutoff of water service. Any repair made within 2 feet of the shutoff valve will require the replacement of the shutoff valve. 
(2)  The Village, in case of emergency, may shut off water service or repair any service pipe, valve, box or plumbing system. The cost of any such repair work shall be paid to the Village by the owner of the premises served. This payment shall include the actual cost plus a 10 percent administrative fee. Failure of the property owner to make full payment of any invoice issued in accordance with this subsection within 90 days of the date of issuance of the invoice shall result in the invoice being included as an amount due on the next regular water bill issued for the property. Such amount due shall be subject to late charges and all collections efforts, including but not limited to shutoff of water service to the property. 
(c)  Shutoff valve and box. Shutoff valves 2 inches or under and service valve boxes shall be placed on every service pipe and shall be located between the curbline and the sidewalk line and shall be easily accessible. Shutoff valves 3 inches or above shall be placed at the water main and will require a 60-inch or larger valve box. If such valve or box cannot be located or is not easily accessible, the property owner shall be responsible for locating or relocating such valve and box in accordance with the provisions of this article. 
(d)  Chlorination and flushing. 
(1)  Any person repairing, replacing or adding to the Village's water distribution system, water service lines, or internal plumbing system shall have the responsibility for chlorination under the applicable IEPA regulations and/or guidelines of Title 35, Subtitle F, Sections 652.101, 652.203, 652.204, and 653.302 and the American Water Works Standards for Disinfecting Water Mains, Publication C601-81, and any amendments to applicable guidelines and regulations, as determined by the Director of Public Works or designee. 
(2)  All work on water service lines which are 2 inches or less in diameter shall require 5 minutes of continuous full flow flushing after any repair or installation work. 
(3)  The Village Manager or designee shall be given 24 hours' advance notice to take water samples necessary to satisfy the requirements of this subsection. The cost of laboratory analysis of the samples shall be paid by the permittee. 
(e)  Fees. All fees shall be as required in Chapter 46. 
(f)  Disconnection of old water service line. Any person replacing a water service line or adding a new water service line shall disconnect the old water service from the Village water main at the connection to the Village water main or as directed by the Director of Public Works. 
(Code 1979, § 9.06; Ord. No. 09-11-C-3715, § 1, 11-2-2009)  
Sec. 110-40. - Material for water service pipes. 
All water service leading into any building shall be constructed of a minimum 1-inch copper or ductile iron. All copper pipes leading into any building must be connected with flared or compression copper fittings. 
(Code 1979, § 9.13)  
Sec. 110-41. - Water meters and remote reading devices. 
(a)  Required; ownership; water rate prior to installation of meter. 
(1)  The Village shall furnish an adequate water meter and a remote reading device to all premises using water from the Village water supply. The cost of such meter and remote reading device and installation thereof shall be at the property owner's own expense. Prior to the installation of such a meter and remote reading device, water service may be supplied by the Village at a flat rate of charge until such meter and reading device is installed. All meters and remote reading devices, including the necessary wiring, shall remain the property of the Village. 
(2)  Prior to any premises being occupied, a water meter and remote reading device shall be installed. If such devices are not installed, the property owner may temporarily request a flat rate of charge for water service until such devices can be installed. If such devices are not installed and a flat rate of charge is implemented, water usage shall be limited for construction purposes only (landscape maintenance is prohibited). 
(b)  Installation; location. All water meters shall be installed in a space easily accessible at all times for replacement and reading. The meter must be installed within 18 inches to 24 inches of where the water line enters the building. No meter shall at any time be placed or located in what is commonly known as crawl spaces, nor shall a meter be placed in a space requiring the removal of stored articles or furniture. All remote water meter reading devices shall be installed on the outside of the premises in a space easily accessible at all times for replacement and reading. However, if it is not possible to install the reading device on the outside of the premises, it shall be installed as directed by the Village Manager or designee. 
(c)  Repair or replacement of damaged meters or reading devices. Any meter or remote reading device damaged shall be repaired or replaced by the Village at the property owner's expense. Expense shall include actual expenses and a 20 percent administrative fee. Failure of the property owner to make full payment of any invoice issued in accordance with this subsection within 90 days of the date of issuance of the invoice shall result in the invoice being included as an amount due on the next regular water bill issued for the property. Such amount due shall be subject to late charges and all collection efforts, including but not limited to shutoff of water service to the property. 
(d)  Interference with meter or reading device. Any person who interferes with the installation or repair of water meters or remote reading devices as required by this section shall be in violation of this section and is subject to the penalties provided in Section 1-6 in addition to any other penalty specifically provided for, or termination of water service. 
(Code 1979, § 9.07)  
Sec. 110-42. - Turning on water; unauthorized use of fire hydrants. 
Water service to premises shall not be provided or turned on without prior approval by the Village. No unauthorized person shall turn on any fire hydrant, or use water therefrom, and the person so using or wasting water in such an unauthorized manner shall be liable for the water and for any damages done or caused to the fire hydrant. 
(Code 1979, § 9.08)  
Sec. 110-43. - Resale of water prohibited. 
No water shall be resold, distributed or diverted by a recipient of water supplied by the Village to any premises other than that for which it is intended. 
(Code 1979, § 9.10)  
Sec. 110-44. - Damaging or tampering with water system or equipment. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to tamper with, alter, or damage any part of the Village waterworks or supply system, or any meter or remote reading device. 
(b)  The Village Manager or designee, after giving notice, shall authorize the shutting off of the water supply to any premises in which water meters and remote reading devices are not installed. 
(Code 1979, § 9.11)  
Sec. 110-45. - Water conservation. 
The Village Manager or designee shall have the authority to implement a temporary or permanent water ban restricting any or all outdoor use due to a disruption or shortage of adequate domestic water flows. 
(Code 1979, § 9.12)  
Sec. 110-46. - Lawn sprinkling restrictions. 
Lawn sprinkling or irrigation, including but not limited to the use of automatic or oscillating sprinklers, is prohibited from the hours of 10:00 a.m. until 4:00 p.m. Property owners with odd-numbered street addresses shall restrict the use [of] sprinklers to odd-numbered days of the month. Property owners with even-numbered street addresses shall restrict the use [of] sprinklers to even-numbered days of the month. 
(Code 1979, § 9.121; Ord. No. 15-8-C-4174, § 4, 8-17-2015)  
Sec. 110-47. - Use of water from fire hydrants by contractors. 
Landscapers, contractors or entities with the intended use of lawn or landscape maintenance, cleanup, watering or construction purposes shall fill their equipment at fire hydrant locations designated by the Village Manager or designee, only after payment of all applicable fees as provided for in Section 46-191 and the issuance of a fire hydrant meter to gauge the quantity of water used and compensation for the water used. 
(Code 1979, § 9.122)  
Sec. 110-48. - Use of public sewers required. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful to dispose into any natural outlet within the Village any sewage, debris or other polluted waters, except where suitable treatment has been provided. 
(b)  Except as provided in this article, it shall be unlawful to construct or maintain any privy, privy vault, septic tank, cesspool, or other facility intended or used for disposal of sewage. 
(c)  The owner, at the owner's expense, of all houses, buildings, or properties used for human occupancy, employment, recreation, or other purposes abutting any street, alley, or right-of-way in which there is now located or may in the future be located any public sanitary or combined sewer, shall install toilet facilities connected directly with the public sewer in accordance with the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1979, § 9.14)  
Sec. 110-49. - Sewer maintenance. 
(a)  Responsibilities of Village. The Village shall be responsible for the maintenance of the public sewer. 
(b)  Responsibilities of property owner. The property owner shall be responsible for the service line from and including the junction and the connection to the public sewer to the property line and beyond. 
(c)  Infiltration and inflow; stormwater inlets. If infiltration or inflow has occurred, it must be remedied to meet MWRDGC, IEPA, State, local, or federal regulations. This shall include but not be limited to maintenance such as cleaning, rodding due to root blockage, sewer pipe or manhole replacement; sewer pipe or manhole lining; sewer pipe or manhole joint sealing and patching; and disconnection of stormwater inlets, downspouts, other connections as specified by Section 110-51(c) to sanitary sewers. Disconnection of stormwater inlets and footing drains shall apply to all those constructed after the date of the ordinance from which this section is derived. 
(d)  Repair by Village. The Village may repair or cause to be repaired the sewer service lines after notice has been given to the property owner. The charge to the owner for this work shall be direct costs plus 20 percent for administrative costs. When a determination is made by the Village that damage to Village property is imminent, water service to the premises may be shut off. Failure of the property owner to make full payment of any invoice issued in accordance with this subsection within 90 days of the date of issuance of the invoice shall result in the invoice being included as an amount due on the next regular water bill issued for the property. Such amount due shall be subject to late charges and all collection efforts, including but not limited to shutoff of water service to the property. 
(Code 1979, § 9.15)  
Sec. 110-50. - Sewer connections; installation of building sewer. 
(a)  Permit required. No person shall uncover, make any connections with or opening into, use, alter, or disturb any public sewer or appurtenance thereto without a permit. 
(b)  Prohibited discharges. All disposal into the sewer system shall be unlawful except those discharges in compliance with federal standards promulgated pursuant to the Federal Act and more stringent State and local standards. 
(c)  Permit classifications. There shall be the following 2 classes of building sewer permits: 
(1)  Class A: For a building service sewer constructed to serve a single building devoted solely for residential purposes and 2 or less residential lots containing single- or 2-family units. 
(2)  Class B: For a building service sewer for all commercial, institutional, governmental, or industrial buildings and residential developments containing 3 or more units. 
The Village Manager or designee shall issue both Class A and Class B permits. Any other regional, State or federal permits shall be required where applicable. 
(d)  Application for permit; fee. 
(1)  Applications for permits shall be made to the Village Manager or designee on forms prescribed and furnished by the Village Manager or designee. The Village Manager or designee may request additional information from the applicant. All permit applications shall be accompanied by plans, specifications, and additional information as required by the Village Manager or designee and the Metropolitan Water Reclamation District of Greater Chicago. Fees for permits shall be as set forth in Chapter 46. 
(2)  An industry, as a condition of permit authorization, must provide information describing its wastewater constituents, characteristics, and type of activity. 
(e)  Restrictions on connection; supervision of connection. 
(1)  A building sewer permit shall only be issued and a sewer connection shall only be permitted if it is demonstrated that the downstream sewerage facilities, including sewers, pump stations and wastewater treatment facilities, have sufficient reserve capacity to adequately and efficiently handle the additional anticipated waste load. 
(2)  Upon completion of the building sewer, the sewer permit holder shall so notify the Village Manager or designee for inspection and connection purposes. The connection to the sewer shall only be made under the supervision of the Village Manager or designee. 
(f)  Payment of costs; indemnification of Village; insurance. All costs and expense incident to the installation and connection of the building sewer shall be the property owner's responsibility. The owner shall indemnify the Village from any loss or damage that may directly or indirectly be caused by the installation or existence of the building sewer, and shall furnish proof of insurance as required by the Village. Proof of insurance for a general comprehensive liability insurance policy issued by an insurance company authorized to do business in the State in an amount of not less than $1,000,000.00 is required. Cancellation of the insurance shall automatically suspend the permit. 
(g)  Separate building sewers required; separation of sanitary and storm sewers. A separate and independent building sanitary sewer service and a separate and independent storm sewer service, carrying waters as defined in Section 110-52, shall be provided for all new subdivision, multifamily, commercial and industrial buildings connected to the public sewer. However, in combined sewer areas, the separate sanitary and storm services may be connected together once the service sewer pipes enter the public right-of-way. The separate storm sewer service shall be disconnected from the combined sewer and connected to an appropriately designed storm sewer within 90 days if a storm sewer becomes available within 100 feet of the service entering the public right-of-way. 
(h)  Use of existing building sewers. Existing building sewers may not be used in connection with new buildings without having an independent televised test made and the results approved by the Village Manager or designee. If a new sewer is installed, the old sewer shall be disconnected at the public sewer main or as directed by the Village Manager or designee. 
(i)  Specifications for building sewer. The size, slope, alignment, and materials of construction of a building sewer, and the methods to be used in excavating, placing of the pipe, jointing, testing, and backfilling the trench, shall all conform to the requirements of the building and plumbing codes of the Village, the MWRDGC Sewer Permit Ordinance and other applicable rules and regulations, codes and ordinances. 
(j)  Elevation of building sewer. The building sewer shall be brought to the building at an elevation to allow proper discharge of the building's sanitary drains. The building's sanitary drains shall conform to the requirements of all applicable plumbing regulations and rules and regulations, codes and ordinances. 
(k)  Specifications for connection. The connection of the building sewer to the public sewer shall be gastight and watertight and conform to the requirements of the building and plumbing codes of the Village, the MWRDGC Sewer Permit Ordinance and other applicable rules and regulations, codes and ordinances. 
(l)  Excavations. All excavations for building sewer installation shall be adequately guarded with shoring, barricades and lights for the purpose of protecting the public. The building sewer permit holder shall be responsible for restoring all public property, including but not limited to streets, sidewalks, and parkways, during the excavation, installation or connection of building sewers. 
(Code 1979, § 9.16)  
Sec. 110-51. - Damaging or tampering with sewer system; prohibited discharges. 
(a)  No person shall break, damage, destroy, or tamper with any structure, appurtenance, or equipment which is a part of the sewage and stormwater collection system. 
(b)  No person shall connect or cause to be connected any sanitary sewage outlet or industrial wastewater outlet to any component of a stormwater sewer system. 
(c)  No person shall discharge, or cause to be discharged, any stormwater, surface water or groundwater, roof runoff, subsurface drainage, uncontaminated cooling water, or unpolluted industrial process waters to any sanitary sewer. 
(d)  It shall be unlawful for any person to cause or allow a discharge not meeting the standards of Article III, Prohibited Wastes, of the Sewage and Waste Control Ordinance, latest edition, of the Metropolitan Water Reclamation District of Greater Chicago (MWRDGC). 
(Code 1979, § 9.17)  
Sec. 110-52. - Stormwater discharge. 
(a)  Generally. Stormwater and all other unpolluted drainage shall be discharged to sewers that are specifically designated as combined sewers or storm sewers, or to a natural outlet approved by the Village Manager or designee. Industrial cooling water or unpolluted process waters may be discharged to a storm sewer, combined sewer, or natural outlet, with the approval of the Village Manager or designee. 
(b)  Disconnection of inflow sources on combined sewer system. Stormwater discharges on the combined sewer system shall be removed from the combined sewer system and connected to an appropriately designed storm sewer within 1 year of a separate storm sewer becoming available within 100 feet of the building. 
(c)  Downspouts on new construction. Downspouts on new construction shall be discharged to flow overland, except where a waiver has been granted by the Village Manager or designee. 
(1)  All detached one-and two-family dwellings and multiple single-family dwellings (townhouses) shall have gutters or scuppers and downspouts to direct stormwater discharge to the front or rear of the building. No stormwater shall discharge directly into the storm or combined sewer system. All discharge shall be located as not to damage or create a nuisance to the property or adjoining properties. 
(2)  Accessory structures, less than 400 square feet in area, shall be exempt from subsection (1) of this section, when in the opinion of the Village Manager or designee, the stormwater discharge causes no damage or nuisance to the property or adjoining properties. 
(3)  All buildings and developments that provide on-site stormwater control facilities in accordance with the requirements of Section 118-81 shall be exempt from subsection (a) of this section. 
(d)  Existing downspouts discharging to sewer system. All downspouts for conducting stormwater from the roof of any building into the Village's sewer system shall be disconnected from the sewer system when a new or revised flood control unit is installed to serve the building or any part thereof. However, no such disconnection shall be made in those cases where, in the opinion of the Village Manager or designee, such disconnection will create an associated stormwater hazard to the building or part thereof or to a neighboring building. The Village Manager or designee shall be responsible for all inspections and final reports required in connection with this subsection. 
(e)  New connections to combined system. New construction tributary to the combined sewer system shall be designed to minimize and/or delay inflow contributions to the combined sewer system pursuant to the Zoning Ordinance (Chapter 118). 
(Code 1979, § 9.18; Ord. No. 14-9-C-4092, § 1, 9-15-2014)  
Sec. 110-53. - Rates and charges. 
(a)  Establishment; basis. 
(1)  Water and sewer rates shall be established by the Village from time to time. The rate shall be based on all costs associated with operations, capital improvements, extensions or reconstructions, transfers, reserves, and costs to service debt (principal, interest, professional service fees, etc.). Capital shall include but not be limited to current machinery, equipment, furniture, fixtures, buildings, standpipes, infrastructure, etc. 
(2)  The water and sewer rates shall be based on the methodology promulgated by the Village and shall be established as 1 combined rate for both water and sewer services. The rate shall be established as a fixed rate per 1,000 cubic feet. Water and sewer rates shall be reviewed by the Village Manager or designee and revised as needed to ensure the fiscal health of the enterprise fund. 
(b)  Measurement of flow. The volume of flow used for computing the water and sewer rates and charges shall be the metered water consumption read in increments of 1,000 cubic feet. 
(c)  Minimum charge. A minimum charge shall be assessed for metered water usage of less than 1,000 cubic feet in any billing cycle in the amount of the water and sewer rate then in effect. 
(d)  Annual review. 
(1)  The Village Manager shall cause a periodic review to be made of the adequacy of the water and sewer rates and charges and shall report accordingly to the Mayor and Board of Trustees. 
(2)  The user of the wastewater collection facilities will be notified annually, in conjunction with a regular bill, of the rate and that portion of the sewer service charge which is attributable to operation, maintenance and replacement of the wastewater collection facilities. 
(e)  Water rates. Water rates shall be as set forth in Section 46-193. 
(f)  Disposition of revenue. All revenues and monies derived from the operation of the water and sewer systems shall be deposited in the enterprise fund. The Village Manager or designee shall cause all such revenues and monies to be held separate from all other funds of the Village. 
(g)  Accounts. 
(1)  The Village Manager or designee shall establish a proper system of accounts and shall keep proper books, records, and accounts in which complete and correct entries shall be made of all transactions relative to the water and sewer system, and at regular annual intervals shall cause an audit to be made by an independent auditing concern of the books to show the receipts and disbursements of the water and sewer systems. 
(2)  In addition to the customary operating statements, the annual audit report shall also reflect the revenues and operating expenses of the wastewater collection facilities, including a replacement item, to indicate that sewer service charges under the cost recovery system meet these regulations. In this regard, the financial information to be shown in the audit report shall include the following: 
a.  Flow data showing total cubic feet of water consumed. 
b.  Billing data to show total number of cubic feet billed per fiscal year. 
c.  Debt service for the next succeeding fiscal year. 
d.  Number of users connected to the system. 
e.  Number of non-metered users. 
(h)  Access to records. The IEPA or its authorized representative shall have access to any books, documents, papers and records of the Village which are applicable to the Village's system of water and sewer user charges. Such access shall be for the purpose of making audits, examinations, excerpts and transcriptions thereof to ensure compliance with the terms of the special and general conditions to any State grant and/or loan agreement and rules of any State loan. 
(Code 1979, § 9.21)  
Sec. 110-54. - Billing and payment of charges. 
(a)  Due date for payment. For a water bill to be considered as paid, the payment must be received by the Village. For purposes of this section, the term "received" shall mean physically in the possession of the Village by 5:00 p.m. on the due date and not merely placed in the U.S. mail and postmarked prior to the original due date of the water bill. 
(b)  Nonpayment. 
(1)  Payment for water and sewer service is the obligation of the property owner at the time the water is consumed. A late charge of 10 percent shall be assessed on the unpaid balance of any water bill and any other invoices included thereon which remain unpaid for a period 30 days. The late charge shall continue to be assessed to all unpaid balances until paid in full, and such late charges shall be cumulative. 
(2)  If a bill remains unpaid for a period of 30 days and it is known that the occupant of the premises for which a water and sewer bill has been issued is not the owner of the premises served, a notice shall be mailed to the owner of the premises at the owner's last known address. 
(3)  In addition to the late charge, the water supply may be shut off from any premises for a bill which remains unpaid for a period of 30 days. 
(c)  Lien for unpaid charges. 
(1)  Whenever a bill for water and sewer service remains unpaid for a period of at least 60 days from the original due date, the Village may file a statement of lien claim with the office of the Recorder of Deeds for Cook County. Such statement shall contain the legal description of the premises served, the amount of the unpaid bill, and a notice that the Village claims a lien for this amount as well as for all charges for water and sewer services subsequent to the period covered by the bill. 
(2)  The failure of the Village to record such lien claim or to mail notices as required in this section or the failure of the owner to receive such notice shall not affect the right to foreclose the lien for unpaid water and sewer bills. 
(d)  Foreclosure of lien. 
(1)  Property subject to a lien for unpaid water and sewer charges may be sold for nonpayment of the charges, and the proceeds of such sale shall be applied towards payment of the charges, after deducting costs, as in the case in the foreclosure of statutory liens. 
(2)  The Corporation Counsel shall institute such proceedings, in the name of the Village, in any court having jurisdiction over such matters, against any property for which the bill for water and sewer service has remained unpaid 60 days after it has been rendered. 
(Code 1979, § 9.22)  
Secs. 110-55—110-100. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - EMERGENCY ENERGY PLANS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference— Illinois Public Utilities Act, 220 ILCS 5/101 et seq. 
 
Sec. 110-101. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Control area means an electrical system bounded by interconnection (tie-line) metering and telemetry. It controls generation directly to maintain its interchange schedule with other control areas and contributes to frequency regulation of the interconnection. 
Control area emergency means a control area that is at risk of having to shed firm load, having taken or committed to take all feasible mitigating action short of shedding firm load and firm sales. 
Controlled rotating interruptions of electrical service means the implementation of a plan to curtail electric service to firm load customers for a short period of time and rotating this curtailment of electric service through different areas within the electric utility's service territory in a situation where the demand has exceeded or is at significant risk of exceeding the supply of electricity available to the electric utility. The action of an electric utility to interrupt or curtail electric service to a customer participating in or taking service under an interruptible or curtailable rate is not included in this definition of controlled rotating interruption of electric service. 
Emergency energy plan means the portions of the emergency load conservation procedures, which immediately precede and include the controlled rotating interruption of electrical service to firm load customers within the Village. The emergency energy plan shall include the following steps: 
(1)  A request for emergency help from neighboring utilities; 
(2)  Declaration of a control area emergency; 
(3)  A public appeal for voluntary curtailment of electricity use; and 
(4)  Implementation of the plan for controlled rotating interruptions of electrical service. 
Emergency load conservation procedures means a planned course of action developed by an electric utility company to be implemented in emergency situations when the demand for electricity exceeds, or is at significant risk of exceeding, the supply of electricity available to the electric utility. 
Electric utility company and electric utility mean any person or entity engaged in the business of distributing, transmitting, or otherwise delivering electricity, regardless of its source, for use or consumption within the Village. This term shall not include any person or entity that delivers electricity to fewer than 50 customers within the Village. 
(Ord. No. 99-6-C-2827, § 1(21.01), 6-7-1999) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 110-102. - Violations; enforcement; penalty. 
Any electric utility company that knowingly violates this article or any rules promulgated thereunder shall be subject to a fine of not less than $2,500.00 and not more than $10,000.00 for each offense. Each day that a violation continues shall constitute a separate and distinct offense. The Village may apply to any court of competent jurisdiction for an injunction or order to compel the other party to comply with the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 99-6-C-2827, § 1(21.05), 6-7-1999)  
Sec. 110-103. - Interpretation of article. 
Nothing in this article shall be construed to preclude or interfere with the implementation by an electric utility company of measures necessary to assure the provision of adequate, efficient, reliable and environmentally safe service, as required by the Illinois Public Utilities Act, 220 ILCS 5/1-101 et seq. Nothing set forth in this article shall be deemed to modify the terms of any existing franchise agreement or franchise ordinance otherwise applicable to any electric utility company, or to excuse any performance required such agreement or ordinance, or to limit any authority that may be exercised pursuant to such agreement or ordinance, or to limit any remedy that may be available under such agreement or ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 99-6-C-2827, § 1(21.06), 6-7-1999)  
Sec. 110-104. - Submittal of emergency energy plan. 
(a)  Every electric utility company must have adopted an emergency energy plan no later than 30 days after the effective date of this article, or within 30 days after becoming an electric utility company, whichever is later. 
(b)  Every such electric utility company shall submit to the Village Manager or designee an emergency energy plan adopted by the company no later than 30 days after June 7, 1999, the effective date of the ordinance from which this article is derived, or within 24 hours of the time the plan is adopted, whichever is later. The electric utility company shall be required to examine and update as needed its emergency energy plan at least annually. The electric utility company shall notify the Village Manager or designee in writing of any material revisions to its plan and the rationale for said revisions within 5 business days of the time said revisions are made. 
(c)  The emergency energy plan shall include, at a minimum, information detailing: 
(1)  Circumstances that would require the implementation of the emergency energy plan; 
(2)  Stages of the emergency energy plan; 
(3)  The approximate geographic limits of each outage area provided for in the emergency energy plan; 
(4)  The approximate number of customers within each outage area provided for in the emergency energy plan; 
(5)  The police facilities, fire stations, hospitals, nursing homes, schools, day care centers, senior citizen centers, community health centers, dialysis centers, community mental health centers, correctional facilities, stormwater and wastewater treatment or pumping facilities, and water-pumping stations that have been identified by the Village and persons on life-support systems that are known to the company, and that could be affected by controlled rotating interruptions of electric service under the emergency energy plan; and 
(6)  The anticipated sequence and duration of intentional interruptions of electric service to each outage area under the emergency energy plan. 
(Ord. No. 99-6-C-2827, § 1(21.02), 6-7-1999)  
Sec. 110-105. - Review of emergency energy plan. 
(a)  Upon submittal of the emergency energy plan to the Village Manager or designee, the Village Manager or designee shall review the emergency energy plan in order to determine if the emergency energy plan is complete and to assure appropriate coordination with applicable Village departments. 
(b)  The Village may reject the emergency energy plan if it does not contain all the information required under Section 110-104(c), in which case the Village shall notify the electric utility company in writing of the rejection and the reasons therefor. The electric utility company shall thereafter submit a complete emergency energy plan to the Village no later than 30 days after such notice is sent by the Village. 
(c)  The Village and the electric utility shall work cooperatively to: 
(1)  Identify customers and facilities for which a controlled rotating interruption of electric service would require heightened response by applicable Village departments; 
(2)  Mitigate the potential impact of the plan on public health and safety; and 
(3)  Mitigate the potential impact of the plan on the duties of the applicable Village departments. 
(Ord. No. 99-6-C-2827, § 1(21.03), 6-7-1999)  
Sec. 110-106. - Implementation of emergency energy plan. 
(a)  This section applies to electric utility companies which implement an emergency energy plan. 
(b)  Whenever an electric utility company determines that it may be necessary to implement a controlled rotating interruption of electrical service due to the demand for electricity exceeding, or being at significant risk of exceeding, the supply of electricity available to the electric utility company, the electric utility company shall do the following: 
(1)  Take appropriate action in preparation for implementing a controlled rotating interruption of electric service and notify the appropriate electric utility company personnel; and 
(2)  Notify the Village Manager or designee that the electric utility company will be implementing its emergency energy plan. The notification shall be made pursuant to a notification procedure approved by Village Manager or designee after consultation with the Village Manager or designee. The Village Manager or designee may waive the notice requirement to accommodate exigent circumstances. 
(c)  Subsequent to providing the notice as required in subsection (b) of this section, an electric utility company shall reasonably and separately advise the Village Manager or designee when it implements the each of steps of the emergency energy plan. Such steps shall include the following: 
(1)  A request for emergency help from neighboring utilities; 
(2)  A declaration of a control area emergency; and 
(3)  A public appeal for voluntary curtailment of electricity use. 
(d)  The electric utility company shall give a separate notice to the Village Manager or designee immediately upon the determination that there will a controlled rotating interruption of electric service pursuant to the emergency energy plan. The notification shall include the areas to be interrupted, the sequence and estimated duration of the service outage for each area, and the affected feeders and number of affected customers in each area. Whenever practical, the notification shall be made at least 2 hours prior to the time of the outages, and in no case shall the notification be made less than 30 minutes prior to the outages, if the company is aware that controlled rotating interruptions may be required. 
(e)  Notification required by this article shall be in addition to any notification requirements set forth in any applicable franchise agreement or franchise ordinance, or as may be required by applicable federal or State law or regulation. 
(Ord. No. 99-6-C-2827, § 1(21.04), 6-7-1999)  
Chapter 114 - VEHICLES FOR HIRE[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Businesses, ch. 26; fees related to motor vehicles and traffic, § 46-221 et seq.; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 90; traffic and vehicles, ch. 106. 
State Law reference— Authority to regulate taxicab drivers and expressmen, 65 ILCS 5/11-42-6. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Secs. 114-1—114-30. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - PUBLIC PASSENGER VEHICLES[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference— Public passenger vehicle fees, § 46-229; public carrier stops and stands, § 106-57; cruising by public passenger vehicles, § 106-59. 
 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 114-31. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Business license means a license issued by the Village Manager or designee to a person or entity authorizing the holder thereof to dispatch, own, or control a public passenger vehicle for hire upon Village streets. 
Certificate means a certificate of public convenience and necessity issued by the Mayor and Board of Trustees, authorizing the holder thereof to conduct a public passenger vehicle business in the Village. 
Chauffeur's license means a license issued by the Village Manager or designee to a person authorizing the holder thereof to drive a public passenger vehicle upon the streets of the Village. 
Holder means a person or entity to whom a certificate of public convenience and necessity has been issued. 
Manifest means a daily record of all trips made by a driver showing the time and place of origin, the destination, the number of passengers, and the amount of fare of each trip. 
Open stand means a public place alongside the curb of a street or elsewhere in the Village which has been designated by the Village Manager or designee as reserved exclusively for the use of public passenger vehicles. 
Public passenger vehicle means a motor vehicle for hire regularly engaged in the business of carrying passengers, having a seating capacity of less than 6 persons and not operated on a fixed route. 
Public passenger vehicle company means any person engaged in business as proprietor of 1 or more public passenger vehicles for hire for the transportation of passengers. 
Public passenger vehicle license means a license issued by the Village Manager or designee to a person or entity authorizing the holder thereof to operate a specific public passenger vehicle for hire within the Village. 
Public passenger vehicle owner means any person owning or leasing a public passenger vehicle for hire. 
Rate card means a card issued for display in each public passenger vehicle which contains the rates of fare then in force. 
Taximeter means a meter instrument or device attached to a public passenger vehicle which measures mechanically or electronically the distance driven and the waiting time upon which the fare is based. 
Waiting time means the time when a public passenger vehicle is not in motion from the time of acceptance of a passenger or passengers to the time of discharge, but does not include any time that the public passenger vehicle is not in motion if due to any cause other than the request, act or fault of a passenger or passengers. 
(Code 1979, § 48.01; Ord. No. 00-2-C-2881, § 1, 2-22-2000) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 114-32. - Violations declared nuisance. 
The operation or maintenance of a public passenger vehicle in violation of this article is declared a public nuisance as that term is defined in Section 42-35. The Village Manager may, in addition to other remedies provided for in Chapter 42, Article II, recommend that the Corporation Counsel seek injunctive relief.  
Sec. 114-33. - Authority to establish additional regulations. 
The Village Manager or designee is authorized to establish rules, regulations and procedures for the implementation of this article. 
(Code 1979, § 48.20)  
Sec. 114-34. - Enforcement; duties of Police Department. 
The Police Department shall watch and observe the conduct of holders and drivers operating under this article. Upon discovering a violation of the provisions of this article, the Police Department shall report the violation to the Village Manager or designee, who will order or take appropriate action. 
(Code 1979, § 48.17)  
Sec. 114-35. - Vehicle equipment and maintenance. 
(a)  Generally. No vehicle shall operate as a public passenger vehicle upon the streets of the Village unless all of the conditions enumerated in this section are met. 
(b)  Registration and license. Such vehicle shall bear proper State and local registration properly displayed and shall be duly licensed by the Village Manager or designee for the current year, and such license shall be properly displayed. 
(c)  Markings. The vehicle shall bear color and identification markings as set forth in Section 114-37. 
(d)  Equipment. The vehicle shall comply with applicable equipment provisions of 625 ILCS 5/1-100 et seq., including but not limited to proper brakes, lights, tires, horn, muffler, rear vision mirror, windshield wipers, and directional signals. Each of these items shall be in good mechanical condition. 
(e)  Maintenance. The vehicle shall be maintained at all times under safe operating condition and in a clean and sanitary condition in that the interior of the vehicle shall be free of refuse and litter and the seats, floor and upholstery shall be clean and undamaged. The exterior of the vehicle shall be undamaged and kept clean and properly painted. 
(f)  Air conditioning. Each public passenger vehicle is required to have the air conditioning on when requested by the passenger and whenever the outdoor temperature is above 85 degrees. 
(g)  Age of vehicle. Each vehicle must be no more than 7 years old as determined by the model year of manufacture when initially placed in service and may remain in service as long as it passes semiannual inspections in accordance with Section 114-36 and is maintained in compliance with the terms set forth in this article. 
(h)  Taximeter. 
(1)  All public passenger vehicles operated under the authority of this article shall be equipped with mechanical or electronic taximeters fastened in front of the passengers, visible to them at all times day and night. After sundown, the face of the taximeter shall be illuminated. All taximeters shall be sealed at all points and connections which, if manipulated, would affect their correct reading and recording. Each taximeter shall have thereon a flag to denote when the vehicle is employed and when it is not employed, and it shall be the duty of the driver to throw the flag of each taximeter into a non-recording position at the termination of each trip. The taximeters shall be subject to inspection from time to time by the Village Manager or designee. Any inspector or other officer designated by the Village Manager is hereby authorized, either on complaint of any person or without such complaint, to inspect any meter, and, discovering any inaccuracy therein, to notify the person operating the public passenger vehicle to cease operation. Thereupon such public passenger vehicle shall be kept off the highway until the taximeter is repaired and passes a reinspection. 
(2)  The taximeters may be operated mechanically or electronically. If the taximeter is operated mechanically, it shall be a mechanism of standard design and construction, driven either from the transmission or from 1 of the front wheels by a flexible and permanently attached mechanism. 
(3)  All taximeters, whether mechanically or electronically operated, shall conform to the standards of the United States Department of Commerce as adopted by the National Conference on Weights and Measures and published in the most recent edition of the Bureau's Handbook No. 44 and the current official revisions and interpretations. These standards are incorporated into and made a part of this section. 
(Code 1979, § 48.063; Ord. No. 15-8-C-4174, § 5, 8-17-2015)  
Sec. 114-36. - Vehicle inspections. 
(a)  Required. The inspections enumerated in this section shall be made for the purpose of determining compliance of each vehicle with the conditions set forth in this article. 
(b)  Inspection standards. In accordance with Section 114-33, the Village Manager or designee shall adopt rules and regulations establishing reasonable inspection standards which public passenger vehicles must satisfy to pass the inspections required by this article. The inspection standards shall be designed to ensure that public passenger vehicles licensed by the Village are mechanically dependable, safe, and clean and satisfy the requirements of this article. 
(c)  Initial inspection. The Village Manager or designee shall conduct an initial inspection of each vehicle with respect to which a license is sought for the first time, prior to the issuance of such license, to determine its compliance with the conditions set forth in this article. 
(d)  Periodic inspections. The Village Manager or designee shall conduct semiannual reinspections of each public passenger vehicle for the purpose of determining continued compliance with the conditions set forth in this article. 
(e)  Inspection stations. The Village Manager or designee shall designate specific licensed motor vehicle repair facilities in the Village with certified mechanics to serve as inspection stations to conduct vehicle inspections required by this article. All public passenger vehicles shall bear a current sticker issued by the Village after proof of passing the required inspection from a certified mechanic at a designated inspection station is submitted to the Village. 
(Code 1979, § 48.064)  
Sec. 114-37. - Designation and marking of vehicles. 
(a)  Display of name of owner; identifying design. Each public passenger vehicle shall bear on the outside of a door on each side of the public passenger vehicle, in painted letters not less than 3 inches and not more than 5 inches in height, the name of the owner, and in addition may bear an identifying design approved by the Village Manager or designee. No vehicle covered by this article shall be licensed whose color scheme, identifying design, monogram, or insignia to be used thereon shall, in the opinion of the Village Manager or designee, conflict with or imitate any color scheme, identifying design, monogram or insignia used on a vehicle or vehicles already operating under this article, in such a manner as to be misleading or tend to deceive or defraud the public. If, after a license has been issued for a public passenger vehicle under this article, the color scheme, identifying design, monogram, or insignia thereof is changed so as to be, in the opinion of the Village Manager or designee, in conflict with or imitate any color scheme, identifying design, monogram, or insignia used by any other person or operator, in such a manner as to be misleading or tend to deceive the public, the license of or certificate covering such public passenger vehicle shall be suspended or revoked. 
(b)  Display of vehicle identification number. The identification number assigned to each vehicle by the public passenger vehicle company shall be placed in the interior of the public passenger vehicle on the back of the driver's seat with a minimum letter size of 3 inches in a color that contrasts with the upholstery in clear sight of the passenger compartment. The identification number assigned to each vehicle by the public passenger vehicle company shall be placed on the outside of the vehicle on the rear of the public passenger vehicle and on the passenger side's front fender of the vehicle. 
(Code 1979, § 48.07; Ord. No. 00-2-C-2881, § 4, 2-22-2000)  
Sec. 114-38. - Rates of fare; rate card. 
(a)  No owner or driver of a public passenger vehicle shall charge a greater sum for the use of a public passenger vehicle than in accordance with the following rates: 
(1)  The "flag pull" shall not exceed $2.00. The rate for each 1/10 mile or fraction thereof shall not exceed $0.20. For Dial-A-Ride participants, the rate shall be based upon each additional 1/7 mile. 
(2)  The rate for each additional passenger over the age of 12 shall not exceed $2.00. Participants of the Dial-A-Ride program shall not pay an additional passenger fee. A card shall be displayed in each public passenger vehicle setting forth the additional passenger rate charge as provided in this subsection, and stating that the total additional passenger charge accrues to the benefit of the driver of the public passenger vehicle. 
(3)  No driver shall transport passengers, nor shall any charge be made, unless the meter flag is in a recording position. The meter shall not register until the passenger is in the public passenger vehicle except as otherwise provided under subsection (6) of this section. 
(4)  Passengers shall be entitled to a conveyance of their ordinary hand luggage without charge. 
(5)  No charge shall be made for children under 12 years of age, accompanied by an adult. 
(6)  The rate for each minute of waiting time or fraction thereof shall not exceed $0.35, and shall not exceed $21.00 per hour. Such waiting time shall include the time beginning 5 minutes after arrival at the place to which the public passenger vehicle has been called and the time consumed at direction of a passenger. 
(7)  The flat rate of fare between O'Hare Airport and a location within the Village shall not exceed $28.00. 
(b)  Every public passenger vehicle operated under this article shall have a rate card setting forth the authorized rates of fare displayed on the back of the front seat as to be in view of all passengers. 
(Code 1979, § 48.08; Ord. No. 01-1-C-2966, § 1, 1-2-2001; Ord. No. 04-6-C-3280, § 1, 6-21-2004; Ord. No. 04-12-C-3323, § 1, 12-20-2004; Ord. No. 05-6-C-3362, § 1, 6-20-2005; Ord. No. 06-1-C-3407, § 2, 1-3-2006; Ord. No. 08-4-C-3615, § 1, 4-22-2008; Ord. No. 15-8-C-4174, § 5, 8-17-2015)  
Sec. 114-39. - Receipts. 
The driver of any public passenger vehicle shall, upon demand by the passenger, render to such passenger a receipt for the amount charged, either by a mechanically printed receipt or by a specially prepared receipt, on which shall be the name of the dispatch company, the identification number assigned to the particular vehicle by the public passenger vehicle company, the amount of the meter reading or charges and the date of the transaction. 
(Code 1979, § 48.09; Ord. No. 00-2-C-2881, § 5, 2-22-2000)  
Sec. 114-40. - Refusal of passenger to pay fare. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to refuse to pay the legal fare of any public passenger vehicle after having hired the vehicle, and it shall be unlawful for any person to hire any public passenger vehicle with intent to defraud the person from whom it is hired for the value of such service. 
(Code 1979, § 48.10)  
Sec. 114-41. - Solicitation, acceptance and discharge of passengers; prohibited acts by drivers. 
(a)  Solicitation of passengers by driver. No driver shall solicit passengers for a public passenger vehicle except when sitting in the driver's compartment of such public passenger vehicle or while standing immediately adjacent to the curbside thereof. The driver of any public passenger vehicle shall remain in the driver's compartment or immediately adjacent to the vehicle at all times when such vehicle is upon the public street, except that, when necessary, a driver may be absent from the driver's public passenger vehicle for not more than 30 consecutive minutes. Nothing contained in this section shall be held to prohibit any driver from alighting to the street or sidewalk for the purpose of assisting passengers into or out of such vehicle. 
(b)  Prohibited solicitation. No driver shall solicit patronage in a loud or annoying tone of voice or by sign or in any manner annoy any person or obstruct the movement of any persons, or follow any persons for the purpose of soliciting patronage. 
(c)  Receipt and discharge of passengers. Drivers of public passenger vehicles shall not receive or discharge passengers in the roadway, but shall pull up to the righthand sidewalk as nearly as possible, or in the absence of a sidewalk to the extreme righthand side of the road, and there receive or discharge passengers, except upon one-way streets, where passengers may be discharged at either the righthand or lefthand sidewalk, or side of the roadway in the absence of a sidewalk. 
(d)  Additional passengers. No driver shall permit any other person to occupy or ride in the public passenger vehicle unless the person or persons first employing the public passenger vehicle shall expressly direct the acceptance of an additional passenger or passengers. No charge shall be made for an additional passenger except when the additional passenger rides beyond the previous passenger's destination, and then only for the additional distance so traveled. It shall be unlawful for the driver of any public passenger vehicle to solicit the permission of the person first hiring the public passenger vehicle to pick up any additional passengers. 
(e)  Riding in front seat. No driver shall permit any person to ride in the front seat unless the rear compartment of the public passenger vehicle is filled to capacity. 
(f)  Restriction on number of passengers. No driver shall permit more persons to be carried in a public passenger vehicle as passengers than the rated seating capacity of the public passenger vehicle based on the number of seat belts. 
(g)  Refusal to carry passengers. No driver shall refuse or neglect to convey any orderly person or persons, upon request, unless previously engaged or unable or forbidden by the provisions of this article to do so. 
(h)  Prohibited acts by drivers. No driver of a public passenger vehicle shall solicit business for any hotel, or attempt to divert patronage from 1 hotel to another. No driver shall engage in selling intoxicating liquors or solicit business for any house of ill repute or use such vehicle for any purpose other than the transporting of passengers or package delivery. 
(Code 1979, § 48.11)  
Sec. 114-42. - Open stands. 
(a)  Establishment. The Village Manager or designee may establish open stands in such place or places upon the streets of the Village as deemed necessary for the use of public passenger vehicles operated in the Village. No open stand shall be created without taking into consideration the need for such stands by the companies and the convenience to the general public. The Village Manager or designee shall prescribe the number of public passenger vehicles that shall occupy such open stands. 
(b)  Use. Open stands shall be used in the following manner: 
(1)  Open stands shall be used by the different drivers on a first come, first served basis. The driver shall pull onto the open stand from the rear and shall advance forward as the public passenger vehicles ahead pull off. Drivers shall stay within 5 feet of their public passenger vehicles; they shall not solicit passengers or engage in loud or boisterous talk while at an open stand. A passenger may board the public passenger vehicle of the passenger's choice that is parked at an open stand. 
(2)  The standing of public passenger vehicles in places other than designated public passenger vehicle stands is prohibited. 
(3)  Private or other vehicles for hire shall not at any time occupy the space upon the streets that has been established as an open stand. 
(Code 1979, § 48.12; Ord. No. 00-2-C-2881, § 6, 2-22-2000)  
Sec. 114-43. - Service requirements. 
All persons engaged in the public passenger vehicle business in the Village operating under the provisions of this article shall render an overall service to the public desiring to use public passenger vehicles. Holders of certificates of public convenience and necessity shall maintain a central place of business and keep the place of business open 24 hours a day for the purpose of receiving calls and dispatching public passenger vehicles. They shall answer all calls received by them for services inside the corporate limits of the Village as soon as they can do so. If service cannot be rendered within a reasonable time, they shall notify the prospective passengers how long it will be before the call can be answered and give the reason therefor. Any holder who shall refuse to accept a call anywhere in the corporate limits of the Village at any time when such holder has available public passenger vehicles, or who shall fail or refuse to give overall service, shall be deemed a violator of this article, and the certificate granted to such holder may be revoked at the discretion of the Mayor and Board of Trustees. 
(Code 1979, § 48.13; Ord. No. 00-2-C-2881, § 7, 2-22-2000)  
Sec. 114-44. - Manifests. 
(a)  There shall be maintained a daily manifest upon which are recorded all trips made each day, showing time and place of origin and destination of each trip and amount of fare, and all such manifests shall be retained by the dispatch company and/or owner. The forms for each manifest shall be furnished by the dispatch company and shall be approved by the Village Manager or designee. 
(b)  Every owner shall retain and preserve all manifests in a safe place for at least the calendar year next preceding the current calendar year, and the manifests shall be available to the Village. 
(Code 1979, § 48.14)  
Sec. 114-45. - Records and reports. 
(a)  Required records. Every holder shall keep accurate records or receipts of operations, expenses, and capital expenditures and such other operating information as may be required by the Mayor and Board of Trustees. Every holder shall maintain the records containing such information and other data required by this article at a place readily accessible for examination by the Mayor and Board of Trustees. 
(b)  Submittal of records. Every holder shall submit reports of receipts, expenses and statistics of operation to the Mayor and Board of Trustees for each calendar year in accordance with a uniform system prescribed by the Mayor and Board of Trustees. The reports shall reach the Mayor and Board of Trustees on or before March 1 of the year following the calendar year for which such reports are prepared. 
(c)  Accident reports. All accidents within the Village arising from or in connection with the operation of public passenger vehicles which result in death or injury to any person, or in damage to any vehicle, or to any property in the amount exceeding the sum of $100.00, shall be reported within 24 hours from the time of occurrence to the Village Police Department in a form of report to be furnished by the Department. 
(d)  Service contract reports. It shall be mandatory for all holders to file with the Mayor and Board of Trustees copies of all contracts, agreements, arrangements, memoranda, or other writings relating to the furnishing of public passenger vehicle service to any hotel, theater, hall, public resort, railway station or other place of public gathering, whether such arrangement is made with the holder or any corporation, firm or association with which the holder may be interested or connected. Failure to file such copies within 7 days shall be sufficient cause for the revocation of a certificate of any offending holder or the cancellation of any open stand privileges. 
(Code 1979, § 48.15; Ord. No. 00-2-C-2881, § 8, 2-22-2000)  
Sec. 114-46. - Advertising on vehicles. 
Subject to the rules and regulations of the Mayor and Board of Trustees, it is unlawful for any person owning or operating a public passenger vehicle or motor vehicle for hire to permit advertising matter to be affixed to or installed in or on such public passenger vehicles or motor vehicles for hire. 
(Code 1979, § 48.16) 
Cross reference— Advertising, ch. 6.  
Sec. 114-47. - Dial-A-Ride program. 
(a)  All public passenger vehicles licensed under this article shall be required to accept subsidy coupons. For the purpose of this section, the term "subsidy coupon" shall be defined as a coupon issued by the Village to residents registered for the Dial-A-Ride program and used at face value towards payment of the fare. 
(b)  No public passenger vehicle driver licensed under this article shall refuse to provide service to any Dial-A-Ride participant. 
(c)  Any person who violates any provision of this section shall be subject to the penalties provided in Section 1-6, the enforcement provisions contained in Section 114-34 and the license suspension and revocation provisions contained in Section 114-107, in addition to any other penalty specifically provided for. 
(Code 1979, § 48.18; Ord. No. 00-2-C-2881, § 9, 2-22-2000)  
Secs. 114-48—114-70. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - CERTIFICATE OF PUBLIC CONVENIENCE AND NECESSITY 
 
Sec. 114-71. - Required. 
It shall be unlawful for any person or corporation to operate or permit a public passenger vehicle owned or controlled by such person to be operated as a vehicle for hire upon the streets of the Village without first obtaining a certificate of public convenience and necessity in accordance with the provisions of this division. 
(Code 1979, § 48.02; Ord. No. 00-2-C-2881, § 2, 2-22-2000)  
Sec. 114-72. - Application information; filing fee. 
Applications for a certificate of public convenience and necessity shall be made to the Village Manager or designee on forms prescribed and furnished by the Village Manager or designee. The Village Manager or designee may request additional information from the applicant. The application shall be accompanied by a filing fee as set forth in Section 46-229. 
(Code 1979, § 48.02; Ord. No. 00-2-C-2881, § 2, 2-22-2000)  
Sec. 114-73. - Public hearing on application. 
Upon the filing of an application for a certificate of public convenience and necessity, the Mayor and Board of Trustees shall fix a time and place for a public hearing to be given to the applicant and to all persons to whom certificates of public convenience and necessity have been theretofore issued. Due notice shall also be given the general public by advertising in a newspaper of general circulation within the Village the date, time, place and purpose of the public hearing. The notice shall be published not more than 30 days and not less than 10 days prior to the date stated as the date of public hearing. Any interested person may file with the Mayor and Board of Trustees a memorandum in support of or opposition to the issuance of the certificate. 
(Code 1979, § 48.02; Ord. No. 00-2-C-2881, § 2, 2-22-2000)  
Sec. 114-74. - Issuance. 
(a)  If a majority of the Mayor and Board of Trustees finds that further public passenger vehicle service in the Village is required by the public convenience and necessity and that the applicant is fit, willing, and able to perform such public transportation and to conform to the provisions of this article, the Mayor and Board of Trustees may issue a certificate of public convenience and necessity, which shall state the name and address of the applicant, the number of vehicles authorized under the certificate and the date of issuance. 
(b)  In making the findings mentioned in subsection (a) of this section, the Mayor and Board of Trustees shall take into consideration the number of public passenger vehicles already in operation, whether existing transportation is adequate to meet the public need, the probable effect of increased services on local traffic conditions, and the character, experience, and responsibility of the applicant. The Mayor and Board of Trustees shall further take into consideration the services being provided by holders of certificates and their ability to provide the additional public passenger vehicle services required, and, upon application of such holders, the Mayor and Board of Trustees shall give due consideration to the distribution of the additional licenses to the existing holders who have so applied. 
(Code 1979, § 48.02; Ord. No. 00-2-C-2881, § 2, 2-22-2000)  
Sec. 114-75. - Suspension or revocation. 
(a)  A certificate issued under the provisions of this division may be revoked or suspended by the Mayor and Board of Trustees if the holder thereof has violated any of the provisions of this article, discontinued operations for more than 30 days, or violated any ordinance of the Village or the laws of the United States or the State, the violation of which reflects unfavorably on the fitness of the holder to offer public transportation. 
(b)  Prior to suspension or revocation, the holder shall be given notice of the proposed action to be taken and shall have an opportunity to be heard. 
(Code 1979, § 48.02; Ord. No. 00-2-C-2881, § 2, 2-22-2000)  
Sec. 114-76. - Transfer. 
No certificate of public convenience and necessity issued under this division may be sold, assigned, mortgaged, pledged or otherwise transferred without the consent of the Mayor and Board of Trustees. 
(Code 1979, § 48.02; Ord. No. 00-2-C-2881, § 2, 2-22-2000)  
Sec. 114-77. - Liability insurance. 
(a)  The holder of a certificate of public convenience and necessity shall file a liability insurance policy issued by an insurance company authorized to do business in the State. The policy shall conform to the provisions of Section 114-104(c). 
(b)  All insurance policies required by this section, or copies certified by the insurers, shall be filed with the Village Manager or designee, and shall not be subject to cancellation except on 30 days' previous notice to the Village Manager or designee. 
(Code 1979, § 48.02; Ord. No. 00-2-C-2881, § 2, 2-22-2000)  
Secs. 114-78—114-100. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 3. - LICENSES 
 
Sec. 114-101. - Required licenses. 
No person or entity shall operate a public passenger vehicle or permit a public passenger vehicle owned or controlled by such person or entity to be operated for hire upon Village streets without obtaining the applicable licenses established by this article. Such applicable licenses consist of the following 3 types: 
(1)  A business license; 
(2)  A public passenger vehicle license; and 
(3)  A chauffeur's license. 
(Code 1979, § 48.03)  
Sec. 114-102. - Application information. 
Applications for a business license, public passenger vehicle license or chauffeur's license under this division shall be made to the Village Manager or designee on forms prescribed and furnished by the Village Manager or designee. The Village Manager or designee may request additional information from the applicant. 
(Code 1979, § 48.03)  
Sec. 114-103. - Issuance. 
Upon receipt of an application for a license under this division, the Village Manager or designee shall review and investigate the information contained therein. Such review may include an investigation of the applicant. When the review reveals that all applicable requirements are complied with, including the payment of all applicable license fees, and the application reveals nothing of a nature that might endanger the health, safety and welfare of the general public as a result of the possession of a license, the Village Manager or designee shall issue the respective license to the applicant which conforms to Village standards. A license may be suspended or revoked in accordance with the terms set forth in Section 114-107. 
(Code 1979, § 48.03)  
Sec. 114-104. - Business license. 
(a)  Required. It is unlawful for a public passenger vehicle which is dispatched, owned or controlled by a person or entity to be operated as a vehicle for hire upon Village streets without first having obtained a business license. A person who is merely an employee of the owner of the public passenger vehicle is not required to obtain a business license. 
(b)  Fees; term. Fees for business licenses shall be as set forth in Section 46-229. The license shall expire on April 30 following the date of issuance. 
(c)  Bond. No business license shall be issued or continued in operation unless there is in full force and effect an indemnity bond for each vehicle authorized in the amount of $100,000.00 for bodily injury to any 1 person, in the amount of $300,000.00 for injuries to more than 1 person which are sustained in the same accident, and in the amount of $50,000.00 for property damage resulting from any 1 accident. Evidence of compliance with this subsection shall be by the issuance of a certificate of insurance issued by an insurance company licensed in the State of Illinois. The certificate of insurance required hereunder shall insure to the benefit of any person who shall be injured or who shall sustain damage to property proximately caused by the negligence of a holder or the holder's employees or agents. The certificate of insurance shall be filed in the office of the Village Manager or designee and shall have as surety thereon a surety company authorized to do business in the State. 
(Code 1979, § 48.04)  
Sec. 114-105. - Chauffeur's license. 
(a)  Required. No person shall operate a public passenger vehicle for hire upon the streets of the Village, and no person who owns or controls a public passenger vehicle shall permit it to be so driven, and no public passenger vehicle licensed by the Village shall be so driven at any time for hire, unless the driver of the public passenger vehicle shall have a chauffeur's license issued under the provisions of this article and an appropriate driver's license issued by the State. 
(b)  Fee; term. Fees for chauffeur's licenses shall be as set forth in Section 46-229. The license shall expire on April 30 following the date of issuance. 
(c)  Eligibility. Every applicant shall be 18 years of age or over, and each application shall be accompanied by a certificate from a reputable physician certifying that, in the physician's opinion, the applicant is not inflicted with any disease or infirmity which might make the applicant an unsafe or unsatisfactory driver. 
(d)  Training program. Applicants for a chauffeur's license are required to attend a chauffeur's training program designated by the Village Manager or designee through the adoption of rules and regulations in accordance with Section 114-33.
